title.en-US: "Miscarriage was devastating, but my relationship stayed strong"

content.value: Maven Real Talk on Miscarriage with Christine
33 years old
Administrative Assistant
New Jersey
How many miscarriages have you had?
Two, and they both happened after getting pregnant with IVF.
Did you experience your miscarriages before you had children or after you already had a child?
Before.
How far along were you when you had your last miscarriage?
6 weeks.
Did it happen at home or in the hospital, or someplace else?
I was at work, actually.
What were your symptoms?
Bleeding and discharge.
What surprised you most about having a miscarriage?
This was my second miscarriage from IVF, and it was with a PGS normal embryo, so we were hoping it would've led to a live birth.
Did you find out what caused the miscarriage? How was that experience?
There was no cause for this miscarriage, which was really upsetting. The embryo was genetically normal.
Did you go on to have a baby after your miscarriages? If so, how soon afterwards?
I was able to get pregnant after doing another IVF cycle and then frozen embryo transfer. That happened about five months after my last miscarriage.
What helped you the most in those initial weeks and months after having a miscarriage?

We knew we'd be trying another IVF cycle. It also helped that this was an "easy"/natural miscarriage. The miscarriage I’d had before was awful and happened when I was much further along in the pregnancy, so it was really difficult to move forward.
Did the experience of pregnancy loss affect your relationship with your partner?
It really strengthened our relationship. As devastating as multiple miscarriages and IVF failures can be, we really felt like a strong team throughout.
Did you seek therapy to deal with the miscarriage? If not, would it have been helpful in retrospect?
No, it may have been helpful, but I'm not sure that it was needed.
What would you want to tell another woman who has experienced a miscarriage?

It sucks—no matter the situation, reason, timing, etc. People will be insensitive, or they may think they understand, but no one will ever know exactly what you are experiencing. Yes, miscarriages happen frequently, but that won't really provide any reassurance when you're the one going through it. Take the time you need to work through it and move forward, however you decide to do that. Don't feel guilty about saying no to baby showers or events with children while you're trying to cope and recover.

title.en-US: The loneliness of postpartum depression

content.value: 30 years old
Stay-at-home mom
Rigby, Idaho
Did you have postpartum depression or postpartum anxiety or both?
Both
How did you know you had it?
I was screened and formally diagnosed by my doctor. I kept imagining bad things happening to my daughter and I wouldn’t let her out of my sight. I was also really unmotivated.
How soon after childbirth did you notice that something wasn’t quite right and you weren’t feeling like yourself?
After the first week or so.
What were your symptoms?
Imagining terrible scenarios of losing my daughter, not wanting to wake up in the morning, and having panic attacks.
How open were you about your experience? Did people know what you were going through?
I was private at first but when I got medicine and felt better, I opened up to some close friends.
Once you identified what you were going through, what helped you get better?
I started medication, which took away the panic and bad thoughts. I also practiced some breathing techniques that my doctor showed me.
What do you wish loved ones would have done for you without being asked?
Hugged me more, listened to me, and generally just checked in on me. I felt alone.
How long did it take to feel like yourself again, and what do you think helped you the most?
I still struggle to feel like myself, but it’s much better. I’d have to say that what helps the most is the medicine.
How did your experience impact your relationship with your significant other?
My husband just didn’t get it—he tried to support but didn’t know how. It made things hard. It would have helped if he understood more of what I was going through.
What’s the one thing you’d like to see change about how our society perceives postpartum depression and anxiety?
I wish men could experience it for themselves! Then they would totally get it!

title.en-US: Help! How do I pick a surrogacy agency?

content.value: First thing to know when you’re starting the surrogacy process: “gestational surrogate” is the technical term for the woman who carries your baby (unless the carrier is using her own egg, which doesn’t typically happen these days). So how will you find a surrogate? In some cases—like when you’ve asked someone you know—it’s possible to bypass the (pricey) agency route and simply hire lawyers to draw up the contracts. But when you have to call in more support, an agency is your best bet. When you’re shopping around for the right one, it’s a good idea to have your “buyer beware” hat on so you can avoid any scams. Use this list to choose confidently:
Talk to “alumni.”

The best way to know if you can trust a surrogacy agency is to chat with former clients. What were their experiences? How many surrogates did they decline until they were matched with a good fit? Did they get the care and customer service they needed? Would they choose a different agency if they could go back in time? Ask, ask, ask away!
Find out what’s happening behind the scenes.

What you may not know when you walk into a surrogacy agency is that they could have a financial interest in referring you to a particular IVF clinic. And while the clinic they send you to might not be a bad choice, you should know if cashing out on the referral is swaying how decisions are being made. Ask for full disclosure— in writing.
Don’t fall for a two-for-one lawyer arrangement.

Surrogacy law is a tricky area, and it’s a good idea for the intended parent (a.k.a.: you!) and your surrogate to have two separate lawyers who can look out for your respective interests. If the agency wants to appoint one attorney to represent you both, beware. That’s a big red flag.
Know the worst-case-scenario policies.

The hope, of course, is that everything goes as planned—from choosing the surrogate to having a baby. But what happens if there are hiccups along the way, and you don’t go forward with a surrogate they’ve matched you with? Find out if you’re entitled to a full or partial refund if things don’t work out.
Remember that one agency doesn’t fit all.

Once you’ve done all your research, weighed all the costs, and have to make a final decision about which agency you’ll work with, it comes down to this: Trust your instincts. Like every different workplace you could seek to be employed, each surrogacy agency will have a different “feel.” Ask yourself: Does the environment work for you? Do you like a small-agency feel or is a larger organization more your speed because they can cover more functions? Whatever your personal preferences are, go with an agency that checks most (if not all) of those boxes.

title.en-US: "Confiding in friends after miscarrying helped me know I wasn't alone"

content.value: Maven Real Talk on Miscarriage with Kate
35 years old
Entrepreneur
Brooklyn, NY
How many miscarriages have you had?
1 (maybe 2, I think)
Did you experience your miscarriage(s) before you had children or after you already had a child?
Before my first child
How far along were you when you had your last miscarriage?
11 weeks
Did it happen at home or in the hospital?
In the ER
What were your symptoms?

My first trimester pregnancy symptoms actually went away at around 8 weeks so I think this might be when I actually had my miscarriage. My new insurance plan didn’t kick in until 12 weeks, so I didn’t go to any 1st trimester doctor visits and therefore wasn’t having any scans to check for a heartbeat. The night of my miscarriage, I started experiencing cramps in the early evening. I actually had a Maven appointment to figure out if this was normal. The nurse practitioner I spoke with told me: cramping is normal, bleeding is normal—but that if I were experiencing both together, I should go to the emergency room immediately. Soon after I got off the video call, I started bleeding as well, so my husband and I got in a taxi immediately to go to the ER.
What surprised you most about having a miscarriage?

A few things. First, I was surprised I had a miscarriage in the first place. Getting pregnant was easy, I was only 32, and I had a clean bill of health. My mother never had one and none of my close friends had one (that I knew of at the time) so it just wasn’t a topic I heard about a lot. Second, I was shocked at the level of inhumanity in the hospital. I miscarried in a busy triage room with about 10 strangers watching. My husband kept asking for privacy and no one helped us. A miscarriage is actually quite painful and graphic. I was in a lot of physical pain during the contractions and couldn’t stop crying at the thought of miscarrying and only one nurse tried to help me get comfort and privacy—which I eventually got 5 hours later, after it was done. One of the other unbelievable things that happened was when a nurse, mid-miscarriage, asked me to pee in a cup. I refused because I was bleeding so much, she insisted, and when I eventually did it, I screamed at what was coming out into the cup. There was no urine.
Did you find out what caused the miscarriage? How was that experience?

No - this was another surprising thing about miscarriage. They didn’t tell me why it happened. In fact, it was through another Maven appointment that I was able to piece together that the miscarriage likely occurred earlier, when my symptoms stopped, at 8 weeks. This information gave me some peace—but I still don’t know for sure what caused it.
Did you go on to have a baby after your miscarriage(s)? If so, how soon afterwards?
Yes. I got pregnant again within a few months and had a healthy pregnancy and baby. I am now in my second trimester with my second child and having a healthy pregnancy.
How open were you with friends and relatives?

I remember I was supposed to go away with a group of friends the weekend after it happened. I debated whether I wanted to go and eventually decided it would be a nice distraction from how I was feeling. It was actually incredibly cathartic; both the men and women on our trip told stories of people in their lives who had experienced miscarriage and I realized that it’s a fairly common occurrence—it’s just that no one talks about it.
What helped you the most in those initial weeks and months after having a miscarriage?

Confiding in friends and learning that they had experienced a miscarriage too. I was able to lean on them emotionally for support. The thing that helped me the most is that I got pregnant again quickly.
If you are married or in a relationship, did the experience of pregnancy loss affect your relationship with your partner?

I think my husband was sad after it happened, but then for him the grief went away fairly quickly. I sometimes still think about it but I don’t think he ever does. I mainly relied on a community of women for support rather than my husband, but he was always understanding if I needed to talk about it.
Did you seek therapy to deal with the miscarriage? If not, would it have been helpful in retrospect?

I did in my own way. I had two therapy appointments in the initial week after having a miscarriage, and then I actually used Maven about 8 times with different types of providers (midwives, OB-GYNs, doulas) to ask their thoughts on miscarriage. I just wanted one million points of view since I never found out why I experienced a miscarriage. That was my therapy.
When people ask you how many children you’ve had (or have), do you include your miscarriage?
No
What would you want to tell another woman after suffering a miscarriage?

Find other women who have had a miscarriage—and talk to women’s health providers to give you the medical perspective and comfort if you still feel like you’re at a loss for answers. I also want to tell a woman going through this: I’m so sorry! It’s a horrible thing, no matter how you look at it. But I’ve learned it’s a natural part of reproductive health—you’re not alone!

title.en-US: 3 ways parents can feel less stressed when the workday ends

content.value: Everyone’s been there at one time or another: You walk out of the office after a long day feeling tense, cranky, frustrated, fatigued. Happy and calm? Nowhere to be found. As a result, it’s normal for working parents to have a tough time transitioning from work mode to home mode. You want to be present with your family, but you just can’t shake off the stress of the last eight hours. Here are a few tips to help you recalibrate before you step foot in your front door.
Just hit the pause button

If you don’t want to miss a minute with your kid, your tendency might be to race from work to home—or to the childcare center to pick up your little one. If you’re doing that and feeling wound up all night long, you might need to practice a pause. What that looks like is different for everyone. Maybe it’s a 10-minute stroll to clear your mind (some people think of this as a walking meditation to re-center themselves); maybe it’s stopping by the newsstand to pick up your “guilty pleasure reading”—like a gossip magazine—and allowing yourself to flip through it to turn your brain off for a few minutes. Maybe it’s just sitting in your car and taking a few deep breaths or listening to your favorite song. Try whatever works for you, and notice if it makes a positive difference in your mood.
Build in a buffer zone

Ironically, how you spend your last moments at work can make the difference between a stressful evening and a peaceful one. Think about it, if you’re trying to cram four new projects into your last half hour at the office, how will you possibly leave feeling relaxed and ready to shift into Parentville? One tactic to try: Consider your last half hour a buffer zone. Use it to wind down, wrap up anything you’ve been working on, and make your to-do list for the next day. As much as possible within your organization, try to avoid starting new tasks or scheduling intense meetings during this pre-takeoff time.
Lose your inner critic

One surefire way to have a hard time shifting roles is to leave work with your inner critic screaming loudly at you: You didn’t do enough! Your boss hates you! Your colleagues think you’re slacking off now that you’re a parent! The more you can replace your harsh inner critic with a helpful, supportive voice, the easier it will be to feel more present and relaxed at home. Remind yourself that the transition back to work isn’t easy—for anyone. It takes time to find your (new) groove, and you don’t have to do it perfectly on day 1—or even on day 100.
If you’re feeling overwhelmed by the transition, and need some extra support, book an appointment with a practitioner in Maven’s network. Our career coaches and therapists specialize in areas that affect new parents, so you don’t have to go through this alone.

title.en-US: Your no-panic guide to gestational diabetes

content.value: This is one pregnancy condition that causes many women to worry. But the first thing to know is that gestational diabetes is far more common than you might think. In fact, it’s estimated that 2% to 10% of pregnant women in the U.S. receive this diagnosis each year. Read on to have all your questions answered, and relax knowing that delivering a healthy baby is totally possible.
First, what is gestational diabetes?

Gestational diabetes happens when you have too much sugar (a.k.a. glucose) in your blood during pregnancy. Your blood sugar levels can spike when your body isn't producing enough of the hormone insulin. Most women who develop the condition go on to give birth to healthy babies, but occasionally the condition can lead to serious health problems. One risk is premature birth, or having a large baby (weighing over 9 pounds) and needing a C-section.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Do you have to be out of shape to get it?

First things first: whatever the cause, this is not something to be hard on yourself about. It’s true that behavioral factors such as diet and exercise habits can contribute to an increased risk. But it’s possible to be in excellent shape and an otherwise very healthy person yet still develop the condition. Very often, it falls into the category of “beyond our control.”
When is it diagnosed?

Most women get tested around weeks 24 to 28 of their pregnancy. That said, if you are overweight or obese and also have another risk factor for type-2 diabetes such as a family history of diabetes, gestational diabetes in a previous pregnancy, a history of giving birth to a big baby (over 9 pounds), high blood pressure, or high cholesterol, your doctor will likely want to test you sooner.
What happens once you’re diagnosed?
Your doctor will likely recommend frequent checkups to monitor your blood sugar. Sometimes women are also asked to monitor their own blood sugar levels daily at home.
Do you have to take medication if you’re diagnosed?

Not necessarily. Some women who don’t respond to lifestyle changes may have to take medication such as insulin injections, but most cases are treated simply with diet and exercise. Limiting carbohydrates (breads, potatoes, pasta) and sugar usually helps normalize blood sugar levels. You may want to book an appointment with a nutritionist in Maven’s network to create a personalized meal plan based on your needs. Exercising regularly—think: at least three times a week—can also help keep the condition under control.
Does gestational diabetes go away after childbirth?

The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists suggests that women who developed the condition during pregnancy be screened for diabetes and pre-diabetes between 4 and 12 weeks postpartum. The bad news first: Once you have gestational diabetes, your risk of developing type 2 diabetes later on can be up to 60%. The good news? In many cases, the situation resolves and blood sugar levels return to normal soon after you deliver the baby. Be sure to work with your doctor post-delivery to help keep risk factors down.

This article is not intended to be a substitute for medical advice or care. Please consult a doctor with any questions you have before taking actions around your health and wellbeing. As always, our Maven practitioners are available, on-demand, to address your concerns.
Book an appointment here.
It’s possible to be in excellent shape and an otherwise very healthy person yet still develop the condition.

title.en-US: 3 nutrients all pregnant women need in their diets

content.value: For a healthy pregnancy, a proper diet is key. Translation: This is not the time to try the latest, wackiest eating trend. You need the right balance of proteins, carbs, and fats. And making friends with the produce aisle is also a good idea. But not all pregnancy foods are created equal. Read on before your next grocery trip to learn the three essential nutrients every expecting mom needs—plus smart ways to get your fill.
Folate
Why you need it:

This B vitamin is vital during pregnancy—which is why you may have noticed it's a major ingredient in your prenatal supplements. (Quick science lesson: the synthetic form of folate found in supplements and fortified foods is called folic acid.) The reason folate is so significant: It helps prevent neural-tube defects like spina bifida, a birth disorder in which part of the baby’s spine is exposed.
Eat up!

Natural sources of folate include legumes, leafy greens, broccoli, asparagus, citrus fruit, and peanuts. Complex carbs fortified with folic acid—such as whole-grain bread and pasta—can also help get you to your goal of at least 400 micrograms per day.
Calcium
Why you need it:

Calcium is essential for building your baby's bones and teeth. Just how big of a role does calcium play? One study found that babies of moms who took 2,000 milligrams of calcium supplements per day during the second and third trimester were born with 15 percent greater bone density than newborns whose moms didn’t get the calcium boost. Interestingly, if you don’t get enough of the mineral, your body will steal from your own stores to give it to your fetus.
Eat up!

Your doctor will likely suggest getting at least 1,200 milligrams a day during pregnancy—and while milk has a well-earned reputation as a go-to source (a one-cup serving has about 300 mg), there are plenty of non-dairy ways to meet your requirement of calcium. Certain leafy greens, seafood, legumes, and fruit are good sources of the mineral. A few calcium all-stars to add to your pregnancy menu: canned white beans (190 mg per cup); almonds (75 mg per ounce); broccoli (86 mg per 2 cups raw); collard greens (268 mg per 1 cup, cooked); and oranges (74 mg in one large fruit).
Iron
Why you need it:

Maybe “eating for two” is a myth, but “mineral-ing for two” isn’t so far off. With iron, you need 27 milligrams a day—that’s about 10 grams more than your pre-pregnant body required. Your body uses the mineral to make hemoglobin, a protein in the red blood cells that carries oxygen to your tissues and also stocks your baby’s growing blood supply. If your iron stores are deficient, you could develop iron deficiency anemia and risk becoming severely fatigued. (Yes, even more than the usual pregnancy exhaustion.) If anemia becomes severe and goes untreated, it can lead to poor fetal growth.
Eat up!

Sure, your doctor or OB-GYN may recommend a supplement to beef up your stores, but reaching for more iron-rich foods is smart. (Real talk: Iron supplements sometimes lead to constipation.) Your best bets are lean red meat, poultry and fish. While iron from animal sources is better absorbed by your body, you can round out your diet with other iron-containing eats like beans, veggies, dried fruit (especially peaches and apricots), and whole grains.
Have more questions about your pregnancy diet?
Book an appointment with a nutritionist in Maven’s network who can help you create a personalized meal plan based on your body and needs.

title.en-US: 8 things to cut yourself some slack about right now

content.value: Expecting a baby comes with lots of “shoulds” and “musts.” To that we say: Sorry, but there’s no such thing as a perfect pregnancy journey. In the name of cutting yourself some slack, use this list to remind yourself it’s OK...

...if you’re counting down the days until you can sleep on your belly, have a cocktail, or see your feet again. You can be grateful your body is bringing a life into the world, and still long for the days when it will be yours again.

...if you choose the steak frites over the salad. As long as you’re eating well the majority of the time, forgive yourself for occasionally letting your junk-food cravings win. Fact: Conception doesn’t turn women into dietary saints.
...if excitement is the furthest thing from what you feel. Pregnancy doesn’t come with a one-size-fits-all emotion, and it’s OK if you’re not exactly skipping with joy through these nine months.
...if a gender reveal party, babymoon, or any other pregnancy “rite of passage” just isn’t your thing. Do what you want and not what you don't.
...if your maternity wardrobe is basically a few stretchy pants and your partner’s oversized shirts. If it works for you, no judgment!

...if your reaction to unsolicited pregnancy advice is: Thanks but no thanks. Yes, that’s a regular coffee in your hands (with your doctor’s blessing) and no you don’t care that Aunt Sally thinks it’s a bad idea.
...if the last time you were in the mood for sex was the night you conceived your baby. Libido changes happen during pregnancy, and it’s perfectly normal if your sex life has its ups and downs.
...to choose naps over, well, anything else. Party pooper syndrome = 100% fine.

title.en-US: Most commonly asked questions about egg freezing

content.value: What is egg freezing?
Egg freezing (oocyte cryopreservation) is when retrieved eggs are frozen and stored using a vitrification (freezing) process, so that they may be thawed and used later in IVF.
What are some reasons that women freeze their eggs?
Egg freezing can be an option if you're not ready to become pregnant now but want to try to ensure your ability to get pregnant or have a biological child in the future.
The most common reason women freeze their eggs today is that they are single and not currently in a relationship but would like the option of biological motherhood in the future.

If someone is about to undergo treatment for cancer or another illness like severe endometriosis or recurrent ovarian cysts that may affect future fertility potential, egg freezing is a great option to preserve the ability to have biological children later. Certain medical treatments—such as radiation or chemotherapy—can harm your fertility.

Another scenario where egg freezing is a good option is if a woman suffers from a condition that causes premature ovarian failure or the removal of ovaries. This could also include a history of early menopause in the family.
What is the best age to freeze your eggs?

From a medical perspective, you want to freeze your eggs when you’re as young as possible. On average, it is reported that there is a slight decline in fertility at the age of 27 and a substantial decrease after the age of 35. That said, there are many other considerations involved, particularly financial considerations, so women shouldn’t put pressure on themselves to do it immediately. Many women have successful egg retrievals in their late thirties and the technology continues to get better every year.
How many eggs should I freeze?

Based on data published in early 2017 from 520 healthy, fertile women undergoing treatment at Brigham and Women’s in Boston, the study, published in Human Reproduction, predicts that women under 35 who freeze 10–20 eggs have between a 70% and 90% chance of at least one live birth later on.
How many eggs will I harvest per cycle?
Most women 38 years of age and under can expect to harvest 10- 20 eggs per cycle.
Is egg freezing an invasive procedure?
You'll need to first use fertility drugs to induce ovulation so that you'll produce multiple eggs for retrieval. These can have unpleasant side effects like nausea and bloating.

During the retrieval process, an ultrasound probe is inserted into your vagina to identify the follicles. A needle is then guided through the vagina and into a follicle. A suction device connected to the needle is used to remove the egg from the follicle. Multiple eggs can be removed from your follicles in about 15 to 20 minutes.
After egg retrieval, you might experience cramping. Feelings of fullness or pressure might continue for weeks because your ovaries remain enlarged.
Does a frozen egg have risks associated with it if I were to use it later?
Research to date hasn't shown an increase in the risk of birth defects for babies born as a result of egg freezing. However, further research is needed to confirm the safety of egg freezing.
If you use your frozen eggs to have a biological child, the risk of miscarriage will be primarily based on your age at the time your eggs were frozen.
If I don’t find a partner, does that mean I can’t use my eggs?

You can use your frozen eggs to try to conceive a biological child with sperm from a sperm donor. A donor can be known or anonymous. The embryo can also be implanted in the uterus of another person to carry the pregnancy (gestational carrier).
What do I do with unused eggs?
You might be able to donate unused frozen eggs to a couple or a research facility. You might also choose to discard unused eggs.

title.en-US: 5 things new parents should keep in their self-care tool kit

content.value: There’s so much talk about new mothers needing self-care, especially when they return to work and life becomes even more stressful. But if you can’t take a week off to spend in a spa (and who can?), you may be wondering what self-care even looks like on an everyday basis. The answer to that is highly individual: whatever helps you refuel so you can continue your work as a parent and employee (and friend... and partner... and all the other roles you play in your life!). Here are a few simple ideas to get you started.
Start a compliments file on your phone or computer.

Anytime someone gives you a compliment—whether it’s a colleague telling you that you did a great job on a presentation or a stranger remarking on your style—write it down. Self-care means not getting down on yourself, so whenever your confidence could use a boost, refer to this file.
Cook a healthy dinner.
Next: Eat it while sitting down. And if you can, let someone else feed the baby while you eat. Never underestimate the power of a nourishing meal to help you tap into some self-love.
Watch a soul-filling Ted Talk.
One we love: Brené Brown’s talk called “The power of vulnerability,” which will remind you of the value of honest human connection, and inspire you to go after more of it in your own life.
Take a mental health day off work.

Those sick days aren’t just there for when you’ve got the flu. If your psychological and emotional health need some attention, consider a day off from work. You’ve already got childcare set up, so use the day to do something for you: nap all day, go see a movie, take a midday yoga class, do whatever always manages to restore you.
Do something you’ve never done before.

If you’ve been feeling like your life has become too much of a routine since having a kid—work- baby-work-baby-work—it may be a good idea to break the monotony. This probably isn’t a time in your life when you can invest an entire month or year to personal growth, but even small opportunities to try new things can bring fulfillment. Be a tourist in your own city and visit a museum you haven’t been to before. Or attend a new kind of exercise class. Even taking a different route to work can expand your mind a little.

title.en-US: What can you do if you don’t have time to exercise during pregnancy?

content.value: Your days are packed, but experts keep telling you to make time for fitness. Don’t panic—the solution is easier than you may have thought.

We get it—pregnancy may increase your belly size, but it doesn’t add extra hours to your day. If you don’t have much time to get to an exercise class, or even to devote a half-hour to yoga by rolling out a mat in your living room, you can still get in some movement. Instead of thinking of fitness as one item to cross off your to-do list, find small, bite-size ways to get more steps into your day.

Perhaps you can turn your morning commute to work into a walking session—park 15 minutes away from the office, or get off the bus or subway a few stops further, and walk the rest of the way. If you usually order lunch, find a go-to spot that’s 10 minutes away—there’s twenty minutes of walking right there, to and from your workplace. Keep a pair of comfortable sneakers under your desk so you can do a few laps around the block whenever you have time. You can also consider “walking meetings”—if you’re comfortable asking a colleague to stroll with you while you tackle your agenda. Chances are, you’ll both feel more alert when you’re back at H.Q.

Bottom line: With all the overwhelming aspects of pregnancy, fitness doesn’t have to feel like another impossible mountain to climb. Small bursts of activity throughout the day can make a huge difference. Try it and you may notice aches and pains go away, weight gain stays in check, and your sleep even improves.

title.en-US: The real deal on Vitamin D for babies

content.value: Vitamin D is becoming the most popular kid on the block when it comes to a healthy diet. But you might not have realized that babies need it too. Here’s a primer on what makes D such a big deal, and how to be sure your little one is getting enough.
What exactly is vitamin D and why is it important?

Vitamin D is also called the sunshine vitamin because the human body makes D on its own when exposed to sunlight. Babies who don't get enough may not adequately absorb the calcium they need to build strong bones. (A severe deficiency can lead to rickets, a disorder characterized by soft bones that are vulnerable to breaks and fractures.)
How much D do babies need?
The American Academy of Pediatrics says that infants and children need 400 international units (IU) of Vitamin D a day.
How can babies get it?
Since sun exposure isn't recommended for babies, diet is the best way to prevent vitamin D deficiency in babies.
If breastmilk provides perfect nutrition, does it contain enough D?

You’re right—breast milk is considered the ideal food for a baby. But when it comes to vitamin D, it doesn’t really pack a punch. Dr. Amy Brandon, M.D., a board certified pediatrician in Maven's network of practitioners explains: “It turns out that most nursing mothers are on the low end of vitamin D levels themselves, and even in those who do have adequate stores for their own bones, D doesn't make it into breast milk easily.” The average breast milk contains only about 25 IU of D per liter. That means supplementation for baby is required.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
If you’re formula-feeding your baby, do you need to supplement?

In the past, experts thought a supplement wasn’t necessary because formula is fortified with Vitamin D. But now we know that formula-fed newborns still need a supplement because they don’t drink enough milk to meet their daily requirement. Once your older baby is taking at least 32 ounces a day of D-fortified formula, or whole milk (after age 1), they should be getting enough without supplementing.
What kind of supplements should I look for?

Liquid-drop solutions are best for infants. A pediatrician on Maven’s platform can write you a prescription or recommend an OTC brand. Carlson Labs Baby Natural Vitamin D Drops and Baby Ddrops are two popular options. Some moms prefer to go strictly organic. In that case, you can look for an organic brand without any chemicals or additives, such as Mommy's Bliss organic vitamin D drops (which you can find on Amazon).
Are there any alternatives to giving my baby the daily drops?

Recent studies have shown that in some cases, supplementing the mother with specially-dosed oral vitamin D capsules can increase levels in breastmilk enough to provide baby with all he or she needs. Ask a Maven provider if this alternative could be an option for you and your family.
Formula-fed newborns still need a supplement.

title.en-US: What are smart breastfeeding strategies for working moms?

content.value: Answer from Back-To-Work Coach Mary Beth Ferrante
First, advocate for a great set-up if you don't have one.

While there are laws in place to help with this, you want to be sure you have access to a clean, private area, ideally with a refrigerator that is close to your office space so it doesn't interrupt your day too much. If possible, ask to work in a private office instead of a cubicle (one without glass walls!) temporarily so that you can simply close your office door when it’s time to pump.
Invest in multiple sets of flanges and bottles.

This way, you won’t have to spend as much time washing parts at work. Another time saver—if you have access to a personal mini-fridge at work—could be to put your fully-assembled pump parts in the refrigerator between pumping sessions so you don’t have to disassemble and reassemble them each time.
Wear pump-friendly clothes.
The worst thing is when you have on the kind of dress that requires you to basically completely disrobe so you can pump.

title.en-US: Best news ever: Chocolate does a (pregnant) body good

content.value: Permission to indulge your cravings.

Treating yourself to a small but decadent dose of dark chocolate daily may have benefits for you and your baby. Sounds too good to be true, but science is on your side, chocoholics. For one, a team of Yale researchers found that eating chocolate during pregnancy was associated with lower rates of preeclampsia, a serious condition characterized by high blood pressure. Another study found a possible link between chocolate consumption and better placental function, thanks to an improvement of blood flow in a mom-to-be.

And chocolate could be the gift that keeps on giving—even after you give birth: Scientists in Finland surveyed 300 women and found that moms who regularly ate chocolate during pregnancy were more likely to say their babies smiled and laughed a lot at 6 months of age. One theory is that it could have to do with chocolate’s ability to make pregnant women less stressed, and pass on those feel-good chemicals to her baby.

That said, no one is sure exactly why chocolate may lead to these perks and more research is needed to confirm these associations, but don’t let that stop you from digging in—in moderation, of course. The one caveat to this awesome cocoa news is that chocolate is also packed with sugar and caffeine. Go for darker varieties to cut down on the sugar content, and try to make a whole bar last a week by having a couple of squares each night (as opposed to polishing it off in an hour). With all the lists of the things that expectant women can’t eat, isn’t it nice to know pregnancy doesn’t have to mean total deprivation?

title.en-US: Should you use laughing gas to ease labor pain?

content.value: Giggling is probably the last thing that comes to mind when you’re thinking about your delivery day. But as it turns out, “laughing gas” can help you relax and push through the pains of labor. The elixir—technically called nitrous oxide—has been used during childbirth for a long time in other countries, but didn’t catch on in the U.S. until recent years. As more hospitals and birth centers are offering it, women are wondering if it’s right for them. Know the facts so you can choose wisely.
Is nitrous oxide used for labor the same thing you get during, say, a root canal?

Yes, but in a different blend. During labor, women receive a 50/50 mix of oxygen and nitrous. For dental procedures, it can be administered at a much higher concentration of 70% nitrous and 30% oxygen.
How does it work?

Depending on the hospital, either the anesthesia team or a nurse will set up the nitrous oxide machine in the delivery room. And during labor, you decide when you need a “hit” of the gas. Just before a big push, for instance, you’ll hold the mask up to your face and inhale the gas. The effect sets in quickly—between 30 seconds and a minute—but also wears off fast, within 3 to 5 minutes.
Does laughing gas completely stop you from feeling the pain of labor?

Actually, no. OB-GYNs say it’s not that you won’t feel the pain, it’s that you won’t care so much about it. You’ll be more calm and relaxed, so instead of stalling out and taking breaks when contractions feel too intense, the gas may help you keep pushing through.
Why do some women choose laughing gas instead of a more heavy-hitting pain relief?

Some women who’ve opted for laughing gas say they wanted pain relief in the moment they truly needed it, and liked the idea of having more control over when it was administered. Narcotics (i.e. morphine) take longer to leave a woman’s system, and an epidural stays in for several hours, making it difficult to get up and move around. There are definite perks, but if you want a labor with the absolute least amount of pain, nitrous oxide may not be the best option.
Are there any side effects from nitrous oxide?

Every woman is different, but it’s relatively low-risk. You may feel a bit nauseous, drowsy, or dizzy. The gas doesn’t cause any harm to your baby. One thing to know: Some people who have a vitamin B12 deficiency aren’t good candidates for nitrous oxide.
What should I do if I’m interested?

Ask your doctor or midwife in advance if it’s an option at the hospital or birthing center where you’ll be delivering. While nitrous oxide is more popular than it was a decade ago, it’s still not available everywhere. Experts say that if more women start asking for it, it may become a standard offering.

title.en-US: What’s a miscarriage and why did this happen to me?

content.value: When we’re going through something as difficult as a miscarriage, it’s natural to want to know: How often does this happen? The truth is, that answer might change depending on who you talk to. You might hear that one in 10 pregnancies ends in a miscarriage—or that number can creep up to one in four. Frustrating as it is, the reason it’s difficult to determine how many miscarriages take place is because they often occur before a woman even realizes she's pregnant. One thing everyone can agree on: Miscarriages are so common that some OB-GYNs consider them a normal part of reproduction.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT

But stats don’t make going through it any easier. Miscarriages can be traumatic and, as a result, they’re something we don’t often talk about with each other or even fully understand. Here are the questions you may have wondered about:
Q: What, exactly, is a miscarriage?

In doctor jargon, it’s often referred to as a “spontaneous abortion.” But simply put, a miscarriage is when a baby dies in the womb before 20 weeks of pregnancy. (After 20 weeks, the loss of a fetus is called a stillbirth.)
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Q: When do miscarriages usually happen?

Miscarriages are most likely to occur in the first 12 weeks, but that doesn’t mean that second-trimester pregnancy loss doesn’t happen. Some experts say that it’s our biology’s programming to miscarry embryos that, in truth, aren’t likely to develop into a healthy fetus. Because the vast majority of miscarriages boil down to genetic abnormalities that are beyond our (or anyone’s) control.
Q: What are the common symptoms of a miscarriage?

Truth? The experience can vary from person to person; sometimes, there are no symptoms at all. Most women you’ll talk to will tell you they had the telltale signs of bleeding and cramping. A pelvic exam, ultrasound, and bloodwork can confirm a miscarriage when you think you’re having one.
Q: Physically speaking, what are the ways to “deal with” a miscarriage?

There’s no one right way to complete the process, but it’s important to make sure that all the fetal tissue is gone. Otherwise, you might end up with an infection or other complications. Some women who want immediate “closure” choose to have a procedure called D&C (a.k.a. dilation and curettage) to surgically remove the tissue from the uterus. Others let their own bodies do the work and complete the miscarriage naturally, which could take a little longer. There are also medicines available that can help speed things along by causing uterine contractions.
Q: I didn't realize this is such a difficult experience to go through. If it's so common, why doesn't anyone talk about this more?

Sadly, we keep too much of our pregnancy experience a secret. Think about it: You often hear the advice that you shouldn’t tell anyone you’re expecting until after the first trimester. As a society, we’ve applied the same hush-hush attitude toward miscarriage. Some women who’ve miscarried think of it as a personal flaw, so they’re reluctant to share. Others want to avoid judgment, or just find the grief too big to address. But know this: If you’ve experienced a loss, opening up can help. And it’s normal to need more support than your inner circle can provide. If you’re thinking about therapy, Maven’s network includes therapists who specialize in pregnancy loss. You can speak to practitioners over video call, or message them if texting feels like a more comfortable place to start.
Book an appointment here.

This article is not intended to be a substitute for medical advice or care. Please consult a doctor with any questions you have before taking actions around your health and wellbeing. As always, our Maven practitioners are available, on-demand, to address your concerns.
Book an appointment here.
Sources: March of Dimes; Mayo Clinic; American Academy of Family Physicians
Miscarriages are so common that some OB-GYNs consider them a normal part of reproduction.
The vast majority of miscarriages boil down to genetic abnormalities that are beyond our (or anyone’s) control.

title.en-US: How to control morning sickness when you're in a car

content.value: Morning sickness (or, for some, all-day sickness) is bad enough without the extra nausea triggered by riding in a moving vehicle. Whether you’re commuting to work or heading on a road trip, use these tips to make the drive a bit more comfortable.
Get in the driver’s seat.

According to the Cleveland Clinic, for some people, driving the vehicle (rather than being a passenger) is an instant remedy for motion-induced morning sickness during pregnancy. If you can’t drive, at least call dibs on sitting in the front—and definitely crack a window (weather permitting).
Stare out the window, not at your phone.
Even better, try to keep your gaze on a fixed point above the horizon. Looking down is likely to make your nausea worse.
Don’t make a pit-stop at the drive-thru.

Fatty, greasy foods don’t do you any favors if you’re prone to getting morning sickness. In fact, just the smell alone can trigger symptoms: One study found that 65% of a group of pregnant women said a whiff of fried food brought on nausea.
Stash some relief in the glove compartment.

Snacks like pretzels and crackers may come in handy. And if you’re going on a longer road trip and your morning sickness is bad, talk to your OB-GYN beforehand about medications. With your doctor’s OK, there are some safe options to take during pregnancy. “The safest medicine is Diclegis, which is a combination of an OTC antihistamine doxylamine and vitamin B6,” says Jackie Stone, MD, a Maven OB-GYN. “It’s considered a Pregnancy Category A drug, which means that in well-controlled human trials, no health risks to the fetus were detected. Other prescription options to discuss with your doctor include meclizine, promethazine (Phenergan), and metoclopramide (Reglan). As for natural remedies, ginger has been shown to be effective in a randomized trial for nausea at 250 mg capsules taken 4 times daily. Vitamin B6 (25 mg every 6 to 8 hours) may also help.” Lastly, there’s always Benadryl—but you should of course only take this if you’re not the one driving, since it will cause drowsiness on the wheel.

title.en-US: Baby on board: 5 things to know about traveling with an infant

content.value: Understandably, traveling with a child gives many new parents anxiety.
Is my baby old enough to fly? Will her tiny ears explode in pain? And what if the passenger next to me turns out to be a walking petri dish with a bad case of the flu?
While we can’t guarantee the perfect seatmate, we can give you some guidance to make the ride less bumpy for you and your little one.
Try not to jet out of town too soon.

There aren’t hard and fast rules against traveling with a newborn, but your baby’s pediatrician may discourage non-essential air travel in the first few weeks after you give birth. It's hard to know what germs are lurking in an airplane, and since their immune system is still developing, babies could be at a greater risk of catching a cold or an infection. And when you do decide to take off, it isn’t a bad idea to be a little O.C.D. about hand-washing/sanitizing; seat-back pockets, tray tables, and other surfaces are hot-spots for icky germs.
Pack a car seat.

Babies under two are technically allowed to sit in your lap. But the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) suggests reserving an extra ticket so you can place your baby in a car seat next to you instead, especially for longer flights. (If budget is an issue, call the airline to see if special discounts are available for little ones, or try to book flights that are likely to have empty seats you can snag two seats next to each other.) The FAA (Federal Aviation Administration) recommends placing a child weighing less than 20 pounds into a rear-facing car seat. Just make sure your car seat is FAA-approved.
Tell the airline about your “plus one” before your departure date.

It’s a good idea to let the airline in advance that you’ll be travelling with an infant—whether you’re planning to hold your baby in your lap or not. While domestic flights within the U.S. usually don’t charge a fee or require a ticket for a “lap child,” that’s not the case for international flights: You can usually expect to pay 10% of the adult fare, and purchasing the ticket in advance can help prevent a hassle when you get to the airport.
You can relax about the liquid rule.

You already know that the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) has strict rules on the volume of liquids allowed on an airplane. But don’t worry—your baby won’t be restricted to 3 ounces of milk. Formula, breast milk, and juice in quantities greater than 3.4 ounces get the green light.
Avoid the ear ouch.

Changing atmospheric pressure during taking and landing might cause some ear pain for your baby. While you can’t always avoid the tears, some experts recommend timing your baby’s feedings so she’s hungry during the ascent and decent, and nursing her or offering a bottle during takeoff and landing. The sucking and swallowing motion can help minimize the inner ear pressure.
Have more questions about traveling with a child? book an appointment) with a pediatrician on Maven’s platform for tips and advice.

title.en-US: 5 reasons to choose a midwife

content.value: Deciding who will be your primary practitioner is one of the first choices you’ll make during your pregnancy. While physician-attended births are still the norm in the U.S., a small but growing number of mothers do turn to midwives. You can see a midwife for just about all your maternity needs, but there’s still a lot of confusion around what a midwife actually is.

First, just because a midwife doesn’t attend med school doesn't mean she hasn’t been through rigorous training. A certified nurse midwife (CNM) is licensed as a nurse and then gets additional master’s level training in midwifery. A certified midwife (CM) goes through a similar accreditation process but doesn’t have a nursing degree. (All of the midwives on Maven, by the way, are CNMs—click here to look for a provider.)

You might also hear the term: “lay midwife” or “direct-entry midwife.” That refers to someone who hasn’t been certified by any national organization and isn’t recognized as a legal practitioner in several states. And if you’re wondering about insurance: Care by a CNM is covered by most health plans if you’re giving birth in a hospital—where, contrary to popular belief, the vast majority of midwife-assisted births take place.
There’s no one answer to why women choose a midwife, but if any of these priorities ring true to you, you might want to explore this option.
1. I want to let my body do what I know it can do.

Here’s their underlying philosophy: Midwives view pregnancy and birth as a natural process that shouldn't require much medical intervention. That’s why midwives are much less likely than OB-GYNS to resort to spinal anesthesia, forceps deliveries, and cesarean sections. (Interestingly, about a third of all births in the U.S. are Cesarean sections, which some experts believe comes down to how the medical community thinks about labor—including how quickly a delivery should happen and when to introduce medical intervention.)
2. I expect a lot of T.L.C. (time, love, care) from my practitioner.

Here’s a little bit of party trivia for you: The word midwife comes from the Anglo-Saxon word “mit wif,” meaning “with woman.” That’s appropriate given that midwives are especially known for their close involvement—and time spent—with you. While it’s true that some OB-GYNs also play a key supporting role for their patients, many time-strapped doctors might not provide the holistic care you’d get from a midwife. What could that entail? Besides the physical services like gynecological exams and screenings, midwives give emotional guidance, nutrition counseling, and individualized help in carrying out your ideal birth experience.
3. I’m open to meds, but want to try natural alternatives to managing pain.

You might have heard that you absolutely won’t be able to get pain medication if you go with a midwife. The reality? CNMs in most states have the right to offer epidurals and other forms of pain relief. (The only caveat is that you can’t get an epidural if you choose to have a home birth.) That said, if it’s important to you to explore natural and alternative methods for managing pain—everything from yoga breathing and massage to water births—seeking out a midwife is a good idea since they’re generally more holistic in their approach.
4. My pregnancy is considered “uncomplicated.”

Most CNMs deal exclusively with women whose pregnancies are considered low-risk. If yours is not—say, for example, you’re carrying twins, or have a condition such as diabetes or severe hypertension—you’ll most likely need an OB-GYN on your team. Some women who have higher-risk pregnancies choose a midwife in addition to their OB-GYN. The theory here: The more practitioners involved, the merrier the pregnancy. (Something like that!)
5. My gut tells me yes.
At the end of the day, you’ll want to choose a practitioner based on who makes you feel safe and supported. Do your homework, talk to a few providers, and then—as always—follow your instincts.

title.en-US: 3 questions that can save your relationship after a baby

content.value: Gabriel Garcia Marquez was on to something when he said, “The problem with marriage is that it ends every night after making love, and it must be rebuilt every morning before breakfast.” Well, when you throw a baby into the mix, keeping a relationship strong requires even more of a daily effort. If you’re feeling a little distanced from your partner right now, totally normal. Asking yourself these three essential questions can help you get over the new-parenthood hump and make your bond stronger than ever.
Am I shutting my partner out?

This phenomenon is so common among new parents that psychologists have given it an official term: maternal gatekeeping. While this habit can take many forms, the basic gist is an attempt to control or limit your partner’s involvement or interactions with your kids. This may be as subtle as a snarky look of disapproval when they are trying to change a diaper or get the baby into a clean onesie. Research shows that when one parent gate-keep, they end up shouldering more of the household work, experience higher rates of depression, and their romantic relationships also take a hit. If you catch yourself in gatekeeper mode, first things first: Cut yourself some slack because the research shows most people don’t do this intentionally or even consciously. Being aware of this tendency is often a big first step to changing the behavior. Next, remind yourself that you partnered with this person for a reason—and trust in them was likely a part of that reason. And if you’re worried that your partner’s swaddling or burping technique isn’t up to snuff, just remember: Neither one of you has to be perfect at this whole parenting thing.
Am I appreciating the little things?

Get this: Saying thank you more often might just save your relationship. But don’t take it from us; scientists from the University of Georgia surveyed hundreds of couples and found that gratitude is the best predictor of how happy someone is in a relationship: "Even if a couple is experiencing distress and difficulty... gratitude in the relationship can help promote positive marital outcomes.” You don’t have to overdo it or be inauthentic or overly gushy. Even a simple text to say, for instance, “What you did this morning was really great” or “Thumbs up on ordering the diapers from Amazon” can go a long way to keep your bond strong and free of resentment.
Am I telling myself that things will be this hard forever?

It may feel like your relationship has taken a complete 180 and that you don’t recognize many aspects of your partner—or even yourself—right now. Exhaustion, leftover baby weight, zero time to even take a shower—those are just a few of the realities of life that new parents say make it difficult to feel particularly desirable in the weeks or months after having a baby. In fact, it’s not uncommon to feel more like “roommates” than an actual romantic couple. Your partner may also be having a hard time navigating this new world as a working parent and figuring out how to best support you and raise a child. While this transition time isn’t easy, getting stuck in “it will be this way forever” thinking makes it harder to get through the tough days. One of the best things you can do for your relationship is to remind yourself of this fact: This will pass. One day, you will have a date night and won’t notice even the faintest smell of baby spit-up. Promise.

If you’re having a hard time riding out the highs and lows of your relationship, and think it could help to talk to a therapist or couples counselor, book an appointment with a Maven provider. They specialize in the struggles specific to new parents, and can video chat with you anytime you feel frustrated or alone.

title.en-US: The top reason new moms stop breastfeeding

content.value: The lactation struggle is real.

Over 80% of moms in the U.S. report breastfeeding at some point, according to CDC data. But how many of them follow the recommended guidelines of the American Academy of Pediatrics to breastfeed exclusively for the first six months? Just 22% of new moms.
Let’s pause right here to say, by the way: No judgments. How you decide to feed your baby is up to you and your doctor. But what if you want to breastfeed, but just... can’t?

The fact is, many moms have the intention to breastfeeding for six months or even a year or longer, but many of them stop early. That’s why researchers wanted to look into the reasons why they give up before they want to. In 2015, 13,000 pregnant women and first-time moms were polled in the Lansinoh Breastfeeding Survey. The researchers wanted to pinpoint the top reasons women decided to stop sooner than they want to.

Here’s what the researchers found: In 9 of the 10 countries represented in the survey, women said the pain factor was the biggest barrier. Other issues included the difficulty of waking up in the middle of the night, as well as trouble learning how to breastfeed and how to gauge whether a baby was getting enough breastmilk. An earlier study published in the journal Pediatrics found that working parents are more likely to breastfeed for longer if they're able to stay on maternity leave for an extended period—so the very real challenge of pumping while working is also a factor for some moms.

Experts say that women who don't seek support might not know that there are ways to make breastfeeding easier so they give up. For instance, getting a proper latch is tricky—and when it doesn’t happen, you may end up with a lot of pain and cracked nipples, and who could blame you if that doesn’t make you want to continue breastfeeding? One of the jobs of a good lactation consultant is to help you establish a good latch—breastfeeding (really) shouldn’t hurt.

If you want to work with a lactation consultant, one option is to ask your doctor or fellow mom friends for a recommendation. You can also book an appointment with a Maven lactation consultant to get guidance via video chat. They can even watch as you nurse your baby in order to provide pointers. The bottom line: Breastfeeding is often hard, but with support, it can be a lot easier.

title.en-US: How being a working mother benefits your child

content.value: To those who say working outside the home does “damage” to a kid, we say: Nah.

If you’re a working parent who is feeling guilty that you can’t be with little one 24/7, there’s a silver lining to the trade-off you make by going to work. When Harvard researchers looked into the long-term impact of working parenthood on kids, they found some notable benefits.

In the U.S., the daughters of working mothers specifically were more likely to hold managerial roles and to earn more—23 percent more, to be exact—than women whose mothers stayed home full-time. Their sons’ career trajectory wasn’t influenced in the same way, but the research did find that they were more likely to step it up at home and make greater contributions to their households as adults. They spent more time on child care and housework than sons of stay-at-home mothers—perhaps because they were exposed to “nontraditional” gender role models.
The takeaway

: Making a decision to go back to work or stay home with your little one is tough—and both choices come with pain-points as well as perks. On days when you’re focusing on everything you’re missing out on, try to remind yourself that things aren’t black and white. Ultimately, a happy parent, makes a happy (and successful) kid.

title.en-US: How to prepare for egg freezing

content.value: What’s the first thing I should think about?

First, you need a good clinic. Data related to egg freezing and pregnancies using frozen eggs is limited, so we recommend you assess clinics on whether they have high single embryo transfer rates (which generally means they are ahead of the curve on IVF technology and procedures) as well as on patient ratings and reviews. Your Maven Care Advocate can also help you figure out which clinic in your area is right for you.
If the expense of egg freezing is a concern, ask for detailed information about the costs associated with each step of the procedure and the annual storage fees.
Do I need to do anything before I start the process?

Before beginning the egg-freezing process, your doctor will have an in-depth discussion with you on your needs and the processes involved. Then, blood tests and a pelvic ultrasound are generally performed to assess the number of eggs in the ovaries. The blood tests include:
Ovarian reserve testing.

To determine the quantity and quality of your eggs, your doctor might test the concentration of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and estradiol in your blood on day three of your menstrual cycle. Results can help predict how your ovaries will respond to fertility medication. Other blood tests (and an ultrasound of the ovaries) may be recommended to get a more complete assessment of ovarian function.
Infectious disease screening.
You'll be screened for certain infectious diseases, such as HIV. Potentially infectious eggs are stored differently than are other eggs.
What else should I consider before starting the process?
A few questions to ask yourself:
When do you plan to become pregnant?
Weigh the probability that you'll be able to become pregnant at that age against the probability of a successful pregnancy with the use of eggs that have been frozen.
How many eggs would you like to freeze?

Most fertility experts recommend freezing a total of 20 to 30 eggs and thawing six to eight eggs for each pregnancy attempt, depending on your age and egg quality. As a result your doctor may recommend that you undergo ovarian stimulation—in which you inject medication to stimulate your ovaries—more than once.

title.en-US: How to burp your newborn baby

content.value: Any new parent knows: one of the skills you’ll become an expert at soon after you bring your baby home is burping. And if you’re wondering, "What’s even the point of burping?", the truth is, it’s a really important step in the feeding process. Learn why it matters, and how to be a pro at it:

You may not have realized that burping a baby is a little extra insurance against a cranky, finicky baby. The point of burping is to make sure babies rid themselves of any air they swallowed while being fed. When air is trapped, they’re more likely to be gassy and irritable.

Depending on your child’s need, you may need to be burping more frequently than you thought— mid-feeding as well as when he or she is done eating. When babies becoming fussy while they’re being fed, or shortly after, it’s a good sign that your burping duties should commence. That said, some babies need to burp a lot, while others rarely do. In general, breastfed babies don't need as much burping as bottle-fed babies because they tend to swallow less air when feeding. But every baby is different, so follow your baby's cues.
We know it’s hard to wake a snoozing baby, but sometimes it will be necessary to wake a baby who has just fallen asleep after a feeding. The bright side: a sounder, more comfortable sleep afterward.
There’s more than one method you can try, so keep these three in your baby burping arsenal:
Classic shoulder burp
With your baby’s head resting on your shoulder, gently pat and rub the back.
Lap lean
Sit the baby on your lap, facing away from you. Lean him or her slightly forward as you support the chest and head, then gently pat on the back.
Face down
Lay your infant across your lap, tummy-side down. With your baby’s head resting on your leg and face turned to the side, gently pat and rub his or her back.

This article is not intended to be a substitute for medical advice or care. Please consult a doctor with any questions you have before taking actions around your health and wellbeing. As always, our Maven practitioners are available, on-demand, to address your concerns.

title.en-US: "I felt like I wasn't a good enough mom"

content.value: 35 years old
Stay-at-home mom
Kentucky
Did you have postpartum depression or postpartum anxiety or both?
Both
Were you formally diagnosed? How did you know you had it?
Yes. My wife and a friend both told me they were concerned about me, and then I spoke with my OB.
Did your doctor or pediatrician screen you for postpartum depression/anxiety in your first few visits after giving birth, or even simply ask how you were doing emotionally?
My OB did at my six-week postpartum checkup.
How soon did you notice that something wasn’t quite right and you weren’t feeling like yourself?
A few days after giving birth.
What were your symptoms?

I felt detached from the baby, I cried all the time, and had unfounded worries about someone taking the baby from me or something bad happening him. I felt like I wasn't a good enough mom. I also had really bad anxiety if I talked about the hospital where I have birth, or was anywhere near it.
How open were you about your experience? Did friends/relatives/colleagues know what you were going through?
My wife knew something wasn't right. And a friend of mine who lives in Australia noticed I was off; she had had a baby four days prior to me.

Once you identified what you were going through, what helped you get better? For instance, did you go to therapy, go on medication, try mindfulness training and other holistic approaches, or something else?
I tried therapy and was also put on medication. The medication is helping me somewhat, but I have been unable to find a therapist that's a good fit.
If you didn’t feel you had enough support, what could have made things better?
It would have helped to have more resources for postpartum depression and postpartum anxiety around me. Better-trained mental health professionals in my area would've been a great help to me.
What do you wish loved ones would have done for you without being asked?
It would've been nice to have more support and help with the baby, as well as someone to talk to about my experiences without being worried about being judged or shamed.
How long did it take to feel like yourself again, and what do you think helped you the most?
I still don't truly feel like myself and it's been 11 months since I had my son.
Did you have postpartum depression or anxiety when you returned to work? How did you cope?
I haven't gone back to work because I'm too afraid to trust anyone else to care for my baby.
How did your experience impact your relationship with your significant other?
We have our ups and downs but for the most part I think we're still doing pretty well as a couple.
What’s the one thing you’d like to see change about how our society perceives postpartum depression and anxiety?
I wish the stigma and shame around it would go away so more women would feel like they could get the help they need.

title.en-US: Don’t believe these myths about exercise during pregnancy

content.value: When it comes to exercising while pregnant, there’s a lot of outdated advice out there. And experts worry that too many women are falling for these myths and missing out on the benefits of an active pregnancy. Read this before you stop getting a move on.
Myth #1: Exercise during pregnancy causes miscarriages.

While you may have heard this rumor and been tempted to put a hold on your gym membership for nine months, it’s a myth. According to the Mayo Clinic, even high-intensity activities such as jogging and cycling are safe during pregnancy—provided you’ve gotten the green light from your doctor to keep up these activities. There are limits, of course, and now is not the type to pick up extreme sports or enter a snowboarding competition. But that elliptical machine or bike is usually a safe bet.
Myth #2: Exercise during pregnancy is all about managing your weight.

While staying active can help you maintain a healthy size, weight control is just one of the many benefits. Exercise (at a moderate intensity) can give you energy, help you avoid constipation, and contribute to a healthier pregnancy and delivery overall. In fact, being sedentary is associated with complications such as gestational diabetes, high blood pressure, and an increased likelihood of giving birth to babies who tend to be heavier (and overweight well in adulthood).
The bottom line on exercise during pregnancy:

Always listen to your body; if you become dizzy or short of breath, or you’re otherwise feeling “off” or in pain, stop what you’re doing and call your doctor. But don’t avoid exercise altogether unless your doctor has warned you against it. ACOG says that physical activity in pregnancy has minimal risks and has been shown to benefit most women. A walk a day can keep the OB-GYN away—at least until you really need to see her.

title.en-US: Beat the Sunday-night blues: 3 tips for new parents

content.value: The end-of-weekend funk isn’t unique to parents, of course. In fact, one survey found that 8% of people in the U.S. experience it. But the Sunday-night blues can feel more intense when you’re still getting the hang of being a working parent. You may be stressing about Monday and the week ahead, worried about how you’re going to get through yet another juggling act, and feeling anxious about leaving your baby with someone else. Here are three ways to take back Sunday night and feel happier and less stressed.
Sit down for 15 minutes to “filter” your to-do list

First, write down all the nagging to-dos that are beginning to stress you out. Then, pick the top three items that you need to get down. Tell yourself that everything else is a “bonus.” Just this simple act can help you get some perspective and make the week seem more manageable.
Go off-duty for an hour

Maybe what you need after a long weekend is a little time to do something purposeless (a.k.a. things that don’t involve keeping a tiny human fed and clean). Ask someone to watch the baby while you go on your own time-out. Watch an episode of that new show everyone is talking about, get a manicure, take a walk—whatever you need to decompress before the new week’s tasks require your attention.
Make Saturday the new Sunday

If you’re in the habit of doing fun family activities on Saturday, and tedious chores on Sunday, try flipping it. Just by capping off the weekend with something fun, you could end up in a better mood.

title.en-US: Confession: “I don’t like being pregnant”

content.value: With all the pressure to “love” being pregnant, it can be hard to admit when you, well, don’t. But for some moms-to-be, the nine months “with child” feel like something to endure, rather than something to savor. Here are three reasons to cut yourself some slack if you’re dreaming of life with a baby in your arms, not your belly.
It doesn’t mean you don’t love your unborn child.

Maven mental health experts say that women sometimes feel they have to keep up the “I like being pregnant” charade because they worry about a bad-mom stigma. But it’s important to remind yourself that loathing the morning sickness, the exhaustion, and any other fact of pregnancy life doesn’t mean you’re not grateful or excited to be on the motherhood path.
Other women will feel less alone.

Everyone’s experience is different. Sure, some mothers look back on that nine-month period with nostalgia, saying they never felt better or more beautiful. But for every woman who’s floating on a pregnancy cloud, there’s another who’s counting down the days until a doctor JUST GETS THE BABY OUT. By acknowledging your own (real, valid) feelings about your pregnancy, you give other moms-to-be permission to do the same.
You (literally) don’t have time to beat yourself up.

Being pregnant already requires a ton of energy, and let’s face it: Being in a guilt loop is exhausting. Remind yourself that your time and mental focus is better spent on other things, like taking care of yourself and preparing for a major life change.

title.en-US: 3 C-section myths not to believe

content.value: Gotta love the rumors floating around in pregnancy circles and on the internet. Before you go down the Google rabbit hole and start believing wacky pregnancy “wisdom”, let’s debunk a few of the most common C-section myths.
The Myth: Once a C-section, always a C-section
The Reality:

Contrary to popular belief, many women who’ve had a prior Cesarean end up being good candidates for vaginal birth. (It even has a nickname in medical circles—VBAC, which stands for vaginal birth after C-section.) If your previous birth was a C-section and you want to try delivering vaginally, your doctor will evaluate your risk for uterine rupture; that’s when the incision in your abdomen could reopen during delivery. The screening process involves what’s called a trial or labor after Cesarean, or TOLAC. Bottom line: This isn’t a black-and-white decision; the reason for your first C-section, the type of incision that was made on your uterus, and other factors in your medical history will ultimately determine whether you get the green light for a VBAC.
The Myth: A C-section is a breeze compared to a vaginal birth
The Reality:

First things first: The decision over how to deliver your child is a personal one that’s between you and your doctor. Sometimes the safest delivery for a mom and her baby is a C-section, making them a life-saving option. But when people talk about elective C-sections to avoid the pain/hassle/fill-in-the-blank they fear with vaginal births, they often don’t consider the full picture. A Cesarean is major abdominal surgery and with that there could be complications as well as a longer and more painful recovery time.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
The Myth: If you’re having a C-section, you don’t need a birth plan.
The Reality:

Every woman deserves to have a say in her delivery experience, and there are many decisions you can still make if you’re having a C-section. For instance, you can let your doctor know you want to have skin-to-skin contact right away, try nursing immediately, or lowering the drape so you can see your baby as soon as he enters the world. If you need help thinking through these options, schedule a Birth Plan appointment to chat with a practitioner on Maven’s platform. Whether you’re having a vaginal or Cesarean birth, planning ahead can help you anticipate your childbirth experience with confidence and, yes, joy.
A Cesarean is major abdominal surgery.

title.en-US: 10 essential questions to ask your doctor after giving birth

content.value: A handy list to bring with you to your six-week postpartum checkup.

After spending nine months running to doctors' offices, you may not be thrilled about schlepping back to see your OB-GYN. And you might be so focused on your little one that you’re tempted to cancel anything that doesn’t involve tending to him. But your six-week postpartum checkup is one appointment you should definitely keep. Healing after childbirth takes time—and it’s sometimes a bumpy road. Being examined is key to addressing any issues and making sure you’re on the right track to recovery. It’s a good idea to jot down anything you want to ask and bring a list with you to your appointment. (Sleep deprivation is real, and you might not remember everything that’s on your mind.) To get you started, here are 10 essential questions all women should ask their doctors after having a baby.
How long should I wait before having sex again?
Is it OK to start exercising again?
Are there foods I shouldn’t eat while breastfeeding? And what’s the best postpartum diet for me?
Are any over-the-counter medications off limits? What about the prescription drugs I stopped taking during pregnancy?
What can I do about my postpartum discomforts/pains (constipation, hemorrhoids, back aches, sore nipples, etc.)?
Can we discuss any medical conditions that arose during pregnancy (i.e. gestational diabetes) and what my next steps should be?
Can we discuss the best birth control options for me?
Does my emotional state seem normal to you? I’d like to be screened for postpartum depression/anxiety.
How is my healing going down there, and do I need to see a pelvic floor specialist or physical therapist?
Do I need any vaccines that weren’t safe for me to take during pregnancy (i.e. Chickenpox, Measles-mumps-rubella, Shingles)?

PS: Remember, this isn’t your only chance to ask questions. If you have concerns before or after your six-week checkup, give your doctor a ring, or book an appointment with a Maven provider. You deserve some special care right now, mom.

title.en-US: What causes heartburn during pregnancy & how to prevent it

content.value: Morning sickness. Backaches. Fatigue. Oh, the many joys of pregnancy. But there’s another common symptom that you might not have been prepared for: heartburn. So why does it happen, and what you can do to extinguish the fire?

Quick science lesson: There’s a muscle at the bottom of your esophagus called the esophageal sphincter. This is essentially a seal that keeps stomach contents in their place. But when you’re pregnant, your growing baby can put extra pressure on your stomach and cause the lower esophageal sphincter to relax or leak. Pregnancy hormones can exacerbate symptoms because rising levels of progesterone and relaxin also contribute to a weakening of the esophageal sphincter—increasing the likelihood that stomach contents flow back up into your esophagus. Luckily, there a few things you can do to avoid the burn.
Steer clear of your trigger foods.

According to the National Institutes of Health, certain foods make things worse by carrying additional acid into the stomach and up into the esophagus. Acidic foods are common culprits, so you may need to avoid citrus fruits (oranges, lemons, grapefruits), as well as tomatoes. Sadly, that tomato-based pizza sauce counts. Other bad-guys associated with heartburn include chocolate (sigh), as well as anything spicy, fried, or high in fat. As for beverages, caffeine and carbonated beverages may be out until baby arrives. Keeping a food journal can help determine which foods cause you the most discomfort.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Eat smaller portions.

Big meals of any kind can trigger heartburn since being extra full can put pressure on your stomach and loosen the esophageal seal.
