If heartburn is a problem, try having six mini-meals instead of three supersized ones. The simple reason: Smaller portions are easier for your body to digest. And if it’s too late and you caved and had a big pasta dinner (hey, it happens), talk to your doctor or a Maven practitioner about what OTC medications you can safely take for relief; she may recommend an OTC like Tums or Zantac.
Sleep in the right position.

Sleeping on an incline allows gravity to keep your stomach’s contents in place. Regular pillows don’t do the job, since they only raise your head. Instead, look for a wedge-shaped pillow that props up your entire upper body. While researchers don’t know the exact reason, studies have found that sleeping on your left side instead of the right can also calm nighttime heartburn. Note to self: Right is wrong.

Have more questions about how to calm heartburn during pregnancy, and which over-the-counter remedies might be safe? Book an appointment here to video chat with an OB-GYN or a nurse practitioner in Maven’s network.
Big meals of any kind can trigger heartburn.

title.en-US: How to avoid the mistake 93% of new parents make

content.value: One of the most nerve-wracking things about leaving the hospital with your newborn is anticipating the drive home. A car seat is designed to protect that fragile little passenger and put your mind at ease as you hit the road. According to the CDC, when collisions happen, car seats reduce the risk of infant death by 71%. But all too often, parents use car seats incorrectly. Researchers at Oregon Health & Science University did a hands-on study observing both the installation and how parents positioned their babies inside a car seat. The alarming finding? 93% of parents made what the study authors call a “critical error.” In a worst-case scenario where a collision might occur on the way home, babies would be at serious risk for a crash-related injury. While this sounds scary, there are a few simple things you can do to make sure your little one travels safely from day one.
Break out the box before the big day.

When you’re getting ready to leave the hospital, you’re understandably eager to get home and more than a little woozy and exhausted. So this isn’t an ideal time to take the car seat out of the trunk and attempt to read the fine print on the user’s manual. Your best is to give yourself a primer in advance. Sad but true: Sometimes, a car seat will be incompatible with your car. A trial run will help you avoid any day-of drama.
Be a type-A car seat person.

There are some things new parents can stand to relax about, but in this case, there’s no room for cutting corners. Interestingly, many parents don’t strap their baby in tight enough out of fear that a newborn is too fragile. But in reality, an ill-fitting harness is a much bigger safety concern. According to the Mayo Clinic, you should buckle the harness straps and chest clip, with the chest clip even with your baby’s armpits. The straps and clip should be flat against your infant’s chest and over his hips with no slack. And wiggly seats are another common no-no—if a tug causes the seat to move more than an inch from side to side or towards the front of the car, it’s too loose.
Register your car seat.

You might not have thought about registering your car seat after you bought it, but experts say it’s a smart idea. Unfortunately, safety recalls do happen—for instance, when there’s a faulty buckle—and unless you’ve registered the product with the manufacturer, you may not get the heads up you need to get the (usually free) repair or replacement.
Consult a pro.

Even if you think you or your partner have done an ace job at installing the car seat, it doesn’t hurt to get a pro’s evaluation before your delivery day. You’ll want to find a car seat technician in your area who’s been certified by
The National Child Passenger Safety Certification Training Program (CPS)
. (P.S. This service is usually totally free.) There are a number of ways to do this, including visiting the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration’s website or
The National CPS Certification Program's database

title.en-US: How to work with negative people during pregnancy

content.value: You may, of course, encounter Negative Nancies in the workplace whether you’re pregnant or not. But if expecting a baby has heightened your emotions or stress levels, dealing with a downer type on the job can be especially tough. So what can you do, besides living in a constant state of side eye? Read on for useful tips and tricks.
Find a way to tap into your calm.

Chances are, you’re not going to be able to do anything about this person’s behavior (unless it’s so egregious that it warrants a call to HR). But what you do have control over is your own response. In the moments when you get particularly triggered, taking a few mindful breaths can help you get out of reactive mode. It’s also a way to reorient your attention back to yourself and remember that you alone are in charge of your emotions.
Tell yourself, “This isn't about me. It's about them."

When you’re around negative people, it’s easy to take things personally. If you detect some hostility when you announce your pregnancy, for instance, you may think your colleague doesn’t like you. But more often than not, other people’s reactions have nothing to do with you. Stopping to remind yourself of this fact can help you keep your cool and avoid confrontation, which could exacerbate the situation.
Do a self-check.

While you might not be causing the problem, it’s still important to be honest with yourself about your own attitude. Are you bringing good vibes to the office, or could your attitude/behavior be causing others to bristle? If everywhere you’ve ever worked there’s someone you hate, it could be a sign to look at your side of the street to see if anything needs cleaning up.
Seek out the smiles, not the smirks.

Interestingly, research shows we all have a negativity bias. While we appreciate positivity, we give much greater weight to negativity. What this means is that it takes conscious effort to train your brain to become more attuned to the good energies in the workplace, instead of becoming a magnet for the bad. Add this to your to-do list. The next time you’re in a big meeting with a person who seems to have a scowl on her face every time you speak, look for at least two people who are smiling. Then, notice how much better you feel.

title.en-US: Moms reveal: “What I wish I had in my birth plan”

content.value: Every woman’s wishes for giving birth are different—the important thing is to make sure you and your providers are on the same page. That’s where a birth plan comes in—writing one out and discussing it with your doctor is key to a regret-free delivery. Use these insights from four moms who share what they would have done differently to get in the “WWID” (What would I do?) frame of mind. Then book an appointment with a Maven provider to customize your own birth plan.
“I wish I had a plan for how I wanted to birth my placenta, not just my baby.”

“Once my baby arrived—after several hours of pushing—I thought my job was done. I was deliriously tired, and wasn’t prepared to answer my midwife’s question when she asked me how I wanted to deliver the placenta. I had two options: a natural approach, where your body does the job on its own, or a managed approach, where a shot is administered to the thigh, helping the body contract and push out the placenta. I went for the shot (Pitocin)—and I’m glad I did—but I wish I had thought through this part of my birth plan in advance. The worst feeling is wondering if you’re making the “right” decision or not, and knowing what my options were in advance would have helped put my mind at ease.”—Alice M.
“I wish I had a plan for pain management.”

"One thing I really wish I'd included in my birth plan: my preference for pain medication. This would have pushed me to talk to my doctor about all of my options for pain relief before being in the delivery room. When you're in the throes of labor, it's hard to ask questions like, "What, exactly, is pitocin?" or "Are there any alternatives to an epidural?"—Sam B.
“I wish I had a plan for an unexpected C-section.”

"I was expecting to have a vaginal birth, and everything was going as planned—or at least I thought. After 10 hours of labor, my doctor said, ‘I think it’s time for a Caesarean.’ I had never thought through this possibility, so I had to wonder: Was my labor truly stalling to the point where I needed a C-section, or were we rushing things? I had the surgery, but I wish I’d been more prepared for this “in-case-of-Caesarean” birth. In retrospect, I would have developed a birth plan that included my preferences in case things didn’t go as planned. I would have discussed things like how I wanted to manage pain during the surgery. Having a birth plan in place that covered this scenario would have helped me cope with the sudden turn of events.”—Samantha M.
“I wish I had a plan for trying different positions.”

“For my first two pregnancies, I didn’t have a plan for trying different positions during labor. By the third time I had a child, I learned that this was an important thing to have in a birth plan. My experience? Laboring upright (standing up) for the first stages of labor feels so much better. And having a doula assist me with using a birth ball (one of those big rubber exercise balls) also made a world of difference. I know it’s different for everyone, but for me being flat on my back was the worst. Now I always tell my pregnant friends to discuss different options with their provider before they’re in the delivery room.”—Rachel

title.en-US: The truth about “pregnancy beard”

content.value: Oh, you thought you were growing a baby, not a beard? Here’s what you need to know about this unexpected pregnancy symptom.
Why does hair growth happen during pregnancy?
Facial hair growth in pregnancy is usually linked to hormonal fluctuations—specifically an increase in hormones pumped out by the ovaries and placenta.
Is it permanent?

Usually not. Any new hair that’s sprouted in unwanted places—not just your face, but also your chest, belly, or back—typically falls out by the six-month postpartum mark. That said, sometimes the hairs that are really deep and coarse (as opposed to peach fuzz) may be a bit more stubborn and stick around. If you don’t start to see an improvement by your baby’s half-birthday, it may be worth seeing an endocrinologist to test you for any hormonal issues that are at play.
Does every woman get hair growth?

Not necessarily. While anyone can get “pregnancy beard,” if you were acne-prone before getting pregnant—an indication of a hormonal imbalance—you may be more likely to deal with unwanted hair growth. And if your mom developed facial hair when she was expecting, you may too, since there could be a hereditary link.
Can you get laser hair removal during pregnancy?

Unfortunately, we don’t have studies to confirm that laser hair removal is safe for the fetus during pregnancy, so most doctors recommend skipping it until after you give birth. Ditto for trying to lighten the hairs—experts say it’s best to avoid bleaching. In other words: A tweezer is officially your new best friend.

title.en-US: How to deal with a moody boss while you’re pregnant

content.value: How to deal with a crabby manager who’s raining on your pregnancy parade.

Just because you’re expecting a baby doesn’t mean everyone around you will get the memo that you could really use a positive work environment right about now. If a moody, short-tempered, or just plain negative boss is starting to drag you down, use this advice to keep your cool.
Don’t over-engage.

Emotional contagion is a real thing, and during pregnancy, it’s especially important to protect your sanity—for the sake of you and your baby. While you obviously can’t avoid your boss 100% of the time, try to limit your interactions if you notice their bad mood is starting to get to you. If you’re used to running into her office whenever you have a question, for instance, see if there’s another colleague or manager who can provide the guidance you need.
Keep it light.

The worst thing you can do is meet her moodiness with more moodiness. Instead of joining your boss in Long Face Syndrome, try to stay upbeat, joyful, and calm. And look for ways to interact with other colleagues who tend to bring good vibes into the workplace—their positive energy may override your boss’s moody factor.
Know your audience.

Confronting your boss to say, “I feel like you’re really angry at me lately,” probably isn’t a great tactic. If her anger is truly heightened at that moment, you could make yourself the target of her bad mood. If her bad moods are chronic and they’re really affecting you, you don’t have to stay silent, but choose your audience. Start by confiding in a trusted colleague or supervisor, and share in confidence that you’re struggling and could use some advice about how—and when—to confront your boss. Just resist the urge to complain to everyone in the office; this can easily backfire if word gets out.

title.en-US: Embarrassing things can happen during birth - and that's OK!

content.value: Yes, you might poop and no, you won’t care.

When you talk to women about their emotions leading up to their delivery day, fear of embarrassment comes up more often than you’d think. The worry: What if something really awkward happens during labor?

Some of this stems from depictions of childbirth they see on TV—like women who are horrible to be around, yelling obscenities to their partners and nurses. Then, of course, there’s the fear that something “gross” will happen—like pooping on the delivery table.

Unfortunately, we can’t assure you that your poop nightmares won’t become a reality—it definitely happens—or that you won’t start cursing when the pain gets intense. But here’s the thing about what might come out of you (whether it’s words or bodily functions) during labor: First, doctors and nurses have literally seen it all before, and nothing phases them. Their job is to help you bring a baby into the world, whatever it takes. And when the intensity of labor sets in, you’re not likely to care about anything else either. If relatives will be in the delivery room with you, you can ask them to stay north of your waist if it will help you feel less embarrassed. Or just file this under things that don’t matter in the long run.

title.en-US: How to create a morning routine for after maternity leave

content.value: Mornings before baby vs. mornings after baby are as different as, well, night and day. So if your A.M. routine is undergoing a big—and bumpy—transition, you’re not alone. But once you have figured out how to go from “time to wake up” to “butt parked in my office chair” with minimal chaos, your entire day will run that much more smoothly. To ease the new-mom morning mayhem, use these tricks:
Set timers

If you’re pressed for time and spend 30 minutes picking out an outfit, everything’s thrown off. Set alarms on your phone to alert you when to move on to the next morning task. You can break this down with a lot of specificity. For instance: 7am: Feed baby. 7:30am put on clothes. Whatever your to-dos are, hearing a bell go off will help you get ahead of the ticking clock and get you out the door faster and less frazzled.
Do as much as you can the night before

Whether it’s writing reminder notes for the nanny, packing the diaper bag for daycare, or cleaning your breast pump parts to take with you to the office, try to get in the habit of doing as much as possible the night before. This one trick can buy you a ton of extra time the next morning.
Wake up an hour before your baby does

The idea is to have time to get yourself ready before it’s time to tend to your little one. Give yourself 45-60 minutes of child-free time to shower, get dressed, read your emails, etc. Then when your baby is up you can focus on feeding/pumping and any last-minute to-dos.
Invest in dry shampoo

We’re only half-kidding here. There will be days when your best laid morning plans will go out the window. (Kid has a diaper explosion after you get him ready for daycare, and all of a sudden you’re back to square one.) Employ ways to cut your getting-ready time in case of poop-mergencies and other unforeseen events. Dry shampoo; a go-to outfit you don’t have to think about; whatever.

title.en-US: Depression after a miscarriage

content.value: Miscarriage brings on a sudden change in your life, and often times it's hard to cope with. You may wonder if your emotions are “normal,” or how long it will be till you feel like yourself again. Here are 6 things to remember as you navigate this challenging time.
There’s no one-size-fits-all response

The truth is, there isn’t a blueprint for the emotional aftermath of a miscarriage. They’re an all too common experience—occurring in about 10 to 20% of known pregnancies according to the Mayo Clinic—but every situation is unique, and some women have an easier time moving on than others. Sometimes the mourning period feels just like the grief you experience when a loved one dies—you may be depressed, anxious, irritable, and angry. Whatever your response to the loss, honor it.
Healing takes time—sometimes more time than you’d expect

You may be asking yourself, “How long will this last?”. Well, the distress may lift quickly, sometimes in less than a month. But it isn’t uncommon for feelings to stick around. Some women experience depression and anxiety for several years after a miscarriage—even if they’ve gotten pregnant again and given birth to a healthy child. So if it feels like the sadness is lingering, know that you’re not alone.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Seek professional help

Some women go through a form of postpartum depression when they have a miscarriage; the only difference is there’s no baby at home. Opening up to your doctor is a good first step to figure out if you have what’s classified as clinical depression. Maven’s network includes OB-GYNs as well as therapists who specialize in pregnancy loss. They can talk with you about things you can do to feel more like yourself, including counseling. Book an appointment to speak with a practitioner over a video call or text message.
Tell your friends what you need

Fact: Often, people want to give you support, but they try not to bring up your miscarriage out of fear that they’ll upset you. If you wish your inner circle would acknowledge what happened and help share your grief, be direct. Once they know that listening and checking in with you is the most comforting thing they can do, you might be surprised by how they show up.
That said, it’s OK to make choices about who you spend time with

Hard truth: Not every person in your life is going to be able to comfort you when you’re going through a rough time. If certain interactions with friends or relatives leave you feeling worse, not better, it’s OK to take a step back from those relationships while you focus on your own healing.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Know your triggers

Unfortunately, we can’t go through life censoring ourselves from everything that may bring up the painful reminder that we’ve experienced a loss. Seeing babies, preggo friends, or even ads for diapers can stir up emotions. Know that it’s normal to experience waves of more intense sadness, and have a plan to reach out for extra support during these times. And if you need to take a pass on attending a baby shower or a first birthday party, give yourself that permission.
Sources: Maven Practitioner Network, Mayo Clinic; The British Journal of Psychiatry
If it feels like the sadness is lingering, know that you’re not alone.
If you need to take a pass on attending a baby shower or a first birthday party, give yourself that permission.

title.en-US: Maven real talk on IVF with Christine

content.value: 33 years old
Administrative Assistant
New Jersey
Why did you decide to start IVF? And how old were you when you went through your first cycle?

My partner and I had been trying to conceive on our own for about four years (since 2011) with the help of my OB. Then, in February of 2015, we saw a fertility specialist who had us try five rounds of intrauterine insemination (IUI). When that didn’t work, they told it was time to try another method. I started IVF in October 2015; was 31 at the time.
Did doctors diagnose the exact reason you couldn’t become pregnant, or did you have “unexplained infertility” (when no obvious cause of infertility can be identified)?

My partner and I both had every test possible. This involved a full spectrum of labs, genetic tests, scans, an HSG test (a.k.a. a hysterosalpingogram, to see whether my fallopian tubes were blocked), and recurrent miscarriage panels including a workup to test for antiphospholipid syndrome, a disorder which can affect fertility. Everything came back normal, so we were diagnosed as having unexplained infertility.
Had you ever been pregnant before, at the time you started IVF?
No.
How many times have you done IVF?
How did you choose your clinic?
We opted for Penn Fertility since it's a large academic hospital with a multi-disciplinary group.
What surprised you most about the procedure?
That the daily injections became "normal.” Before starting IVF, I had always had a bad fear of needles and would pass out for simple lab draws.
What could have made your patient experience better?

I wish I had been better prepared for transitioning from my infertility team to the OB/GYN team. During my miscarriages, the clinical staff told me that I would be switched off to the O.B. team for care instead of continuing to work with my regular IVF nurse who had been with us through everything. This wasn’t easy, and I wish I knew it was going to be happening ahead of time.
What was the most difficult part of your IVF experience?

Going through multiple miscarriages while others around me continued to get pregnant even though they "didn't want to” was very difficult. It was doubly hard because I had high hopes when the embryos we transferred were identified as “normal” according to preimplantation tests that check for chromosomal abnormalities.
Any tips for managing the emotional stress of IVF?

Make sure you have someone that you could be completely open with throughout the entire process—whether that's your partner or a family member/friend. Try not to make the "big" decisions in the midst of being really upset (like when you receive bad news from the IVF team). Instead, whenever possible, wait a couple of days before determining your next steps. You might have a different perspective.
Any tips for managing the stress that IVF can put on a relationship?

My husband was amazing, and we opted not to tell anyone else what we had been going through for years. It was difficult at times being somewhat "isolated,” but it also strengthened our relationship since we felt like we were battling this together as a team. It also helped to take a day trip or spend a weekend away a couple of times throughout the two-year process just to get our minds off things in between IVF cycles.
Did your insurance cover IVF? If not, how much did it cost each time you did it?

The first year, the insurance we had did not cover anything. It was $5,000 for the cycle itself, plus the medications which were another few thousand dollars. The second year, we had a different insurance which partially covered up to three cycles after our deductible was met. Medications were not covered at all through our prescriptions benefits. In the end, IVF cost us about $20,000 total.
If IVF was successful, how quickly did you get pregnant?
I got pregnant with the second and third cycle, but both of those pregnancies ended in miscarriage. The live-birth pregnancy occurred on the 4th cycle.
Do you have any plans to do IVF again?
We have three embryos left, which we may or may not to have a baby with. We are not planning to do any full IVF cycles again—we would only consider a frozen embryo transfer of a single embryo.
If your best friend was about to go through IVF, what would you want her to know?

That I'm here for her; that women/families go through it all the time, but it doesn't make it any easier; that she'll learn more about obstetrics and hormone levels than she could possibly imagine; that the emotional pain hurts more than the physical; that it's OK to stop or pause along the way if she needs time to recover and heal.

title.en-US: Does pregnancy really make you more forgetful?

content.value: You may have heard of “pregnancy brain” or “mom-nesia”—but is the phenomenon real or simply a myth?
It turns out, there may be something going on in the minds of pregnant women that cause you to lose focus or forget where you put that... wait, what were you even looking for, exactly?

A 2018 study published in the Medical Journal of Australia explored how pregnancy may affect cognitive function, and also looked at how these changes take shape depending on which trimester you’re in. What the research found: Pregnant women performed worse on tasks measuring memory and executive functioning (such as decision-making and planning), and this change tended to be heightened during the third trimester. (The study found very insignificant changes early in pregnancy.)

That said, it’s important to note that there wasn’t a severe drop-off in cognitive ability, even in the last trimester of pregnancy. Everyone still functioned within a normal range. Think of it as baby brain “light.”

Interestingly, an older study in The British Journal of Psychiatry found that pregnancy made women think they were more forgetful during pregnancy because they had been primed to worry about memory loss. But the researchers who carried out that study found no significant differences in cognitive function, except for this: Late pregnancy was associated with changes on one of four tests that looked at memory and cognition.
Bottom line:

Maybe you’ll feel a bit less sharp as your pregnancy comes to an end, or require a little more mental effort to do everyday tasks. But “baby brain” isn’t likely to have a dramatic impact on your daily life. You’re still a competent, capable (albeit very tired) human. Given how tough it is to get sleep, and all the increased stress levels many expectant woman experience, cut yourself some slack if you walk into a market and can’t remember if you needed batteries or breakfast foods.

title.en-US: 5 rules for bottle-feeding your baby

content.value: If you and your partner have decided to introduce bottle-feeding, you’re about to play an important role in Operation Raise-A-Human. If mom has been breastfeeding until now, she gets to experience a few hours of the day without a tiny person hanging from her nipple. But besides giving her a much-needed break, you get to experience the special closeness that comes with feeding your child.
That said, like may baby-related matters, bottle-feeding isn’t always straightforward, and can come with a hefty learning curve for many parents. Here are a few tips to make it easier.
Find the right gear

Don’t be alarmed if it takes some trial and error to find a bottle your child doesn’t reject. Get some recommendations from friends, do some research, and consult your budget. Keep in mind, not all baby bottles are created—or priced—equally. It’s fine to start with a basic, inexpensive option. But if you’ve got a picky eater (er, nippler) on your hands, you may need to splurge on something fancier, like a bottle that is designed to mimic the look and feel of a breast.
Be a temp master

It would be nice if you could just nuke the bottle in the microwave, but that method doesn’t distribute the heat evenly so it can create hot-spots that could burn your baby’s mouth. Your options? You can warm up the bottles the old-fashioned way: Heat water on the stovetop, remove it, then plonk the bottle in until the milk is room temp. (A few drops on the inside of your wrist will tell you if it’s still too hot.) Or you can invest in a bottle warmer—which can be useful in the middle of the night when the last thing you want to do is wait for the water to boil on the stove. These gadgets make it a no-brainer: Put milk in the bottle, the bottle in warmer, and wait for the beep.
Don’t go by the clock
Unfortunately, you can’t set your alarm to go off at baby-feeding time—there’s no set time-table for when and how often to feed a baby. Babies’ feeding system is what you might call “on demand.”
Learn to spot hunger cues

Sadly, when hunger strikes, your baby can’t tell you to pass the bottle. But he will give you other cues. For instance, he may start opening his mouth, turning his head to the side with an open mouth as if trying to "root" to a nipple, or smacking his lips. He may also begin to get more squirmy and discontent. And if you miss these signs altogether, don’t worry: You can expect some wailing to really clue you in.
Don’t be a food pusher

It can be a good idea to check in with your pediatrician about how much milk you should aim feed your baby. One very rough guideline is to multiply your baby’s weight by 2.5. So if your baby weighs 10 pounds, he might drink 25 ounces of milk per day—usually in 3 to 4 ounce servings. But keep in mind that any suggestions are really just a ballpark figure. Ultimately, babies will only take as much milk as they’re hungry for.

This article is not intended to be a substitute for medical advice or care. Please consult a doctor with any questions you have before taking actions around your health and wellbeing. As always, our Maven practitioners are available, on-demand, to address your concerns. Book an appointment
here

title.en-US: 3 things you need to know about traveling while pregnant

content.value: Whether it’s a babymoon or a work trip, you might be thinking about operation get-out-of-town. The good news: For most women, it’s perfectly safe to fly during pregnancy, even in the third trimester. So what’s the cut-off point, and how can you make a flight more comfortable when you’re expecting? Read on for all the answers. Bon voyage!
The size of your bump matters.

“Most airlines don’t let pregnant woman on board after 36 weeks—which is a good idea,” says Dr. Jackie Stone, a Florida-based OB-GYN and practitioner in Maven’s network. “You don’t want to give birth in the air!”
If a patient is having twins, Stone recommends that they not fly after 28–32 weeks. Triplets? Your “no-fly zone” (a.k.a. the cut-off point for air travel) suggested by your doctor will likely be earlier.
The rules are different for high-risk pregnancies.

If you have any kind of pregnancy complications, definitely check with your doctor before you line up for that boarding pass. Most women with a high-risk pregnancy will be cautioned against air travel much earlier, says Stone. This includes women with gestational diabetes that's uncontrolled, preeclampsia (a.k.a. pregnancy hypertension), placental abnormalities, a short cervix, and anyone who is at risk for pre-term labor.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Pregnancy travel requires a little bit of extra planning.

If you’re given the OK to fly, be sure to stay hydrated, and get up to stretch and move around regularly. The risk of deep vein thrombosis—a blood clot in a deep vein of the leg—is higher when you’re sitting for long periods of time. Expert tip: Wearing compression stockings can also help prevent clots. Another travel suggestion from Stone? “I always recommend bringing a copy of your prenatal records with you in case you need to seek care while you’re away, or you do happen to deliver early.” While a newborn is one “travel souvenir” you’d never think you’re going to bring home from a trip, surprises do happen.
Have more questions about staying healthy while traveling? Book an appointment
here
and chat with a practitioner in Maven’s network.
If you’re given the OK to fly, be sure to stay hydrated.

title.en-US: How to manage the stress of being a new parent

content.value: Answer from Mental Health Specialist Mercedes Samudio, LCSW, MSW

Things can get pretty overwhelming right after having a baby. Your body, lifestyle, emotions, and even your relationships with others go through many changes. But here are a few tips to help make this stressful time a bit more manageable:
Be gentle with yourself.

You're going through a lot of shifts that may make you feel like you're spiraling out of control. You may have the desire to quickly rush through this transition, and even beat yourself up for not getting through it fast enough. As much as you can, try not to fight the storm—just let it pass. Some of the changes will sort themselves out as you heal, some will require more rest and quiet time, and others will become your new normal. Be gentle with yourself as you adjust.
Build a supportive tribe.

When you can't be gentle with yourself, you’ll need this group of people to remind you that you're only human. Your tribe may include relatives and friends who are parents, but it can also involve others like your OB, parenting groups, friends without kids to provide some relief. Whoever you add to your trusted crew, be sure that they respect you and your parenting choices, and that they can offer support when asked instead of overwhelming you with what they think you need.
Get help.

A lot seems to be made of being a super parent and doing it all on your own. But when you're learning about your baby's needs and adjusting to your new identity as a parent, it's okay to get help with everything that still needs to get done. Hiring a maid, a sitter, or asking for help with daily tasks doesn't make you a bad parent. Beyond the practical stuff, you’re allowed to need emotional support, too, and may benefit from talking to a Maven therapist or a counselor near your home.
Give yourself time to get to know your child.

This is a lifetime relationship between you and your little one, and you both deserve time to get to know each other. While others will be eager to meet the newest member of your family, be sure to carve out time for you (and your partner) to have alone time with your child so that you can begin to build a healthy foundation for what is sure to be a wild ride together.

title.en-US: Can pregnancy alter your food preferences for good?

content.value: Answer from Nutritionist and Lactation Consultant Melissa Flynn, IBCLC, MPH, RD

During pregnancy, women often eat more nutritiously than they do at any other stage of life. It is highly motivating to have your food choices be tied so closely to your baby’s growth and development. The recommendation is that women limit caffeine, avoid alcohol, eat more fruits and vegetables, and consume a well-balanced diet. It is said that it takes 28 days to create a new habit. Pregnancy affords a much longer length of time to hone these new, healthy eating skills and create habits, which can lead to healthier diets after delivery.

As for cravings and food aversions that may pop up doing pregnancy? They usually don’t last; food aversions such as meat, fish, raw vegetables, and coffee often disappear after delivery. Same goes for cravings—like pickles on everything. We're not sure why exactly these set in, but they seem to be exclusive to the nine months of pregnancy.

title.en-US: Salad dressings you shouldn’t eat during pregnancy

content.value: A salad seems like a fail-proof healthy choice during pregnancy. After all, piling on the greens and medley of veggies is a great way to fuel your body with important nutrients that are good for you and your growing baby. But what you put on top can make or break a healthy meal. Read on for three dressings to always avoid.
Blue cheese dressing

Soft cheese is off the buffet table when you’re pregnant, and so is dressing made with it. The concern is that soft cheese may contain listeria—a bacteria that gets killed during the pasteurization process of a hard cheese.
Caesar dressing

Before you order a Caesar salad at a restaurant, ask if the dressing contains raw egg. If so, skip it. Raw eggs can be tainted with salmonella, and contracting the infection can spell misery for a mom to be. Salmonella can cause fever along with vomiting and diarrhea—which up your risk for dehydration.
Creamy dressings

The concern here usually isn’t bacteria—it’s the amount of fat hiding in creamy dressings like French and Ranch. If you’re going to use it, stick with a one or two-tablespoon serving to keep calories in check and maintain a healthy weight during pregnancy.

title.en-US: Maven real talk on C-sections with Garen

content.value: 30 years old
Stay-at-home mom
Rigby, Idaho
What happened during your labor/delivery that you weren’t expecting?
I had to have an emergency C-Section because my baby was wrapped by the umbilical cord.
How did you cope?

The truth is, I was scared for my life and my baby’s life when I was told I would be having an emergency C-section. I prayed it would all be fine, and held my husband’s hand through it. Ultimately what helped me cope was the fact that I had faith in my doctor.
What was your recovery like and are you recovered 100% today?

After the surgery, I made myself get up and move around even when I didn’t want to (with C-sections, the sooner that you can get up and move around, the faster healing will occur). It did help me with the recovery from my C-section, but there were other complications I dealt with after giving birth, like a diagnosis with joint hypermobility disorder.
How did it affect your relationship and/or sex life?
Majorly. My libido was lower because I was depressed after going through what I did, plus I hurt too much to be the wild, fun woman I once was. I wasn’t who my partner was used to.
Was there any other fallout?
Yes. The weight I gained while going through this experience led to me having fertility issues.
Any wisdom or advice to share, based on your experience?
You just never know what can happen during labor and delivery, so make sure you have a doctor you really trust. I really believe mine saved my own life and my baby’s.

title.en-US: What’s up with the nesting instinct during pregnancy?

content.value: Even if you’re not exactly the domestic type, there may come a time during your pregnancy when nothing is more enticing than organizing your closets, meticulously folding onesies, and organizing your little one’s socks by color. Welcome to the “nesting” phase.
When is nesting most likely to occur?

It can happen at any time, but researchers at McMaster University in Hamilton, Canada say that the nesting instinct peaks in the third trimester. Interestingly, their study also found that nesting is more likely to be characterized by organizing and sorting rather than cleaning and disinfecting.
Why do pregnant women nest?

It could be your evolutionary biology telling you now isn’t a great time to stray too far from home. After all, a baby is on the way, and preparing the house seems a lot more prudent than, well, anything else. You may also be seeking some coziness and the comfort of familiar people (like your closest friends and family) to ground yourself before entering a vulnerable time as a new mom.
So it’s nothing to worry about?

No. Enjoy this time, and give yourself permission to channel your inner Martha Stewart to your heart’s content. Just exercise caution if you get the urge to rearrange (and rearrange again) any furniture in the nursery. Now would be a good time to invite your partner into your “nest” and offload any heavy lifting.

title.en-US: What’s considered “normal” weight gain for a baby?

content.value: The truth about what to look for on those tiny scales.

First, all babies are unique. They may go through different phases of chowing down (or, rather, slurping down) less or more food, and have different growth spurts. So if your pediatrician thinks your baby is on a healthy track, that’s your normal. However, it can be helpful to know averages.

Infants may lose 5-10% of their birth weight in the first few days, but regain it by 10-14 days of life. After that, they usually gain 5-7 ounces per week in the first 3-6 months, and 3-5 ounces per week in months 6-12. Most infants double their birth weight by 4 months of age and triple their birth weight by one year. Breastfed infants usually grow faster to month 3, and then slower after that.

If the scale is moving in the right direction and your baby is gaining weight, don’t worry if your little one doesn’t seem hungry as often as she did as a newborn. Remember, baby’s tummies grow and can hold more milk—plus they’re sleeping for longer stretches at night.
If you’re concerned that your baby isn’t eating enough or isn’t gaining weight, talk to your pediatrician or book an appointment with a Maven practitioner.

title.en-US: How can working moms make breastfeeding less stressful?

content.value: Answer from Midwife, Danika Severino Wynn, CNM, IBCLC

I always advise making a plan with your employer prior to returning to work to ensure you have clear communication about you needs for pumping—including adequate breaks, and a private location where you can be comfortable. If it’s a possibility given your position, you could consider asking your boss for a flexible schedule. Going part-time in the beginning, or working remotely for part of the day may help you manage your supply as well as your stress level.

If you’re only feeding your child from the breast while on maternity leave, test out your pump about one month before returning to work to get the hang of how it works and make sure the flanges fit your breasts (there are different sizes). A few weeks prior to your return, I also recommend that women start pumping 1-2 times per day after feedings to start building a freezer stash.

title.en-US: 5 things to know about babies & sleep

content.value: If your partner just had a baby, the one thing you probably already know about sleep is that the two of you aren’t getting much of it. But you might not be aware of all your infant’s sleep needs. Here’s a primer:
Babies were born to sleep.

Knowing how much sleep your baby needs can be confusing when your sister's baby gets 19 hours of shuteye a day and your next-door-neighbor's infant gets 15. The truth is, all babies are different, and some may need a little more or less than sleep than others. But newborns typically sleep 16 to 18 hours, in total, per day. By four months, that total sleep time may drop to 12 to 16 hours—think 10 or 11 hours at night (with a feeding or two in the middle of the night), plus a few daytime naps. Yes, there's a reason the expression "sleep like a baby" exists.
Babies aren't born knowing day vs. night.

Put it this way: There was no dimmer setting in the womb, so babies don't exactly associate darkness with sleep-time. You can begin to teach her the difference between daytime and nighttime by keeping the days bright and more stimulating, while making sure evenings are dark and quiet. Even when you're feeding a baby in the middle of the night, do so in a dim room and keep the environment boring (i.e. no Netflix in the background).
Babies have short sleep cycles.

That means if your baby is fussing after about 30 minutes and you think she's going to burst into wakefulness, she could just be getting ready to enter the next sleep cycle. Resist the urge to pick her up, since she'll likely fall back asleep on her own.
Put the nursery naps on hold.

Guidelines from the American Academy of Pediatrics suggest that your baby sleeps in the same room as you and your partner for at least the first six months—but not in your bed. Sleeping in the same room can help reduce the risks of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS). Other must-dos to keep your baby safe: Always put her to sleep on her back, and make sure the crib or bassinet is totally clear—no pillows, toys, stuffed animals, even blankets. As for the baby’s binky? Interestingly, research has found that the use of a pacifier during sleep greatly reduced the chances of a baby suffering from SIDS.
Conking out should happen in the crib, not on you.

If you're waiting for your baby to fall asleep before putting him down in the crib, he may not learn to put himself to sleep without your help, or drift back into snoozeland after waking up in the middle of the night. Once your baby is sufficiently drowsy—but still awake—it's fine to bring him to his crib. And as tired as you will be during these first few months, it’s a good idea to avoid falling asleep with your baby on your chest. There's a serious risk of accidentally suffocating your child if you happen to roll over on the bed or couch.

title.en-US: What are the best breastfeeding positions?

content.value: Nursing is one of those topics that often brings on a feeling of “I have to get this right.” It doesn’t help when everyone around you has an opinion on how to do it—including what position is “best.” The first thing lactation specialists want you to know: There’s too much pressure for women to master this breastfeeding position or that one, but if something isn’t working, it’s OK to ditch it and try a different one.

Just as helpful to note: It isn’t about finding the “one” position that works for you. Alternating is perfectly OK, so feel free to switch things up. The important thing is for you and your baby to be comfortable—and for your child to latch on well so he gets the milk he needs.
Here are four common breastfeeding positions you might want to try—but if they don’t work for you, don’t get discouraged.
Book a video appointment
with a Maven lactation consultant. They’re available on-demand so you can ask questions and get live support anytime you need it.
Cross-cradle position

According to La Leche League International, the cross-cradle position works well for many women during the first few weeks of breastfeeding. To do it, you’ll bring your baby across your body, tummy to tummy. A pillow on your lap can help raise her to your nipple level. (Propping a couple of cushions under your elbows is also useful.) If you are breastfeeding on your left side, support your baby with your right arm and hand while your free hand supports the breast. Your baby’s mouth should be close to your nipple from the start. Then, when she opens her mouth wide, she’s ready to latch. You can place the palm of your hand between her shoulder blades to gently guide her mouth toward your breast.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Football hold

While it can work for any woman, this position can be particularly useful—and less painful—if you’ve had a C-section. In a football hold (also called the clutch hold), you don’t have to place your baby on your belly or up against the incision. To get your baby latched onto your right breast, tuck him under your right arm off to the side (yep—like a football player holds the ball while running), with his feet toward your back. You’ll likely need pillows for support under your arm, so his head is raised to breast level and he can latch.
Laid-back breastfeeding

One position that really helps your baby tap into her natural feeding reflexes is called laid-back breastfeeding. (Bonus: It can be relaxing for you, too.) With pillows supporting you, lean back about 45 degrees while lying on a bed or a couch. Your baby will lie face down on top of you, with her cheek somewhere near your breast. She’ll use her natural senses to locate your breast and bob her head to find your nipple.
Side-lying position

For those middle-of-the-night feedings, your go-to might become the in-bed, side-lying position. Lie on your side with a pillow under your head and one behind your back. Place your baby on his side, facing you. Your baby will nurse from the breast that’s resting on the bed; lean back on the pillow behind you until your nipple is in line with his mouth. When he opens his mouth wide and moves towards your breast, you can gently press the palm of your hand between his shoulder blades to help him latch.
If something isn’t working, it’s OK to ditch it and try a different one.

title.en-US: 4 things to think about when buying maternity clothes

content.value: Read this before you go on an I’m-sporting-a-bump shopping spree.
Check the length.

Boxy, loose blouses may seem like a godsend for pregnant women, but keep in mind: A top that ends right at your waist now may be barely covering your boobs in a couple of months. In no time, your growing baby will make your tops a lot shorter. Slightly-longer silhouettes may help you get more mileage out of your maternity wardrobe.
Remember: Accessories will always fit.

On days when you need a little outfit oomph to up your confidence, accessories will be your BFF. Borrow what you can from friends, but even if you invest in a couple of pieces, at least you’ll feel better knowing that you won’t grow out of bold earrings or a necklace.
Think about how you’ll feel.

There are certain items that end up on everyone’s “essential maternity wear” lists. Take, for instance, wrap-style dresses, which are so popular because they’re the easiest thing to adjust as you expand. But if you know you’ll feel ridiculous or not like yourself while wearing it, it’s OK to break the rules. Feel free to override the “classic” advice and slip on pieces that don’t make you cringe when you wear them.
Reconsider investment purchases.

Fact: Your body may change even faster than you anticipate at the beginning of your pregnancy. It’s OK to splurge if it’s within your budget, but if you’re going to drop serious cash on a dress that will “get you through the next several months,” recognize that your body is TBD (truly baby-decided) and you may be at risk of a wardrobe malfunction sooner than you think.

title.en-US: How to fight fatigue towards the end of pregnancy

content.value: If your exhaustion seems to grow faster than your belly, read this.
It’s one of nature’s insults: Carrying a baby can make you too tired to move, and yet it also takes away your rights to a 24-7 IV drip of caffeine. What’s an exhausted pregnant lady to do?

While you can’t dive head first into a pot of coffee, there are some natural ways to boost your energy in the final months and weeks of pregnancy. First, following a healthy diet and avoiding junk food will help you maintain your pep. To keep your energy up and avoid a crash, reach for a diet high in lean protein, fruits and vegetables and low in processed foods.

And while exercising may seem like it will wipe you out more than anything, a little bit of movement can pay you back by giving you more energy than you had before you started. Exercise also allows you to get a good night's rest—something that can be hard to come by as your pregnancy progresses. And when you get better sleep, you’ll feel more refreshed during the day. If getting on an elliptical feels like climbing Mount Everest, you don’t have to. A short brisk walk or two during the day definitely count.

title.en-US: 3 things no one tells you about post-pregnancy bodies

content.value: Giving birth is life-altering, but it’s also body-altering. And there are a few common changes that first-time moms don’t realize are coming. Read on so you know what to expect—and which items from your closet you might need to replace.
Your baby won’t be the only one who needs a diaper (or at least pads).

If you have a vaginal birth, you’re probably expecting some soreness and a bit of discharge down there after your delivery. But many pregnant women don’t know they may continue to bleed for as long as 6 weeks. According to the Cleveland Clinic, this blood is called lochia. Lochia starts out red in color, like regular menstrual discharge, but will turn more watery and brown or pinkish as time passes. It’s also good to know that the flow might be heavier when you get up in the morning or while you’re breastfeeding. Don’t be alarmed if you see blood clots—they’re normal in the first few postpartum days. That said, if the clotting seems excessive and doesn’t stop, check in with your doctor.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Your shoes may no longer fit.

Having swollen feet during pregnancy doesn’t come as a shock to anyone. But a larger shoe size could be permanent. Research has found that about 60 to 70% of women had longer feet and shorter arches after childbirth. It turns out that the extra weight women carry around during pregnancy could flatten the foot, and the tissues and ligaments in your feet may become looser thanks to the role of pregnancy hormones.
You may look pregnant for longer than you’d think.

Every woman’s body is different, but the post-baby bump is a reality for many moms. “When I still looked six months pregnant even thought I was holding my baby in my arms weeks after giving birth, I thought something was seriously wrong,” one mom confessed to us. After all, isn’t “baby weight” mostly... baby? Not exactly. Before pregnancy, your uterus is about the size of an orange. By the time you give birth, it’s closer to the size of a watermelon. After delivery, your uterus gradually returns to its regular size, but this deflation doesn’t happen overnight. In the meantime, try to remind yourself that your bump is perfectly normal and nothing to be embarrassed about.
60 to 70% of women had longer feet and shorter arches.

title.en-US: Are you a pregnancy cyberchondriac?

content.value: When Googling your symptoms does more harm than good.

These pregnancy symptoms are normal—or, wait, are they really? Within seconds, you’re deep into an Internet hunt for health info and declaring yourself doomed with every scary diagnosis you can find. Whether you call it hypochondria or cyberchondria, there’s good reason to back away from Google.

Research has found that many people who search for answers about their health on the Internet end up more anxious than they were before. It turns out that the plethora of advice online, some of it from questionable sources, can be more disturbing than info you’d get directly from a doctor. Sure, while a certain amount of anxiety can motivate you to seek answers from your OB-GYN or midwife, too much isn’t good for you.
The lesson:

Don't ignore your symptoms, but don't jump to the worst possible (and often very unlikely) conclusion. Bringing your concerns to your doctor or a Maven provider has a major advantage over a down-the-rabbit-hole Internet search: Medical professionals are trained to look at your symptoms holistically, and consider factors that you may not be thinking about when you’re playing Dr. Google.

title.en-US: 3 things to do during your lunch breaks during pregnancy

content.value: Because time is doubly precious when you’re expecting.
Squeeze in doctor’s appointments.

When you start to realize just how many doctors appointments you’ll be having during pregnancy, you’ll learn the importance of scheduling them wisely. If your OB-GYN is close to your office, plan for them during your lunch breaks when possible, and take some busy work you can do in the waiting room if your doctor is running late. For all those issues that don’t require an in-person visit, like when you have general pregnancy-related questions you need answered, book an appointment with a Maven provider and chat with them in a conference room.
Take a nap.

The first 12 weeks of pregnancy might as well be called the Zombie Trimester, considering how much fatigue women feel during this time. If exhaustion is making it challenging to keep your eyes open at work, don’t underestimate the effects of a power-nap. Some offices have nurses rooms or dedicated nap rooms where you might be able to take a short snooze. If that’s an option, or you can find another safe space to rest your eyes for 15 or 20 minutes, go for it.
Go on a digital binge.

Research has found that “constant checkers” – people who check their emails, texts, and social media constantly– experience more stress than those who don’t. Since taking care of your emotional health is crucial during pregnancy, it’s a good idea to consider becoming a “lunchtime checker” instead. Use this dedicate timed read your personal emails, scroll through Instagram, etc.

title.en-US: What to know about your partner’s pregnancy waddle

content.value: Real question from a Maven user: “I know better than to make a comment about a pregnant woman’s body, but what’s up with my wife’s waddle?” First: Smart to do your own research! Keep reading for the answers you need.
Q: Is it normal for women to waddle when they’re expecting?

A: Yes, in fact this is so common that “pregnancy waddle” is a real term. Research actually looked into the reason why many women walk and move differently when they’re pregnant. In fact, an expectant mom’s movements begin to change as early as the first trimester, because her “center of mass” is further forward. That’s why you may notice your partner leaning back more when she’s standing and bending her hips less while walking.
Q: Is waddling a health risk?
A: Generally, no. But pregnant women should definitely use caution—one study found that they experience falls at the same rate as 70-year-old women.
Q: What if my partner does fall during pregnancy?

A: That can be scary—both for the mom and her partner. But a woman’s body is actually built to keep her developing baby safe when she’s pregnant. Take the uterine walls, for instance. They’re strong muscles that help protect the baby. And that amniotic fluid? It serves as a cushion to add even more protection. That said, if a fall is serious and you’re even a little bit concerned about the health of your partner and the baby, definitely see your provider who can do an exam to make sure everything is OK. And always get medical attention right away if your partner’s fall was painful, if she bled, or if there was a direct blow to the abdomen.

title.en-US: Breakfast foods that fight problems during pregnancy

content.value: Sometimes you can't do much to avoid common symptoms that creep up when you’re expecting. Luckily, some foods and drinks may offer some relief from the misery. Read on for delicious A.M. cures, because starting the day off with a symptom-fighting breakfast is just what the doctor ordered.
The problem: Constipation
What to eat: Oatmeal

Being backed up is pretty high up there on the (most uncomfortable pregnancy symptoms). One way to get things, um, moving? Fiber. For a breakfast that really packs a punch, go for a bowl of oatmeal with berries. “Just make sure you’re going for plain or steel-cut oats—not the sugar-packed varieties kids love,” says Jackie Stone M.D., a Maven OB-GYN. Oats contain two types of fiber—the soluble and insoluble kind. Together, the two types of fiber soften and add bulk to stool, making it easier to pass through the intestines. (Sorry, we know this isn’t the most glamourous subject, but you may thank us later.) Topping off your breakfast bowl with berries helps bathroom matters even more. Raspberries, for example, pack a whopping 8 grams of fiber per cup.
The problem: Heartburn
What to drink: A banana almond milk smoothie

Pregnancy comes with a surge in progesterone, a hormone that can play a role in heartburn, making this another common symptom when you’re expecting. So what can you eat—or drink—for relief? Reach for almond milk; this dairy alternative is alkaline, which means it can help neutralize acidity that contributes to heartburn. And many people also find that bananas ease the burn. (Do a self-test to see if you feel better or worse after eating one, but keep in mind that you should reach for bananas that are ripe—they’re less acidic.) Make this your go-to heartburn-fighting smoothie: Toss a large banana and a cup and a half of almond milk into a blender with ice and (optional) a drizzle of honey.
The problem: Fatigue
What to eat: A veggie omelet

If you’re not getting enough iron, you may feel like you’re sleepwalking through your pregnancy. The recommended daily intake of iron for women jumps from 18 mg to 27 mg if you’re pregnant. And since you can’t live on steak, this requirement can be difficult to meet. Start your day off on an iron-rich note with a spinach and bell pepper omelet. Eggs and spinach provide iron, while the peppers give you vitamin C. Interestingly, eating vitamin C with plant-based sources of iron boosts the amount of iron your body absorbs. Don’t eat eggs? A kale and orange juice smoothie will give you the same iron + C superpower. Also: Take a nap.
Have more diet questions? Book an appointment with a Maven nutritionist for fast answers.

title.en-US: 5 "weird" newborn symptoms that are totally normal

content.value: Having a new baby means lots of “wait... is this normal” moments. We’ve rounded up a list of symptoms that may seem odd, but in fact, are common amongst newborns. From serious dandruff to black and yellow poop (yep — you read that correctly), be prepared to expect the unexpected.
My baby is cross-eyed.

If your baby’s eyes sometimes cross, it’s usually nothing to worry about. This is a normal part of the infant stage, when the muscles that control eye movement on each side don’t move in perfect unison. If your baby’s eyes are crossed 24/7, definitely let your pediatrician know.
My baby's skin is yellow.

The culprit here is a yellow pigment in the blood called bilirubin. Quick science lesson: The liver is responsible for ushering bilirubin out, but because your newborn’s liver is still developing, a build-up can occur. If bilirubin levels get too high and go without treatment (usually involving phototherapy—a.k.a. putting the baby under special lights), they can be toxic to brain cells. Most doctors encourage a follow-up appointment three to seven days after you give birth to check bilirubin levels. If your baby has already had that exam and things seem to get worse (i.e. skin becomes more yellow), call your doctor.
My baby has major dandruff.

“Cradle cap” is a common skin condition—also known as seborrheic dermatitis—that usually causes crusty or scaly patches (often with a waxy texture) on an infant’s head or scalp. The good news is it doesn’t cause your baby any itching or pain and usually clears up on its own in a few months. Your doctor might suggest more-frequent washes with a gentle shampoo or a medicated lotion for more severe cases.
My baby is swelling up in the oddest places.

Remember those maternal hormones that wreaked havoc on your body for the last nine months? Well, those same chemicals can pass through the placenta—explaining why some newborns (yep—boys and girls) experience breast swelling or even “witch’s milk”; that’s when some fluid leaks from a baby’s nipples. Another area that might appear puffy: The skin tissue around the labia. While this sounds scary, these symptoms are common and usually go away within a couple of weeks or months.
My baby has 50 shades of poop!

Your baby's first poop will be tar-like and blackish-green. That’s phase 1, which can last a couple of days. Next up: greenish-brown poop. Then, about five days after a child is born, we’re in the yellow-stool stage. If you’re breastfeeding your baby, yellowish stool that’s a bit seedy is normal. Formula-feeding? Poop is usually denser and can be a range of hues, from yellow to brown-green. If you're concerned about the color or consistency of what you’re finding in the diaper, call your baby’s doctor or book an appointment with a pediatrician in Maven’s network; they’re available anytime you need some reassurance or advice.
Sources: Maven Practitioner Network; Mayo Clinic; MedlinePlus

title.en-US: What every new parent wonders about sleep training

content.value: If you’re a new parent who hasn’t slept for longer than a three-hour stretch since giving birth, you may be looking for the bible on baby sleep. There are many different ways to teach a baby to doze off so everyone in the family can get a little more rest, but—here’s the tough part—not everyone agrees on these interventions. Here’s what you need to know before making your sleep training decision.
First, does everyone have to sleep train a baby?

No, there are no musts here. And there are definitely parents who opt out and their children go on to learn how to sleep through the night on their own. But if you don’t want to “wing it,” sleep training your infant is an option.
If there are many acceptable sleep training methods, how do I choose the best one?

The best method is the one you can sustain—sticking them out is key to making sleep strategies effective. Some styles, like “extinction sleep training,” require letting your baby cry it out with no intervening to soothe her. If you know that your threshold for hearing your baby cry is low, and after a certain amount of time you won’t be able to cope with your baby’s tears any longer, this probably isn’t the best approach for you. (Experts say it’s better to rush in to comfort your baby quickly rather than caving and going in to swoop her in your arms after, say, a half hour—which may backfire by reinforcing the crying.) In this case, a gentler tactic may be a better fit for your family. One example you may have heard about is the Ferber method, which promotes checking on your baby at timed intervals when she’s crying during sleep.
When can you start sleep training?

The timing of sleep training is as hotly debated as which method is best. Conventional parenting wisdom says sleep training before four to six months is a no-no. But there are doctors who advocate for an earlier initiation—like around 8 weeks. Whatever you decide, talk to your pediatrician before you begin just to make sure you’re on the same page and she doesn’t have any concerns about kicking things off in the Zzz’s department.
Need more advice?
Book an appointment with a Maven sleep coach who can introduce you to different sleep training methods and get you on the right track.

title.en-US: How to prepare your office for your maternity leave

content.value: Fact: A well-planned leave is a win for everyone involved. Of course, being mindful about your exit makes things easier on your boss and colleagues. But you also get the major benefit of feeling less stressed on your way out. “Instead of worrying about what was happening back at the office, or feeling guilty about how I’d left things, I was able to relax and focus on the bonding time with my little one,” says one parent who took a bit of a Type-A approach to planning for her time away. So what, exactly, does it take to plan for a successful leave? Follow these guidelines from Maven career pros.
Take initiative

Our career experts say that many people wait for their manager to get the conversation going on how workflow will be handled during their leave. But if you’re the one to get the ball rolling on this, you’re sending a strong message that you’re a committed employee who’s invested in making this a smooth transition. Set up some time with your boss to talk strategy; doing this only reinforces your value at the company.
Consult the calendar

While pregnancy doesn’t always go as planned and you might need to adjust your out-of-office dates, it’s a good idea to give your boss an idea of how many weeks you’ll be away. In addition to your due date, share when you anticipate you’ll start and end your leave. While everyone is different, some people have found it helpful to start their leave a few days before their little one is scheduled to make an entrance into the world. This can help you tend to last-minute personal errands before the baby arrives, and it also gives your team a trial run without you—so you’ll be available to answer pressing questions before you’re in full-on mom mode.
Develop a coverage plan

Work with your boss to determine if a temporary hire will be brought in or if your responsibilities will be managed internally. If your colleagues will be taking on your work, think strategically about how different team members could be matched to each of your tasks. Some career pros say that suggesting colleagues who can cover for you is easier if you have direct reports. If you don’t, it may be better to provide a detailed list of your responsibilities and let your supervisor ensure tasks are allocated fairly.
Brief your coworkers

Once you and your manager have settled on who will cover for you, develop a plan for handing off your projects. The key is to make things as simple as possible for team members—whether that means developing a cheat-sheet of simple processes or carving out some time for short in-person trainings. It’s also a good idea to indicate who they can turn to for help during your absence in case any questions come up, whether that’s your boss or another peer.
Be gracious

Even if you do a stellar job at leaving your office in good shape, it’s likely that some co-workers are going to work extra hard while you’re away—often for no extra pay. Before you leave (as well as when you return), express your gratitude for their help. Then, practice trust. Experts say one source of frustration for employees back at the office is being micromanaged by parents who have a hard time letting go of the work they’ve offloaded. A little confidence in your teammates goes a long way.
Have more questions? Book a video chat to get one-on-one guidance from the Career Coaches on Maven. They’re available anytime and can help you through every phase of your leave and return to work.

title.en-US: Can you be too obsessed with your weight during pregnancy?

content.value: Read this before you jump on the scale.

On the one hand, people tell you to revel in this time where you don't need to think about your size and can eat whatever you want. On the other, experts dole out cautionary advice about not packing on too many excess pounds during pregnancy because of the harm it can cause both you and your baby. It’s no wonder that healthy concerns have turned into unhealthy fixations for some moms-to-be.

If you’re getting on the scale daily (or multiple times a day) and stressing about the number, it’s important to step back—or off—and evaluate how helpful these check-ins really are. Your doctor will be weighing you during prenatal visits and keeping an eye on things to make sure you’re not in an unhealthy range. With this in mind, it may be a good idea to monitor your obsession with the scale and weigh in weekly to cut down on the crazy-making thoughts. Ultimately, if you’re focused on eating the right foods, you’re likely to be on the right track.
Bottom line:

Your weight is important, but it isn’t what you should be thinking about during every waking moment. Pregnancy may come with some periods of more gain, and some phases of less. It’s the long haul that matters most. Remember to take it easy on yourself. After all, growing a baby inside of you is hard enough without the extra pressure to control every ounce you see on the scale. And if you’re unsure about what to feed yourself and need some guidance, 
 with a Maven nutritionist.

title.en-US: The working parent’s guide to leaving the office on time

content.value: One thing that has likely disappeared along with cute pre-maternity bras? Your flexibility to stick around the office for an extra hour (or even an extra 10 minutes) at the end of a workday. After all, when you need to relieve your sitter or pick up your baby from childcare, your wiggle-room time is precisely... zero. But how, exactly, can you punch out on time while still feeling like the competent, productive employee you are? Our guide will—hopefully—make things a little easier.
Own your schedule—don’t apologize for it

One thing to try to avoid, according to many career coaches, is going into Remorse Mode. When communicating to colleagues that you need to leave at, say, 5:30 PM on the dot, don’t say, “I’m sorry I have to leave at X time” or “Unfortunately I can’t stay late now that I have a child.” That sends a communication that leaving work on time is something to be apologetic about. (Hint: It isn’t.)
Be laser-focused

The more focused you are, the easier it will be to keep your end-of-day boundaries. What that requires: a hefty dose of discipline. No more meetings without a clear agenda. No more long email replies when a quick phone call to a colleague would save you 15 minutes. No more buying cute baby outfits for your kid on your lunch break. One happy outcome: You’ll prove to yourself that you are a master of efficiency in the time you are at work.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Time your to-do list

When you’re looking at your to-do list for the day, you probably see a bunch of “whats.” Something that can give you better control over your day is adding “how longs” next to each task—this is an estimate of the time required to do it. The idea is to be realistic as you approach your day so you don’t leave with a sense of “I should’ve accomplished more.” Another benefit: Getting clear with yourself on how long things will take may help you ditch anything that isn’t essential to your role—or at least move it lower down on your priority list.
Be clear about your availability

If you have a shared calendar at work, make it clear that you’re not free after a certain time. You can even schedule ‘Train O’Clock” or another “event” that indicates your departure. Then, if meetings pop up unexpectedly and they’re close to your exit hour, you can say something like, “I’m available for 20 minutes. Will that work?” Guaranteed, being upfront with colleagues will be appreciated. If the organizer of the meeting thinks it’ll take 45 minutes instead of 20, she may suggest putting it off until the next day.
Find a work friend who will have your back

Here’s the reality: Despite your best intentions, there will probably be days when you need to duck out of work and can’t attend an important meeting or complete a task. Having a pal who can step in to take notes for you or tie up a loose end (and you can return the favor when she needs the same support) can help put your mind at ease.
Schedule power-down time

Twenty or 30 minutes before you have to leave, scan your to-do list, wrap up anything that can quickly be done, and make a few notes about tomorrow’s priorities. This will help you feel less anxious as you walk out the door. And, hey, as a working parent, a little less angst is just what the doctor ordered.
Have more questions about finding balance when you return to work?
Schedule a video appointment to chat with a Maven Career Coach. This transition is hard—and you don’t have to figure it out alone.
The more focused you are, the easier it will be to keep your end-of-day boundaries.

title.en-US: 3 ways to troubleshoot anxiety during pregnancy

content.value: One moment you’re feeling confident and strong; the next you’re telling yourself that the tiniest twinge in your body means something is wrong. Adopting these strategies can help sidestep pregnancy anxiety before it really takes over.
Proactively find ways to build calm into your life.

In other words, don’t wait until you’re feeling level-10 overwhelmed to seek some inner Zen. By building habits that promote a sense of calm, you can keep anxiety in check when worried thoughts try to creep in. Take a daily walk to clear your mind; surround yourself with people whose presence makes you feel more relaxed; prioritize sleep; avoid caffeine—whatever it is that helps you stay chill.
Bug your OB-GYN.

It’s normal to have lots of questions as your pregnancy progresses. “I haven’t felt the baby kick in an hour—what does that mean?”... “This wacky symptom appeared overnight—is it normal?”... Whatever your concerns, if you keep them to yourself—or worse: find yourself reading online message boards to find answers—your anxiety may quickly rise. Vow to put self-reliance aside during these nine months and rely on your pregnancy A-team. Don’t be embarrassed to call your doctor or a Maven practitioner to find out what’s really going on or get some real-time reassurance.
Look for the funny.

Sure, many aspects of pregnancy are serious business, but that doesn’t mean you can’t look for the humorous side of things. When your belly gets so big you can’t see your feet, or when that abdominal cramp turns out to be just a bad case of gas, it’s OK to laugh at the situation. If you need help lightening up the intensity of your pregnancy journey, actively seek out ways to feel more joyful. Choose books/TV/Netflix binge-a-thons that are light hearted and funny, and give the war documentaries and CNN a rest.

title.en-US: How sleep problems affect your pregnancy

content.value: When you’re pregnant, you might feel as if there just aren’t enough hours in a day to get a good night’s rest. And when you do finally crawl into bed, you may have lots of trouble snoozing. If sleep was just about avoiding feeling like a zombie for nine months, it might not seem important enough. But the truth is that studies are continually showing that sleep is crucial for your health and a smooth delivery. So how much do you need? According to the National Institutes of Health, adults should get 7 to 9 hours of shut-eye, and pregnant women “may need a few more hours of sleep per night or a few short naps during the day.” Read on for the three sleep issues that affect pregnancy, and what can you do about them.
Too little shut-eye

A study from the University of California at San Francisco found that women who got less than six hours of sleep in late pregnancy had longer labors and were 4.5 times more likely to have a C-section. There are plenty of reasons why pregnant women don’t adequate sleep. So the first step is to identify the root cause. Talking to a doctor can help you determine whether it’s anxiety-related insomnia, a physical issue like heartburn, or something else. Once you know what’s keeping you up, you can work on ways to clock more Zzz’s.
Low-quality sleep

In one study, Researchers at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center discovered that both the quantity and the quality of a woman’s sleep during pregnancy was linked to low-birth weight and preterm births. It turns out that when you don’t get good, deep sleep consistently, there may be disruptions in the body’s normal immune processes. These disturbances can drive up inflammation levels in your body, leading to an overproduction of cytokines. What are cytokines, you ask? They’re substances that, in excess, can attack healthy cells and tissue in pregnant women. Sounds scary, but experts offer the reassurance that making an effort to protect the quality of your sleep through behavioral and lifestyle changes can have a huge impact and help ward off these complications.
Sleep apnea

Sleep apnea—a disorder that causes you to stop and start breathing repeatedly throughout the night—has been linked with gestational diabetes, preeclampsia, preterm delivery and low birth weight. For most people, sleep apnea is caused by an obstruction in airflow in the back of the throat; your airway narrows and you can't get an adequate breath in. The good news is that there are things you can do about this condition. For one, work with your doctor or nutritionist to maintain a healthy pregnancy weight; sleep apnea is more common in obese women. Some moms-to-be who already have sleep apnea use something called a CPAP machine—a.k.a. a continuous positive airway pressure device. This involves wearing mask over your nose while you sleep to help keep your airway open. If that’s too uncomfortable, a doctor can help you figure out if other solutions will help you.
Bottom line:

Sleeping well during pregnancy can be a challenge, but it doesn’t have to be impossible. If you have any of these issues, it’s worth making your sleep a priority. Talk to your doctor or book a video appointment with a Maven practitioner.

title.en-US: How often should you pee when you're pregnant?
