content.value: The frequent urge to go is one of the first signs of pregnancy—and one of the most annoying. So if you’re feeling like you need your own personal porta-potty next to your cubicle or bed, you’re not alone. In fact, one study found that pregnant women may be peeing up to seven times more than normal. Find out why this happens, and what you can do about it.
Why do I need to pee all the time?
Pregnancy hormones cause lots of body changes, and this is one of them. They increase blood flow to your kidneys, which stimulate the production of more urine.
When will the constant need to go end?

Probably after you deliver your baby. But you could get a brief reprieve in the second trimester; experts say things may start to settle after the first 16 weeks of pregnancy (for a little while, at least). In the last trimester, the bathroom breaks often become more frequent but for a different reason: the pressure on your bladder as your baby gets bigger and moves further down into your pelvis.
Should I see my doctor if I’m peeing a lot?

Talk to your OB-GYN or a practitioner on Maven’s platform if you’re peeing a lot and you have pain or a burning sensation when you’re urinating. This could be a sign of a UTI (urinary tract infection). It’s important to treat UTIs quickly when you’re pregnant so they don’t turn into a kidney infection, which is far more dangerous for you and your baby. This is one of the reasons your doctor gives you a urine test during all your prenatal visits.
If I’m getting up frequently in the middle of the night to pee, should I cut back on fluids?

Probably not. The Office on Women's Health recommends that you drink about 10 cups—or 2.4 liters—of fluids a day when you’re pregnant. Becoming seriously dehydrated can lead to pregnancy complications including preterm labor and birth defects. So don’t skimp on water, but try meeting your quota earlier in the day. Cutting down on liquids at night should help with the middle-of-the-night wake up call to the loo.

title.en-US: Why do some women get back to their pre-baby size so fast?

content.value: Answer from Nutritionist and Lactation Consultant Melissa Flynn, IBCLC, MPH, RD

There can be many variables at play for how fast a new mom returns to her pre-baby size. The amount of weight gained during pregnancy, as well as a woman’s weight, overall diet and physical activity before getting pregnant all make a difference. Breastfeeding and genetics also factor into the equation.

If you’re feeling anxious that you “should” be somewhere you’re not, remember that weight loss is never quick. It took nine months to put on the weight, it will take some time to take it all off. Working with a registered dietitian or nutritionist in Maven’s platform can help you create a plan specific to your needs to help fuel you right as you get back to a healthy weight for your body.

title.en-US: 5 foods to help you get enough fiber during pregnancy

content.value: Good news: It’s not all beans and prunes, people.

Filling up on high-fiber foods is always a good idea, but during pregnancy, it’s key. First, fiber helps you avoid the common-but-no-fun symptom of constipation by keeping your digestive system running smoothly. It also helps keep your blood sugar levels normal, and promotes a feeling of fullness so you may have an easier time keeping weight gain within a healthy range. But getting the recommended 25 to 30 grams of fiber each day isn’t easy—if you’re not reaching for the right foods. Here are a few ways to get your fill, even if prunes and legumes aren’t really your thing.
Artichokes

One medium artichoke has more than 10 grams of fiber. Steer clear of artichoke dip loaded with cheese and other high-cal ingredients; try tossing them into a salad or simply grilling them with olive oil and lemon.
Raspberries
When it come to fruit, raspberries top the fiber chart with about 8 grams per cup. Use them to give your Greek yogurt a fiber-boost or to satisfy a sweet tooth the healthy way.
Avocados
Two words: Avocado toast. Half an avocado has 7 grams of fiber. Not that you needed any convincing to eat it.
Popcorn

With more than 7 grams of fiber per 2-cup serving, you can’t beat popcorn for a Netflix treat. Just make sure you’re popping your own or choosing an air-popped variety to avoid the high-calorie trap of some microwave options.
Whole Wheat Pasta
Who are we to get in between a pregnant woman and her spaghetti? And if you’re reaching for whole wheat pasta—with 6 grams of fiber per cup—we wouldn’t dare try.

title.en-US: How to work well with colleagues after maternity leave

content.value: When you’re returning to work after parental leave, you may be anticipating how you’ll get back in sync with your boss. Totally understandable. But peer relationships can be equally tricky. Some common anxieties we hear about from parents: Will my coworkers feel resentful of the work they’d taken over for me—or, alternatively, too territorial to give it up? Will I have a hard time bonding with everyone (or be deliberately excluded) now that I won’t have as much time for happy hours and other team outings? While your concerns are normal, there are ways to feel a lot less stressed about this transition. Here are four tips for navigating peer relationships after your time away from the office.
Use your manager as an ally

Here’s the thing: Once you and your manager have an agreed-upon plan for getting you ramped up, it will be a lot easier to navigate any potentially thorny situations, like when a coworker has trouble relinquishing your old projects. Toward the end of your maternity leave, set up a call with your direct supervisor to discuss how any duties that had been shifted onto a colleague’s plate while you were on leave will be handled when you return. Have a timeline in place for getting caught up on where things stand, as well as your official “back in action” date for each of your responsibilities.
Thank any coworkers who did double-duty

While there’s no need to feel guilty or apologetic about your time away from work to have a baby, it’s a good idea to express your gratitude to anyone who took on parts of your job. When colleagues feel appreciated, they’re likely to feel a lot warmer about your re-entry. Bonus points for letting them know you’re looking forward to helping them out in the future, whether they’re out of work on vacation, taking a leave of their own, or just need a mental health day.
Reconnect with your office B.F.F.

It’s always a good idea to ease yourself into office culture before your first day back. If you’ve been out of the loop on work gossip, who got hired, who got promoted, catching up with your office B.F.F. may help you feel like less of an outsider when you return. Think of someone on your team you had a close relationship with—maybe a fellow working parent who has been exactly where you are now—and ask if they'd like to meet for coffee or schedule a phone date. Many new parents say that having even one peer on their team who they see as a friend can make a huge difference in how they feel about work.
Just listen

You left to have a baby—so all eyes and ears are going to be on you when you return. Can we see photos? Are you getting any sleep? How hard was it to leave your baby today? (Ugh.) Be gracious while responding to your coworkers’ questions, but be sure you also find time to ask about them: How have things been going? Is there a business win they’re dying to share with you? Taking the time to really listen will send the message that you truly care about the relationship.
Need more advice about returning to work after leave? Book an appointment with one of our Maven Career Coaches. They specialize in helping parents re-enter the workforce.

title.en-US: Real talk from Maven user Kathryn about IVF

content.value: 35 years old
In-house attorney
Brooklyn, NY
Why did you decide to start IVF?

My husband and I were categorized as "unexplained infertility" patients after trying to conceive naturally for 1.5 years. Doctors could not find anything wrong with us. We went through 4 rounds of IUI with no success and IVF was the next, natural step for us.
Had you been pregnant before when you started?
No.
How many times have you done IVF?
Two.
How did you choose your clinic?
We live in New York and Weill Cornell is known for having an excellent fertility program. I was also already in the Weill Cornell system through my OB-GYN so it was a no-brainer.
What surprised you most about the procedure?

How all-consuming it was. The shots and physical effects and procedure were totally secondary to the emotional toll it took on me and on my husband. IVF / having a baby was all I could think about and concentrate on for months. Now that I'm on the other end of it, it seems totally worth it, but in the thick of it, it was brutal.
Do you think you had a positive patient experience?

All in all . . . yes. I loved my doctor and the nurses we were paired with were incredible. But unless IVF works, it's hard to say that any experience is a positive experience. You don't walk away from the multiple appointments that you have to go to a week noting how great the office was or how nice a nurse was or how great the system works. You are obsessed with becoming pregnant and resent every minute you're spending at an office getting blood drawn and getting your follicles monitored. When I look back, Weil Cornell is an unbelievable place and helps so many people. It feels a bit like a factory, but if feels like that because it is helping so many people at once and has many return patients.
What could have been better?

I think we could have been educated a bit better from the outset about the likelihood of success with IUI (not a great likelihood). If we'd understood that more, I think we would have gone right to IVF. Personally, I would tell most people to skip IUI and go to IVF if you can (insurance might require IUI first). The IUI drugs I found to be way worse in terms of side effects and IVF just has such a higher success rate. Being stuck in fertility treatments is brutal regardless of what fertility treatment you're facing. Might as well just go for the big guns from the outset and save time and agony.
How much did it cost each time you did it?
Out of pocket, it would have been around $10k each time, but thankfully our insurance covered it.
How quickly did you get pregnant?
We got pregnant with our second round of IVF when they introduced ICSI into our procedure. EVERYONE DO ICSI THE FIRST TIME YOU DO IVF.
Are you going to do it again?
Yes.
What is your advice to someone about to go through IVF?

Accept that this is just the hardest thing and find people to talk to that have gone through it. That is what got me through. I found a woman at work that had gone through IVF successfully and talked to her nonstop about it. I've found that most people that have gone through it are happy to talk to other people that have gone through it. It's kind of a beautiful community. No one else can understand what it is like and how difficult it is. So having that kinship in the hardest of moments helped so much. Also know and accept that it may not work the first time (and a lot of times it doesn't). That does not mean it will not work. There is so much uncertainty in this field and doctors learn a lot from the first round of IVF (at least in our experience).
Any tips for managing the emotional stress of IVF?

Talk about it. Especially with people that have gone through it before. (See above.) Also don't be embarrassed or ashamed about what you're going through. Once I opened up I learned how many people were dealing with similar issues. Weirdly, I made so many friends going through this process and have an amazing connection to a lot of mamas who have gone through fertility treatments.
Any tips for managing the stress that IVF can put on a relationship?

Talk about it. Laugh about the ridiculousness. Make your partner go to the appointments with you so it feels like you are completely in it together. Continue to create memories that are separate from the fertility process. It's really hard to be happy for and enjoy other people who seem to be having babies without any effort—remember that everyone has their own struggles.
What other question are we not asking but should be?
Were you successful with IVF? If not, what is your plan? When do you decide to stop IVF?

title.en-US: Acupuncture and IVF

content.value: Where did acupuncture come from?

For more than 3,500 years, acupuncture has been providing relief to people around the world. Originally developed and practiced in China, this soothing therapy is today embraced by infertility patients.

The Eastern medicine philosophy of acupuncture draws on the belief that an energy called Qi (pronounced “chee”) circulates throughout our body, from the top of our head to the soles of our feet. When we experience good health, this energy flows unobstructed along pathways in the body called meridians. Each meridian is believed to be connected to a specific organ system, and when an energy flow is disrupted by a disease or an injury, illness or pain occurs. Acupuncture is then used to balance the flow of Qi and stimulate our body’s natural ability to heal.

Ongoing modern research in the field of acupuncture has provided insights into how acupuncture works. Functional MRIs point to specific brain activity in addition to the release of endorphins, the body’s natural pain-relieving chemical, when acupuncture treatment is performed. Research has also shown acupuncture’s ability to release muscular trigger points which can cause myofascial pain, in addition to having an anti-inflammatory effect.
Why is it believed that acupuncture can help infertility patients?

The causes of fertility are typically 40% due to female infertility, 40% due to male infertility, and 20% unknown. One of the main ways acupuncture is believed to help with infertility is by reducing stress, which is often a key factor in the fertility of both men and women.

When people are under stress, the hormone cortisol is released in the brain. This alters the brain's neurochemical balance, thus changing hormone levels and disrupting the pituitary balance that is key to the reproductive cycle.

Stress can also lead to a decline in blood flow to the uterus and ovaries. Acupuncture can increase blood flow by slowing down the nervous system which then causes the blood vessels to dilate. When the vessels dilate, they release a flood of nutrient dense blood to the ovaries and uterus. Increased ovarian blood flow may help with response to fertility medications. Increased uterine blood flow ensures a thick uterine lining and sets up an ideal environment for implantation.

Acupuncture can also “be used to treat any type of fertility disorder including spasmed tubes. Spasmed tubes are often de-spasmed with acupuncture, though blocked tubes will not respond to acupuncture,” according to the American Pregnancy Association.

The other reason that patients are turning to acupuncture is that undergoing fertility treatments is hard on your body, expensive, and doesn’t necessarily lead to successful results. In a search for affordable and effective healthcare, alternative and holistic treatments are gaining wider appeal among the general public.
Are there actually better clinical outcomes associated with acupuncture?

There hasn’t been a definitive study published by any government-funded research institution. However, these studies are in progress, and anecdotally the early results are promising. Some acupuncturists report that women who added acupuncture sessions to IVF were twice as likely to have a baby compared to women who did IVF alone.
When should I start acupuncture?

If you are going through an IVF cycle, it's best if you can start acupuncture six to eight weeks prior to transfer. 
In an ideal world, you would go three to four months prior to conception/transfer so that acupuncture can also help with egg quality, work on any cycle or lining irregularities, address any nutritional concerns, and help reduce stress.
How often should I do it?

Generally speaking, if you are a woman trying to conceive, the most important times to have acupuncture are during the follicular phase—day 5, 6, 7 or 8 of your menstrual cycle (day 1 being the first day of heavy flow), the day of, day before or day after ovulation (as indicated by your LH surge), and during implantation time (six to ten days after ovulation). This works out to be approximately once a week except when you're menstruating, so most women should be receiving acupuncture treatments roughly three to four times per month.
Does acupuncture hurt?

Modern acupuncture consists of the gentle insertion and stimulation of thin, disposable sterile needles at strategic points near the surface of the body. Typically patients report feeling a light pinch, with some points more painful than others.

Research shows that when needles are placed in the skin, the body releases its own natural painkillers (endorphins). They cause your muscles to relax, your breathing to slow, and your mind to calm. Endorphins are responsible for the relaxed feeling one gets after a session—and can even cause patients to fall asleep during a session.
Does insurance cover acupuncture?

Many insurance companies recognize the health benefits of acupuncture. Your Maven Care Advocate can help you figure out which acupuncturists in your area are in-network and if there is a co-pay. If your insurance doesn’t cover acupuncture, your Maven Care Advocate can help you figure out how much acupuncture will cost and the more affordable program.
How should I choose my acupuncturist?

First, ask your doctor for a referral. If your doctor doesn’t have a referral or you’ve chosen someone in-network, ask your acupuncturist about their level of training and experience in treating fertility patients. They should be able to describe their cases and successes with you, and if they have not established a relationship with your doctor, they should be willing to do so. Some acupuncturists who specialize in treating fertility patients are Fellows of the American Board of Oriental Medicine, which requires its Fellows to pass an exam and receive continuing medical education.

title.en-US: Everything you want to know about sex during pregnancy

content.value: If this is your first time as a mama-to-be, you may be wondering: Is sex safe? As long as your pregnancy is healthy, there’s no reason to skip the between-the-sheets bonding time with your partner. Not only does sex get the green light; it’s encouraged. OB-GYNs say that business-as-usual (in the bedroom) can help couples stay bonded throughout these nine months. (If your partner is reading this over your shoulder, we’ll pause here while clapping commences.)
Now that you know sex is safe, you probably have a few other questions. Here are answers to common head-scratchers.
Are there any times to hit the pause button on sex?

Certain pregnancy complications can make sex unsafe, so definitely get your doctor’s okay first. Even if your pregnancy is healthy, there may be times when you need to take a break. If you’re dealing with morning sickness, fatigue, and you’re just not feeling up to it, communicate a no-go to your partner. Being open about your needs is an important part of this pregnancy journey.
Is it normal to feel extra-frisky during pregnancy?

While your sex drive may fluctuate throughout pregnancy, you may hit a stretch of “I can’t get enough!”—often late in the first trimester and into the second. There’s a scientific reason why: Libido goes into overdrive thanks to rising levels of estrogen and progesterone, which increase blood flow to your pelvic area and up the lubrication factor, too. Have at it!
Is there any chance my partner’s penis can hit the baby during sex?

We don’t blame you for wondering—OB-GYNs say this is a very common question. But this should put your mind at ease: Your cervix serves as a barrier between your vagina and your baby, so there’s no chance of “poking.”
Is oral sex allowed?

Yes, but doctors do offer this one piece of (random, we know) cautionary advice: Never let your partner blow into your vagina, since that can trigger a fatal air embolism. The other big caveat: If your partner gets cold sores (a.k.a. Herpes Simplex Virus Type 1), oral sex is off the table in the third trimester. Genital herpes can be passed on to you through oral sex, and if this infection crosses the placenta wall, your baby could end up with neonatal herpes. Congenital defects, premature birth, and stillbirth are all considered risks.
What if my growing belly is getting in the way?

If your baby bump is making sex a challenge, you and your partner may need to get creative. It’s a known fact that during the third trimester, certain positions—like missionary with your partner on top—can cause too much strain for a pregnant woman. In fact, some doctors will tell you that to be on the safe side, you should opt for side positions (i.e. spooning) or pregnant woman on top as you get closer to your due date. Experiment until you find what’s most comfortable for you.

title.en-US: Is it ever too late to start exercising during pregnancy?

content.value: The scientific case for third trimester exercise

Let’s face it: Despite our best intentions, some of us aren’t as active as we’d like to be during pregnancy. In the first trimester, there’s the morning sickness that doesn’t exactly make you want to spring out of bed and tie up your jogging shoes. In the second trimester, you might have been feeling better but couldn’t find the mojo to get moving again. So by now you might be thinking, “What’s the point in getting started—shouldn’t I just wait until after the baby is born?”

Well, here’s some evidence that it’s never too late to start exercising when you’re expecting. A study by the University of Colorado School of Public Health looked at the effects of exercising after 29 weeks. Tracking 826 mothers and their babies, the researchers found that women who exercised in their third trimesters gave birth to babies with less body fat. (Remember, two babies can be born at the same weight, but have different amounts of fat mass and lean mass.) Being active didn’t mean these women were signing up for boot camp and marathons—a modest amount of exercise on most days of the week did the trick. While researchers are still looking at the long-term implications of a baby’s body composition at birth, experts say a newborn’s excess body fat could continue into childhood.

The bottom line: Don’t worry about what you did or didn’t do in your pregnancy until now. Beating yourself up over a lack of exercise won’t do you or your baby any favors. But if you can muster up the motivation, it’s not too late to start taking a nightly walk after dinner, swim a few laps, or do some light yoga in your living room.

title.en-US: How to deal with changes in appetite in the third trimester

content.value: What to do when you’re just not hungry.

The closer you get to your due date, the more space your baby takes up in your belly. No wonder some women notice a decrease in appetite in the third trimester. Of course, your baby still needs nourishment, and skipping meals (or eating only junk food) isn’t really an option. So how can you adjust your eating habits so you can tolerate what you’re putting into your mouth?

The key is to focus on quality instead of quantity. Maybe you can’t stomach a big salad with an entrée-sized filet of grilled salmon in one sitting. That’s OK. Aim to have smaller meals or snacks more often. For instance, maybe a crudité with hummus (protein! veggies! fiber!) goes down easier and is more appealing than a large meal.

Another benefit of 4 to 6 mini-meals versus 3 big ones: You’ll avoid triggering a case of heartburn, which may get worse as your pregnancy progresses. And if you suspect the cause of your loss of appetite is the hormonally-induced constipation that’s common during pregnancy (um, who wants to fill up again when they’re never empty?), try adding more fiber to your diet—as well as drinking plenty of water—to see if that helps get things moving again.
Have more questions about eating during pregnancy? Book an appointment with a Maven nutritionist.

title.en-US: "I didn't grieve my miscarriage as much as I assumed people might"

content.value: Maven Real Talk on Miscarriage with Amy
38 years old
Physician
How many miscarriages have you had?
Did you experience your miscarriage(s) before you had children or after you already had a child?
After two healthy children.
How far along were you when you had your last miscarriage?
9 weeks.
Did it happen at home or in the hospital, or someplace else?
Bleeding started at home, then I was diagnosed at the hospital and had a D&C later that day.
What were your symptoms?
Light bleeding on and off for several days, but it wasn't getting worse and I didn't have any pain, so I hoped maybe it could be a normal part of early pregnancy.
What surprised you most about having a miscarriage?

That we (husband and I) could be so matter-of-fact about it when we had to decide what to do. Decisions came before emotions, and though we both were sad, I don't think we grieved as much as I assumed people might.
Did you find out what caused the miscarriage?
No, I never did.
Did you go on to have a baby after your miscarriage(s)? If so, how soon afterwards?
Yes, I got pregnant again within two months—and I’m about to have this baby!
How open were you with friends and relatives?

We had only told a brother of mine (and my sister-in-law) that we were pregnant. I also told a few friends who were visiting us, because they saw that I was not drinking alcohol when we were out. Nobody else in our family knew we were expecting. So then we had to call them while the miscarriage was happening to tell them what was going on and ask for prayers—and it was hard to share the bad news when we hadn’t had the chance to first share the good. We decided to tell our parents and siblings (and allowed them to share the news if they felt inclined) but we never told our two children, who are three and four years old. (Our kids never knew we had been pregnant). We definitely never posted on social media!
If you are married or in a relationship, did the experience of pregnancy loss affect your relationship with your partner?
No.
Did you seek therapy to deal with the miscarriage? If not, would it have been helpful in retrospect?

No, and I don't think official “therapy” would have been as helpful as just talking with other women who had experienced something similar. My sister in law had also had two miscarriages and she was very empathetic, but we didn't really go into many details with each other.
What would you want to tell another woman who has experienced a miscarriage?

It's hard and sad and that's okay, or it might not be hard or sad—and that's okay too. It has probably happened to many more women than you think and we are here for you if you want to talk or not talk about it.

title.en-US: The risks associated with egg freezing

content.value: Egg freezing is still a relatively new procedure, so we’re still learning about the long-term risks. Right now, most of the shorter-term risks involve the use of fertility drugs. Risks include:

The chief near-term risk during an egg freezing cycle is overstimulating your ovaries - ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. In severe forms it can be dangerous, with symptoms that include shortness of breath, gastric reflux, pain and vomiting.
Conditions related to the use of fertility drugs

Rarely, use of injectable fertility drugs, such as synthetic follicle-stimulating hormone or luteinizing hormone to induce ovulation, can cause ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome—in which your ovaries become swollen and painful soon after ovulation or egg retrieval. This happens in approximately 5% of IVF and egg freezing cycles. Signs and symptoms include mild abdominal pain, bloating, nausea, vomiting and diarrhea. Even more rarely, it's possible to develop a more severe form of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome that can also cause fluid to build up in your abdomen and shortness of breath.
Egg retrieval procedure complications

Rarely, use of an aspirating needle to retrieve eggs causes bleeding, infection or damage to the bowel, bladder or a blood vessel. Risks associated with general anesthesia—which might be used for some egg retrieval procedures—also might pose a concern.
Emotional risks

Egg freezing can provide false hope. Deciding to freeze your eggs may be empowering and provide hope for the future; however, there is still no guarantee of success.
If you use your frozen eggs to have a biological child, the risk of miscarriage will be primarily based on your age at the time your eggs were frozen.
Ovarian cancer

This linkage is light at best but we wanted to cover this in case this came up during a Googling session. Probably the best study on the role of hormone therapy and ovarian cancer comes from a British registry of 233,000 patients where those receiving IVF recorded a small absolute increased incidence (15 vs. 10 cases for every 10,000 patients) of ovarian cancer. Whether the underlying causes of infertility, or the IVF treatment itself, drove those incremental 5 / 10,000 cases is hard to say, as there is evidence in both directions.

title.en-US: Is it better to pump more often or for longer periods of time?

content.value: Answer from Midwife Danika Severino Wynn, CNM, IBCLC, MS

If you are pumping to feed your baby breast milk exclusively then pumping every 2-3 hours (or 8-12 times per day) is crucial to keep up your breast milk supply. Ideally, each pumping episode should last approximately 10-15 minutes. If you are pumping to supplement a formula-fed infant with breast milk, then you can decrease the amount of times you pump per day; I recommend cutting out some of the night sessions so you can get some rest!

Everyone has different experiences and their bodies react differently to a reduction in pumping, so book an appointment with a lactation consultant if you’re having trouble. Make sure you’re also eating, drinking, and getting enough rest to keep up your supply too!

title.en-US: How one mom juggles work and life

content.value: 35 years old
Administrative Assistant
Seattle, WA
How long after having a child did you return to work?
4 months
Who cares for your child while you’re at work, and how did you make your childcare decision?

I chose to do a nanny share. I wanted my child to have the safety of my home but be able to interact with more than just a caregiver. I liked the idea of my little one having another child around to socialize with during the day. Joining together with other parents to hire one nanny was another perk, so this seemed like the best option all-around.
What was the most challenging part about your first days back at work?
Realizing that you have so little time with your baby after a full day of work.
Have things gotten easier/harder with time? How so?
It gets easier when you shift your thinking about time. It isn’t so much about how many hours you spend as it is about being more present with your family and in the moment in general.
How could your workplace have helped make the transition smoother?
It would have been helpful if they didn’t expect me to go back into the full swing of things right away when my life had changed so dramatically.
Most working parents say work/life “balance” is a myth—and the reality is more of a “juggle.” Any tools or tricks that help you manage the juggle?
Put clear boundaries around work. Be present at work and at home. Remember what is your biggest priority and let that be the guide.
Did you have thoughts of quitting your job?

In the beginning, I thought no one was qualified enough to watch my child. But I ultimately accepted that it didn’t make any sense financially for me to quit my job. I also contemplated what would make me the best mom to my son, and I realized that being a stay-at-home parent would have ultimately not been right for me. If I’m being honest, I think I would have been an awful stay-at-home mom.
If your best friend was returning to work after maternity leave, what would you want to say to her?
You will hate it for the first 6 months!
What’s one thing you’d like to see change about the return-to-work conversation for parents?
Applauding parents for taking their full parental leave—the most time off available—and not the opposite.

title.en-US: How to cope with missing milestones when you're at work

content.value: If you ask a Maven therapist or career coach what issues plague working parents the most, they’ll almost always mention “absentee guilt”—a feeling that tends to flare up anytime a child reaches a milestone and you're not there to catch it. If you can relate, know that this is a common experience, and with some mental training and a little compassion (psst... toward yourself), it can be a bit easier to cope. Here are three things to remember the next time you kiss your child goodbye and head off to the office.
Recognize you’re not a superhero, and that’s OK

It would be nice if working parents had the ability to be in two (or twenty) places at once. But it’s important to accept that none of us are ever going to have this superpower, and try to come to terms with life’s trade-offs and sacrifices. Building a career and earning a living means that it’s impossible to be there for everything that happens in your child’s world. (PS: That doesn’t mean you aren’t there for your kid.) Letting go of unrealistic expectations can be the first step to dropping any feelings of guilt or regret.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Decide how much—or how little—your caregiver shares with you during the day

Some parents want their babysitter or childcare center to send texts/photos/videos every time their child rolls over. If that helps you feel better and more connected while you’re at work, make sure your caregivers know you’d like regular contact. For some parents, however, the constant updates can be a hard reminder of what they’re missing. Of course, you should always be kept in the loop on things that require a parent’s attention, like if your baby gets sick or has an accident. But if the video evidence of, say, your baby uttering the word “mama” while you were in a board meeting triggers major sadness, give yourself permission to set some boundaries. This strategy may also help you stay focused at work so you can get home faster. Double win.
Think of milestones as “mile stages"

Babies first word. Babies first step. Babies first bite of solid food. Instead of thinking of these firsts as isolated incidents to catch, try viewing these baby breakthroughs simply as new stages of your child’s development—beyond a single moment in time. You might not be there for the first step, but you’ll definitely be there to hear the many pitter-patters of your baby’s feet—as she walks right into your arms.
Give yourself permission to set some boundaries.

title.en-US: The truth about exercising your abs during pregnancy

content.value: There are lots of things you get a pass on when you’re expecting—painting the nursery, lugging heavy groceries up two flights of stairs, taking over your partner’s side of the bed. Exercise, however, isn’t one of them. Staying active during pregnancy is safe for most moms-to-be, and doctors usually encourage it unless a health condition is at play. But when it comes to working your midsection, you might think you can say goodbye to your abs until the baby is born—or five years old. Not so fast. Read on for the facts.
Are there any ab moves you should avoid during pregnancy?

Once you start sporting a baby belly (typically by the end of the first trimester), it’s time to give crunches/sit-ups/curls a rest. These moves—the technical term is “forward flexion abdominal exercises”—can worsen a common pregnancy symptom called diastasis recti, which happens when your ab muscles get stretched to make room for the growing baby in your uterus and, in time, separate. Another reason to tweak your usual ab workout: Lying on your back can cause your uterus to compress your vena cava, the major vessel that returns blood to your heart. This can lead to less blood flow, so some moms-to-be feel dizzy or lightheaded when they’re in this position.
Does that mean you should avoid working your core during pregnancy?

No. While getting a six pack obviously isn’t the goal here, strengthening your core—which includes the pelvic floor and the deep spinal muscles—can help you have a more comfortable pregnancy. It can keep your posture healthier and reduce lower back pain as your belly expands. Just as important: A strong core may help you have a smoother delivery and postpartum recovery. Luckily, there are strengthening moves that engage your core that you can do while standing upright or kneeling.
Are planks OK too since you’re not lying on your back?

It depends. We’ve heard of some women doing them right up until their delivery day, but you should exercise caution because there is a possibility of the move putting too much strain on your body. A better bet may be a plank variation that puts less pressure on your back and core. With an incline plank, for instance, you get into push-up position with your feet on the ground, but you place your hands—shoulder width apart—on a sturdy bench instead of on the floor.

Have more questions about exercise during pregnancy, or want specific guidance on ab exercises that are safe for you and your growing baby? Book an appointment with a physical therapist in Maven’s network. The best thing about a video chat is that they can demo specific moves or correct your form as you try.

title.en-US: How to deal with new-parent isolation

content.value: Feeling disconnected since having a baby? We’ll help you cope.

How can you feel so alone when another human is practically glued to you 24/7? That’s the unexpected reality some new parents experience: being with their baby, yet experiencing an intense sense of loneliness. Even Kate Middleton has described parenthood as being “lonely at times. You do feel quite isolated. But actually so many others are going through exactly what you’re going through.”

Royalty or not, if you’re going through this right now, the first thing to know is that it’s normal. You aren’t the only one who feels isolated from everyone—friends, coworkers, your favorite barista at the coffee shop near work, and maybe even your partner.

Of course, the fact that it’s normal doesn’t mean it’s easy. All parents need someone to talk to. And you don’t have to feel guilty if the time with your little one doesn’t fulfill all your needs for social contact. Sure, it’s part of the job requirement to focus on your baby. But there’s something we can learn from parents with kids who are a bit older now. When they describe the loneliness they felt in the early days, many of them say they closed themselves off more than was necessary. As one parent told us, “I thought this was my one and only moment in time to bond with my baby, especially before going back to work, so I didn’t think it was OK to prioritize contact with anyone else.”

Even if you’re the primary caregiver and you don’t have a sitter who can watch your baby while you get some time outside of the house, try not to spend all of your time with your child indoors. Staring at the same four walls all the time will only make the feeling of isolation worse. Make time to get to a park or sit in a kid-friendly café. Look for a local parent group you can join in your area. Ask a relative if they can watch your little one so you and your partner can go on a date night.

At home, when your baby is napping, look for ways to connect with the outside world. For instance, call a fellow parent friend who you know will be home and chit-chat about your days. And when someone offers to come visit, resist the urge to say no. Loneliness sometimes stems from not being comfortable letting other people get close to us—so try to remind yourself that the people who care about you won’t care if your house is a mess or you’re wearing three-day-old spit-up; they just want to see you.
Bottom line:

Not feeling disconnected takes work, but ultimately, it’s the kind of self-care that will pay you back. And if you’re struggling to find someone to talk to, don’t hesitate to reach out to one of our providers for help.

title.en-US: The postpartum symptom no one warned us about

content.value: As if sleep wasn’t hard enough to come by, it’s common for postpartum women to suffer from night sweats. Here’s what’s happening, and how to deal (and cool off).
What causes postpartum sweating?

You probably guessed it: Your hormones are the culprit here. Remember all those extra fluids that filled your body during pregnancy? Well, excess sweating is one of the ways your body is flushing them out.
How long will it last?

Women who experience postpartum night sweats often worry that they are never going to stop. But this phase is temporary; the sweats may last anywhere from a few days to about six weeks. (The perspiration tends to go on a bit longer if you’re breastfeeding.)
When should you see a doctor?

Although postpartum sweating is totally normal, if you’re also running a fever, it may mean you have an infection. Give your doctor a call if you’re feverish or if the perspiration seems excessive (for instance, you have to change the sheets multiple times per night).
What should you do in the meantime?

Drink plenty of water so you don’t become dehydrated. Wear loose PJs made of lightweight cotton. (Interestingly, sleeping in the buff might actually make you hotter because the fabric helps wick moisture away.) If you’re waking up in the middle of the night and can’t go back to sleep, you can also try applying cold compresses or ice packs to pulse points in the neck, wrists, ankles, and behind your knees.

title.en-US: Is it normal to feel like you’re failing at work after baby?

content.value: Answer from Back-To-Work Coach Mary Beth Ferrante

Yes, this is quite a common feeling among working mothers—they feel like they’re failing not just their kids but also their careers. It takes some effort, but it’s important to retrain your mind to focus on what’s going well at work. Perhaps you’re not the first one in or the last one out, but maybe you scored an important new client or played a key role in getting a project off the ground. If you’re being too hard on yourself, you may have unrealistic expectations of what you “should” be accomplishing at work. Remember that everyone has days or periods when their efforts fall short of perfection.

If your feeling bad stems from missing out on opportunities—for instance, drinks with colleagues, networking events, etc.—because you have a baby you have to run home to, remind yourself that you are making trade-offs, and that’s OK. What’s more, you don’t always have to miss out. Even if you can’t go to everything, plan to attend at least a few after-work activities each month. Sure, you might miss bedtime once a week, but you’ll be there those other six nights.

title.en-US: Taking a laxative during pregnancy: Is it okay?

content.value: Read this before you head to the drug store in an attempt to get things... moving.

Try dietary changes first. If you’re not drinking at least six to eight glasses of water a day, start sipping your way to more hydration. And don’t skimp on fiber, which can put the gas pedal (instead of the brakes) on your digestive tract. If diet and lifestyle changes—like making sure you get some exercise each day—don’t get things moving, a mild product like Metamucil is generally considered safe. It works by softening your bowel movements and making them easier to pass. Just be sure to consult your doctor or a Maven practitioner before you try it (or any OTC medications, for that matter).

As for other “stimulant” laxatives? They’re not recommended. These products can trigger the muscles around your intestines to squeeze and move stool through your colon, and they can also jump-start contractions. If you’re suffering with pregnancy constipation during pregnancy and have more questions, book a chat with a Maven OB-GYN or nurse practitioner.

title.en-US: The real cause of postpartum belly and what to do about it

content.value: Having a baby changes your body in more ways than you probably ever expected. But it’s especially frustrating when you don’t know why things are happening—and what you can do about them. If you’re looking down at your midsection and feeling like the bulge isn’t just leftover baby weight, you could have a common post-pregnancy condition known as diastasis recti.
What, exactly, is diastasis recti?

Understanding the condition requires a quick biology lesson: The two sides of your main abdominal muscle (rectus abdominus) are held together by a connective tissue called the linea alba. It’s normal to have a small space between your ab muscles whether you’ve had a baby or not. The problem occurs when too much pressure from your growing stretches out this tissue, leaving a bulge (a.k.a. “mommy pooch”) where the separation occurs. A separation that's more than two centimeters wide classifies as diastasis recti.
So how common is it?

Research suggests that roughly 60% of moms at six weeks postpartum have diastasis recti. That said, some experts believe that number could be a lot higher since many women aren’t evaluated for the condition after giving birth and plenty of cases go unreported.
How do you know if you have it?

It’s a good idea to have your doctor confirm it, but if you’re reading this article and want to do a quick test, try this easy self-check. (Disclaimer: Be gentle. The last thing your body needs is aggressive poking.) Lie on your back with your knees bent and your feet flat on the floor. Place your hand on your belly, fingers at your midline. Engage your pelvic floor (as if you’re trying to stop yourself from peeing), then lift your head and shoulders a few inches off the ground like you’re doing a crunch. Now, feel for the muscles on each side of your finger (do this check from your naval down to about two inches above your pubic bone). Note how much of a gap is in between your ab muscles. You can measure it in finger-widths; a separation of two or more fingers means you likely have the condition.
How do you treat it?

Sometimes the condition heals on its own. There are also special exercises you can do that “knit” your abs back together, but it’s important to do the right kind. Some ab moves such as crunches make things worse, not better. While treatment varies from person to person, it usually involves specific core work plus pelvic-floor exercises and breathing techniques. Talk to your doctor about a course of action, or book a video appointment with a physical therapist in Maven’s network. Our pelvic floor physical therapists are specially trained in issues like diastasis recti and can provide a specific recovery plan.

title.en-US: Maven real talk on IVF with Shauntae

content.value: 40 years old
Self-employed
L.A.
Why did you decide to do IVF?
I was 38, which is considered “advanced reproductive age” and I’d already had multiple miscarriages trying to conceive. My husband and I desperately wanted a baby.
Did you have any biological kids before you started IVF?
No. We started IVF in 2015, did one cycle but it failed. Then we spontaneously got pregnant in early 2016 (naturally), and had our daughter later that year. We started another IVF cycle in 2018.
How did you choose your clinic?

I was referred via a doctor who happens to be a friend of mine. We were working out together one day and I started opening up about my fertility challenges, and that’s when she recommended her doctor.
Would you say you had a positive patient experience?
Yes.
How much have you spent on IVF?
$20,000—all out of pocket. Not everyone knows that it’s costly to store embryos; we pay $500 per year.
What surprised you most about the procedure?

It’s so much to think about emotionally. I was working full-time while going through it, my husband was traveling a lot for work, so it was just a lot to process. Also, I wasn’t prepared for the number of hormones I had to take and what these hormones did to my mood and my skin. My skin went crazy, acne-wise.
What could have made your patient experience better?
I wish that it were a less costly procedure. Even if you have a two-income family, it’s a financial stress.
What was the most difficult part of your IVF experience?
The fear of the unknown and the devastation when it doesn't work.
Any tips for managing the emotional stress of IVF?

I worked out a lot! Everyone has their own way of managing stress, but exercise was key for me. Another thing that’s helpful: Try to find another woman who’s gone through it so you can ask questions and get support.
Any tips for dealing with the stress that IVF can put on a relationship?
Someone needs to educate men more on what we are going through. Sometimes they don't get it.
If your best friend was about to go through IVF, what would you want her to know?

Get a support group, prioritize managing your stress, and try not to think too much about the cost because if you get a baby out of it, you don't really care. Also, do PGS testing on all of your embryos. Through testing, we learned we had some abnormal embryos, some really good ones, and others that were really great. It’s helpful to know that the embryos they implant have the highest possible chance.
Do you have any plans to do IVF again?
Fingers crossed, probably not. I'm technically 12 weeks pregnant now—we haven't told anyone yet, but all is looking good so far, and yes, this pregnancy was via IVF!

title.en-US: How soon can you start exercising to lose the baby weight?

content.value: Before you hit the gym, hit the pause button. It’s important to prepare your body—and mind—so you can safely shed the pounds. Here are four musts for every postpartum woman who’s thinking of lacing up her gym shoes.
Get the green light from your doctor

Experts say it’s important for moms to give their bodies a break after childbirth. It’s OK to want to take the pounds off, but check with your doctor before you start an exercise program. Two weeks postpartum is a minimum “wait period” before exercise can resume; most moms need 4-6 weeks. And if you’ve had a C-section, at least 6-8 weeks is usually recommended. But keep in mind that every woman’s body is different, and be patient with yourself if you need a bit more rest time.
Set realistic goals

The frustration of not being able to fit into your pre-pregnancy jeans may lead you to think you have to work out to YouTube videos every time your baby naps. But if you start telling yourself that you need to lose the weight fast, you’re setting yourself up to have unrealistic expectations. There are lots of factors that play a role in how quickly (or slowly) women lose weight after having a baby, including genetics, how much sleep you—and your newborn—are getting, and your emotional state. Setting extreme goals could be a set-up for giving up entirely: If you feel you can’t possibly reach them, you may think, “Why bother?”
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Don’t ignore your pelvic floor.

Pelvic floor problems are common after birth, whether you delivered vaginally or by C-section. (By the way, the term pelvic floor refers to a group of muscles at the base of your pelvis which support the bladder, bowel, and uterus.) But experts say that when women are eager to start shedding pounds, they often forget what their pelvic floor has just been through and may launch back into their pre-baby activities too soon. Signing up for a 5K right after giving birth might not be the best idea; activities like running and jumping put too much pressure on this area. A Maven physical therapist who specializes in pelvic floor function can help you develop a program to strengthen the area and—if you’re a running fan—get back to the track.
Consider a walking program.

Once your doctor gives you the green light to start exercising again, set yourself up for success. That spin class across town or 2-hour yoga immersion you loved before getting pregnant may have been realistic back then, but you’ll probably need to find activities that are more accessible (read: fast! nearby! stroller-friendly!) now that you’re a time-strapped mom. One of the best activities for postpartum weight loss? Walking. Besides being low-impact—which is good while your body is still in recovery mode—you don’t need to get to a gym to do it. Simply tie up your sneakers and head outside. Bonus: Being outdoors will also provide a little bit of mind-clearing you need.
There are lots of factors that play a role in how quickly (or slowly) women lose weight.

title.en-US: Can fevers during pregnancy raise autism risk?

content.value: What the science says.

With about one in 68 children in the U.S. having autism-spectrum disorder, it’s normal for expectant parents to worry about this diagnosis. Luckily, researchers are continuously trying to identify all the factors that could be involved in developing autism. One 2017 Columbia University study suggested that expectant moms who come down with fevers while pregnant have a 34% higher risk of having a baby with autism. Those who had a fever lasting a week or longer—which could have been caused by flu or another infection—were three times as likely to have an autistic child.

The researchers are not sure exactly what the link is, but one theory is that fever-induced inflammation could play a role in a baby’s brain development. If you do get a fever, don’t panic. About 20% of women in the U.S. come down with fevers during pregnancy, and the vast majority go on to have perfectly healthy kids. Likewise, there are children who develop autism even if their moms didn’t report fevers during pregnancy. What the experts are talking about here is just a risk factor. Knowing that this is one possible risk could lead to finding better ways to manage fever during pregnancy as well as discovering strategies to prevent the cause of fever.

So what should you do if you come down with a fever? Never ignore it or brush it off, says Jackie Stone, MD, a Maven OB-GYN. Maternal fevers are associated with many unwanted outcomes, including birth defects and preterm labor. The good news is that there are ways to treat a fever and get back to being a healthy mom-to-be. “Acetaminophen is highly effective and is the recommended medication for fevers in pregnancy,” says Stone. “If you have a temperature of 100.4 or higher, I recommend taking Tylenol and notifying your doctor.”

title.en-US: The key to avoiding conflicts with your caregiver

content.value: While it isn’t always comfortable to think about the arrangement with the person who will look after and nurture your little one as a business relationship, in the long run, it will be better for everyone if there’s a bit of formality involved. Enter: The nanny contract. Setting clear expectations—and writing them down in a formal doc—helps both parties know what they’re signing up for. A signed nanny contract is legally binding, meaning you can both count on some level of protection in case the unforeseen happens. What’s more, instead of being left wondering what you want and need, your nanny will know your wishes—so she can confidently deliver. Read on for a few details you may want to include.
Clearly define your nanny’s responsibilities.

She’ll care for your kid(s), of course, but are you expecting her to double as a housekeeper? (Keep in mind that not all caregivers are right for a nanny-housekeeper combo role, so you’ll need to be clear about your needs when you first start your search.) If your nanny agrees to do any of the cooking, cleaning, or laundry, be specific about those tasks. Two loads of laundry per week? Light tidying up, or a full scrub-down of the house when the baby is sleeping? Walking the dog? You get the idea. The point is to be as detailed as possible to avoid any misunderstandings or conflicts later.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Have a payment plan.

Will you pay your nanny every week, or bi-weekly? By the way, to get a ballpark idea how much nannies typically get paid in your area (the average varies greatly by where you live), you’ll need to do a bit of research. You can check out PayScale.com, Sittercity.com and the International Nanny Association. Keep in mind, the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) entitles nannies to minimum wage rules as well as time-and-a-half (1.5 times their normal hourly rate) when they work more than 40 hours over the course of seven days. Decide how you want to keep track of her hours, and include this in the written contract.
Define your time-off policy and other benefits.

How much notice will you need when your nanny requests time off for a vacation? Will she be paid for any vacation and personal days, as well as holidays? If so, which ones? What health benefits, if any, will you cover? Will you pay your nanny on days when you’re unexpectedly at home and don't need her to come—such as snow days or when you’re out from work because you or your child are sick?
Consider your nanny’s expenses.

Will you reimburse your nanny for gas when her driving is work-related, such as picking up baby items or taking your child to the doctor? Will you allow her to eat any food/snacks you have in the house, or do you expect her to pack and bring her own meals?
Forecast your vacations.

Will your nanny join you for family vacations, and how many hours per day will she be on duty? Will you be paying for her meals when she eats with your family, or providing a per diem? If you won’t need her on vacation, will you pay her for the days you’ll be away?
Set the social media boundaries.

Your nanny may have several social media accounts, and you may have a few opinions on how comfortable you are with info about your family being shared. What’s OK with you, and what’s off limits? Set these guidelines in writing so you don’t, for example, see a video of your child taking his first steps on Instagram before you’ve witnessed it for yourself. Or so your caregiver doesn’t “check in” to every spot she visits with your baby, announcing her location to friends as well as strangers!
Be as detailed as possible to avoid any misunderstandings or conflicts later.

title.en-US: 3 surprising rules for baby skin care

content.value: When you became a mom, you quickly realize that the amazing baby skin that feels and smells so delicious actually needs some serious TLC. The truth is, it’s incredibly delicate and sensitive, and taking care of it right requires some expert know-how. We consulted a Maven pediatrician for three ways to make sure your baby’s birthday suit is always safe, smooth, and protected.
Know when to cover that baby up.

We hate to spoil that family trip to Barbados, but the general thinking is that it’s always best to keep infants out of the sun as much as possible, especially when they are younger than 6 months. You can go on vacation, of course, but it’s important to “stay in the actual shade, and making sure your baby’s arms, legs, face, and head are covered (go for lightweight but long-sleeved shirts, pants, and hats),” says Dr. Amy Brandon, M.D., a pediatrician in Maven’s network. “By the way, Babiators is a great brand of sunglasses for the smallest babes.” Can’t avoid the sun? Brandon offers this advice: “If you’re in an unavoidable situation and don't have the right clothes or shade to protect your baby, a small amount of sunscreen—with an SPF of at least 30—on the exposed areas, like a baby’s face and hands, is preferable to allowing them to burn. But this doesn’t mean we should lube them up from head to toe for a full day at the beach. I always advise parents not to let the sun shine on that sensitive baby skin. It’s not just a sunburn issue; infants are far more susceptible to overheating which can lead to dehydration (their temp regulation mechanisms aren't super reliable).”
Relax about bath time.

As a new parent, you’re probably trying to keep track of everything you need to add to the Raise-a-Tiny-Human to-do list. Finally, one thing you can do less of: bathing your baby. Turns out, a nightly bath isn’t necessary. The goal is to keep moisture in a baby’s delicate skin and avoid rashes—and overdoing bath-time can dry thing out. Of course, a daily wipe-down of the diaper area with a washcloth is a good idea. But two or three baths per week is plenty.
Skip the baby powder.

Baby powder = powder for baby skin, right? Surprisingly, no. The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) and most pediatricians recommend leaving this product on the shelf. The ingredient in traditional baby powder that puts it on the Don’t list for baby care is talc, which has the potential to cause breathing trouble and lung damage for babies if particles are inhaled. As for cornstarch-based powders, ask your pediatrician. While some experts think they’re fine to use sparingly, others are more wary. Your best bet is a cream. “I recommend Aquaphor for preventing diaper rash, and Triple Paste to treat a bad rash; you can usually find both at Target or Amazon,” says Brandon. “If a rash does arise, set aside the pre-moistened baby wipes for a few days and clean the skin with just lukewarm water on a washcloth or a disposable cotton pad.” And one last word of advice from Brandon: “Be sure to ask your doctor if you notice any raw or skin that’s weeping a fluid or pus. On Maven, we can recommend or even prescribe some heavier-duty diaper creams, or advise when it's time to bring baby to your offline pediatrician for an in-person assessment.”

title.en-US: How do you know if your baby is eating enough?

content.value: Answer from Pediatrician Amy Brandon, MD, IBCLC
There are a few signs. Usually, you’ll know your babe is getting enough to eat when...
...she seems satisfied or “done” after feeding.
...she can wait (fairly) patiently until the next scheduled feeding.
...she has at least 6 wet diapers a day.
...your doctor is pleased with her growth charts at regular checkups.

Parents who have started solids often worry that their baby doesn't like eating cereal/peas/pears/whatever, or that it goes everywhere but into his mouth, or that their BFF's baby (who is the same age) is eating way more than their own little guy. Remember this mantra: “Foods before 1 are just for fun.” What this means is that until about 12 months, a baby gets almost all of his nutrition from breastmilk or formula.

The introduction of solid food before this is more to give baby exposure and practice eating—not to fatten him up! Another common misconception is that a well-nourished baby should poop daily; some little ones do go once or more per day, but some, especially breastfed babies, can have stools as infrequently as once a week—and this can be perfectly normal. If you have any concerns about what your baby is or isn't eating (or is or isn't pooping), hop on a Maven appointment with a pediatrician.

title.en-US: How should you ask for a flexible work schedule after baby?

content.value: Answer from Back-To-Work Coach Mary Beth Ferrante
Ask!

Of course, you can't have something you want if you don’t have the willingness to ask for it. Start by writing down the benefits to you, and more importantly to the organization, then put together some talking points. If you’re asking for the option to work remotely, you could highlight benefits such as increased focus and an ability to manage your time better and be even more efficient.
Anticipate any concerns.
For example, what’s your plan for communicating with clients and other team members? Thinking about any sticking points, and prepare your response.
Propose a trial period.

If your manager has some resistance about signing off on a flex work schedule, suggest that you try it out for three months, with periodic check-ins about how things are going. This may help your boss get comfortable with the idea.
Wow them.

Whether you’re starting off with a trial period or have been giving the green light to work from home, make sure you are showcasing how successful you can be in your role with your new schedule. You may even want to track any metrics that are measurable to highlight your achievements.

title.en-US: How long does it take for your belly to go down after birth?

content.value: Answer from Nurse Practitioner Rebecca Callahan, MSN, WHNP

Every woman has a different body type and a different pregnancy journey. Much of how your belly looks after delivery depends on your pre-pregnancy weight, your weight gain during your pregnancy, and if you are breastfeeding.

Another big factor is if you have developed diastasis recti. Diastasis recti is a separation of the abdominal muscles which often occurs during pregnancy. If you want to get technical about it, it refers to the two rectus muscles being separated more than 2 cm. It is affectionately referred to as “mommy tummy,” although it can sometimes be prevented with the right strengthening exercises during pregnancy. Proper physical therapy can help repair this condition in the postpartum period.

Right after childbirth, you obviously lose the weight of the baby, the placenta, and the amniotic fluid. However, your body is undergoing a lot of hormonal changes at this time and is still retaining a lot of extra fluid. Do yourself a favor and try not to get on a scale for at least a month after the arrival of your little one. You will be peeing a lot of that extra water weight out, and, if you are nursing, you can usually count burning an extra 300-500 calories a day.

If you have had a vaginal delivery, your OB or midwife will usually give you the green light to get back to your exercise routine after your six-week check-up. If you’ve had a C-section, you may not get the OK until at least eight weeks postpartum. Try to be patient with yourself and your body. You just birthed a human being! Get as much rest as you can and book an appointment with a Maven practitioner if you have any questions. Maven nurse practitioners, nutritionists, physical therapists, and lactation consultants can give you critical guidance during this period.

title.en-US: Is “anticipation anxiety” taking over your pregnancy?

content.value: The closer your delivery date gets, the louder the “what-ifs” can become. Learn how to manage your fears and stay calm during the home stretch.

Anticipatory anxiety centers around one main question: What If?! What if something goes wrong during delivery? What if I can’t handle the pain? What if my baby isn’t in a position to move down the birth canal?

It’s normal to think about the unknown, and wonder how your delivery will go. But letting the anxiety get too intense isn’t useful. So what can you do? First, make sure you’ve educated yourself. In psychology speak, when there’s a disconnect between the perceived event (i.e., a difficult labor) and your perceived ability to handle it, you end up anxious. If you’re afraid of a hellish childbirth, one of the best ways to tamp down the fear is to get rid of some of the unknowns. In other words, try to learn as much as you can about what actually happens during labor so you’re as prepared as you can be. Sure, delivery complications could still happen, but talking to your OB-GYN or an instructor at a birthing class, or polling your friends who’ve been through it, will help you realize that doctors have ways of dealing with whatever might occur. Having answers to all your questions will go a long way toward putting your mind at ease.

It’s also good to remember that anxiety is more likely to appear when you focus more on the future than the present. To bring yourself back into today, ask yourself, Is there anything useful I can be doing right now instead of worrying? You might, for instance, decide to pick up some pain-management techniques from a doula; exercise; practice meditation to learn how to cope with stress. Once you move past the mental chatter and spring into action, the jitters may start to go away.

If you're pregnant and you think you may be suffering from serious anxiety, talk to your OB-GYN or midwife—or book an appointment with a Maven practitioner. They’ll either treat you directly, or can connect you with the appropriate mental health care provider who can.

title.en-US: Secret signs you’re doing a great job after parental leave

content.value: Adjusting to work life after parental leave is not easy. Many working parents we speak with say the hardest part is truly believing that they are the same competent, capable, kick-ass employees they were before having a baby. And when self-doubt sets in, it’s even more of a challenge to perform at your best. Sure, some managers make it a point to give new parents the feedback they need during this transition. But, let’s face it, some bosses are less effusive than others. If you’re wondering how things are going, here are a few signs you’re on the right track—even if your boss isn’t doling out the praise and gold stars.
You’re given more flexibility

If you’ve successfully negotiated a more flexible arrangement after having a baby, like working from home a couple of days a week, try not to fall into the “out-of-sight, out-of-mind” paranoia. After all, empowering you to work with less supervision is a sign that your boss believes in your ability to succeed without having to keep a close eye on you. That said, checking in with your boss occasionally to make sure she’s still happy with your work can put your mind at ease even more.
You’re asked to give input

If your supervisor regularly turns to you to ask for your opinion, or gives you a voice during meetings, you’re probably doing something right. This is a good sign that your ideas matter and your presence within the company is valued.
You’re given high-stakes responsibilities

If you're feeling a bit overwhelmed with all the important duties that landed on your plate after maternity leave, it can be hard to see the silver lining. But if you’re asked to deal with major clients, or making decisions that affect the company’s bottom line, your boss likely thinks you’re capable of handling whatever needs to be done. Little footnote: This still doesn’t mean you’re not allowed to ask for help when you need it; it’s just a big sign of your boss’s trust in you.
You’re getting regular check-in requests from your boss

If your manager is checking in on you and asking how things are going since you’ve been back—and even offers to get you some extra help—don’t assume you’re being doubted or interrogated. Often, this is a sign that your boss is invested in keeping you on the team—and wants to make sure you have the resources you need to succeed.

title.en-US: When self-esteem dips the lowest during the postpartum period

content.value: If your confidence has been on a roller-coaster ride since getting pregnant, you’re not alone.

We hear a lot about how pregnancy and motherhood lead to changes in a woman’s body, but what about her emotions? Well, researchers from the University of Tilburg in the Netherlands surveyed more than 84,000 women to see how expecting a baby and becoming a mom affected their self-esteem.

What they found: During pregnancy, most women saw a decline in their self-esteem. After giving birth—and for the first six months of their baby’s life— new moms reported an increase in their self-confidence. But then things start to take a dip again, and they can take a while to recover: Three years post-baby, most women still hadn’t regained the self-esteem they had before they got pregnant.

What gives? The six-month uptick in self-esteem could be related to having accomplished a major victory (um, bringing a child into the world) and the sense of meaning and purpose some women say they feel as a new mom. But once this high wears off, seeing yourself as the rock-star you are may become more challenging.

If you’ve recently had a child and you’re reading this news, don’t despair. Knowing the commonalities women experience during motherhood can help you feel less alone on days when you’re not exactly riding high on confidence. What’s more, you can use this information to actively look for ways to boost your self-esteem now and sustain your confidence over the long haul.

If you notice that you’re having more days of self-doubt and fewer days of, “I’ve got this!,” don’t be afraid to open up. It’s normal to have fleeting feelings of inadequacy as a mother, but if they become persistent, they could be a sign of a mental health issue that warrants a call to your doctor or a chat with a counselor on Maven’s platform.

title.en-US: 5 things to know about babies & sleep

content.value: If your partner just had a baby, the one thing you probably already know about sleep is that the two of you aren’t getting much of it. But you might not be aware of all your infant’s sleep needs. Here’s a primer:
Babies were born to sleep.

Knowing how much sleep your baby needs can be confusing when your sister's baby gets 19 hours of shuteye a day and your next-door-neighbor's infant gets 15. The truth is, all babies are different, and some may need a little more or less than sleep than others. But newborns typically sleep 16 to 18 hours, in total, per day. By four months, that total sleep time may drop to 12 to 16 hours—think 10 or 11 hours at night (with a feeding or two in the middle of the night), plus a few daytime naps. Yes, there's a reason the expression "sleep like a baby" exists.
Babies aren't born knowing day vs. night.

Put it this way: There was no dimmer setting in the womb, so babies don't exactly associate darkness with sleep-time. You can begin to teach her the difference between daytime and nighttime by keeping the days bright and more stimulating, while making sure evenings are dark and quiet. Even when you're feeding a baby in the middle of the night, do so in a dim room and keep the environment boring (i.e. no Netflix in the background).
Babies have short sleep cycles.

That means if your baby is fussing after about 30 minutes and you think she's going to burst into wakefulness, she could just be getting ready to enter the next sleep cycle. Resist the urge to pick her up, since she'll likely fall back asleep on her own.
Put the nursery naps on hold.

Guidelines from the American Academy of Pediatrics suggest that your baby sleeps in the same room as you and your partner for at least the first six months—but not in your bed. Sleeping in the same room can help reduce the risks of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS). Other must-dos to keep your baby safe: Always put her to sleep on her back, and make sure the crib or bassinet is totally clear—no pillows, toys, stuffed animals, even blankets. As for the baby’s binky? Interestingly, research has found that the use of a pacifier during sleep greatly reduced the chances of a baby suffering from SIDS.
Conking out should happen in the crib, not on you.

If you're waiting for your baby to fall asleep before putting him down in the crib, he may not learn to put himself to sleep without your help, or drift back into snoozeland after waking up in the middle of the night. Once your baby is sufficiently drowsy—but still awake—it's fine to bring him to his crib. And as tired as you will be during these first few months, it’s a good idea to avoid falling asleep with your baby on your chest. There's a serious risk of accidentally suffocating your child if you happen to roll over on the bed or couch.

title.en-US: How long does it take to recover from childbirth?

content.value: Answer from OB-GYN Jacquelyn Stone, MD

Hello, supermoms! We all feel like we need to tie on our capes and conquer the world, but this is one instance where you get to give yourself some much deserved rest. You just grew a baby and brought that person into the world. That’s some strong work, and it takes a toll on your body. While the standard answer is that most new moms can go back to usual activities (including sex and exercise) in six weeks after a vaginal delivery or six to eight weeks after a Cesarean section, the truth is that every woman is different.

If you had a complicated pregnancy, a difficult delivery, or certain medical problems, your recovery may take a little bit longer. You also have a newborn now, which means you’re likely in for very little sleep. Although pregnancy hormones can throw us for a loop, postpartum hormones can also make us very emotional. So, don’t get discouraged if it takes several months to really feel like yourself again (or to get your “new normal”). Get rest when you can, take care of yourself, eat healthy, and accept help when people offer it in order to recover well.

title.en-US: You work. Your child is sick. Now what?

content.value: Working parenthood can be challenging enough without dealing with the unpredictable. But kids—like the rest of us—get sick. That can lead to a double-whammy of stress: For one, there’s how painfully helpless you feel when your little one has a dreaded bug or worse, like a recurring illness. Then there’s the fear over how you’re going to manage things on the work front. The first thing to remember is that you’re not alone. This is a common struggle, and you will survive. Here a few things to make the my-child-is-sick-days a little (or a lot) easier.
Be thoughtful about your communication.

The best way to get support from your organization? Give your office the heads-up soon as you know you’re on sick-child duty. At the same time, assure your manager that you’ll do what you can do to deal with the most urgent matters. If your child’s illness will prevent you from being online for a few hours, let them know that, too. Communication is key.
Make it easier on yourself to work from home.

When your child is sick and your only choice is to work remotely, you don’t want to find yourself in a “Where’s that file?” situation. If possible, make arrangements so you’ll have access to the tools/servers/whatever you’ll need at home to do your job. Plan B: Have an “office buddy” who you can call on for help—someone who can email you an important file, or help you get your hands on anything essential that you might need.
Plan ahead.

Sure, you might not be able to predict when your child will come down with a cold or an ear infection, but the reality is that you can count on (unfortunately) a sick day happening sooner or later. So it’s a good idea to consider your game-plan. A few things to think about: Who might you be able to rely on for back-up childcare? If you’re co-parenting, how will you and your partner decide who’s on baby-duty? A little bit of “what if?” strategizing now may save you a lot of anxiety later.
Don’t let access to medical care be harder than it needs to be.

Sometimes you can’t avoid bringing your child to the doctor. But there will be times when a FaceTime appointment will give you the answers, the prescription, or simply the reassurance you need. Ask yourself: Will your pediatrician likely make things a little easier for you on days, or more of a hassle? If you’re at home with a sick child and need to consult someone right away, remember that pediatricians in Maven’s network are available almost 24/7.

title.en-US: 3 debates couples should settle before they have a baby

content.value: You and your partner might already be discussing baby names, childcare options, and how long the grandparents are allowed to invade your home. But there may be a few important discussions you think you can put off for now. Here are three biggies experts recommend hashing out before your little one arrives.
