How will you split the parenting duties?

Some experts say that when it comes to a couple’s happiness and overall satisfaction in the relationship, it’s not a 50/50 split of parental duties that matters most. It’s having a clear understanding of who is doing what. You and your partner don’t have to have a formal meeting involving Excel sheets and charts, but it’s a good idea to get on the same page about baby duties before you give birth. How will you tag-team on feedings, diaper changes, household chores, and the zillion other to-dos soon to be on your list? Duties may shift when your little one arrives—and staying flexible is a must in parenting—but talking about things early can help prevent serious burnout from not having a plan and shouldering too much on your own.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Who will be your baby’s pediatrician?

Finding a doctor you and your partner both like sometimes takes a bit of effort, and it’s worth getting a head-start on your search. Many pediatricians welcome appointments with prospective parents so you can get acquainted and see if it’s a good fit. (Getting recommendations from friends is often a good place to begin scoping out the doctor scene, and we also have pediatricians on Maven’s network that you can video chat with anytime). The important thing is for you and your partner to agree on the doctor qualities that are important to you. For instance, do you want someone who will give you options about how to care for your child and let you decide? Or do you want someone who doesn’t leave much room for debate? If your partner thinks you’ll have plenty of time to “test out” different doctors after your baby’s arrival, keep this tidbit in your back pocket: One study found that infants who were examined by the same pediatrician during their first six months of life were more likely to receive appropriate preventive health screenings.
What will your sex life be like?

If you’ve already been having less sex, especially in your third trimester, you’re probably not going to be psyched to bring up the reality of post-pregnancy sex with your partner. But the more open communication you have now, the healthier your relationship—and sex life, when it resumes—will be later. Most physicians recommend waiting at least until your 6-week postpartum check-up (and getting the green light from your doctor) before having intercourse. And some couples don’t get back in the swing of things until several months after childbirth. Every woman is different, and you won’t know how you’ll feel—physically and emotionally—until after you give birth. Bringing this up in conversation with your partner is worth it, simply so you both know you’re entering a state of unknown.
Talking about things early can help prevent serious burnout.

title.en-US: Are sleep aids safe during pregnancy?

content.value: Trouble conking out? Read this before you hit the medicine cabinet.

Sleep aids can be safe, but there are some rules. Generally speaking, Benadryl is OK to take in any trimester of pregnancy. Just make sure it's Benadryl without pseudoephedrine—a nasal decongestant found in allergy-relief medications. Tylenol PM—which is essentially a combo of acetaminophen mixed with Benadryl—is also typically considered safe. But you’ll definitely want to talk to your doctor before taking any OTC medicine on a regular basis while you’re pregnant.

As for sleep aids that are prescription? Since researchers don’t have hard facts about the reproductive safety of taking these medications—such as Ambien (zolpidem) and other sedatives like Lunesta (eszopiclone) and Sonata (zalepion)—OB-GYNs generally try to avoid prescribing them during pregnancy.
Book an appointment with a Maven practitioner to talk about healthy solutions to your sleep woes.

title.en-US: Do a baby’s eating habits start in the womb?

content.value: Learn how your little one’s palate begins to form even before you give birth.

You might not think of your baby gulping down a meal while hanging out in the amniotic sac. But by the second trimester of pregnancy, a fetus is able to swallow several ounces of amniotic fluid daily. And, it turns out, that fluid is flavored by whatever foods you ate and the beverages you drank in the last few hours. In other words, what you taste, your baby tastes. (Don’t worry about having to give up your hot sauce or other strong flavors in your diet—the taste experienced by your baby will be very blunted.)

So does this mean your food choices during pregnancy can influence the taste preferences of your child later on? One of the classic studies that set out to test this theory gave 15 women carrot juice to drink for four days a week during their last trimester of pregnancy. A control group of expectant moms was asked to avoid carrots during that same time period. Several months after the babies were born and solid foods were being introduced into their diets, both groups of moms tried to feed their infants cereal mixed with carrot juice (#yuck) as well as cereal that wasn’t spiked with the carrot flavor.
Get this: Babies whose moms drank carrot juice during pregnancy showed significantly fewer negative facial expressions for the carrot-flavored cereal compared with the plain cereal. Meanwhile, the infants whose mothers were a part of the control (the no-carrot group) had equal negative facial expressions for both the carrot-flavored and the plain cereal.

Based on this study and others, some scientists believe that the foods a woman eats when she’s expecting could shape a child’s eating habits for life. If you want your baby to be a fruit and veggie lover, it may be a good idea to start digging into plenty of salads and smoothies now. And if you have strong ties to your ethnic background, and want your kid to one day embrace your culture’s traditional dishes too, by all means keep eating them during pregnancy.

title.en-US: Should you have an amniocentesis?

content.value: Your baby’s home while in your belly is the amniotic sac. The fluid that fills the sac not only keeps your baby safe and protected; it also contains cells from the fetus that provide valuable information about your baby’s genetic makeup. Here’s what you need to know about amniocentesis—and how to decide if it’s right for you.
What, exactly, is an amniocentesis?

Amniocentesis is a procedure that removes a small amount of the fluid from your amniotic sac using a fine needle. The fluid is then sent to a laboratory to be tested for chromosomal abnormalities such as Down syndrome, as well as neural tube defects and other disorders.
Who can have an amniocentesis?

Anyone. But certain factors may make it more of a consideration for some women. For instance, you may make your decision to have an amniocentesis based on the results of your first semester screen or cell free fetal DNA test; if that proved worrisome, your OB/GYN may want to do more testing. (Remember, screens and ultrasounds can tell you if there’s a good chance there’s an abnormality, but they can’t diagnose a disorder. An amniocentesis, however, can confirm if there’s a problem.) Your doctor might also offer you an amniocentesis if you’re 35 or order (since there’s a higher risk of having a baby with a chromosomal abnormality), if you or your partner have a genetic disorder, if a previous pregnancy showed one of these chromosomal disorders, or if an ultrasound shows a birth defect, notes Jackie Stone, M.D., a Maven OB-GYN.
What is the procedure like?

First, an ultrasound is performed to see exactly how the baby is positioned in your uterus—that’s important so the needle isn’t able to harm the fetus. Then your health care provider inserts a thin, hollow needle through your belly and into the uterus to withdraw the fluid. You might feel some cramping during and after the procedure, so it’s best to head home and take it easy once it’s done.
When is amniocentesis done?

According to the Mayo Clinic, genetic amniocentesis is usually done between week 15 and 20 of a woman’s pregnancy. Amniocentesis performed earlier—before 15 weeks—has been associated with a higher rate of complications; we’ll get to what those are in a sec. (Sometimes an amniocentesis is done later on in pregnancy—usually after 32 weeks—to see if the baby's lungs are developed enough for birth. This would happen if your doctor thinks an early delivery may be a good idea to prevent problems for you or the baby.)
What are the risks?

Amniocentesis in the 2nd trimester carries a low risk of miscarriage—about .6%. (If amniocentesis is done before 15 weeks, the risk of pregnancy loss could be higher.) Other potential risks, although incredibly rare: Amniotic fluid could leak through the vagina after amniocentesis, or a baby might move a limb in the path of the needle while the amniocentesis is happening. This isn’t cause to panic; it just highlights the importance of working with an experienced provider; definitely ask the specialist or testing center about their miscarriage rate related to the procedure.
What if you’re having trouble deciding?

That’s normal; this can be a tough decision for many women. Ultimately, you and your partner—along with your doctor and genetic counselor—can weigh the pros and cons and make the choice that seems best for you.

title.en-US: How to prepare for IVF

content.value: IVF has the potential to be an emotionally, physically, and financially exhausting experience. If you are about to begin a cycle, here are some tips to help get ready for IVF:
Educate yourself and plan ahead.

Good decision-making involves being well educated and informed about your body, the IVF process, and your clinic. IVF creates a lot of anxiety, and one of the best antidotes for anxiety is information and knowledge. The more you know and understand about the process, the less stress you may feel. Take advantage of resources from your treatment center, talk to others who have been through IVF, as well as the many practitioners in Maven’s network who specialize in fertility.
Know the decisions you’ll need to make.

It is important to anticipate decisions that may occur during IVF and discuss your options ahead of time. How many embryos should be transferred while maximizing your chances for pregnancy and minimizing the possibility of multiple babies? You will also need to decide what you will do with extra eggs and/or embryos, i.e. freeze, dispose of, or donate them. If there is a possibility that donor gametes (sperm or egg) will be used in the cycle, it is important that you carefully discuss the issues involved in raising a donor-conceived child before starting the cycle. A big decision: how many cycles do you want to do? Maven has practitioners who specialize in these types of issues and can assist you in exploring these issues, or your Maven Care Advocate can help you find someone in-network with your insurance carrier if you wish to see someone in-person.
Tend to yourself and your relationships.

A long struggle with infertility may have taken a toll on how you are feeling about yourself, your relationship, and/or your relationship with others. It’s important to be in a good place emotionally and have your relationship on solid ground before starting an IVF cycle. Facilitate communication with your partner by setting a limited amount of time to talk about IVF, such as 20 minutes a day, and then put infertility talk aside. Discuss ahead of time your hopes and expectations of each other during the cycle. For example, do you want to be together at appointments? Do you want to be together on the day of the pregnancy test? Counseling can be very helpful when you and/or your partner are feeling depressed, unusually anxious, emotionally stuck or in a rut. An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure, so get help early before problems arise.
Build your support network.

Friends and family can be your best support or they can be your worst. Decide in advance who you will tell about the procedure by identifying who will give you the support you need. It can be helpful to designate a friend/family member as a "spokesperson" who will let others know, when you are ready, what is going on. In addition, there are IVF support groups and various other infertility self-help organizations. Maven Practitioners can also be a great resource to lean on. A great deal of healing can come from others who understand.
Know your stress and identify your coping mechanisms.

Each person experiences stress in different ways. Anticipating ahead where your stresses may come from will help in developing coping strategies. Know your own and your partner's styles for dealing with stress and what has helped in the past. It’s worth mentioning that exercise is one of the best ways to alleviate feelings of stress, anxiety and depression although the level of exercise may have to be adjusted during the treatment cycle. Meditation apps and other mind/body techniques used regularly can help in handling these feelings and dealing with treatment procedures, as well as acupuncture.
Decide what you have control over and what you don't.

To help eliminate any unnecessary stress, you will want to make your life as simple as possible during the cycle. This is not a time to make important decisions or changes in your life, such as a move or job change. If at all possible, avoid major undertakings at work that can add stress to your life. In addition, you will want to think about how to deal with other daily life challenges at work, at home, and with family and friends. You do have control over the choices you make in your daily life while how the treatment course progresses is usually out of your hands.
Anticipate problem areas.

Plan for possible changes and difficult times during your cycle, such as the waiting period after transfer and the day you will get the results. Expect the unexpected, as changes are frequently made in the cycle because of everyone's unique medical situation. There are possibilities for failure at every step of the cycle, from a poor response to medication to no fertilization after retrieval. Be ready for them, and know that there are always more options.

title.en-US: How sleep impacts your relationship during pregnancy

content.value: Pregnancy and marital stress often go hand-in-hand. But did you know that how much sleep you get can help—or hurt—your relationship?

Researchers at The Ohio State University recruited 43 married couples, and asked each couple to “discuss and try to resolve” a hot-button issue in their relationship (a.k.a. they had them enter into arguments). Money conflicts, intruding in-laws, or differences in communication styles were all fair grounds for “discussion.” Interestingly, the scientists discovered that a lack of sleep (less than seven hours for two consecutive nights) was associated with nastier, more hostile fights. Getting enough rest, on the other hand, helped couples hash things out constructively and even kindly.

The study took things one step further to show how physical health was also impacted: When given a blood test after their spats, those who didn’t get enough sleep the night before showed higher levels of inflammation in their bodies. Inflammation, has been linked with heart disease, cancer and other health problems. The takeaway: Lack of sleep isn’t great for your health, and stress isn’t great for your health, but when you combine the two, things look even uglier. Adults need 7 to 9 hours of sleep a night, and during pregnancy, you might require even more shut-eye.

title.en-US: What’s the best way to lose baby weight?

content.value: Answer from Nutritionist and Lactation Consultant Melissa Flynn, IBCLC, MPH, RD
Here are my top five tips for postpartum weight loss.
Move more.
Take the baby for a walk, do a quick exercise video while your little one naps, squeeze in a few squats while folding the laundry. All these small activities can really add up during the day.
Be mindful of portion sizes.

Quantity matters, even when you’re reaching for nutritious options. Foods like nuts and avocado, for instance, are healthy and filling but the calories can add up quickly. Limit a portion of nuts to 1 ounce (about a handful) and stick to 1/4 of an avocado per serving.
Snack!

It may sound counterintuitive to eat more, but snacking ensures you're never ravenously hungry, allowing you to make good choices at each meal. You’ll end up thinking with your mind instead of your stomach.
Eat balanced meals.

Each meal should contain a complex carb (like a whole grain, sweet potato, beans, or fruit), a lean protein, some healthy fats, and lots of veggies. By not restricting any food groups you're making sure your body gets all the nutrients it needs including fiber and protein, both of which digest more slowly which means you'll stay fuller longer.
Consider breastfeeding.

While it’s not a guarantee, many women do see the baby weight come off faster while breastfeeding. Making milk and feeding your baby requires a lot of calories, so the more you breastfeed the more calories you will burn. It might not make all the baby weight melt off but it can certainly help, and it’s certainly nutritious for your baby!

title.en-US: Is bug spray safe to use during pregnancy?

content.value: The best and worst insect repellents when you’re expecting.

Yes. The most effective kind of insect repellent contains DEET—and luckily it gets the green light. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, DEET used as directed (translation: don’t over-apply!) is safe for women at any stage of pregnancy.

The scientific evidence is limited (and some experts wish we had more studies on humans) but the research we have so far is reassuring. One study involving nearly 900 women found that when DEET was used regularly in the second and third trimesters, it didn’t cause any birth defects or affect a baby’s survival rate. Picaridin is another safe alternative that is safe to use during pregnancy, but the Environmental Working Group says repellents containing lemon eucalyptus oil should be avoided. As for “natural” sprays—like those with citronella and cedar: They’re fine to use but not as effective as DEET or picaridin at warding off bugs.

title.en-US: The emotional considerations of IVF

content.value: Many IVF patients rank the stress of going through IVF more stressful than any other life event, including death of a family member and divorce. The aspects of IVF that create this level of stress are multifaceted and affect every part of life including your relationship, your job, your emotional and physical state, and your finances.

Here are a few issues that IVF patients have reported to cause heightened levels of stress. Of course, each individual’s experience is personal and unique, and each individual will experience and cope with stress differently. This list is meant to inform, so you can get ahead of any stressors on the horizon.
Reduced sexual intimacy
Increased financial strain
Decision-making about embryos, their disposition and multiple pregnancies.
Religious, social, and moral issues, especially for those dealing with third-party reproduction, if these values conflict with the choice of treatment
The first treatment cycle is typically the most stressful for patients, with the possibility of high levels of confusion, bewilderment, and anxiety.

The 10-14 day waiting period between transfer and receiving the pregnancy test results is often described as the most difficult part of the cycle. Having had daily contact with your medical support staff during monitoring and retrieval, you suddenly are on your own after transfer and just have to wait.

The level of uncertainty about the outcome is often highly distressing. Research has shown that in order of perceived stress for patients, waiting to hear the outcome of the embryo transfer is the most stressful, followed by waiting to hear whether fertilization has occurred, and then the egg retrieval stage.

Additionally, dealing with the medical staff and with the side effects or potential complications of medical treatment has its own stress. You might experience hot flashes, headaches, mood fluctuations, injections, sonograms, and future health concerns.

Despite the stressful consequences of infertility and IVF, the good news is that research has shown that the vast majority of patients adjust well emotionally. Further, there seems to be no long-term impact on the relationship and individual functioning. In fact, some research has shown that the crisis of infertility may actually improve communication and emotional intimacy. Couples may learn coping skills and communication patterns that provide life-long benefit.

title.en-US: 4 scary new-parent moments (and how to deal)

content.value: You’ve just brought home a baby—operating instructions were not included. If you're feeling a bit anxious about certain aspects of mothering, rest assured: You’re in good company. The good news? That fragile-looking human in your arms is actually an incredibly resilient little being. And with a bit of guidance, you will soon feel like an old pro at this whole parenting thing. Read on for a few scary new-parent moments you might encounter—and why you should (really, truly) relax.
Scary moment #1: Touching the soft spots on your baby’s head

You might think that those soft spots on a newborn’s noggin (technically called “fontanels”) exist simply to cause you to hyperventilate—like when you wash your baby’s head and accidentally touch them. The reality: These areas are tougher than they seem, thanks to a thick fibrous covering. Just think of what they have endured getting through the birth canal! Fontanels are safe to touch (and important to wash to prevent flake buildup). They’ll typically close by the time your baby is two—when the bones in the skull have come together. Another thing you can relax about: When these soft spots look like they’re throbbing, it’s just the normal pulsing of blood. So when is there cause for concern? Bulging or sunken soft spots could be linked to health problems like dehydration and other serious health conditions, so let your pediatrician know as soon as possible.
Scary moment #2: Your sleeping baby is jerking all around

Seeing your newborn jerk uncontrollably in her sleep is, understandably, something that could send you into a panic (#majorunderstatement). But this phenomenon usually isn’t something to worry about. The technical name for these spasms is “benign sleep myoclonus” and they can happen because babies’ nervous systems are still maturing. One clue that these seizure-like movements fall into this “benign” category and are harmless? They only occur during sleep and stop instantly when a baby wakes up. Clues that you should worry and get to the E.R. right away: If abnormal eye movements accompany the jerky movements, or if you baby has trouble breathing, turns blue or the spasm lasts more than five minutes.
Scary moment #3: Trimming your newborn’s nails

We know: It seems like a form of baby torture. But if you don't trim your baby's nails—which grow very fast—he may scratch his face or eye. Many experts suggest doing the task while your baby is sleeping. And you’ll want
to go at it with a mini nail clipper designed for babies; they're much safer than adult-sized clippers. During the first few weeks of a child’s life, your pediatrician may recommend using only an emery board (a.k.a. nail file) to
avoid accidentally nipping the skin. If you do see a drop of blood, don’t fret. Just apply a bit of pressure and a dab of antibiotic ointment—and consider it a right of passage into parenthood.
Scary moment #4: Giving your teeny-tiny-slippery baby a bath

Soft baby skin is extra slippery when wet, so it's normal for new parents to put bath-time on their list of Top 10 (or Top 1000) fears. First thing to know: Until your baby's umbilical cord stump falls off, you'll be giving her sponge baths, using a soft washcloth and mild soap. Once baby is cord-free, you can move on to a plastic baby tub that fits into the sink and prevents the baby from slipping. Test the water to make sure it's not too hot—it should be just a little bit warmer than lukewarm. Two big don’ts to keep in mind: Don't keep the water running while your baby is in the tub, and never leave your child alone in the bath, not even for a second. (Terrifying but true: babies can drown in less than an inch of water.)

title.en-US: 4 tips for taking better maternity photographs

content.value: You don’t have to be Demi Moore or Beyonce on the cover of a magazine to stage your own maternity shoot. Many moms-to-be are getting in on this trend, and often they’re choosing to document their growing bump in an ongoing way, time-lapse style. Here are a few tips to keep in mind before you strike your next pregnancy pose.
Consider settling on a go-to pregnancy uniform.
This is one outfit you can wear each week (or each time you take a photo). Go for something monochrome—solid colors will keep the focus on your bump, not the busy pattern on your dress.
Avoid baggy clothes.

While you might be tempted to reach for your husband’s oversized button down, the whole purpose is to show off your belly. A simple T-shirt and maternity jeans, or a stretchy dress that you won’t grow out of as the months pass, is perfect.
Skip the selfies.

Bathroom-mirror selfies are fine, but having your partner, sibling, or best friend take the shots for you can help you bond over this experience and make it more fun. Let yourself feel special while they play the role of your personal photographer.
Keep a private collection.

Ideally, these photos will be for you, your partner, and—one day—for the child you’ll soon give birth to. It’s OK to share a few photos on Instagram or Facebook, but resist the urge to put it all out there. You’ll get to maintain a little privacy and also spare yourself the stress of looking for social approval—i.e. “How many likes have I gotten so far?”

title.en-US: How to deal with visitors when you have a new baby

content.value: Congrats, you had a new baby. And sometimes, by the sheer number of people stopping by to meet your little one, it can also feel like you opened a new motel. Let’s face it: Not all visitors are the same. Some will relieve new-parent stress and some will add to it. So when you’re figuring out how to raise a tiny human and running on zero sleep, visitor discretion is key. Use these tips before you roll out the welcome mat.
Don’t commit to visitors too far in advance.

Having a new baby grants you a pass to be a last-minute person. The reason: The postpartum phase is unpredictable, and you can’t really be sure how you’ll feel from week to week. Your little one might be snoozing fine right now, but two weeks from now, if the binkie hits the fan and you’re seriously sleep deprived, you might not be up for having the ladies from book club over. Let people know how much it means to you that they want to see you and meet your baby, but don’t feel pressured to commit too far in advance.
Make sure live-in visitors pass this cry test.

When the baby arrives, a relative might offer to stay with you for a bit. While this can be helpful—and the only chance you and your partner have of catching some shuteye—it’s important to think about who’s taking up residence on your pull-out couch. If you have a difficult relationship with someone (whether it’s your own mom, an in-law, or a friend), will you be able to be “messy” in front of them? There’s no denying that having a newborn isn’t always easy, and if you can’t “keep it all together” and have a meltdown, you just have to embrace it. Ask yourself this: Will I be comfortable crying in front of this person, or expressing my vulnerabilities? If the answer is no, you might want to reconsider.
Spread out the love.

Know what’s really exhausting? A string of back-to-back visitors who, well-intentioned as they might be, suck every last ounce of energy out of you. Whenever possible, try to stagger the visitor circuit so you can focus on being a new mom, and not acting like the president of the welcoming committee.
Subtly drop an end time.

Unless you know you won’t mind having your guest over for as long as she’d like to stay, set boundaries at the start. When making plans, you could say something like, “How about 2:30? I’ll have to put the baby down at 4—and that’s when I’ll try to sneak in a nap myself—so this way we’ll have plenty of time to catch up.”
Take advantage of opportunities to leave the house.

Visiting with the baby doesn’t have to happen on your sofa. If you’re going stir-crazy inside the house, arrange a date at a local coffee shop instead. Another benefit: You can say au revoir without any of the awkwardness when someone coming to your home overstays their welcome.

title.en-US: Can you drink alcohol while pregnant?

content.value: This is one of those hot-button questions that can bring out a lot of opinions and, um, testimonials. For instance, your friend might insist, “I had wine on occasion and my baby is perfectly healthy.” These anecdotes might be true, but the medical community is clear on their stance: It’s not worth the risk. Read on for more answers to everything you’re wondering about booze and pregnancy.
C’mon, will a little bit really do any harm?

Here’s the thing: Experts stress that there’s no way of knowing how much alcohol is harmful. Since there’s no “safe level,” it’s best to avoid drinking altogether. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) puts it this way: “Every pregnancy is different. Drinking alcohol might affect one baby more than another. You could have one child who is born healthy and another child who is born with problems.” Translation: It’s not worth the risk. That’s why groups like The American Association of Pediatrics and the American Congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists say definitively that the smartest choice for women who are pregnant is to abstain from alcohol completely. This includes all wines, beer, and mixed drinks.
How can alcohol affect my baby?

That dirty martini or glass of merlot enters your bloodstream and reaches your baby by crossing the placenta. The effects of alcohol in utero can range from mild to severe. The list includes everything from an increased risk of miscarriage to Fetal Alcohol Syndrome Disorders (FASD), which can lead to birth defects as well as intellectual development problems and mental health issues. The good news? This is one area of pregnancy risk that’s 100-percent preventable.

title.en-US: How can you avoid comparing yourself to other moms?

content.value: Answer from Mental Health Specialist Mercedes Samudio, LCSW, MSW
Know your strengths.

We always compare our weaknesses to other people’s strengths—and that’s a setup for feeling “less than” as a parent. One way to combat that type of comparison is to acknowledge what you do well as a mom. Are you great at getting your kid to sleep? Are you super engaged with your child during play time? Or, are you skilled at finding the right help you need for your home, like a nurturing babysitter? Whatever it is that you're good at, give yourself praise and acknowledgement for those things.
Find your tribe.

Comparison happens mostly in isolation. Without people to use as a sounding board and “reality check” our thoughts and help us reframe them, it’s easy to label ourselves bad and then wallow in self-pity. When you're starting to feel the comparison bug coming on, connecting with your tribe will help you see yourself in a new light, the way that friends who love you see you. (PS: If you struggled with tip #1 above, and can’t find things about yourself that make you a wonderful mom, ask those closest to you what you do well.) Make sure you pay it forward and point out the awesomeness in them, too. Ultimately, at the root of all comparison is judgment. Usually when we stop looking for flaws in others, we also quit turning on ourselves.
Use social media wisely.

We sometimes scroll through our feeds and begin to feel bad that our lives are not as good as the ones displayed. However, we forget that what we’re witnessing is everyone's highlight reel. That means you're only seeing what they want you to see and not the full picture of their lives. When you find yourself getting triggered negatively by what others are posting, take a break from social media for while. This helps you to reconnect to the people around you in a real and unfiltered way.
Just slow down.

If you could quiet your mind for a moment—long enough to check in with your true self—would you say you’re doing the best you can? When we strip away the noise of comparison (i.e.: “She’s doing a better job than I am!”) and refocus our attention on our own experience, we can see clearly whether or not we’ve put our all into something. We also remember that we’re each unique and have different skills and ways of doing things. Tapping into these intuitive truths can help sidestep the comparison that makes us feel like we're not as good as others. Trust that whatever you're doing is the best that you can do in that moment.

title.en-US: Braxton Hicks: What they really feel like

content.value: If this is your first pregnancy, you might not have known that contractions can happen as early as the second trimester (although they’re more common in the third). They’re your body’s way of warming-up for the actual birth and the technical name for these practice runs is Braxton Hicks contractions.
What do they feel like?

Braxton Hicks contractions start out as a contracting of the uterus, but they can also be felt higher up in the abdomen—some women describe a feeling that’s similar to period cramps. Others experience a rock hard belly, a sensation that the baby is pushing against the abdomen, and even a contorted belly shape. Many women say Braxton Hicks contractions don’t hurt, while others say they can be uncomfortable or even painful. (If the pain seems to be getting worse, not better, definitely call your provider.)
Is the warm-up exactly like the real thing?

Nope. Unlike active labor contractions, with Braxton Hicks contractions you can’t predict when the next one is coming. They are usually sporadic and last for just a few minutes. Braxton Hicks contractions happen more commonly at the end of the day when you’re tired or if you have a full bladder. If you notice that there’s a regular pattern of contractions that get progressively stronger and closer together, definitely let your doctor know, since that could be a sign of preterm labor.
Can you make them stop?

Some experts will tell you to “appreciate” Braxton Hicks contractions when they happen because they give you a chance to test-drive an actual labor. You can use them as an opportunity to practice the breathing and relaxation techniques you’ll rely on when delivery day comes. But if gratitude is going too far and you just want to know if there’s anything you can do to end the discomfort, try this: drink a tall glass of cold water. Dehydration is the number one trigger for these types of contractions. If you’ve been sitting around, take a brief stroll. And if you’ve been on the go-go-go or even exercising, take it easy and just rest.
Have more questions?
Video chat or message with a Maven OB-GYN. They’re available anytime you need reassurance about a symptom during your pregnancy.

title.en-US: 4 questions to ask yourself before making a childcare choice

content.value: Talk to working parents about what decisions are the most daunting, and chances are they'll mention childcare. Private nanny? Daycare? Nanny share? Drop-off at grandmas? It can feel overwhelming to think about who you should leave your little one with, but before you can consider your emotional needs, it’s important to look at the practical ones. Here are four things to ask yourself when you start your childcare search.
Do I know what benefits my company offers?

If your workplace provides benefits to help offset the hefty costs of child care in the U.S., make sure you’re clear on what you’re entitled to. Call your H.R. manager to ask what’s offered, such as reimbursements for child care or access to a backup daycare facility. Bottom line: You can’t take advantage of all the perks if you’re not sure what they are.
Do I really know my budget for child care?

We know it’s not the sexiest date night, but sitting down with your partner or a friend to calculate how much you can realistically spend on childcare will be worth it. Don’t just look at your salary; if your employer offers a flexible spending account (FSA) program, you can set aside some pre-taxed dollars (up to $5,000) for childcare expenses. Factor that in to your budget, as well as any annual bonuses and tax savings you can count on. Starting in 2018, the child tax credit—which gives you a dollar-for-dollar reduction on the taxes you owe—has doubled. So your baby might get you up to a $2,000 credit.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
How predictable is my work schedule?

If your hours shift regularly, it’s important to find childcare that can accommodate your changing schedule. For instance, if you’re set to pick up your child from daycare at 5:30, but end up working till 6:30, will the center have enough caregivers on staff during the night shift? And what are the extra costs for extended hours—if you’re regularly working late, factor this in to your budget. If you’re considering a nanny, does she have a hard-stop or can she be flexible with her hours? Every family’s needs are different, so what works for your neighbor or best friend might not be right for you.
What’s the commute like?

Unless you’re planning to employ a nanny who comes to your house, you’ll need to factor in how long it takes to get to your caregiver. If you and your spouse both work outside of the home, finding an option closer to your office (or your partner’s) may come in handier than daycare that’s close to home. This way, if your little one gets sick during the day, you can dash over as quickly as possible—Supermom cape optional.
Every family’s needs are different.

title.en-US: How much to stay in touch with work during maternity leave

content.value: New parents often wonder how much contact they should have with the office during maternity leave. While you may be looking for a clear-cut answer to this question, the truth is, how plugged in you should be is a personal decision. Whatever you decide, here are a few things to keep in mind.
It’s up to you to protect your away time

Interestingly, experts say that it’s usually the employee, and not the employer, who instigates communication during her leave. Lurking on email is OK. But once you start responding, you could send the message that, “Oh, they're back online!” If you truly don’t want to set up any expectations, peek but don’t press send.
Factor in the length of your leave

If you’re taking a short break, you might consider taking a complete break from office activities to really focus on your role as a new parent. If your leave is a few months or more, check-ins toward the end of your time off may help make your re-entry less challenging.
Give yourself some rules—and stick to them

If the idea of disconnecting completely makes you feel anxious, or just isn’t possible, make a plan for being in touch and stick to it. Maybe, for instance, you’ll check email once a week on Wednesday mornings, then step away. Consider your baby’s sleeping and feeding schedule—which, let’s face it, is all-consuming in the beginning—so that you can carve out times that work for you and your little one.
Keep your work FOMO in check

FOMO, a.k.a. fear of missing out, is a very real phenomenon for some people on parental leave. But resist the urge to stay hyper-involved in office happenings, especially if the reason is a reluctance to give up control. Colleagues who are picking up your work for you while you’re away will be happier to pinch-hit when they feel you trust them and aren’t micromanaging from your baby’s nursery.

title.en-US: The top 5 secrets to baby sleep

content.value: As with all things that are new, learning how to put a baby to sleep often requires some practice. So whether you’re a new parent or awaiting your little one’s arrival, don’t worry if you have more questions than answers about your baby’s shut-eye. To the rescue: Christina Gantcher, one of the most popular sleep coaches on Maven and the founder of Good Night Sleep Coaching. Here’s a round-up of Christina’s top 5 tips from our latest webinar, Secrets to Baby Sleep. (PS: If you missed it, stay tuned for the next one.)
1. Make feeding a priority.

You already know that establishing healthy feeding patterns is important. But you might not know that eating and sleeping go hand in hand. In other words, feeding issues could disrupt your baby’s ability to get the sleep she needs. If things aren’t going smoothly, talk to your pediatrician or book an appointment with a Maven lactation consultant for some guidance.
2. Create the right sleep environment.

Babies love routine, and that includes having a predictable place to conk out. Once you establish your baby’s sleep space, make sure it meets these three criteria: 1.) It’s quiet. 2.) It can be made dark. 3.) It’s free of toys, blankets, and pillows (that’s important for your baby’s safety).
3. Put a tired baby—not a sleeping baby—in the crib.

Common wisdom says: Wait till your baby is sufficiently drowsy (a.k.a. almost conked out) before moving him to his crib. Christina’s advice? Watch for cues that your baby is getting tired, but don’t wait until the deliriously drowsy moment to put him down. This technique helps babies learn to put themselves to sleep. Of course, you can stay in the room with your baby until he dozes off, gently patting his back and offering comfort and vocal reassurance.
4. Know that sleep time isn’t one-schedule-fits-all.

One of the most common question Christina hears from parents: “How many hour should my baby sleep?” Her response: There are general guidelines to follow (a cheat sheet is below). “But ultimately, if your child seems rested, that’s more important than the actual number of hours logged.”
REPLACEWITHASSET
5. Remember, your sleep matters, too.

While it can be tempting to catch up on life, throw in a load of laundry, or respond to emails when your child is sleeping, try not to neglect your own shut-eye. Extreme sleep deprivation has been linked to an increased risk of postpartum depression. The lesson here? Sleep when your baby sleeps.

Have more sleep questions? Book an appointment on Maven to video chat with a Maven sleep coach. They can help you develop a personalized sleep plan and tackle any issues that are getting in the way of baby’s (and mom’s) rest.

title.en-US: Can white noise help your baby get better sleep?

content.value: What you need to know before plugging in these sound machines.
How do white noise machines help babies sleep better?

They cancel out noise such as conversations in the other room, cars driving by, and other distractions that may get in the way of your little one’s Zzz’s. What's more, they actually recreate the sound of the womb. Being in mom’s belly is noisier than you’d think, so infants may associate a constant, lulling sound with that soothing space they occupied before being born.
I’ve heard conflicting advice about sound machines—what should I believe?

You’re right—while some parents and even doctors swear by these devices, others are concerned about the potential harmful effects that could be caused by misuse. One study conducted in 2014 got a lot of press after revealing this finding: At maximum volumes, all 14 of the white-noise gizmos that the researchers tested exceeded the recommended noise limit for infants in nurseries—50 dBA.
Does that mean you shouldn’t use a white noise machine?

Not necessarily. Some baby sleep experts adhere to the belief that safe use is possible, and say that they can make a huge difference for sleepless babies (and parents). Ultimately, the decision is between you and your doctor. If you’ve gotten your pediatrician’s OK to use one, the best way to protect your little one’s ears is to stash the device further away from your baby (skip the models that are designed to be attached to a crib) and keep the volume to a low level. Limiting how long your baby is exposed to the sound is another tactic some experts advise.

title.en-US: How mindfulness can make labor & delivery less scary

content.value: No matter how much you read about childbirth, or learn what to expect, there will always be a certain amount of unknown. While deep breathing and meditation can’t change that, evidence suggests that mind-body training can help you cope with your fears and even have an easier delivery and postpartum experience. Read on for the science behind pregnancy mindfulness.
Doesn’t everyone fear childbirth?

Well, there are degrees. A little bit of nervousness is normal, but if it’s intense, you may want to learn some coping strategies. Get this: When researchers in Norway looked at how anxiety and fear affect a woman’s experience of birth, they found that labor takes 47 minutes longer for women whose fear-factor was high.
How can mindfulness training help?

Simply put, mindfulness is attempting to be more aware in everything that you do, and that mentality can be applied to anything—including giving birth. The theory is that by learning to be in the present moment, you don’t need to worry so much about what will happen in the future. Instead of approaching childbirth with a great deal of anxiety, you may see it as something you can manage moment by moment. And when you’re in the delivery room and a killer contraction hits, you may be able to remind yourself that the pain will pass, and it’s OK to keep pushing.
If I’m already taking a childbirth class, can I still benefit from mindfulness training?

Definitely—and there’s research to prove it. In a small but promising study, first-time moms in their third trimester were offered either a standard childbirth preparation course or an intensive workshop based on mindfulness-based childbirth education. Those who participated in the workshop were taught skills for coping with childbirth anxiety, and picked up practices like sitting and walking meditation, and knowledge of how to use mindfulness training to manage pain. (They were also given handouts and guided audio materials so they could practice at home.) The result: They felt more prepared for giving birth, and were less likely to use opioids to manage pain during labor.
Of course, there’s nothing wrong with using medication if you choose to, but mindfulness may add to your arsenal of tools to bring into the experience. It even appears that training your mind could make you more resilient in pregnancy and during the postpartum period: Interestingly, the researchers found a reduction in depression symptoms in the mindfulness group, which continued through their follow-up appointment at approximately six weeks after they gave birth.
The bottom line:

Mindfulness skills may help you cope with the unknowns of labor as well as help you adjust to being a new mom. If you want to learn more, book an appointment with a mental health specialist on Maven’s platform. They specialize in mind-body approaches that can make a big difference in your journey to new motherhood.

title.en-US: Ugh. Hemorrhoids during pregnancy (yes, they’re a thing.)

content.value: Your body goes through so many changes during pregnancy—that’s expected. But if no one warned you that one of those changes might be a case of hemorrhoids, we’re so sorry to be the ones to break the news. Hemorrhoids are more common than anyone wants to believe. By some estimates, 25% to 35% of pregnant women suffer from hemorrhoids. That number could climb up to 85% in the third trimester. Here’s everything you do/really don’t want to know about hemorrhoids—including a few ways to lessen the misery.
What, exactly, are hemorrhoids?

Scientific definition: Hemorrhoids are swollen blood vessels inside your rectum or outside your anus that can be as tiny as a pea or as large as a cherry tomato. Real world definition: A throbbing pain that makes it difficult to sit, walk, or focus on anything other than your backside.
How will you know if you develop them?

There are a few telltale symptoms—and trust us, they’re hard to miss. Hemorrhoids that pop up on the outside are usually itchier, but the ones in your rectum may cause more pain, and may also lead to rectal bleeding. P.S. You should definitely call your doctor if you notice any blood in your stool.
Why are hemorrhoids more common during pregnancy?

Well, the reason is twofold. First, as your uterus and baby grow, there’s more pressure on the veins below your uterus, causing them to swell. That’s why flare-ups tend to be worse in the third trimester. Constipation—another common issue during pregnancy—is another factor. Being backed up can be a result of an increase in progesterone, a hormone that may slow down your intestinal tract. And when you’re constantly straining to have a bowel movement, it’s easy to end up with the ‘rhoids. Your doctor may suggest stool-softeners to help move things along.
How can you treat hemorrhoids?

As always, you should check in with your OB-GYN or book an appointment with a Maven practitioner before you give any kind of medication or treatment a go—that’s especially important when you’re expecting. But here are a few tools that many women keep in their help-for-hemorrhoids arsenal. At home, sitting in a warm bath for 15 minutes, drying off, then applying a medication like Preparation H may help; OTC ointments like this form a protective layer over the tissue and can tame welling. Your doctor may also recommend a cream that contains steroids to soothe the inflammation. No time for a warm bath? A cold compress may also provide relief, as can using witch hazel pads after every bathroom visit.

title.en-US: A story of recovery from postpartum depression

content.value: 52 years old
Director of Corporate Development
New Jersey
Did you have postpartum depression or postpartum anxiety or both?
Postpartum depression
How did you know you had it?
I wasn’t formally diagnosed, but I was crying uncontrollably all the time, felt very isolated, and was indifferent about the baby.
Did your doctor or pediatrician screen you for postpartum depression/anxiety in your first few visits after giving birth?
No, my doctor did not screen me or ask me how I was doing emotionally. I wish he would have made an effort to see how I was managing after giving birth.
How soon after childbirth did you notice that something wasn’t quite right and you weren’t feeling like yourself?
Right when I got home from the hospital.
What were your symptoms?

I was crying and sleeping a lot, felt very insecure, trapped, and alone. At one point had thoughts (but would never act on them) of throwing my baby out the window. I share that because postpartum mental health is very serious. If it’s not acknowledged and spoken about openly, there could be consequences.
How open were you about your experience?
I spoke to my sister about everything, and shared a small amount with my husband.

Once you identified what you were going through, what helped you get better? For instance, did you go to therapy, go on medication, try mindfulness training and other holistic approaches, or something else?

My sister came to visit me, watched the baby, and told me to get out of the house—which is exactly what I did. I began to meditate and breathe consciously, and worked on accepting the place I was in. We often fight our situation when we are not comfortable with the changes happening around us and in us, but when we resist, it often makes things worse. (That was my experience, at least.) Another part of getting better was reminding myself that feelings are not always facts.
If you didn’t feel you had enough support, what could have made things better?
Having my sister stay with me—I felt safe with her. Going to meditation classes and a support group would also have been helpful.
What do you wish loved ones would have done for you without being asked?
I wish that friends had offered to watch the baby so I could leave the house even for a half hour.
How long did it take to feel like yourself again, and what do you think helped you the most?

Honestly, right at three months postpartum, I woke up one morning and it was like a cloud was lifted. I really believe that I had a hormonal imbalance and once it began to balance out, I felt like myself again.
Did you have postpartum depression or anxiety when you returned to work? How did you cope?
I was fortunate to not have to work, but any time I was away from the baby I had horrible anxiety that something would go wrong.
How did your experience impact your relationship with your significant other?

It sucked. His life continued and mine stopped. I wish my husband’s life stood still—like mine did—for longer than just a week. He still went out socially; I felt jealous, angry, resentful, and so many more emotions. I felt our life together was over, that we would never have that individual time as a couple back. He wasn’t very understanding which I felt pushed him away a bit more. My husband loved our baby, but it took him a longer than it took me to slow his life down.
What’s the one thing you’d like to see change about how our society perceives postpartum depression and anxiety?

That it’s real and needs to be addressed with all births. I wish hospitals had support groups for postpartum depression, anxiety, and what to expect after childbirth. It would be helpful if women were given the phone numbers of other new moms who where going through similar things to reach out to. Also, I’d like for doctors to not push for treatment with medication, but instead help women have the tools to work through these emotional issues.

title.en-US: 3 ways pregnancy wreaks havoc on your skin

content.value: When you’re pregnant, you’re naturally anticipating all the ways your body will be different—including changes that happen to your skin. Some of these aren’t a surprise (hi, stretch marks). But you might not be aware of other common skin issues that can creep up when you’re growing a bump. Read on so you know what to expect, and how to deal.
Melasma

During pregnancy, some women develop melasma, a condition in which areas of the skin on the forehead, cheeks, and upper lip become darker. This is often called “the mask of pregnancy,” and it happens because rising levels of estrogen and progesterone trigger more melanin to be produced. These pigment changes may go away on their own in the months after you give birth, but if they don’t, different treatments methods are available. Pricier options include non-invasive procedures like “micropolishing” as well as Intense Pulsed Light (IPL). Other skin gurus recommend going the Rx-route, which is much cheaper; your derm may prescribe a steroid cream that contains a bleaching agent. Staying out of the sun and making sure to slather on the SPF is also a must to avoid further darkening the pigmentation. If you’re a busy new mom who can’t get to your derm, book an appointment with a provider on Maven’s platform; they can make a recommendation and even send in a prescription to your pharmacy.
Acne

You may have thought hormonal acne was something you put to bed during your teenage years. But it’s not uncommon to see a flare-up after having a baby—even if you were blessed with a perfect complexion before. You can thank the intense hormonal fluctuations that happen to your body during pregnancy, childbirth, and lactation. If you’re breastfeeding and want to treat your acne, it’s important to know which products are safe to use while nursing and which should be avoided, since it’s possible to pass along ingredients to your baby through breast milk. Over-the-counter medicines containing benzoyl peroxide or salicylic acid are generally considered safe. There are also oral and topical antibiotics as well as other prescription drugs to treat acne that don’t pose any risks. Accutane, however, should never be used by nursing moms. If you’re concerned about post-baby breakouts, see your doctor or FaceTime with a Maven practitioner for advice on how to combat the bumps.
Varicose veins

You were expecting a bulging belly, but not those bulging veins in your legs—a.k.a. varicose veins. When you’re pregnant, you have more blood flowing through your body, making its way to placenta to provide nourishment to your growing baby. But this increase in blood volume can cause veins to enlarge. Another culprit: As your uterus expands, it can put pressure on the big vein in your body called the inferior vena cava, which also leads to swollen leg veins. Sometimes they’ll go away on their own, but when treatment is needed, the primary method is to literally close off the vein so that it collapses. This is called sclerotherapy, which involves injecting a solution directly into the problem veins that causes it to close, then fade away or disappear. There are other treatments a doctor may recommend based on the size of the veins (really large varicose veins may not respond to sclerotherapy). As for creams, ointments, and massaging techniques? There’s no evidence that they’re effective. Your best bet is to visit a specialist—whether that’s a dermatologist or a vein surgeon.

title.en-US: Tricky surrogacy questions—answered

content.value: Q: Is surrogacy legal in all states?

Surprisingly, no. While it’s more accepted in the U.S. than in many other countries, it’s still a polarizing issue. Since there’s no national consensus, surrogacy laws vary wildly depending on where you live. A few states, like California and Connecticut, allow commercial surrogacy, which means a surrogate can be paid to carry a child. Meanwhile, places like New York and Washington ban paid surrogacy. Since the laws are so tricky, some couples who want to use a surrogate have to travel to a state where the practice is legal. Want to know the rules in your state?
Click here.
Q: Should I use an agency?

There are definitely benefits to going this route. You can entrust experienced professionals with the (sometimes daunting) task of finding a good surrogate candidate. (By the way, there are two types of surrogates: A “traditional surrogate” is a woman who is artificially inseminated with the dad’s sperm but uses her own eggs—this type of surrogacy rarely happens these days. More common is “gestational surrogacy,” where a woman carries a child who has no genetic ties to her.) An agency’s job is to handle everything from background checks to health screenings, as well as psychological evaluations. They may also save you from a zillion logistical headaches, since they typically advise on financial and legal issues as well. That said, they don’t come cheap. Price-tags in the $100,000-range aren't uncommon.
Q: What if the surrogate doesn’t want to give up the child?

In most states where surrogacy is allowed, the baby is registered as the legal child of the intended parents right at birth. The problem is, surrogacy is not equally enforceable in all states. The best way to make sure you’re protected is to hire a lawyer who specializes in reproductive rights and can carefully put a legal agreement in place.
Q: Will I go into debt to have a baby?
There’s no way to sugarcoat it: Paid surrogacy isn’t cheap. Basic fees start around $30,000—and that doesn’t include the medical bills, egg-donor costs, and legal/agency fees.
Q: Should I be worried about the emotional difficulties involved with using a surrogate?

It’s definitely a good idea to explore your decision thoughtfully and thoroughly before moving forward. There are many factors to consider before you go down this path—some emotional, some practical. Talking to other women who’ve been through it is always smart; they can share their experiences with you—the ups, and yes, the downs. You never have to be alone in the process; Maven’s network includes therapists who specialize in reproductive issues and can help you sort out your feelings. Book an appointment to speak with a practitioner over a video call or text message.

This article is not intended to be a substitute for medical advice or care. Please consult a doctor with any questions you have before taking actions around your health and wellbeing. As always, our Maven practitioners are available, on-demand, to address your concerns.
Book an appointment here.
Sources: Surrogatemothers.org; Allthingssurrogacy.org; Surrogate.com

title.en-US: Can you ditch a healthy pregnancy diet in the 3rd trimester?

content.value: Read this before you break out the Brie.

A lot of moms-to-be feel like by the time that they have reached the third trimester, they’re in the clear and can take a few liberties with all the pregnancy rules. Unfortunately, the nutrition advice you followed in the first and second trimester still applies now.

A quick refresher of some of the rules: Deli meats and rare juicy burgers, sadly, will have to wait. It's also best to avoid soft cheeses such as Brie, goat, and blue cheese. And when you eat fish, choose varieties with the lowest levels of mercury.

But what about happy hour? OB-GYNs say they’ve heard women say, “I’m in the third trimester now so I’m golden—a drink or two can’t hurt.” But the truth is a baby’s brain can be harmed by alcohol at any stage in pregnancy. Bottom line: Play it safe now, but know that the Brie and wine you may be jonesing for are just around the corner.

title.en-US: Maven real talk on C-sections with Stephanie

content.value: 30 years old
Stay-at-home mom
Utah
What happened during your labor/delivery that you weren’t expecting?
My baby was face-up, instead of face-down, and my doctor told me I had to have an emergency C-section.
How did you cope?
I was terrified, but I knew my baby needed to come out one way or another!
What was your recovery like and are you recovered 100% today?

I nearly died. Because of severe blood loss, I needed four units of blood after the surgery. A week after being released from the hospital, I was readmitted because of complications. It turned out I had dangerously low levels of potassium and needed another three units of blood. Then a few weeks later, I got an infection in the surgical incision. Even now, 7-months postpartum, I wouldn’t say I’m 100% recovered. I’m still dealing with some pain, but I'm mostly back to normal.
How did it affect your relationship and/or sex life?

Since I still have pain every now and then, I am hesitant to have sex; it’s hard on my husband. I also have anxiety about getting pregnant again, given what I went through, although I know we want more children.
Did it affect your decision about if/when to have more children?
Before giving birth, I felt like we should have another baby soon after. But now I may wait a lot longer before we try again.
Any wisdom or advice to share, based on your experience?
Anything can happen. Expect the unexpected. Accept all the help you can get after you give birth.

title.en-US: The cost of raising a baby in year one might surprise you

content.value: Babies are awesome, exhilarating, and life-changing—but they’re definitely not cheap.

For all that we hear about how expensive it is to raise a child, many of us don’t know exactly how much it costs. A 2017 survey by the financial advice site NerdWallet.com found that a large percentage of Americans greatly underestimate the price tag attached to raising a newborn. Eighteen percent of Americans estimated that baby-related costs would be $1,000 in a child’s first year, while 44% said they’d expect to spend less than $5,000 in year one.

So what’s the reality? Every family is different, and there will be variation based on your income, where you live, and how you make money decisions, but based on the participants in this study (the survey was sent to 2,243 American adults) the real costs of raising a baby in the first year were between $21,248 and $51,985. The bottom line might be less for you and your partner, depending on your personal spending decisions, but the key takeaway from the survey is this: Expectant parents often don’t consider how quickly everything adds up, including food, baby gear, clothes, diapers, life insurance, and of course child care and healthcare. It’s never too early to start preparing yourself so your financial life isn’t so daunting when your baby enters the world.

Don’t panic if you and your partner haven’t sat down together to educate yourselves or make a budget yet—you can start having those important conversations now. The bright side of all this? Becoming a parent forces you to live with more financial clarity and deal with any money issues you may not have focused on in the past.

title.en-US: How to survive your baby’s sleep regression

content.value: Just when your baby’s sleep habits are getting good—or at least a little better than they were at the beginning—things take a nosedive. This is called the sleep regression, and it’s a common phase that typically occurs around three or four months. Depending on how bad things get, it can either be a minor bump on the sleep road or a bigger setback.
Why does it happen?
Not that this is much consolation for seriously sleep deprived parents, but as your baby’s healthy brain continues to develop, there may be an interruption in sleep patterns.
How do other parents get through it?

First, they remember that this period ends. Although the time can feel like forever, most regressions last from a couple of weeks to a month. A proper sleep environment is especially important now—keep the room dark and quiet at sleep and nap times. And remember that it’s best to put your little one down when she’s drowsy but not fully conked out; this helps your baby learn how to fall asleep again on her own when she awakes in the middle of a snooze-session. As for your own rest, make sure you’re not facing the brutality of sleep regression all on your own. Having a partner or a friend to help out when your baby isn’t sleeping may be your only chance at catching a few Zzz’s yourself.
Have more sleep questions?
Book a Maven appointment with a baby sleep coach. Their expertise in pediatric sleep issues can help when something is getting in the way of baby’s (and mom’s) rest.

title.en-US: The truth about breastfeeding & weight loss

content.value: We all know someone who claimed to “bounce back” to her pre-baby size without doing anything to lose the weight except breastfeed. So what’s the reality behind this tactic—and how many pounds can you realistically expect to drop if you’re nursing? Read on for the answers.
Is breastfeeding a good way to lose weight?

First things first: Some experts worry about the slim-down buzz overshadowing all of the other benefits of nursing, but the connection you’ve heard about between breastfeeding and weight loss is real. Research supports it can burn between 300 and 500 calories a day or more. Sure, that can make a difference on the scale, but depending on how many pounds you put on during pregnancy, it may not be the “fix.”
Why do some women burn more calories breastfeeding than others?

How many calories you burn while breastfeeding depends on a number of factors—like how often your baby nurses, whether you’re breastfeeding exclusively or supplementing with formula, and how much milk you’re producing. And (odd as it may seem) the calorie count of your goods also makes a difference. There are an average of 22 calories per ounce of breastmilk, but this can vary.
What if I’m not losing any weight?

First of all, don’t get too discouraged—you’re definitely not alone. Biology could be at play here: Prolactin, the hormone that regulates breast milk production, is released each time you nurse and can stoke your appetite. So the simple reason for weight gain may be that you’re eating more. As one mom told us, “While nursing my first son, my hunger levels were out of control.” But things aren’t always this straightforward. Other reasons the scale may be stuck include sleep deprivation, stress, and fatigue that leads to more sedentary, less active days. Try to cut yourself some slack, and definitely get support if you need it. The nutritionists on Maven’s platform can help get you on the right track. Remember that it’s best not to rush into a diet program until you’ve established a milk supply, so our experts can help you reach your goals in a healthy way.

title.en-US: What you need to know about the glucose screening test

content.value: Glucose screening checks for gestational diabetes—a diagnosis that about one in 10 women receive during pregnancy. Here’s what you need to know about this time-consuming but important test.
When does the glucose tolerance test occur?
Most women receive the test between weeks 24 and 28. But if your doctor is especially concerned, you may have it done earlier.
What’s involved in the test?
Basically, you drink a syrupy drink that contains 50 grams of glucose, wait around to see how it affects your blood sugar, and then have your blood tested about an hour later.
How awful is it?
We’re not going to sugar coat it (pun intended): This isn’t the most fun you’ll have during pregnancy. Many moms say the taste is hard to handle, especially if morning sickness is an issue for you.
What happens if the test is positive?

If your blood glucose levels are high, your doctor will likely recommend another test to rule out gestational diabetes. This time you’ll have to fast beforehand, and you’ll be given a drink with 100 grams of glucose and be tested a few times over three hours to rule out or confirm a diagnosis of gestational diabetes. If it’s positive, you and your doctor will work on a treatment plan for the remainder of your pregnancy.

title.en-US: Relationships after baby number two

content.value: 40 years old
Marketing
NYC
What was the hardest thing on your relationship after having a child?

The low point came after having our second child. My husband and I were no longer the cool, aspirational couple with a baby we handed off to each other while we each moved effortlessly between personal and work lives. We were exhausted, with no time to do anything well, in a relationship that was running on fumes. We were dealing with a long-standing, deep-seated build-up of issues around the division of responsibilities in our marriage. I was 34 years old—an age where I could really put my foot to the floor on my career growth, if only I could muster up the energy and drop the diaper bag for long enough. Shit was bad.
What was the best thing that happened within your relationship after having a child?

Having two kids under the age of two made me put on my big girl pants way before I knew how to potty train. It took courage to say to each other, "This shit is bad and I don't like you very much right now”—being committed to our relationship required us to have the hard talks and confront what was happening instead of deny it. We could do that, though, because of the profound love we had for each other and for the two incredibly awesome human beings we created.
How do you think you changed with motherhood?

Overall, I became more empathetic and tuned into how people (not just parents) were really feeling, even if they said they were “fine." In work, I think I'm a better manager as I have a more balanced point of view on work priorities that I didn't have pre-kids. I'm also much more open to new ways of doing things—not just my way. As any mother who's trying to get kids dressed and out the door in the morning will tell you, there is more than one way to put on a pair of socks in the morning....apparently.
How do you think your partner changed with fatherhood?

My partner became much more vulnerable. He was very successful professionally, popular socially, and had had a pretty linear path in life before becoming a father. The first time I heard him say, "I think I'm doing a bad job" was when it came to parenting and our relationship after kids. That must have made him feel completely unprotected; he had no prior coping mechanisms for dealing with those feelings, and had to unpack and deal with his own guilt, on top of supporting me emotionally, being the lead breadwinner for our family. His vulnerability and willingness to show up for me and our kids is what makes me love and support him the most.
In those early weeks of adjusting to motherhood, what did your support system look like and how did your partner fit into that picture?
With my first child, I was very independent. The second time around, I asked for help from anyone who gave me eye contact! My sisterhood was, and still is, my sisters and girlfriends.
Is there any advice you can give new moms about how to keep your relationship strong after having a child?

Communication and compromise. Don't let resentment build up. If they are the villain in your story (a.k.a. your bitchfest), there’s a good chance you are the villain in theirs. Even when you want to stick to your version, try extra hard to listen to how your partner is actually feeling.
Did you and your partner pursue couples counseling during pregnancy or afterwards? In retrospect, do you think therapy would have been helpful?
We didn't. I think we worked through most things together.
Do you feel like you had a more equal relationship before having children? Please explain.

Yes. Unfortunately the division of labor in terms of childcare and running of the house still falls mostly on women's plate. This is true of my own experience. Even if my partner is seen as a "hands on dad."
When did everything balance out again (if ever)?
WIP (work in progress).

title.en-US: The 4 friends every new mom needs

content.value: We often hear other women say, “I never needed my girlfriends more than when I became a mom.” The truth is, it doesn’t matter how big your inner circle is, as long as you have the right people to count on:
The friend who’s out of the “new-mom woods"

In other words, a friend with a child who’s a bit older than yours. She’s been right where you are now, and can give you the kind of wisdom only another mom can offer. She can also be a much-needed voice of reason/calm/reassurance when you’re facing all the (totally normal) baby surprises, like the many disturbing shades of newborn poop. Inheriting the onesies she no longer needs and other hand-me-downs? Bonus.
The childless friend

The day will come when you want to keep up with something other than feeding times and your baby’s nap schedule. When you need a break from the 24/7 role of being a parent, this is the friend you can call to dish about the news, the latest episode of This Is Us, whatever.
The friend who doubles as your therapist

Give yourself this quick gut check: Who’s the friend who’s most likely to tell you you’re doing an amazing job at this parenthood thing (PS: you are), let you vent about your mother-in-law, or keep reminding you that you don’t have to do anything perfectly? This is a good person to reach out to on days that call for some kindness, not criticism. Because when you’re dealing with the stress of being a new parent, the last thing you need is a pal who makes you feel worse about yourself instead of better.
The friend who always has your back

It takes a village to raise a baby? Sure. But sometimes just having one friend you can always count on will do. This is the BFF you can turn to when you need someone to watch your baby so you can sneak out for an hour to grocery shop, buy some jeans that fit, or even, you know, just take a shower.
One last thing...

If you ever feel alone, or your inner circle can’t provide all the TLC you need, we’re here to help. Maven therapists are experts in issues that new moms commonly face, and they’re available to video chat anytime you could use some extra support.

title.en-US: Is hair thinning normal after pregnancy?

content.value: Answer from OB-GYN Jacquelyn Stone, MD

Thanks to prenatal vitamins as well as pregnancy hormones, your hair may be super thick and luscious during pregnancy. Fast forward to life after birth, and your hair is coming out by the handfuls. What is going on with that?

Postpartum hair loss is so common that it actually has a name: Telogen effluvium. Up to 90% of new moms experience at least some hair loss, which peaks about four months after delivery and usually resolves by six to 12 months postpartum. It has nothing to do with whether or not you breastfeed. So, what does cause it? We think it’s triggered by the increase of estrogen in a woman’s body during pregnancy and the decrease in estrogen after childbirth. During pregnancy, there is generally more hair growth. But after you deliver, your hormone levels drop and the growth period ends. The medical term for what’s happening is that hairs enter the telogen, or "resting" stage. These telogen- or “resting”-phase hairs are the ones that shed.

The amount of hair loss varies from woman to woman but can be quite noticeable for some. I’ve had patients report clumps of hair falling out or feeling like their hair is super thin. Don’t worry! If it bothers you, you can use some volumizing shampoo or a new hairstyle that you feel good about. By your baby’s first birthday, your hair should be back to its normal thickness.

title.en-US: Can yoga help keep you sane during pregnancy?

content.value: It’s the next best thing to a daily prenatal massage. (Hey, one can dream.)

Sure, prenatal yoga may seem like one of those trends that was created for celebrity moms-to-be with a strong Instagram game. But besides being a gentle way to move your body and stretch your tired limbs, yoga is one of the best ways to de-stress when you’re expecting and manage pregnancy-related anxiety.

In fact, studies show that prenatal yoga can lower perceived stress levels, dial down back pain, and improve sleep quality, says Jackie Stone, M.D., a Maven OB-GYN. And the way you learn to breathe is more important than any physical challenge. That’s because yoga can increase your breathing capacity—and using your inhales and exhales effectively during each breath can make a big difference in your stress levels.

Even if the only pose you practice is Savasana—that’s the final resting pose that basically looks like the world’s most comfortable nap—you’re still doing something great for yourself by quieting your brain and giving your stress hormones a few minutes to chill. Trust us, as your pregnancy progresses, these moments will be golden.

While you can find plenty of prenatal yoga videos on YouTube to follow along with, there’s an added bonus to finding live prenatal yoga classes in your area: You may meet other women who are pregnant, and begin to build a community of support.

title.en-US: The art of burping your baby

content.value: One of the most satisfying, results-oriented tasks after having a baby: The burp session! Grab a cloth (hint: the end goal is getting your baby to spit), and consider this your Burping 101 guide.

You may not have realized that burping a baby is a little extra insurance against a cranky, finicky baby. The point of burping is to make sure babies rid themselves of any air they swallowed while being fed. When air is trapped, they’re more likely to be gassy and irritable.

Depending on your child’s need, you may need to be burping more frequently than you thought—even mid-feeding. When babies becoming fussy while they’re being fed, or shortly after, it’s a good sign that your burping duties should commence. That said, some babies need to burp a lot, while others rarely do.
