In general, breastfed babies don't need as much burping as bottle-fed babies because they tend to swallow less air when feeding. But every baby is different, so follow your baby's cues.
We know it’s hard to wake a snoozing baby, but sometimes it will be necessary to wake a baby who has just fallen asleep after a feeding. The bright side: a sounder, more comfortable sleep afterward.
There’s more than one method you can try, so keep these three in your baby burping arsenal:
Classic shoulder burp
With your baby’s head resting on your shoulder, gently pat and rub the back.
Lap lean
Sit the baby on your lap, facing away from you. Lean him or her slightly forward as you support the chest and head, then gently pat on the back.
Face down
Lay your infant across your lap, tummy-side down. With your baby’s head resting on your leg and face turned to the side, gently pat and rub his or her back.

title.en-US: 3 need-to-know facts about surrogacy

content.value: 1. There isn’t just one type of surrogacy.

First, a basic definition. In simplest terms, surrogacy is when a woman carries a pregnancy for another woman or couple. There are two ways to go about it. There’s "traditional surrogacy," which means the woman who provides the egg also carries the baby. And “gestational surrogacy,” which involves IVF: Embryos are created with eggs and sperm from the intended parents (or from donors), then they’re implanted into the surrogate’s uterus. Gestational surrogacy is the most common because the surrogate has no genetic tie to the baby she carries.
2. Not just anyone can be your surrogate.

This should put your mind at ease. Unless you’re choosing someone you know, like a friend or relative, a surrogate would have to go through a pretty thorough screening process and background checks before she can be a potential carrier of your baby. To be eligible, she must already have had at least one child of her own—and an uncomplicated pregnancy to boot. Medical screenings are in place to vet any potential red flags, including drug use or STDs. And of course mental-health evaluations help make sure she’s psychologically ready to enter this kind of relationship with you.
3. Knowing who to call “mom” is complicated.

The who’s-who in a surrogacy arrangement can be tricky. “Intended parent” is the term that refers to the mom-(or dad)-to-be. “Surrogate” is the woman carrying the baby to term. But terminology is only the beginning of what can be a very complex emotional experience. Will you attend your surrogate’s doctor visits? Do you want her to meet your family? The truth is, the relationship between you and the carrier of your child can only be established by you (and, of course, an agency can help if you’re using one).
Sources: CDC.gov; American Society for Reproductive Medicine

title.en-US: Can light therapy help with the pregnancy blues or depression?

content.value: The myth that pregnancy is sure to be the happiest times of a woman’s life may leave you confused if you’re not exactly a ball of joy. But according to The American Congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG), between 14-23% of women will struggle with some symptoms of depression during pregnancy. If you’re not feeling like yourself and think you may be depressed, know that you’re not alone. And you definitely don’t have to pretend you’re “fine.” Help may include talk therapy, as well as low-risk medication and/or non-pharmaceutical options. One treatment that doesn’t get talked about much is light therapy. Find out what it is and if it might be right for you.
How does it work?

Bright light therapy has been used effectively to treat seasonal affective disorder (SAD)—the kind of depression that sets in during the dark days of winter, and then lifts when the days get longer. Light therapy is also used to treat certain sleep disorders. Basically, the therapy is just what it sounds like: You sit near a device called a light therapy box that mimics natural outdoor light (also known as blue light). It’s believed that exposure to this kind of light can positively affect the chemicals in your brain that relate to mood and shuteye.
Is it a good option during pregnancy?

We don’t have any large, conclusive studies about light therapy use during pregnancy, but experts believe it can be useful and safe—particularly if the kind of depression you suffer from is mild to moderate and you and your doctor are reluctant to go the medication management route. One small study that was done published in 2011 in the Journal of Clinical Psychiatry showed some promising results: 13 out of 16 pregnant women with moderate depression had 50% or more improvement in symptoms after receiving light therapy for five weeks. Even better: They had no side effects.

If you’re struggling with depression, anxiety or any other mood issues during pregnancy, and need some support, book an appointment with a Maven OB-GYN or mental health provider. There’s no one path to feeling better, but with support, you’ll find the right path for you.

title.en-US: A Maven nutritionist’s top no-cook meals for busy parents

content.value: When you’re a busy new mom, you need quick and healthy meals that help you keep up with the hustle and bustle of daily life. Put these no-cook ideas from Maven nutritionist Camilla Lee into your dinner rotation, and you won’t have to resort to a bowl of cereal or PB&J sandwich ever again.
Easy Rotisserie Chicken Salad

Pick up a whole, already cooked rotisserie chicken from the grocery store. Not only is this a time-saving move, but it’s also an affordable way to make a bunch of meals. Maven nutritionist Camilla likes this healthy chicken salad, which requires minimal prep-work: Slice up some rotisserie chicken into a bowl of arugula, pumpkin seeds, chopped apples, parmesan cheese, and sliced red onions. For dressing, combine a bit of olive oil, vinegar, and Dijon mustard in a jar and give it a shake.
Healthy tip:
Removing the skin makes rotisserie chicken better for you.
Veggie-packed Tuna Wraps

Here’s an easy upgrade to a boring tuna salad: In a bowl, flake some canned tuna with a fork and mix in a little bit of olive oil, onion, capers, and tarragon or dill. Next, add in diced celery, tomatoes and/or fennel, and season to taste with salt and pepper.
Healthy tip:
Serve inside of lettuce wraps for a bread-free tuna sandwich.
Speedy Salmon Salad

Yes, you can turn the canned-food aisle into a nourishing meal—fast. Camilla’s go-to: Canned salmon (smoked works too) over greens with avocado, canned black beans (just rinse them under cold water first) and a simple dressing of lemon and olive oil. For extra flavor, add some red onion, cilantro, tomatoes, and crumbled feta. (At 80 calories per ounce, feta is lower in calories than many other cheeses.)
Healthy tip:
Opt for fish packed in water instead of oil when making a tuna or salmon salad.

title.en-US: Are prenatal massages safe in the 1st trimester?

content.value: The lowdown on rubdowns.

Considering the symptoms pregnant women deal with—insomnia, mood swings, swollen feet and ankles, and all kinds of stress—a prenatal rub-down may be just what the doctor ordered. Some studies have shown that massage therapy can improve mood and sleep, increase circulation, and help you relax.

But if you’re wondering whether or not it’s OK to get a pregnancy massage in the first trimester, well, that depends. Many massage therapists won't give pregnancy massages during the first trimester just because this is the time when miscarriages are most likely to occur, and they simply don’t want any liability issues. That said, studies don’t show that massage actually causes miscarriage, so if your doctor clears you for the treatment and the spa has no objections, you should be fine to get massage therapy at any point during your pregnancy.

One thing to think about, however, is how good (or bad) you’re feeling. If morning sickness is making you very uncomfortable, you may want to wait until the second trimester when symptoms tend to subside so you can really enjoy it.

And definitely call the spa in advance to find out if they have someone trained in prenatal massage, specifically, and what the treatment is like. Most pregnancy massage therapy involves lying on your side, but some spas also give the option to lie face-down table that has a cutout for your belly. And here’s a little tip: If you’re super sensitive to smells right now, get a whiff of any products they’ll use before you’re slathered in them.

title.en-US: 25 essential questions to ask in a nanny interview

content.value: Few conversations are more important than the one that will determine who will care for your little one when you or your partner are at work. So if you’re considering a nanny or a nanny-share, make sure you set aside an un-rushed hour (or more) to get to know any prospective candidate. Inviting her over to your home—and seeing how she interacts with your child—can tell you a lot. Remember: The more you ask, the easier your decision will be. Use this list of questions to find your best childcare fit.
Why are you interested in this job? Why did you choose to become a nanny?
What hours are you available? How flexible are you to stay late whenever needed?

Where do you live and how you would get to my home? Do you drive and have a car that’s reliable? What’s your driving record like? Have you driven for family you’ve provided care for before? Do you know how to install a car seat?
Do you smoke?

Are you open to doing any household chores? (Ask this if you’re looking for someone who can pick up some of the daily tasks like cooking and laundry, but keep in mind that a nanny’s primary responsibility is to look after your little one. For that reason, many parents consider keeping the chores to a minimum or hiring a separate housekeeper to do the heavy-lifting.)
Are you currently in school or do you have another job?
Will any of your personal or professional commitments affect your availability to provide childcare now or in the future?

What’s your experience with childcare and taking care of infants in particular? What did you find the most challenging about that experience? Have you taken care of multiple kids at once? (If relevant.)
What’s the longest you’ve ever worked for a family? How and when did your last caregiving commitment end?
Do you have any children of your own? How old are they?
What are your wage or salary expectations?
Would you be willing to provide contact info for parents you’ve worked for before so we can do reference checks?
In your view, what are the biggest challenges to being a good nanny?
What was the most difficult situation you have encountered in childcare and how did you resolve it?
What’s your go-to method for putting a baby down to sleep? And what precautions do you take to make sure a baby is safe in a crib?
During the hours my child is sleeping, what do you consider your responsibilities to be?
How do you handle a crying baby? How long do you think a baby should be left to cry?
When caring for a child, what circumstances do you think warrant a call to the parent? When would you call 911 before calling me?
Do you have CPR certification or first aid training? If not, are you willing to be trained?
What other professional development in childcare do you have?
How do you feel about playdates with other children?
How do you see your role as a caregiver changing as my child gets a bit older?
How do you respond to feedback from parents? How would you feel if I wanted a childcare issue handled in a very specific way that differed from your approach to doing things?
Based on our conversation so far, are you interested in the job?
Do you have any questions for me?

title.en-US: New parents’ guide to messy house guilt

content.value: Why is it that none of the recommended baby books tell you that having a child can turn your life and your house upside down? Even though keeping your little human alive is your priority right now, it’s hard not to feel like you “should” be able to be both an amazing parent and Martha Stewart. Just how pervasive is this pressure new parents feel? Surveys have found that messy-house guilt is right up there with the “I don’t spend enough time with my kids” guilt. Use this guide to do what you can to stay organized but also cut yourself some slack. Because coming unhinged over that trail of binkies you haven’t managed to pick up is so not worth it.
Try the snack method

Instead of telling yourself you need to carve out “at least an hour” to make a dent in the mess, take advantage of bite-sized snack opportunities to clean up. Experts say that once you lose the all-or-nothing mentality towards housework—or any work—you’ll be amazed by what you can accomplish. Even a 10-minute burst of time can lead to a sorted pile of mail or an unloaded dishwasher.
Focus on the “hot spots”

Now is not the time to begin a Marie Kondo-level organizing project. If you don’t have the energy to do a whole-house cleanup, focus on the most visible areas, or the ones that really get to you. Tell yourself that the rest can wait till you have more time to spare or when your baby is in daycare—or college.
Get help

Fact: It will be tougher to keep your home clean if you’re the only one in the household who knows where the broom is. Get your partner involved so you’re not carrying the weight of the world (and the laundry basket) all on your own. Besides ensuring that there’s a division of labor within the house, let others—like your mom or in-laws—pitch in when they want to help. And if outsourcing is an option for you, consider a cleaning service. If cost is an issue, it doesn’t have to be a weekly investment to make an impact. Try monthly or every other month for help with deep cleaning.
Feel good about the message you’re sending to other parents

You probably didn’t think that messy entryway filled with baby shower gifts, the stroller you haven’t gotten around to returning, and a month’s supply of diapers could be a service to all parentkind. But think about the message you’re sending others: You’re giving them permission to be a little messy and still feel like they’re doing a great job with this whole parenting thing. (PS: So are you.)

title.en-US: 5 changes your body goes through after a miscarriage

content.value: How is it that you’ve just gone through one of the most painful times of your life, yet no one tells you much about what to expect in the days or weeks to come? Here are 5 things that women who’ve had a miscarriage wish they’d known:
Your milk could come in.

First: This is more likely if you experience a loss in your second-trimester, and not all women will go through it. (Some just have breast tenderness.) But when it does happen, it could seem like nature’s cruelest joke: Your body is preparing to feed a baby you no longer have. It may take a week or two for the milk supply to completely dry up, but wearing a tight bra and using cold compresses can speed the process along.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Two words: Period problems.

If you see spotting after a miscarriage, don’t freak: It’s a normal part of the process and could last up to a few weeks. But if it seems to get heavier, not lighter, over time, make an appointment with your OB-GYN. She’ll likely do an exam to make sure there isn’t any remaining pregnancy tissue in your uterus. And when you do start ovulating again, know that it’s not uncommon for your periods to be a little out of whack for the first couple of months. Things should get back in sync on their own, but birth-control pills can help regulate your cycle. A video chat or a quick private-message session with a Maven OB-GYN
could bring the reassurance—or Rx—you need.
Cramps may kick in.

Your uterus has just been through a trauma, so it makes sense that you’d experience aches in your abdomen similar to period cramping. It’s usually nothing to worry about, but if the pain is ever severe, don’t ignore it—call your OB-GYN right away to rule out hemorrhaging.
You’re not peeing as often.

If you had a ripcord between you and the bathroom during your pregnancy, that urge to pee wasn’t random. The culprit? Pregnancy hormones (aka human chorionic gonadotropin, or HCG), which trigger changes throughout the body—including how much fluid ends up in your bladder. As these hormones leave your body, you may notice that you’re peeing less often—totally normal.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
An overwhelming sadness.

Anyone who thinks emotional pain can’t be a mind-body issue hasn’t experienced true heartache. Deep distress can bring on physical stress symptoms such as headaches, upset stomach, elevated blood pressure, and trouble snoozing through the night. Sadly, we can’t run away from the stress, but we can find ways to help manage it. Maven’s network includes therapists who specialize in pregnancy loss; they’re available anytime you need to talk through what no woman should go through alone.
Book an appointment.
American Pregnancy Association; Mayo Clinic
Nature’s cruelest joke: Your body is preparing to feed a baby you no longer have.
Deep distress can bring on physical stress symptoms such as headaches, upset stomach, elevated blood pressure, and trouble snoozing through the night.

title.en-US: How to survive a cold while pregnant

content.value: Colds are never fun—but when you’re pregnant, being sick is its own special misery. What’s more, treatment can be especially tricky when you have a baby on board. We answer a few common questions to help you feel better fast.
What should you do if you catch a cold during pregnancy?

The number one rule is to listen to your body and take it easy. Your first line of defense should be drug-free; drinking warm fluids, using a humidifier, and trying saline nose drops may help ease your symptoms. That said, not all OTC medicines are off limits. Some drugs have a good track record during pregnancy, but the lowest effective dose (taken for the shortest period of time) is the safest bet. According to the Mayo Clinic, when cough/cold medicines are used at higher doses and/or for a long time, the chance that problems might occur may increase.
What medicines are generally considered safe for treating a cold or cough?

You ask your provider about dextromethorphan, a suppressant found in OTC cold medications. Many studies suggest that there is no association between dextromethorphan use and an increased risk of birth defects. That said, you want to make sure dextromethorphan isn’t combined with other ingredients that could be harmful. For instance, some cough syrups contain high amounts of alcohol—which should be avoided during pregnancy. Another remedy to avoid: medicines containing iodine as an expectorant; these might cause serious harm to a baby's thyroid gland.
What can you take for aches and pains?

Most experts say that acetaminophen is safe to take in pregnancy as long as you stick to the dosing instructions. (One study about acetaminophen raised concerns that the medicine is linked to potential health risks, but more research is needed.) As for other painkillers and fever reducers, pregnant women should generally avoid taking aspirin and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as ibuprofen (in Motrin and Advil) and naproxen (in Aleve) during pregnancy. Studies have suggested they can raise the risk of birth defects or cause problems during labor.
The bottom line:
You don’t have to suffer unnecessarily; just be sure to get a doctor’s OK before hitting the drugstore. Maven practitioners are available to video chat anytime you need guidance or advice.

title.en-US: Could you have prenatal depression and not know it?

content.value: Pregnancy is supposed to be a magical, happy, blissed-out time—right? The truth is, for the significant number of women who deal with depression during pregnancy, it’s not exactly a joy ride. Here’s what you need to know about the condition, and how to get help.
Just how common is prenatal depression?

While postpartum depression gets most of the headlines, prenatal depression happens, too. In fact, an estimated 14 to 23% of pregnant women experience depression, according to the American Congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG).
What are the symptoms?

Symptoms will vary from person to person. You may experience intense feelings of sadness, sleep issues, or even paranoia that goes far beyond the common “am I doing this whole pregnancy thing right?” If you have a hunch that something just feels off, let your care team know or book an appointment with a mental health specialist in Maven’s network. Too often, maternal health issues get diminished or ignored, and you deserve support and proper screening—not a pat suggestion that “you’re just hormonal and it’ll pass.”
How does depression during pregnancy affect my baby?

Depression causes stress hormones such as cortisol to rise. Cortisol can cross through the placenta into the fetus, which could affect your baby’s development. Studies have found that women with prenatal depression are more likely to deliver premature and low-birth-weight babies. And since depression can also get in the way of self-care, other fallouts during pregnancy may include a tendency to miss doctor’s appointments, fall into unhealthy eating habits, and pick up smoking or drinking. All of those behaviors raise the risk for pregnancy complications.
How can I treat prenatal depression?

There are many ways to get help—the important thing is to open up with a professional who can work with you on the best course of treatment for you. Talk therapy, which comes in many forms, as well as lifestyle changes, are usually the first line of defense. But in more severe cases of depression, medications shouldn’t be ruled out. “It’s also important to note that for women who were on medications prior to pregnancy, relapse rates due to stopping medication are up to 68% according to studies,” says Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone. While some studies have found links between certain drugs taken during the pregnancy and problems for babies, the findings aren’t definitive. Just as important, a woman and her doctor have to weigh the risks of the drugs against the effects of untreated maternal illness. “Untreated maternal depression can lead to poor maternal-infant bonding,” adds Stone. There’s no easy answer, but don’t worry, you don’t have to make it alone.
Will my depression go away after I give birth?

Everyone is different. In some cases, prenatal depression ends once the baby is born. Others may go on to develop postpartum depression. Definitely stay in close touch with your doctor who can help keep tabs on how you’re feeling and make sure you’re getting the care you need.

title.en-US: Returning to work as a single mom

content.value: 33 years old
Senior Copywriter
New York
How long after having a child did you return to work?
14 weeks
Who cares for your child while you’re at work, and how did you make your childcare decision?
Daycare. The decision was financially based. I’m a single mom so I was basically forced to return to work, and the family daycare was what I could afford on my own.
Any advice for someone navigating childcare for the first time?
It sounds simple, but it’s key: Go with your gut.
What was the most challenging part about your first days back at work?
Leaving my daughter to be essentially raised by someone else.
Have things gotten easier/harder with time? How so?

Harder... so much harder. I was actually bawling in front of the office just this morning. The truth is, I’m trying to find a way to work from home. My daughter is only getting bigger and growing as time passes, and I’m missing it. I also don’t agree with everything the daycare does but I don’t want to complain about every single thing for fear they’ll be negligent, stop communicating important information to me, or retaliate in some other way.
How could your workplace have helped make the transition smoother?

They could allow more flexibility. I asked to work from home two days per week and was told I couldn’t—although other people in the company have moved to remote locations completely out of state and are allowed to work from there. It’s horrible.
Any tools or tricks that help you with work/life balance?
Always choose your child first. There will always be another job. But seeing your child grow up, right in this moment, happens once.
Did you have thoughts of quitting your job?

Every. Single. Day. I plot and plan how I can work for myself. I’ve only continued working for this company because I’m a single mom and this is my only source of income. If I had a partner, we’d definitely discuss my impending resignation! So for now, my plan is to continue working on starting my own business.
If your best friend was returning to work after maternity leave, what would you want to say to her?
Funny you should ask—my best friend is actually pregnant! I’ve told her it will be hard, and to be realistic with her expectations and her family’s needs.
What’s one thing you’d like to see change about the return-to-work conversation for parents?
That’s easy. In-office daycare centers.

title.en-US: Two words pregnant women never want to hear

content.value: If you cringe when you hear them, you’re not alone.

As you approach the end of your pregnancy, the well-wishes from acquaintances—as well as perfect strangers—will likely become a regular occurrence. And most of the time, they’re appreciated. It’s nice to feel like people are sending you good juju for childbirth and motherhood with phrases like...
“I’m really happy for you!”... “I can’t wait to meet your baby.”...“You’re going to be a great mom.”
But...
“Good luck!”
Good luck? The truth is, those are two words of encouragement that don’t sit well with every mom-to-be.
As one new mom put it:

“The more people wished me luck—like at my send-off into maternity leave at work—the more terrified I became. I thought, ‘I’m already freaked out enough without the reminder that I need luck on my side for what’s to come.”
Of course, if you’re fine with anything along the lines of
“break a leg”
and
“may the force be with you,”

that’s OK too. But if you cringe every time someone wishes you luck with bringing a child into the world, you’re not crazy or “overly sensitive.” In the same way that a patient about to go in for surgery may not want to hear “hope it works out!,” some pregnant women prefer words that are a bit more... comforting.

title.en-US: How cats (yes, cats!) can affect your pregnancy

content.value: Pet lovers, this advice is for you.

You might never think of contact with your kitty as anything other than furry love, but it turns out cats can pose a health hazard to you and your unborn baby. Before you panic, however, know that not everyone needs to worry, and there are precautions you can take.

Here’s the deal: Cats can carry Toxoplasma gondii, a parasite that causes birth defects, miscarriages and other serious pregnancy complications. Once cats have the disease (called toxoplasmosis), their feces can infect anyone who comes into contact with them. About 20 percent of Americans are infected with toxoplasmosis, but most don’t even know they have it because a healthy, non-pregnant person’s immune system can usually fight the infection.

Interestingly, if you’re pregnant and you’ve been a cat owner for a while, you may have already been exposed to toxoplasmosis and developed immunity to it. A test early in pregnancy will tell you for sure, and it can be repeated anytime. But taking steps to avoid a first-time infection is important.

Keeping your cat inside to avoid contact with the parasite and giving it tin food that’s cooked is key; never let your cat eat uncooked meat. You should also put your partner or another family member in charge of changing the litter box.

title.en-US: Pregnant? Read this before you take your next bath

content.value: Pregnancy and high temperatures can be a risky combination. But don’t worry, you don’t have to succumb to nine months of frigid showers. Find out the safe ways to feel the heat—and a few activities to avoid until your little one arrives.
Can I relax in a hot tub if I’m pregnant?

It’s not the best idea. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) recommends that pregnant women avoid letting their temperature get above 102.2o F—and spending just 10 minutes in a hot tub can do that. According to the Mayo Clinic, some studies suggest that hyperthermia—a.k.a. an above-normal body temp—during pregnancy is linked to birth defects and miscarriage. While the greatest concern is in the first trimester, most experts think it’s safest to skip these high-heat relaxation ops until after your baby is born. PS: This warning includes saunas and steam rooms, too.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Does that mean baths are off-limits?

Luckily, it’s fine for most pregnant women to take a soak in their bathtub. For one, the water starts to cool off as soon as you’re done filling the basin. The only caveat? Although nobody likes a lukewarm bath, just make sure the water isn’t too hot. You should be able to sit right into it without easing in inch by inch the way you might have to in a jacuzzi. Of course, if you start to feel faint or dizzy, it’s time to get out.
Do I get a pass on exercising because it raises my body temp?

Nope. Exercise has amazing benefits during pregnancy—it may decrease your risk of gestational diabetes, preeclampsia, and cesarean delivery. So unless your doctor has reasons to caution you against it, staying active right up through labor is usually smart. The CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) suggests that pregnant women get at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic activity every week. As with all things, listen to your body and don’t push yourself to unhealthy extremes, but if you feel good, it’s definitely OK to get your heart rate up and start sweating. As for Bikram yoga and hot Pilates—activities that take place in a heated room? While different experts have mixed views, the word from ACOG is that it’s best to skip these forms of exercise because of your risk of becoming overheated.
Although nobody likes a lukewarm bath, just make sure the water isn’t too hot.

title.en-US: Can babies be too serious?

content.value: Despite all your cooing and coaxing, you can’t seem to trigger you baby’s funny bone. What gives?

Some infants, just like some adults, are naturally more serious than others. “Up until about nine months, I had to work really hard to get a smile,” recalls one mom. “But now our daughter has a joyful little soul; I think she was just really a ‘thinker’ who was taking the world in.” In other words, just because you’re raising a SSB (Super Serious Baby) doesn’t mean you’re doing something wrong or that your child isn’t happy.

Experts note that every child is different, and temperaments aren’t one-baby-fits-all. As long as your baby isn’t uncomfortable or sick, don’t worry if she’s not constantly smiling when you expect her to. If you need some reassurance that your baby is happy as a clam (even if she’s crabby-faced), look for other cues of contentment. For instance, maybe she waves her hands or wiggles her little toes when you play Peekaboo or make funny faces.

The important thing is to continue providing as much affection as you can, and allow your child to be who she is. She will learn how to express herself and the joy she feels in her own way and in her own time. In the meantime, keep trying to figure out what your baby finds entertaining. And when she does let out a chuckle, you’ll know she’s truly amused.
One last thing...

As long as your baby is interested in interacting with you and generally social, there’s usually no reason to worry about something being developmentally wrong. But if you’re concerned and need some extra reassurance, don’t hesitate to talk to your pediatrician or a Maven provider.

title.en-US: 4 little ways to improve your body image during pregnancy

content.value: Interestingly, many women say their first trimester of pregnancy was the toughest on their body image. “It was too early to wear maternity clothes, so I felt like a stuffed sausage in my regular ones,” one mom recalls. “And I didn’t see a nice round bump yet, so I just felt fat.” Use these tips in early pregnancy and beyond.
Get sleep.

Ever notice how your mood always takes dip when you’re sleep deprived? It isn’t always easy during pregnancy, but do your best to prioritize rest. Feeling rested can have a surprisingly powerful effect on your body image.
Change the chit-chat.

Research shows that women are more likely to report being dissatisfied with the way their bodies look when their friends regularly discuss dieting, exercise, and weight. The next time you notice the dialogue with your pals going in this direction, shift the conversation.
Stay out of your partner’s closet.

If being comfy if your priority number one, by all means, steal your partner’s shirts and lounge freely. But if you’re telling yourself you look “frumpy” (p.s. not true!), resist the urge to drape yourself in baggy clothes, whether they’re from your closet or your partner’s. Pregnancy doesn’t mean you don’t deserve to feel good in what you’re wearing.
Avoid the bump-watch habit.

It’s natural to be curious about other expectant women’s experiences, but if you’re constantly comparing yourself to other pregnant silhouettes, you may end up feeling more despair. Remind yourself that everyone is different—and your body is changing because it’s doing a very important job of growing a human.

title.en-US: How do you deal with working parent guilt?

content.value: Answer from Back-To-Work Coach Mary Beth Ferrante
Focus on what you’re doing well at home.

So often we dwell on the ways we are failing. Instead, look for evidence of your parental accomplishments (promise, you’ve got them!). Sure, you may not be cooking homemade meals every night, but you might be devoting some time to bonding with your child by reading to him when you get home. When you recognize all the little ways you’re doing a great job, you may find your working parent guilt start to diminish.
Put your phone away when you’re with your kids.
While it can be difficult to disconnect from work, being more present at home can help you ditch the guilt. The idea is to focus on the quality of time with your family—not the quantity.
Take a break from social media.

Comparing yourself to other working parents who you think are doing it “better” only makes things harder—and we tend to forget that people tend to post things that show their good sides, not their bad. Unfollow friends who trigger comparison, get off the email chain about the mommy-and-me park dates you know you won’t be able to attend, etc. The guilt creeps in when you are reminded about the things you “should” be doing. As the saying goes, “Don’t should on yourself!”

title.en-US: 5 little ways to bond with your baby

content.value: Building a strong parent-child relationship starts now. Here are a few simple ideas that are effective for bonding—and having some fun.
Keep a journal.

Even if it feels like every day is an endless cycle of feeding and crying, trust us when we say the infant stage will go by in a blur. Journaling your feelings along the way can help you feel more connected to your baby and crystalize the memories you’re making together. (Being a portal for your baby’s spit-up counts as a memory.)
Give your baby a massage.

Infant massage has been shown to deepen the bond between babies and parents—and, interestingly, even some non-cuddly infants respond to the light rub. The best way to learn baby massage techniques is to consult your pediatrician; a Maven practitioner can also give you guidance by video chat. The key is to keep things gentle.
Read to your little one.
It’s never too early to start story time. Reading to infants isn’t about comprehension—it’s about your baby getting cuddle time and hearing the tone of your voice.
Talk out loud.
Hey, it beats talking to yourself, and you don’t need to with such a captive (8-pound) audience who would love to listen to you. Bonus for making extra eye-contact.
Make a playlist.

Pick a few of your favorite songs (probably best to think happy, not heavy metal), and play them for your little one regularly. Even better if you want to sing along. If you're having fun, your baby will, too—and let’s face it: It’s never too early to create a Beyonce lover. Just keep the volume to a reasonable (not live-concert-loud) level.

title.en-US: Maven real talk on IVF with Leila

content.value: 40 years old
Entrepreneur
Brooklyn
Why did you decide to start IVF? And how old were you when you went through your first cycle?
For two and a half years, my partner and I tried to have a baby naturally and with the help of intrauterine insemination (IUI) cycles but didn’t have success. I was 32 when we started IVF.
Did doctors diagnose the exact reason you couldn’t become pregnant, or did you have “unexplained infertility” (when no obvious cause of infertility can be identified)?
I had unexplained infertility, although there was some suspicion that there were "killer cells" in my body getting in the way. We tried to treat that with steroids.
Had you ever been pregnant before, at the time you started IVF?
No.
How many times have you done IVF?
One.
How did you choose your clinic?
We did our homework and found out it was reputed to be the best—meaning the clinic with the highest success rate—in London, which is where we lived at the time.
What could have made your patient experience better?
It would have been valuable to have some kind of support group and connection with others during this time.
What was the most difficult part of your IVF experience?
The time commitment. I was surprised by how much is involved in this process.
Any tips for managing the emotional stress of IVF?
To be honest, I didn't feel all that stressed; I just focused on the end goal and that helped me. I strongly believed IVF would work and kept my thoughts positive.
Any tips for managing the stress that IVF can put on a relationship?
Approach it like you would take on any other project—moving, planning a trip or a wedding, etc. Focus on the logistics at hand, not the emotions or fears.
Did your insurance cover IVF?
No.
If IVF was successful, how quickly did you get pregnant?
We got pregnant on the first try. There’s a “two-week wait” after you do an IVF transfer to find out if it worked, and that’s when we found out that it did.
Do you have any plans to do IVF again?
No. Following my pregnancy (via IVF), had another child naturally.
If your best friend was about to go through IVF, what would you want her to know?
It's worth it. Be focused. Be positive. Don't dwell on the potential failures. Feel confident in the doctor/clinic you choose. Ask questions, but not too many—don't drive yourself crazy!

title.en-US: Choosing your OB-GYN or midwife

content.value: You will see your prenatal care provider many times before you have your baby. So you want to be sure that the person you choose has a good reputation, and listens to and respects you. You will want to find out if the doctor or midwife can deliver your baby in the place you want to give birth, such as a specific hospital or birthing center. Your provider also should be willing and able to give you the information and support you need to make an informed choice about whether to breastfeed or bottle-feed.
Ask your primary care doctor, friends, and family members for provider recommendations.
When making your choice, think about:
Reputation
Personality and bedside manner
The provider’s gender and age
Office location and hours
Whether you always will be seen by the same provider during office checkups and delivery
Who covers for the provider when they are not available
Where you want to deliver
How the provider handles phone consultations and after-hour calls

title.en-US: 5 things everyone wonders in the third trimester

content.value: If these questions are running through your mind, welcome to your last act of pregnancy.
Is the nearest bathroom less than 20 feet away?
Peeing is now your full-time job, so naturally the first thing you do when you enter a restaurant, mall, or movie theater is identify the closest bathroom.
Is 7 PM an appropriate bedtime for an adult?
When you’re so tired that your sentence-completion rate is about 50% these days, it’s normal to want to curl up into a ball and conk out when the rest of America is just sitting down to dinner.
When will I be able to see my feet again?
At this point, you’re not even sure what those swollen puppies look like anymore. You’ve been unable to locate them since, oh, around week 28.
How horrible would it be to wake my sleeping partner for help cleaning the ceiling fan?
You know you’ve reached the nesting phase—which peaks in the third trimester—if an obsessive need to clean, organize, and Magic Erase everything has hijacked your mind.
Am I giving birth to Ninja Baby?
Your baby’s kicks have gone from cute to kill-me. Who knew such tiny feet, elbows, and knees could hurt so bad?

title.en-US: The truth about surrogacy success rates

content.value: What are the odds of a successful surrogacy?

In simple terms, a “successful” surrogacy simply means that you—the intended parent—end up with a baby. The most common process today is called “gestational surrogacy” where an embryo from a mom and dad is implanted into the uterus of the surrogate using in vitro fertilization (IVF). (Traditional surrogacy is when the carrier of the baby uses her own egg, but that’s generally frowned upon.) When using IVF, success may be as high as 60 percent if the surrogate and the egg donor/biological mom are under 35. (The success rate tends to decrease as the women get older.) Unfortunately, since surrogacy regulation isn’t where it needs to be, agencies and clinics looking for “bragging rights” may report success rates based on their own inconsistent criteria. Try not to fall for it—it’s important to ask questions about the data when you see claims like “85% success rate” on an agency’s website.
Will I have more success with fresh or frozen embryos?

It used to be that a fresh embryo transfer was thought of as the “gold star” method because slow-freezing techniques upped the chances that the embryos would develop ice crystals. Fast forward to today: Many IVF centers now use a fast-freezing process called vitrification, which has much higher survival odds for embryos during the thaw process. The result? Success rates are often comparable whether you go the fresh or frozen route.
Can I ever be “too successful”—a.k.a. What are the odds of multiples?

Keep this in mind: Your surrogate is chosen because she’s a good candidate for getting pregnant and carrying a child to term, right? Well, being a fertility all-star combined with the fact that your doctor may recommend transferring more than one embryo (to increase the likelihood that implementation happens) could result in a multiple pregnancy. It’s not uncommon for gestational carriers to end up carrying twins—and even triplets.
Sources: Maven Practitioner Network

title.en-US: Lunch advice & ideas for time-strapped working parents

content.value: You know those days when you’re so busy the only choices you have for lunch are the office snacks or fast takeout from the nearest food joint? Those options often fail you because they aren’t likely to be nutritious, and you may not have the sustenance you need to power through your day. Every nutritionist on Maven’s platform will tell you that planning ahead makes it easier to stick to your healthy eating goals. Here are three ideas for healthy midday meals.
Cook up dinners that make great leftovers.

When you're a busy new working mom and there's not a lot of time in the A.M., the easiest thing is to box up last night’s dinner for today’s lunch. But not all meals make great leftovers, so cook dinner with this in mind: How good will this taste tomorrow? Unfortunately, a spinach salad with dressing mixed in will be too soggy. And microwaved tilapia? Um, not so much. Roasted root veggies like onions, sweet potatoes, beets, parsnips, and carrots are always a sturdy—and healthy—idea. You can even make a big batch on Sunday night to eat all week, and just add a protein such as lean chicken breast or some legumes like chickpeas.
Have a smarter snacky lunch.

A lunch made of snack foods doesn’t have to mean grazing on your coworker’s candy plus the chips and other junk foods in the vending machine. At the beginning of the week, bring a few containers of plain Greek yogurt (it’s high in energizing protein) to stash in the office fridge so you can easily mix up a hold-you-over-till-dinner meal. The classic nuts-and-honey combo makes a satisfying topping, or try this: Stir about a quarter cup of peanut butter into a bowl of plain Greek yogurt with a dash of cinnamon. Top with sliced banana or use it as a filling dip for apple slices.
Pack the protein.

For sustained energy, protein is key. (A carb-heavy lunch might give you a spike of energy, but it will be followed by a crash later.) A stuffed avocado makes a great, quick lunch: When you’re leaving the house, throw an easy-open can or pouch of tuna, an avocado, and a lime into your bag. Then all it takes is this 3-minute prep in the office kitchen: Slice the avocado in half and remove the pit. Scoop out some of the avocado from each side (so that you have more room for your “bowl”). Mash up the scooped avocado with the tuna, and squeeze in some lemon or lime for flavor. Then scoop this tuna salad back into the avocado bowls, season with salt and pepper if you’d like, and dig in. Not a fan of tuna? Chicken salad made with avocado instead of mayo also works.
Need more nutrition advice or help with your healthy eating goals? You can book an appointment with a nutritionist on Maven’s platform and video chat from your couch.

title.en-US: Is it safe to use artificial sweeteners during pregnancy?

content.value: New motto: It’s better to be safe than saccharin.
While there are experts who advise steering clear of artificial sweeteners altogether—whether you’re pregnant or not—a few are technically considered safe during pregnancy.

So which ones can you use? Aspartame (Equal), sucralose (Splenda), and stevia (Truvia) are allowed. Acesulfame-K, or Ace-K, is also fine, according to the Food and Drug Administration (FDA). But saccharin, the sweetener found primarily in Sweet 'N Low, should be avoided. Saccharin crosses the placenta and can make its way into the fetal tissue. Since researchers still don’t know if its harmless for an unborn baby, your safest best is to skip it.

By the way, even if you steer clear of saccharin, it’s a good idea to use the “safe” sweeteners only in moderation. Get this: Moms-to-be who reported consuming more artificial sweeteners during pregnancy were twice as likely to have children that were overweight or obese at one year, compared to women who didn’t rely on the sweeteners as often. Diet Soda, we’re looking at you.

title.en-US: What is cord blood banking?

content.value: Cord blood banking is a procedure in which cord blood — a rich source of stem cells — is taken from the umbilical cord after delivery and used for research or preserved for possible use in a stem cell transplant. Collecting cord blood poses few, if any, risks. If a baby’s cord blood isn’t collected for preservation or research, it’s discarded. If you’re considering cord blood banking, consider the differences between using a public and private facility. For example:

Public cord blood banking facility: You might choose this option if you’d like your baby’s cord blood to be available for research or public use. Cord blood from unrelated donors can be used to treat conditions such as leukemia. Cord blood can be collected at any facility where healthcare providers are trained to recover cord blood. Public facilities don’t charge to store cord blood, but there might be a hospital fee for collection. The donation is then shipped to a cord blood bank. Cord blood banked in a public program won’t likely be available for future private use.

Private cord blood banking facility: You might choose this option if you want to preserve your baby’s cord blood for possible personal use. The cost can be considerable, including a collection fee and ongoing maintenance fees — yet the chance that your child will ever use the banked cord blood is remote. Also, should your child need a stem cell transplant, there’s no guarantee that the banked cord blood will remain viable or be suitable for a transplant.

If you’d like to know more about public cord blood banking or wonder whether private cord blood banking would be a worthwhile investment, consult your healthcare provider. They can help you make an informed decision.

This article is not intended to be a substitute for medical advice or care. Please consult a doctor with any questions you have before taking actions around your health and wellbeing. As always, our Maven practitioners are available, on-demand, to address your concerns.
Book an appointment here.
Sources
http://www.mayoclinic.org/healthy-lifestyle/labor-and-delivery/expert-answers/cord-blood-banking/faq-20058321

title.en-US: 7 best rules for a happy surrogate relationship

content.value: First, a quick Surrogacy 101 lesson: While “surrogate” is the word most people use for the woman who will carry the baby, the official term is “gestational surrogate” or “gestational carrier.” A “traditional surrogate,” on the other hand, is what you call a surrogate who is also the baby's biological mom because it's her egg that was fertilized by the intended father's sperm. Today, it’s rare that a carrier will be the biological mom—so when you see the word surrogate, it’s safe to assume we’re referring to the gestational carrier.

Tricky, right? Yes, but that’s nothing compared to the task of choosing who will carry your baby. Unless you’ve picked a friend or a relative, you’ll be matched with a surrogate based on a myriad of factors. Beyond the medical vetting and background checks, it’s important to find a “personality fit.” Get this: Some agencies ask prospective gestational carriers to fill out questionnaires that include everything right down to their taste in music. But even with all the facts you’ll be given about your surrogate, how do you know you’re making the right decision, and how will you manage the relationship for the next nine months—or years? Read on for a few key rules for a happy surrogate relationship.
Don’t rush the process.

Your gestational carrier is someone you’ll need to trust—possibly more than you’ve ever trusted anyone before. Do you get a good sense that she’ll take care of herself, eat healthfully, and generally make the best decisions during her pregnancy? Give yourself time to get to know the personality and lifestyle of your surrogate before you decide to move forward.
But remember, you can’t control another person.

Once you choose a woman to be your gestational carrier—someone you feel comfortable with who passes all your “gut checks”—it’s important to realize that you won’t be with this person 24/7 or be able to control their every step. That’s why therapy can be useful—a professional may be able to help you stay sane when you can’t dictate your gestational carrier’s minute-by-minute decisions. Our Maven network includes therapists who can talk with you by video or text when emotions (as, sigh, they tend to do) get out of whack.
Know the difference between open and closed surrogacy.

Many agencies encourage what’s called an “open surrogacy”—meaning you’re in touch during the pregnancy as much as you want to be. If that’s not for you, “closed surrogacy” gives an agency the task of being your “surrogacy middleman” so your contact is limited to just the essentials.
Figure out if you’re “communication compatible.”

If one person likes to send check-in texts from morning till night but the other leaves their cell-phone on silent for most of their workday, you might not be a good communication match. Determine what level—and type—of interaction you’ll have on a daily/weekly basis.
Have a plan for doctor’s visits.

Some intended parents want to be included in every aspect of the pregnancy. Will you go to all of your gestational carrier’s doctor’s appointments, or just the “milestone” ones—like, say, when you first get to identify the gender of your baby?
Discuss what happens after the birth.

There’s no one right to handle the amount of interaction you (and your child) have with your gestational carrier after the birth. Some women are comfortable with close bonds—for example, regular visits, invitations to birthday parties, etc. The more open you are about expectations early on, the easier things will be later.
Breathe.
No matter how prepared you are for this journey, there’s no denying that it’s going to be a deeply emotional one. In moments of stress, remember the simple calming power of your own breath.

title.en-US: Baby fears: 3 things your infant may be scared of

content.value: Fear isn’t an emotion you see a lot of in little ones. But there are a few triggers that can set off an infant’s fright response. Learn what they are and how you can make sure your baby always feels protected and safe.
Baby Fear #1: Loud Noises

Some babies can go from calm to mega-crying-episode in an instant when they hear a loud noise—say, for instance, if there’s a plane overhead or the rattling of pots and pans in the next room. Loud noise is actually one of the first fears a newborn experiences: A baby’s nervous system is still developing, which means that certain sensory stimulation can be frightening. So what can you do? Loud noises are inevitable but try to limit your baby’s exposure to them when you can. And offer some comfort and soothing when he does become startled.
Baby Fear #2: Strangers

Suddenly, you may notice that your child who would go to anyone without crying now starts to wail when an unfamiliar face approaches. While some babies experience this a bit earlier, a fear of strangers usually doesn’t set in before the 6-month mark. Whenever it happens, it’s important to give your baby cues that this “stranger” can be trusted. So when your cousin Sally from out of town comes to visit, be sure to greet her with a smile and a big hug. (Do this while your partner holds your baby from a slight distance, so she can see the interaction but has time to warm up to the newbie in her life before they get too close.)
Baby Fear #3: Separation

If your little one hasn’t had a half-birthday yet, chances are you haven’t experienced this just yet—but it’s good to be prepared, say experts. Babies can begin to fear being apart from their parents—a.k.a. separation anxiety—as early as 6 or 7 months, but for most children it peaks between 10 to 18 months. This has less to do with being left with a stranger and more to do with the fact that mom or dad is going away. One way to ease your baby’s mind is to spend some time with your baby while the nanny or caregiver is in the room before you jet off to work or to run an errand. The idea is to show your child that you’re leaving him in good, safe, trustworthy hands, and will be back. While it can be tempting to sneak out through the back door, doing say may only increase your baby’s anxiety.

title.en-US: Is it normal to feel sad about pregnancy coming to an end?

content.value: Everyone else is “so over it,” but you’re getting kind of attached to the bump. What’s up with that?

We may hear more tales of women who, especially toward the end of the third trimester, can’t wait to “just get this baby out of me.” But don’t worry if you’re not one of them and you feel sad about this period of your life coming to a close. It turns out, there are plenty of moms-to-be who admit to mourning the end of their pregnancies. “I’m going to miss feeling my baby kick, all the quiet nights nesting with my husband, and the feeling of nurturing my unborn child,” one woman told us.
As excited as they are to meet their little one, women can still feel unready to be bump-free. While motherhood will be its own special experience, it will also, no doubt, be a very different one.
Bottom line:

There’s no one “right” way to experience pregnancy. Loving being pregnant or hating it has no connection to being a good mother. Give yourself permission to feel whatever emotions you feel, and if they change from one minute to the next, that’s OK too.

title.en-US: “I mistakenly thought making it to 12-weeks meant I was in the clear”

content.value: Maven Real Talk on Miscarriage with Sam
36 years old
Account Management
Yardley, PA
How many miscarriages have you had?
One
How far along were you when you had your miscarriage(s)?
19 weeks
How did you find out? Did you have any symptoms?

I did not have any physical symptoms. In my second trimester, I had a routine alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) blood test (which is used to checks the level of AFP in a pregnant woman's blood). The test revealed that my AFP levels were extremely high, and my doctor requested an ultrasound as soon as possible to determine the status of the baby. That’s when I found out that I had miscarried.
What surprised you most about having a miscarriage?

There was so much that surprised me. For one, I thought that by making it past the 12-week mark, and seeing moving arms and legs during an ultrasound, I had passed all the “red flags” and that I was in the clear. All measurements were on track, genetic testing results were normal, and I had even felt the baby kick. 
Later, when it was time to have the D&C procedure to remove all the fetal tissue, I was surprised that the medications given to me beforehand (to start the process of dilating the cervix) caused me such physical pain. In fact, the entire D&C process was very emotional. After it was over, I wasn’t prepared for the fact that my body would think that I had delivered a baby and my milk would came in; my breasts were engorged which was extremely painful.
Did you find out what caused the miscarriage? How was that experience?
Doctors are still unclear but they think it was a fluke situation. The baby may have had a congenital disorder called arthrogryposis or it developed a virus that I may have passed on.
Did you go on to have a baby after your miscarriage(s)? If so, how soon afterwards?
We recently started trying again. I wanted to wait at least 3 months so I’d have time to meet with specialists and ensure that I had all the information I could gather before we tried again.
How open were you with friends and relatives?
I wrote all of my close friends and family members an email after my surgery. I didn’t want to have to repeat the story over and over again.
What helped you the most in those initial weeks and months after having a miscarriage?
Spending time with my daughter and talking to doctors who were familiar with my case.
If you are married or in a relationship, how did the experience of pregnancy loss affect your relationship with your partner?
It made us closer. My husband constantly reminded me how lucky we were to have a healthy daughter—and having her in our lives already gave us hope.
Did you seek therapy to deal with the miscarriage? If not, would it have been helpful in retrospect?

I didn’t seek out therapists; I spent more time talking to doctors. But I do plan to consult a therapist once I’m pregnant again to deal with any anxiety that, given what happened to me, could come up.
When people ask you how many children you’ve had (or have), do you include your miscarriage?
No
What would you want to tell another woman after suffering a miscarriage?

It’s not your fault. Know that women who’ve had a miscarriage do get pregnant again. And, lastly, let yourself be upset, but make the choice to live life, heal (in your own time), and grow from this experience.

title.en-US: How do you know if you’re really bonding with your baby?

content.value: Answer from Pediatrician Amy Brandon, IBCLC, MD

Bonding with your baby is a hormone-mediated physiological process occurring in the postpartum period which has been shown to maximize the survival of the species—friends, it's science! That said, don't feel bad if bonding with your baby hasn't happened for you or your partner...yet. Some parents bond immediately, while for others it takes a little more time and effort.

If you’re making eye contact with your baby and engaged in frequent physical touch—not just holding her, but letting her hold your finger in her tiny hand, stroking her chubby cheeks, smoothing her soft hair—and marveling at all these things, bonding is likely going well. You may also find yourself talking to her in low, soothing tones, sometimes mimicking her little squeaks and grunts. You'll know your baby feels a connection too when she stops crying when you pick her up, or settles at the sound of your voice or the smell of your skin.

If you're thinking you (or your partner) could be doing more to bond, try some skin-to-skin time before or after a feeding, or gently massage those tiny legs after a bath. Read to her. Sing. Before long, your baby will be showing you why it's all worth it with that million-dollar gummy smile. Occasionally, difficulty bonding can be a sign of the postpartum depression or anxiety which affects many moms. If you're wondering whether this could be you, please reach out to a Maven midwife, OB-GYN, or mental health provider for help sorting things out.

title.en-US: How much coffee can you really drink during pregnancy?

content.value: The reality check on caffeine.

Coffee is one of those pregnancy nutrition topics that never leads to a totally straight answer. Frustrating, we know. But one reason that the advice isn’t clear-cut is that it’s not exactly ethical for scientists to give a bunch of pregnant women a few cappuccinos a day and see what happens. So most of the recommendations come from looking back at women’s pregnancies, and seeing what health outcomes they had based on their consumption.

According to the Mayo Clinic, while we do know that caffeine can cross the placenta, the effects on your baby aren't clear. Studies on animals have shown that caffeine can cause birth defects, premature labor, and increase the odds of having a low-birth weight baby.

Until more is known for certain, to be safe, your OB-GYN might recommend limiting the amount of caffeine in your diet to less than 200 milligrams a day during pregnancy. But exactly how much caffeine is there in the beverages you consume? Here’s a look at some of the ways you may be getting your jolt, according to The Center for Science in the Public Interest. Take a look, and then check in with your provider to see what intake is best for you.

title.en-US: Real talk from Maven user Ann about IVF

content.value: 33 years old
Operations at early-stage company
NYC
Why did you decide to start IVF?
My husband and I got pregnant pretty easily when we first tried, though had a miscarriage and then were trying nearly a year unsuccessfully. We tried two rounds of IUI before moving to IVF.
Had you been pregnant before when you started?
Yes.
How many times have you done IVF?
One retrieval, one transfer (successful!).
How did you choose your clinic?
Success rates of the clinic, personal experience of two friends with the doctor we chose.
What surprised you most about the procedure?

I expected IVF to be tough physically (>100 shots, going under general anesthesia for the retrieval), though to me the most surprising thing was how difficult IVF was emotionally. There are so many ups and downs and unknowns throughout the experience; I'm really thankful for my husband and friends who supported me through it.
Do you think you had a positive patient experience?

Yes, definitely. I loved my doctor—she was extremely caring and 100% on my team. Even just starting the process with a reproductive endocrinologist helped; before it felt like my husband and I were in it alone.
What could have been better?
There were a few times when I had misinformation about medications or next steps—always double-check with your care team. No question is too small!
How much did it cost each time you did it?
Our insurance does not cover infertility treatments. We paid approximately $30K all-in for IVF, plus the two IUI treatments.
How quickly did you get pregnant?
Thankfully within one transfer cycle! The whole process from start of IVF retrieval medications to successful pregnancy test was three months.
Are you going to do it again?
Yes, most likely.
What is your advice to someone about to go through IVF?

Try to find a friend who is supportive. My husband was wonderful throughout the whole experience, but it was so helpful to have a close friend who I could also speak with. In my case, one of my best friends was going through IVF with the same doctor at the same time. I'm sure that's rare, but it made a huge difference in how I felt about the whole experience—and now we're both pregnant together! Also, try to forgive your other friends who unintentionally are not very supportive. I think it's hard for others to relate to the stress of IVF—even parents! We had some friends who unintentionally said some comments that were hurtful at the time; it's hard, but my husband and I tried to tell ourselves they mean well even if it didn't come through in that instance.
Any tips for managing the emotional stress of IVF?

Keeping busy with work, friends, and exercise helped, and I tried to keep something on the calendar for the next week that I was really looking forward to. I also did acupuncture leading up to the IVF retrieval and transfer; I think it helped with stress but research shows it also helps IVF implantation rates.
Any tips for managing the stress that IVF can put on a relationship?

While IVF can be all-encompassing (physically, emotionally, financially), it helped my husband and I to go out do dinner and not talk about IVF or do something fun together. He also came with me to all the major appointments (which was helpful emotional support but also because there are often so many details to remember!) and helped with many shots, which made this feel like it was something we're going through together.
What other question am I not asking but I should be?

What type of IVF did you do? We chose to do a full IVF cycle (unlike a "mini-IVF" cycle some of our friends used). I'm thankful we went through the upfront longer journey since we now have a few more healthy embryos we can use to grow our family when we're ready. We also decided to do pre-implantation genetic screening; for us, it was the right choice as we wanted to reduce our miscarriage risk as much as possible. Given that, we had a frozen transfer.

This article is not intended to be a substitute for medical advice or care. Please consult a doctor with any questions you have before taking actions around your health and wellbeing. As always, our Maven practitioners are available, on-demand, to address your concerns.
Book an appointment here.

title.en-US: Is secondhand smoke really that dangerous during pregnancy?

content.value: Can you have a clean bill of health as long as you’re not the one taking the puffs?

You already know smoking during pregnancy is a major health no-no. But what about being around people who light up? Nonsmoking women who expose themselves to secondhand tobacco smoke during pregnancy see many unwanted outcomes. Harms to their babies include low birth weight, premature delivery, serious birth defects, as well as an increased risk of stillbirth and sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS).

The safest place for you and your growing baby is a smoke-free environment. If you live with a smoker, tell them it’s doctor’s orders: Take it outside—or, better yet, encourage them to look into a cessation program to get help quitting the habit.

title.en-US: Why your 6-week checkup is too late, according to your doc

content.value: OB-GYNs say we need a whole new way of thinking about how to check up on and tend to new moms. Read on to make sure you’re getting the care you deserve.

The weeks and months after childbirth can be tough for new mothers. It’s not like you give birth and, just like that, you’re physically and emotionally back to your pre-pregnancy self. But how much support are you really getting during this time, and how much do you need?

That’s where there’s a disconnect, and finally doctors are starting to speak up about it. In April 2018, The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists put out what’s called an official “committee opinion” that basically said we, in the U.S., do a horrible job of taking care of new moms after they give birth—or at least a totally inadequate job. They said that the postpartum period is "devoid of formal or infor­mal maternal support” and that in order "to optimize the health of women and infants, postpartum care should become an ongoing process, rather than a single encounter, with services and support tailored to each woman's individual needs.” (Individual needs...what a concept!)

Translation: One measly checkup at the 6-week mark isn’t enough. Contrast that one appointment to your baby’s pediatrician visits—which usually happen at birth; 3 to 5 days later; and then at 1, 2, 4, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18 and 24 months. Or even compare it to the number of appointments you had during pregnancy (you probably lost count!).

The first year is a crucial time in child development, and doctors aim to keep close tabs on baby’s health and progress. Similarly, the period after childbirth is a very vulnerable time for new moms, where they’re at risk for hypertension, pelvic pain, incision pain from C-sections, depression, anxiety, trouble with lactation—and that’s just to name a few of the issues that come up. The problem is, if you have barely any contact with a medical provider, how will you know what’s a real problem and what needs treatment? The proposed ACOG guidelines advocate for more comprehensive care beginning as early as three days after childbirth, and lasting as long as three months, when a full assessment would take place to make sure your physical, social, and psychological well-being is in a healthy place. Moms probably deserve even more, but that would be a big improvement from the healthcare practices we’ve got now.

So what can you do today? Your provider may have read the guidelines and already recommended seeing you more often. That said, if your insurance doesn’t cover frequent visits, you may not be keen to make regular appointments. Until our insurance system catches up, use this knowledge to prioritize your own health during this time—not just your baby’s. After all, the best way to take excellent care of your little one is to look after your own well-being. Be your own advocate and call your doctor if anything seems off. Lastly, remember that our extensive network of Maven providers is here—and you can chat with them anytime jetting off to a doctor’s appointment isn’t, for one reason or another, a possibility. You matter, mom!

title.en-US: The mindset that makes following a pregnancy diet easier

content.value: The power of positivity may not turn a bowl of cauliflower into a cheese plate, but it can make healthy foods more enjoyable.

What you eat and drink during pregnancy is your baby's main source of nourishment. So there are many rules to eating for two—and some of them may have surprised you if you imagined this time in your life would be license to call ice cream and hot fudge a “balanced” meal. With all the can’t-haves your doctor may have warned you about, it’s easy to focus on the negative.

But pregnancy eating doesn’t need to feel like a bummer. When you catch yourself in a pity party about all the things you can’t eat (for now), remind yourself that this period in your life is temporary. Beer, brie, and a bottomless cup of coffee will all be waiting for you on the flip side if you choose to have them after pregnancy. What’s more, reframing your diet as a choice you’re making—for you and your baby—can keep you from feeling like someone imposed it on you. And instead of fantasizing about the pleasure that off-limits foods would give you, notice other things that make you happy right now.

Whether you’re about to prepare a meal, hit up a farmer’s market, or eat out at a restaurant, try to apply a positive mindset. For example, don’t scan the menu and make a mental list of all the things you “don’t get to” eat. Rather, focus on all the food options available to you that you truly enjoy. What meals do you feel excited to dig into? And make sure not to cut flavor out of your diet—healthy eating does not have to mean deprivation.

title.en-US: 5 excellent reasons to write a birth plan

content.value: If you’ve never written a birth plan before, you might be wondering what it even is. In the simplest terms, think of it as a memo that lets your care team know your preferences for labor and delivery. "A lot of people don't know how to start developing a birth plan because their providers aren’t bringing it up. In fact, they often don't realize they have options around things like fetal monitoring, getting their water broken, deciding who will be present for the birth, and requesting skin-to-skin contact or immediate breastfeeding after delivery,” says Danika Wynn, a Certified Nurse Midwife specialist and Maven practitioner.

Of course, the unpredictability of childbirth is part of what makes it so amazing. “Birth often deviates from our expectations and that's OK as long as you feel empowered with the knowledge and confidence to make decisions,” says Wynn. With that in mind, here are five reasons birth-planning is worth it—yes, even when your little one ends up having his own plans.
You’ll figure out if you and your doctor are a good match.

“It's important that your health care provider's perspective on birth is similar to your own; this will make a huge difference in your birth experience,” says Wynn. Writing a birth plan and discussing it with your doctor not only helps you get on the same page, it also helps you manage your expectations. “As midwives, minimizing intervention and allowing a laboring woman to follow their instincts are hallmarks of our care,” Wynn adds. “But if a patient has preferences that are unrealistic or need some further questioning, it’s always best to tackle these before labor starts.”
You’ll be better prepared for the unexpected.

Sometimes, when it comes to childbirth, what you don’t know can hurt you. Jackie Stone, an OB-GYN in Maven’s network, gives this example: “Episiotomies used to be common practice to keep women from tearing on their own, but we’ve since discovered that they can lead to worse tears (read: all the way through to your rectum) and a greater chance of incontinence later in life. I still see some doctors performing them routinely.” The problem is, if you don’t educate yourself on issues like these and make your preferences clear to your provider in your birth plan, navigating the unexpected will be a lot harder. And let’s face it: When a snap decision is a snip decision, there’s no going back.
You’ll feel more empowered when it comes to your labor options.

If you’re reading this thinking, “Isn’t my only labor option to push and push?” The truth is, childbirth isn’t one-labor-fits-all, and with some thoughtful planning, you’ll get to have a say in many aspects of your delivery. Will you give birth in a hospital or at a birthing center? Do you want to be able to walk around during labor, or use a birthing ball to help move things along? If given the option, will you go for fetal monitoring that’s continuous or intermittent? It can be hard to wrap your mind everything that could come up, but with some guidance and a carefully designed birth-plan, you’ll be able to approach your labor feeling like a childbirth champion.
You may end up with fewer regrets.

As one mom put it: “I feel strongly that if I hadn’t educated myself and written a birth plan, I would have had a second C-section, just like I did the first time around.” Sure, there will be times when an adjustment to the birth plan—including your method of delivery—is an absolute must for the safety of you and your baby. But considering that about half of all Cesareans performed in the U.S. aren’t medically necessary, educating yourself may be the first step to having more of a say in how things unfold.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
You and your partner may have more open communication.

While every couple is different, it isn’t uncommon for a spouse or partner to feel a bit left out of the birth process. But writing a plan and discussing your decisions with your S.O. will help ensure you’re approaching childbirth as a duo. Another bonus: Even if you’re in too much discomfort or doozy from pain medication, your partner can make your wishes clear to everyone in the delivery room.
The bottom line on birth plans:
You deserve to have a voice in how you’re welcoming your baby into the world. Book an appointment with a Maven practitioner who can help you customize a birth plan.
You’ll be able to approach your labor feeling like a childbirth champion.

title.en-US: How to feel inspired at work again after maternity leave

content.value: Even if you have a job you once loved, that feeling of being jazzed about work can be difficult to recover when you’ve been out of the game for a while on maternity leave. Is there anything you can do if you’re a little “blah” and “meh” on the work-front lately? Luckily, experts say inspiration can be cultivated. Here are four tips to revive your office pep.
Use your commute to build an inspiration routine.

One surefire way to trigger inspiration is to tap into new ideas and learn new things. But when you’ve got a baby to get home to, you might not have the time to, say, attend speaking events or take nighttime classes. The solution: Put your commute to good use. Find a mind-expanding podcast you love and listen to it on the way to work. Sometimes we feel blasé because we lack perspective, and when we engage in activities that change our view of things, the boost we need just... comes.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Focus on the results, not your time sheet.

If you’re telling yourself stories like, “I can’t win over the boss any longer because being a new parent means I’m clocking out at 5,” flip the script. Employees who don’t see their potential to be valued are more likely to dread their jobs. So what can you do? Avoid being in a competition with your colleagues over who’s the first one in and last one out. Instead, focus on doing your job and doing it well. Are you getting results? Are you resolving issues that are critical to the success of the organization? Keep those successes at the forefront of your mind, and you’ll stay out of a slump.
Make a friend—or five—at work.

When you’re thinking about what’s standing in the way of feeling inspired, don’t underestimate the impact of your connections to your colleagues. The return-to-work phase is a challenging time for many reasons. When you’re exhausted and simply trying to get through the day crossing items off your to-do list, you may prioritize efficiency over interactions with your peers. But bonding with coworkers, feeling supported, and building relationships may be just what you need to break out the back-to-work rut. Small actions—like asking someone to join you on a mid-day coffee run, or getting to a meeting five minutes early to chit-chat before the agenda kicks off—can make a big difference.
Don’t wait to feel inspired to act inspired.

Often, people wait for a flash of inspiration to proactively behave like an employee who is jazzed about work.
