But research has shown that sometimes you need to change your actions first, and then the inspiration follows. If you know that you’re most energized when you’re immersed in a new or innovative project, take steps to get things off the ground even if you’d rather just go through the motions of business-as-usual. Bottom line: Change your behaviors, and your emotions may follow suit.
Find a mind-expanding podcast you love and listen to it on the way to work.

title.en-US: When do babies really start sleeping through the night?

content.value: Answer from Pediatrician Amy Brandon, MD, IBCLC

"Sleeping through the night" means different things to different parents—and to different babies! Some parents are looking forward to the day their little one will sleep 12 hours straight, whereas some would just be happy with a 6-hour stretch! (Yours truly is among the latter group of new moms, as I’m regularly wide awake in the night with a 7-week old.)

Some variables that affect when and how long your baby will be able to "sleep through the night" include her age, whether she is nursing or bottle-fed, any underlying medical conditions (reflux, teething, or prematurity, just to name a few), and her temperament. Most babies should be able to do a 6-hour block of sleep by the time they are around 4-months old, when their daytime sleep patterns begin to consolidate and they start to learn self-soothing skills.

Check with your pediatrician or a pediatric sleep coach on Maven if you feel your baby should be able to sleep longer but isn't. We may have a few tricks up our sleeves—often from personal experience!

title.en-US: 3 pep talks every new parent needs

content.value: Taking care of a new baby can be a daunting experience. So it’s completely normal if you’re struggling with self-doubt, have a case of “bad parent” syndrome, or sometimes wonder if your kid will be in college before you feel like yourself again. But when challenge strikes, it’s more important than ever to check your inner critic and avoid negative self-talk. Here are the three pep talks every new parent needs to give themselves at one point or another.
“I’m doing the best I can, so I don’t need to compare myself to other parents.”

Having a new baby can feel like trying to helm a ship for the first time... in the middle of a storm. Why can’t I get my baby to sleep, or stop crying, or take a bottle, or...? The feelings of inadequacy go on and on. Making things worse, there can be a tendency for new parents to compare themselves to others and think, “They're doing this parenting thing so much better than I am.” Sizing ourselves up to others is human nature, so you’re not alone if this sounds like you. But psychologists have pointed out that being in a state of comparison can distort your thinking so you can’t really see the truth—or how well you’re actually doing. The reality is this: Those other parents in the waiting room at the pediatrician’s office, at the park, and in your mommy-and-me group aren’t perfect either—because there’s no such thing. If you’re following your instincts and doing your best, trust that it’s enough.
“This too shall pass—everything does.”

Life with a new baby isn’t easy. Yes, the struggle is real—but it isn’t permanent. “Most of my new-parent despair came from not seeing the end to each of the road bumps,” one Maven member confesses. “I wish someone told me that everything passes—sometimes a lot quicker than you’d expect. The isolation of being at home with a newborn, the sense that my nipples might actually fall off because they were so raw from breastfeeding, even my zombie-state from a serious lack of sleep—all of it passed, and everything turned out OK.”
“I deserve a break.”

No, really, you do. And we get it: The break you need (i.e. week in Tahiti) might not be the break you can get (i.e. hour in Target without a child in tow.) Our Maven mental health specialists say that many new parents feel overwhelmed, yet they feel guilty about accepting help when someone offers support. Taking time away from your baby can be tough in the beginning, but none of us were meant to do it all ourselves, and trying to be a solo act can lead to worsening stress and anxiety. Ultimately, the quality of time you spend with your baby matters more than the quantity. So when a friend texts you to say she’s coming over and sending you on a pedicure outing—or even just to your bedroom for a nap—let her.

If you’re feeling so much despair that no pep talk will lift you out of it, it’s important to know that you’re not alone and help is available. Think you might have postpartum depression, or just need some extra support?Click here to book a video chat with a mental health specialist in Maven’s network.

title.en-US: How can you cancel plans last minute because of mom duties?

content.value: Answer from Mental Health Specialist Mercedes Samudio, LCSW, MSW

There’s no denying that having a baby can make your life very unpredictable. You could have every intention of showing up for a party or dinner with friends, until your child runs a fever or your babysitter sends you a last-minute text telling you she can’t make it. This can be frustrating for friends who may have even changed their plans to accommodate your schedule.

The best way to manage this is to be up front when making plans. Be honest that you will happily pencil in a time and date, and will do everything in your power to stick to it, but that if something comes up with your child, you may have to cancel. Ask your friend right from the beginning, “Would you be OK with that? I just want to be honest about how crazy things are right now.” Being honest and letting your friends know that you may have to choose your child over dinner plans helps them to understand where your priorities and boundaries are—and hopefully will quell any frustration when you do have to cancel. Lastly, as easy as it is to send a text, consider the impact you’ll have on your friend with a “can’t make it” message. You may be able to soften the blow if you pick up the phone to let her know you’re so sorry something came up.

title.en-US: When to worry about your partner's bad mood during pregnancy

content.value: It turns out, pregnancy mood swings aren’t exclusive to the parent giving birth. Get this: About 13% percent of partners experienced spikes of depressive symptoms too, according to research from McGill University. Read on for the need-to-know info, and how to help if your partner is struggling.
What are the symptoms of partner depression?

It can manifest differently for everyone, but there are some classic signs that may clue you in to an issue. For instance, if your partner has zero interest in activities they used to enjoy, they're gaining (or losing) a ton of weight, or they have sleep problems, something might be up. Likewise, increased irritability, agitation, or a low mood could tip you off.
What should you do if your partner is depressed?

There’s no doubt that this can present challenges in a relationship—especially if you’re dealing with your own emotional struggles. But now is a great time to learn how to support each other. One of the best things you can do is encourage any steps your partner is willing to take to get help, including counseling, meditation, etc. Remind them that if their feeling left out of your pregnancy, or anxious about being a parent, you want to know about it. Be there for them, but also remember that this isn’t a time to abandon your own needs. After all, self-care is crucial during pregnancy. And remind yourself that clinical depression has nothing to do with you. You didn’t “cause” it by being pregnant, and there’s no reason to feel guilty.
Lastly, recognize that you may need some extra support. That’s OK! Rely on friends, talk to a Maven therapist—whatever you need to do to get through this time.

title.en-US: 4 no-brainer ways working parents can buy time

content.value: Fact: Time is the greatest asset any working parent can have. And when you're trying to juggle a job and raising a family, you're probably left with very little of it—not to mention energy—to tend to things that keep your household running. To the rescue: four sanity- and time-saving shortcuts new parents swear by.
The time suck: Laundry, laundry, and more laundry.
Sanity-saver: Cut corners like a boss.

If you’re reading this thinking about the big, growing pile of laundry that seems to taunt you every morning as you walk out the door, you’re not alone. Laundry is one of the most time-sucking household chores. One solution? Look for a local laundry service that offers pick-up and delivery. But even if you are the laundromat, you can find ways to speed things up. For instance, invest in divided hampers for darks and lights. That way, things are already sorted from the get-go. And fold the clothes as soon as you’re taking them out of the dryer—it’s a more efficient way to do things, according to organizing experts.
The time suck: Driving anywhere.
Sanity-saver: Use apps to your advantage.

Sure, scrolling through Facebook might not be a time-saver. But there are plenty of ways to use technology to shave minutes—or hours—off your to-dos. For instance, use an app to deposit checks from your phone instead of running to the bank. For appointments that don’t require an in-person visit, use a telemedicine app (like Maven!) to chat with a doctor instead of schlepping yourself or your little one across town. Use Venmo to pay your babysitter when you forgot to do that last night.
The time suck: Shopping.
Sanity-saver: Buy (almost) everything online.

Many working parents say that online shopping—for groceries, diapers, household items, even birthday presents—isn’t a luxury, it’s a necessity. There may even be a cost benefit: When you’re making purchases online, you can search for the best deals and avoid the “impulse buys” for stuff you don’t really need. You can also subscribe for certain purchases you make all the time so they're automated. Think: Amazon, Fresh Direct, Jet.
The time suck: Getting a healthy dinner on the table.
Sanity-saver: Stock your pantry and freezer right.

If you end up eating Cheerios for dinner because you suffer from cooking perfectionism (“it’s either made from scratch or it’s not a ‘real’ meal”), give yourself permission to not be so gourmet for the time being. Frozen veggies, canned beans, splurging on the pre-chopped variety—all fair game. Having a few of these kinds of staples on-hand can help you easily throw together a nutritious meal like a stir-fry or a vegetable-based soup in a hurry. No more cereal for dinner, starting now!

title.en-US: What you need to know about cord blood banking

content.value: When you give birth, the umbilical cord attaching your baby to you will be cut. And when that happens, you’ll have the option to save the cells inside for their life-saving potential. But there’s a lot to understand before you make this important decision. Read on so you can be armed with the facts.
What is cord blood and how is it used?

Cord blood is the blood inside the umbilical cord that can be collected right after your baby is born. Cord blood contains stem cells that can be used in the treatment of people with blood cancers such as leukemia and lymphoma, as well as other disorders of the blood and immune systems, such as sickle cell disease and Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.
Where does cord blood usually end up?

In most cases, cord blood is discarded along with the placenta after a baby is born. But the American Academy of Pediatrics strongly encourages parents to consider saving their baby's cord blood and donating it to a public bank. A national registry matches donated cord blood to patients in need, so a life may someday depend on it. Donation to a public cord blood bank is free, but you should talk to your doctor about it in advance because not every hospital collects cord blood for public donation. If you aren’t delivering at a hospital that is affiliated with a public bank, the only way you can donate is to register for a mail-in donation program. (For more info, go to parentsguidecordblood.org.)
What’s the deal with private cord blood banking?

Cord blood stored in private banks remains the property of the donor family, so this option might give peace of mind to some parents who have a family history of diseases that can be treated with cord blood. But if you decide not to, that’s OK. “I tell my patients that the chances of their baby or another family member developing a disease that can be treated with cord blood stem cells is very remote,” says Dr. Jackie Stone, a Maven OB-GYN. In fact, the American Academy of Pediatrics discourages the use of private cord blood banks, except when a relative has a current need for a transplant. If you’re doing it for potential use later, there’s a small chance—from 1 in 1,000 to 1 in 200,000—that a child will ever need the blood. Many medical organizations share the AAP’s view, but this is one of those parenting controversies that isn’t black and white. Ultimately, it’s a very personal decision.
How much does private cord blood banking cost?

It depends on which bank you choose, but you can expect to spend around $1,500 to $2,000 for the initial placement, with annual storage fees around $150 to $300. For people who are on the fence, finances may ultimately be the deciding factor, notes Dr. Jane van Dis, MD, an OB-GYN in Maven's practitioner network. “It’s a significant financial investment and to say that it's not is misleading. If it comes down to private cord blood versus saving for your child’s college tuition, you may want to donate to a public bank.” That said, Dr. van Dis offers the perspective that parents with the financial means for private banking have a right to do so: “It’s valid for parents to feel they don’t have much to lose from private banking—even if the chance that the cord blood stem cells will be needed or useful in the future is very slim.”
What if the technology evolves as your baby grows?

It’s true that there are studies underway to test cord blood stem cell therapy in healing other conditions like brain and spinal-cord injuries, diabetes, and heart disease. While cord blood research is a passionate area of medicine for some doctors, experts worry about parents being fear mongered into private banking with very little evidence of which advances are likely to manifest.
The Bottom Line:

Future medical uses for cord blood are highly uncertain at this point, so it’s up to every parent to decide the ratio of risk to potential reward. Ultimately, you and your partner should do your research and make a choice that’s right for your family. It you are going the private-banking route, make sure you’ve selected a high-quality and reputable company. Maven’s Care Advocates can help point you in the right direction; book an appointment here to learn more.

title.en-US: What’s hygge, and will it make pregnancy more comfortable?

content.value: It’s been a buzzy concept in the U.S. for a couple of years, but if you haven’t gotten in on the hygge lifestyle yet, pregnancy may be the perfect time.
What is hygge?

Hygge (pronounced ‘hoo-gah’ or 'hue-ugh’, depending on who you ask) is the Danish word for cozy, and it’s basically the pursuit of life’s coziest pleasures—think candlelight, wood-burning fires, fuzzy socks, comfort food, and a close-knit clan. And it turns out that the constant quest for hygge may be what distinguishes Denmark as of the most-blissed out countries; the Danes get bragging rights as the happiest workforce in the world.
Does it have to be cold out to live this way?
Nope, winter is the most hygge season, but you can be hygge any time of the year.
How can you get your hygge on during pregnancy?

If you’re hunkering down for a hygge weekend at home, the first thing you want to think about is comfort, starting with your clothes. (We’ll wait right here while you go take off the Spanx and the underwire bra.) Soft pants, fuzzy slippers, a decadent blanket are all fair game. Light some candles or plug in a string of twinkly lights, and then plot your hygge menu. If porridge for dinner isn’t your style, a slow-cooked beef stew or bowl of chili also works. What’s for dessert? A movie and mug of hot chocolate, naturally, while your partner sips some mulled wine. Not surprisingly, how you indulge is as important as what you’re indulging in. The key is to take time to savor and enjoy—no rushing, no scarfing down meals. Your leisure time can be truly leisurely—board games, naps, you name it. For a tired, pregnant woman, hygge sounds like heaven.

title.en-US: What to eat before your pregnancy workouts

content.value: When you’re sweating for two, fueling right is key.

If you’re getting regular exercise during pregnancy, first off: Great job! Research has shown that physical activity while you’re expecting has benefits including weight management, reducing the risk of gestational diabetes and preeclampsia, and making it easier to endure labor. But self-care around your workouts is especially important when you’ve got a bun in the oven—and how (and when) you feed yourself is key. Not eating enough before your sweat sessions can make you nauseous or dizzy, lightheaded, and overly fatigued. The timing of your meals and snacks also matters.

So what should you eat? If you’re having a full meal a couple of hours before your workout, aim for a mix of healthy carbs, protein, and fat. A couple of ideas: Try a quinoa-chicken-avocado bowl or a salad with tofu, legumes, and olive-oil dressing plus a slice of whole-grain bread. As you get closer to your workout, a full meal may put you over the edge, so stick to a snack in the 150-200 calorie range. And focus on carbs with a smaller amount of protein; carbs are easier to digest, so your body can use the fuel faster. One great go-to is the classic apple-and-peanut-butter combo.
If you have more questions about nutrition during pregnancy, or need help with meal planning, book a video appointment with a Maven nutritionist.

title.en-US: Monitoring baby's heart rate during labor: What to know

content.value: The idea is to catch potential problems during labor before they become a serious issue. But keeping tabs on your baby’s heart rate is more complicated than you’d think. Read this before your delivery day.
What is fetal heart rate monitoring?

It’s a way of checking your baby's heart rate to make sure it isn’t too high or too low during labor. With continuous electronic fetal monitoring (EFM), doctors have a record of your baby’s heart rate throughout your entire labor. Continuous monitoring can be internal or external: External monitoring involves strapping a couple of devices around your belly that are connected to a monitor. Internal monitoring (which can only happen after your water breaks) requires inserting a small electrode through your vagina and placing it on your baby's scalp.
What could affect your baby’s heart rate during labor?

Lots of things. According to Johns Hopkins Medicine, these include uterine contractions, pain medicines or anesthesia, tests done during labor, and pushing during the second stage of labor. In a high-risk pregnancy where preterm labor is a concern, EFM may be used to check how medicines that keep labor from starting too early are affecting your baby.
Is there a good reason to use continuous fetal monitoring in low-risk pregnancies?

So here’s where things get tricky. Electronic fetal monitoring has become one of the most common labor practices in the U.S.; by some estimates, it’s used with 85% of pregnant women. But the science doesn’t show it actually leads to healthier deliveries. According to The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG), “the widespread use of continuous electronic fetal heart-rate monitoring has not improved outcomes when used for women with low-risk pregnancies.”
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Even if that’s true, what could be the harm in using consistent monitoring?

There are definitely risks when it comes to continuous fetal monitoring. False alarms–which indicate a problem when there is none—are common. For this reason, continuous monitoring is associated with more deliveries by C-section and more assisted vaginal births using forceps. Jackie Stone, an OB-GYN and Maven practitioner adds: Continuous electronic fetal monitoring has been shown to reduce the incidence of seizures in newborns, but there has been no effect in decreasing cerebral palsy.
What’s the alternative?
The ACOG recommends that doctors consider intermittent instead of continuous use of fetal heart rate monitoring when it’s appropriate in low-risk pregnancies.
So why do so many doctors still choose continuous monitoring?
It’s a complicated issue. Some physicians hold onto the belief that EFM might still be a valuable assessment tool. Experts have also suggested that fear of malpractice suits could also be at play.
What should you do?

The most important thing is to start an open dialogue with your doctor. That way, you can approach your labor with fewer surprises, feeling confident about every decision and understanding why it was made.
False alarms–which indicate a problem when there is none—are common.

title.en-US: 3 ways to get your sex life back on track after having a baby

content.value: Bringing a child into the mix can equal a dry spell for many couples. That’s normal, but it doesn’t have to go on forever. Once you feel physically recovered from childbirth, there are ways to rekindle the flame. Hey, remember that you once desired each other enough to make a baby in the first place. Use these research-proven tricks to get your sex life back on track.
Get comfortable talking openly about your sex life.

Many couples shy away from talking about sex—or the lack thereof. Here’s why that’s a mistake: Research found that less than 10% of couples who can't comfortably talk about sex with one another say that they're satisfied in bed. If you don’t know where to start, consider taking a stroll down memory lane: Discuss what you both loved about your sex life when you first started having it. You both may need a few reminders of what turns you on.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Make good use of the babysitter’s time.

A study at the University of Virginia found that couples who spend more couple-time together have higher levels of sexual satisfaction than those who don’t carve out regular one-on-one dates. Getting a babysitter not only makes time for nocturnal bonding, it also places a real value on it. And when you do sneak away, try not to talk about everything that might be happening back at Baby HQ. Remembering who you are as a couple—and the connection between the two of you that existed before you had kids—is key to staying out of a sexual rut.
Get even, then get busy.

One study found that couples who split childcare duties evenly between both partners have the best sex lives—and most satisfying relationships in general.
So make sure you aren’t always doing the lion’s share of the chores. To avoid keeping a scorecard, consider teaming up on some of the to-dos. For instance, take the dog on a long walk together. (And when you get back home, head straight to the bedroom.)
Need more sex advice? Book an appointment with a Maven sex coach and video chat about anything that’s on your mind.
You both may need a few reminders of what turns you on.

title.en-US: When do your pregnancy hormones level out after childbirth?

content.value: Answer from Midwife Danika Severino Wynn, CNM, IBCLC, MS

Recovery after childbirth varies greatly from one woman to the next—and breastfeeding certainly has an impact. Hormonal mood swings and changes in your body are most intense during the first 1-3 weeks postpartum. Breastfeeding can alter hormones to suppress ovulation and your periods delaying the return to "normal" for a while.

It's important to know that while the "baby blues" aren’t uncommon in the first couple of weeks, if you have signs of anxiety or depression that are worsening over time or last longer than this you should discuss it with your healthcare provider. Many new parents suffer from various forms of postpartum mood disorders that can respond well to treatment. Diagnosing these mood disorders early can make treatment easier and the first year of parenting more enjoyable.

title.en-US: Stretch marks during pregnancy: How to deal

content.value: When you’re growing a human life inside you, some changes are inevitable. Enter: stretch marks, the “badges of honor” that make their way onto the breasts, thighs, and bellies of between 50 to 90 percent of pregnant women. Considering how common stretch marks are, it’s no wonder Maven users have so many questions about what causes them and how to get rid of them. Read on for the must-know answers.
What causes stretch marks during pregnancy?

When your skin stretches quickly—i.e. to accommodate a growing baby—collagen and elastin fibers tear, and lines appear. That’s why any period of rapid weight gain, even if you’re not pregnant, can lead to more marks.
My friend carried twins and didn’t get stretch marks during her pregnancy—why do I have them?

The simple truth: Some people are just genetically predisposed to stretch marks. If your mom and grandma had them, chances are you will, too. In fact, genetics may play an even bigger role than how much weight you gain during pregnancy.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Can I use a stretch mark cream while I’m pregnant?

It depends on what you’re reaching for. Retin-A, a common ingredient in stretch mark creams, generally isn’t safe to apply when you’re pregnant or breastfeeding. That said, many OTC creams are fine to use and can help keep skin hydrated to minimize stretch marks. Two options many moms-to-be swear by are Vitamin E oil and Palmer's Cocoa Butter, which you can find in your local drugstore or buy online. Derms say your best defense is to moisturize morning and night, but they caution against falling for any miracle claims. Sometimes no amount of cocoa butter can ward off a line.
Stretch marks are making me very self-conscious—how do other moms deal with their body changing?

You’re definitely not alone; lots of women struggle with body image issues during pregnancy. You might have heard the sound of moms everywhere clapping when Chrissy Teigen posted a close-up of her stretch marks on social media with this caption: “Whatevs.” It may help to remind yourself that every stretch mark or additional pound you see on the scale is all part of this amazing motherhood journey. An expanding belly is, after all, a crucial part of a healthy pregnancy. Having a community of other expectant moms can also be valuable; once you start opening up—about body image and everything else—you’ll quickly realize that this is a shared experience.
Sometimes no amount of cocoa butter can ward off a line.

title.en-US: 11 best pumping hacks for nursing moms

content.value: If you’re thinking about nursing, a breast pump may become a lifesaver when you can’t feed your baby directly, when you need a break from middle-of-the-night feedings, and when you return to work and want to continue providing breast milk to your little one. But just like breastfeeding, pumping can come with its own set of challenges—everything from sore nipples to trouble with let-down (that’s the reflex that allows milk to flow from the ducts towards the nipple). To the rescue: 11 genius tips that pumping moms swear by.
Get in the right P-FOM (pumping frame of mind).

Stress can slow the flow, so it’s a good idea to have a strategy for getting into a calm mindset before you begin a pumping session. You could make a pumping playlist on your phone with relaxing tunes, or even practice a couple of minutes of deep breathing. Just 10 deep, slow inhales and exhales may up your chill factor—and your milk supply.
Become a label machine.

When you open the fridge or freezer to grab a bag or bottle of pumped milk, you’ll want to reach for the oldest one first. That’s because there are guidelines on how long your liquid gold can be stored before you use it. (Exactly how long depends on the storage method. For instance, freshly expressed milk can be stored in the back of the refrigerator for up to five days, according to the Mayo Clinic, while milk in the freezer lasts much longer.) Labeling your stash with the milkspiration date will help you avoid any confusion.
Double up on parts.

The CDC recommends cleaning your pump—all parts that come into contact with your milk—before every single use. This isn’t the cheapest hack in the books, but some moms say it’s worth the convenience, especially when you’re pumping at work and short on time: Keep an extra set of parts in your breast pump bag for days when you don’t have time to stand over the office sink carefully washing everything with soap and water and letting it air dry. (Yep, that’s another requirement, since drying with a cloth can spread germs.)
Take a pre-pump shower.

Turns out, pumping when your breasts are warm can help with output. So if you’re pumping at home before work, taking a hot shower first may make things a bit easier. A steam bath works, too, but let’s keep it real, people. #whohastimeforthat?
Store “milk tapas”—not entrees.

According to the Mayo Clinic, research is unclear on whether it’s safe to give your baby previously frozen milk that's been thawed and frozen again. So your best bet when storing your pumped milk in the freezer is to keep portions small. Making sure you’re only defrosting a serving-size your baby typically eats can help save you from crying over spilled (read: dumped-down-the-drain) milk.
Pump and nurse at the same time.
Multitasking—or, in this case, multimilking—at its finest: When you’re pumping at home, try nursing your baby from one breast while you pump from the other.
Get your partner involved.
Know that rule that says the person who cooks dinner is exempt from doing dishes? Well, consider striking a similar deal here. The person pumping gets a pass on cleaning the contraption.
Wear your LBD (legit breastfeeding duds).

Some outfits aren’t exactly pumping-friendly. A dress with a back zipper, for instance, will make getting to the goods on your body a bit more of a hassle. Many nursing moms say wrap-style dresses are their go-to. Another gift from the breastfeeding gods: hands-free pumping bras that allow you to do other things at the same time—text, email, fly a kite (kidding).
Schedule pump meetings at work.

OK, the only “invitees” to this meeting are boob number one and boob number two. But breastfeeding moms who return to work say there’s no better way to ensure you have time for pumping. Blocking out time on your calendar may also relieve a lot of your when-will-I-pump? anxiety.
Lube up.

If you’re pumping multiple times a day, your nipples may become dry, and the “horns” of the pump can also cause friction on your breasts. Applying a tiny bit of lanolin cream on these areas can make things more comfortable. One brand lactation consultants recommend is Lansinoh; it’s hypoallergenic and preservative-free.
Be sure you have the right pump.

While all the tips on this list can make things easier, the best way to get off on the right foot is to make sure you have the right pump. The first step is finding out what your insurance will cover (different plans cover different manufacturers and styles). If dealing with your insurance company sounds more like a hassle than a hack, there’s help: We’ve partnered with
1 Natural Way

, a company that does the legwork for you at no cost to you. They’ll let you know which suppliers you can choose from under your plan, and even work with your OB-GYN to obtain a prescription for a pump.

title.en-US: Why you should tour the hospital before you give birth

content.value: It’s hard to imagine what childbirth will be like if you don’t know anything about the delivery venue. So even if you’re getting sick of all the schlepping to medical appointments these days, a maternity tour is worth it. Here’s what you need to know:
When should you take a hospital tour?

The end of the second trimester or the beginning of the third works well if you’ve already decided where you want to give birth. But if you’re using the tour to suss out whether you’re making the right choice and you may want to consider other options, taking the tour a bit earlier is good idea and will give you peace of mind.
Should you just show up unannounced?
It’s better to call ahead, since many hospitals only give tours on certain days. Sadly, some hospitals only offer virtual tours, but speak up to your OB-GYN if you’re denied an in-person visit.
Which rooms will you visit?

You’ll likely see the triage area, where you may be checked out before you’re admitted to the labor and delivery ward. You can also view the rooms so you can get a sense of what the shared rooms look like, as well as the private ones—if that’s an option. And if you’re wondering if you’ll get to see the nursery, the answer is: maybe. “Many hospitals today do not have a nursery, which means that babies who don’t need special care stay in the room with you,” says Jackie Stone, MD, a Maven OB-GYN. “A tour gives you a chance to see if there is a nursery or if you and your newborn will be roommates the whole time.”
What questions should you ask?

As many as you can think of! The purpose of this tour is to get you familiar with what to expect on delivery day, and ease some of your anxiety. You can ask about the ratio of nurses to patients; whether doulas are allowed in the delivery room; if nursing students will be in the room (and if you have a say in that); what you need to bring vs. what the hospital will supply (i.e. extra pillows); what happens immediately after you give birth. And don’t be afraid to get specific. For instance, if you’re planning to use a birthing ball or try other mobile labor positions that can help move your baby down the birth canal, ask what they can accommodate. Do they have a tub that you can labor in? Chance are you’ll forget half of your questions if you don’t write them down, so bring a list.

title.en-US: How to pick a great egg freezing clinic

content.value: Fertility doctors, clinics and laboratories have an enormous range of experience. For instance, while nearly every fertility clinic in the US markets their ability to do egg freezing, less than half have ever thawed a single egg. The freezing and thawing of eggs are delicate processes and you’ll want to choose a clinic that can prove to you they do it regularly, and successfully.

Egg freezers should also pay attention to whether this clinic is competent at performing IVF. The reality is that if you need to use the eggs you froze, you’ll have them thawed, inseminated, and transferred at the clinic where they are stored. That is IVF, and it’s a much more involved process than egg freezing.
Here are some things to consider when picking an egg freezing clinic:
Clinic Size and Affiliation

Fertility clinics vary dramatically, and two parameters of real differentiation are both the size of the clinic, and whether the clinic is run as a standalone business, or is part of a larger academic institution. There are trade-offs in all scenarios, and to overgeneralize here are a few:
Larger versus Smaller Clinics

Larger clinics typically have more resources for patients, and often have laboratories that do more cycles and thus have more data to use to fix their processes. On the other hand, a higher percentage of patients (69% vs. 61%) at small clinics feel like they are treated with greater care and decency. Finally, larger clinics tend to make more mistakes, until they reach the “mega clinic” level of 1,000 or more annual cycles.
Private Practice versus Academic Affiliation

Data shows that patients are more likely to consider private practices better run than academic medical center clinics, and after controlling for a number of factors, possibly see higher rates of success. Patients who see doctors in a private practice are nearly twice as likely to have their doctor perform all of their medical procedures, including the transfer (
here
is why that matters). On the other hand, doctors within an academic medical center often have no financial interest in steering a patient in one direction or another.
How Good Is The Laboratory

Most embryologists say that a superb laboratory can double your likelihood of success, and yet patients have almost no way to ascertain if their clinic’s laboratory is any good. Here are a few things to keep in mind. Find out the laboratory's fertilization rate (70% is respectable) and blastocsyst conversion rate (40% – 50% by day five is solid) to get a sense for their ability to take eggs and sperm and deliver promising embryos. Also, have a close look at the experience of the embryologists working in the laboratory, and the culture conditions they keep: are their incubators state-of-the-art (“desktop” are better than “big box”), and are the atmospheric temperatures in those incubators at the recommended 5% levels?

Maven can help you determine what clinics in your area are the highest quality and will give you the best chance for success, determined by rates of single embryo transfer, pregnancy rates, and patient satisfaction—benchmarked against national averages.

title.en-US: 3 mistakes to avoid when feeding your newborn at night

content.value: Whether you’re breastfeeding or bottle-feeding your baby (or doing a bit of both), there’s definitely a learning curve. But the nighttime feedings can get especially tricky. To help make things a little easier, we’ve rounded up a few common mistakes new moms make. Learn them so you can get baby fed and back to snoozing.
Mistake #1: Turning on the light.

Your natural instinct may be to switch on the light so you can see exactly what you’re doing, if your baby has a proper latch, etc. But this sends an immediate message to your little one that it’s wide-awake time—which is not what you’re after. A better bet is to keep the room as dark as you can, maybe by switching on a light in the hallway and keeping the door cracked. This will help your baby doze off again quickly after a feeding.
Mistake #2: Changing your baby after a nighttime feeding.

If you notice that your baby has a dirty or wet diaper before you’re about to feed him, do a diaper change first. This way, he’s more likely to fall and stay asleep after his “meal” because changing him may stimulate wakefulness.
Mistake #3: Staring at a bedside clock.

There’s no way around it: A newborn's need to feed around the clock will leave you seriously sleep-deprived. The last thing new moms need is a constant reminder that they’ve only had their eyes closed for a couple of hours since the last feeding. Try turning your alarm clock around so you’re not staring at the time, which only adds insult to exhaustion.
If you have more questions about baby feeding or sleep, Maven lactation consultants are available to chat with you by video or text anytime you need them.

title.en-US: 4 ways to keep your relationship strong after having a baby

content.value: Remember what your relationship was like before becoming a parent? If you don’t, you’re not alone. Bringing a newborn into the fold can rock your duo in major ways—but that doesn’t mean you can’t survive with your bond healthy, intact, and stronger than ever.
Here are four rules to help you hit your relationship stride after a having a baby.
Be realistic.

Having unattainable expectations of what your relationship will be like after having a baby is a set-up for disappointment. You just became a party of three—or more—and with that comes challenges you often can’t predict. Over time, however, you and your partner will be able to figure out your relationship’s “new normal.” It may not be what you imagined, but—with the right attitude and support for each other—it could be even better. After all, you’re learning to operate as a team in ways you never had to before.
Don’t make assumptions.
One guaranteed way to end up in an argument? Assume that the other person is “in charge” of ___

. The solution: Communicate. Once you and your partner decide who will tackle which duties, there will be fewer chances for resentment. For instance, who is on diaper duty at night? Who will bathe the baby, or put him to sleep? Is laundry a shared task? Take note of everything that needs to be done, then decide on your roles. Disclaimer: Be flexible. There will be plenty of times when The Plan needs to change. Because, baby.
Acknowledge the little things.

Fact: Nothing saves a relationship like a dose of appreciation. Making an effort to thank each other for the small stuff—like, say, ordering a new supply of diapers or doing the dishes—can help keep your bond strong.
Schedule couple time.

OK, so a full-on date night with a five-course dinner might not be realistic in the first few weeks or months of parenthood. But that doesn’t mean you can’t schedule regular mini-dates—say, a quick breakfast at a local cafe while a grandparent babysits, or an hour of couch-time watching your favorite Netflix series together. The only rule: No talking about which stroller to buy or baby’s last feeding. Connecting with each other without all the baby talk can help you band together and remember all the things you love about each other.

title.en-US: Feeling angry at your partner after having a baby?

content.value: Short answer: Abso-freakin-lutely. Longer answer: Read on.

You’ve just had a baby with this person, which could qualify as the most bonded thing any two people can do together. Yet, he or she walks in the door from work, and all you feel is a seething anger. Sound familiar?

It turns out, many new parents admit to having these internal rage-a-thons after having a baby. You’re probably feeling a lot of pressure to tend to your newborn, respond to every cry, feed on demand, and generally keep this little human alive and happy. And if your partner has returned to work after you've been on 24/7 parental duty, it’s easy to think, “If he/she only knew what this is like—but they don’t!”

Enter: The death glance when they walk through the door. Whether it’s the inequity you’re mad at, or you’re just sleep deprived and all this emotion has to come out somewhere, know that your emotions are normal. But it’s a good idea to keep an eye on them, and try to avoid a stressful screaming match every night. At the same time, letting your anger build without ever expressing your feelings can also be toxic. So what’s the middle ground? Step 1: Breathe. (Really—take some deep breaths when you want to throw the breast pump in the general direction of your partner.) Step 2: Hand your baby over to your partner and take a nap.

Giving yourself time to emotionally regroup can help keep your internal volcano from erupting, so that when you do speak up, you’re calm and not reactive. More often than not, it also gives you some perspective. You may tell yourself you’re “in this alone,” but when you really stop to think about it, do you feel you have a willing and compassionate partner? Keeping your heart open to each other will help you get through this challenging time seeing each other as teammates—not opponents.

If it gets increasingly difficult to manage your anger, definitely let your doctor know at your postpartum check-ups, or schedule a video chat with a Maven therapist. Postpartum emotions are a doozy, and support is available.

title.en-US: "I still think about the baby I lost, but the grief did subside"

content.value: Maven Real Talk on Miscarriage with Nicole
32 years old
TV Producer/
Jersey City, NJ
How many miscarriages have you had?
Did you experience your miscarriage(s) before you had children or after you already had a child?
Before
How far along were you when you had your last miscarriage?
6 weeks
How did you find out? Did you have any symptoms?
I started bleeding and called my doctor, who told me to come in.
What surprised you most about having a miscarriage?

I was shocked by how much you have to advocate for yourself to doctors. After it happened, my doctor said I it was “common” and that I should “just try again.” I didn’t like that answer and ended up finding a new doctor.
Did you find out what caused the miscarriage?

My new doctor ran a full panel of bloodwork that he described as “recurrent miscarriage syndrome blood work.” (He explained that two or more miscarriages counts as “recurrent miscarriage”—so I definitely qualified.) The blood tests showed that I had two markers for blood clotting, including a gene mutation that indicates clotting.
Did this knowledge help you when you tried to get pregnant again?

Absolutely. My doctor suggested that, for my next pregnancy, I take a blood thinner—a shot I gave myself every day. Another thing we did differently the next time around was frequent appointments early on; while many women don’t have regular doctor’s visits until their 8th week of pregnancy, my doctor saw me weekly right from the start so he could closely monitor my pregnancy. This allowed us to “troubleshoot.” For instance, he noticed in my early bloodwork that I had low progesterone, so I took progesterone shots daily for the first 12 weeks. He also put me on modified bedrest as well when my ultrasound revealed that I had a hematoma.
How soon after your miscarriage did you start trying again?
I waited an entire year to recover mentally. Then, when I felt I was ready to start the process over again, I made sure I was under the close watch of my doctor.
How open were you with friends and relatives?
Extremely open!
What helped you the most in those initial weeks and months after having a miscarriage?

While we worked to find out what was the cause of my losses, we traveled. I started grad school. I decided to live the life to the fullest and do things that, quite honestly, I couldn’t have done as effortlessly once I had a child.
If you are married or in a relationship, did the experience of pregnancy loss affect your relationship with your partner?

My husband and I were each other’s rock, and going through a miscarriage made us stronger as a couple. His love and support gave me everything. I know, though, that he often felt helpless. I think he wished he could take away the pain I felt, and he hated that I was feeling that my body was somehow to blame for what happened.
Did you seek therapy to deal with the miscarriage? If not, would it have been helpful in retrospect?

I was already in therapy (mainly for my disordered eating), so it was really beneficial to have that support in place when I had my miscarriage. Therapy helped me so much; I suggest it to everyone! My motto: Take care of your mental health as much as your physical well-being.
When people ask you how many children you’ve had (or have), do you include your miscarriage?
No, I do not.
What would you want to tell another woman after suffering a miscarriage?
Find a doctor you love. Sometimes I think my doctor was a placebo. He did everything to help me get pregnant, and he believed we could from the minute I walked into his office.

Stay in your own lane. Every woman’s body is different, especially when it comes to having a baby. Don’t compare yourselves to others. Everyone will have an opinion on what you should try or what you should do next. Try not to take it on, because this needs to be a journey with you, your partner and your doctor at the center.

If or when you have a baby, you may still often think about the babies you lost. But, at least in my experience, the grief does subside when you have a baby. The second I met my daughter, I thought: This is exactly how things were supposed to be.

title.en-US: What is ICSI?

content.value: How is ICSI different from IVF?

Intracytoplasmic Sperm Injection (ICSI) involves injecting a sperm directly into an egg whereas during other types of IVF the unfertilized eggs are exposed to the sperm in a petri dish. ICSI has as good a success rate, but carries a small increased risk of birth defects.
Is ICSI a common procedure?

Some countries have high rates of ICSI, and in Turkey it accounts for more than 70% of all IVF treatments. In the U.S., for cycles with male factor infertility, ICSI use increased from 76.3% in 1996 to 93.3% in 2012. For cycles without male factor infertility, ICSI use increased from 15.4% in 1996 to 66.9% in 2012. In the UK, roughly equal numbers of ICSI and traditional IVF treatments are performed.
What is the most common reason to do ICSI?

ICSI is an effective method of fertilizing eggs in situations when insufficient sperm is available, sperm parameters are compromised, or when previous fertilization methods have failed. Through ICSI, even the most severe cases of male infertility–very low numbers of sperm or even no sperm in the ejaculate–can be successfully treated. In these cases, sperm often can be obtained from the testes or epididymis by a minor outpatient procedure.

title.en-US: Must-know tips for bottle-feeding your baby

content.value: Holding a newborn in your arms and feeding them—whether it's from a breast or a bottle—is an amazing way to bond. But just like breastfeeding, bottle-feeding isn’t always straightforward. Here are a few tips to make the learning curve a little easier.
Time it right.

In some cases, breastfeeding isn’t possible—so you may be bottle-feeding from the start. But if you’re nursing, experts recommend letting your baby get the hang of breastfeeding before introducing a bottle. Check with your OB-GYN or midwife, but the general rule of thumb is to hold off until your baby is at least 4-6 weeks old to avoid “nipple confusion,” says Jackie Stone, M.D., a Maven OB-GYN. (Another word of cautionary advice: If you wait much longer, your child may not want a bottle at all. So when you leave her with a sitter few hours, she may go on a bottle strike and resist eating until you come home—not what you want.)
Select the right sipper.

The reality: you won’t know which bottle your baby prefers until she tries it.
So don’t be alarmed if it takes some trial and error to find a bottle your child doesn’t reject. Get some recommendations from friends, do some research, and consult your budget. Not all baby bottles are created—or priced—equally, so it’s fine to start with a basic, inexpensive option. But if you’ve got a picky eater (er, nippler) on your hands, you may need to splurge on something fancier, like a bottle that is designed to mimic the look and feel of a breast.
Be a temp master.

Room temperature formula is perfectly safe for babies. For breast milk bottles, unless your milk was freshly pumped, it’s probably been hanging out in the freezer or fridge, so warming it up might be the only option. Whatever’s inside the bottle, one thing to know is that you should never nuke them in the microwave; that method doesn’t distribute heat evenly so it can create hot-spots that could burn your baby’s mouth. You can try the old-fashioned method: Heat water on the stovetop, remove it, then plonk the bottle in until the milk is room temp. Or you can invest in a bottle warmer—handy gadgets that make the process a no-brainer: Put milk in the bottle, the bottle in warmer, and wait for the beep. A few drops on the inside of your wrist will tell you if the milk’s too hot or just right.
Don’t be a food pusher.

It can be a good idea to check in with your pediatrician about how much milk you should aim to feed your baby. One very rough guideline is to multiply your baby’s weight by 2.5. So if your baby weighs 10 pounds, he might drink 25 ounces of milk per day—usually in 3 to 4 ounce servings. But keep in mind that any suggestions are really just a ballpark figure. Ultimately, babies will only take as much milk as they’re hungry for.
Learn to spot hunger cues.

Sadly, when hunger strikes, your baby can’t tell you to pass the bottle. But he will give you other cues. For instance, he may start opening his mouth, turning his head to the side with an open mouth as if trying to "root" to a nipple, or smacking his lips. He may also begin to get more squirmy and discontent. And if you miss these signs altogether, don’t worry: You can expect some wailing to really clue you in.

This article is not intended to be a substitute for medical advice or care. Please consult a doctor with any questions you have before taking actions around your health and wellbeing. As always, our Maven practitioners are available, on-demand, to address your concerns. Book an appointment
here

title.en-US: 3 ways to satisfy a frozen treat craving during pregnancy

content.value: Expectant women often wonder if it’s OK to give in to their dietary urges, especially when it comes to sweets. Ice cream and pickle craving, anyone? Well, experts say that as long as you have a balanced diet and get the nutrients you need for you and your growing baby, there can be room for treats. So first, let’s be clear: You are a human—a pregnant human—and enjoying an ice cream cone on occasion is perfectly OK. But if moderation isn’t really your thing (we get you, lady), there are great portion-controlled, lower-calorie, and still totally delicious options in your local grocery store (or online, if you’re a FreshDirect kinda girl). And none of them will do nearly as much damage as polishing off a pint of Ben & Jerry’s. Here are three nutritionist-approved brands to reach for when you have a hankering for frozen treats
Pickles not included.)
GoodPop Freezer Pops

A lot of frozen treats are made with artificial flavors as well as artificial sweeteners, but GoodPop’s natural ingredients mean you can indulge without guilt. The Orange N’ Cream flavor, which tastes like a Creamsicle, has only 80 calories. Other flavor combos like Watermelon Agave, Pineapple Basil, and Cucumber Lime Chile keep things a little more exciting than your average supermarket pop.
Chloe's Pops

The founder is a self-described fro-yo addict whose own pregnancies inspired her to seek out a healthy alternatives to satisfy her sweet tooth. Chloe’s pops are made with fruit, water, and a touch of sugar. There’s even a dark chocolate variety with simple ingredients and less than 60 calories per pop.
Yasso Frozen Yogurt Pops

They're less than 150 calories per serving, and the Greek-yogurt base provides a decent dose of protein (5 grams per bar). Flavors like Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough, Peanut Butter Cup, and Mint Chocolate Chip should keep you from frequenting Baskin-Robbins when an ice-cream craving strikes.

title.en-US: So-called healthy foods to avoid during pregnancy

content.value: Buzzwords never to believe.

You’re trying to make nutritious decisions for you and your growing baby, but relying on the labels marketers slap onto food items could sabotage your healthy-eating goals. Take “gluten-free,” for instance. Unless you’re ditching gluten because you suffer from an actual intolerance, reaching for gluten-free foods isn’t going to help you maintain a healthy pregnancy weight. In fact, gluten-free products are often packed with fat and sugar to make them taste better. Plus, gluten-free processed foods lack fiber—an essential nutrient that helps keep your digestive system running smoothly and increases a feeling of fullness so you’re less likely to overeat.

Similarly, labels like “natural” or “organic” slapped onto a food item may also mask other bad-for-you ingredients. Organic candy, for instance, doesn’t qualify as a superfood. And soda “made with antioxidants” but still packed with sugar isn’t exactly a health elixir. “Lightly sweetened” is another one of those labels that isn’t defined by the FDA.
The bottom line:
Look past the hype on the label, and take stock of all of the ingredients before you toss a so-called health food into your grocery cart. Your body (and your baby) will thank you.

title.en-US: 4 pitfalls to avoid when you’re losing the baby weight

content.value: After spending the last nine months watching the scale creep up, you may be eager to start dropping the pounds. Once you’ve given your body a few weeks of needed recovery time after childbirth, it’s usually OK to begin a diet—as long as you’re following sensible guidelines. Here are four common mistakes to avoid as you approach postpartum weight loss.
Mistake #1: Eating too little.

Every woman’s caloric needs are different, but most women need to eat at least 1,800 calories a day after having a baby—especially if they’re breastfeeding. “It takes between 300 and 700 calories a day to breastfeed a baby!,” says Jackie Stone, M.D., an OB-GYN on Maven’s platform. Even if you don’t intend to skimp on your nutritional needs, it’s easy to “forget” to feed yourself when you’re so focused on taking care of your baby. Keeping some easy go-to meals in rotation can help you avoid undereating on a regular basis—something that could cause fat to be more stubborn than it needs to be. When your body thinks you’re in starvation mode, it may try to hoard every calorie that passes your lips. The lesson: Extreme restriction can backfire.
Mistake #2: Being in a rush to lose the weight.

One to two pounds a week is considered safe at any point in a woman’s life—and the same rule applies to the postpartum period. Not to mention, if you’re breastfeeding you may notice that a more rapid weight loss causes a drop in your milk supply. If you do lose more than two pounds a week, you probably need to add more calories to your diet. But before you rip open the bag of Pirate’s Booty, know that the nutritional value of those extra calories matter. Reach for foods that contain vitamins, minerals, complex carbohydrates (i.e. beans or whole grains, not bagels), protein, and healthy fats.
Mistake #3: Thinking you’re hungry when you’re really just thirsty.

Sometimes when your tummy is gnawing at you, what it really needs is some H20. Maven nutritionists say that women often mistake dehydration for hunger. In fact, sipping regularly may be the easiest weight-loss tool in the postpartum book. One study from Virginia Tech found that people who drank two cups of water before every meal lost an average of 15.5 pounds over three months. That was almost four pounds more than the group who didn’t chug before meals.
Mistake #4: Forgetting that, hello, you just had a baby.

You may have dieted in the past and think you can apply those same principles now. But you might be forgetting that the person you are now needs a little more TLC. Your hormones are still going haywire, you’re sleep deprived, and you’re adjusting to a whole new life as a mom. Plus, if you approach weight loss without a dose of self-compassion, you could set yourself up for added anxiety in the postpartum period. The result? Post-baby life—and losing weight—will be harder than it already is. Bottom line: Cutting yourself some slack is as important as cutting calories.

Need more advice about eating for weight loss after having a baby? book an appointment with a nutritionist on Maven’s platform. You can video chat or text and get the support you need, exactly when you need it.

title.en-US: How to look like you got more sleep than you did

content.value: Despite your best attempts to get some rest before your workday, your baby was up all night, or you were tossing and turning worrying about the next day’s presentation. Look, if the bags under your eyes don’t bother you, then grab your biggest portable mug of coffee, leave the makeup bag untouched, and head into the office confidently accepting that parenthood isn’t always pretty (it doesn’t mean you aren’t). But if you feel better looking more refreshed, here are a few ways to fake a good night’s sleep.
Curl your lashes
If you can barely keep your eyes open, an eyelash curler will instantly make your eyes look larger.
Think cutlery, not cucumbers
If bags under your eyes are a problem, try this: Put a couple of spoons in the freezer, then press them—curved side in—gently over your eyes.
Avoid a vampy lipstick
A dark lip hue will draw attention to dark undereye circles. A natural pinky-tone lipstick is a better bet.
First water, then coffee

Lack of sleep can affect your skin barrier function—specifically, how much water is retained in the outermost layer of your skin. The more hydrated this layer is, the more rested you’ll look. So before you start chugging coffee, make sure you’ve had enough H20 first.
Take a whiff of something invigorating

Here’s a fun fact: Certain scents and essential oils may work better at perking you up than a cappuccino. For instance, breathing in the scent of jasmine can release brain chemicals that boost energy as well as reduce anxiety, according to a study done by the Smell and Taste Treatment and Research Foundation in Chicago. Similarly, peppermint or rosemary can also make you feel more alert. Did somebody say peppermint patties for breakfast?

title.en-US: How to deal with being distracted at work during pregnancy

content.value: Being distracted is something many people deal with, but when you’re pregnant, the struggle may reach a new level. After all, there are so many changes to think about, so many preparations to make, so many onesies to browse. But your ability to stay focused is key to a sense of accomplishment and productivity. Use these tips when you’re starting to feel a little all over the place.
Make a mental now vs. later file.

When the cause of your distraction is a ticker-tape of pregnancy-related to-dos running through your mind, step back and ask yourself: Does this need my attention now? Sure, you’ll have to (at some point) think about childcare, decorate a nursery, and start a savings account for your child’s future. You don’t have to push these thoughts away. Simply acknowledge them, and put them on the mental shelf to think about later—like after the workday.
Prioritize sleep.

The less sleep you get, the more easily you can get distracted from work by scrolling Instagram, surfing the Internet, whatever. A study in the Journal of Applied Psychology found that the less shuteye people got the night before, the more they were likely to stray from their tasks. Sleeping during pregnancy is challenging, so do what you can to protect the quality—and quantity—of your zzz’s.
Be deliberate about your breaks.

Haphazardly deciding you “need” a break from your work can easily spiral into lost hours of productive time. One way to keep yourself on track is to schedule mini-breaks in advance. For instance, you might block out 20-minutes during lunch for a news catch-up, and use this to catch up on the day’s headlines. Or step out of the office to call a fellow pregnant friend and swap first-trimester “can you believe this is happening?” stories. Knowing this putz-around time is planned will help you feel less guilty when you take it—and more focused beforehand.

title.en-US: Fast facts about using your eggs

content.value: When you choose to use your frozen eggs, they'll be thawed, fertilized with sperm in a lab, and implanted in you or a gestational carrier's uterus.
Your health care team might recommend using a fertilization technique called intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI). In ICSI, a single healthy sperm is injected directly into each mature egg.
About 90 percent of eggs survive freezing and thawing, and about 75 percent will be successfully fertilized.

The chances of becoming pregnant after implantation are roughly 30 to 60 percent, depending on your age at the time of egg freezing. The older you are at the time of egg freezing, the lower the likelihood that you'll have a live birth in the future.
Keep in mind that pregnancy rates might be lower when frozen eggs are used, compared with fresh or frozen embryos.
The cost of thawing and insemination can be $5,000 - $7,000 per cycle.

You don’t have to thaw your eggs all at once. Though egg freezing is still new to put an exact number on this, many clinics say that long-term storage of frozen eggs, for up to 10 years or more, does not result in any decrease in quality.
Sources: Mayo Clinic, USC Fertility

title.en-US: Pregnancy and Zika: What you need to know

content.value: First, a quick recap: Zika is a mosquito-borne virus which was first identified in Africa in 1947; it circulated for decades in Africa and Asia but had never been seen in the Americas before it surfaced in hard-hit Brazil in 2015. Then, in February 2016, the World Health Organization declared a Public Health Emergency of International Concern—making Zika a global issue. Here are answers to the Zika questions on many women’s minds:
People aren’t talking about Zika as much lately—is it still an issue?

Yes. It’s true that the number of cases has dropped dramatically in many of the regions where it was prevalent. But that doesn’t mean the virus has disappeared, and the CDC still says that anyone living in or traveling to Zika areas may be at risk for infection.
What does Zika means for baby-making plans?

Women who are pregnant or trying to get pregnant are cautioned against traveling to any locale where Zika lurks. If a woman has traveled to Zika-territory, the CDC suggests waiting at least 2 months before trying to get pregnant. And if a male partner has been exposed through travel, the recommendation is to wait at least 6 months. Not only that, but condoms should be used during vaginal, anal, and oral sex until you have the green light to try having a baby.
How does Zika spread?
Primarily, it’s spread through infected mosquitos. But you can also get Zika by having unprotected sex with someone infected by Zika, even if they don’t have any symptoms.
What, exactly, are the symptoms?

If you do have symptoms at all (most people don’t), you’d could experience a fever, rash, red eyes, muscle pain and headaches. These typically last for less than a week. Keep in mind, so far, there isn’t a vaccine or medication available to treat Zika.
What can happen to your baby if you get Zika while pregnant?

Zika virus is most notorious for causing the birth defect microcephaly, a congenital abnormality that can result in babies being born with abnormally small heads and stunted brain development, as well as other severe fetal brain defects. Babies born after Zika exposure may also have hearing loss, vision problems, and impaired growth.
If you’re pregnant and have been exposed to Zika, do you need to get tested?

Actually, the CDC recently changed their recommendations on this. If you’re pregnant, they recommend getting tested only if you have symptoms of the virus. If you don’t, testing is recommended on a case-by-case basis. The revised recommendations were a result of a growing number of false-positive test results. But the truth is, many OB-GYNs don’t want to take the risk and will support testing even if you don’t have symptoms. So you should definitely talk to your doctor if you’re concerned, or book an appointment with a Maven practitioner for more guidance.
What countries are on the no-go list?
The list is constantly changing, so be sure to check
CDC’s travel website
for areas with risk of Zika before booking that babymoon. This, for the time being, may have to be your motto: #ColoradoIsTheNewCaribbean

This article is not intended to be a substitute for medical advice or care. Please consult a doctor with any questions you have before taking actions around your health and wellbeing. As always, our Maven practitioners are available, on-demand, to address your concerns.

title.en-US: How can I feel good about my body while losing the weight?

content.value: Answer from Mental Health Specialist Mercedes Samudio, LCSW, MSW

Thanks to celebrities and the Royal Family, looking fabulous post-baby is something our society believes is a realistic expectation. There are so many people who shame and guilt women for not bouncing back right away after pregnancy. But the idea that your body will look the same as it did pre-baby, or that you should look a certain way after you give birth, is something worth examining. Having a positive self-image affects so many aspects of your life as a new mom. Here are some tools to help you get your body confidence back.
Develop a routine that feels good.

It’s important that whatever fitness routine you start post-baby is about feeling good and giving yourself the energy you need to keep up with your new baby—as opposed to fitting into a certain dress size. Check in with your OB to make sure that you are cleared for exercise, then maintain a routine that feels loving and not punishing.
Eat foods that make you feel good.

After having a baby, and whether you're nursing or not, it's important to eat foods that give you energy and help you feel your best. When you focus only on losing weight, you may not be getting the nutrition you really need. Knowing you’re making good decisions about what you’re putting into your body can help you be patient with the process of trimming down.
Be gentle with yourself.

If you’re finding it difficult to cultivate self-acceptance, there are things you can do to lighten up on yourself. For instance, repeating mantras and affirmations every morning can help you change your thoughts about your body and make you believe the truth—that you’re OK exactly as you are! Working out your feelings with a therapist can also be valuable during this time.
Find your A-team.

There are tons of mothers who go on walks with their babies in tow (in strollers) and groups where women support each other to stay healthy in the postpartum phase. You can also book an appointment with a Maven nutritionist who can help you figure out how to stock your kitchen and set yourself up for success.

title.en-US: Feeling extra-clingy during pregnancy, explained

content.value: Find out why it’s happening, and what you can do about it.

If giving your partner a goodbye hug in the morning practically makes you hyperventilate, or you’re obsessively sending check-in texts throughout the day, you’re not alone. Even self-described “fiercely independent” women have said they’ve felt extra-clingy during pregnancy.

The magnetic pull to be with your partner could be a form of separation anxiety. Sure, this is usually something you hear about in the context of young kids, but it turns out Adult Separation Anxiety Disorder (ASAD) is a real thing, and it can set in during pregnancy. An occasional bout of can’t-be-without-you feelings toward your partner doesn’t necessary mean you have it, but if the attachment is ongoing and causing you turmoil, separation anxiety could be at play. Some of the signs of ASAD include excessive distress when you anticipate being apart from someone you’re closely linked to, as well as extreme worry about losing (or possible harm befalling) your S.O.

It’s easy to see why, then, pregnancy is a time when separation anxiety can rear its head. Some women say they find their partner’s physical presence to be deeply comforting during pregnancy, and when he or she is away, they get panic-y and overwhelmed. When you’re bringing a new life into the world, it’s normal to feel an intense need for help from your partner to protect it, or just a desire for extra T.L.C. during this vulnerable time.

Obviously, some degree of anxiety while pregnant is normal when you’re going through this major life transition. But if you feel you’re worrying way more than necessary, it’s important to get help. Let your OB-GYN know what you’re experiencing, or make an appointment with a Maven therapist who can offer guidance on ways to find relief.

title.en-US: Real talk from Maven user Adriane about IVF

content.value: 33 years old
Higher Education Admissions
NYC
Why did you decide to start IVF?
3 years of TTC without success, and diagnosis of endometriosis.
Had you been pregnant before when you started?
No.
How many times have you done IVF?
Once.
How did you choose your clinic?
Affiliation with my gynecologist.
What surprised you most about the procedure?
How time consuming it is.
Do you think you had a positive patient experience?
Yes, I liked my doctor and the clinic, and we had success on the first try.
What could have been better?
I wish I would have gotten more eggs but that is something that is out of my control.
How much did it cost each time you did it?
Around $10,000 including medications.
How quickly did you get pregnant?
On the first try.
Are you going to do it again?
Yes, probably for baby #2.
What is your advice to someone about to go through IVF?
Talking with other couples who have gone through the process really helps.
Any tips for managing the emotional stress of IVF?
For me it was having a doctor that I had a good relationship with who I felt comfortable confiding in. Also staying busy with work and other activities.
Any tips for managing the stress that IVF can put on a relationship?
Being open and honest with each other about feelings throughout the process.

This article is not intended to be a substitute for medical advice or care. Please consult a doctor with any questions you have before taking actions around your health and wellbeing. As always, our Maven practitioners are available, on-demand, to address your concerns.
Book an appointment here.

title.en-US: The do's & don'ts of telling your boss you’re pregnant

content.value: You're expecting a child, and you could not be more excited. But if you’re like many moms-to-be, you might be also be a little nervous about delivering the news to your boss. Read on for a few dos and don’ts that will make the whole experience less scary.
Do time it right.

The general rule: The earlier your team knows, the sooner everyone can plan for your time away from work. But this doesn’t mean you have to tell your boss the second you get a positive pregnancy test. Most women announce their pregnancy around the third- or fourth-month mark. (Once you start showing a bump, it’s hard to keep things under wraps.) If you’re up for a promotion, some experts recommend considering waiting until you actually get the job. That said, this isn’t a blanket rule, and depending on your unique circumstances, you may decide it’s best to share before you’re presented with an offer.
Don’t let your boss be the last to know.

Even if you’re close friends with many of your coworkers, telling them before you break the news to your manager is too risky. Career experts caution against this because the last thing you want is for your manager to hear through the office grapevine—instead of from you—that you’re expecting. And in our nothing-is-really-private social media world, you might want to hold off on Instagramming photos of your sonogram until you’ve made the announcement in your workplace.
Do meet face-to-face.

This is one conversation you’ll want to have face-to-face or over video chat if you're working remotely. Set up some time on your boss’s calendar, and hold your head high. (Remember, no apologizing!) Experts also recommend doing some homework about your company’s leave policy and benefits before this talk, so you’ll feel more prepared—and confident.
Don’t leave her hanging.

Even the most cool-and-collected manager could use a little reassurance that she’s not going to lose her awesome employee at the end of your leave. To put her mind at ease, let her know you plan to return (if you do).
Don’t take things too personally.

In a perfect world, every boss would leap from her chair to give you a big hug and tell you how excited she is for you. While this might happen, it’s also a good idea to prepare yourself for any possible reaction. A warm-but-not-exuberant congratulations may simply mean that your boss is dealing with her own set of work pressures.
Do remember that this is your first conversation of many.

The first time you tell your manager you’re pregnant doesn’t have to be lengthy—so resist the urge to cover every aspect of your pre-leave plan. Saying things like, “I look forward to our next chat and working out the details for how I’ll hand over my projects” will demonstrate that you’re already thinking about ways to make your maternity leave successful, without breaking out the project plan Excel sheets prematurely.
Follow up with a thank you.
A quick email after the meeting to let your boss know you appreciate her support of your news will go a long way.
Need some extra guidance? The career coaches on Maven’s platform are pros in this area and can help you navigate any pre-baby work stressors. Book a video appointment to chat anytime, day or night.

title.en-US: What to know about yeast infections during pregnancy

content.value: Coming down with a yeast infection during pregnancy might drive you nuts with discomfort. Here’s the must-read advice for you and your vagina.
How common are yeast infections during pregnancy?

Pretty common. An estimated 10% of women who are expecting get them. Pregnant women are more susceptible to yeast infections because hormone changes can mess with the pH balance of the vagina and make it an ideal environment for yeast to grow.
What are the symptoms?
A yeast infection can triggers intense itching or burning, redness, and a thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge. No fun—we know.
How do you treat a yeast infection during pregnancy?

According to the Mayo Clinic, you can safely treat a yeast infection during pregnancy with OTC suppositories and antifungal vaginal creams like miconazole (Monistat) and clotrimazole (Gyne-Lotrimin). These products are available in one, three, six, and seven-day treatments; the worse the infection, the more likely you’ll need a seven-day formula. One word of caution before you hit the drugstore: You should still check with your doctor before starting treatment to make sure your symptoms aren’t being caused by another type of infection.
What if the OTC treatments don’t cut it?

When yeast infections happen repeatedly or symptoms are severe, some doctors do prescribe an oral drug called fluconazole (Diflucan). But you should stick to the topical stuff during pregnancy, according to guidelines from The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. In a study, use of the oral treatment during pregnancy was associated with an increased risk of miscarriage. While the research didn’t prove a cause and effect, it did raise concerns that the medication may not be safe for expectant women.
Have more questions about coping with common discomforts during pregnancy? Book an appointment with a Maven practitioner and you can video chat—anytime, anywhere.

title.en-US: Is your baby's head too flat?

content.value: Find out what’s going on and how to fix it.
What does it mean if my baby’s head looks abnormally flat?

He may have flat-head syndrome, also called plagiocephaly, a common condition that sounds scary but is usually harmless. The best way to confirm it is to visit your child’s pediatrician for an evaluation.
Why does it happen?

Babies have soft skulls, which is necessary to allow their brains to grow. But it also means their heads can be shaped and molded easily, particularly when they’re spending lots of time on their backs.
How common is it?

Much more common now than it used to be. In the 1990s, the National Institute of Child Health & Human Development launched the “Back to Sleep” campaign. Before this, infant side-sleeping or even snoozing on their tummies was a lot more prevalent. But the initiative encouraged parents to place their little ones on their backs when sleeping, to help reduce the risk of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS). The campaign was successful, and greatly reduced the rate of SIDS. Plagiocephaly, however, has increased from 1 in 300 infants to nearly 1 in 10 infants.
Does that mean I should stop putting my baby down to sleep on his back?
No! SIDS is a life or death issue, and a flattened head deformity (one that can be corrected or even correct itself) is not.
