What can I do to correct my baby’s flat-head syndrome?

Your pediatrician will monitor it at first to assess the severity. Mild cases sometimes resolve on their own. You’ll likely be encouraged to make sure your baby is getting plenty of tummy time. Avoiding long car rides can also help, since too many hours in a car seat can contribute to the problem. That said, if your baby’s flat spot doesn’t seem to be getting better with these strategies, your doctor may recommend the use of a special helmet. These are molded to your child’s head but leave space in the back so the skull can grow in that direction. In most cases, parents are advised to not wait longer than 4 to 6 months to begin treatment with a helmet because babies head growth is pretty rapid in the first year.

title.en-US: Read this on “I want to quit my job” days

content.value: Nearly every working parent has that moment when they wants to throw in the towel. Here are a few things to consider before you take a career time-out.
Write down 5 things you get out of your job

Don’t worry, this can get very basic—because even the small stuff is important to acknowledge. PS: If the reason you went back to work after having a baby is, first and foremost, getting a paycheck, that’s valid. Put $$$ at the top of the list. Other things that might be true for you: Work gives me an intellectually stimulating environment to go to everyday, and I get to have conversations with inspiring people. Or, my job provides opportunities to identify my strengths and explore my potential. Or, I have a real community at work; my colleagues are more than peers, some of them are friends. The idea isn’t to paint a rose-colored picture—it’s simply to see things in a more balanced light instead of focusing only on the hard parts of being a working parent.
Write down 5 things you contribute to the workplace

We’re sure the office wouldn’t be the same without your famous funfetti cake. But try to note the stuff that makes you walk out of the office feeling better about yourself than you did when you walked in the door. Maybe you have a special skill set that has been crucial to the company’s growth, and that fills you with pride. Maybe you’re the one who is always looking out for the newbies, doing what you can to elevate and inspire others. Whatever your contributions, seeing them on paper can put you in touch with your value on days when a crisis of confidence makes you want to run. Even if you think you’re not “enough” or “doing enough” after having a baby, you’re probably contributing more to the workplace than you give yourself credit for.
Just pause

Leaving the workforce isn’t a mistake—every parent has to make a decision that’s best for their family. But what you might regret is making a choice to quit your job in the middle of a heightened emotional state (which, let’s face it, most new parents are in the middle of). In the same way that experts suggest holding off on big decisions following the death of a loved one or after a break-up, it could be wise to press the pause button now. Wait until your emotions aren’t so intense, give it some time, and then ask yourself what you really want.
If you need more help with your transition back to work, Maven career coaches are available, and have specific experience helping moms in this phase of their lives.

title.en-US: How to make it through all 3 trimesters at work

content.value: For most pregnant people, working in a fully-reclined position with occasional foot massages in between meetings isn’t going to happen. But that doesn’t mean you can’t make yourself as comfortable as possible. Steal these six smart tips from Maven providers.
Give your desk set-up a pregnancy makeover

It’s a known fact that pregnancy and back pain often go hand in hand. If working at your desk seems to be exacerbating matters, a few easy tweaks can help ease the strain. For instance, adjusting your chair so your knees are at a 90-degree angle, directly over your ankles, can help keep your spine comfortably upright. You can also try propping a pillow behind your low back or even bring heat packs to work if the pain is intense. Before making any purchases, talk to your manager or HR team as they may cover the cost of workplace comfort items such as a lumbar pillow.
Keep a water bottle on your desk

Drinking lots of H20 is important for plenty of reasons, including helping to prevent pregnancy constipation (#notfun) and decrease your risk for preterm labor. Keep a water bottle on your desk to remind yourself to sip regularly. If you’re expecting, your goal should be to drink at least 10 cups of fluids each day, according to the Mayo Clinic.
Skip the heels
If your feet are swollen or heels tend to lead to back pain, you may need to retire them (for now). Try a lower heel, wedge, sneakers or flats. Your lumbar spine will thank you.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Ask for help

One common struggle pregnant people feel is the desire to be perceived as competent—a.k.a. capable of performing all the tasks they did before they got pregnant. But Maven OB-GYNs say you shouldn’t let that keep you from asking for help when you need it. If any of the physical demands of your job feel unsafe—even, say, lifting a box of photocopy paper or getting ready for an office move into a new workspace—don't be afraid to ask a colleague to help with heavy-lifting.
Take mini walking-breaks

Because we’re all about real talk, one word: hemorrhoids. They’re more common during pregnancy than you think, so when you sit for long stretches, you could be putting much pressure on the veins around your rectum. Even if you’re lucky enough not to be dealing with this issue, getting up to walk around can prevent you from feeling fatigued and also do good things for your circulation. Set a timer on your phone to remind you to stand up every 30 or so minutes.
Bypass the office vending machine

While giving into a craving for a Pop-Tart or a Twix bar may seem like good self-care, a junky diet has been shown to make pregnancy more exhausting and uncomfortable than it needs to be. High-sugar, high-fat foods may lead to an energy crash, heartburn, and other pregnancy discomforts. An occasional indulgence is nothing to fret about, but stocking your desk drawer and office fridge with some healthy snacks like almonds, fruit, and plain yogurt can help you from hitting the vending machine too often. Need more nutrition advice? Maven Nutritionists have experience working with women before, during, and after pregnancy, so they can help you customize a plan that makes you feel amazing.
Don't be afraid to ask a colleague to help with heavy-lifting.

title.en-US: The best & worst fats to eat during pregnancy

content.value: Because not all fats are created equal. Read on for the need-to-know info.

If you're a fat-free-everything kind of person, pregnancy is an ideal time to rethink your approach. Similarly, if you’ve been on a high-fat meal plan, it’s a good idea to find a more moderate ground. Fat is an essential nutrient in a healthy diet, providing energy and helping your body absorb certain nutrients. And fatty acids are also vital for your baby’s development throughout pregnancy.
How much fat should you eat per day?

According to The University of California, San Francisco Medical Center, roughly 25% - 35% of your daily calories should come from fat. Since fat contains 9 calories per gram, aim for no more than 78 grams of fat daily when eating 2,000 calories per day and no more than 97 grams of fat per day when following a 2,500-calorie meal plan. (The amount of calories you need during pregnancy varies from one woman to the next, so check with your doctor or book an appointment with an OB-GYN or nutritionist on Maven’s platform.)
Where should those fats come from?

Great question—let’s start with the ones to avoid: Trans fats are often found in processed foods; they show up in things like chips, cookies, and your favorite fast food. Trans fats are created through a process that adds hydrogen to liquid vegetable oils and increases the shelf life of products. The problem is that they raise your body’s bad cholesterol and lower the good cholesterol, putting you at greater risk for heart problems and diabetes. Another type of fat that’s low on the list of nutritionists’ recommendations is saturated fat–which is found in butter, cheese, red meat, and other animal-based foods. While some experts are studying whether they are as dangerous as we once thought, for now the American Heart Association says saturated fats shouldn’t take up too much space in your diet. So if trans and saturated fats are mostly out, what’s left? Polyunsaturated and monounsaturated fats. Polyunsaturated fats—good sources include fatty fish such as salmon and and sardines, as well as flaxseeds and walnuts—can help lower your bad (LDL) cholesterol levels. Likewise, monounsaturated fat is a great plant-based source of fat found in nuts, seeds, avocado, olives, and avocado.

title.en-US: Yes, postpartum OCD is a thing—here's what you need to know

content.value: We hear a lot about the baby blues, and, increasingly, about postpartum depression. But one mental health issue that some new moms deal with often flies under the radar: postpartum OCD. One mother we talked to describes her experience this way: “I started having intrusive thoughts a couple of weeks after I gave birth, and they got so bad that I was scared to be alone with my son.” So what’s at the root of this, and how can women get help? Read on for the need-to-know info.
What, exactly, is postpartum OCD?

This is the term for obsessive compulsive disorder that manifests in moms during the postpartum period. Experts don’t know exactly how many women suffer with the condition, but they do know it’s underreported. For one, there’s often a lot of guilt associated with it, so moms are afraid to open up. It can also be hard for providers to diagnose, given that worrying is par for the course when you’re a new parent. But when OCD is present, worry takes on a whole new meaning. According to the Mayo Clinic, “OCD obsessions are repeated, persistent and unwanted thoughts, urges or images that are intrusive and cause distress or anxiety.” It’s not just that you’re having the thoughts; it’s that you’re really, really bothered by them.
What counts as an OCD obsession?

The OCD Center of Los Angeles says that in mothers with the condition, “the focus of obsessions is often on the fear of purposely harming the newborn, or somehow being responsible for accidental harm.” Every woman’s experience is obviously very different, but parents with OCD have described things like counting their child’s breaths during a nap to make sure their baby is still alive, having visions of an infant drowning in the bath, and recurring images of a little one suffocating in her sleep. Interestingly, the more that people with OCD try to stop their obsessions, the more distressed and anxious they become.
Does having scary thoughts mean you’re going to act on them?

Although the things you’re thinking and picturing can be very frightening, research shows there’s a very low risk of acting on them. Many moms with OCD don’t realize this, which only adds to more suffering and isolation. For instance, if you constantly have thoughts of your baby dropping out of your arms, you might think you’ll intentionally drop him, so you deal with this by avoiding picking your baby up. That can wreak havoc on a mother-child bond. Experts say it’s important to remember that the thoughts are anxiety driven and not psychotic. (Postpartum Psychosis is another illness, and it’s very rare.)
Does the stress of new motherhood cause OCD?

Not exactly. According to the Anxiety and Depression Association of America (ADAA), stress doesn’t cause OCD. But if someone is already predisposed to the condition, a stressful life event (i.e. becoming a new mom!) can trigger OCD symptoms. And if OCD symptoms are already present, stress can worsen them. By the way, fatigue—something that new moms are definitely familiar with—can also affect OCD.
How can you tell if your thoughts or tendencies require professional help?

It usually comes down to a matter of degree. It’s normal to have fleeting thoughts about the possibility of something happening to your baby. But if the thoughts are pervasive and keep you from doing everyday parenting tasks, it could be cause for concern. For instance, if a fear that strangers might hurt your little one keeps you from ever leaving the house, that’s a sign to seek help. Talk to your doctor or book an appointment with a mental health specialist in Maven’s platform. The good news is that there are good treatment options, including cognitive behavioral therapy and medication. The main thing is to know you’re not alone, and support is out there.

title.en-US: Maven real talk on egg freezing with Rachel

content.value: 35 years old
Registered Dietitian & Health Coach
NYC
Why did you decide to freeze your eggs?
January 2018
How old were you when you did it?
Did your doctor ever bring up egg-freezing with you?
No. And if things hadn’t gone the way they did, I would have been devastated she hadn’t brought it up.

Do you feel your doctor was real with you about the fact that egg freezing isn’t foolproof? How did he or she explain the risks to you, and do you feel you were as informed as you could’ve been going into the process?
They were very, very real. The consent form was like selling my soul. But I needed real talk.
How did you choose your clinic?
Based on a recommendation from someone else.
How much did it cost?
How many eggs did you get?

Eleven. After a final count of 32 self-administered shots of hormones, 10 blood draws, 9 ultrasounds, and a lot of people digging around in and outside “down there,” I got put under with general anesthesia and, miraculously, 15 eggs were retrieved. 11 of these eggs were mature and viable and are now cryogenically frozen...frozen in time.
Would you say you had a positive patient experience? What could have made it better?
Yes. I needed the kind of care I got!
What surprised you most about the procedure? Was it painful?

I was surprised by how many hormones I had to take leading up to the procedure. Another thing I was shocked by: Anesthesia is so ridiculous. I don’t remember a thing that happened after it was administered. I am still baffled by how you just “go away” while the retrieval is happening, and then... poof, it’s over.
Were there any emotions involved with deciding to freeze your eggs, and going through the process?

Immense. In June 2017, I turned 35. I was semi-single. What I mean by that is I was holding onto to an entirely wrong-for-me romantic match. Though I did love him, I was pushing to make it work because he said we were going to have a baby. I was jumping through hoops, going to couples’ therapy alone, adjusting who I am so we could be parents. Sometimes you want something so much—in my case, a child—that your brain chemistry changes. My intuition finally overrode me and that relationship exploded. I decided to empower myself and move toward my goals. I went to get tested to see what my fertility looked like, and I was told I am likely going through early menopause, and if I ever wanted a chance of having a biological child, I had to “harvest” immediately. So I started the process soon after that.
How do people react when you tell them you froze your eggs?

It depends on the person. Many women my age don’t want to face that they might not be able to have a child on their own. It’s also really hard for people to believe that someone as healthy as I am might not be able to have a child without medical interventions.
If your best friend was thinking about freezing her eggs, what advice would you give her?

Get your AMH measured and your follicle count done. AMH is an “anti-mullerian hormone” test that gives you an estimate of your remaining egg supply. Then you have a picture of your fertility outlook, and you can really make an informed decision. I am so happy I got tested.
What’s one thing you’d like to see change about the perceptions around egg-freezing?
I’d like people to understand that what you want to do with your body and your life is your own business, and not anyone else’s. No one can decide what’s right or wrong for you.

title.en-US: 3 newborn worries almost all new parents have

content.value: You and your partner have just brought home a baby—operating instructions not included. If you're feeling a bit anxious about how to care for your newborn, that's totally normal. First, know that the fragile-looking tiny human in your arms is actually an incredibly resilient little being. And with a bit of guidance, you will soon feel like an old pro at this whole parenting thing.
Here are a few common things many new parents stress about, and tips on how to relax.
Touching the soft spots on your baby's head

These soft areas (a.k.a. fontanelles) might seem very fragile, but they're actually a strong, protective membrane. Hey, think of what they endure getting through a birth canal in vaginal deliveries. Enough said. No need to freak out if you've touched these spots, and you should even wash them just like you do the rest of the baby's head during bath time.
Trimming your baby's nails

We know: It seems like a form of baby torture. But if you don't trim your baby's nails—which grow very fast—he may scratch his face or eye. Many experts suggest doing the task while baby is sleeping. And you definitely want to go at it with a mini nail clipper designed for babies—they're much safer than adult-sized clippers. During the first few weeks of a baby's life, your pediatrician may recommend using only an emery board (a.k.a. nail file) to avoid accidentally nipping the skin. If you do see a drop of blood, apply a bit of pressure and a dab of antibiotic ointment—and consider it a right of passage into parenthood.
Giving your baby a bath

Soft baby skin is extra slippery when wet, so it's normal if you and your partner feel a little anxious about bath time. But a little know-how will help you feel more confident. Keep in mind: Until your baby's umbilical cord stump falls off, you'll be giving her sponge baths, gently washing with a soft washcloth and mild soap. Once baby is cord-free, you can move on to a plastic baby tub that fits into the sink and prevents the baby from slipping. Test the water to make sure it's not too hot—it should be just a little bit warmer than lukewarm, and don't keep the water running while your baby is in the tub. One biggie to always remember: Never leave your baby alone in the bath, not even for a second. (Scary but true: babies can drown in less than an inch of water.) When bath-time is over, gently pat your baby dry, then dress her in a clean diaper and clothes. Baby bath robe with cute bunny ears? Totally optional.

This article is not intended to be a substitute for medical advice or care. Please consult a doctor with any questions you have before taking actions around your health and wellbeing. As always, our Maven practitioners are available, on-demand, to address your concerns. Book an appointment
here

title.en-US: 5 things no one tells you about periods after pregnancy

content.value: Maven OB-GYNs say that one of the most-asked questions about what body changes women can expect after pregnancy is this: “When will my period come back, and what can I expect when it does?” To put an end to the confusion, here are five facts you need to know.
Breastfeeding is a big factor.

Prolactin, the main hormone responsible for milk production, suppresses ovulation. So if you’re breastfeeding exclusively morning and night, you may be not get your period until you stop nursing, or until you start supplementing with formula-feedings. (Some breastfeed-only moms do see their period return six months after they give birth.) Not breastfeeding at all? You might notice your period resume within a month or two after you give birth. And if you’re breastfeeding and giving your baby a bottle (whether it’s breastmilk or formula), ovulation could kick back in within a few months.
You can get pregnant before your first postpartum period.

This means that when you’re ready to start having sex again after giving birth—by the way, doctors advise waiting at least six weeks—you'll need to use some form of protection to avoid getting pregnant. Breastfeeding moms who turn to hormonal contraception should stick to progestin-only options since estrogen can affect your milk supply.
Click here
to book a video appointment with a Maven OB-GYN to discuss the best birth control for you and give you a same-day prescription.
Your cycle may be irregular for a while.

Just because your period made its first appearance after baby doesn’t mean it’s committing to regular showtimes. It isn’t uncommon for things to be a little wonky for a while—you may miss a period (or more), or deal with spotting in between. The good news is that period mayhem should work itself out within a year.
Holy flow! This is not what we’re used to, people.

Remember when you knew exactly what was coming every 28-ish days, and could plan your underwear/panty liner/life accordingly? Well, in the Great Big Body Upheaval that is childbirth, your flow may look a lot different for a while. For instance, it could become heavier. One reason for a heavier flow, according to the Cleveland Clinic, is having a larger uterine cavity after childbirth, which may mean more shedding of the endometrial lining. (PS: A bit of blood clotting is normal the first time you get your period, but if the clots last longer than a week, call your doctor.)
Sometimes things get better, not worse.

Call it a gift from the childbirth gods: Some women say goodbye to the long or painful periods they had pre-baby. When this happens, it can be attributed to a dilated cervix or the pregnancy hormones that help relax uterine muscles. Our advice? Don’t ask why. Just say, hallelujah.
Have more questions about periods after baby, or need an Rx for birth control? Book an appointment with a Maven OB-GYN.

title.en-US: How to spot the signs of a good (and bad) daycare

content.value: There comes a time in every working parent’s life when the question of who will watch your child will come up. Let’s all acknowledge a parenthood reality: For most people, the decision often comes down to what you can afford. Remembering that children can thrive in many different environments—whether that’s at home with a nanny, at a daycare center, or over at grandma’s house—may help you find peace with whatever option you choose.

If you’ve decided that daycare makes the most sense for your family, you might be wondering where to begin your search, and how you’ll know when you’ve found the right match. Here are some tips to help you through this process.
How do you begin to look for the right daycare?

The first and most obvious way: Talk to other parents. A recommendation from someone you trust can be reassuring as you prepare to leave your child with someone who, well, just isn’t you. One good resource to keep in mind is the National Association for the Education of Young Children. To get the NAEYC stamp of approval, a day care must go through a pretty strict accreditation process. As for home-based child care, search the database of the National Association for Family Child Care (NAFCC) for accredited providers. While you’ll still need to do your homework, these avenues can help you zero in on childcare centers that are held to higher standards.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
What criteria do you need to look for in a daycare?

Every family’s needs will be different. But there are some factors that can help you rest assured that your child is in the right hands. Here’s a cheat-sheet of questions to ask during your site visit:
What’s the ratio of children per caregiver? Many experts recommend one caregiver per every three to four infants.
How flexible is the daycare with drop-off and pick-up and times? And if late pick-up is an option, will you be hit with a bill for the extra watch time?
Will you still need to pay for the days your child doesn’t go to daycare, say, when he’s sick or you’re taking a family vacation?
What’s the turnover rate? This will help you uncover how consistent (or not) your baby’s caregivers will be.

Is there a webcam? This might be a relief if you’re the type of parent who wants to keep an eye on your child during the day (yes, that’s your little Johnny rolling over, and we’re sure all your coworkers want to huddle around your computer to take a look) But make sure you ask safety questions, too. For instance, is the webcam password protected?
Will any of the essentials—like diapers, blankets, formula–be provided for by the daycare? Or is it a strictly B.Y.O. environment?

What’s for lunch? If your child is past the milk-only stage, you’ll want to know what kind of grub is on the menu. If it’s nothing but junk, and you’re all about organic baby food, you’ll probably want to make a note to self.
What’s the nap-time M.O.? For instance, if your child won’t nap without being rocked to sleep with a bottle, find out if the daycare can accommodate that.

And the one question only you can answer: What does your gut say? Even when a daycare checks all the right boxes, if your Bad Vibes Radar is going off, it’s probably not the best childcare choice for your baby.
If your Bad Vibes Radar is going off, it’s probably not the best childcare choice for your baby.

title.en-US: 3 ways to deal with stress during pregnancy

content.value: Quick tips for dealing with mom-to-be anxieties.
Sadly, any stress you had before you got pregnant doesn’t disappear or go on hiatus along with your period. (Although that would be nice.) Here are a few stressors that may sound familiar:

Can I afford this baby? How will I function as a sleep-deprived person? Am I healthy enough for my growing baby? Will I ever feel confident in body again? How will I cope with work while feeling so awful?
We can go on... but we won’t. When you find yourself working yourself up into a pregnancy tizzy, take a deep breath and...
1. Recognize that worrying is par for the course.

Whatever worry thoughts are running through your head, it’s important to know that you’re not alone. Early pregnancy can be a doozy for many women. Besides the weepiness (totally normal), you may be dealing with new anxieties that didn’t surface until you were expecting. So if you’re a little more on edge than usual, try not to add to stress by labeling it “wrong.”
If you're concerned that you're experiencing above-normal levels of anxiety, we're here to help. Take
this assessment
to see how severe your symptoms are and share your results with a Maven Mental Health provider.
2. Remind yourself that you don’t have to have all the answers now.

One thing that intensifies anxiety is a pressure to have all your worries resolved today. Most likely, however, things can wait. Even if pressures feel real (because they are), you can remove the burden of needing to have everything figured out ASAP—like how you’re going to pay for your kid’s college tuition.
3. Learn to ask for help.

If you’ve been self-reliant all your life, it can be hard to lean on others. But there’s no better time to learn that important skill. Reaching out for support may alleviate some of the pressure you feel now, and also set you up with a team of allies who can be there for you after you have the baby.

title.en-US: How one relationship changed after baby

content.value: 38 years old
Stay-at-home mom
Illinois
What was the hardest thing on your relationship after having a child?
Lack of sleep, and realizing that sometimes we had no idea what we were doing.
What was the best thing that happened to your relationship after having a child?
Seeing my husband turn into a daddy, and falling in love with our baby.
What was the biggest stressor on your relationship after having a child?

As much as we both wanted a child, we were so unprepared for how scary caring for a newborn can be. We took all the classes beforehand, but nothing can truly prepare you. We called the pediatrician often, and asked what websites she recommended for us to look things up (they are not all equal). That helped a lot. I wish we had reached out and asked for more help sooner.
How do you think you changed with motherhood?
I don’t second guess my instincts anymore.
How do you think your partner changed with fatherhood?
He worries a lot more, but I have to say, his paternal instincts are spot on.
In those early weeks of adjusting to motherhood, what did your support system look like and how did your partner fit into that picture?
My support system was almost nonexistent, but my husband really tried his best.
Is there any advice you can give new moms about how to keep your relationship strong after having a child?
Enjoy the quiet moments together, offer to keep an ear out for the baby so your wife can nap/shower/rest
How involved was your partner in your prenatal or pediatric care? Do you wish he/she came with you to more doctor’s appointments?
I do wish he came with me to more prenatal appointments. That said, he’s very involved in her pediatric care.
How does your partner describe any differences in your relationship?
Sleep deprived but adjusting. Priorities adjusted tremendously, but she’s so worth it.
Did you and your partner pursue couples counseling during pregnancy or afterwards? In retrospect, do you think therapy would have been helpful?
We didn’t pursue any couples counseling.
Did you have any disagreements in terms of your family values and how to raise your children?

We didn’t have these disagreements. The truth is, we’ve been married for a long time and tried for years to have a baby before our daughter was born, so we had lots and lots of discussions before she came along and we were on the same page.
Did you feel any strong negative emotions towards your partner after having a child?
Honestly, no. I wish he helped more in the beginning, and we had arguments, but I didn’t feel any jealousy or resentment.
Do you feel like you had a more equal relationship before having children?
Sometimes. Before having our daughter, we both worked and contributed financially. Now we’re a one-income household.
When did everything balance out again?
Well, my being home allows me to do more than when I worked outside the home. I cook way more, do all the shopping, and most of the cleaning and holiday planning.

title.en-US: Which pregnancy symptoms don’t go away after childbirth?

content.value: Answer from OB-GYN Jacquelyn Stone, MD

It would be nice if our bodies resumed complete “normal” functioning right after we deliver, but sometimes things can take a while to recalibrate. Here are three pregnancy symptoms that typically don’t just go away when you give birth.
Constipation.

Increased progesterone related to pregnancy can cause constipation. After delivery, pain medications as well as the stress on your body from delivery (or from surgery if you had a C-section) can lead to constipation. You may also experience being backed up while breastfeeding due to hormonal changes: High levels of progesterone can cause constipation to linger.
Heartburn.

Sometimes heartburn and acid reflux go away pretty soon after birth. However, some women who breastfeed continue to have symptoms. The culprit here is progesterone. Progesterone levels are high during pregnancy and breastfeeding, and the result is that the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) can become relaxed, making it more likely for stomach contents including acid to push up through the valve. Dietary changes or over the counter medications can usually help.
Hemorrhoids.

These painful swollen blood vessels around your rectum unfortunately do not promptly disappear once that bundle of joy is in your arms. Constipation and prolonged pushing can cause these unwanted friends to stick around. The good news is, however, for most women hemorrhoids resolve within the first month after delivery.

title.en-US: Could loud noises hurt your unborn baby’s hearing?

content.value: Find out if it’s really OK to turn up the music.

It turns out that the womb isn’t exactly a quiet sanctuary. Besides the sounds of your tummy growling and heart beating, for example, at a certain point outside noises also make their way to your baby. A fetus’s ears are mostly developed at around 20 weeks—which means this is when babies can begin detecting sounds (although they usually don’t start responding to sound until 24 - 32 weeks).

You may be wondering if this means you need to avoid loud concerts or even walking by construction sites. When high-decibel noise is extreme and consistent, studies suggest there is a chance for hearing problems to occur. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says moms should avoid consistent loud noises exceeding 115 dBA—we’re talking chainsaws and heavy machinery, not an iTunes jam-session in your living room. But unless you’re attending rock concerts regularly or work near a construction site, your OB-GYN will likely tell you to relax, and that the occasional live music event won’t cause your baby any hearing loss. Thanks to the protective sac of amniotic fluid, things get substantially muffled in utero.

title.en-US: Real talk from Maven user Alia about freezing her eggs

content.value: 38 years old
Entrepreneur
NYC
Why did you decide to freeze your eggs?
Once I broke up with my boyfriend, I realized it would take longer than I thought to get married and have children.
How did you choose your clinic?
My friend referred me.
What surprised you most about the procedure
? I was pretty well-informed so thankfully nothing too shocking.
Was it painful?
No, not very painful at all.
Did you like your experience?
It was a positive experience but looking back, I didn’t get as many eggs as I wanted, and I didn’t like being on birth control.
What could have been better?
More eggs.
How much did it cost?
How many eggs did you get?
Are you going to do it again?
Yes.
What is your advice to someone about to go through egg freezing?
Try to get as little medication as possible. Use Maven to find out the success rate of egg retrieval and pregnancy per clinic.

title.en-US: Real talk from Maven user Samantha about IUI

content.value: 36 years old
Account Management
Bucks County, Pennsylvania
How old are you?
Where do you live?
Bucks County, a suburb outside of Philadelphia.
What is your job?
Account Management.
Why did you decide to start IUI?

I've been told since I was 15 that I would probably need help having children since I am hypothyroid and have PCOS. At age 33, I was evaluated by a reproductive endocrinologist and infertility specialist who said I was not ovulating and would need to seek treatment. Letrazole plus IUI was the plan.
Had you been pregnant before when you started?
No.
How many times have you done IUI?
Twice. For both the first and second pregnancy.
How did you choose your clinic?
I chose the specialist based on top reputation and the best success rate in my area.
What surprised you most about the procedure?
The calculated timing of everything and amount of testing to determine your next move.
Do you think you had a positive patient experience?
Yes. I felt like the office and my doctor were my biggest advocates to get me pregnant.
What could have been better?

The only hiccup was during my first pregnancy when I went to see a partner in the practice at my five-week ultrasound, they told me I was having twins. When I went back the following week my main doctor said my ultrasound was read incorrectly and I only had one baby. I was concerned with the misinformation and alignment between the doctors.
How much did it cost each time you did it?
Insurance paid for everything except the ovulation injection shot which cost $136. I also had $10 copays each time I went.
How quickly did you get pregnant?
First try for both pregnancies.
Are you going to do it again?
Yes.
What is your advice to someone about to go through IUI?

Clear your mind. Don't get obsessed with the results. You will receive feedback on blood, urine, ultrasounds measuring your follicles, partner’s sperm, etc. over a three week period of time. Schedule activities for yourself that will distract you. Go out with friends (except for when you need to have intercourse), book a massage or read an uplifting book. And get in the mindset that your time will come—if it works this time it will be fantastic but if not you can do it again.
Any tips for managing the emotional stress?

Seek out a therapist that has experience treating patients going through IUI/IVF if your family/friend support group is not helping. Sometimes we all need an objective professional to listen and guide us through this time. Talking with other friends who have gone through it is also helpful but remember that everyone is unique and your journey may be different.
Any tips for managing the stress this can put on a relationship?

Discuss how you feel when needed. Prepare your partner that you may act a little differently or off during time time based on the medications. But it should all be temporary. Tell them how they can best support you and what you need from them during this time.
What other question are we not asking but should be? Anything else you want to add?
How many times do I need to go through IUI before I try something else? Research clomid and letrozole. You have a smaller chance of getting pregnant with multiples with letrozole.

Also, look into acupuncture! I received this during my first IUI treatment when my follicles were not at size. I did acupuncture and my follicles grew to size in two days. My doctor was really impressed.

This article is not intended to be a substitute for medical advice or care. Please consult a doctor with any questions you have before taking actions around your health and wellbeing. As always, our Maven practitioners are available, on-demand, to address your concerns.
Book an appointment here.

title.en-US: 3 habits of working parents who leave the office on time

content.value: If you’re a working parent, chances are that leaving the office at the time you planned to head home feels like a major victory. There’s also a pretty good likelihood that this happens far less than you’d like it to. So what can you do to squeeze more hours out of your workday? These three habits have been proven to work. Try one or all of them to see if your days become a little (or a lot) less stressful.
Practice circuit training.

In the same way that circuit training can help you get a full workout if your time at the gym is limited, circuit training at the office can help you get more done in less time. The idea is to focus on one task, and go “hard”—give it your full attention to completion—before you move on to the next. This is the opposite of multitasking, which may seem like a good idea but often backfires. If you’re trying to crank out a few emails while simultaneously participating on a conference call, your efficiency takes a hit instead of getting a boost. Not convinced? The American Psychological Association reported that even brief mental blocks created by shifting between tasks can make you 40% less productive.
Attend meetings when you have to.

As a working parent, time is your most precious asset. So when you have some control over it, make sure you’re only attending meetings that will help achieve the goals of your company. Of course, it’s important to be a team player, but there may be instances when a tactful decline can help you skip meetings that aren’t central to your role. How do people actually go about this? First, they assess the situation to make sure bowing out really seems like a good idea. Then they might take the following approach: Ask the meeting organizer how she’ll need you to contribute. If her response makes it clear that your presence is a nice-to-have but not essential—for example, “Oh, I invited everyone on the team”—ask if it would be OK to sit it out and get a quick download later. Another tactic would be to suggest attending a portion of a meeting that might be most relevant to you.
Back away from your email.

Don’t worry—no one is suggesting you ditch email and tell your boss you’d prefer she delivered sticky notes to your desk instead. But checking your inbox in discrete chunks instead of responding whenever you hear a ding can go a long way in boosting your productivity—and your happiness. Research found that when people limited email to just three times a day, they were more able to complete their most important work. Not to mention, their stress levels also decreased. While it can be scary to feel like you’re going to miss an important message the second it comes in, if you’re struggling to leave work on time to relieve your sitter, you might try this method as an experiment for a week. Or start with a smaller goal: Take 2-hour breaks from email. While there’s no one magic formula for working parents, a little bit of trial and error can help you figure out the strategies that work for you.
One last thing...

Struggling with your re-entry back to work, or juggling your new role as a working parent? Our Maven network includes career coaches and counselors who can help you navigate this (so-not-easy) transition. Book an appointment
here
to video chat on your time.

title.en-US: Are any diets off-limits after you have a baby?

content.value: Answer from Nutritionist and Lactation Consultant Melissa Flynn, IBCLC, MPH, RD

Remember that your body is healing in the postpartum period. The effort you put into labor can be likened to running a marathon—with the reward much better than any medal of course. You may have had vaginal tearing, a C-section, or at the very least, muscle fatigue—all of which requires adequate nourishment to heal properly.

In the immediate postpartum period, dieting is not recommended. Once your body has begun to resume its normal function, typically round 6 weeks after a vaginal birth or 8 weeks after a C-section (but always check with your doctor!), any diet that creates a modest calorie deficit is usually OK. Extremes such as putting your body in ketosis, avoiding entire food groups, or relying on overly-intense workouts are not recommended for anyone, much less a new mom trying to care for herself and another human.

title.en-US: 4 getting-dressed hacks for working parents

content.value: If you’re a working parent, mornings are often the most hectic part of the day. And getting dressed? That can be a battle of its own. Here are four tips to simplify the not-so-simple process of leaving the house, you know, not naked.
Move your pre-maternity clothes to the back of the closet.

One guaranteed way to lose precious time when you’re trying to get out the door in the morning? Staring into a closet full of clothes that no longer fit. You don’t have to get rid of your favorite pre-baby dresses, pants, etc., but it may not be helpful to keep these items front-and-center if you’re wearing a different size right now. (By the way, that’s totally normal, so you can show your inner critic the door when that voice tells you that you should have “bounced back” to a certain size.) Save time—and your sanity—in the A.M. by putting only your guaranteed-to-fit outfits in your view, and tucking everything else into the back.
Plan your outfits like you plan your meals.

You’ve heard of Sunday meal planning. Well, Sunday outfit planning isn’t a bad idea, either. Before the weekend ends, think about the week ahead and take a quick scan of your closet. Then, jot down (you can keep a weekly outfit list on your phone) what you’re going to wear based on exactly what’s on the agenda. For instance, if you have an important meeting on Tuesday morning, and you know you’ll feel your best in that navy dress and classic pair of heels, write that down. Thursday’s a big running-around day, when you’ll need to leave the office in the middle of the day to take your baby to the pediatrician? Set aside your comfiest work outfit—and shoes.
Build yourself a mini closet.

Don’t worry—you don’t need a jackhammer and other tools for this getting-dressed hack. The idea is simply to pull out your favorite go-to pieces and hang them on the back of your closet door. As long as you feel good in what you’re wearing, you don’t have to be a fashionista who never re-wears a pair of pants right now (or, um, ever). Deciding which items are going to be in your back-to-work outfit rotation will also help you make sure these are washed or dry-cleaned and ready to slip on when it’s go-time.
Make getting dressed the last thing you do.

This will save you from going through multiple outfit changes if you have a baby who loves to leave you with a soggy shoulder before you walk out the door. If you tackle the rest of your morning to-dos first, and wait till you’re practically walking out the door to put on your work clothes, you’ll drastically reduce the odds of an “accessory” no working parent ever wants to bring to the office: baby spit.

title.en-US: The cost of egg freezing

content.value: While the price of egg freezing varies from clinic to clinic, there are several costs to keep in mind.
Because it’s considered elective by the majority of insurance companies, coverage for egg freezing for both elective freezing and for oncofertility is rarely, if ever, covered in full by insurance.

Another factor to keep in mind is that the cost of the treatment only covers one cycle, and often times women go through several freezing cycles to get the recommended 10-20 eggs to have a high probability of one live birth, and more to have a high probability of two live births.
Here’s a range of what egg freezing costs could look like for patients:
Egg freezing cycle: ≅ $7,000 to $15,000 per cycle
Medications needed per cycle: ≅ $2,500 - $7,000 per cycle
Annual storage fee: ≅ $500-$1,000 per year
Thawing and insemination: ≅ $5,000 - $7,000 per cycle
Maven has select discounts at its network of preferred clinics so be sure to ask your Maven Care Advocate about clinics in your area and how much of a discount you could get.

title.en-US: How to deal with a workaholic boss after having a baby

content.value: Going back to work post maternity-leave is hard enough without a manager who tends to be “on” 24/7. New parents who return to a situation like this often say they struggle with their boss’s lack of boundaries. While it's not always easy to prevent your work life from spilling into other areas (i.e. your time with your little one), there are ways to draw the line in a professional—not career-sabotaging—way. In fact, doing so may benefit everyone, your boss included: Evidence shows that employees who avoid burnout tend to make fewer mistakes, stay more calm under pressure, and have lower turnover rates. Use these tools below to protect your me time—and if you need more advice on navigating your reentry after baby, a video chat with a Maven Career Coach can help.
Point out how disconnecting will make you (and the company) more successful

If you’re going to tell your boss that you will be offline after a certain point in the evening, point out that disconnecting—and going to bed early—helps you perform at your best the next day. You could also say, “While I may not get your email until the next morning, if an emergency comes up, you can text or call me.” This sends the message that you’re still a considerate employee who would be happy to help in urgent matters, while at the same time setting your boundaries.
Don’t send replies outside of working hours

Whether you tell your boss you’ll be offline or not, she may continue to send you emails after-hours. If it doesn’t warrant an immediate response, resist the urge reply right away. One option is to set up a delayed email that will be sent the next morning. And if you manage other people, you could also employ this tactic: Start saving drafts of your emails and sending them during regular business hours so no one feels the pressure to be chained to their inbox over the weekend.
Ask for help before a ball gets dropped

If you’re dealing with unrealistic expectations from your boss, communicate your concerns early. Don’t wait until after you miss a deadline to ask for help or explain that you can’t get to the finish line in the allotted time. Even if you’re afraid to speak up, giving your manager a chance to redistribute the workload is a better strategy than dropping the ball.

title.en-US: “I’m a new mom and can’t bond with my baby”

content.value: Most women expect that when they give birth, they’ll feel an instantaneous connection to the little being they carried for nine months. So when that doesn’t happen, it can feel frightening, sometimes even shameful. The reality is that bonding isn’t always immediate. If you’re struggling, it’s important not to feel isolated in your experience, and to trust that your relationship with your child—like all relationships—is a work in progress. To help demystify the difficulties of postpartum bonding, here are few things no one ever tells you.
You can still be a great mom even if you don’t feel an insta-bond with your baby.

Just because you’re not feeling an overwhelming attachment with this little person you just birthed doesn’t mean you aren’t doing a great job at parenting. If you’re taking care of your child—holding her, soothing her when she cries, feeding her, and keeping her safe—remind yourself that you are, in fact, fulfilling your mom duties. Remind yourself that you’re doing the best you can, and that the bonding will happen; it just hasn’t happened yet.

It's important to note that difficulty bonding with your baby can be a symptom of perinatal depression, especially if you're also experiencing other signs like depressed mood, loss of appetite, or loss of interest in activities you used to enjoy. If these sound familiar, take
this assessment
to see how severe your symptoms are and share the results with your in-person provider or a Maven Mental Health Provider to get support.
If your baby was in the NICU, bonding could be a bit delayed.

If your baby was born prematurely or needs some special care until he’s healthy and strong, the NICU may be “home” for a period after giving birth. Because of this, it’s common for NICU mothers to miss out on the initial bonding with a newborn. Sometimes, just knowing that what you’re going through is normal can help you get through it. “Even when I was allowed to have contact with my son in the NICU, I couldn’t feel an emotional connection, and that was really hard,” one mom says of her experience. “I was scared that I never would, but little by little, I did.”
If labor left you traumatized, ambivalent feelings toward your baby are totally normal.

Every woman’s experience of labor and delivery is different, and depending on how yours went (especially if an invasive or risky procedure was performed) you might be feeling traumatized afterward. When childbirth leaves moms with a form of PTSD, they could be having flashbacks of the experience, or dealing with other psychological scars that interfere with bonding. It’s important to know that you may need time to heal, and extra support to help form a connection with your baby.
The bottom line:

If you’re struggling in the aftermath of a traumatic childbirth—or coping with any challenging emotional issues of motherhood—Maven mental health counselors can help. Book an appointment here to get the support you need and deserve.

title.en-US: 3 surprising reasons new parents can’t sleep

content.value: We don’t have to tell you why being a new parent and operating as an SDP (Sleep Deprived Person) often go hand in hand. After all, getting up every couple of hours to the cry of a newborn or being a 24/7 feeding machine isn’t exactly a recipe for blissful rest. But sometimes what’s getting in the way of your sleep isn’t so obvious. One clue that something may be up: You’re so exhausted you think you could fall asleep standing upright, but when you do finally hit the hay (or the floor next to your baby’s crib), you just can’t nod off. So what gives? Read on for 3 sneaky sleep issues new parents deal with, and how to fix them.
You’re anxious about not sleeping

Get this: The one thing that can trump your sleepiness is your anxiety. Interestingly, sleep experts say that new parents’ anxiety over their new state of sleep deprivation can be the very thing that creates insomnia. Yes, the more you worry about a lack of shuteye, the fewer Zzs’s you may get. One way to begin tackling this problem is simply to notice if you start to churn out thoughts like “I’m never going to be able to sleep again; this is horrible!” the moment you get into bed. Although feeling like a walking zombie all day long isn’t an ideal situation, experts recommend trying to “de-catastrophize” the situation and reminding yourself that the exhaustion that comes with having a newborn isn’t permanent or even the end of the world.
You have a postpartum thyroid problem

One of the many possible changes that happen to a woman’s body when she’s expecting? Her thyroid gland can get out of whack. According to the American Thyroid Association, postpartum thyroiditis occurs in about up to 10 percent of women in the U.S., thanks to changes that happen to the thyroid hormones during pregnancy. It’s easy for the condition to go undiagnosed because symptoms aren’t always clear-cut. Some factors that may mean you should get checked out for the condition: Look out for other signs of thyroiditis including weight gain (or an inability to lose weight despite dieting), depression or moodiness, muscle cramps, and a lower sex drive. We know: Many of these “symptoms” sound like standard new-motherhood, but if you have a hunch something could be up, definitely get in touch with your doctor for an exam. New motto: Better safe than sleepy.
You’re suffering from depression

Many people think that postpartum depression is a constant state of sadness. But the reality is that the illness can have many characteristics—including worry, anxiety, and insomnia. Symptoms can start to show soon after delivery, but sometimes they manifest months after childbirth. If you suspect that you're suffering from postpartum depression/anxiety, it's a good idea to reach out to a mental health specialist for help. Our Maven practitioners and sleep coaches are available any time you want to video chat—so you can even schedule an appointment during your baby’s naptime. Getting to the root cause of your distress and tapping into the support you need can make a huge difference—day and night.

title.en-US: Yes, the world is silently judging pregnant women

content.value: It’s not all in your head. Here’s what to do about it.
Get this: In a small study published in
Families Relationships and Society

, researchers surveyed mother/grandmother pairs to see how attitudes toward pregnant women have changed over the years. Their findings revealed that scrutiny of pregnant women has significantly increased with newer generations of moms-to-be. In other words, when your granny was pregnant, she probably didn’t get as many stares for ordering an extra shot of espresso as you do now. Moms today say their baby bump is an invitation to be watched, evaluated, and judged.

And in some cases, it wasn’t just that others were silently judging them—moms actually reported that strangers tried to regulate their behaviors, such as the food decisions they made, during pregnancy. The researchers said that the effect of all this public surveillance is that women may end up feeling self-conscious and even doubt their own abilities to take care of themselves and their babies.

So what can you do when someone tries to play interference? You could try a smile-and-nod, simply to acknowledge you heard them (mostly so they don’t repeat their comments!), then go about your business without engaging further. And try to remind yourself that the people who get a say during your pregnancy are you, your partner, and a trusted doctor. To the rest of the world offering you advice, a “thanks but no thanks” is a perfectly acceptable response.

title.en-US: Can you eat smoked fish while pregnant?

content.value: Before you slap that smoked salmon on a piece of toast, find out whether it falls in the “cooked” or “uncooked” category.

You already know that you need to give your sushi habit a break during pregnancy, but things get confusing when you’re considering smoked fish. Is it cooked, well, enough? Sadly, it doesn’t get the green light when you’re expecting. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention cautions pregnant women against eating smoked fish because of the risk of Listeria. Pregnant women are 10 times more likely than other people to get Listeria infection. This is one of those infections that can be passed to an unborn baby, and lead to miscarriages, stillbirths, and preterm labor. It sounds scary, but if you steer clear of the culprits, you won’t have to worry. Smoked salmon, cod, trout, or any other smoked fish should be avoided. And that bagel with cream cheese and lox will taste a lot better after nine months without it.

title.en-US: What really happens to your pelvic floor after giving birth

content.value: Giving birth is an incredible experience, but it can also be quite traumatic. Months and years after childbirth, far too many women are dealing with urinary incontinence, pain during sex, chronic back aches, and other postpartum issues issues that go unaddressed. Even if you took a childbirth class, chances are you didn’t learn the real deal on pelvic floor issues. Read on for common symptoms, why they happen, and how you can really fix the problem.
What, exactly, is the pelvic floor?

It’s a major hub of muscles, ligaments, and nerves at the bottom of the pelvic region. The pelvic floor has many functions, including helping to support your uterus, bladder, and rectum, so when issues arise, they can cause an array of problems.
How common are pelvic floor issues?
Far too common! According to the National Institutes of Health, as many as one-third of women suffer from a pelvic floor disorder. The condition is more likely to happen after childbirth.
What are the pelvic floor issues women experience after giving birth?

Labor and delivery can wreak all kinds of havoc, including nerve damage and a weakening of the pelvic floor. This can eventually lead to urinary and bowel incontinence as well as prolapse, which is when pelvic organs such as your bladder or uterus drop from their normal place. They can even bulge outside of the vagina. Another issue is painful scar tissue that forms after a C-section, a tear between the vagina and the anus (aka the perineum), or episiotomy during childbirth. This can lead to pelvic tightness and vaginal pain during intercourse.
Is there anything women can’t do when they have pelvic floor issues?

Many women with pelvic organ prolapse stop exercising because physical activity—especially running and jumping—tends to worsen matters and cause too much pain. But everyday issues can be equally debilitating: Some moms say even squatting to pick up their baby’s toy on the floor leads to leakage. And sex with their partners may be just too agonizing so they avoid it.
So why don’t we hear more about pelvic floor disorders?

Well, for one, too many women suffer in silence because they’re embarrassed by their condition; some women we talked to described feeling “dirty and isolated” because they were peeing (or even pooping) their pants unpredictably. Another issue is that doctors don’t always pinpoint the root problem to begin with. Pelvic floor problems aren’t considered life-threatening, so they may not take priority during postpartum visits or be taken seriously. One small but revealing study from the University of Michigan gave women MRIs seven weeks after birth and found that 41% of them had tears in their pelvic floor muscles that they weren’t even aware they had, and 29% had signs of fractures in their pubic bones that weren’t diagnosed.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
What’s the treatment?

Physical therapy with a pelvic floor specialist is often very effective. A treatment plan may also include electrical stimulation or hormone therapy. Surgery is sometimes needed, but there are usually many other treatment options to try before going that route.
Is physical therapy all about Kegel exercises?

It’s true that Kegels are often prescribed and they do help a lot of people regain pelvic floor strength. But one study found that about a quarter of women don’t know how to do them correctly. Another reason Kegels aren’t a universal fix: Not all issues are caused by stretched-out muscles. In some cases, the problem is an excessive tightness, which could happen when pelvic floor muscles over-contract during childbirth. “A skilled physical therapist can also perform manual therapy to treat scar tissue caused by childbirth/tearing,” says Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, M.D. “There are other available treatments as well including medications, estrogen cream, and even Botox injections.”
The bottom line:

When you’re suffering, feeling empowered to talk to your doctor (or find another practitioner who truly listens to your concerns) is key. The OB-GYNs and pelvic floor physical therapists in Maven’s network specialize in post-pregnancy issues and can help you with a treatment plan. Painful sex or leaking during yoga may not be life-or-death issues, but that doesn’t mean they don’t deserve attention and care.
Some women we talked to described feeling “dirty and isolated.”

title.en-US: Can't hold your pee? Here's the help new moms need

content.value: Thirty to 40% of new moms experience some degree of leaking. Isn’t it time we stopped joking about it—or simply staying quiet—and just started talking about it?

Before you had a kid, you can probably count the moments—somewhere between zero and a handful of times—when you just couldn’t hold it in. You may have laughed a little too hard or had an extra drink at happy hour and ended up with a little “spritz” before you could make it to the bathroom. (It happens.) But if urinary incontinence—that’s the sexy medical term—has become a more persistent problem since giving birth, you’re not alone. And you definitely don’t have to suffer in silence or be ashamed to address it.

Some women say the problem isn’t just embarrassing; it keeps them from living their lives. Doing the kind of exercise they used to love—like running or Zumba or even conditioning classes with lots of simple jumping jacks involved—is sometimes impossible or not worth the effort. But exercise isn’t the only issue; plenty of other activities—even sneezing, coughing, or laughing—can trigger a tinkle.

So what can you do? If you’ve already had your six-week postpartum checkup and your doctor glossed over these parts of your childbirth recovery—parts that may not be life-threatening but are still debilitating and uncomfortable—the first thing to do is to proactively ask for a thorough evaluation. It’s a sad fact that many OB-GYNs are not trained to evaluate pelvic floor muscles or simply don’t give this exam the time and attention it deserves.

Another proactive measure you can take is to talk to a physical therapist (PT) who specializes in pelvic floor rehab. “Most women do not do Kegel exercises correctly and cannot correctly isolate their pelvic floor muscles,” says Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, MD. “Many women inappropriately use their abdominal muscles.” And to really deal with urinary incontinence you can’t just fix one muscle—you need a well-functioning pelvic floor system, which is a whole network of muscles that keeps your uterus, bladder and bowels in place. PT can help with rehab-ing the entire system.
Bottom line:

PT isn’t the only answer—there are other lifestyle changes that can help, and even “bladder sling surgery” for more serious cases—but it’s usually a good first step. Book an appointment with a Maven pelvic floor physical therapist if you’d like to get support in this area—and you’re not willing to spend the rest of your adult life in black pants.

title.en-US: Top 5 questions about multiple miscarriages

content.value: Q: For the record, what actually counts as recurrent miscarriage?

It used to be classified as the loss of three or more consecutive pregnancies. But the American Society of Reproductive Medicine (ASRM) established new guidelines. By their definition, recurrent miscarriage is two or more pregnancy losses.
Q: I’ve had multiple miscarriages and my doctor told me to “just keep trying”—is that good advice?

Every woman deserves a doctor who truly listens to her concerns, and takes the time to explain the reasons for the advice being doled out. What your doctor may not have explained: While miscarriage statistics vary wildly, they all point to reasons to not give up on having a child if you want one. Of course, there are no guarantees, but the Mayo Clinic, for instance, advises that after one pregnancy loss, the risk of miscarriage is about 14 percent. After two miscarriages the risk of another miscarriage increases to about 26 percent.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Q: I’ve heard I shouldn’t see a specialist unless I’ve had three miscarriages in a row—is that true?

That used to be the case, but testing has improved so much over the years that there’s no reason to wait if you feel concerned—even after the first or second miscarriage. You can “keep trying” while also doing what you can to get to the root of the issue.
Q: Will I definitely find out what led to my multiple miscarriages?
Unfortunately, no. About half of women who are evaluated for recurrent miscarriage (via blood tests and scans) never get a clear diagnosis. But that shouldn’t stop you from seeking answers.
Q: What are the most common causes?

Most early pregnancy losses–whether they are recurrent or not–are caused by chromosomal abnormalities. It’s also important to know that as we get older, the risk of having a miscarriage due to genetic abnormalities increases. If you have had two or more miscarriages later in your pregnancy—between 10 and 20 weeks—a doctor is more likely to discover non-genetic factors at play. What could those factors be? Anything from an autoimmune issue to a weak cervix or a uterus that’s abnormally shaped. The good news is, often there are treatment options available to resolve these complications so you can go on to have a full-term pregnancy.
Still have questions we didn’t cover?
Book an appointment
with one of Maven’s women’s health practitioners—you can video chat or just text message; whatever works for you—to get answers to anything that’s on your mind.
Every woman deserves a doctor who truly listens to her concerns.

title.en-US: Superfoods that calm you down during pregnancy

content.value: It's common to feel anxious or stressed when you’re dealing with all the changes that are happening to your body/life during pregnancy. But it turns out, if you’re struggling with mood issues, your diet can be a powerful ally. The probiotics in fermented grub boost the good bacteria in your gut—a.k.a. your second brain—and research found that people who dig into these foods more often were less likely to experience anxiety. Yep, kefir may be the ultimate comfort food.
What’s the link between probiotics and mood?

While scientists don’t know for sure, one theory based on animal research is that good bacteria in the gut decrease inflammation and increase GABA, a neurotransmitter that calms nervous activity in the brain. An aside worth noting: Eating fermented foods also helps with digestion, which—if you suffer from pregnancy constipation—can keep your whole system a lot happier.
What are the best probiotic foods to eat during pregnancy?

Kefir, miso soup, and tempeh are all good options. Kefir has the added bonus of containing tryptophan, an amino acid that helps raise serotonin, the calming hormone. Just remember that it’s always a good idea to check with your doctor or a Maven practitioner before introducing new foods to your diet.

title.en-US: Food swaps that make losing the baby weight easier

content.value: When you’re trying to drop the pounds you gained during pregnancy, small diet changes can make a big difference. And the best part is that you’ll trim down without feeling deprived. After all, the key to sticking with a healthy eating plan is feeling satisfied with the foods you put into your body. So instead of trying to kill your cravings (not possible!), consider smarter alternatives you can dig into instead. Here are a few no-brainer swaps to get you started.
Instead of white rice, have cauliflower rice.

“Rice” made of vegetables isn’t just a great way to sneak more veggies into your diet; it’s also a surefire way to cut calories and refined carbohydrates. A 1-cup serving of cooked cauliflower rice contains less than 30 calories and 8 grams of carbs. Compare that to 242 calories and 53 grams of carbs in an equal-sized portion of white rice. Stir-fry night just got a whole lot healthier.
Instead of chips, have roasted chickpeas.

Let’s face it: Sometimes snacking is all about the crunch factor. Roasted chickpeas (which you can buy pre-made or DIY in the oven with a bit of cooking spray and sprinkle of sea salt) can keep your hands out of the chip bowl and provide filling protein and fiber. They’re also a great swap for croutons in a salad.
Instead of fro-yo, have plain Greek yogurt topped with berries and cinnamon.

You can only deprive your sweet tooth for so long before sneaking out of bed to devour the ice cream your partner stashes in the freezer. So rather than resisting your craving for a creamy, decadent treat, get your fix the healthy way. A bowl of plain Greek yogurt with handful of berries gives you the satisfying sweetness of your favorite ice cream of frozen yogurt bowl—without the sugar overload. Nutritionist tip: A heavy sprinkle of cinnamon can also trick your taste buds into dessert mode. By the way, don’t be fooled by flavored yogurt with fruit on the bottom—that “fruit” is usually just a blueberry-colored sugar mix.
Instead of a bagel with cream cheese, have a whole grain English muffin with tablespoon of nut butter.

A bagel can easily tally 250 to 350 calories—and that’s before you even slather on the cream cheese or butter. But when eggs for breakfast just won’t do, get your carb fix with a whole-grain English muffin instead. Calorie savings: about 100. A swipe of natural almond or peanut butter also provides a bit of protein and healthy fat for satiety.
Instead of a latte, have a brewed coffee with milk.

Even if you can’t bear the thought of skim milk in your coffee (we don’t blame you), a brewed cup of joe with two tablespoons of half & half will set you back less than 50 calories. Compare that to a 16-ounce latte made with 2% milk, which has 190 calories. If you prefer an espresso drink, skip the lattes and cappuccinos and go for an Americano with a dash of your milk of choice.
Instead of spicy mayo, have hot pepper sauce.

No doubt, your turkey sandwich needs some kick. But swapping a tablespoon of hot sauce for an equal serving of spicy mayo will save you about 100 calories. Bonus: Hot peppers contain capsaicin, which has been shown to boost metabolism as well as suppress appetite.
Need more nutrition advice? Book an appointment with a nutritionist in Maven’s network.

title.en-US: Is it always bad to wake a sleeping baby?

content.value: Answer from Pediatrician Amy Brandon, IBCLC, MD

I get it: It’s almost hard to believe that your infant is still sleeping, hours after you put him down. It's amazing! It's liberating! It's... kind of weird? Most of the time you can rest easy that when baby is sleeping it's because his little body needs rest.

But there are a few times when you should keep a closer eye on the clock and not let him sleep for too long. Newborns, for instance, usually need to eat every 4 hours if they are taking formula; and for breastfed, premature, or smaller babies, it's more like every 2 or 3 hours (your pediatrician should let you know).

You'll also want to wake your baby sooner if long daytime naps seem to be contributing to day/night confusion in newborns. One sign that this is happening: Your infant seems to be sleeping for longer stretches during the day than he does at night.
Schedule a
video appointment
with a Maven pediatrician or sleep coach for guidance or encouragement, especially if you know in your bones that you should be waking your little one sooner but just can't bring yourself to do it.

title.en-US: 5 questions every new parent has about feeding a newborn

content.value: How much milk is enough? And how many times a day—or night—will you be breastfeeding your little one or giving him a bottle? Read on so you can rest easy (you know, when you actually have time to rest).
How often should a newborn eat?

Newborns feed on-demand. In other words, whenever they seem hungry. This will help them gain back any weight they lost after birth. While every baby is different breastfed infants typically feed 8-12 times a day—or every 1-3 hours. If you’re feeding from the breast, it could take approximately 10-20 minutes per breast during each feed for a newborn baby to get their fill. If you're feeding from a bottle, they may drink more quickly.
If I’m pumping, how many ounces of breast milk does a newborn need?

Because newborns’ stomachs are so small, during the first week most full-term babies take no more than 1 to 2 ounces per feeding. (At three days old, a baby may only take in a mere 1/2 ounce at a time.) Little by little, as their stomach size grows, they can take in a bit more. Most newborns take in 2-3 ounces of milk at a time by week three. And by the time they’re a month old, the average portion could be about 4 ounces per feeding. Keep in mind that every baby is different. Some are "snackers" who prefer fewer ounces and more frequent feedings, while others will consume large volumes across fewer feedings. There is no set number, it's more about watching for signs that your baby is full (turns away from bottle, gaining weight on schedule according to your pediatrician, plenty of soiled diapers, etc.)
Are the rules the same for formula?

Formula-fed babies tend to digest formula more slowly, so they usually can go a little longer before they get another bottle. Instead of eating every 2-3 hours in month one, for instance, babies who drink formula may go 3-4 hours between feedings. Breastfed babies digest breast milk more quickly and may want to feed more frequently as a result. But again, every baby is unique.
Is there a daily ounce limit to shoot for?

There can be a lot of variation from one baby to another—and if all signs point to your baby’s healthy development (healthy weight gain, soiled diapers, etc.), there’s no reason to fret over exactly how many ounces they consume. As a very approximate guide, by the end of month one multiply your baby’s weight in pounds by 2.5. For example, if your baby weighs 9 pounds that would equal 22.5 ounces per day. But again, this can vary by many factors including your individual baby and whether they consume breast milk, formula, or a combination of both. Speak to your pediatrician or a pediatrician on Maven for more individualized advice.
It’s easier to track how much my baby is drinking from a bottle; how will I know she’s eating enough when she’s feeding from my breast?

You’re right—unfortunately your breast isn’t labeled in ounce increments the way that a bottle is. But take heart, according to the Cleveland Clinic and many other expert sources, babies know when they are hungry or full. And there are plenty of signs that should reassure you that your baby is eating enough, like if she’s steadily gaining weight.

According to the Mayo Clinic, from birth to age 6 months, a baby might gain 5 to 7 ounces a week. By five months, she could be roughly double her birth weight. (Keep in mind that a little bit of weight loss in the week following birth is normal; babies should be back up to their birth weight by 2 weeks.) The good old diaper check can also tell you if your baby’s nutritional needs are being met: While you won’t be changing quite so many diapers until about day five, regular diaper changes are a good sign that baby’s eating is on track. About 6 wet diapers a day, plus 3 to 4 dirty ones? Yay—baby is probably sipping to satisfaction.

Have more questions or concerns about feeding your baby? None of this is easy, and many women need guidance in the beginning. Book an appointment with a lactation consultant on Maven’s platform to start getting the support you deserve.

title.en-US: How to tell friends with infertility that you're pregnant

content.value: Read this before you make a big splash on social media.

When you’re expecting a baby, your natural instinct may be to break out the Faux-tinis and celebrate with those closest to you. But things get tricky when the person on the receiving end of your bump update is someone who’s been unable to get pregnant or suffered a miscarriage. (And considering that roughly one in every 10 couples have problems with infertility, and 10-20% of pregnancies end in miscarriage, according to the Mayo Clinic, the chances of knowing someone who’s struggling are high, notes Jackie Stone, M.D. a Maven OB-GYN.)

While it may be difficult to share, experts say you don’t have to hide your news or feel guilty when sharing it. The key is to be sensitive to your friend’s emotions. You could even start by acknowledging how hard it is to tell her, knowing what she’s been through, but remind her that she’s very important to you and you want her to be a part of this experience—if she would like that, too. A gentle approach is best, and having your conversation in private (versus in the middle of a big dinner party) will honor your pal’s experience and give her the space to process it without other people around.

Along those same lines: You definitely don’t want to have her find out on Facebook. A social-media announcement will be harder on your bestie than a one-on-one talk. Lastly, recognize that while she might not be in a place to help you with your baby registry and rejoice in every moment of these nine months, she still loves you and—in her own time—will be able to share in your happiness.

title.en-US: What you need to know about postpartum depression

content.value: Whether you spent your pregnancy painting an idyllic picture of what life would be like once baby arrived, or you had—let’s be honest—no idea what you were in for, you may not have been prepared for the ups and...downs. The truth is, many new mothers go through an emotional upheaval just at the point when everyone around them is saying, “Congrats on your little one—you must be so happy!” When joy is overshadowed by other emotions, it could be a fleeting case of the “baby blues”—but about 1 in 5 new mothers experience more serious postpartum depression. Here’s what you need to know, and how to get the support you deserve if you’re struggling.
Is postpartum depression just a case of “baby blues”?

No. Both are valid and deserving of attention and care, but they’re not the same condition. Besides being physically and mentally exhausted, your body goes through hormonal changes during and after pregnancy—and that leaves many women feeling down, anxious, or uncharacteristically irritable after giving birth. This is often referred to as the baby blues. But the key difference is that baby blues tend to pass after a couple of weeks. Postpartum depression, on the other hand, lasts longer and the symptoms tend to be more continuous and severe.
What are the symptoms of postpartum depression?
