Besides a depressed mood or anxiety, hallmark signs of postpartum depression include difficulty bonding with your baby, excessive crying, insomnia or overwhelming fatigue, and a tendency to withdraw from family, friends, and activities you used to find pleasure in. But the symptoms aren’t one-mom-fits-all—so if anything feels off, it’s important to trust your instincts and seek support. Case in point: Some women with postpartum depression don’t feel sad at all; instead they describe a sense of emptiness, or purely physical symptoms—like intense headaches and body aches.
When should I be on the lookout for postpartum depression?
Symptoms often occur a few days or weeks after delivery, but sometimes they set in as late as a year later.
How do I know if I’m at risk for postpartum depression?

First, it’s important to know that any woman can develop postpartum depression. But there are some factors that could make it more of a concern. For instance, if you have a history of depression or anxiety or you’ve been through a particularly stressful event during the past year—like pregnancy complications, an illness, a job loss—you could have an increased risk. if you've had postpartum depression with a previous pregnancy, your odds of having it again after a future pregnancy are higher. Ditto if you have difficulty breastfeeding, lack a support system, or deal with financial woes. If there’s anything about your personal circumstances or health history that sets off alarm bells for you, definitely talk to your OB-GYN or book an appointment with a Maven mental health practitioner to open up and discuss a support plan.
What should I do if I think I have postpartum depression?

First and foremost: Try to have as much compassion for yourself as possible. Depression during this (or any other period in your life) is nothing to be ashamed of. Second: Tell a healthcare professional (or friend or loved one who will step in to make sure you get help). Many women who have been through this struggle—and come out on the other side—say that feeling isolated and not talking about their problems made things harder. The sooner you let in the support, the sooner you’ll start to feel like yourself again.

title.en-US: 3 things you need to know before buying a breast pump

content.value: One of the biggest and most personal decisions you’ll make as a new mom is how to feed your baby. No one choice is right for everyone, but if you're thinking about nursing, you may also be thinking about pumping. One study found that 85% of women who breastfeed in the U.S. use a pump. As one Maven member who’s been there put it: “Even if you don’t think you’ll use one, believe me when I say you might—and it’s a good idea not to wait until you’re a sleep-deprived parent of a brand new human to do your buying research.” So who really needs this contraption, and how do you find the right one? Read on for a few basic must-knows.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
A breast pump isn’t just for returning to work.

Women who are going back to work—full- or part-time—and want to continue providing breast milk for their baby will need to add “pro pumper” to their resumes. But there are many other situations that require women to pump—sometime much earlier than they’d expect. Moms of babies born prematurely who can’t latch onto the breast may need to pump from day one. Pumping also helps maintain milk supply for moms whose babies are not nursing well (or nursing at all). And even if breastfeeding is going smoothly, there may be times when a mom needs a break from nursing, or is apart from her child for a few hours and (blessedly) a partner or a babysitter is in charge of a feeding.
One pump fits all? Not even close.

Finding the right pump depends on every woman’s unique needs and lifestyle. For long-term or regular pumping, a double electric pump that allows you to express milk from both breasts at the same time is ideal. (Productivity, people!) Single-breast pumps are smaller, so they’re less bulky but also less efficient. Little tip? Many women go for an electrical version but choose to have a back-up manual pump (you can find one for less than $20) they can use for a quick pump session on the go—for instance, at a wedding or during a night out—to prevent engorgement. Whatever type you go with, lactation consultants recommend looking for a pump that gives you the option to swap out “flanges” of different sizes—these are the cone-shaped parts that attach to your nipple. The wrong fit could affect output or cause pain—two things that experts swear are totally avoidable.
Your insurance company has a say in which pump you go with.

The good news: Many insurance plans will provide a breast pump to moms free of charge. (Others offset the cost significantly so you’re left with only a co-pay.) The not-so-great news: You might have to jump through a few hoops to use this benefit and figure out what, exactly, you’re entitled to since different plans cover different styles of pumps. To make the process easier, we’ve partnered with
1 Natural Way

, a company that does all the homework for you. Once you fill out a quick form with some personal info, they’ll verify your insurance and let you know which suppliers you can choose from under your plan. They’ll even work with your OB-GYN to obtain a prescription for a pump, help you place the order, and make sure you have it when you need it. That said, it’s important to know that whether you receive the pump before or after the birth of your baby depends on your insurance company. Sigh.
85% of women who breastfeed in the U.S. use a pump.

title.en-US: 4 things to practice before your maternity leave ends

content.value: True or false: Going to work post-maternity leave will be exactly like it was before you left to give birth to a tiny human. Of course, you know the answer to that one. To make the transition a little smoother, give yourself a few trial runs so you feel more comfortable with your new M.O. and schedule.
Pump. Clean. Repeat.

If you’ve been breastfeeding exclusively since giving birth, you don’t want to wait until you’re back at the office to add “master pumper” to your New Mama resume. Trust us: No one is an expert pumper on day 1. And did we mention the cleaning? Every part of the pump that came into contact with breastmilk should be washed in warm water with gentle soap every time you use it. Pro pumper tip: Some models do come with “steam bags” that let you disinfect the pumps more quickly in a microwave.
Get dressed.
That a.m. routine you had before you had a tiny human to tend to? Not gonna cut it. Get a feel for your new morning schedule—where you’re dressing (and feeding) at least two people.
Time your commute.

This is especially key if you’re dropping your baby off at a sitter or relative’s place. Set the clock, head to your childcare locale, then beeline for the office. That’s the average time of your new commute, plus or minus any crying fits (real talk: the person getting emotional might not be your baby) while you’re on route.
Visit nannyville.

If possible, ask your sitter, nanny, or daycare center to do a practice run (or runs) with you before your official back-to-work day. If it’s harder than you expected, know that you’re not alone. Maven’s community of therapists are especially trained in the postpartum issues most women experience; book an appointment to chat with one by video or text.

title.en-US: Love and pregnancy: “My partner feels left out”

content.value: When your bump comes between you and your S.O.

It’s not always easy to realize that your partner is feeling left out during such an important time in your lives. But it might bring you some comfort to know that it’s completely normal. And as your journey progresses, partners may feel even more alienated. After all, between frequent doctor’s appointments and the 24/7 prep-work for welcoming a newborn into your life, the focus on your baby may take up all your time and energy.

One way to help your S.O. feel included is to be clear about what you’d like him to show up for. This could be doctor’s appointments, a birthing class, or even a weekend away bonding with each other before baby arrives. The key is to communicate so no one is left guessing.

And when your partner shares how he or she is feeling, do your best to listen. Bringing the focus back to how hard pregnancy is for you without really considering your partner’s experience can make him or her feel invalidated and put an added strain on your relationship. Keep in mind that opening up may have taken some courage—partners often say they fear speaking up because they don’t want to seem selfish when you’re the one who has to carry a baby for nine months.
Bottom line:

Being pregnant can certainly bring new dynamics into a relationship, and it’s normal to go through ups and downs. If the changes you’re experiencing are impacting your emotional well-being, know that support is available. A Maven mental health counselor or relationship expert can help you navigate this time and strengthen your bond with each other—now and as you enter parenthood.

title.en-US: When’s the best time for exercise during pregnancy?

content.value: Find out when your fitness mojo may make a surprise experience.

While staying active is a great goal to maintain throughout your entire pregnancy, the second trimester has some advantages in the fitness department. The morning sickness and nausea common in the first trimester may have let up, and your energy levels are probably getting a spike, too. If you’re feeling good and have your doctor’s OK, take advantage of this opportunity to exercise.

Many pregnant women say the initial inertia to hit the gym or break a sweat in their living room can be hard to tap into. But once they give themselves a little push and get started, they not only feel more awake but some of their pregnancy aches and pains go away, too. What’s more, the mood boost they feel gives them a reason to tie up their gym shoes day after day. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists' guidelines encourage most pregnant women to engage in 30 minutes or more of moderate exercise a day.
If you need some help getting started, book a video chat with a Maven physical therapist to discuss safe options.

title.en-US: Maven real talk with Elizabeth on returning to work after baby

content.value: 39 years old
Occupational Therapist
New Jersey
How long after having a child did you return to work?
I owned my own new business so I had to go back to work rather quickly. Four weeks postpartum, I was back at work a few hours a day, 3 to 4 days per week.
Who cares for your child while you’re at work, and how did you make your childcare decision?
I was very blessed that my mother-in-law was able to watch my son.
Any advice for someone navigating childcare for the first time?

When I eventually did put my son into a daycare program—he was 3 years old at the time—I chose a childcare center that had video cameras in all the rooms. That allowed me to see how he was transitioning every day after I dropped him off. I’d watch him from the front desk monitor before I left the center. (I was also able to view him during the day if I wanted to, although I didn't use that option.)
What was the most challenging part about your first days back at work?

I actually felt a sense of relief when I dropped my son off for the first time at grandma’s house. I hadn't been away from him at all for an entire month. I remember taking a sigh of relief and feeling some of my anxiety leave that first day. I’m an independent woman, so to get back to myself and the work I loved, even for short periods, was actually helpful for me.
Have things gotten easier/harder with time? How so?

Leaving an infant with anyone has its challenges. I had to learn to trust that even though my mother-in-law and I may do things differently, that was OK. Ultimately, I knew that my son was well cared for and that’s what mattered.
How could your workplace have helped make the transition smoother?
Being the owner, my situation was unique. I do feel that a gradual transition back was positive for me as opposed to jumping back into a full schedule on day one.
Any tools or tricks that help you manage the juggle of work/life?
I think you have to figure out what your personal balance or juggle is and not worry about if it’s "right" or "wrong" by anyone else's standards. We all do things differently.
Did you have thoughts of quitting your job? And if you kept yourself in the game, what helped you stay?

I never thought of quitting. I knew that children don’t stay little forever, and eventually they were going to go to school and I didn't want to be out of the game completely for that long. Over time, as my children got older, I needed to change my schedule so it worked better for my family. When my kids were younger and took naps, if I got home later and they stayed up later than usual, it wasn’t a big concern to me and my husband. Once they entered school and didn't nap, I wanted them to get to sleep sooner and realized that, with earlier bedtimes, both my husband and I only had limited time with them. I chose to change my work arrangements in order to get home earlier.
If your best friend was returning to work after maternity leave, what would you want to say to her?

Focus on doing a great job when you are at work so that you can focus on connecting with your child when you are at home. Also, unless you hire a daily cleaning service, your house will never be as clean as you want it to be. Choose to ignore the dust and never-ending laundry—not your kiddo.
What’s one thing you’d like to see change about the return-to-work conversation for parents?

I have seen many young professional women leaving jobs due to inflexibility of work schedules. I always encourage people to discuss options for flexible scheduling, such as part-time to full-time transitions back to work, or working from home if needed.

title.en-US: How can you deal with changing friendships after kids?

content.value: Answer from Mental Health Specialist Mercedes Samudio, LCSW, MSW

There’s no doubt that becoming a parent can be tough on friendships—especially when your friends don’t have children yet. Many clients I’ve worked with tell me they feel guilty for not being able to be the same friend they were before having a child. Between figuring out your baby's needs and schedule, and eventually getting back to work, free time for brunches and happy hours may be hard to come by.

One solution is to ask friends to visit you at home. This way, you can stay connected while still showing up for your mom duties. If you need a break from parenting (everyone does!), ask your pals if they can be flexible—maybe scheduling a girls night out once every couple of months instead of every week.

A great way to help your friends understand your new realities is simply be honest with them. Being tied to a human who needs you 24/7 can make even the simplest decisions feel like a huge ordeal. This is your new normal; letting your bestie know this could help her realize that you can't just hop on the phone for a quick chat all the time, like you used to. Be open to hearing how your friend feels about this change in your dynamic. But don’t assume that since you've been close for a certain length of time that everyone will understand. If they cannot support you and your needs, give yourself permission to let friendships go for a while and make the decision to reconcile later—if you want to.

title.en-US: How your hair changes during & after pregnancy

content.value: When you’re growing a baby inside you, you’re expecting lots of body changes, but you may have thought they’d only be happening from the neck down. Turns out, there’s a lot that can happen on top of your head, too. Read on to find out how your hair might get a pregnancy makeover—no trip to the salon required.
Your hair during pregnancy

One happy side effect of the hormonal changes during pregnancy: Many women end up with thicker, fuller hair. That’s because your body is pumping out a lot of estrogen, a hormone that plays a role in hair growth and stimulating the hair follicles. Another factor in a lusher pregnancy mane is that you’re actually retaining more hair on your head, since hormones can also lead to a decrease in normal shedding. If your hair is looking shinier, too, that could be due to an increase in the oil production by your scalp.
Your hair after pregnancy

Your estrogen levels decline after giving birth, so those hair perks you may have experienced during pregnancy might start to go away with the cutting of the umbilical cord. Don’t panic if you see extra hair in the drain; according to the American Pregnancy Association, postpartum hair loss affects up to 50% of women who have just given birth. The shedding is simply hormonal—and temporary.
When to consult a doctor

If the shedding seems extreme or you’re still losing hair when your baby is approaching his 1st birthday, check things out with your doctor. Hair loss can also be related to thyroid problems, a physical or emotional shock, and certain medications. While the post-baby shedding is usually nothing to worry about, ruling out any medical issues can bring you some peace of mind.

title.en-US: Your pregnancy breasts questions, answered

content.value: Remember when you looked down at your body and could recognize all your parts? Then came pregnancy, where every day seems to bring on another transformation. Everyone tells you that you’ll probably be wearing a bigger bra size for a while, so your larger endowment doesn’t come as much as a surprise. But what’s up with all these other changes? Let us explain...
Why do my breasts feel more tender?

You can thank your pregnancy hormones for this. The same mechanism that leads to breast soreness when you have your period is at play when you’re pregnant: Levels of progesterone and estrogen rise causing breast tissue to expand and your milk ducts to puff up. If the achiness factor is extra high, there are things you can do, like making sure you have on a supportive bra, applying a warm compress, or (sorry, partners) declaring your chest a no-touch zone till the discomfort lets up. The good news is that soreness lightens up after the first trimester.
Why do my breasts look so veiny?

When you’re pregnant, your blood volume increases by almost 50%. PS: That’s a good thing—since that extra blood flow is making its way to the fetus to keep it healthy. But the extra blood flowing through your veins is also what causes some women’s breasts to look like a road map of blue-ish lines. Don’t worry, the veins should be less visible by about six weeks postpartum, or—if you’re breastfeeding—about a month after you stop nursing.
Why is fluid coming out of my breasts?

You probably weren’t expecting any leakage from your nipples to happen until, you know, you’d actually given birth. But your breasts may go through some test runs during pregnancy as your body is getting ready to supply a baby’s nutrition. As you get closer to your delivery date, production of milk and colostrum (that’s the thicker “pre-milk” that your baby will drink in the first few days after birth) ramps up even more, and sometimes a little spillage occurs. If it’s getting a bit too damp in your bra, you can try wearing insert pads. And if your partner is “handling” your breasts? A little heads-up on milk matters can’t hurt.

title.en-US: Can stress during pregnancy harm your baby?

content.value: The first thing to remember is that stress is one of the most normal reactions to carrying a little life that you’re responsible for inside your belly. So if you’re feeling your fair share of it, you’re not alone. That said, there’s evidence that doing your best to manage stress during pregnancy is beneficial for you and your baby.

High levels of stress that continue for long bouts may cause health problems like high blood pressure and heart disease. According to the March of Dimes, when you're pregnant, this type of stress can increase the chances of having a premature or low birth weight baby. One study by University of Denver researchers looked at the effect a pregnant woman’s stress reactions have on her unborn baby and found that when moms-to-be had consistently high levels of the stress hormone cortisol in early pregnancy, their babies showed more sensitivity to stress after birth than infants born to more relaxed moms.

Experts enforce that the message here isn’t to panic or force yourself into a state of calm (not possible). It’s simply to realize that your emotional wellbeing during pregnancy deserves the same attention you give to your physical health. The occasional tough week at the office or argument with your partner isn’t likely to lead to severe stress. But if you find yourself feeling tense on a regular basis, try to prioritize self-care. And if talking to someone could help, book an appointment with a mental health specialist in Maven’s network.

title.en-US: Maven real talk on postpartum depression with Jamie

content.value: 38 years old
Stay-at-home mom
Illinois
Did you have postpartum depression or postpartum anxiety or both?
Both.
How did you know you had it?
I was formally diagnosed. My doctor screened me for postpartum depression/anxiety within my first few doctor’s visits after giving birth.
How soon after childbirth did you notice that something wasn’t quite right and you weren’t feeling like yourself?
Within a few weeks.
What were your symptoms?
There was lots of crying, plus mood swings and a crippling anxiety.
Did friends/relatives/colleagues know what you were going through?
I kept it very private.
What helped you get better?
A combination of medication and therapy.
If you didn’t feel you had enough support, what could have made things better?
If I hadn’t felt so ashamed or embarrassed, or tried to tough it out by myself, I think things would have been less hard.
What do you wish loved ones would have done for you without being asked?
I wished they’d checked in on me, asked how things were going after having a baby, and offered encouragement.
How long did it take to feel like yourself again, and what do you think helped you the most?
I started to feel better once I reached out for help. After a few months of treatment that included therapy, I felt strong enough to phase off of meds safely and with my doctor’s supervision.
Did you have postpartum depression or anxiety when you returned to work? How did you cope?
Actually, I didn’t return to my workplace. I’m now a stay-at-home mom.
How did your experience impact your relationship with your significant other?
The truth is I felt very judged by my partner, and at times I felt like a failure.
What’s the one thing you’d like to see change about how our society perceives postpartum depression and anxiety?
I wish our society didn’t make any woman feel judged or ashamed if she’s struggling. It’s more common than most people realize, help is available, and it can get better—but probably not on it’s own.

title.en-US: Why you should never skip a dental visit during pregnancy

content.value: With all the doctor’s appointments you have to keep up with these days, you may be tempted to skip your regular visits to the dentist. But it turns out good oral hygiene is especially important when you’re expecting. Taking care of those pearly whites helps protect your own health—and your baby's too. Read on for the 411 on dental care during pregnancy.
Why are my gums bleeding during pregnancy?

Thanks to increased levels of the hormones progesterone and estrogen during pregnancy, you’re at an increased risk of gingivitis—inflammation of the gum tissue that can cause bleeding. If you don’t treat it, gingivitis may become a more serious dental problem called periodontitis, which is when the tissues that surround and support the teeth are inflamed. As gums pull away from the teeth, small pockets for bacterial infections to inhabit get created, and these infections could be released into the bloodstream. While it may sound crazy, research suggests there’s a link between gum infections and an increased risk of delivering a preterm baby of low birth weight. So what can you do to prevent these problems? Maintain good brushing and flossing habits to make sure bacteria don’t make a home in your mouth and gums. If your gum problems are already severe, or it’s been more than six months since you’ve seen your dentist, make an appointment.
Is it safe to have dental work during pregnancy?

It depends. Most routine dental work like cavity fillings and crowns are considered safe—and, in fact, putting them off may increase the chance of infection. As for more extensive dental interventions, oral surgery and elective procedures like teeth whitening, your dentist may recommend waiting until your baby is born to avoid any potential health risks.
Can morning sickness cause mouth problems?

Unfortunately, yes, but there are steps you can take to reduce the damage. If morning sickness is plaguing you with constant vomiting, your instinct may be to run and brush your teeth right away. However, brushing can do more harm than good—causing the stomach acids to damage your enamel. Instead, neutralize the acids by rinsing your mouth with water or with 1 cup of water mixed with 1 teaspoon of baking soda. After about an hour, you can go ahead and brush with toothpaste and a toothbrush with soft bristles.

title.en-US: Real talk from Maven user Meg about freezing her eggs

content.value: 29 years old
Co-founder at e-commerce startup
NYC
Why did you decide to freeze your eggs?
It's a wonderful scientific breakthrough and I love the optionality it gives me on my fertility.
How did you choose your clinic?
They had the most number of live births in the world across their network.
What surprised you most about the procedure?
How efficient it was and the relative lack of impact on my day, apart from the effect of drugs.
Was it painful?
Um, yes! And the swelling was also unexpected.
Did you like your experience?
Yes, I would thoroughly recommend it and think everyone should do it.
What could have been better?
I understand the next technology improvement in egg freezing would mean only one injection a day, which means you don't need to carry around a chilled bag of injections on a date.
How much did it cost?
How many eggs did you get?
24 eggs out, only 10 were mature and frozen.
Are you going to do it again?
I hope not.
What is your advice to someone about to go through egg freezing?
Don't waste another moment, do it right now!
What other question are we not asking but should be?
Do I fully understand the procedure at my clinic? What is their thaw rate and live birth rate?

This article is not intended to be a substitute for medical advice or care. Please consult a doctor with any questions you have before taking actions around your health and wellbeing. As always, our Maven practitioners are available, on-demand, to address your concerns.
Book an appointment here.

title.en-US: "After miscarriage, it stings to find out friends my age are pregnant"

content.value: Maven Real Talk on Miscarriage with Anna
29 years old
Photographer
Maryland
How many miscarriages have you had?
Did you experience your miscarriage(s) before you had children or after you already had a child?
Before. It was my first pregnancy.
How far along were you when you had your last miscarriage?
9 weeks
How did you find out? Did you have any symptoms?

I assumed something was off from the very early on. Two days after I got a positive pregnancy test, I started spotting. That went on every day but I tried to keep calm about it because my doctor said spotting was normal as long as I didn't have any cramping—which I didn't. But I spotted for weeks until my first sonogram. The sonogram confirmed what I had already assumed: that I didn't have a viable pregnancy.
What surprised you most about having a miscarriage?

I was shocked by how long it took my body to heal. I had to have a D&C procedure and my doctor said that I could experience bleeding for two weeks afterward. Well, I bled for 2 months. I had already been bleeding during the weeks of my pregnancy so in total I bled basically every day from July to October. It was a constant reminder of what happened to us—and it kept us from trying again and moving forward.

I am also surprised by how much it stings when I find out friends my age are pregnant. I am happy for them, of course, but I do feel physically uncomfortable and get a chill every time I see a sonogram photo posted online or sent via text. I hope that feeling goes away. I don’t want to taint the happiness I feel for the people I love.
Did you find out what caused the miscarriage? How was that experience?

My doctor made it pretty clear to me that this happens all the time to many women, and often there's no clear-cut reason why. He assured me that it wasn't my fault and that there was nothing I could have done differently to “save” the pregnancy.
Did you go on to have a baby after your miscarriage(s)? If so, how soon afterwards?
I have not yet gotten pregnant again.
How open were you with friends and relatives?

When we were pregnant, I didn't tell many people that I was expecting; just 2 close friends. I thought it was too soon to share the news because I didn’t know what would happen. When we miscarried, I told all of my family and friends. I needed people to understand that I was going through something and needed some space. Also, people kept saying things like, "When are you guys going to have a baby!?"—which is the worst thing to hear after a miscarriage. So telling them what we experienced stopped those questions (hopefully) forever.
What helped you the most in those initial weeks and months after having a miscarriage?

The fact that I had my husband by my side—someone who understood what I was going through and was just as connected to my pain—helped me the most during those initial weeks. I couldn't imagine going through that as a single woman or if I lived apart from my partner; I have such compassion and sympathy for anyone who goes through a miscarriage without a support team. Being together was truly healing and made me feel less alone. After we got over the initial shock and emotions were less raw, my husband and I were able to have candid conversations and I really feel that our bond strengthened.
Did you seek therapy to deal with the miscarriage? If not, would it have been helpful in retrospect?

No, I didn’t. I'm not sure if it would have been helpful in this situation. I am a big believer in therapy, but this was something I just had to mourn and move on from. Luckily, I didn’t experience feelings of guilt: I already knew it wasn't my fault and there was nothing I could have done to change it.
When people ask you how many children you’ve had (or have), do you include your miscarriage?

No—definitely not. The D&C procedure I had was a result of my amniotic sac being empty. At a 9-week sonogram, they should have been able to clearly see a fetus with a heartbeat. For some reason, the fertilized egg in my body stopped growing and essentially disappeared. So there was a sac but no baby. Thinking about it like that helps me, emotionally. I didn't lose a baby—there was no baby. In reality, I lost the potential of having that baby, and I lost the hopes and dreams we had made for that potential baby.
What would you want to tell another woman after suffering a miscarriage?
You're not alone, sister. We, who have been there, see you; we know your pain. You will heal and you will be ok.

title.en-US: How can you avoid getting mommy-tracked at work?

content.value: Answer from Back-To-Work Coach Mary Beth Ferrante
Make your career goals known.

When you deliver the news at work that you’re pregnant, you can bet that at least one person is thinking that you might not come back after having a baby. Right or wrong, it happens. That’s why it's important that you communicate your intention to return and your commitment to staying on track and meeting the career goals you've been working toward. While it may be obvious to you, it is not always obvious to your manager!
Be a leader—even before your maternity leave begins.

As you plan for your time out of the office, get involved and show that you are committed to the success of the team. Can you identify projects that might be stretch opportunities for more junior employees and help them grow? Are you able to assist your manager with divvying up your work or hiring and training a temp who will fill in for you?
If you see something, say something.

In other words, if you detect any signs that you are in fact getting mommy-tracked, the first course of action is to speak up! Even when you’re a sleep-deprived new parent, don’t ignore a hunch that it’s happening or tell yourself that it’s just "in your head." Trust your gut and bring your concerns to leadership. Share (over and over again!) what your career goals are and remind them of your past successes. And if your direct manager won't listen, be strategic. Find another mentor or someone in a position of power who will hear your concerns and can be an ally.

title.en-US: Is it okay to eat spicy foods while pregnant?

content.value: Find out if you need to back away from the hot sauce.

If you’ve got a constant craving for Sriracha or curry, you may be wondering if it’s OK to indulge when you’re expecting. According to an old wives’ tale, spicy foods can trigger contractions and bring on premature labor. But there’s no scientific evidence to back up this rumor. In other words, there’s no reason you can’t satisfy for your craving.

That said, if you notice any digestive problems that could be linked to the fire on your plate, you may want to control the heat. Pregnant women are prone to getting heartburn because high levels of progesterone cause the muscle between the esophagus and stomach to relax—so acids from your stomach can climb back up. And spicy foods may increase the burn when this happens.

Another potential problem (although it doesn’t happen to everyone) is diarrhea. Spicy foods can irritate the lining of the stomach, causing food to move more quickly through the digestive system which could result in loose stools. If your five-alarm chili leaves you without these discomforts, by all means, keep digging in. But if your body is protesting, you may want to dial down the burn until after your baby arrives.

title.en-US: Do you know the perfect temperature for baby sleep?

content.value: Wrapping your baby like a burrito for bed is one thing. But how warm should that little burrito be?
What’s the temperature sweet spot for a baby sleep?

The rule of thumb is that setting the thermostat to somewhere between 65 to 72 degrees provides a comfortable environment for a baby to sleep. It might vary depending on how insulated your home is; if the insulation is poor, you may need to crank things up a bit more in the colder months. If it’s perfect, 68 might be the sweet spot.
Are there any health concerns with making a room too hot or too cold?
Yes! Sleep temperature isn’t just a comfort issue—it’s also a safety issue. A nursery that's too warm substantially increases a baby’s risk of SIDS, or sudden infant death syndrome.
How should you dress a newborn for sleep?

While it’s not an exact science, one way to go about this is to see what you’re wearing, and add an extra layer for your baby. The toe-and-tummy temperature test can help you get things right: When you feel your baby’s belly, it should be warm. Meanwhile, her toes should be slightly cooler. (Her circulation system is still developing, so the hands and feet can be on the chillier side—but not freezing.
Is it OK to use blankets to keep a baby warm?

Not until your baby turns one. The American Academy of Pediatrics advises keeping cribs free of blankets, pillows, and anything else that could become a suffocation hazard and raise the risk of SIDS. If you need to add an extra layer, your pediatrician will usually give swaddling the green light up until your baby reaches 2 months of age. After that, your little one may try to roll over (remember, babies should sleep on their backs) and the swaddle blanket could become undone and pose a safety issue. You can also use infant sleep sacks, which are meant to make swaddling safer by giving babies a secure feeling without extra fabric around the head. Two to try:
Sleepea
, available for $23.95 at happiestbaby.com; or
Swaddle Up
; $29.99 at Amazon.

title.en-US: Read this before you book a babymoon

content.value: A babymoon—the vacation that many couples take before their little one makes an appearance—can be a perfect chance to relax, bond with your partner, and pamper yourself a bit. But where should you go? And when is the best time? Read on for the advice you need before you skip town.
Consult the calendar—and your doctor.

If you’ve had some complications, check with your doctor first to make sure you don’t need to stay close to home. Once you’re given the green light, you’ll want to choose the best time. While air travel before week 36 of pregnancy is considered safe for women who have healthy pregnancies, you may want to consider a 2nd-trimester trip. As you get closer to your due date, travel might not be as comfortable.
Don’t go totally off the grid.

As tempting as it is to go to a super-remote destination to decompress, it’s important to know you’ll have access to healthcare wherever you’ll be, in case of an emergency. Check to see where the nearest hospital or medical center is before booking your trip.
Think twice about a cruise.

The medical care you’ll find on a ship may not be on par with what you’ll have access to on dry land. But there’s another reason to carefully consider taking a babymoon cruise. Gastrointestinal illnesses including noroviruses are associated with cruise ships, and the CDC says it’s because close living quarters may increase the amount of group contact. (No wonder norovirus is sometimes called the cruise-ship virus.) Cruises aren’t off-limits, but do you research to make sure the one you choose has a good—and healthy—reputation. And definitely check their policies; many cruise ships don’t let women on board after the 24-week mark (yes, even if you have a doctor’s note clearing you to sail).
Steer clear of the Zika zone.

Unfortunately, the Z word is still a factor to consider when planning a trip. Getting bitten by a Zika-infected mosquito during pregnancy puts your baby’s health at risk for various disorders including microcephaly, in which the head and brain are smaller than normal. Don’t worry—plenty of warm-weather locales are on the safe list, including Southern California, Florida, Bermuda, Hawaii, and the Seychelles. For a regularly updated list of countries affected by Zika, you can check the Centres for Disease Control and Prevention website.
Consider your energy levels.

Every pregnancy is different. Some expecting women find they have enough energy for an active(ish) getaway—like touring a new city that requires a lot of walking. If you’ve been feeling fatigued, you may want to narrow your search to locales that maximize the R&R potential. A beach, a cozy cottage, anywhere with 24/7 room service and on-demand foot rubs? Count us in!

title.en-US: What you should really expect when your water breaks

content.value: If your life were a movie, you could count on having a big, dramatic splat of fluid between your legs when your baby is ready to make a debut. In reality, the experience can vary wildly from woman to woman. To help you know what to expect and put your mind at ease, here's everything you need to know about your water breaking.
What is water breaking?
During pregnancy, your baby is protected by the amniotic sac, a fluid-filled membrane made of two layers. When the amniotic sac ruptures, and fluid leaks out, that’s your water breaking.
What will it feel like when it happens?
Don’t worry, it isn’t painful. And despite what you see in movies, it’s not always a big gush of fluid. Sometimes it’s more of a trickle.
When does your water break?
Most of the time, a woman’s water breaks after labor is in full gear. But in roughly 10% of births, the amniotic sac ruptures before contractions start.
What happens if your water breaks before labor begins?

In this case, you’ll likely go into labor within 12 to 24 hours. If labor doesn’t happen naturally, your doctor may induce you to prevent a risk of infection. That said, in low-risk pregnancies when a woman at term experiences a water-break before labor, waiting to induce may be OK. New recommendations by the American Congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists say that a doctor or midwife could consider delaying induction for a little while if there are no health reasons to expedite delivery.
On the flip side, what happens if you’re in labor and your water hasn’t broken yet?

If your cervix is adequately dilated (usually between 3 and 5 centimeters) and your doctor thinks it’s a good idea to help move things along, a tool inserted through your vagina can be used to rupture the amniotic sac. If things are progressing normally and your provider decides there’s no need to pop the sac and up the ante on contractions, it will likely break on its own during labor. While extremely rare, sometimes babies make their debut while still being encased within their amniotic sac.

title.en-US: Everything you need to know about swaddling

content.value: Swaddling—also known as wrapping your baby up in a blanket burrito-style—is one of the oldest techniques in the parenting book for calming a baby down. The theory is that it mimics the security of baby’s experience in the womb; after all, it’s pretty tight in there! A lot of people rely on swaddling to help fussy babies doze off, but does that mean it’s safe? Read on for answers to important questions about this sleep-tight method.
When is swaddling a good idea?

“I encourage parents to try swaddling if their baby seems fussy or tough-to-calm,” says Christina Gantcher, one of the most popular sleep coaches on Maven and the founder of Good Night Sleep Coaching. “Swaddling often helps babies relax what’s called the ‘startle reflex’ that wakes them up—that’s one of the involuntary reactions newborns are born with.”
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
How should I lay my baby down?

The most important thing that parents need to know is that—swaddled or not—babies should always be put down to sleep on their backs until their first birthday. Tummy- or side-sleep has been linked to an increase in sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS). Even if you know this rule, the Mayo Clinic offers this advice: Don't assume that other caregivers will place your baby to sleep in the right position; insist on it. “Once your baby can roll over both ways on his own in the crib, it isn't necessary to return him to his back each time you find him flipped,” says Maven pediatrician Amy Brandon M.D. “Just be sure to follow the rest of the American Academy of Pediatrics Safe Sleep Guidelines’, such as making sure your baby is is on a firm, flat sleep surface and keeping bedding or soft materials out of the crib.”
When should you stop swaddling?

Once your baby shows signs of being able to roll over, it’s time to stop swaddling. “Most pediatricians feel babies should be weaned from the swaddle by four months, but every infant is different,” says Brandon. “For instance, some babies start to roll over at 2 months, and the day you celebrate this milestone is the day to stop the swaddle.” The good news: During and after the transition from swaddling, you can still suit up your baby for cozy sleep without wrapping their arms close to their body. Brandon recommends the Halo Sleepsack, Merlin Magic Sleepsuit, or the Zipadee-Zip (all available on Amazon).
Is there such thing as a too-tight swaddle?

Yes. Researchers who looked into this found that in order for a baby’s hips to develop properly in the first six months, the legs need to be separated instead of held rigidly together; tight swaddling may leave babies at a higher risk for hip dysplasia. This doesn’t mean you need to ditch the method—just avoid wrapping your baby so tight that she doesn’t have enough room to bend her legs. Bottom line: It’s OK to make your baby snug as a bug, but within reason.

If your newborn is inconsolable every time you put her down to sleep, and you need some advice,book an appointment with a pediatrician or sleep coach in Maven’s network. They can help you figure out if your baby is going through a normal bout of finickiness, or if something else—like colic or acid reflux—could be to blame.
Don't assume that other caregivers will place your baby to sleep in the right position.

title.en-US: How to deal with rude comments during pregnancy

content.value: Advice for stopping the cringe-fest.
"You look ready to pop—are you due tomorrow?"
"Look at that belly—you must be having twins!"
“I don’t know how you put up with a partner who travels all the time while you’re pregnant. My partner was right beside me 24/7.”
“I worked right up until my due date—that’s nice that you get to be on ‘vacation’ for a while before your baby arrives.”

Oh, the comments. The sometimes insensitive, often clueless, and occasionally just-plain-rude remarks that pregnant people hear every day. If you’ve been on the receiving end of a jab, you know how it feels. You may even have worried that you’re overreacting, or blaming your pregnancy hormones for how deep they cut. Let us assure you: Feeling hurt—or annoyed—is totally normal.

So what should you do? Everyone reacts differently, and you’re allowed to determine your response based on your relationship with this person (or lack of relationship, if it’s a stranger). Think about what will make you the most comfortable: Tackling it head on, deflecting, making a joke—it’s up to you. The important thing is to not take on other people’s opinions, internalize them, or use them to turn on yourself. If it helps, write down a few mantras that you can turn to when you need them. For instance...
...My belly is the size it’s supposed to be.
...My choices are the best ones for my baby and me.
...My view of myself matters more than the opinion of others.
The bottom line:

Feel free to say your peace and set your boundaries. But also know that sometimes the best response is no response. When you don’t engage, others get the picture that your experience is not open for judgment.

title.en-US: Is your OB-GYN giving you bad exercise advice?

content.value: Read this before you retire your gym shoes.

When it comes to keeping you and your baby healthy, erring on the side of caution is generally a good idea. But considering all the perks of prenatal fitness, too-much caution (i.e. resigning yourself to nine couch-potato months) may not do you any favors. “Exercise during pregnancy has many benefits including decreasing the risk of gestational diabetes and excess weight gain,” says Jackie Stone, MD, a Maven OB-GYN. Of course, if your pregnancy is high-risk and your doctor has advised laying off the exercise for medical reasons, it’s important to follow her recommendations. But some women with perfectly normal pregnancies say their providers dole out advice that conflicts with the latest research on exercise. They’ve been warned, for instance, to keep their heart rate below 140, or skip out on fitness if they’re feeling tired. (Um, who doesn’t feel tired when they’re expecting?)
What’s the reality?

The truth is, studies show most moms-to-be fall short of the recommended guidelines for exercise. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) takes a clear stance: Women with uncomplicated pregnancies should be encouraged to engage in both aerobic and strength-conditioning exercises; they suggest 20 to 30 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic exercise most days of the week. The Department of Health and Human Services also recommends at least 150 minutes a week without any specific heart rate limits. As long as you can pass the “talk test"—meaning you can talk normally while exercising—ACOG says your heart rate should be fine.
So what should you do if you want to stay active but your doctor isn’t on board?

You can always get a second opinion from another OB-GYN or midwife, and ask if they are familiar with the newest guidelines from ACOG. Finding a supportive doctor who will allow you to have a voice in decisions surrounding your pregnancy is important. If your doctor believes exercise is dangerous, ask what—specifically—makes vigorous activity risky. There may be good reasons to lay low; just make sure you’re getting personalized care, and not one-size-fits-all advice. And if exercise gives you more energy, a better night's rest, and helps you prepare for labor, wouldn’t it be nice to cash in on the benefits if you’re able to?

title.en-US: The one stress-relief tool every pregnant woman needs

content.value: Hint: It involves a pen.

Being pregnant sometimes feels like a roller coaster ride of emotions. And when stress peaks, it can be hard to know how to calm yourself down. But scientists have found an easy and accessible tool that can help ease anxiety and give you a sense of resilience during pregnancy. In fact, it’s right at your fingertips—journaling—and it boils down to a link between writing and processing our feelings.

When researchers asked subjects to write about emotionally challenging experiences they were going through, people saw countless positive effects on their wellbeing—including increased happiness, less depression and anxiety, and even better relationships. So when stress takes hold, consider grabbing a journal or even your phone, setting the timer for 15 or 20 minutes, and jotting down how you’re feeling (or go with wherever you mind wanders). You may be surprised to find that the simple act of writing gives you a new perspective and can make the journey to motherhood more joyful.

title.en-US: How can you and your partner stay close after the baby?

content.value: Answer from Mental Health Specialist Mercedes Samudio, LCSW, MSW
Having a baby can be one of the happiest times in your relationship, but also one of the most stressful. Here are a few ways to manage the stress and keep your bond strong.
Be honest about the hard stuff.

When a child comes into the world, you may want your partner to think you’re handling everything well. But it’s okay to share when you have those moments that make you question yourself, and even to admit that you're not sure you want to have a child now that you've brought one into the world. By the way, having these thoughts and feelings doesn't mean that you don't love your baby or that you will not be good parents. When two people can be honest with each other about their struggles and share uncomfortable admissions, they learn to be more gentle with each other about the lifelong commitment that is caring for a child.
Make together time a priority.

It's important that you schedule time to do things as a couple—without the baby—to remind you both of the relationship that existed before having a child. If leaving the house feels too exhausting, hire a sitter to come to watch the baby for a few hours while you watch a movie in bed together. That counts! However you spend your date nights, remember to set aside some time to discuss things other than parenting.
Communicate your needs.

While you’re prioritizing your baby's needs, it can be hard to remember you both have needs, too. This can be difficult to admit without feeling selfish as a parent. But self-care is essential for showing up at your best for your child. Be open about whatever it is you’re lacking—sleep, food, a moment to shower, etc.—and work with each other to help accommodate those needs.
Schedule solo time.

Yes, you need time together as a duo, but it's also important to spend time apart. You both need a break from the 24/7 focus of caring for a baby. Work out a schedule so that you can carve out an hour to hang out with a friend or sit in a coffee shop. Think of it as time to recharge your batteries so that you can both be there for each other and the baby.

title.en-US: Childbirth education

content.value:
Birthing classes often are offered through local hospitals and birthing centers. Some classes follow a specific method, such as Lamaze or Bradley method. Others review labor techniques from a variety of methods. You might want to consider the different methods beforehand to decide if one appeals more to you than others. That way, you will know what to sign up for if more than one type of birthing class if offered. Try to sign up for a class several months
before your due date, in your sixth or seventh month of pregnancy as the classes can run for six to eight weeks. Classes sometimes fill up quickly. Also, make sure the instructor is qualified.

Most women attend the class with the person who will provide support during labor, such as a partner, sibling, or good friend. This person is sometimes called the labor coach. During class, the instructor will go over the signs of labor and review the stages of labor. They will talk about positioning for labor and birth, and ways to control pain. They also will give you strategies to work through labor pains and to help you stay relaxed and in control. You will practice many of these strategies in class, so you are ready when the big day arrives. Many classes also provide a tour of the birthing facility.

Childbirth classes can be useful for mothers planning both natural and medicated births! Childbirth preparation classes provide valuable information and practical tips regarding all phases of labor. Classes are geared towards educating pregnant women and their partners about the process of labor and birth and the choices available to them, including medications.

Most pregnant women and their labor support find group classes to be the most helpful method of meeting both their need for education and reinforcement in comparison to watching online videos. Listening to other partners’ questions in class and recognizing the normalcy of what they are feeling can be very reassuring. In addition, most of the coping techniques are difficult to grasp just by reading a book or watching a video. Because some class time is devoted to practicing techniques, most participants have increased confidence in their coping skills by the completion of the course.
Common birth methods
Lamaze
Designed to increase women’s confidence in their ability to give birth
Uses evidence-based education and advocacy to teach options to women and their labor support
Covers medical interventions and their pros and cons
Bradley
Only prepares women for natural births without the use of medication
Provides relaxation techniques to manage pain
Also addresses postpartum care, breastfeeding, and labor rehearsals

This article is not intended to be a substitute for medical advice or care. Please consult a doctor with any questions you have before taking actions around your health and wellbeing. As always, our Maven practitioners are available, on-demand, to address your concerns.
Book an appointment here.
Sources:
http://www.lamaze.org/LamazeFundamentals
https://www.womenshealth.gov/pregnancy/getting-ready-baby/birthing-breastfeeding-and-parenting-classes
http://www.babies.sutterhealth.org/during/preg_classes.html
http://www.sutterhealth.org/health/healthinfo/?section=healthinfo&page=article&sgml_id=hw194320&_

title.en-US: 3 documentaries to watch when you’re having a baby

content.value: Netflix and chill? That motto was basically coined for the tired days of pregnancy. There’s a time for pure entertainment flicks—Knocked Up, anyone? But when you want a dose of reality, bust out the popcorn and get cozy with one of these (all-too-real) documentaries.
The Business of Being Born

This documentary, produced by Ricki Lake, raises questions about the way most women experience childbirth in the U.S.—namely, in a hospital setting—and explores different ways of doing things. Alternative practices like home births aren’t right for everyone, but it’s a good view into your options.
Babies

This film follows four infants from birth to first step. Part of what makes this documentary so interesting: Each baby hails from a different part of the world, which means you’ll get a glimpse of how babies experience life in Namibia, Japan and Mongolia—as well as the U.S. Cue the awwws!
9 Months That Made You

This three-part TV series that originally aired on PBS uses the latest in science to reveal how babies spent their time in the womb. You’ll get a fascinating look at the growth process of a fetus and insights into how genetics can cause unexpected mutations that make people unique.

title.en-US: Baby percentiles: Do they matter?

content.value: When to obsess over the results, and when to chill.
What is a percentile chart?

Pediatricians use a baby percentile chart to plot infants’ height, weight, and head circumference—and spot trends in a child’s growth over time. The percentiles you’re given at the end of an appointment reflect your little one’s stats compared to the average measurements for other kids who are the same gender and age as your child.
Where does the chart come from?

The WHO (World Health Organization) created the charts most doctors use for children under the age of 2. The charts are based on a large sample of infants from around the world, not just the US. Keep in mind, adds Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, MD., “these charts are based only on breastfed infants from 6 countries (not on formula-fed infants).”
How do you interpret the results?
If your baby is in the 30th percentile for weight, that means in a group of 100 kids, 29 infants weigh less and 69 babies weigh more.
What does it mean if your baby it at one extreme or the other?

Having a daughter who’s “11th percentile for height” or a son who is “95th percentile for weight” often sends parents into a tizzy, say experts. But pediatricians note that these stats—viewed alone without any other context—don’t tell you much. In other words, you can likely relax. The value of these percentiles lies in tracking growth over time. For instance, if your baby has been steadily gaining weight and suddenly that growth curve takes a nosedive, he could be undernourished and not eating enough during feedings.
The bottom line:

Try not to get too focused on the numbers. Your pediatrician’s job is to monitor the growth and development of your child, and to alert you if there’s an issue. So if your little one is literally off the charts yet shows all the signs of being a happy, healthy kid, consider that... 100.

title.en-US: What are the most common myths about pregnancy?

content.value: Answer from Maven OB-GYN, Jacquelyn Stone, MD
With all the pregnancy “wisdom” out there, it's hard to tease out what you should really believe versus what you can ignore. Here are a few of the most common misconceptions.
Myth #1: Moms-to-be should eat for two.

Remember, your baby starts out about the size of a sweet pea when you find out you are pregnant and grows to only an average weight of 6 to 9 pounds. That hardly justifies eating enough to feed two adult people! It takes about 300 extra calories or so per day to sustain a healthy pregnancy and gain the recommended 25-35 pounds (for someone starting out at a healthy weight and having only one baby—not multiples). Where those calories come from matters, too. While there’s room for the occasional indulgence, fruits, veggies, and lean protein are a healthier bet—for you and your baby—than a nightly bowl of ice cream.
Myth #2: You can tell the sex of the baby because....

It must be a girl because you are carrying high. It must be a boy because the heart rate is low. It must be a girl because you are having excessive morning sickness. You’ve probably heard all kinds of old wives’ tales regarding gender prediction. (The craziest one I’ve heard had to do with peeing in a toilet bowl full of Drano and looking for a color change.) While these are all fun, the best way to know the gender of your baby is to have the sonographer look at your anatomy scan around 18-22 weeks. If you choose to have cell-free fetal DNA prenatal screening, chorionic villus testing, or amniocentesis, you can find out the gender of your baby then, too.
Myth #3: Pregnant women have to stop dying their hair.

It is important to avoid the strong fumes, but as long as you make sure that you are in a well-ventilated area, there is no evidence that hair dye can be absorbed through your skin and cross through the placenta to harm the baby. If the smell of the dye makes you nauseous, wait until after morning sickness eases up. But rest assured, you don’t have to give up all of your pampering and self-care for nine months.
Myth #4: Exercise should be avoided during pregnancy.

Unless you have a specific medical condition or pregnancy complication that would make exercise dangerous (always get the green light from your doctor first), exercise is perfectly safe. In fact, exercise has been shown to reduce the risk of excessive weight gain and gestational diabetes and make labor and delivery easier. So tie up your jogging shoes or do some prenatal yoga in your living room. Just make sure you don’t get so winded that you can’t carry on a conversation.

title.en-US: What’s one piece of pregnancy advice that’s 100% wrong?

content.value: Answer from Maven OB-GYN, Jacquelyn Stone, MD
"Pregnant women should avoid all fish.”

This advice is based on a fear of mercury levels in fish. While it’s true that exposure to high mercury levels in the womb can cause terrible neurological damage in kids, some providers continue to tell pregnant women to avoid all fish, mainly as precautionary advice. But the (overhyped) fear of mercury risk is getting in the way of the benefits moms-to-be could reap by eating fish. Fish is a major source of omega-3 fatty acids like DHA—and DHA consumption during pregnancy has been shown to improve cognitive functioning, spatial reasoning, and motor function in children later in life (up to 14 years of age!).

Prenatal vitamins are often supplemented with DHA, but it is unclear if a supplement is as good for babies as DHA obtained by eating fish. The FDA recommends that pregnant women eat two to three servings of low-mercury fish per week to get the important developmental benefits. Of course, make sure it’s cooked (no sushi), and choose fish high in DHA like anchovies, Atlantic herring, Atlantic mackerel, mussels, oysters, farmed and wild salmon, sardines, snapper, and trout. As long as you avoid fish that’s high in mercury—tilefish from the Gulf of Mexico, shark, swordfish, orange roughy, bigeye tuna, marlin, and king mackerel—you can definitely enjoy your surf & turf.

title.en-US: What tests can you say no to during pregnancy?

content.value: Answer from Maven OB-GYN, Jacquelyn Stone, MD

Most tests performed during pregnancy are necessary to make sure that you and your baby are healthy. Tests that are considered routine include checking your blood counts and blood type, as well as ones that make sure you don’t have certain infections like Rubella or HIV. An ultrasound in the middle of your pregnancy to confirm that your baby is growing well and does not have any birth defects is also necessary, and a glucose test (usually given between 24 to 28 weeks) is an important screen for gestational diabetes.

However, some tests available to pregnant women are optional. These include genetic tests to see if you or your partner may be a carrier of a genetic disease that you could pass along to your baby, and diagnostic tests that can identify Down syndrome and other chromosomal abnormalities. Your doctor should always tell you about any test that will be performed and ask your permission. That said, I’m always surprised by how many patients aren’t told which tests are optional and counseled about their options. The best way to avoid unnecessary tests is to be armed with information and to ask questions. Be sure you understand which tests are being run and why. Reach out to a Maven OB-GYN to get guidance before your next prenatal appointment.

title.en-US: How can you avoid unnecessary interventions during birth?

content.value: Answer from Maven OB-GYN, Jacquelyn Stone, MD

The best way to avoid unnecessary interventions during delivery is to have a good relationship with a provider you trust. If your doctor says the baby’s heart rate is worrisome and an intervention needs to happen, you need to be able to trust her recommendation that action should be taken. However, if you and your baby are doing well, and there’s no reason to quickly pull the trigger on an intervention, you want to have confidence that your doctor won’t rush you into a decision that you aren’t ready to make.

Having a doula by your side is also a great idea. Studies show that women who have continuous support from a doula during pregnancy and delivery are less likely to have C-sections or forceps-assisted births, as well as pain medication, or negative feelings about childbirth. Tap into Maven’s Doula network if you want to talk more about this option.

title.en-US: When should you switch doctors during pregnancy?

content.value: Answer from Maven OB-GYN, Jacquelyn Stone, MD

Women switch doctors during pregnancy for all kinds of reasons. These may be because of a necessity, like moving to a new city or an insurance-related factor. However, simply not having a good connection with your provider is also a valid reason to switch. It is so important to feel comfortable with your doctor or midwife and to believe that you are in good hands so that you can feel at ease when the big day arrives. You may not understand exactly what those squiggly lines on the fetal monitor mean, how long is too long to push, or when an emergency C-section really does need to be performed, so you need to know that you can trust this provider and her judgment.

If you have doubts or don’t feel like your concerns are being heard, it’s okay to interview other practitioners and switch if you find a better fit. It’s always better to make a move like this earlier rather than later as sometimes it is difficult to find a practice that will take a transfer after 32-36 weeks.

title.en-US: Why do people have weird dreams during pregnancy?

content.value: Answer from Maven OB-GYN, Jacquelyn Stone, MD

This is a common symptom in the first trimester for many pregnant people, but it can continue throughout pregnancy. No one knows for sure what brings on these vivid dreams, but it’s likely due to an increase in pregnancy hormones. Your need for more shuteye during pregnancy combined with sleep disruptions may also have something to do with your dream life. As we tend to have difficulty sleeping and wake up more often in pregnancy (thanks to having to pee every two hours, baby kicking, and a bump the size of a basketball), our REM sleep patterns change. Dreams occur during deep or REM sleep, so you're a lot more likely to remember your dreams if you wake up during the REM stage. The result: Dreams may seem more intense or real. Some women who keep a daily dream journal say that paying attention to recurring themes helps them better understand their emotions or aspects of their lives that need extra attention.

title.en-US: What are the best ways to manage stress during pregnancy?

content.value: Answer from Maven OB-GYN, Jacquelyn Stone, MD
Use these tips to feel happier and calmer when you’re expecting:
Be kind to yourself.

Give yourself permission to not get everything done today (or tomorrow... or the next day). It’s OK to rest instead of tackling another item on your to-do list—some things truly can wait. If you’re feeling overwhelmed, do something that makes you happy. Watch some bad TV. FaceTime with your best friend. Better yet, watch some bad TV while FaceTiming with your best friend. Whatever it is that helps you unwind.
Exercise.
Get your doctor’s OK first, but exercise in most pregnancies is safe and healthy. And just taking a walk or doing some yoga can be a great physical and mental stress reliever.
Have sex.

Yes, seriously. Always check with your doctor, but as long as there are no complications, sex is safe in most pregnancies. Find a position that is comfortable for your growing belly and get busy between the sheets. You will feel closer to your S.O. and unwind at the same time. In general, after the 20th week of pregnancy, doctors recommend avoiding positions where you’re lying flat on your back. And, of course, if you do have sex and notice you are uncomfortable, find other ways of being intimate.
Open up to someone.

Venting to a friend can often put things into perspective and help you feel better. Steer clear of Negative Nancys. Instead, make a point to talk to a friend who is your best encourager and supporter.
Know when it’s more than stress.

We all get overwhelmed, and pregnancy is a major life change that can increase our stress levels even more. For some women, however, it’s more than just stress. If you’ve ever struggled with anxiety or depression before, you are more at risk for those conditions creeping up again during pregnancy. Even if you haven’t been diagnosed in the past, it’s possible to experience anxiety or clinical depression for the first time during pregnancy. Talk therapy can be very helpful, and sometimes medication is necessary as well. Make an appointment with your doctor or talk to a Maven practitioner if your symptoms are keeping you from sleeping, if you aren’t able to eat, of it they are interfering with your relationships. If you are thinking about hurting yourself or someone else, call your doctor and get help right away.

title.en-US: What do experts wish they knew before having a baby?

content.value: Answer from Maven Pediatrician, Amy Brandon, MD, IBCLC

I wish I had known that the baby doesn't need anything except you (and to be fed and to have his diaper changed). That is, your infant doesn't know if his clothes are brand new or second-hand (or even if they’re “cute”). He doesn't care if the nursery is finished when you bring him home. He isn't watching the clock so you shouldn't worry about a strict baby schedule either. As they say, the days are long (oh, how long they can be!) but the years go fast, so just do what you can to prepare yourself and then... just try to relax and enjoy the ride. Your baby is new at this and it's okay if you’re a beginner at it, too—you'll learn together.

Another thing I wish I had known before I had my first child (and before I became a lactation consultant): Breastfeeding is hard. If you are planning to breastfeed your baby, try to take a class or two beforehand and find out how the hospital and your OB and/or pediatrician clinic handle breastfeeding issues. How can you access an International Board Certified Lactation Consultant (IBCLC) or other lactation support person if you need one? Don't be shy to ask for help in the hospital or after you go home. If you can't find someone to help locally, come find me or another lactation consultant on the Maven platform and we will do what it takes to get you and your baby to your breastfeeding goals. I promise you, asking for help is worth it!

title.en-US: What postpartum depression symptoms are commonly overlooked?

content.value: Answer from Maven OB-GYN, Jacquelyn Stone, MD

The most common symptom of PPD (postpartum depression) is a depressed or anxious mood. It can interfere with life in a big way—for instance, some moms are unable to bond with their infants because they are so overwhelmed with depression. Some women feel extremely anxious about things they have no control over; they may be constantly worried that something bad will happen to their baby. Pervasive thoughts and feelings of worthlessness or guilt are a factor for some (i.e.: “I’m no good. My family would be better off without me. I don’t deserve to be a mom.”) And while all new moms experience overtiredness, postpartum depression goes beyond feeling exhausted; women with PPD may lack any motivation to care for their babies or do daily tasks. A change in appetite is also common, and it can manifest in not eating at all, or overeating/stress eating. In extreme cases, women will think about or develop a plan for harming themselves or their babies.

Learning to recognize what’s going on and to seek help for it is key. If you start to notice that something isn’t quite right, let your doctor or a Maven practitioner know. There’s a way out, but it requires letting someone in.

title.en-US: How can women manage weight gain during pregnancy?

content.value: Answer from Maven nutritionist, Melissa Flynn, RD

The first thing to consider is how much weight you really need to gain. It is recommended that women at a normal weight and pre-pregnancy BMI (body mass index) gain 25-35 pounds over the course of their pregnancies. Underweight women need to gain more: between 28-40 pounds. Overweight women need to gain 15-25 pounds, while those who are obese should gain 11-20 pounds. Definitely check with your doctor to make sure you’re on the right track.

Some women think pregnancy is a time to “eat for two,” but gaining a healthy amount of weight usually comes down to a couple of extra (nutritious) snacks a day. While guidelines vary, women who are at a normal BMI pre-pregnancy might need no additional calories in the first trimester, about 340 extra calories a day in the second trimester, and about 450 extra calories a day in the third trimester. Women starting off with a lower BMI may need to add more calories by increasing the size and/or frequency of their meals and snacks; and women with higher BMIs may need to focus only on the quality of their meals in order to gain an appropriate amount of weight.

Pregnancy is stressful enough without feeling like you have to control your weight without any support, so definitely ask for help if you need it. A Maven nutritionist can tailor a customized eating plan to your to your specific goals.

title.en-US: Is a Rock 'n Play safe for sleeping?

content.value: Answer from Maven Pediatrician Amy Brandon, MD, IBCLC

Probably any mom you’ve met has told you about the Rock 'n Play, if not holds it solely responsible for restoring the sleep of her baby and therefore her sanity. It’s a baby holder that rocks back and forth. Baby gets snuggled into it, in position that’s similar to sitting in a car-seat (somewhat upright). The problem is that guidelines from The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) say babies should sleep flat on their backs, on a firm, flat surface. The Rock ‘n Play Sleeper doesn’t meet these requirements—it’s not firm, and it’s not flat.

Despite any testimonials you hear, the Rock ‘n Play (and other items like it) is not a safe sleep surface, as recommended by the AAP, and infants should not be allowed to sleep there unsupervised. In fact, as of 2019, the product has been recalled, and should not be used under any circumstances.

title.en-US: What baby gear is essential for the first month?

content.value: Answer from Maven Pediatrician Amy Brandon, MD, IBCLC

There are really only a handful of must-haves in the first month. Aside from a carseat to get home from the hospital, everything else pretty much revolves around food and sleep. With those two priorities in mind, here’s what’s on my list:
Gear for feeding.

If you’re breastfeeding, you'll want good nursing bras and tank tops, a nursing ointment (lanolin) as well as gel pads (I loved Soothies by Lansinoh). If you’re bottle feeding, make sure to start with slow-flow nipples. For all moms: You'll need breast pads for that inevitable leakage, as well as a nursing pillow—either a Boppy or My Brest Friend pillow. If you’re able to, it’s a good idea to invest in a good, comfortable chair for feeding your baby; after all, you'll be spending hours upon hours there! Many women like chairs that glide, rock, and/or recline. Try them out beforehand and make sure your pick is tall enough for you to rest your head comfortably when leaning back! If your insurance covers a breast pump, now is a good time to research your options and choose the one that seems to suit you best. [A word from Maven: We’ve partnered with 1 Natural Way, a company can help you verify your insurance for a breast pump and select a model.
Click here for help
Gear for sleeping.

I recommend a Pack & Play, which may be your baby’s primary sleep location in your bedroom (room-sharing is recommended by the American Academy of Pediatrics) or another spot where you can lay your little one down during the day. Some parents rely on a white noise machine for getting their baby to doze off. As for mom’s sleep, an eye mask can help you catch some Zzz’s during the day. Lastly, good waddle blankets for baby; I love the big ones made of muslin—a lightweight, finely-woven breathable fabric—that can work as a swaddle, blanket, or nursing cover.

All the rest can wait. The reality is, most baby gear will only be used for a couple of months, tops, and that's if your baby even likes it. I also tell parents: There's no shame in buying some gear secondhand or even letting your baby try out a friend's swing or bouncer before investing. One great resource is a book called "Baby Bargains" (
$11.50 on Amazon

), which groups gear by type and then ranks it according to safety, features, and parent reviews. This is a perfect place to start if you have no idea which crib/stroller/high chair/bathtub you should be choosing for your little bundle of joy.

title.en-US: Returning to work with postpartum anxiety

content.value: 28 years old
Health Education
Wisconsin
How did you know you had postpartum anxiety?

I was formally diagnosed when my baby was about 9 months old, but it started a few weeks after birth. I knew things were a problem because the anxiety became crippling—I couldn’t really function. I also found myself so fearful about losing my child or my husband. I had irrational fears that my baby would die in her sleep, fall down the stairs, swallow something and choke or be poisoned from whatever it was. I was constantly terrified that something bad was going to happen.
Did your doctor or pediatrician screen you for postpartum depression/anxiety in your first few visits after giving birth, or even simply ask how you were doing emotionally?

My doctor brought it up at my 6-week visit. But it was only one question about how I was feeling, and I hadn’t yet figured out that the anxiety I had was an issue. I also felt like a bad mom admitting that I was overwhelmed with fear.
How soon after childbirth did you notice that something wasn’t quite right and you weren’t feeling like yourself?

I was really sad and stressed the first few weeks which I thought was just normal. About 3 to 4 weeks after birth, I started to realize it wasn’t quite right. At that point, my fears really started taking over.
What were your symptoms?
Tightness in my chest and trouble breathing when things were really bad. Constant fear and irrational thoughts about things that could potentially hurt my baby.
How open were you about your experience? Did friends/relatives/colleagues know what you were going through?

I wasn’t open at all—I didn’t even talk to my husband about it until several months later. I was embarrassed and afraid that people would think I was a bad mom or unfit to take care of my baby and take her away from me. It was a vicious cycle of stress and fear.
Did you have postpartum depression or anxiety when you returned to work? How did you cope?
