Actually, my anxiety peaked when I returned to work around 10-months postpartum. I really struggled with the idea of being away from my baby for the first time ever. This is when I started taking the herbs and listening to meditations and self-help podcasts.
How did your experience impact your relationship with your significant other?
My husband didn’t understand postpartum depression or anxiety at first, but once I began talking about it and explained my anxiety, he was very supportive.

Once you identified what you were going through, what helped you get better? For instance, did you go to therapy, take medication, try mindfulness training and other holistic approaches, or something else?

I got a few recommendations for medications and my doctor said I could have them called in at any time. I started taking adaptogenic herbs as they helped immensely when I was doing natural fertility treatments. I started practicing yoga again and focused on stress relief throughout the day, like listening to guided meditations or podcasts that relaxed me. I also started speaking up when I was feeling anxious. If my husband would bring up a topic that triggered my anxiety or just started talking at all when I was already feeling anxious, I would tell him I couldn’t talk about that thing at the moment, and explained to him my physical symptoms. He was pretty receptive.
If you didn’t feel you had enough support, what could have made things better?
I think more information, more questions from my providers, and more follow-up opportunities with my OB would have made a huge difference.
What do you wish others would have done for you without being asked?

I wish my loved ones would have listened without offering solutions. I just needed to talk without being told how to “fix” things. The emphasis on fixing the problem made me feel like I was doing something wrong by feeling anxious.
How long did it take to feel like yourself again, and what do you think helped you the most?

I still struggle with my anxiety today and I am 16-months postpartum. I continue taking steps to naturally control it and I keep that list of medications in my purse as a sort of safety net. Knowing the option is there is really helpful.
What’s the one thing you’d like to see change about how our society perceives postpartum depression and anxiety?

I wish people knew how hard it is and how it’s not just normal “new baby stress.” I wish there was more postpartum care offered in general but specifically more screenings and follow-up on a mom’s mental health.

title.en-US: Separation anxiety and returning to work

content.value: 32 years old
Non-profit
San Francisco, CA
How long after having a child did you return to work?
6 months.
Who cares for your child while you’re at work, and how did you make your childcare decision?
For both financial and scheduling reasons, I use the combo approach to childcare. That includes my child’s dad, other family members (grandparents), and a daycare center.
Any advice for someone navigating childcare?
Use your community. Other parents are often the first ones to have a heads up on which day care facilities have openings, the quality of the programs, carpooling(!), and so on.
What was the most challenging part about your first days back at work?

The anxiety I felt, which I only experienced when I was away from my baby. I felt a constant worry about everything that could be happening—or wasn’t happening but should have been— while I wasn’t there. The anxiety would vanish as soon as I was reunited with him at the end of the workday, but all the time in between drop-off and pick-up was very difficult. I found it hard to stay focused on anything other than wondering how he was doing, being cared for, and anything that could potentially be going wrong.
Have things gotten easier or harder with time? How so?

Things have gotten easier; there is much less worry. It is possible I was dealing with some undiagnosed postpartum anxiety. I may not have noticed it until the separation of going back to work at six months. And since I only had one six-week postpartum check-up after giving birth, the window for
diagnosing it and getting help with that was probably missed. However, time and practice (at being a working mom) eventually enabled me to a foundation to trust all of my son’s other caregivers in my absence, and things have greatly improved.
How could your workplace have helped make the transition smoother?

My workplace just started offering new parents the option to return to work part-time. That would have been wonderful if it was available when my child was born. I think it would have been helpful to ease into the return-to-work transition with a more flexible, adaptive schedule.
Did you have thoughts of quitting your job? And if you kept yourself in the game, what helped you stay?

I remind myself of the importance of caring for my family though my work. Being able to pay rent, bills, create some savings, and have health insurance are not things that would be possible without my job. It also really helps that I work for an organization whose mission is important to me and has a direct and positive impact on my community.
What’s one thing you’d like to see change about the return-to-work conversation for parents?

I think we need to see all people in the workforce as whole people, and not only their contributions as measured by their job titles. Whole people have complicated, messy, wonderful, lives. And in order to truly value what they bring to the economic table and keep them there, we need to appreciate and support all of who they are.

title.en-US: What do all moms-to-be need to know about finding a pediatrician?

content.value: Answer from Maven Pediatrician, Amy Brandon, MD, IBCLC

The best time to start searching for a pediatrician is in your last trimester, at least a few weeks before your expected due date. You'll want to look for an office that is conveniently located for you and (ideally) covered by your insurance. Once you've narrowed it down to a few doctors, how do you choose the best one for your family? Here are some questions you may want to ask before making your decision.
How many practitioners work at this practice, and how do things work when my baby needs to be seen but our primary pediatrician isn't available?
How does the office handle advice and/or appointments when parents call in with a concern that needs prompt attention? Can I be seen the same day, or will you likely refer me to urgent care?
What are your office hours, and what can you tell me about the after-hours and weekend availability of your practitioners?
Do you have a nurse/advice line, and how does it work?

In the unexpected circumstance that my baby needs to be admitted to a hospital, where would that be, and would our pediatrician be able to care for him or her there? How does the hospital handle billing and fees?

How soon after birth will the pediatrician be seeing my baby, and what is your schedule for routine visits and immunizations? Do you follow the recommended schedules set forth by the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)?
Once you've chosen a doctor for your baby, the most important considerations going forward are open communication, mutual trust, and confidence in the care he or she provides for your baby.

title.en-US: How should you prepare for the first week with a newborn?

content.value: Answer from Maven Pediatrician Amy Brandon, MD, IBCLC

The first week at home with a newborn will be a blur of emotions, hormones, and lack of sleep. You'll wonder if you're doing anything right and convince yourself you're doing everything wrong. Rest assured: You've got this! Here are a few things to keep in mind.
1.) If you plan for anything, plan for that first week to be about nothing but feeding (your baby and yourself) and sleeping (whenever you can). Anything else you accomplish is gravy.

2.) Once you're sure you have more than enough diapers and wipes (let's avoid those midnight CVS runs if we can), see who from your tribe can help you after you get home from the hospital. As much as you can, lean on your partner, parents and in-laws, friends, etc. And try to get specific commitments from them on when they can be there in the beginning and what they will do for you. For instance: Your brother Charlie helps out on Friday; Your friend Sally brings lunch Saturday and can stay an hour to hold the babe while you shower, etc.

3.) Once you have your helpers pencilled in, give yourself the freedom to tell everyone else, in the nicest way possible: no visitors until you're ready! The last thing you need to worry about is having to “look presentable” and smile politely while Great Aunt Susan And Her Perfume Cloud ooh and ahh over baby when you'd much rather spend those precious minutes showering or napping. Communicate ahead of time that they'll each be the first to know when you and your baby are up for a visit.

4.) Before your due date, stock the pantry and fridge with easy, accessible snacks and meals: protein bars, nuts, and fruit you can grab while feeding your baby, plus simple ingredients for crock-pot meals. And put all your favorite take-out numbers on speed dial.

5.) Prep your feeding station with a stack of magazines, books, and an updated Netflix queue on your iPad. Because you’ll be spending a lot of time here as you settle into a week—and beyond—of getting to know your beautiful newborn!

title.en-US: A career pivot and promotions after baby

content.value: 34 years old

Senior Asset Manager for a Commercial Real
Estate Firm
California
How long after having your first child did you return to work?
12 weeks
Who cares for your children while you’re at work, and how did you make your childcare decision?

My kids are at a daycare center. It happened by accident, really. When I had my first child, I totally dropped the ball when I was pregnant and didn’t get around to reserving a spot at a daycare, finding in-home child care at someone’s house, or finding a nanny. So when there was a last-minute opening at a daycare center, I grabbed it—and it ended up being the best experience. I had never really considered a large daycare center but my kids have thrived in that environment.
What was the most challenging part about your first days back at work?

Aside from the obvious part about leaving your baby in someone else’s care, my biggest struggles were pumping breast milk and worrying about my career progression. When I went back to work with my oldest, I was the only female attorney in my law firm. I’d block out time on my calendar for pumping, only to have that time totally ignored. There were so many little comments about my “commitment” to being on partner track and the future of my career. I was killing myself working 70-plus hours a week trying to prove my worth and my dedication. It was so unhealthy.
Have things gotten easier or harder with time?

Things have gotten much easier. When my oldest child turned one, I made a career change and moved into asset management in commercial real estate. My second pregnancy, maternity leave, and return to work were much more positive experiences because I was employed at a company that was more family-friendly. Over time, I’ve also eased up my own expectations of myself and I’m able to set better boundaries. And I’m still moving up in my career, with three promotions under my belt in the five years I’ve been a mom.
How could your workplace have helped make the transition smoother?

The obvious answer to that is something that is so lacking in the US: longer—and paid—maternity leave, and more options to “ease” back into work. Even today I struggle with the lack of flexibility in a traditional corporate setting. An environment and culture of trust where I have flexibility to work from home once a week or more would be life-changing for me.
How to you manage the “work/life” juggle?

One of my law school friends said it best when she told me: At the end of the day, look at your overall net outcome. Maybe you were distracted at work and did C+ work for the day, but you were 100% focused on your kids when you got home and had a happy evening with giggles and story-time, so you get an A+ for parenting. Or maybe you rocked a big meeting but you snapped at your kids all morning because you were stressed before your presentation. If, overall, you’re averaging a B or better, you’re doing great. It really is a pendulum that swings back and forth and you have to just go with it and stop aiming for perfection in everything every day.
Did you have thoughts of quitting your job? And if you kept yourself in the game, what helped you stay?

I’ve never wanted to stop working, but I am losing hope that the traditional corporate setting will ever offer true work-life balance, so I’ve been developing two side businesses in the hopes that one day I can make them my full-time work. The goal is to be totally in control of my schedule without giving up the intellectual stimulation and career growth I crave. But I do love how my kids, even at just 2 and 5 years old, really appreciate how both of their parents have engaging careers and work hard. It’s especially satisfying when my daughter talks about all the careers she’s considering for her future.
If your best friend was returning to work after maternity leave, what would you want to say to her?

Give it time. I’m not talking a few days—it might take a few months to find your new normal. Don’t judge working motherhood by the first weeks back after maternity leave. And, embrace the challenge of each phase and know you have a tribe of other working moms supporting you every step of the way.
What’s one thing you’d like to see change about the return-to-work conversation for parents?

I’d love a more open and honest discussion about how leadership, and the older generation in particular, views working mothers and the unconscious biases against them. Sometimes it feels like an uphill battle working against the presumption that you aren’t as committed to your job because of old-school beliefs.

title.en-US: What can people do to get better sleep during pregnancy?

content.value: Answer from Danika Severino Wynn, a Certified Nurse Midwife and International Board Certified Lactation Consultant on Maven
While there’s no one solution that works for everyone, there are plenty of ways to try to get better sleep. Give these a shot:
Practice good sleep hygiene.
Try to maintain a consistent sleep schedule; use the bedroom as a place for rest (instead of a home office, etc.); and don’t keep your phone and other blue-light devices near your bed.
Invest in a pregnancy pillow.

This might seem like an unnecessary indulgence, but if your bump is robbing you of shuteye, it might be worth the splurge. Pregnancy pillows aren’t one-woman-fits-all—they’re designed to ease various body aches and come in many different types, so shop around for the one that’s best for you.
Cut back on fluids before bed.
It’s important to stay hydrated, but drinking large amounts of water and other beverages close to bedtime can result in frequent trips to the bathroom during the night.
Consider acupuncture, massage, or aromatherapy.

If stress or tension is making it difficult to catch some Zzz’s, body work can bring relief and help you get some rest. You can enlist your partner to give you a shoulder and foot massage. If you want to go the aromatherapy route, lavender essential oil is a good go-to for sleep during pregnancy thanks to its soothing properties. You can use a diffuser in your bedroom or try a drop or two on your temples.

title.en-US: Navigating a tough transition back to work

content.value: 29 years old
Graphic Design
Pennsylvania
How long after having a child did you return to work?
5 weeks
Who cares for your child while you’re at work, and how did you make your childcare decision?
My boyfriend got laid off from his job the week after I gave birth. It was an obvious choice for him to stay home with our baby. Now my son is 4, so he’s in preschool.
What was the most challenging part about your first days back at work?

For one, I was still a little bit sore from my C-section. And pumping presented a huge challenge; I worked in a place where the only place to pump was in the bathroom. I only got half-hour breaks, so I would eat my lunch while I pumped in the bathroom. It was so inconvenient that eventually I gave up pumping and breastfeeding altogether at about 3 months. My brain was also somewhat foggy; I was forgetful and made a lot of errors at work for a few months. I don't know if it was stress, or lack of sleep, or depression, or something else. I got over the hump, but it took a while.
Have things gotten easier or harder with time? How so?

Yes and no. Every stage has its struggles, but you get better at managing things and those struggles just become your life. And then sometimes you have a mental breakdown in Target— but it's all good!
How could your workplace have helped make the transition smoother?

They could have offered paid leave so I could have stayed home with my baby for longer than just five weeks. And when I returned to work, they could’ve encouraged me to take the extra breaks I needed in order to pump. Letting me work from home one or two days a week would have also been a huge help.
Most working parents say work/life “balance” is a myth—and the reality is more of a “juggle.” Any tools or tricks that help you manage the juggle?

I think that it's important to realize that you can't excel at everything. If work is really stressful and demanding at one point, you're going to have to accept that your relationship might be on the back burner. But you should remember that if you’re making these trade-offs, they should only be temporary—and try to reclaim lost time when things settle down. What helps me and my partner tremendously is to have the occasional night off from parenting, kid-free. Some people have a hard time leaving their kids with a babysitter or relative overnight, but it's so good to get a good night's sleep and reconnect with your partner—or even yourself! Sometimes you forget who you are without your little one.
Did you have thoughts of quitting your job? And if you kept yourself in the game, what helped you stay?
No. I love what I do, and I have also been the bread winner of my family since our son was born. I take pride in my work and that I can provide for my family.
If your best friend was returning to work after maternity leave, what would you want to say to her?

Stand up for yourself. Make sure you have time to pump. Don't feel bad about calling out when your child is sick. Work is work—your child is most important. Also, try to enjoy being with adults again and make time for friends.
What’s one thing you’d like to see change about the return-to-work conversation for parents?
Extended PAID maternity leave. Period.

title.en-US: What are the biggest feeding challenges for new moms?

content.value: Answer from Danika Severino Wynn, a Maven Certified Nurse Midwife and International Board Certified Lactation Consultant
The challenge: Being overly concerned about your milk supply.
How to deal:

It’s easy to think your baby isn’t getting enough milk, and while sometimes this is true and needs to be addressed, often moms worry without needing to. The truth is, newborn's bellies are the size of a marble and they consume small amounts of breastmilk approximately every 2-3 hours. Sometimes infants will cluster feed by eating every hour for several hours in a row. This is a normal infant behavior, and it doesn't indicate an insufficient milk supply. If babies are making an appropriate number of wet and dirty diapers a day, they are likely getting plenty of milk.
The challenge: Engorgement.
How to deal:

A mother’s milk will “come in” (begin the change from colostrum to mature milk) between 48-72 hours after birth. Often when this initial mature milk comes in, a woman’s breasts can become very full, tender, and uncomfortable. To minimize the discomfort, wear a supportive, wireless bra, don't pump or express milk between infant feedings, and use cool compresses between feedings when your breasts feel too full. This stage will pass within a couple of weeks as your milk supply regulates to your infant's needs.
The challenge: Not getting adequate rest.
How to deal:

Sleep deprivation is a major struggle for new moms, and nighttime feedings are a big part of it. Ask your partner, friends, or family for help so that you can get some stretches of sleep. You may want to consider letting another caretaker give your baby a bottle of expressed milk or formula during the night. Even a little extra shuteye can make a world of difference!

title.en-US: Missing your child when you return to work

content.value: 28 years old
Flight Attendant
Minnesota
How long after having a child did you return to work?
8 months postpartum.
Who cares for your child while you’re at work?
Daycare, plus a combination of friends and relatives (grandmothers).
Any advice for someone navigating childcare for the first time?
Look into your daycare options as early as you possibly can, and be prepared to spend more money for quality care and staff than you think you will need to shell out.
Any tools or tricks that help make managing the day-to-day of child care easier?

There will be days when you forget to pack something, and the stress of, say, getting a call from your sitter about where the sippy cup is will stress you out and make you question your ability to be a mother. So provide duplicates for relatives and friends or ask if they can stockpile the essentials at their homes.
What was the most challenging part about your first days back at work?

I commute to Dallas for work, and never realized how much I could miss someone until I had my daughter. The guilt of getting on a plane and leaving her was so great, and what made it even harder was the fact that she always seemed to get sick when I was at work. It’s hard to find a balance between doing what’s best for your child, blocking out what other people think, and not bashing yourself. But loving our children is what we mothers do—and we should never feel shame or guilt for needing to work in order to provide for them.
Have things gotten easier or harder with time?

It feels much harder to me now that my little one is a toddler. There are days where she cries when I drop her off, or is more distant when I return home. But another flight attendant told me to try to start explaining where I was going, and why mommy has to leave. I started doing that and it makes me feel a little better.
How could your workplace have helped make the transition smoother?
By offering more paid family leave options or a leave of absence.
If your best friend was returning to work after maternity leave, what would you want to say to her?
Make time for you. You aren’t superwoman. Ask for help, cry if you need to, and don’t feel guilty about staying home with your baby if you’re able to and it gives you peace of mind.
What’s one thing you’d like to see change about the return-to-work conversation for parents?

I think we should stop shaming mothers into feeling bad about missing their kids. You form such an amazing bond with your child when you’re pregnant, relish in every milestone. Of course leaving your child is hard, and each woman should be allowed to feel what she feels around returning to work.

title.en-US: What do you wish more women knew about breastfeeding?

content.value: Answer from Maven midwife, Danika Severino Wynn, a Maven Certified Nurse Midwife and International Board Certified Lactation Consultant
1. Even though it's a normal physiologic process, it's not always easy.
I encourage expectant parents to learn as much as they can about breastfeeding before their birth either through videos and books or taking a breastfeeding class.
2. Partners can get more involved.

There are lots of ways for a partner to provide support to a mom who is nursing. For one, they can try to better understand the process of breastfeeding. They can also tend to their partner's needs while they nurse, and help with other aspects of infant care as much as possible so that everything does not fall on mom’s shoulders.
3. Most new mothers (about 98% of them) are physiologically capable of producing sufficient milk for their newborn.

Often times they supplement with formula because of a misconception of how much milk their baby needs and a misunderstanding of what constitutes normal milk production for a new mother. If you are concerned, seek help from a International Board Certified Lactation Consultant (IBCLC); Maven makes it easy to book a video appointment.
4. It gets easier.
Even if you do have a tough time at first, know that many new moms report that breastfeeding gets easier as their milk supply increases and their babies get bigger.
5. Breastfeeding is not for everyone, and that’s OK!
There are women who choose not to breastfeed for a myriad of reasons. They deserve just as much help and support as breastfeeding moms.

title.en-US: How much time will your doctor spend in the delivery room?

content.value: Knowing what to expect will help ease your mind on delivery day.

All OB-GYNs and midwives are different, so your provider may spend more time with you than most doctors do. But don’t be alarmed if she lets the labor and delivery nurse run the show during the early stages. If things are going smoothly, your doctor will know what’s happening (your nurse’s job is to give her updates on your progress) but may be M.I.A. (aka taking care of other patients) until it’s go time.
Does that mean my doctor will show up when I start pushing?

Not necessarily. As you probably know, there could be a big gap between when you enter the pushing stage and when you actually give birth. Often times, the nurse will be on “push-duty” in the beginning. Don’t worry—your doctor will take over when you’re ready to deliver. And most likely, she will be popping in to check on you every few hours.
Doesn’t my doctor need to be there to administer the epidural?
Don’t worry about going too long without your pain meds—epidurals are administered by an anesthesiologist, so your OB-GYN’s whereabouts shouldn’t get in the way.
Wait, what happens if my doctor isn’t on duty when I give birth?

This really depends on the doctor, so you should talk to your OB or midwife about what happens if she’s not on call (or out of town) when you go into labor. Some doctors choose to go into the hospital when their patients are giving birth. But there are definitely cases when that’s not possible, or it isn’t the way your doctor chooses to do things. Bringing it up now, and asking whose hands you’ll be left in (if you haven’t had this conversation already) will allow you to get more comfortable with any scenario that might unfold later.

title.en-US: What advice do you have for women who are worried about labor?

content.value: Answer from Danika Severino Wynn, a Maven Certified Nurse Midwife and International Board Certified Lactation Consultant

It's normal to be anxious about labor and delivery—especially if you’re a first-time mom. I encourage people to try to expose themselves to positive stories and videos about labor and birth as an anecdote to all of the scary things we see and hear. A lot of the depictions of birth on TV and in movies are inaccurate and alarmist.

I also advise expectant parents to take a childbirth education course and consider using a doula to help guide them through the birth process. A doula is a trained birth coach who offers support—both physical and emotional. I try to remind them that pregnancy, labor, and birth are all natural events that have been happening throughout time. Our bodies are wise and know how to birth babies. It can be hard to get our minds on board with the process but having adequate support can truly help!

title.en-US: Pregnancy and work: How can you deal with being so exhausted?

content.value: Answer from Maven Back-To-Work Coach, Mary Beth Ferrante

Of course you’re tired—you are growing a human! Even though that human may only be the size of a pea, your body is in overdrive as it supports another being. Not to mention, sleep may become more and more of a challenge as your pregnancy progresses, which only increases a mom-to-be’s fatigue. While exhaustion on its own my not derail your success, it may keep you from being 100% on your game at work. Here are three strategies that may help you keep your focus—or at least your head up.
1) Embrace the power nap.

If you have the opportunity to sneak in a quick snooze in the middle of the day, take it! I’ve had clients sleep in their cars on their lunch breaks or even close their office doors and get 15 or 20 minutes of shuteye in between meetings.
2) If you can’t nap, get moving.

Standing up often and taking a quick, energizing walk—even if it’s from your desk to the bathroom—may give you just enough of a boost to power you through the day. You’ll likely discover that even though you expend a little energy walking, you get more back than you use. Even better if you can sneak outside (bonus: fresh air also helps with nausea).
3) When all else fails, reach for the coffee mug.

Check with your doctor first, but almost all medical professionals agree that consuming small amounts of caffeine while pregnant is safe. If you’re crashing in the afternoon, time your cup accordingly, maybe skipping your morning latte and going for a P.M. fix. (Just don’t drink caffeine too late in the day so it won’t interfere with your sleep.)

title.en-US: How should you handle pregnancy bias at work?

content.value: Answer from Maven Back-To-Work Coach, Mary Beth Ferrante

A common challenge/concern of expecting moms is that they will get passed up for opportunities or moved off critical projects. Maternal bias is real and it often gets overlooked because managers think they are doing you a “favor” by giving you lighter assignments. If this does not align with your professional goals, the first step is to try to get in front of this happening in the first place. When you tell your manager that you are pregnant, come with a loose plan for when you’ll be out on leave and how you intend to transition your work. Reiterate at that moment that it’s important for you to remain engaged and involved in critical work throughout your pregnancy. You need to be sure they understand your goals and ability to commit to projects and new opportunities now, even in the midst of a life change.

If you still feel like it’s happening to you, find an ally in your organization and discuss the best way to approach it. This is a case-by-case scenario and depends largely on the company you work in and the environment, but I usually recommend that women discuss their concerns directly with their managers. And don’t forget to document, document, document! Pregnancy discrimination happens, and it’s always a good idea to have a paper trail of occurrences.

title.en-US: What questions should you ask HR about your maternity leave?

content.value: Answer from Maven Back-To-Work Coach, Mary Beth Ferrante
Use this list to make sure you tackle all the right things.
Ask your HR manager to walk you through your exact maternity leave benefits and how they work in tandem with any state or local benefits provided.

Maternity leave is complicated and often cobbled together based on a bunch of different policies—for instance, vacation time, sick time, paid leave, state-provided bonding time, and unpaid leave. Once you understand what you are entitled to, be sure that you are prepared to actually activate your leave. Create a folder of anyone you will need to notify and any documentation you will need to set things in motion for your departure.
Ask about unpaid leave
and how long your job will be protected while you step away to have a baby.
Ask if you are able to utilize vacation and/or sick leave to take more time off.
A word of advice: Be careful not to use all of this extra time. It’s smart to have some paid time still available to you when you return to work in case of any unforeseen illnesses or events.
Ask about the process of coming back to work.
Do they have any support available for your re-entry (coaching/mentoring, a ramp-up period, flexible work arrangements)?
Ask about communication expectations.

When do they want to hear from you while you’re away? Just before your return, or periodically during your leave? Will they be sharing any departmental updates or information with you while you’re out?
Ask about transitioning your work.

Who is required to be involved in your transition plans, and what will happen to your position while you are gone? Knowing this information will help you have a smoother hand-off—and return to work after leave.

title.en-US: What do I need to do first at work when I become pregnant?

content.value: Answer from Maven Back-To-Work Coach, Mary Beth Ferrante
Being pregnant in the workplace can feel overwhelming. This advice can help you manage everything from announcing your bump to familiarizing yourself with your basic maternity leave rights.
1. Time your announcement right.

Generally, people start to tell friends and family that they’re pregnant as they near the end of their first trimesters. Sharing the news with your boss and coworkers around this same time is often beneficial because your professional and personal networks may overlap, especially on social media. This also gives you and your employer more than enough time to plan for your absence from work. As a general rule, aim to share the news before the rumors start. If you’re dealing with severe morning sickness, if you require any modifications to your work, or if you’re really starting to show, it’s time to share.
2. Tell the boss first.

While you may have close relationships with certain members of your team, you definitely don’t want someone spilling the beans before you’ve had a chance to tell your boss. Depending on your role within the company, your boss may want to get aligned on a plan before sharing it more widely with teammates and business partners, so it’s important to speak with her first. Whether it’s a phone call or a face-to-face meeting, make sure that you schedule a meeting on her calendar rather than popping into her office casually. This sends the message that you realize this is important news that will have an impact on the job. Taking a professional approach now can help assure your boss that you’re going to be a team-player, especially as plans for your coverage get underway.
3. Know what you'll need (and ask for it!).

Do you need any accommodations or changes to your working environment now that you are pregnant? For instance, if your job includes a lot of travel or requires heavy lifting, you may have to work with your employer to make some adjustments. Your needs may change as you get closer to your due date, but make it a point to ask for any immediate needs when you initially share the news. Even asking for time off for doctor’s appointments that are already on the calendar will help your manager keep business running smoothly. As your pregnancy progresses, commit to having an open dialog with your boss.
4. Have a loose plan—and write it down.

Knowing how long you’ll be on leave, if you plan to return, and how your work will be handled while you're out are the key things your boss will want to know. Your plan does not need to be ironclad, but it’s helpful to at least have an outline for how you expect things to go. Be prepared to answer your boss’s questions, even if you simply say: “I'm working on a creating a comprehensive plan for coverage. Right now I’m researching my eligibility for leave benefits, and I have every intention of returning."
5. Educate yourself on your leave benefits.

Leave benefits vary by company and state, so it's up to you to understand exactly what benefits are offered in your location and place of work. As far as countrywide leave initiatives go, the Family Medical Leave Act (FMLA) protects your job for up to 12 weeks. The law doesn’t require that you be paid for that time off; it just requires that your job be waiting for you when you return. Further, you’re only eligible if your employer has more than 50 employees. Some states do have their own laws that supplement the FMLA protections. For instance, they can extend the amount of unpaid leave employers must extend, and several states including California, New Jersey, New York, and Rhode Island offer leave that is partially paid. Bottom line: Be sure you find out exactly what you’re eligible for, and rely on your HR department if you do have questions.

title.en-US: How should you prepare for maternity leave in the 3rd trimester?

content.value: Answer from Maven Back-To-Work Coach, Mary Beth Ferrante

Ideally, you went to your boss earlier in your pregnancy with a loose plan for how you would approach your maternity leave and the time leading up to it. Once you’ve entered your 3rd trimester, however, it’s time to get busy and get detailed. Work with your manager and team to understand exactly how your work will be handled once you deliver the baby. Will your manager be hiring someone to temporarily take over your job, or can you divvy up responsibilities across your teammates?

Whatever the case, you’ll want to make the handing-off of your work as seamless as possible. Think about whether there is anything that only you know how to do. If so, how can you ensure you teach your team to handle these responsibilities while you're gone? Do certain clients rely solely on you? If so, who can you introduce them to so that they have a point of contact?

Share your plan and with your manager and colleagues so you can get their feedback (and buy-in) to help make this a smoother transition. It’s important that your team feels invested in the work and supported in taking on extra duties on top of their normal responsibilities. And be considerate. For example, are there projects you normally take the lead on that you can transition to others before your due date, so that they can get a feel for doing them before you're gone? Are there teammates you can include in your client meetings now so everyone knows each other and will feel more comfortable working together while you’re away?

There's always a fear that if you plan well and ensure your work is handled, people won’t miss you when you're gone and your value as an employee will diminish. But I’m here to tell you that this is not the case! If you leave things unmanaged or don’t have a plan in place, your team may miss you. But more likely, they’ll be frustrated and confused, and will probably be trying to figure out a way to contact you. Leaving everything in a good place is the best way to showcase your abilities and truly shine as a leader. Your manager and team members will truly appreciate the work you put into planning for your leave, and see how committed you are to the goals of your company.

title.en-US: What's the biggest misconception about eating during pregnancy?

content.value: Answer from Maven nutritionist, Melissa Flynn, RD

The biggest misconception about nutrition during pregnancy is that there are many foods expectant women need to avoid. This is not true! Sure, there are a few foods to be careful around, and a few to steer clear of, mainly due to the risk of foodborne illness or high levels of heavy metals. Raw or undercooked meats and seafood, unpasteurized milk and cheese, and high mercury fish such as swordfish, king mackerel, tilefish and shark should all be avoided.

But even with these “don’ts,” there’s plenty of room for variety in your diet. Most cheeses (even soft cheeses) are made from pasteurized milk. So if you’re craving cheese, check the label—if it says that it’s pasteurized, you can safely dig in. Caffeine also does not need to be avoided; 1-2 cups per day is safe for most pregnant women to consume. While it’s true that cold lunch meats are off the table during pregnancy, you can even eat deli meats if they are heated to an internal temperature of 165oF. Isn’t it nice to know you won’t have to eat the same five foods on rotation?

title.en-US: How can you balance pregnancy cravings and healthy eating?

content.value: Answer from Maven nutritionist, Melissa Flynn, RD

While we may not know exactly what causes them, pregnancy cravings are real! And the good news is they can be managed so you can stay satisfied while still keeping your nutrition goals on track. The key is this: When a hankering for a certain food strikes, stop to think about what attributes of that food you are really craving. Do you want something salty? Sweet? Creamy? Crunchy? Tart? Chewy? Once you have figured out what it is about that food you desire, you can come up with a healthier alternative.

The idea isn’t to end up feeling deprived; it’s to make a more nutritious choice the majority of the time. For instance, if you want ice cream, a bowl of greek yogurt with fruit may satisfy your taste for something creamy and sweet. If it’s a salty, crunchy bite you’re after, air-popped popcorn might do the trick—and it’s a better choice than a bag of chips. Indulging in your cravings occasionally is also perfectly fine! (Translation: You don’t have to swear off your favorite fro-yo for nine months.) Just remember to watch the portion size and keep it to the occasional—not daily—treat.

title.en-US: Does your pregnancy diet impact your child's food allergies?

content.value: Answer from Maven nutritionist, Melissa Flynn, RD

Previously it was suggested that women avoid highly allergenic foods when pregnant to reduce the risk of allergies in their children. These foods included cow's milk, peanuts, wheat, and eggs. However, this recommendation is no longer given since it has not been shown to actually reduce or prevent allergies in kids. Consuming a well-balanced diet—including all the healthy foods that you’re not allergic to—is most beneficial for you, and it may actually reduce the risk of allergies in your baby by exposing him to the proteins of these foods in utero through the amniotic fluid. (More research needs to be done in this area.)

As for once your baby is born, research has shown that breastfeeding exclusively for 6 months may reduce the risk of food allergies in infants. Moms do not need to restrict their diet in anyway during this time to reap this potential benefit.

title.en-US: What gestational diabetes myths should be ignored?

content.value: Answer from Maven nutritionist, Melissa Flynn, RD

Gestational diabetes occurs when a woman’s body isn’t able to make and use all the insulin it needs for pregnancy. If left untreated, the condition can expose both a mom and her baby to a high concentration of sugar. So, yes, treatment is crucial. But it’s also important to keep in mind that everything you hear about gestational diabetes might not be true—and separating fact from fiction can spare you from feeling too stressed if you do happen to be diagnosed.
Myth: “It’s your fault that you have it.”

Gestational Diabetes is a metabolic disorder of pregnancy; it can affect any woman, whether she eats exceptionally healthy or not. The fact is, all woman have some degree of insulin resistance as their pregnancy progresses, and half of women who develop gestational diabetes have no known risk factors. (Factors that increase your risk include: being overweight or obese before becoming pregnant; a family history of diabetes; being over age 25; previously giving birth to a baby that weighed more than 9 pounds; being African-American, Hispanic/Latino, Asian-American, American Indian, or Pacific Islander American.)
Myth: “Gestational diabetes is rare.”
In fact, gestational diabetes is a common complication of pregnancy affecting up to 10% of pregnant women every year.
Myth: “It causes diabetes in babies.”

Research shows that most babies won't have diabetes after birth, but they may be somewhat more likely to get type 2 diabetes later in life. Having gestational diabetes does, however, increase the risk of your baby growing too large.
Myth: “Every woman with gestational diabetes has to give herself insulin injections.”

Insulin is a medication that can be used to treat high blood sugar in gestational diabetes, but it isn’t the only treatment option. Management of the condition through diet and exercise is also important, and use of oral medications may be a possibility.

title.en-US: What’s the main source of relationship problems during pregnancy?

content.value: Answer from Mental Health Specialist, Mercedes Samudio, LCSW, MSW

The biggest stressor on relationships during pregnancy is the shifting roles couples experience as they make space for another (tiny) human to enter their lives. Pregnant women tend to feel like they bear all the burden since they are carrying the child, and partners often feel either left out or unable to really be useful. It's important to be honest with each other about your anxieties, fears, expectations, and any other feelings that come up. If you can, try to schedule medical appointments at a time when you’re both able to attend so that you both know how things are progressing and feel more connected to your growing baby.

Another thing that may help is trying to get away periodically during pregnancy. These trips are commonly known as "baby moons,” but they don’t have to be expensive or over the top. Perhaps there is an AirBnB you can rent for a weekend or even a night in a cute town close by; the idea is to get away from your to-do lists and focus on reconnecting with each other before the baby arrives. And when you do find time to connect, try to be open and honest about what you each need. It’s important that one person isn’t taking up all the space in the relationship—in a healthy partnership, there’s room for both of you. If you’re having a hard time getting on the same page and working as a team to truly hear each other and meet each other’s needs, don’t hesitate to get outside support. Maven therapists and relationship coaches are available anytime you’d like to video chat.

title.en-US: Is it normal to resent being pregnant?

content.value: Answer from Mental Health Specialist, Mercedes Samudio, LCSW, MSW

Yes! No matter how many books you read about what to expect or how much you think you know about what carrying a baby will be like, nothing can prepare you for the realities of being pregnant yourself. We often create these fantasies that pregnancy is 100% joyful and beautiful—and for some women it is just that. But for many others, pregnancy can be a medical nightmare, a source of constant fear and worry, or simply a 9-month stretch of too many sleepless nights and inadequate care for your physical and emotional needs. So if you’re resenting pregnancy a little (or a lot), you’re allowed.

Even if you entered the pregnancy as part of your life plan—with or without a partner—it doesn't mean that there won't be any feelings of regret that come up. Bringing a child into the world can be just as scary as actually raising the child. It’s important to recognize that any woman, no matter what her path to pregnancy, is entitled to her emotions. Women who had infertility issues who finally get pregnant can experience regret as well—and should not feel guilty about having these feelings. The most important thing is to know that you are not alone—and that you can reach out for support, whether that’s from a Maven therapist or people in your own network who are encouraging and non-shaming.

title.en-US: What books should pregnant women read?

content.value: Answer from Mental Health Specialist, Mercedes Samudio, LCSW, MSW

First things first: While some parents-to-be find reading about pregnancy helpful, prenatal books aren’t for everyone. Don't be afraid to skip the books in favor of parenting classes, birthing classes, and/or parent groups. Additionally, be aware that your own personality and lifestyle will lead you to the best books for you when you're expecting (and parenting)—so what’s on your friend’s list may not be the most fitting read for you. That said, here are a few books that many expectant parents find helpful—explore them for support and knowledge as you get ready to welcome a child into your family.
Mayo Clinic Guide to a Healthy Pregnancy
A good option if you like a direct approach and appreciate the medical pedigree.
The Baby Bump: 100s of Secrets to Surviving those 9 Long Months
This guide mixes expert advice with tips from moms who have been through pregnancy.
What to Expect When You're Expecting
Disclaimer: You’ll either love it or hate it. Some moms-to-be appreciate knowing everything that could happen during pregnancy; others find it overwhelming.
The Happiest Baby on the Block
Written by a pediatrician, this book teaches sleep advice that promises to troubleshoot all your infant sleep problems.

title.en-US: What should you do if you’re pregnant and hate exercising?

content.value: Answer from Maven Nurse Practitioner, Rebecca Callahan, MSN, WHNP

Even if you don’t feel like it (and trust me, a lot of people don’t), getting your body moving will most likely make you feel better and give you more energy than you had before you started. Research has shown that exercise during pregnancy has benefits like helping with weight management, reducing the risk of gestational diabetes and preeclampsia, making it easier to cope with labor pain and easing childbirth recovery.

If you’re struggling to lace up your gym shoes and get out the door, it’s important to eliminate all the barriers to exercise. For instance, if you tend to feel the most starved for energy in the evening, a morning or midday workout may be the best for you. Figure out the time of day when you are at your “best” and commit to making it happen.

You don’t have to attempt intense workouts—start out really gentle and do activities that make you feel good afterward. Some good options include prenatal yoga videos at home or taking a long stroll in your neighborhood with your partner or your bestie. You can also walk on a treadmill while catching up on your latest Netflix addiction for extra motivation. Or join a prenatal fitness class in your neighborhood; it’s a great way to meet other local moms-to-be!

title.en-US: What’s the best way to exercise during pregnancy?

content.value: Answer from Maven Nurse Practitioner Rebecca Callahan, MSN, WHNP

As long as you don’t have any health or pregnancy complications that exclude you from exercise, pregnant women are advised to get at least 30 minutes of moderate activity each day. Try to include both aerobic and strength-training exercises into your workouts. Some great activities during pregnancy include power walking, swimming, and prenatal yoga.

For those who exercised a lot before getting pregnant, continuing your jogging or virtual spin classes will usually get the green light from your doctor. Just make sure you pace yourself appropriately. If you can't speak normally or carry on a conversation while you're working out, you're probably pushing yourself too hard. Stay well-hydrated and use good judgment. For instance, running outside on the hottest, most humid time of day is not a great idea because you may overheat. You should also avoid activities with a high risk of falling on your belly, like skiing, horseback riding, and (duh) mountain climbing.
One last thing... Working with a pelvic floor physical therapist during pregnancy can go a long way to protecting your pelvic floor health.
Book an appointment
to video chat with one of the physical therapists in Maven’s network, and childbirth and recovery may go a lot more smoothly.

title.en-US: How can you lower your risk of postpartum depression now?

content.value: Answer from Maven Nurse Practitioner, Rebecca Callahan, MSN, WHNP

The last thing you want to think about when you’re expecting is the possibility that your baby’s arrival will coincide with some difficult emotions. Yet baby blues, postpartum depression or anxiety, as well as other mood issues are very common in new moms.

The biggest risk factor for postpartum mood or anxiety disorders (PMADs) is having one of these mood or anxiety conditions during pregnancy. Other risk factors include poor social support, history of traumas, and lack of sleep. During your pregnancy, make sure you pull together a support network that can help you after your baby is born. That can include your partner, parents, family, coworkers, a nanny, etc. As for a difficult past, you cannot go back and undo traumas that have already happened in your life, but I encourage you to seek counseling either with a Maven therapist or offline to help you with any unresolved issues before your baby is here. Therapy after your baby is born is also important.

People often joke about lack of sleep once you have a newborn, but it is nothing to laugh about, and it can have a huge impact on your mood. Get in the habit now of practicing good sleep hygiene, and try to keep it up when your little one arrives. (This includes not perusing Facebook or email in the hour before bed; keeping your bedroom a dark, quiet sanctuary at a comfortable temperature, etc.) And, again, prepare to lean on your partner and support network so you can get some rest in those draining postpartum days.

Ultimately, one of the best things you can do now is to have realistic expectations about what life will be like as a new mom. Getting comfortable with the ups and downs motherhood may throw at you could help you from feeling too overwhelmed later. Perhaps you can pick up habits like meditation and other stress-relieving tools that can be useful now and post-baby.

title.en-US: Need-to-know facts about acupuncture during pregnancy

content.value: Acupuncture, which involves inserting hair-thin needles at various places in the skin to stimulate acupoints, is one of the most popular forms of alternative medicine treatments in the U.S. And many moms-to-be include the healing art in their toolbox to relieve pregnancy symptoms. Here’s what you need to know before getting in on it.
First, is acupuncture safe during pregnancy?
Yes. Always get the green light from your doctor or midwife first, but acupuncture has been shown to be safe for pregnant women.
What are some of the pregnancy symptoms that acupuncture can help with?

Acupuncture designed to treat depression was found to improve symptoms in pregnant women, according to a large study in the journal Obstetrics & Gynecology. Since depression in pregnancy is a risk factor for postpartum depression, experts are always looking for safe ways to address any prenatal mood issues. Acupuncture may also be effective for back pain as well as pelvic pain in pregnancy. While studies showing how well it can help moms-to-be sleep haven’t been done, it has been shown to help with insomnia in in non-pregnant women.
How many treatments will you need?

Acupuncture therapy usually involves a series of weekly or biweekly treatments. But it depends on the severity of your symptoms, and—let’s face it—your budget. Some insurance plans cover acupuncture while others do not. Look into your benefits before you book your first appointment.
Are there any special precautions you need to take during pregnancy?

To make sure you’re in the best possible hands, look for an acupuncturist who’s board-certified by the National Certification Commission for Acupuncture and Oriental Medicine. Even better: Find someone who specializes in treatment during pregnancy, and always tell your provider you’re expecting. That way, he or she can steer clear of acupuncture points that are not recommended during pregnancy.

title.en-US: Itchy belly syndrome during pregnancy and how to stop it

content.value: Right around the second trimester, many moms-to-be feel the urge to scratch their bellies. Find out why it’s happening, and how to deal.
Is an itchy belly normal during pregnancy?
Yes, and while you may feel the itch mostly on your belly, it could also occur on your back and breasts.
What causes it?
The main cause is an increase of blood supply to the skin. But it also has to do with your skin stretching as your belly grows bigger—which is why it’s most common in the second and third trimesters.
What if my palms and the soles of my feet feel itchy?

It could be a sign that you have a condition called cholestasis. With cholestasis, most women feel itchy on the palms of their hands or the soles of their feet, but some women feel intense itching everywhere. “Cholestasis is a serious complication of pregnancy that leads to an increased risk of stillbirth and needs to be treated,” says Jackie Stone, M.D, a Maven OB-GYN. “If you’re experiencing these symptoms, tell your doctor or midwife so that your liver enzymes and bile acids can be checked to rule out or confirm this condition.”
How can you relieve the itchiness?

A thick moisturizer—especially one containing cocoa butter—will likely bring some relief. Soaking in an oatmeal bath can also help. Choose your clothing and undies wisely: Cotton and other non-irritating fabrics are your best bet. Keep in mind, while granny panties might be comfy overall during pregnancy, a band that’s too high on your belly might create extra friction. Lastly, check your laundry detergent to make sure it’s unscented and gentle. If the itch is unbearable or you experience a rash, call your dermatologist or book an appointment with a Maven provider.

title.en-US: 10 rude questions people ask when you're pregnant

content.value: And why you don’t have to answer.

Pregnancy is a highly personal experience, but also a very visible one. As soon as your bump is on display, it can seem like everyone around you—people you know as well as perfect strangers—wants to prod you with questions. The truth is, you are entitled to have a journey as private as you want it to be. And just because someone feels entitled to know the intimate details, even down to the night of conception (!), doesn’t mean you owe anyone an answer.
By all means, share when you want to. But if any of these questions pop up and you’d rather plead the fifth or pretend you didn’t hear it, you’re 100% allowed to do that.
“Was it planned?”
“You’re tiny! How much weight have you gained so far? / You’re huge! How much have you packed on?”
“How long were you trying?”
“Did you get pregnant naturally?”
“Are you going to deliver naturally?”
“Do you have any (gender) preference?”
“Why did you wait so long? / Why so soon?”
“How are you going to handle your career and a baby?”
“Are you going back to work?”
“Are you planning to breastfeed?”

title.en-US: Are vegan or vegetarian diets safe during pregnancy?

content.value: Yes, but...

First, the good news: A 2015 review of 22 observational studies discovered no increase in major birth defects or other serious problems in mom or baby when mothers followed vegan or vegetarian diets during their pregnancies. (It’s important to note, however, that the women in the study were all healthy, and the study authors say more research is needed to see if plant-based eating would be safe for moms-to-be who have certain medical conditions.)

The one caveat? Meal planning isn’t optional—it’s essential—if you’re following a vegan or vegetarian diet. Filling your body with the right balance of nutrients is key for safeguarding your own health and supporting the growth of your baby. If you don’t make a conscious effort to cover all your nutritional bases, you may fall short on certain nutrients that often don’t play a starring role in a vegan diet. A few examples: calcium, iron, omega-3 fatty acids, vitamin B 12 and folate, all of which are found in meat and dairy. That said, a combination of plant-based foods and prenatal vitamins/supplements can usually ensure you’re getting what you need. Dried beans, spinach, and peas, for instance, can provide iron—even if you’re not digging into iron-packed steaks.

If you were vegetarian or vegan before getting pregnant and plan to continue that way of eating throughout these nine months, expert support from a dietician can be very beneficial. Book an appointment with a Maven nutritionist who can help you with everything from creating meal plans and shopping lists to choosing the right supplements.

title.en-US: Vaginal discharge during pregnancy: Normal or not?

content.value: Having more discharge than you’re used to is a pregnancy symptom you might not expect (or want)—but a lot of women experience it. If it’s white and odorless—or at least pretty mild in smell—it’s usually nothing to worry about. But there are a few times when discharge indicates a problem.
What is “normal” discharge?

It’s made up of secretions from the cervix and vagina, and the technical word for it is leukorrhea. Because your body is pumping out more estrogen these days, your discharge might be heavy at times. Translation: (Unscented) panty liners are your friend.
When is discharge something to worry about?

Generally, anytime you see a change in consistency or a surge in volume, it’s worth a call to your OB-GYN or midwife. If the discharge has a foul/fishy odor, and you feel burning or itching, it could be a sign of an infection such as bacterial vaginosis (BV). (You definitely want to let your doctor know if you suspect you have it, because BV during pregnancy is associated with preterm labor/birth and low birthweight.) Another type of discharge that warrants an immediate call to your doctor: amniotic fluid. Keep in mind that you should never leak amniotic fluid unless you’re in labor. You may be wondering how to even recognize the signs that your water has broken and you’re leaking amniotic fluid. Well, if this happens, the discharge won’t be sporadic; instead, the leakage will be continuous and thin like pee (but it doesn’t have the same odor as urine). If your symptoms sound suspicious to your doctor, you’ll likely be instructed to head to the hospital right away.

You’re probably well aware by now that your vagina goes through many changes during pregnancy. If you have any questions and need to talk to someone ASAP, book an appointment with a Maven OB-GYN. Trust us, they’ve seen and heard it all.

title.en-US: How to get enough calcium during pregnancy without dairy

content.value: Luckily, you’re not doomed if cheese, milk, and yogurt aren’t your friends.

Calcium is one of the most important nutrients when you’re expecting; the requirement for pregnant women in the U.S. is 1,000 milligrams a day. But what if you don’t eat dairy—whether because you don’t like it, you follow a vegan diet, or you’re lactose intolerant?

The reality is, no one gets a pass on the requirement. Calcium is crucial for the proper functioning of your circulatory, muscular and nervous systems. And your growing baby needs plenty of calcium for strong bones. It’s so crucial to fetal development that your baby will draw what it needs from your bones if you’re not supplying enough. As Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, MD, explains, “Calcium is actively pumped from the mother's blood across the placenta during pregnancy.”

While dairy products are the best absorbed sources of calcium, there are other ways to meet your quota. Calcium is found in tofu, fortified juices, broccoli, spinach, and other greens, as well as in fish like sardines and salmon. If you’re still coming up short, talk to your doctor about calcium supplements.
Interestingly, experts notes that many women who are lactose intolerant find their ability to digest lactose improves during pregnancy. Talk to your doctor about whether it’s a good idea to (slowly) add dairy to your diet to see if your symptoms have gotten better. Adds Stone: “Lactaid supplements are also safe in pregnancy. This supplement contains the enzyme needed to breakdown the lactose sugar, which allows you to digest lactose—and have dairy!”

title.en-US: The important pregnancy mineral you might not have heard of

content.value: Research shows many women don’t get enough.

Iodine is an important mineral for your baby’s growth and brain development. In fact, a landmark study published in The Lancet in 2013 showed that pregnant women who were deficient in iodine were more likely to have children with learning difficulties. When they followed up with mothers several years postpartum, their eight-year-old children were more likely to have IQ scores in the bottom 25%.

So how much iodine do you need? During pregnancy, the RDA (recommended daily allowance) for iodine increases from 150 mcg per day for nonpregnant women to 220 mcg per day for moms-to-be. It turns out, many expectant women in the U.S. fall short of this recommended amount, even if they don’t show any symptoms of iodine deficiency. Luckily, including a range of iodine-rich foods in your diet can help you meet your quota. Here are some ways to get your fill, according to the National Institutes of Health:
Seaweed (1 gram), anywhere from 16 to 2,984 micrograms of iodine
Cranberries (4 ounces), 400 mcg
Cod, baked (3 ounces), 99 mcg
Low-fat yogurt (1 cup), 75 mcg
Reduced-fat milk (1 cup), 56 mcg
Shrimp (3 ounces), 35mcg
Large egg, 24 mcg
Dried prunes (5), 13 mcg

Have more questions about eating healthy during pregnancy? Maven nutritionists specialize in prenatal dietary needs and can help you make sure you’re getting the right food for you and your growing baby.
Book an appointment
to video chat anytime.

title.en-US: What you need to know about running during pregnancy

content.value: You already know that exercise does a pregnant body good. But you may not know the rules for running with a bump. Read on if you’re thinking about hitting the treadmill or the track.
Is running safe during pregnancy?

If you have an uncomplicated pregnancy, it’s usually perfectly safe to continue your running routine. Of course, you should always get your doctor’s OK before you lace-up your shoes. Certain factors, like preeclampsia or issues with the placenta, will likely mean having to take a break from running as well as other forms of exercise.
Should you start running during pregnancy if you’re weren’t a runner before?

It’s probably not the best idea, since your center of gravity is off during pregnancy. It can also be hard on your body if you don’t ease into it. If you consult with your midwife or OB-GYN and you do get the green light, try a jog-walk method to start in order to avoid putting too much stress on your body.
Can you go at your normal, pre-pregnancy pace?

Only if you can keep up your pace without overexerting yourself or getting overheated. As your pregnancy progresses and your belly grows, however, you’ll probably have to come to terms with the fact that taking breaks to walk or slow it down will be necessary. Another precaution in the first trimester: If you’re vulnerable to morning sickness, pushing your body too hard during exercise may make you even more nauseous. On days when you feel particularly sick, it may be best to take a break. Go easy on yourself—there’s a lot going on in your body during pregnancy, and if you have to take things down a notch (or 20), that’s okay.
Will you have to pee more often while running during pregnancy?

Probably, thanks to increased pressure on your bladder. This is good thing to keep in mind if you’re used to running outside; make sure your route is bathroom-break friendly. Whatever you do, don’t try to drink less water—staying well-hydrated during pregnancy is essential.
Can you run during pregnancy if you’re having multiples?

It depends on your doctor’s evaluation. High impact activities like running put strain on the pelvic muscles that hold your babies in. If your OB-GYN or midwife is concerned about your risk for premature labor, you may have to put running on hold during pregnancy.

title.en-US: What you need to know about anemia during pregnancy

content.value: Is this the reason you’re zombie-level tired? And what can you do about it?
What is anemia?

Your red blood cells have the important job of delivering oxygen throughout your body. If you have anemia, you either don't have enough red blood cells or those cells don't have enough of the iron-rich protein called hemoglobin. While anemia can have many different causes, the most common one is a shortage of iron. Pregnant women are at a higher risk for developing anemia thanks to the excess amount of blood a mom-to-be’s body produces to provide nutrients for the baby.
Is anemia during pregnancy something to worry about?

Not if you address it right away. Anemia during pregnancy can be a mild condition and easily treated if you catch it early on. But there can be serious health risks—both to you and your baby—if you have a more severe form of anemia and let it go untreated. Anemia during pregnancy is associated with premature birth, low birth weight, and maternal mortality.
How will you know if you have it?

If you have a more moderate to severe case, signs like dizziness, fatigue, weakness, and looking pale may clue you in. But in mild cases, you may not show any signs at all. Whether you have symptoms or not, routine blood tests will screen you for anemia during pregnancy.
How do you treat anemia during pregnancy?

There are several types of anemia, so treatment will differ depending on your exact issue. Iron deficiency is the most common cause of anemia in pregnancy, and it’s treated with iron supplements—as well as eating more iron-packed foods. These include dark leafy greens, lean red meat, poultry, beans, peas, and dried fruit. If you have folate-deficiency anemia, your doctor will likely prescribe a daily folic acid supplement and a diet that is rich in this mineral.
If you have more questions about anemia during pregnancy, book an appointment with a Maven nurse practitioner or OB-GYN.

title.en-US: What’s the difference between a push party & a baby shower?

content.value: Thanks, Beyonce and Jay-Z, for making push parties a thing.

Not everyone has the same idea of a good time, and for some women, a baby shower doesn’t exactly spell fun. So what’s an alternative? A push party is like a shower, but with some key differences. First, it’s not a females-only affair. Dad can attend, as well as other male friends and relatives that wouldn’t typically make it onto the invite list for a baby shower.

And while you’re breaking the rules of traditional showers by letting guys in on the fun, feel free to ditch any other “customs” you’re not a fan of either. Pin the diaper on the donkey? Buh-bye. An hour sitting around opening gifts while people make you a ribbon hat? No thanks.

A push party may be a good alternative—but it’s not the only one. A “baby sprinkle” is another party style to consider. It’s usually how parents-to-be approach baby showers for a second child, since they’re already stocked up on a lot of the big-ticket baby gear they were gifted when they had their first. A sprinkle is lower-key, and while guests might bring diapers, books, or small tokens of congrats, the emphasis here isn’t on gifts.

By all means, if a traditional baby shower is your thing, plan one (or let your closest friends organize it for you) and unapologetically enjoy every aspect of it. However, if you’d rather go outside the box and celebrate your soon-to-be baby with a ritual that feels more like you, that’s totally allowed—and, ahem, Beyonce-approved.

title.en-US: Can you donate blood during pregnancy?

content.value: The truth about being a superhero when you’re sporting a bump.
Considering how often you’re getting pricked with a needle during pregnancy, it’s amazing to even wonder if you can be a blood donor during these nine months. But the answer, sadly, is no.

You might think that all the extra blood your body produces during pregnancy—an increase of about 50%—means you have plenty to spare. But the truth is you need every drop to keep you and your baby healthy. Another reason blood-donation and pregnancy don’t mix: Anemia is common when you’re carrying a baby, and if you’re anemic, losing even a small amount of blood can take a significant toll on your body.

Once you have your baby, you’ll be able to donate again—even while you’re breastfeeding. But the American Red Cross states that in the US, you have to wait at least six weeks after birth to be eligible to give blood. As Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, MD, points out, “this gives your body time to recover from blood lost during childbirth.”

title.en-US: 7 things you need to know about hiking during pregnancy

content.value: Exploring the great outdoors can be exhilarating, mind-clearing, and stress-relieving—all while helping you get your recommended dose of cardio during pregnancy. But there are some rules to keep in mind if you’re thinking about hitting the trails when you have a bump.
Get your doctor’s OK to hike for two.
While most moms-to-be are cleared for hiking, complicated pregnancies and other health conditions could require staying away from the trails.
Wear the right footwear.

Make sure you head out in hiking shoes that are supportive and have the appropriate traction. If you’re a beginner going out on an easy hike, you can find shoes that are basically a cross between a regular sneaker and a hiking boot (this way, you can get more mileage out of your purchase even on non-hiking days). One we like: New Balance Women's WT690V1 Trail Shoe, available on Amazon.
Heights matter.
If you’re thinking about an adventure with an aggressive elevation, talk to your doctor first to make sure your plan is safe for your pregnancy.
The rockier the terrain, the riskier.
Remember, changes to your center of gravity during pregnancy can make you wobblier than usual. An even terrain will help you keep your balance.
Don’t go off the grid.
Keep your hikes to locales that have cell phone service. Better yet: Also bring a buddy with you. In case you start to feel unwell, or there’s an emergency, you’ll be able to get the care you need.
Pack a buffet with you.
Water! Snacks! More water! Getting adequate hydration—and sustenance—is essential.
Make sure you have a plan for bathroom breaks.
Because, hey, all that hydration has to go somewhere.

title.en-US: Sneaky sources of sugar to avoid during pregnancy

content.value: You already know the obvious sources of added sugars—candy, cupcakes, chocolate, etc. But there is also sugar lurking in foods and drinks you may not expect. The problem with a little sugar here and a little sugar there is that it all adds up—and too much of the white stuff can derail you from your healthy eating goals during pregnancy. Besides, wouldn’t you rather “save” your sugar calories for a worth-it piece of pie instead of blowing your intake on...
Pasta sauce

It looks like mashed-up innocent tomatoes, but jarred spaghetti sauce is notorious for sneaking in the white stuff. One popular brand packs 20 grams of sugar in one cup—that’s equal to a Snickers bar.
Peanut and other nut butters
If the ingredients label includes cane sugar or corn syrup, skip it. Natural options are a better bet.
Lemonade

You know lemonade is sweet, but you might think it’s at least a better option than a can of soda, right? With 40 grams of sugar in a 12-oz can, it’s basically a coke. Make your own with less sugar, or go halfsies: half lemonade, half unsweetened iced-tea.
Bottled salad dressing
You’d never pour a bowl of ice cream over your chopped salad, but the truth is some bottled dressings pack 20 grams of sugar in a 1-ounce serving.
Dried Fruits
Fruit is already sweet, but a lot of the dried stuff out there includes added sugar. When this is the case, you’re no longer eating produce—it’s candy.

title.en-US: Is driving risky while pregnant?

content.value: It’s probably not a question you’ve thought to ask your doctor when running down a list of “is it safe during pregnancy?” concerns. But it turns out, it should be.

A few years ago, a team of researchers in Canada decided to see if pregnancy affected a woman’s driving and accident risk. After all, they theorized, certain realities of pregnancy might make moms-to-be more vulnerable behind the wheel. Fatigue, mental distractions, and hormonal changes don’t exactly make you feel like the sharpest version of yourself.

So how did they execute the study? First, they collected the medical records of over 500,000 mothers in Ontario. Then they analyzed the data to compare moms’ accident rates before and after pregnancy to see if there was any difference.

Before pregnancy, the average was about 4.6 crashes per 1,000 women. Compare that to data from women in their second trimester of pregnancy, where the average was 7.7 crashes per 1,000 women. What this means: Women run a 42% increased risk of being in a car accident when they’re in their second trimester. (In the study, the risk resolved by the third trimester and after birth—perhaps because women acclimated to the physical changes of pregnancy and became more cautious drivers.)

The lesson here isn’t to avoid driving. It’s simply to drive a little more carefully and minimize distractions. The good news is that that the study authors say that moms could have avoided these accidents with just a little more focus and caution behind the wheel.

title.en-US: The health benefits of orange foods during pregnancy

content.value: Sorry moms-to-be, we don’t mean Cheetos.

While you’ve probably heard about some important nutrients during pregnancy—iron, calcium, and folate, to name a few—you may not be familiar with beta-carotene. Beta-carotene is the powerful antioxidant that gives certain orange fruits and vegetables their brilliant color. Your body converts beta-carotene to vitamin A, which is a key player in pregnancy nutrition. For one, research has shown that vitamin A is essential for fetal eye formation. And besides the vision connection, vitamin A also plays an role in the development of your baby’s bones, teeth, and skin. In other words, if you include beta-carotene rich foods into your diet, your baby will reap lots of benefits.

Interestingly, getting too much preformed vitamin A (like from supplements) during pregnancy is a concern, because in high doses it can be associated with health risks including birth defects. So getting your vitamin A in the form of beta-carotene found in fruits and vegetables is preferred. “In contrast to preformed vitamin A, beta-carotene is not toxic even at high levels of intake,” according to the Harvard School of Public Health.

As for the orange foods that provide the nutrient, beta-carotene is abundant in carrots, sweet potatoes, squash, pumpkins, orange bell peppers, apricots, cantaloupe and papaya. But you can also get a healthy dose by eating other colorful produce. Mangoes, yellow squash, yellow and red bell peppers, tomatoes, radishes and watermelon are all good options. Yep, another reason to eat the rainbow.

title.en-US: 5 foods that help you stay hydrated during pregnancy

content.value: Hydration is important for a host of reasons that include building new tissue, carrying nutrients to your baby, easing constipation, and even decreasing the risk of preterm labor. No wonder pregnant women are encouraged to get a whopping 10 cups of fluids each day. It's important to drink plenty of H20, but you can stay extra hydrated with certain foods that are high in water weight. Here are five that top the list, and tasty snack ideas that will make you want to reach for them more often.
Zucchini: 95% water

Snack idea: Take a cup or two of spiralized zucchini noodles and toss in a bowl (uncooked) with a little bit of olive oil and lemon juice, plus a pinch of salt and pepper. Optional: Top with fresh shavings of parmesan (a pregnancy-safe cheese!).
Cucumbers: 96.7% water
