Snack idea: Make a simple dip of plain Greek yogurt with fresh dill, then spread over individual cucumber slices.
Cantaloupe: 90% water
Snack idea: Cut a cantaloupe into 2-inch-thick slices. Heat up a grill, and once hot, add cantaloupe slices directly onto grill, grilling for 1 to 2 minutes on each side.
Celery: 95.4% water
Snack idea: It doesn’t get better than the classic peanut butter boats; simply spread some PB inside a few celery ribs and dig in.
Watermelon: 91.5% water

Snack idea: Here’s a yummy watermelon strawberry smoothie. In a blender, combine 2 cups diced watermelon (seedless), 1 cup frozen strawberry slices, and the juice of one lime. Then add 1⁄4 cup of unsweetened coconut milk and give it a buzz until smooth. Cheers!

title.en-US: Will having a baby help you live longer? What the science says

content.value: The perk of parenthood you might not expect

Almost every mom-to-be has that moment when pregnancy symptoms become a little too uncomfortable or when the stress of it all becomes overwhelming. So it’s nice when science shows up with some happy news to remind you that becoming a parent has its plus sides—besides, you know, that whole endless love for your offspring thing. Get this: Motherhood could boost your chances of living longer in your later years.

Using Swedish census data from over 1.4 million men and women, researchers found that once they hit 60, both men and women have a longer life expectancy if they had at least one child. Dads were expected to live 2 years longer than childless men at age 60, while moms were expected to live 1.5 years longer than non-mothers. By age 80, fathers were expected to live about 9 months longer and mothers about 7 months longer than non-parents. Parents had a longer life expectancy regardless of the gender of their kids, and regardless of whether they were single parents or married.

Researchers don’t yet know why this association between children and longevity exists, but it may have to do with a few factors. Perhaps having kids affects your lifestyle choices and inspires healthier habits, like ditching smoking. And having children tends to force you into more social interactions (for instance, with other parents)—and a greater sense of community and lack of isolation may also have a positive impact on extending your years. Whatever the reason, on those days when you find yourself saying, “this kid will be the death of me,” it can be good to remind yourself that the opposite may be true.

title.en-US: The truth about high cholesterol during pregnancy

content.value: A pregnant woman’s cholesterol levels can increase by 25 to 50 percent. But how much should you panic? Read on for the answers.
Why is your cholesterol higher now than it was before you got pregnant?

Pregnancy can naturally cause cholesterol levels to rise—usually in the second and third trimesters. Unless your OB-GYN or midwife determines that your cholesterol levels put you or your growing baby at an increased risk for health complications, this is normal and you don’t need to worry.
Why do cholesterol levels tend to rise during pregnancy?

Cholesterol is required to make certain hormones that are important for pregnancy and fetal development. Your baby’s brain and limbs actually rely on this surplus of cholesterol (which enters the placenta), so your body makes sure it’s available.
Does this mean you get to load up on cholesterol-producing foods when you’re expecting?

No. Your liver naturally provides for your cholesterol needs during pregnancy. Overdoing it could lead to unhealthy cholesterol levels that put your well-being at risk. According to the Mayo Clinic, some of the worst offenders for cholesterol include trans fats, often used in margarines, cookies, crackers and cakes.
When do cholesterol levels return to normal?
Usually 4 to 6 weeks after giving birth. Be sure to stick to your postpartum check-ups with your doctor to make sure everything is back on track.

title.en-US: 3 easy but effective pool exercises for pregnancy

content.value: Working out in water has lots of perks for pregnant women, including decreasing the impact on joints, improving circulation, and improving flexibility. Not to mention, have you ever not felt a little happier and less stressed after a dip? You can, of course, get a great workout with a simple doggy paddle or freestyle swim stroke. But if you’re looking for a few exercises to keep things interesting and fun, here are a few moves to add to your pool workout. (Just get your doctor’s OK to exercise before you dive in.)
Water jacks

Water makes high-impact jumping jacks much more joint-friendly. Start with your feet flat on the bottom of the pool, hip-width apart, and your arms relaxed by your sides. Simultaneously raise your arms out to the sides and over your head, and jump your feet out so they are slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Reverse the movement and continue these jacks for about a minute (it’s OK to take breaks if you need to and stop if you get winded).
Flutter kicks

Holding on to the edge of the pool or a paddleboard, flutter kick your legs behind you. Your goal should be to avoid splashing; keep your legs under water the whole time and focus on moving them faster instead of higher.
Leg swings

Stand with your right hand on the pool edge and your left hand extended overhead. Sweep your left leg forward (aim to get it up to hip height, but it’s OK to keep it a little lower if that’s too challenging). Then sweep your left leg behind you. Continue this movement for 30 seconds. Switch legs, and repeat.

title.en-US: Restless legs syndrome during pregnancy

content.value: Between 15 to 25% of women get restless leg syndrome during pregnancy. Here’s what you need to know about the condition—and how to cope.
What is restless legs syndrome?

Restless legs syndrome (RLS) is a condition that causes a strong and unpleasant urge to move your legs. It typically happens in the evening hours when you're sitting for an extended period of time or lying down—and it can easily disrupt sleep. Moving your legs or stretching seems to ease the unpleasant sensation temporarily.
What’s the pregnancy connection?

According to the Mayo Clinic, hormonal changes during pregnancy may bring on RLS even if you’ve never had it before. And if you were previously diagnosed, your symptoms may temporarily worsen, especially during the later trimesters. The good news is things should resolve after you give birth.
What should you do if you have it?

Sometimes RLS is sometimes a sign of low iron; if your doctor determines that to be the case, she’ll work with you to make sure you meet your requirements for the mineral. Otherwise, your best bet is to turn to lifestyle changes. Soaking your legs in warm water before bed and massaging them (ask your partner to get involved) can help. And sometimes cutting back or eliminating caffeine also makes a difference.

title.en-US: Is using pesticides during pregnancy unsafe?

content.value: How to deal with bugs when you’ve got a bump.

According to the CDC, it’s not known what levels of exposure to pesticides are safe during pregnancy, so the best approach is to limit your contact with these chemicals as much as possible. Exposure to pesticides could increase your chances of having a miscarriage, a baby with birth defects, or other problems.

If you must treat your home or yard with pesticides while you’re expecting, take some cautionary steps. Avoid entering areas where pesticides have been sprayed for at least a few hours. Instead of spraying the entire backyard, spray only the areas where the chemicals are needed. If your partner is walking through the yard or around the garden after pesticides were applied, ask him or her to go shoes-off before entering the house; pesticides can be carried into the home via shoes and even clothing. And if you garden, wearing gloves is a must.
Lastly, if pest control has to treat the inside of your home (ick, but it happens), this would definitely be a good time to make it a spa day or even stay at a family member’s house for the night.

title.en-US: What’s up with all these nosebleeds during pregnancy?

content.value: As if being pregnant wasn’t dramatic enough, sometimes there’s a sudden rush of blood out of your nose to add to all the “excitement.” Here’s what’s happening, and how to stop it.
Your nose has a ton of blood vessels, and thanks to an increase in blood volume circulation through your body, these vessels are more prone to burst during pregnancy.

It can happen randomly, but some factors may trigger a gush. If you live in a very dry climate, for instance, or the heat inside your home or office is turned way up in winter, you may be more likely to have a nosebleed. That’s because excessively dry air can create tiny cracks in your nose’s membranes which injure these blood vessels. Even blowing your nose too hard can turn things a bit, well, red.

So what can you do? If dryness is an issue, try to keep a humidifier on to keep moisture in the air around you; this may prevent nosebleeds from happening in the first place. You can also keep the lining of your nose moist with a dab of petroleum jelly (especially at bedtime). If you do get a nosebleed, make sure you lean forward (your instinct may be to lean back, but this will cause you to swallow blood). Then pinch your nostrils shut and hold them closed for 10 to 15 minutes to slow down and stop the blood flow. Continue breathing in and out through your mouth as you do this. If the bleeding doesn’t stop, call your doctor.

title.en-US: Is it OK to wear Spanx during pregnancy?

content.value: Some moms-to-be (and pregnant celebs) swear by wearing shapewear during pregnancy, especially for special events. But how safe is it to wear constricting garments while you're expecting?

Even when you aren’t pregnant, wearing shapewear that’s too restrictive or the wrong size can leave your stomach and intestines compressed, and even trigger heartburn. No wonder some women say they end up with abdominal discomfort, bloating and gas after spending too many hours in too-tight shapewear.

These discomforts are never fun, but they can be especially miserable during pregnancy. While there isn’t a definitive ruling from medical experts on shapewear during pregnancy, you might want to limit your Spanx-wearing to special occasions. (Side note: Your pregnant figure is perfectly shaped just as it is—so if you’d never think of wearing body armor over your bump, we’re 100% in support of that, too.) And don’t be tempted to go for a smaller size—always pick shapewear that fits you.

Even if you’re buying maternity shapewear that’s specifically designed for a pregnant woman’s body, test it to make sure you don’t feel overly compressed. Here’s a clue: You should still be able to breathe.

title.en-US: Is it a good idea to drink smoothies during pregnancy?

content.value: Let’s talk about the plus-sides and the risks.

Slurping fruit/veggie-packed smoothies can be a great way of giving your body (and your baby) the nutrients it needs. What’s more, smoothies tend to have more fiber than juices, since they’re typically a blend of whole foods. Before you down them every day, here’s what you need to know.
First, who might want to reach for them?

Liking the taste of smoothies is enough of a reason to have one for breakfast. But if you go days without eating anything green, or stopping to have a full meal with a knife and fork takes a lot of effort for you, then smoothies can be especially helpful for you, ensuring that you get adequate nutrition. And if you have any lingering morning sickness issues in the second trimester and the sight of a salad makes you ill, smoothies may be a godsend.
So when are smoothies not a great idea?

Well, according to the FDA, there have been foodborne illness outbreaks associated with drinking smoothies that were made with unpasteurized juice. Pasteurization is a process that kills any potentially harmful bacteria lurking on your fruits and veggies; bottled varieties are usually pasteurized but smoothies that are made at your local health food store/specialty shop, farmer’s market, or at home using a juicer can contain unpasteurized juice. The lesson: Be sure any made-to-order smoothies don’t contain any unpasteurized ingredients.

That said, store-bought smoothies don’t always come with a nutritional halo, either. To be certain your drink isn’t being sabotaged by too many unhealthy additives, read the label and watch out for excess sugar or other sweeteners, as well as too much fat (like from overdoing it on the nut butters that are mixed in).
The bottom line:
If you sip smart and follow these guidelines, smoothies can definitely have a place in a healthy pregnancy diet.

title.en-US: The difference between binge eating and pregnancy cravings

content.value: How to tell when overeating is a problem.

It’s common to have cravings when you’re expecting, and most women are even encouraged to eat a few hundred extra calories per day during pregnancy. So if you’re noticing some extra snack attacks these days, that’s normal. But where do you draw the line between normal mom-to-be indulgences and disordered eating?

Binge eating disorder isn’t just having an another serving of spaghetti with dinner or an extra slice of cake for dessert. It’s when you’re driven to eat large amounts of food, often quickly (or in secret), and possibly to the point of feeling sick. What’s more, binge eating disorder is often accompanied by intense sense of shame and self-loathing afterward.

While research shows that some women with a history of binge eating see their symptoms cease during pregnancy, others don’t. Further, some moms-to-be develop binge eating disorder for the first time during pregnancy.

How binge eating can affect your pregnancy and your baby is still being studied. One concern is that binge eating may be associated with excessive weight gain in pregnancy—and we know that women who gain too much weight are more prone to gestational diabetes themselves as well as increasing the risk of having a big baby or delivering prematurely.

Dealing with eating disorders is never easy, so if you’re struggling, it’s important not to beat yourself up. The best thing you can do is seek support. Maven OB-GYNs and mental health counselors are available to chat with you and help you develop a plan that keeps you and your baby safe.

title.en-US: 3 ingredients never to put in your salad if you’re pregnant

content.value: For once, croutons aren’t the ultimate bad guy at the salad bar. But there are some other offenders that experts say shouldn’t make it onto your plate.
Sprouts

According to the Mayo Clinic, pregnant women should skip raw sprouts of any kind. These include alfalfa, clover, radish and mung bean, to name a few. The sprout seeds harbor the bacteria, and as they grow, the bacteria can multiply quickly. Experts urge women to make sure sprouts don’t sneak into their bowls at the salad bar.
Caesar dressing

Caesar dressing is one of those iffy salad add-ins: some recipes call for raw egg yolks, while others don’t. And pregnant women are urged to avoid eating anything that contains raw or undercooked eggs. Your best bet at a restaurant or salad bar is to skip the Caesar dressing. As for the supermarket shelf, check the label to make sure it’s either free of eggs or, if it does have eggs, clearly states that they’re pasteurized.
Lox

Smoked fish can be tricky; does it fall into the category of cooked (allowed) or raw (not allowed)? According to the Food and Drug Administration, smoked seafood shouldn’t be eaten during pregnancy unless it's in a cooked dish, such as a casserole. As the CDC notes, lox can contain listeria since the smoking process may not heat the food at temps high enough to kill the bacteria. Sadly, that spinach and smoked salmon salad from your favorite lunch spot will have to wait until after your little one arrives.

title.en-US: The one wardrobe update you definitely need during pregnancy

content.value: News flash: Your breasts are going to grow and change a lot over these nine months. You may go up a size or two—and when that happens, wearing your pre-pregnancy sports bras for a jog or your prenatal yoga class will be a recipe for discomfort. Here’s how to keep the girls happy and supported.
At what point during your pregnancy should you buy new sports bras?

As with all things pregnancy, every woman is different. Some moms-to-be don’t need new bras until the second or third trimester, while others outgrow their regular bras soon into the first trimester. Whenever things start to feel uncomfortable, it’s time to shop.
What should you look for when buying maternity sports bras?

First, you don’t need to buy a bra that is meant specifically for a pregnant woman. In fact, you’ll have more options—and can probably find a better deal—if you don’t. Look for a sports bra with wide straps. Straps that are too thin can put too much pressure on your neck and shoulders and make chafing inevitable. A racerback is also ideal for evenly distributing the weight of the breasts. And skip the underwires; a wire-free bra will be more comfortable and forgiving as your rib cage expands. Lastly, you’ll get the most mileage out of a bra with a couple of rows of hooks so that it can be adjusted if you go up another size or more.

title.en-US: Why you may get carpal tunnel syndrome during pregnancy

content.value: You know all that fluid retention during pregnancy that makes your feet swell to the size of Michigan? Well, it could also be to blame for your hand and wrist problems.
How does carpal tunnel syndrome happen?

Quick science lesson: Your median nerve is a nerve that runs from your forearm through a passageway in your wrist (aka your “carpal tunnel”) to your hand. When pregnant women retain fluid, they may experience increased pressure within the carpal tunnel, causing the median nerve to become compressed. Since the median nerve provides sensation to the palm side of your thumb and most of your fingers, you may feel the area go numb or get tingly. You may even feel a fair amount of pain at times. The good news is that if you do develop carpal tunnel syndrome during pregnancy, it typically resolves on its own right after you give birth.
What can you do if you get this condition?

Try to keep your hand and wrist as relaxed as possible, especially if your work involves typing away way at a computer all day or any other repetitive hand movements. And take regular breaks to gently stretch your hands and wrists. Interestingly, working in an environment with cold air circulating may increase the stiffness in your wrists, making the condition more irritating. Fingerless gloves might look a little silly, but if it’s frigid in your office, they can help keep your hands warm and stave off discomfort.

Another tool some find helpful: wearing a brace (you can find one at your local pharmacy), especially to bed. If the pain is intolerable, ask your doctor or talk to a Maven provider about other solutions, including any OTC pain medication that might be safe for you to take.

title.en-US: One bizarre skin change caused by pregnancy

content.value: It goes by the name “linea nigra”—and it looks freakier than it actually is.
What is the linea nigra?

If you’ve started to notice a dark line running from your belly button down to your pubic bone, that’s your linea nigra. (For some moms-to-be, the line extends all the way up to just under their breasts.) It’s very common, and usually appears sometime in the first or second trimester, getting darker as your pregnancy progresses.
Why does this skin change happen?

While we don’t know for sure what causes it, one theory is that it has to do with a woman’s fluctuating hormones during pregnancy. Hormones can cause your body to make excess melanin, a compound responsible for giving your skin pigment (which is why your nipples may also appear darker).
Is there anything you can do to prevent it?

Sadly, no. But for most women the line usually fades within a year after giving birth. We’re all for proudly showing off your bump in a bikini, but it’s a good idea to keep your belly covered at the beach. Exposing your skin to the sun can make the line more pronounced.

title.en-US: The truth about second trimester dizziness

content.value: A common complaint among women in the middle of their pregnancy journey is constant dizziness. Here’s what’s happening and how to cope.
What’s to blame for the spins?

Well, as your uterus grows, it puts more pressure on your blood vessels. Meanwhile, to help nourish your baby, your heart is also pumping more blood than usual and beating faster. All these changes combined can cause you to feel faint or light-headed.
What can you do if you tend to feel dizzy during pregnancy?

Self-care, once again, can go a long way. Be sure to not let too much time go in between meals/snacks, and stay hydrated. (Dehydration can make you lightheaded.) Avoid sudden movements—like jumping out of bed too quickly, or standing abruptly if you’ve been sitting for a while.
When should you see a doctor?

Dizziness on its own usually isn’t cause for alarm, but if it’s accompanied by certain other symptoms, call your doctor right away to rule out a more serious problem. If you’re experiencing vaginal bleeding, severe abdominal pain, blurred vision, or heart palpitations along with the dizzy spells, alert your provider right away or get to the ER.

title.en-US: Is this vitamin a magic cure for morning sickness?

content.value: There’s no magic pill that cures everyone’s morning sickness. But there are plenty of remedies you can try and that might work for you. When it comes to the vitamin aisle, your best bet may be B6, which has been shown to reduce early pregnancy nausea for some women.
What is Vitamin B6?

Vitamin B6 is made up of six different compounds that promote a healthy immune system, nerve function, and formation of red blood cells. Vitamin B6 is water-soluble, which means it dissolves in water and other bodily fluids, so whatever your body doesn’t use gets excreted in urine instead of stored in the body.
Is supplementing with B6 safe during pregnancy?

Usually, yes. Your doctor may recommend taking 25 mg of vitamin B6 three times a day. This is considered a safe level, but be sure you know how much B6 is in your prenatal vitamin and discuss it with your doctor before you start supplementing. High doses of vitamin B6 over a long period of time may cause nerve damage, leading to numbness and loss of control of bodily movements.
Are there any foods that provide the vitamin?

Yes, and the good news is that vitamin B6 from food sources have not been reported to cause adverse effects. Chickpeas, lentils, kidney beans, and other beans and legumes are rich in B6. Nuts and seeds, certain fruits such as bananas or papayas, fish, and lean meats are also good sources of the vitamin.

title.en-US: Is it safe to eat hot dogs during pregnancy?

content.value: Let’s tackle frankfurter fear. (Because, barbecues.)

Good news: You don’t have to deprive yourself. But whether or not you can enjoy your favorite BBQ food depends on who’s doing the grilling, and how well they’re cooking your dog. According to the FDA, hot dogs can be contaminated with Listeria after they have been processed and packaged at the plant.
What’s the big deal about Listeria?

Listeria, a harmful type of bacteria, can cause an infection called listeriosis. Before you were pregnant, getting listeriosis from an undercooked hot dog may have led to an uncomfortable night of food-poisoning symptoms. But now that you’re expecting, the fallout could be much more serious. Listeriosis has been associated with pregnancy complications including stillborn births, preterm delivery, and birth defects.
So what’s the safe way to eat a hot dog?
Make sure it’s cooked to at least 165°F. If you don’t have a thermometer, slice it open and make sure it’s steaming inside before you dig in.

title.en-US: Eat these foods now, protect your baby from asthma later

content.value: A few specific foods from the produce aisle may be the best preventative medicine around.

No mother likes to see her little one wheezing or struggling to catch a breath. Well, every time you dig into a spinach salad for lunch or a green smoothie, you may be offering your unborn baby some early asthma protection.

Get this: A 2018 study from the National Research Institute for Child Health and Development in Tokyo found that pregnant women who consumed green vegetables during the first trimester helped prevent asthma in their kids. Regularly eating broccoli, spinach, cabbage, sprouts or kale led to having babies who were 52% less likely to suffer from wheezing by the age of two.

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 6.1 million kids under age 18 years currently have asthma in the U.S. No one knows exactly why asthma is so prevalent, but scientists are constantly researching new ways to address the—sometimes serious—problem. Sad but true: One in six children with asthma may have an attack that puts them in the emergency department or urgent care.

title.en-US: 3 yoga poses with benefits every pregnant woman needs

content.value: Yes, exercise can be soothing during pregnancy. Here are three yoga poses that will bring you more "ahh" and less “ouch.” As always, check with your doctor first before trying any new workout routine while you’re expecting, then get started.
Modified Extended Side Angle Pose
The benefits: Helps strengthen your legs and entire body (you’ll need the stamina for childbirth!). Plus it can reduce swelling in your ankles and feet.

Start from a lunge position with your left foot forward. (To get into a lunge, stand tall with feet hip-width apart, then take a big step forward with your left leg. Your left knee should be bent and either directly over or behind your ankle.) Next, turn your right heel down to the floor so your foot and toes at a 45-degree angle. Then, place your left elbow above your left knee (rest it lightly) and extend your right arm up overhead, trying to keep your bicep by your ear, and hold for a few breaths. Then repeat on the opposite side.
Yoga Squat
The benefits: Helps release tension in your hips and lower back.

Separate your feet about hip-width apart and come into a squat. (As your bump grows, you may need to separate your feet further apart to give your belly more space.) If your heels don’t reach the floor, fold a blanket underneath your heels for support. Bring your palms together in front of your chest so you can use your elbows to gently push against the inside of your knees to open up the hips. Try to hold this position for about 30 seconds. You should feel a nice stretch, but if it gets too intense or the weight of your uterus is getting heavy to support, back off and try a modification: Do the same squat sitting on a yoga block or a few piled-up folded blankets. And if you have any risks for preterm labor, skip the squat unless you get your doctor’s OK first.
Legs-up-the-wall pose

Benefits: For one, it will seriously chill you out; it’s considered a mild inversion, which means it helps your nervous system shift out of an anxious flight-or-flight mode. It can also help reduce swelling in the ankles and feet.

Grab a blanket and fold it a few times until you have a firm, supportive cushion. Place your folded blanket about 6 to 12 inches away from the wall. Sit sideways on the right end of the blanket, with your right side facing the wall. Then, with one smooth movement, swing your legs up onto the wall and let your shoulders and head fall gently down onto the floor. Close your eyes if you’d like, and stay in this position for 5 to 10 minutes—or longer if you have the time and like the feeling of being totally blissed out.

title.en-US: What's a quad screen during pregnancy?

content.value: As you’re thinking about the next several months of your pregnancy journey, you may be wondering how much more poking and prodding you’ll have to endure. While we can’t promise you there won’t be any more needles, we can help you know what to expect. Here’s the 411 on a common second trimester test.
What is the quad screen?

The Quad Screen is a blood test, usually given between the 15th and 20th weeks of pregnancy, that checks the levels of four substances in your blood. Ready for a quick science lesson? The test measures alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), a protein made by your baby; human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), a hormone made by the placenta; unconjugated estriol (uE3), a hormone produced by the placenta and your baby; and inhibin A, a hormone produced by the placenta. Testing these levels helps your doctor determine whether your baby has an increased chance of being born with certain problems with the brain and spinal cord (called neural-tube defects) as well as chromosomal abnormalities such as Down’s syndrome.
Does everyone need quad screening?

No. “If a patient has had cell free fetal DNA testing or first trimester screening, then she will not need quad screening,” says Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone M.D. “In that case, a woman could be given only the part of the quad test that screens for neural tube defects in the second trimester.” What’s more, anyone can choose to opt out of any screening for genetic conditions such as Down’s syndrome.

Make sure that you and your doctor have talked about why you might want to consider genetic testing and what you will do in the event that you receive results you weren’t hoping for. It’s natural to want to avoid such conversations, but part of being an empowered patient means knowing why these tests are given in the first place.
Will the results tell me definitively if my baby has a problem?
No. They only reveal the possibility of a problem—which is why the results shouldn’t immediately send you into a panic.
Is the test harmful?

No, there are no risks to you or your baby. If the results indicate that further testing is good idea, you may be given the option to have an amniocentesis. Unlike the quad screen, which isn’t diagnostic, amniocentesis can tell you if your baby does or doesn’t have a chromosomal condition. But it is more invasive than a quad screen and therefore carries more risks.

title.en-US: Pop quiz: What’s the most common time of day to give birth?

content.value: Yes, apparently childbirth has its own prime time.

Even if you’re months away from giving birth, you may be wondering what to expect. Will you give birth at work, in the middle of the workday? Or will contractions start when you’re sitting down to breakfast in the morning? Of course, no one can predict exactly when or how the birth of your baby will go down, but a recent study does offer a fun insight.

Researchers at University College London looked at 5 million births between 2005 and 2014 to find out when babies are most likely to be born. When it came to spontaneous labor births, more babies made their debuts into the world between 1 AM and 7 AM than any other times of day. The peak time? 4 AM!

The lead study author offered an evolutionary explanation for all these middle-of-the-night births: Our ancestors likely spent their daytime hours active and dispersed (i.e. out there hunting and gathering). But they came together at night to rest. So giving birth at night may have offered a mother and her newborn baby some protection.

Ultimately, whether you give birth at 4 AM or 4 PM, you deserve the best care. Researchers hope that increased knowledge about birth trends will help providers anticipate women’s needs and deliver better healthcare during childbirth.

title.en-US: The "doorknob phenomenon"—and how it can affect you

content.value: Find out why this way of communicating with your doctor can backfire.

By definition, the doorknob phenomenon is when a patient waits until the last moment—when her physician or midwife is grabbing the doorknob to exit the room—to mention something important or give critical insight to her provider.

The outcome of doing this, of course, is that your doctor may not have the time to give your sudden revelation the thorough attention it deserves. And waiting until your next visit to address your “doorknob statement” may put your health at risk, especially if what you’ve decided to utter at the last minute would benefit from timely care.

Doctors say the reasons for patients’ “doorknob statements” vary. It may be that a woman has talked herself out of mentioning something because she’s scared, but finally gets the courage at the end. Or else she is embarrassed or just wants to downplay the issue in her own mind. But think of it this way: When an OB-GYN is walking out the door and a mom-to-be drops a bombshell like, “Oh by the way—I sometimes feel a very sharp pain in my abdomen,” that’s not going to foster an ideal healthcare experience.

The way around this? Make a list of things you want to address with your doctor before each appointment, and prioritize it from most to least important. Ab pain, bleeding, etc. would be at the top—and, for instance, an occasional bout of pregnancy constipation would go below the bigger issues.

Ultimately, you want to partner with your providers on making sure you get your needs met. But if you do ever find that you’re too rushed in an appointment and have questions that have gone unaddressed, don’t hesitate to book an appointment with a Maven provider.

title.en-US: Is it safe to paint your baby’s nursery while pregnant?

content.value: Read this before you break open that can of pastel yellow.

Disclaimer: This is one of those topics that doesn’t exactly give women the straightforward advice they’re looking for. That said, there are a few things you should be aware of before designating yourself chief designer/painter of your baby’s room.

The first thing to know? Before the late 1970s, most paint contained lead. If you’re renovating an older house that was painted in the lead-based-paint days, definitely ask someone else to scrape the paint off the wall. As for oil-based paints: These may expose you to VOCs (volatile organic compounds) while the paint is drying, and it’s best to avoid these potentially harmful compounds while pregnant. A safer alternative is a water-based (latex) paint, but experts are mixed on their recommendations about whether pregnant women should expose themselves to paint at all. (Even low- or non-VOC paints have toxic chemicals in them.)

The current assumption is that your level of exposure to chemicals in household paints is low, but the truth is we don’t know for sure. There haven’t been adequate studies to determine if absorbing a small amount of the fumes could affect a woman or her unborn baby.
So why have so many of your friends painted their own nurseries?

When research is “iffy,” a lot of times the decision comes down to how comfortable a woman and her doctor are with the potential risk. More conservative doctors hold this belief: Why take a chance? Ask your partner or a professional to do the job, and you can still get involved in the decorating—which is the most fun part anyway—after the paint has dried.

title.en-US: When can you really stop taking your prenatal vitamins?

content.value: Find out when it’s OK to ditch the supplements.

Many women joke that in the third trimester, “baby is fully baked”—and therefore some of the healthy habits they’ve been practicing can go out the window. But don’t dump those prenatal vitamins just yet. Experts recommend taking them throughout your entire pregnancy. In fact, your OB-GYN or midwife may even suggest continuing to pop prenatal vitamins after you give birth if you're planning to breastfeed.

While you may be in the homestretch of your pregnancy, your baby is continuing to develop. According to the Mayo Clinic, vitamin D and calcium are especially important during the third trimester, when your baby's bones are rapidly growing and strengthening. And babies born to moms who didn’t get an adequate supply of iron in the last trimester are more susceptible to premature birth and low birth weight. In other words, the nutrients you give your body still matter—a lot.

title.en-US: The difference between back pain and preterm labor

content.value: Learn the red-flags so you’ll know when to call your OB-GYN immediately.

A lot of moms-to-be experience back pain—which is a normal symptom of pregnancy—for many months. That’s why some women worry they ­­­won’t be able to tell the difference between normal back pain and back labor. Luckily, there are a few ways to spot the signs of something more eventful than your usual aches and pains.

Pregnancy back pain is a constant ache. Back labor, on the other hand, comes and goes at regular intervals. What’s more, things that typically brought you some relief—such as changing your position—don’t help to alleviate the pain if it’s truly labor. If this is happening, call your doctor ASAP.

You should also seek immediate medical attention if the discomfort is excruciating, or if your back pain is accompanied by bleeding or a change in vaginal discharge. These are signs that there may be a problem with the placenta or your water has broken.

title.en-US: Is it possible to get too much fiber during pregnancy?

content.value: The rough side of roughage.

Women are told to up their fiber intake during pregnancy, but is it possible to add too much? Actually, yes. And the reason you might not want to overdo it is that excessive fiber intake can cause the kind of gastrointestinal distress that would be uncomfortable for anyone but is downright miserable for pregnant women. Gas, bloating, and ab pain won’t happen to everyone who fiber-loads, but if you weren’t used to eating much fiber before, your body may have a harder time tolerating it.

Interestingly, while you need fiber to prevent pregnancy constipation, consuming too much can actually backfire and cause you to be backed up. Or the opposite could happen—food may move through your system too quickly (aka diarrhea) and the prenatal vitamins you and your growing baby need may not be adequately absorbed by your body.
The lesson: Don’t ditch fiber, but keep it to about 30 grams of fiber per day. And make sure you’re staying hydrated—water helps fiber move through your system.

title.en-US: What if the umbilical cord wraps around my baby’s neck?

content.value: It sounds deeply worrisome—the idea of a cord twisted around your baby, at the neck or anywhere on her body. Fortunately, she often ends up unwrapping it all by herself, or, when the time comes, the doctor can slip her out of the tangle. Still, it’s understandable if you have questions about the scenario. Here are some answers:
How is it detected?

It’s typically picked up during a routine ultrasound. It may also be suspected if the baby is suddenly not moving around as much—which is all the more reason why kick counts at least twice day are so important (you should be able to detect five movements within a half hour). You might also notice it if your baby seems to be squirming around a bunch and then suddenly quiets down.
How common is it?

According to a September 2017 Maternal Health, Neonatology and Perinatology journal article, a cord that wraps 360 degrees around the neck (known technically as a nuchal cord) occurs in about 10 to 29 percent of pregnancies. The risks increase as your little peanut grows bigger and bigger. Moms of all ages and races are susceptible, and it seems to be more common if you’re having a boy.
How do doctors handle the situation?

The majority of babies are delivered as expected, and are completely normal. Still, the compressed cord could cause a decelerated heart rate during labor and delivery. If this is the case, the doctor might:
Have the mom roll over to a certain position to reduce compression.
Give supplemental oxygen to the mom, which would mean more oxygen for the baby.
Perform an emergency C-section.
Will my baby be healthy?

In the very rare cases where the compression is tight and/or multiple knots surface, the pregnancy can end up in a stillbirth. But, again, that’s very rare! In the vast majority of cases, you have no need to worry. Sometimes, evidence of cord compression will show up on the baby’s body—whether it’s a dusky face; red or purple splotches on the body; or abrasions—but these signs eventually disappear. Your doctor’s got this! And your mischievous little baby will escape any long-term injury and emerge scot-free.

title.en-US: Your guide to eating ice cream during pregnancy

content.value: Because, cravings.

First things first: A little bit of indulgence is allowed. We aren’t here to be the ice-cream police and tell you to swear off a big scoop of deliciousness on a hot day. But when it comes to your favorite frozen treat, there are some Dos and Don’ts to follow during pregnancy. Read on to find out what’s safe vs. what’s off-limits.
Can you have coffee ice cream during pregnancy?

Yes. Most experts agree that you can have up to 200 mg of caffeine a day when you’re expecting. And coffee ice cream tends to pack far less caffeine than your average cup of joe. In a 1-cup serving of Häagen-Dazs coffee ice cream, for example, you'll get less than 44 mg of caffeine. For perspective, an 8-ounce cup of coffee has 95 mg of caffeine according to the USDA.
Can you eat soft-serve during pregnancy?

Ask your doctor, but probably. The reason why you may have heard to avoid it is due to a risk of listeria that can lurk inside the ice-cream machine, including the dispenser nozzle, when it isn’t cleaned properly. (During pregnancy, getting an infection called listeriosis would be serious.) But most experts say the risk is very, very small. Of course, if the cleanliness of the restaurant or ice-cream shop is questionable, definitely skip it.
Can you eat homemade ice cream during pregnancy?
Usually, no. Homemade ice cream is often made with uncooked eggs, which may contain Salmonella. Unless you’re sure the mixture didn’t contain raw eggs, go for store-bought varieties instead.

title.en-US: Only 30% of pregnant women hit their weight gain target

content.value: The struggle with the scale is real.

If you’ve been having a hard time managing your weight—either gaining less or more than the recommended amount for your pregnancy—this news may be comforting: You are definitely not in the minority. A 2017 study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association (JAMA) discovered that about 70% of women fall outside of their weight targets when they’re expecting. The researchers analyzed data from 1.3 million pregnancies and discovered that 47% of women gained more weight than the Institutes of Medicine (IOM) advises and 23% gained less than what’s recommended.

Other research has found that many moms-to-be do not receive adequate guidance from their health care providers about how to manage their weight during pregnancy. Surveys have shown that while most doctors want to help their patients with their weight, they often don’t know what to say or avoid the topic because they feel uncomfortable about what might be a sensitive issue for a woman. And the fact is that many OB-GYNs have very little training in nutrition.

But all this avoidance isn’t doing patients any good. An unhealthy amount of weight gain has been linked with a higher risk of adverse outcomes for both mothers and babies. So if you’re struggling and you need help, open up a dialogue with your provider or book an appointment with a Maven practitioner. Weight management can be hard before, during, and after pregnancy—and you deserve to be supported wherever you are on your journey.

title.en-US: Can I exercise right up to my due date?

content.value: The verdict on G.T.L.: gym, training, labor

As long as you’ve been working out these last 8+ months, and you don’t have any medical issues that have made exercising off-limits, there’s no reason you can’t power walk straight into the delivery room.

Exercise that involves lying flat on your back should be avoided, since it can decrease blood flow to the uterus. But with your doctor’s blessing, feel free to continue other workouts you’ve been enjoying. You may be surprised to find out that strengthening your body by exercising during pregnancy leads to an easier labor and delivery, as well as a smoother recovery from childbirth.

That said, remember that any exercise you do at this point should be about helping you stay healthy and making you feel good. It’s OK to need a break and take a breather before the workout of your life: childbirth!

title.en-US: Maven real talk on miscarriage with Amie

content.value: 41 years old
Administrative Assistant
Michigan
What were the circumstances of your miscarriage?
I already had a 14-year-old son, but decided to have another one. I was seven weeks along when then miscarriage happened.
Where were you when it happened?
I was at work when I started spotting. And then I started cramping.
What surprised you most about having a miscarriage?

Realizing how many women had the same experience. I was very open about the miscarriage with my friends and family. But knowing that others have gone through the same thing really helped in those first few difficult weeks.
Did anything else help?
My spiritual community gave us immense support. Also, we got pregnant a couple of months afterward. I was a nervous wreck until I heard the heartbeat.
What would you want to tell other women suffering from miscarriage?

That they’d be amazed to hear how common miscarriage is—but that shouldn’t minimize their feelings of loss. My doctor explained it so well: He understood that from the second we learned we were pregnant, we already had most of that child's life planned out. So, when someone tells you, "at least you were only X weeks along," that doesn't do any good. It hurts no matter how far along you are.

title.en-US: What’s a “birth ball” and how can it help during labor?

content.value: You’ve probably seen an exercise ball before—at the gym or even at your office. (They’ve become a trendy replacement for office chairs in many workplaces.) These large inflated balls made of tough polyvinyl are sometimes called “birth balls” because they’re often used to assist in labor.

One mom we spoke with whose been through three deliveries said she didn’t discover the beauty of the ball until the birth of her third child—and it made all the difference. If you’re allowed to get up from the bed and move around, you might consider using a ball as both a comfort device and a tool to help your baby descend.

While sitting and bouncing is one way to help relax the pelvic floor and move your labor along, other uses of the ball can also be helpful. For instance, kneeling while having your upper body draped over the ball can bring some back pain relief. If you and your doctor decide that a birth ball is a good option for you to try, it’s best to give it a trial run before your delivery day so you can get comfortable and feel secure using the ball. You can buy one online, but keep in mind that some hospitals and birth centers have balls that women can use during labor so do you research first.
Book an appointment with a Maven doula to get guidance about ways some women use birth balls during labor as well as other techniques and labor positions that can make your delivery easier.

title.en-US: Fat-shaming by doctors: What new moms need to know

content.value: It’s easy for the baby weight to come on, but taking it off is a different story. Sadly, some doctors aren’t helping matters.

Of course, you deserve compassion, guidance, and support as you work to get back to a healthy weight for your body. But the one person who may not offer you those things is your doctor. Studies have looked into the attitudes and practices of health care providers in treating overweight patients, and the results are shocking. In one study, physicians were found to spend less time with obese patients and also neglect to refer them for diagnostic tests. The reason? Instead of thoroughly evaluating a problem and recommending blood work and other treatments, they're more apt to just prescribe weight loss.

In a world that puts pressure on new moms to “bounce back” to their pre-baby weight quickly after giving birth, women need support from their providers—not more stigma and criticism. If your provider’s bias about your weight is getting in the way of giving you a thorough assessment of your health, and recommendations for care that go beyond “go on a diet”—you deserve better.

No one is arguing for complacency on the part of healthcare providers. Weight and health go hand-in-hand, and there’s validity in taking small steps to a healthy body size. But accepting where you are today—even if you’re still wearing maternity clothes—is an important part of moving toward these goals. If you need some support that you’re not getting from your own OB-GYN, primary care provider, or midwife, book an appointment with a Maven practitioner. Here you’ll find a teammate in your weight-loss journey, not a harsh or neglectful coach.

title.en-US: Why babysitters and relatives need a primer on baby sleep

content.value: The good news: Parents and licensed childcare providers are paying attention to safe baby sleep practices that reduce SIDS. The bad news: friends, relatives, and the babysitter from down the street may not have caught on yet.

If you come home from work to find your little one in an outfit you wouldn’t have chosen, that may bug you a bit, but it’s not the end of the world. On the other hand, if your caregiver is not following the guidelines for safe baby sleep, that could have serious consequences.

A 2018 study from the University of Virginia Children's Hospital examined 10,000 cases of SIDS (sudden infant death syndrome) and then zeroed in on the 1,375 cases that involved a death while the parent wasn’t present. The results revealed that babysitters, friends and relatives aren’t as diligent as parents when it comes to safe sleep practices. They were more likely to place a baby down on his tummy (a big no-no), or let an infant sleep on the couch or where there are blankets and other suffocation hazards around.

The picture looks better in the case of licensed childcare providers—which should ease your mind a bit if you’re leaving your little one with a nanny or accredited daycare center. According to the study, over 70% of licensed childcare providers placed babies in a bassinet or crib. Among babysitters, this number was 49.1%. And less than 30% of friends and relatives put babies to sleep in a crib.
As for back-sleeping: 54.1% of childcare providers placed babies on their backs, while only 38.4% of relatives, 38.6% of friends, and 37.8% of babysitters followed that important sleep rule.

Going back to work is stressful enough, and reading this news may—understandably—add to your worry about leaving your baby in the care of someone else. But the point isn’t to panic, say researchers. It’s to make sure that anyone taking care of your little one knows how important it is to use safe sleep practices. Even if your mother-in-law gets offended because she’s “raised kids before,” she needs to be reminded of the rules—which have changed since she had babies.

title.en-US: 4 things no one ever tells you about formula feeding

content.value: Odds are, you don’t need to read another article telling you that breast milk is perfect food. You’ve heard it enough—from your pediatrician, the World Health Organization, other mothers, and even non-parents who’ve put breastfeeding pressure on you. Here are four things you probably need to hear instead:
You have permission to do both.

Breastfeeding with formula supplementation is a possibility, and it’s largely missing from the breast vs. bottle debate. In other words, it doesn’t have to be all or nothing. If adding formula to the breastmilk buffet helps you stick with nursing longer, unapologetically go for it.
Sometimes the decision not to breastfeed isn’t really a choice.

Breastfeeding isn’t always possible, like when the amount of milk being produced isn’t enough to meet a baby’s needs. It may also be wholly incompatible with your life as a working woman. You might have the best intentions to breastfeed in an ideal world—but life’s circumstances are often not ideal.
You’ll still be able to bond.

Closeness, eye-contact, nurturing, affection—key ingredients for bonding with your little one—can happen whether you give your baby a breast or a bottle. And if you co-parent, your partner will be able to get equal dibs on the bonding opportunities.
Moms who bottle-feed need support, too.

It’s hard work no matter how you feed your baby—and formula-feeding can present its own challenges. Just because you aren’t nursing (or nursing exclusively) doesn’t mean you need to go through the struggle alone. Book an appointment with a lactation consultant, a midwife, a doula or an OB-GYN on midwife to video chat on your time.

title.en-US: What happens if your water breaks in the pool?

content.value: Find out if it’s best to avoid the deep end in the third trimester.
Swimming is a great way to stay active during pregnancy without adding weight and stress to your joints. Plus, there’s no risk of losing your balance when you’re floating.

Sounds ideal, right? But Maven OB-GYNs say that one fear some expectant moms have in the third trimester is that they won’t know if their water has broken if they’re swimming (or even taking a bath) when it happens.

First thing to keep in mind: Although we’re exposed to a lot of crazy stories about women’s water breaking—usually on TV and in movies—in real life, this event tends to be much less dramatic. The phrase "water breaking" simply means the fluid-filled amniotic sac that is your baby’s home during pregnancy ruptures and releases fluid. This can happen spontaneously before labor, but it's more common for a woman’s water to break when labor is already in full-swing with contractions coming regularly. And at that point, you’re not likely to be practicing your breaststroke at the local pool.

On the off chance that your water does break while you’re swimming or in the bathtub, you’ll likely feel it happening or realize it as soon as you get out. Even if you think your water has broken but you aren’t positive, you should call your OB-GYN or midwife immediately because it could mean labor is imminent. And in the meantime, if you enjoy swimming and your doctor has given you the green light to exercise, you can keep doggy paddling toward your due date.

title.en-US: Would you crowdfund to pay for child care and education?

content.value: A growing number of new parents are asking friends and strangers to help foot the bills involved in raising a child.

Digital crowdfunding for help in dealing with a broken healthcare system is nothing new. Medical-related funds—sometimes involving the bills incurred during pregnancy and childbirth—make up a sizeable percentage of crowdfunding campaigns. It turns out, new parents are also using crowdfunding platforms like GoFundMe to raise money for a variety of child-related expenses after birth, everything from the costs of baby gear to child care.

Whether this trend is a do or a don’t is for every person to decide for herself. Some parents say they’d never hit up friends, family, and sometimes total strangers to help pay for child care. But before we pass judgment on anyone, we have to consider a reality you’re probably well aware of: While the costs of child care vary wildly depending on where you live and the type of care you choose, Americans spend a huge portion of their income on child care. Most parents can safely expect to be spending over $1,000 per month, so they’re often forced to get creative.

A report in 2016 found that GoFundMe campaigns that mentioned maternity leave or child care had mixed results, but in total, they added up to over $8.8 million raised. As a new mom, you might be thinking: Does this mean I should consider crowdfunding to pay for other expenses related to child rearing, like education? Financial experts say that these efforts should never be a substitute for saving and budgeting. The funds are never a sure bet until you actually raise the cash—so think of them as a nice supplement, but don’t rely on them.

title.en-US: Good-for-you foods that make a pregnancy diet less boring

content.value: You’re doing your best to eat healthy, but a girl can only eat so many kale salads. The secret to getting through your pregnancy while maintaining a healthy diet? Look for ways to trick your taste buds into believing you’ve just had junk food. These treats taste delicious and pack in special health benefits for moms-to-be.
Bakes sweet potato fries

Preheat the oven to 425°F. Cut a large sweet potato into strips that are about 1/2-inch wide. In a large bowl, toss potato strips with about a tablespoon of olive oil until evenly coated. Place potatoes on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper and bake for about 30 minutes (flip potatoes over halfway through baking time). Remove from oven, add a sprinkle of sea salt if you’d like, and dig in.
Mom-to-be benefit:
Sweet potatoes are a great source of beta-carotene, which your body transforms into vitamin A—a necessity to help your baby grow bones and teeth.
Banana frozen yogurt

To make it, use a banana that has been peeled, sliced into chunks, and frozen. Add the frozen banana pieces to a food processor with about 1⁄4 cup of plain 2% Greek yogurt and 1 level tablespoon of natural peanut butter. Puree until smooth, then freeze the mixture for 15 minutes before eating.
Mom-to-be benefit:
Bananas are rich in potassium and offer quick energy—something you may really need if you’re suffering from pregnancy fatigue.
Walnut apple "pie"

Core and dice a small apple. In a small microwave-safe dish, combine the diced-up apple with 2 teaspoons of lemon juice, 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon and 1/2 teaspoon of brown sugar. In a separate bowl, mix together 1/2 teaspoon of brown sugar, 1/4 teaspoon of cinnamon, 2 tablespoons of old-fashioned oats, and 1-2 tablespoons of chopped walnuts. Then use a fork to coat this mixture with a teaspoon of butter. This is the nut topping for the apples; crumble it over the apple in the baking dish and microwave for about 3 minutes or until apples are soft.
Mom-to-be benefit:
Fiber is a key nutrient during pregnancy, and just one apple packs more than 4 grams.

title.en-US: The signs of a postpartum thyroid problem to watch for

content.value: Sigh—one more thing to add to the list of body changes that are triggered by pregnancy. Here’s what you need to know about postpartum thyroiditis.

What is postpartum thyroiditis? Postpartum thyroiditis—which is said to affect 5 to 10% of new moms—is an inflammation of the thyroid following childbirth. The underlying condition appears to be an immune system attack on your thyroid gland.
What are the symptoms?
According to the Mayo Clinic, postpartum thyroiditis has two distinct phases—each with their own set of symptoms. During the first phase (usually lasting a few months) of
hyperthyroidism
, or an overactive thyroid, you might be notice anxiety, irritability, a fast heartbeat, or rapid weight loss that can’t be attributed to diet or exercise habits. The second phase of
hypothyroidism
(underactive thyroid) brings on another set of symptoms such as hot flashes, fatigue, tremor, and insomnia.

Keep in mind that it can take a few months for thyroid issues to surface after birth, so if you’re tired, anxious, and irritable in the first month or two, it could just be run-of-the-mill new mom fatigue. Still, doctors say it’s important to monitor how you’re feeling and not be quick to brush off your symptoms as “nothing out of the ordinary.” A simple blood test can check your thyroid function and diagnose or rule out the condition.
How is postpartum thyroiditis treated?

The good news is that in the majority of cases, the condition resolves on its own—typically within a year to 18 months. If hypothyroidism doesn’t go away, however, treatment will most likely require medication.

title.en-US: Can babies choke before they start eating solids?

content.value: Read on for the life-saving information all new parents need.

Choking occurs when an infant can’t breathe because something is blocking the throat or windpipe (airway). While many parents think choking isn’t a possibility until solid foods are introduced, the risk starts at birth. Newborns can choke on breast milk or even their own mucus and saliva. Once they’re a little older and begin crawling or eating solids, everything from taking a big bite of food to putting small objects (toys, coins, etc.) in their mouths can lead to a choking event.

Wondering how to tell the difference between choking and gagging? When a baby is gagging, he’s still able to breathe, cry and make noises. If he’s choking, however, this won’t be the case. The danger signs of choking also include babies’ skin color turning red or blue; weak, ineffective coughing; making soft or high-pitched sounds while inhaling; and even losing consciousness.

It’s scary to think about any of this happening to your child, but the best way to stop freaking out about worst-case scenarios is to prepare for them. Pediatricians encourage all parents—and everyone who cares for the child—to take an infant CPR class in person. Experts say seeing a trained instructor perform CPR—and getting hands-on practice yourself—can mean a difference between life and death. Besides knowing exactly what to do, you’ll have the confidence to do it. The American Red Cross website will point you to classes available in your neighborhood.
According to the Mayo Clinic, if you aren’t trained in child CPR or forget what to do, you should call 911 immediately so the dispatcher can instruct you in the proper procedures until help arrives.

title.en-US: The link between new-parent sleep deprivation and your income

content.value: Could baby-induced fatigue somehow cause your paycheck to take a hit?

We’ve long known that the sleep deprivation new parents experience after having a baby can wreak havoc on many parts of their lives. But experts started to wonder about the effect on one’s bank account.

In 2017, researchers at the London School of Economics and Political Science decided to look into this. Their method involved examining data from 14,000 families—beginning with the birth of a new child up until their 25th birthdays. The data contained detailed information about kids’ sleep, including their middle-of-the-night wake ups.

You don’t need a scientist to tell you that how often a child wakes up through the night has a direct impact on how much shuteye parents get. But here’s what might be a surprise: The study suggested that there may also be a strong relationship between the number of times a little one wakes and parents’ income over time.

But it isn’t all bad news—because it doesn’t take doubling the amount of sleep you get to see a positive impact. Getting just one more hour of sleep per night was associated with an 11% boost in household income.

The takeaway? This research adds to the evidence of how hard it is to be a working parent—and reminds us all of just how important it is to prioritize sleep. If scoring 60 extra minutes of shuteye each night seems impossible, start with a more realistic goal. Maybe instead of staying up to write thank you notes for baby gifts, you can tuck in a half-hour early. And instead of cleaning the house when your baby sleeps, try to rest. Whatever strategies you can find to prioritize Zzz’s, know that a bit more sleep may—literally—pay off.

title.en-US: Back from maternity leave? Here's how to manage envy at work

content.value: Returning to work after maternity leave can be one of the most challenging times in a woman’s career. While you’re trying to find your footing again, and dealing with a slew of postpartum emotions and mixed feelings about being back, you might find that envy is one thing you didn’t anticipate.

Naturally, lots of things go down at work when you take a hiatus to have a baby. Other colleagues cover for you. New hires are brought on. Roles shift and the organization goes through transitions. What sometimes happens is that you return to find things very different from when you left. A peer, for instance, may have been promoted or completely taken over your department. A newbie may have taken your place as the “star player” on the team and ingratiated herself with the boss. Someone else may be handling a plum project you’d love to have your hands on.
If you encounter these or similar situations during your reentry, and envy flares up, this advice can help:
Acknowledge your envy

If you find yourself standing at the kitchen cooler gossiping with your work BFF and saying things like, “Why did the boss think she was cut out for that assignment?” or “I can’t believe she got promoted,” take a step back and ask yourself if you’re having a flare-up of envy. Just admitting to yourself that you might be envious can keep you from acting out on it.
Recognize how envy is affecting you

While it’s perfectly normal to feel jealous of a colleague from time to time, getting too wrapped up in others’ status can take a toll on your well-being. The more preoccupied we become with what our colleagues are getting (accolades, praise, raises, etc.), the easier it is to question our own self-worth. Keeping envy in check will help protect your self-esteem as well as making it less likely that you’ll slide into resentment, anger, anxiety, and shame.
Know that defusing your envy will make you better at your job

The thing about envy is that it doesn’t end there. It usually turns into competition, negativity, and being withholding at work. In other words, envious people are rarely team players; instead they are the ones who doesn’t collaborate, communicate, or strive for the success of the team. On the other hand, managing your envy can put you back in a position to contribute to the organization’s big gains—and before you know it, you may be the person people admire.
Focus on yourself

This may sound like the clichéd advice that applies to many different emotional struggles, but that doesn’t make it any less valuable. When we’re envious of others, often it means we’ve lost sight of our own path, unique trajectory, and values in life. What other people are up to at work has very little to do with why you’re there, what makes you successful, and what you need to be happy. Shifting the focus back to yourself—and competing with no one but you—can make you more joyful overall and lessen the stress of this return-to-work transition.
One last thing

: If you are being triggered each time you step into the office and feel too overwhelmed, consider booking an appointment with a Maven career coach or therapist. The one-to-one support may help you cope with your emotions and establish strategies that make you feel better about your work life.

title.en-US: 3 things to add to your work calendar after maternity leave

content.value: Working parenthood requires being very savvy about your time. If your workplace has a shared office calendar, using it effectively can help you manage your day and reduce stress. But even if it doesn’t, plotting out your day on your phone’s calendar will go a long way in keeping you on track—especially when it comes to...
Pediatrician appointments

Fact: Even babies who are perfectly healthy go to the pediatrician a lot. In the first year, the American Academy of Pediatrics recommends infants get checkups at birth, 3 to 5 days after, and then at 1, 2, 4, 6, 9, and 12 months. Waiting till the last minute to schedule these appointments is a recipe for stressful days when you’re at work. Planning in advance (ideally before you even return from maternity leave) will give you the best chance at snagging appointment times that are most convenient for you. As soon as they’re booked, update your calendar with when you’ll be out of the office or coming in a little late. (Just be sure to give your manager the heads up when the date gets close.)
Pumping sessions

As one new parent told us, “I hadn’t thought about how I was going to pump two to three times a day while also getting all my work done and attending meetings—this was a big oversight.” That’s why experts recommend scheduling times for pumping into your work calendar. You don’t have to explicitly say, “Tanya's pumping session”—simply marking yourself as busy will do.
Your exit time

It’s too easy to get stuck at work later than you planned when you don’t have a firm end time. Adding your departure time to your calendar is the first step. Then, if possible, block out the last 30 minutes of your workday on your office calendar as "busy.” The key to getting out the door is giving yourself time to wrap up anything you’ve been working on—without being pulled into last-minute meetings.

title.en-US: What expectant moms need to know about placental abruption

content.value: The good news: It's unlikely to occur. The not-so-good news: When it happens, it's considered a serious complication of pregnancy.

Even before your baby is born, you tend to her night and day. And it’s the placenta that makes that possible. The placenta is a special organ that attaches on your uterine wall, and delivers, with help from the umbilical cord, nutrition and oxygen to your baby. So when that all-important transfer station becomes detached from your uterine wall prior to delivery—a situation known as a placental abruption—there can be cause for concern. Fortunately, it’s a rare condition. Placental abruption affects approximately 1 in 100 to 120 pregnancies.
What’s more, even if you experience a placental abruption, delivering a healthy baby can still be possible. Here’s the lowdown.
What is placental abruption?

There are two types of placental abruption: a partial abruption, when the placenta detaches slightly from the uterine wall; and a complete (or, total) abruption, which as it sounds, happens when the entire organ becomes detached. When any kind of placental abruption occurs—usually in the third trimester, but also any time after week 20— the baby’s air and food supply is hindered.
Placental abruption symptoms

The main symptoms are abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. The ab pain may be severe, and you might also experience contractions. (According to the March of Dimes, sometimes placental abruption occurs without vaginal bleeding because the blood is trapped behind the placenta.) These symptoms may be a sign of other complications of pregnancy—so if you experience any of them, call your doctor immediately to get to the root cause. “Usually, we’ll have the patient come in to triage for uterine and fetal monitoring, lab work, and an ultrasound,” says Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, MD.
Placental abruption causes and risk factors
While trauma is a common cause (i.e. a car accident, a blow to the stomach, or a fall), certain factors can put you at risk. These include:
Getting pregnant after age 40
Having suffered an infection while pregnant
Hypertension (chronic high blood pressure) or diabetes
Early rupture of membranes, which causes leaking of amniotic fluid
High blood pressure during pregnancy
Uterine fibroids or other uterine problems
Carrying multiples
Drinking more than 14 alcoholic beverages a week; smoking; drugs
Experiencing a placental abruption in a previous pregnancy
Placental abruption complications

A placental abruption can result in complications for the pregnancy. For the mom, it could result in shock, blood clotting, organ failure, blood transfusion, or possible hysterectomy. At the same time, your baby could have problems growing and lose oxygen. She could be born prematurely or not survive at all.
How can I prevent placental abruptions?

There’s nothing you can do to prevent them, but always wearing a seat belt in the car and avoiding falls and injury can help cut your risks. Let someone else change that light bulb already! Also: Don’t smoke and don’t take drugs. If you have conditions like high blood pressure or any of the above risk factors, be conscientious about following your doctor’s orders to keep them under control.
Placental abruption treatment

You can’t reattach the placenta, unfortunately. What the doctor does next depends on the situation, such as where the tear is, how far along you are with the pregnancy, and how well you and your baby are doing. A minor abruption at 24 to 34 weeks typically requires monitoring at the hospital. You may be put on bedrest. If you’re near term, however, you may deliver your baby very quickly. A C-section would probably be required if the baby is in distress; if the baby is okay, a vaginal delivery may still be possible.

title.en-US: How bad is it when you take a fall while pregnant?

content.value: One moment we’re walking along, minding our own business, and the next, we’re on the ground. If this has happened to you during pregnancy, don’t feel embarrassed—it’s more common than you think. Wondering why? First, as your belly grows, your center of gravity shifts. Some experts theorize that the hormone relaxin—which eases the delivery of your baby by relaxing the ligaments in your pelvis and softening and widening the cervix—may also affect joint stability. More likely, you’re exhausted, which, as we all know, can make slips and spills more common, too.

If you take a fall, first things first: Try not to panic. Chances are, your baby will be OK. The uterus is a muscle; it’s thick and strong, and, for the everyday mishap, it acts as a cushion for your baby. The amniotic sac is an added safety net.

That said, make sure you check in with your doctor right away, especially if there’s direct impact on your belly. She’ll want to make sure that your placenta is still seamlessly attached to your uterus and that there’s no hemorrhaging. Get emergency help if you are bleeding, feel contractions, abdominal pain or don’t feel the baby move.
How to reduce your risk of falling when pregnant
These tips are obvious, but everyone can use a reminder from time to time.
Wear comfortable shoes.
Use the railing when walking up and down stairs.
If the possibility exists, ask your manager about working remotely if the weather is stormy and roads are slippery.
Avoid climbing ladders or carrying heavy loads (Get pals or your partner to help!).
Take a break from potentially dangerous sports (your corporate softball league will just have to trudge on without your fastball).

title.en-US: The common stroller mistake that's putting babies in danger

content.value: Find out if you’re making it—and how to keep your little one safe.

When the temps rise and you’re out and about with your little one, how do you shield him from the sun’s rays while also keeping him cool in his stroller? One method many parents rely on is to simply drape a blanket over the stroller.

It turns out, this practice can actually have an unintended effect, increasing a baby's body temperature drastically. Case in point: A Swedish experiment found that if it’s 71°F outside, and you cover your baby’s roller with a blanket, the inside of the stroller can reach 94°F within just 30 minutes. Yikes!

Meanwhile, babies are at the greatest risk for heat-related illness. Their temperature-regulating systems aren’t fully developed, so they can become overheated faster than adults and become dangerously dehydrated.
So what should you do instead of draping a blanket over the stroller on a steamy, sunny day? Besides limiting your time outside, you can look for a sun shield for your stroller—unlike a blanket, these don’t restrict the air flow and ventilation. Some stroller models come with them, or you can buy a shade separately. One of the top picks on Amazon is the Manito Sun Shade, available for less than $30.

title.en-US: 6 things new parents hate hearing when they’re back at work

content.value: It’s hard enough as it is to manage your emotions about being back at work after maternity leave. But then a colleague (well-intentioned, of course) makes a comment that really throws you for a loop. Hopefully you’ll never have to hear one of these doozies, but if you do, know that you’re not alone. And even if it doesn’t feel like it in the moment, you will survive.
Back already?
That went by so fast! It did for you, too, but you don’t need another reminder.
How was your vacation?

Definitely the most relaxing, restful time of your life. Not once did you feel like a sleep-deprived zombie who spent her days cleaning up poop and on-demand feeding a baby she pushed out of her body—not even once.
You stopped nursing already?

Underlying message: You’re a selfish quitter. But don’t let anyone—at work or otherwise—impose their beliefs on you. Breastfeeding is one of the biggest challenges for working parents, and you don’t need anyone shaming you about this very personal decision.
It must be really hard being back.
Here’s the thing: For some new parents, it isn’t. Some new parents are genuinely happy to be back at work. If that’s you, you probably don’t want anyone implying that you should feel differently.
You’re so lucky you got the boss to agree to a special schedule!
Even if you do have more flexible hours now, you’ll still be working just as hard—so it would be nice if people focused on your productivity, not your time-sheet.
How close are you to your pre-baby size?
Oh, let me get out the scale during the all-hands meeting so we can all have a look together. Sigh.
The bottom line

: Don’t assume a colleague has bad intentions if they say something completely rude—often, people are just trying to engage with you, but they don’t know exactly what to say. Respond in any way that feels comfortable for you (psst: no response is also a response.) Need a little help coping? book an appointment with a Maven career coach or therapist to discuss the best way to handle awkward conversations when you’re back at work.

title.en-US: The inconvenient truth about bed rest during pregnancy

content.value: It can sound oddly ideal—clear the calendar, load up Netflix, and commit to not lifting a finger for a long while. But as anyone who’s actually been on bed rest knows, it gets really old really quickly. Here are some common questions.
Why would I need bed rest?
Your doctor might prescribe bed rest for a range of reasons, including the following:
To manage ruptured membranes (preterm premature rupture of membranes, or pPROM, comes with complications like preterm birth and a serious bacterial infection that could harm the fetus)
To control bleeding
To manage placenta previa (when the placenta partially or completely covers the cervix)
To prevent preeclampsia
To manage a high-risk pregnancy with multiples

But the funny thing is, the medical community isn’t quite sure just how beneficial bed rest is. After all, staying inactive for weeks and months at a time has its dangers, too—your risks for blood clots go up, your muscle strength diminishes, joints stiffen. And then there’s the issue of constipation.

But given that the ultimate goal is to deliver a live, healthy babies, many doctors err on the conservative side. As you probably realized by now, so much of pregnancy is about treating the patient on a case-by-case basis. Some moms with twins might be able to swing some semblance of a gym workout; others may need to avoid walking just to avoid any chance of strain in the abdominal muscles. The wisest option is to listen to your doctor (or get a second opinion if you want more clarity on the recommendation) and work together so that her prescription for bed rest comfortably fits your needs and concerns.
