Does it literally mean I need to lie in bed all day?

It depends. For some women, bed rest requires checking into the hospital; for others, it’s about staying home. It’s hard to generalize what you can and can’t do. It can mean simply working from home with limited hours of sitting at the desk. It can mean staying in bed but with permission to join your family at the table. It can mean being absolutely stuck in bed and peeing in a bed pan and taking sponge baths. Whatever the case may be, make sure you fully understand your doctor’s recommendations and don’t be shy about asking lots of questions. A few might include:
How much can I move in bed? Should I be in a particular position?
How should I handle using the restroom?
Are showers or baths allowed
Is sex allowed? Are orgasms?
Should I lay off on Kegel exercises?
How long will these restrictions last?
Am I allowed to move to the couch to lie down during the day?
Can my partner share the bed with me?
How to have a safe bed rest

The biggest danger is clotting (deep vein thrombosis), brought on by poor circulation. When a clot travels up to the lungs, it could be life threatening. It’s common to see no symptoms at all, but if you experience any of these below, call your doctor right away:
Swollen, red, or warm-to-the-touch legs, feet, and ankles
Achy chest
Difficulty breathing
Cough accompanied by blood

To prevent these dangers, ask your doctor whether you should consult with a Maven physical therapist on a regular basis. This way, you could have an expert show you exercises and stretches that can prevent these problems; she can also offer advice as to how best to ergonomically manage tasks in bed, such as typing on your laptop, texting, or watching TV.
Be sure to arrange for help with household chores, too. And don’t be shy about getting help from friends and family.
What could I possibly do in bed all day?

For one, many women continue working on their laptops. Bed rest can also be an opportunity to tackle all those things you never have time to do, like learning a language, organizing your photo library, creating that really cool playlist, ordering everything online that you need for the nursery, reading all those books on the New York Times best-seller list, or, heck, plowing through a delicious pile of Us magazines.

Of course, some women go above and beyond. How’s this for inspiration? One woman named Jennifer Burling went into turbo-drive with crocheting, and then donated her baby caps to the NICU ward at Brigham and Women’s Hospital in Boston. Another mom named Sarah Bilston wrote a book and sold it to a publisher. The title? Bed Rest.

title.en-US: 5 labor positions that could make childbirth easier

content.value: If you’ve watched your fair share of movies in which a pregnant lady gives birth, you’d think there’s only one labor position: lying reclined on a hospital bed, elbows propped, gearing up for a dramatic push. The reality is, there are a variety of ways to labor. Keep in mind, some women will be allowed more movement than others, so ask your doctor if your mobility will be restricted at all. But considering that most women today don’t have to lie flat in bed the whole time, it’s a good idea to familiarize yourself with all the possibilities. Trying different positions is not only a way to take the edge off the pain; it could also expedite delivery. That said, no one position is perfect for every woman, so if your health-care provider is okay with venturing off the beaten path, it may be worth giving a combination of these positions a whirl.
Upright

Laboring while standing on your own two feet is often associated with less pain than the traditional on-the-back position. Research suggests that it could speed up the first stage of labor by an hour and 22 minutes, and may make the second stage go a few minutes faster, too. A bed, chair, or partner can offer support as you try an upright labor position, which can mean walking, swaying, or even a doing a “labor lunge”; that’s where you open one leg and lunge out to the side of your body, propping your foot up on a stool or low chair. In comparison with non-upright positions, people who go upright in the second stage of labor are less likely to have an episiotomy but more likely to have natural tearing. (That said, there’s strong evidence that natural tears heal easier and are less traumatic than episiotomies.)
Hands and knees

This entails lowering yourself to your knees and getting “on all fours.” You’ll still take advantage of gravity, helping to move the baby down the birth canal. Bonus: There’s a smaller risk of perineum tears (the area between the anus and vulva) than in fully upright labor position.
Side-lying

This can be a good option if you’re especially tired in the second stage of labor. Compared to the supine (on your back) position, side-lying can reduce the pressure on your pelvis and on a major vein in your body (the vena cava). If your baby's heart rate shows signs of distress during labor, your midwife or doctor may recommend side-lying.
Sitting

This position is done with a birthing chair, ball, toilet, or edge of the bed. Besides allowing you to rest, it also makes it easy for your doctor to monitor your progress. In particular, sitting on the toilet can help relax the perineum. Sitting also takes advantage of gravity and can help speed up the laboring process.
Squatting

Squatting’s main benefit is that it allows your pelvis to be fully open. You’ll be helping your baby line up with the opening of your pelvis and enhance its opening by 15 percent, according to Lamaze International. You’re also somewhat upright, which takes advantage of gravity. Of course, squatting is physical work, so even if you’re being supported by your partner or a nurse, you may find it too exhausting to do for long. In that case, alternating with other positions can be a good idea.

title.en-US: A handy guide to prodromal labor

content.value: You’ve been waiting for the big day to happen, and now you’re feeling regular contractions. You’re convinced that this is go time, but when you show up at the hospital, you’re told that those contractions weren’t actually real labor contractions. (Oh, that pain was definitely REAL, you think to yourself.) You end up back home and waiting and waiting....
What, exactly, is prodromal labor?

The situation we just described is known as “prodromal labor”—aka “false labor” or “prelabor.” They’re contractions felt at some point in your third trimester (days, weeks, or months before the delivery date) and they can be regular and robust, like your baby is about to bust out any minute—except he isn’t. Unlike in actual labor, the cervix hasn’t thinned or dilated, and your baby isn’t ready to leave the comfort of your womb quite yet. Prodromal is Greek in origin, meaning “precursor”—and that’s what the contractions are. They’re contractions that come before (though not necessarily immediately before) actual labor contractions.
What causes prodromal labor?

It’s unclear what causes prodromal labor. Some experts theorize that you might feel it when you’re stressed. Others think it’s your body just prepping for the big day—whether it’s limbering up the muscles or shifting your baby into a better position.
Prodromal labor vs. Braxton Hicks

Prodromal labor falls in between Braxton Hicks and actual labor. Braxton Hicks can happen as early as the second trimester, and it’s just the uterus tightening up. So you might feel uncomfortable, but usually you’re not in absolute pain and that squeeze-y feeling might come and go. Prodromal labor, on the other hand, happens more regularly and the contractions tend to be more painful (but not always).
Prodromal labor vs. active labor

Prodromal labor contractions don’t become increasingly more frequent, nor more severe. The intensity and frequency typically stays pretty constant, and usually there’s no discharge. You’ll find that if you drink water or soak in a tub, the contractions will eventually go away.

With actual labor, in contrast, the pain is even more intense—and you feel it not just in your belly but the back seems to be involved a bit, too. What’s more, you might also see a blob of discharge—it could be your mucus plug, which until now had kept the cervix plugged up. You might feel leakage, which would mean your water broke. Also, with actual labor, water and a bath will do you no good—the waves and contractions will keep coming, increasingly faster and more furious.
What to do when you feel contractions (prodromal or otherwise)

Never feel embarrassed about calling your health professional when questions come up. (That’s why we’re here at Maven—to answer anything!) It may be a false alarm, but so what? Better safe than sorry.

Take note of your contractions, because your provider will ask you for all the details. How long do they last and how frequent are they? How do they feel? Do you see any discharge? Is the baby moving?

If it seems that you have prodromal labor and your health care provider has confirmed it, then relax. Treat yourself to a bath or take a walk. Check on your go bag. While chances are, they’ll vanish as mysteriously as they appeared, they might progress into actual labor contractions, in which case, you’ll be prepared to head out to the hospital.

title.en-US: What you need to know about baby-wearing workouts

content.value: Meet your new workout partner—she’s on the small side, super-cute, and happy to go wherever you go: She’s your baby, and not only will working out with her perk up your mood and get you in shape, it’ll get her all giggly too, which just may be the best motivator ever. Baby-wearing allows you to work out even if you don’t have a sitter, and the close contact doubles as bonding time. Here are four things to know before you strap your baby on and get moving.

Baby-wearing isn’t right for everyone. You should always talk to your OB-GYN to make sure you’re ready to work out. Most doctors recommend waiting at least 6 weeks after giving birth; 8 if you had a C-section. If you have problems with your pelvic floor or core after delivery, or have a condition known as a diastasis recti, you may be told to hold off a while longer or be given very precise instructions on how to ease back into fitness. If the added weight of your baby could pose a problem in your recovery, you might be better suited to solo workouts. And while you’re getting the green light from your OB-GYN, also check with your pediatrician to make sure they’re ready for baby-wearing workouts.
Do a safety check.

Every carrier is different and will have its own instruction manual, but there are a few universal guidelines to keep your baby safe. Your child should sit high enough so that you can easily kiss the top of her head. The carrier should keep your little one snug against your body without restricting her breathing (make sure you can see your baby’s face at all times). Keep in mind, if your baby’s legs hang straight down, healthy hip development could be at risk, so be sure to use a carrier than supports your baby in a frog squat.
Watch your form.

A good babywearing device will support both you and your baby. Once your baby is set up for safety, do a test run to make sure you’re protecting your body, too. With your baby strapped in front, your body positioning may feel a bit off-balance, and the tendency can be to overarch the back and slump the shoulders. Check your alignment to avoid injuring yourself over time.
Don’t get too crazy with workouts.

It doesn’t matter how securely your baby is attached to your body, there are still some workouts that should be adults-only affairs. Avoid high-impact cardio (jumping jacks, for instance) and stick to activities like walking, basic yoga, or easy lunges.

title.en-US: Should your baby sleep with a pacifier?

content.value: A binky? In the crib? It seems as wrong as sending a toddler to bed with a bag of Cheetos. But actually, research suggests the benefits of pacifiers at bedtime go beyond calming your little one down.
The perks of pacifiers

All babies are unique, of course. Some babies stop crying as soon as you give them one; others might take one critical look at the binky and keep wailing. But for those who embrace their pacifier, you might discover the following:
Pacifiers can soothe.

The act of sucking is a natural newborn reflex with calming abilities, so it helps some infants fall asleep. If you’re able to make it through dinner in relative peace by giving you baby a pacifier, then chances are you’ll fast-track putting your baby down in the evening with it, too.
Pacifiers are associated with reduced risk of SIDS (Sudden Infant Death Syndrome).
Experts don’t know why this is the case, but the association is so convincing that some health-care providers are even recommending the binky as a precautionary measure to keep babies safe.
Pacifier safety tips
Not all pacifiers are created equal. Keep these precautions in mind.
Choose pacifiers that are made of one seamless piece. The reason is that you don’t want individual parts (nipple, shield, and handle) to pop off and present a choking hazard.
Skip the strap. Attaching the pacifier to your baby's clothes or crib while he sleeps can present another strangulation hazard for a baby.

Check the shield. The shield (also called the guard)—which prevents the nipple from being sucked into the mouth—should be large enough that your baby couldn’t accidentally swallow it, and it should also have ventilation holes.

Clean the pacifier with soap and water before giving it to your baby. If she’s younger than six months—when her immune system hasn’t matured yet—keep it germ-free by boiling (and cooling) it regularly or running it in the dishwasher.

Learn when to wean your baby from the pacifier. While experts have different opinions on when children should say goodbye to the binky, eventually you’ll have to pull the plug. Use of pacifiers in older children can increase your child’s risk of ear infections and dental problems. (Check with your pediatrician or pediatric dentist to find out her recommendation for when to stop—which could be sometime between your child’s first or second birthday.)

title.en-US: How to survive parenting a baby when you have a cold

content.value: Just when you’re feeling back to your normal self after giving birth–eh, sort of—you start noticing a tickle in your throat. And then those all-too-familiar symptoms begin: the coughing, sneezing, sore throat, and annoying stuffed-up feeling. If any visitors showed up at your doorstep, hoping to see the baby in this condition, you’d certainly shoo them away. But what should you do when you’re the germ-factory?
Delegate

Give yourself a break so that you can get better as soon as possible. Whether it’s changing diapers, soothing the baby between feedings, or doing run-of-the-mill housework, enlist help if you’re able to.
Continue to breastfeed

If you’re nursing, you don’t have to stop just because you have a cold. It’s actually good for your baby, since your milk contains antibodies that will protect her from the virus you’re suffering from. If you’re too weak to hold your little bundle, try “laid-back breastfeeding”—where you’re reclining instead of doing all the work to hold yourself up.
Get as much shut-eye as you can
Yes, lack of sleep can affect your immune system, so Zzz’s = medicine.
Ignore the chores
It’s OK if the laundry piles up and the dishes in the sick don’t get done for a couple of days. Your main priorities right now are getting better and taking care of your child.
Protect

You know the typical precautions you take when you have a cold? Be extra vigilant about them now. Wash your hands with warm water and soap before touching your baby. Try not to cough and sneeze on your baby. (While the typical advice is to do so into your elbow, it’s probably not a good idea for new moms, since your baby’s head is often resting right in that spot, when you’re feeding her or rocking her to sleep.) If this seems impossible, reminder to go back to the first tip on this list: Ask for help. There’s no need to try to do it all ever, but when you’re sick, superwoman syndrome seriously needs a rest.

title.en-US: 3 common baby accidents and how to handle them

content.value: As you may have noticed by now, your little one has an outsized curiosity. Turn around for a split second, and he’ll likely surprise you, whether it’s thrusting his little fist into your Aquaphor and sticking it in his mouth or trying to wriggle out of his stroller. Most of the time, it’s no big deal, but that doesn’t mean it feels any less scary. Here are some common mishaps and what to do about them.
Swallowing non-food items

Once your baby is crawling—and sometimes even before—he may manage to get his hands on anything in his path and put it in his mouth. Coins, buttons, M&M’s, you name it. Whatever the object, take it out as soon as you notice. If he’s already choking by the time you get to it, dislodge it with forceful blows to the back.

Here’s how Harvard medical school suggests you do it: Place your baby face down across your forearm (resting your forearm on your leg) and support the infant's head with your hand. Give four forceful blows to the back with the heel of your hand. You may have to repeat this several times until the obstructing object is coughed out. If this does not work, the next step is to turn the baby over. With two fingers one finger-width below an imaginary line connecting the nipples, give four forceful thrusts to the chest to a depth of 1 inch. You may have to repeat this several times until the obstructing object is coughed out. Sounds complicated, but learning how to do this could be life-saving. If you’re having trouble, immediately call 911.
How to prevent it:

Keep dangerous materials locked up and out of reach. Vacuum and sweep more frequently than you think you need to. Lastly, check with your hospital or local Red Cross about baby-safety classes for an in-person primer on smart safety habits. PS: If your child has swallowed a substance, call the National Poison Center at 888-222-1222 to get directed to your local center. (Of course, in the case where your child is having an obvious reaction, call 911.)
Falling

Even if your baby is still staying on his back for the most part unless you move him, don’t leave him unattended on a raised surface, such as the bed and changing table. You never know when he’ll crawl or roll over for the first time. If he falls and is unconscious, or he’s acting differently, call 911 immediately; don’t move him, in case he has a head or spinal injury. If he’s crying but otherwise seems normal, apply cool compresses (to avoid swelling) and call your child’s health care provider to find out what steps need to be taken next.
How to prevent it:

Set up child-safety barriers to zone off stairs. Don’t leave your baby unattended on a changing table or your bed; if he’s in a car seat, that seat should be either in the car, on the ground, or latched onto its own travel system. Be extra vigilant in other people’s houses, especially with stairs, outside decks, and pools. Always buckle your baby up in the stroller. And avoid multitasking whenever possible—even if you think you can make it up or down the stairs with your baby in one hand and something bulky in the other, don’t risk it.
Sunburns

Babies and small children are especially susceptible to the sun's damaging effects. If your baby gets burned after some time in the sun, you probably won’t notice anything wrong until six to 12 hours later. If it’s simply red and chafing, apply cool compresses. If you notice that your child has a fever, blisters, or chills, call the doctor ASAP. Specific treatment for a sunburn will be determined by your child's pediatrician and will depend on the severity of the sunburn.
How to prevent it:

Try not to take your baby out when the sun is strongest, between 10 AM and 2 PM. When you do venture out, keep infants younger than 6 months out of direct sunlight, protected by the shade. Dress your baby in clothes that cover up her skin. When physical protection from the sun won’t cut it, applying a small amount of sunscreen. Go for an SPF of at least 30 on the exposed areas like face and hands, and be sure to apply it 15 to 30 minutes before you head outdoors.

title.en-US: What to know if you feel postpartum depression is your fault

content.value: Mental Health Specialist Mercedes Samudio, LCSW, MSW, addresses this common sentiment.

This is a concern I hear all the time—even with all the research about postpartum depression that exists, women still feel it’s somehow their own fault. When a close friend of mine confided in me that she was experiencing postpartum depression, she also expressed guilt over her feelings. I helped her to understand that postpartum depression is equal parts chemical fluctuations from childbirth and a flood of emotions that come with becoming a new mom. I explained that although women with a history of mood disorders/problems have a higher risk for experiencing postpartum depression, postpartum depression is a blind issue. It other words, it can happen to anyone. Whatever risk factors might exist, it’s crucial for women who are suffering from postpartum depression to understand that it is not the result of something they did or didn’t do; it is never your fault.

I also shared with my friend that her recovery may not look like anyone else’s—and that’s OK—but everyone affected by postpartum depression needs help. Coping with postpartum depression includes being honest about your feelings, talking with a professional about your symptoms, joining a support group of other moms experiencing these issues, creating a solid team of people can lean on so that you can take time for yourself (like to take a shower, eat, sleep). I encouraged my pal to work with a professional to identify the best treatment options for her, and then be open to trying other things if her initial methods don’t work. Another important part of the process is patience—especially patience with yourself as you learn how to create a routine that attends to the well-being of both you and your baby.

title.en-US: Why self-care is a critical part of parenting (yes, really)

content.value: Here’s what Maven Mental Health Specialist Mercedes Samudio, LCSW, MSW tells her friends about the importance of self-care after having a baby.

Self-care has become such a buzz word that many new moms will scoff at it rather than embrace how they can uniquely define self-care for themselves. Many of my close friends seem to think that once you become a mom, self-care is a luxury. I help them reframe their thinking by asking this one question: “Can you pour from an empty cup?” They usually laugh and say, “No! Of course not!”

I always try to help debunk the idea that self-care is all about indulgence and decadence. At its core, self-care is about finding activities that help restore you and/or center you. For some women, it does include spa days and mani-pedis, and that’s okay for them. But, for others it can be very simple—it may include getting a few hours of sleep, being able to read a few chapters of a good book, eating a favorite meal, getting to have a few hours out of the house, inviting friends over for company, squeezing in a yoga class, or anything else that allows someone to feel less stressed and more energized.

When people say to me, “But I don’t know where to start,” I always suggest picking one small self-care act that feel doable, such as taking a nap or eating a nourishing meal in peace and quiet. Hopefully that allows them to prioritize other activities like leaving their baby with a trusted person for a hour or two so they can do something to recharge. Back to that cup analogy: The goal is to find activities that help a new mom feel restored so she can get back to caring for her new baby without being so drained.

title.en-US: What an extra 340 calories a day looks like during pregnancy

content.value: At some point during pregnancy, you might ask yourself:
When do I get to eat for two?
Sadly, never. That whole eat-for-two rumor is a myth that can lead to unhealthy weight gain. But it’s not all bad news. Keep reading.

Beginning in the second trimester, it’s often advised that women add an extra 340 calories per day to their diets to support their own nutritional needs as well as their baby's growth and development. Of course, you should check with your doctor to make sure you’re on the right nutritional track for your bod; depending on your pre-pregnancy BMI (body mass index), you may need to add a bit more or less food to your diet.
So what does 340 calories look like? And what can you eat when you want something satisfying while still staying on the healthy side? Here are a few ideas to cure every craving.
Berry nut oatmeal
Cook 1/2 cup dry quick 1-minute oats, and top with 1 cup berries (any kind you like), 2 tablespoons of crushed almonds, and 1 tablespoon of honey. About 390 calories
Homemade healthy pizza

Preheat oven to 450 degrees. On a baking sheet, place a whole-wheat tortilla topped with 1/4 cup crushed tomatoes, basil, and 1/2 cup shredded part-skim mozzarella. Bake for about 10 minutes. (As long as the mozzarella is pasteurized, it’s safe to eat during pregnancy. Double check the packaging to be sure, then... mangia!) About 350 calories
Overnight chia pudding

Combine 3/4 cup vanilla unsweetened almond milk, 2 teaspoons of honey, 1 teaspoon of pure vanilla extract in bowl. Then add in 4 tablespoons of chia seeds and 1 tablespoon of cacao powder. Whisk together to combine ingredients. Refrigerate overnight. The next day, give it a good stir before digging in. About 340 calories
Peanut butter smoothie
In a blender, blend 1 cup vanilla soy milk, 2 tablespoons of peanut butter, half a banana, 6 ice cubes, and 1⁄4 tsp of cinnamon. About 300 calories
Need more pregnancy snack/meal ideas? Book an appointment with a Maven nutritionist.

title.en-US: How does prenatal yoga differ from “regular” yoga?

content.value: One part downward dog plus one part pregnancy support group. Here’s exactly what you can expect.

While you may not need to give up your regular yoga classes during pregnancy, you might have to modify certain poses or skip them altogether. With prenatal yoga, instructors are aware of both the limitations and the needs of moms-to-be, and tailor the classes accordingly. For instance, pregnancy hormones make ligaments and muscles looser, so certain precautions need to be taken to avoid overstretching. And as your belly grows, you’ll want to avoid any big twists where you’re swiveling so far that you push your belly across the midline of your body (not recommended). It’s adjustments like these that prenatal yoga teachers keep top of mind.

But don’t underestimate the non-physical reasons to consider a pregnancy-specific class. For one, you may find it especially comforting to be in a room full of expectant mothers who can relate to what this period in your life is like, with all the ups and downs. And you might also have an easier time keeping the focus on relaxation and how good it feels to take a time out to nurture yourself and your connection with your baby.

title.en-US: "Help! My maternity leave is ending and I want to quit my job"

content.value: Here’s what Sara Daly-Padron, a Maven Career Coach, tells her friends who are afraid to return to work after having a baby. Her advice can help any woman going through “reentry fear.”

A friend recently confided in me that she was thinking of leaving her company instead of returning from maternity leave. Six weeks into motherhood and she just couldn’t envision how she would handle finding a caregiver she trusted, manage the commute, and find time in her day to pump. I asked her to try to name the feeling driving these concerns. Simply naming a feeling—putting it into words—can help dampen down the emotional response.

“Overwhelmed!” my friend exclaimed. I replied, “Indeed—all of the new responsibilities and mental load that new parents face can be extremely overwhelming.” Then I encouraged my friend to put the breaks on her big decision in order to examine it from all angles. “Before making a major life change such as leaving your job, think about what you really need to feel less overwhelmed,” I told her. Sure, maybe leaving the job altogether is one way solution, but perhaps there are others, too. To get my friend thinking, I offered up some questions for her to consider: Would it help to build your support network at home? Find time to focus on something you enjoy? What is one thing you can do today to help relieve some of the overwhelming feelings and inform your next steps?

Ultimately, new parents who are thinking about a job change should ask themselves: What does my ideal post-baby career look like and how close is my current situation to that ideal? What are the barriers standing in my way of achieving that ideal career and how might I overcome them? Every mom's post-baby career decision is unique, but the first steps are to understand what feelings are driving you, what you really want, and how you are going to get there.

title.en-US: Is swelling during pregnancy a sign of preeclampsia?

content.value: When you're expecting, your tissues can accumulate more fluid due to increased blood volume in your body. Hence, many moms-to-be become swollen, especially in warmer weather. In fact, more than half of all pregnant women will experience some swelling during pregnancy. But don't worry—swelling alone doesn't mean you have preeclampsia.

Preeclampsia (also known as pregnancy-induced hypertension) is diagnosed if the swelling is accompanied by both high blood pressure and protein in your urine. Your doctor will screen you for preeclampsia during your regular prenatal appointments, but if your hands and feet swell excessively or suddenly, or your face and eyelids are swollen, let your doctor know right away.

title.en-US: “Will my baby be closer to their caregiver than to me?”

content.value: Whether you’re currently preparing to go back to work or your maternity has already ended, you may be dealing with lots of what ifs. Among them:
What if my little one develops a stronger bond with his caregiver(s) than with me?

Maven therapists and career coaches who work with new moms returning to work say this is a common fear. The good news? Just acknowledging your emotions about sharing childcare duties with others puts you on the right path toward a successful parent-caregiver relationship. Unexamined feelings about leaving your baby in the care of someone else may lead to resentments, anger, and even acting-out. Put in this way: Over time, if you start to do things such as abruptly sweep your child away without allowing him time to transition out of the caregiver environment, he may become anxious at pick-up times.

As normal as it is to feel jealous of a closeness between your child and someone who isn’t you, remember this: Finding a childcare provider who is loving, nurturing, and has the capacity to form a bond with your baby is ultimately a huge success on your part. The plight of the working mother is immense, and knowing your child is in good hands can make it a lot easier. Rather than feeling displaced by caregivers, try to see them as a valuable teammate supporting you in your motherhood journey.

title.en-US: How to make new friends if you’re a busy working parent

content.value: Once you’re back at work, it can be tricky to squeeze in time to connect with other new parents. Who can meet up for coffee and play dates at 11 AM on a weekday? Why aren’t there any Rock ‘n’ Roll Baby classes at, like, 7:30PM? (OK, it’s a little late for a 5-month-old but still...) If it’s been tough to make new parent friends, we’ve got a few strategies to help:
Establish a playground routine

Hit the local park or playground on a Saturday or Sunday and you might notice that you see the same parents and kids all the time. You may gradually get to know a few of them and make friends without much effort, but don’t be afraid to approach a friendly-looking parent and say hi. As odd as it may feel to strike up a conversation with a stranger, the awkwardness is worth it, and you might be surprised to find they’re just as eager to talk to you.
Look for weekend children activities

Check out baby events at your local bookstore, library, and museums, or sign up for regular classes (such as baby swim). Again, go regularly and you might eventually see some familiar faces. Even if they don’t turn into life-long friendships, consider this another outlet to seek out parenting ideas and opinions—while also teaching your little one how to socialize.
Try an app

Ever wish there was a way to meet new parents the same way single people meet? There is! Peanut, for instance, is an app that allows moms to “wave” at a potential friend who lives in the area based on profile information like work schedules, kids’ ages, and other interests.
Check in with parents from your birthing class

Often, contact information is passed around during the last class so that parents can get in touch with each other once the baby is born. Dig out the list and reach out to a few people you were fond of to plan a reunion. If you had a good experience with your instructor, you could also contact them and ask for recommendations to local new parent groups.
Spend a little extra time at daycare during your drop-off/pick-up times
This is an especially good place to look for new friends because, chances are, you’ll meet parents who are are juggling a busy work schedule, just like you.

title.en-US: 4 safety tips for dressing your baby in cold weather

content.value: Getting a little human dressed when the temps drop can feel like a guessing game. These tips can help.
Layer, but don’t over-layer.
Experts say they often find that parents do a great job of keeping little ones warm—but sometimes too warm, to the point that babies overheat even when there’s a snowstorm outside.
Keep the puffer coats out of the carseat.

For safety reasons, no extraneous materials should come between the belt and your baby; the straps and harnesses will be much more secure without a jacket. In extra cold weather, you could dress your child with extra layers (go for warm but non-bulky pieces, like a thin fleece). Still too frigid? Layer on a blanket after you’ve buckled him in, and remove it once the car warms up.
Invest in a winter hat.

In summer, hats are all about sun-protection. But babies lose a lot of heat from their heads, so a warm topper is a must when you’re going for a stroll in cold weather. And don’t forget the mittens and footed pants, since your baby’s extremities are especially prone to getting cold in nippy weather. Socks get lost easily, so nothing beats a pair of footsies.
Have a safe “crib wardrobe.”

Even if it's cold when you put your little one down to sleep, blankets aren’t recommended, since they can cause suffocation or strangulation. Instead, dress your baby in a sleep sack (it’s like a baby-sized sleeping bag with holes for his head and arms).

title.en-US: 6 ways working parents can stay organized

content.value: Investing a little time and energy upfront to anticipate and plan can greatly reduce the stress that comes hand in hand with juggling a job and a family, says Sara Daly-Padron, a Maven work coach. Here, Daly-Padron offers her six essential tips for keeping chaos at bay.
Hold a weekly “Family Strategy Meeting.”

Knowing what lies ahead each week is the first step to managing it. Set your timer for 60 minutes on Sunday evening and sit down with your partner to set family priorities for the seven days in front of you. What do you want to accomplish as a family? Setting specific intentions and priorities for the week can help you feel in control of your time, because let’s face it—a lot of parenting is reacting to other’s needs. Also use the time to review schedules, discuss upcoming events and agree to own tasks that need to be accomplished. If time remains, get a jump-start on the to-do lists by folding laundry or chopping veggies for healthy snacks to grab on the go. Pro tip: As soon as the school calendar is released, sit down with your partner to manage coverage for vacation days, decide who will attend school events, and block time for parent conferences on your work calendars to avoid conflicts later in the year.
Write it down!

Does your mind ever wander in a meeting with a reminder to take out the trash or buy more diapers? The mental load, or constant “to do list” chatter in our mind, can cause us to lose focus, lower productivity and can eventually lead to burnout. Taking your to do list out of you head and onto paper (or your computer/phone) not only guards against forgetting, but frees up mental space for focusing on the tasks at hand. Pro tip: Find a solution that fits your style and that you will use consistently. Print out a calendar to hang in your kitchen if you prefer a low-tech solution, or use Google or iCal to keep tabs on schedules and events. A family organizer app like Cozi is a one-stop shop to create lists, share calendars, manage meal planning and even create a family journal.
Use your “village.”

As a working parent, there are some responsibilities that you must share with others because there just aren’t enough hours in the day. The best way to drop the guilt that can creep in when we can’t “do it all” is to understand what responsibilities are most important to your parenting experience and find a way to do those yourself. Perhaps being home to read bedtime stories is important to you, even if it means checking in with work afterwards. Work with your manager to make that a reality. Next, decide what tasks others can help with, like stopping for groceries, and ask for help. Talk with other parents and come up with creative ways to share the load. Pro tip: I recently started a meal swap with another family. When I’m cooking on Tuesday nights, I double my recipe and share, and they do the same on Thursdays. One less night to cook and it adds variety to our meals!
Start each day the night before.

Ever feel like you’ve lived a full day before you even got to the office? The morning rush can be super-stressful for working parents trying to get themselves and the kids ready and out the door. Thirty minutes before you go to bed, pack everything you and your child will need the next day; doing this at night can make the morning less hectic. This includes your work-bag, lunches, school/diaper bags, etc. Pro tip: Help avoid a wardrobe hold-up in the morning by pulling out your clothes the night before.
Simplify your choices.

Making even simple decisions when you are sleep deprived and under stress can feel nearly impossible. Reduce the number of decisions that need to be made. For instance, make breakfast a no-brainer by limiting your choices to one or two fast, easy-but-nutritious options like yogurt with granola or cereal with fruit. Pro-tip: Make a few days of worth of breakfast in advance—like oatmeal in jars that you can quickly microwave at home or when you get to the office.
Have a backup plan (before you need it).

Even the best-laid plans are interrupted when your child wakes up with a fever or your caregiver calls out sick. Knowing what options you have in advance can help keep your stress levels down and help navigate the bumps in the road. Know your employer’s take on sick or flex time; some employers even provide emergency backup care so speak with your HR team to understand your benefits. Pro tip: Pre-register an extra friend or neighbor at the daycare to pick up your child if you are running late.

title.en-US: Tips for leaving your baby overnight for the first time

content.value: The idea of an overnight stay without your baby is enough to leave new parents giddy, petrified, or a little bit of both. Whether you’re planning a business trip or a quick escape with your partner, being away from your baby for the first time is never easy. But with preparation and a trusted caregiver, your baby will handle your time apart like a rock star—and so will you.
1. Use a familiar caretaker (or two).

Whether it’s Grandma or your nanny, choose someone your baby is familiar with (and obviously someone you deeply trust). You might even consider assigning shifts—like having your babysitter come over during the day, and your best friend or sister take over at night. And whenever possible, have the sitter come to you. Besides keeping your child’s surroundings the same, you’ll eliminate the risk of forgetting to bring some essential item.
2. Provide instructions in detail.

When you’re leaving a cheat sheet for your caregiver, get as specific as possible to avoid any misunderstandings or throw a wrench in your child’s routine. A “few” Cheerios could mean six little O’s to you but half a cereal box to someone else. And just because you think it’s a no-brainer to dress your little one in a hat on a scorching day doesn’t mean everyone would. PS: Written rules leave less room for misunderstandings.
3. Write your contact information down in one place and make it available for easy access (such as on your fridge).

This includes your cell number as well as the details of your getaway address (phone number of the hotel, etc.). Also consider leaving the name and number of a friend or relative who lives in the neighborhood and can swing by quickly to help out in case of an emergency .
4. Have a practice run.

If your child isn’t used to being put down at night by anyone but you, then it may be worth scheduling a night visit prior to the trip. This way, your caretaker can get acquainted with the evening routine and observe actually how you do it.
5. Try not to feel too guilty.

If it helps you to check in and have the sitter facilitate a Facetime with your child, go for it. Do whatever you need to do to feel better about your time away. But try to ditch the guilt—you’re allowed to be away from your child. And imagine how good those snuggles will feel when you’re back at home.

title.en-US: Does baby talk help or hurt your child's development?

content.value: If you adjust the way you speak when you talk to your infant, you’re not alone. Find out what kind of an impact the cutesy convos are having long-term.

You might still be a few months away from hearing your little one’s first words, but you’re probably already spending a lot of time chatting up your infant, just waiting until you’re on the listening end.

It turns out, the more "baby-talk" you use with your child, the quicker she may be able to grasp the meaning of words. Scientists at the University of Edinburgh in Scotland conducted a long-term study to see whether baby talk affected a child’s language development. It did—but in a positive way! They discovered that kids who were exposed to more “baby talk”—i.e. look at the doggy, there’s the “choo-choo” train—had a better handle on language and vocabulary than children who didn’t get the cutesy version of words. (In the study, kids were evaluated at nine, 15 and 21 months.)

So the next time someone in your local mom group tells you that baby talk is “dumbed down” and you’re depriving your child of learning, you can now respond with science on your side: By making words easier to understand, your little one could become a sesquipedalian (and, unlike most people, he’ll know the definition of that is someone who uses big words).

title.en-US: Help! Why is my baby suddenly waking up during the night?

content.value: Note to all the bleary-eyed moms out there: You (and your baby) will sleep again, promise. But in the meantime, Nicole Avena, Ph.D., a Maven practitioner and author of What to Feed Your Baby and Toddler, helps explain the infant wake-up calls.

Babies' sleep patterns can be affected by many things, and sometimes it’s just their normal development. As newborns, babies jumps right into a deep sleep stage. But around 4 months old, little ones start to have more light and deep sleep phases (and more light sleep phases means there are more chances that your baby will be easily aroused—even by the sound of a mere breeze—and end up awake in the night).

While your baby’s wakefulness may be a result of normal development, if you want to rule out other causes, play detective. As your baby grows, he needs fewer and fewer nighttime feedings, so as long as he gets his calories throughout the day, the problem most likely isn’t hunger. Think about any changes you might have made recently. Did you switch out your baby’s mobile over the crib for a sound machine? Does your baby no longer fall asleep in your arms or by your side? What do you notice about your baby when she wakes up in the middle of the night? Something as simple as hearing the heat turn on or an AC unit switch on and off could be the culprit. Other times, it’s a wet diaper, a cold coming on, or something less noticeable, such as itchy pajamas.
Still can’t get to the root of the issue? Book an appointment with a Maven baby sleep coach for guidance that can help the whole family get better rest.

title.en-US: 3 little ways to be more present with your child after a workday

content.value: All day long, you looked forward to being back home with your family, but then you walk through the door, and you just feel so... distracted? Exhausted? Tense? All of the above? That’s normal. It can be hard to go from work mode to family mode in a snap, but these tips can help.
Schedule a baby meeting—and stick to it.

Treat this like any other meeting during your workday—show up on time, stay till the end, and have your game face on. Once you commit to a set hour or so for bonding with your family after work, your mind will be less likely to try to pull you into something else.
Put your devices in another room.

If it’s not realistic to step away from your phone/email until work the next day, that’s OK. But for the first hour of your re-entry time at home, try to put your gadgets in the other room. Use this as your reset time to re-engage with your family so you don’t feel “split” between your two worlds.
Get on your child’s level.

You might have heard that giving babies time to explore on the floor allows them a completely different perspective of the world. If you can’t drop the days to-dos from your mind, break out the playmat and get on the floor with your little one. Just like she’s seeing things differently from down there, you might start to see the world through her eyes, and momentarily shift your focus away from work distractions.

title.en-US: "Help! I cried at work after maternity leave and I'm embarrassed"

content.value: It happens.

Weeks and weeks of sleepless nights, a demanding job, challenging postpartum emotions. The truth is, even the most self-composed women may find themselves in a crying episode when they return to work after having a baby. So if you couldn’t shut down the waterworks, know that you’re not alone. Crying at work happens–and despite what it may feel like in the moment, it’s not the end of the world.

Even if you’re in a senior-level position in your company, your tears do not make you incompetent. In fact, showing vulnerability is one of the most admirable traits in a leader—and it gives permission to others to be human as well. If you need to excuse yourself from a meeting for a few minutes, go ahead. But don’t be afraid to acknowledge your tears. If being away from your baby is what triggered you, you could say something simple like: “I’m happy to be back at work but still adjusting to being away from my child.” Bottom line: There’s no need to be embarrassed about a very normal, automatic reaction—especially during a very stressful time.

title.en-US: Is it normal to second guess your childcare decision?

content.value: “Help–I’m falling out of like with our caregiver!”

You did all the legwork to find a childcare option you felt good about, so it’s understandable if this is upsetting to you now. But if you have a sense that things aren’t working out—whether with your daycare center or a nanny—it’s important to acknowledge your feelings and be honest with yourself if you feel something is “off.”

Have you asked yourself what’s making you second guess your decision? Are you feeling like you (or your child) aren’t as happy to see the caregiver as you were in the beginning? Has she become a little lax at meeting your expectations, or does she leave out important details about the day? Or is there something else going on—like constant lateness or an unwillingness to respond to your texts in a timely manner?

Try to identify the root cause of your newfound discomfort. And if you need help addressing the situation with your current caregiver or exploring other options, know that Maven providers can guide you through the process.
Bottom line: Working parenthood will be a lot easier if you truly believe your child is thriving in the care of someone else. If you have any doubts, don’t ignore your feelings.

title.en-US: How can I say no when people ask to hold my child?

content.value: Not surprisingly, everyone want to get their mitts on your adorable baby.

To be sure, parents have different feelings about handing their baby over to someone else. Some don’t even want visitors in their own home touching their little one, while others don’t sweat it even when a total stranger (like an airline stewardess or a nice waitress at the local diner) asks to hold their baby.

But saying no to someone who leans in to swoop up your little one can be tricky. How can you tactfully tell someone hands-off—whether you’re concerned about germs, your baby is finicky with strangers, or something else?

One method that tends to limit the awkwardness: Simply say that your pediatrician advised not letting anyone hold the baby until she gets her next round of shots. You could also blame it on the baby, and say she’s been very fussy lately, so you’re making an effort to leave her be for a little while to help her relax. Another tactic: Wear your baby in a sling, and say that it was so hard to get the darn thing on, that you’d rather not take her out of the carrier. When all else fails, be honest and say you’re just not comfortable passing your baby around till she’s a little older.

title.en-US: Study says: Babies get even cuter with age

content.value: Warning: Approaching peek adorableness is about to happen any day now.

Disclaimer—this is not the kind of experiment you hear about everyday. Researchers at Brock University in Canada showed 142 participants photos of babies taken shortly after birth, at 3 months old, and at 6 months old. On a cuteness scale, here were the results: The 6-month-olds had the highest ratings, while the adults rated the newborns as the least attractive.

Shocked that cuteness seems to peek at the half-year mark? So were the researchers. The prevailing theory on cuteness is that it’s an evolutionary mechanism that turns on the nurturing, caretaking, and protective instincts in adults. And since newborns are the most vulnerable, it would make sense if they were seen as the cutest.

But if you identify with the results of the study, and you didn’t fawn over your baby right away, now you know it’s totally normal. As long as you’re giving your baby love, affection, and care, you can trust that the “heart skips a beat for baby” phase comes on its on time—and it may be just around the corner.

title.en-US: "Help! My BFF and I have different parenting styles"

content.value: Real-world advice from Danika Severino Wynn, a Certified Nurse Midwife and International Board Certified Lactation Consultant on Maven.

It’s so wonderful to have close friends who are also parents. That said, it can also be incredibly challenging when pals take vastly different approaches to raising their kids. But the truth is, differences are very common—even among couples who co-parent. Feeding, diapering, disciplining, bed-sharing—these are all topics ripe for big (and controversial) opinions. The good news? With some care, you can definitely keep your relationships strong even if your parenting philosophies seriously clash. Here’s how:
1. Keep advice to a minimum.

When you and your friends parent differently, it can be easy to try to share advice or give your thoughts on why they should change their ways. Even if you think you have the solution to a pal’s parenting problem, It’s often best to keep your parenting advice to yourself unless it’s requested. Even if you are trying to help, it can come off as being judgemental and may cause a riff in your friendship.
2. Know when to speak up.

This may be less of an issue with babies, but when your kids are a little older and a friend’s parenting decisions cause concern for your child’s safety, then you need to address the issue. If your friend has taken a stance against formal discipline, for instance, and her child shoves your daughter at the playground without being stopped, staying mum won’t be an option. Choose your words wisely, and explain your specific concerns without making generalizations. You might say: ‘I just wanted you to know that my daughter is unhappy about playing with your son because he has shoved her the last few times at the playground. I’d like us all to stay friends. What do you think we could do about it?” A strong friendship can likely handle this type of conversation if it’s honest and full of good intent.
3. Find time to hang out without your children.

Even if you have kids around the same age, it’s important to have girlfriend time without your children around to remember why you are such great friends. It can give you an opportunity to reconnect, share ideas, and de-stress.
4. Focus on shared values.

Try to find similarities in your parenting styles instead of focusing on the differences. It will help minimize frustrations and strengthen your friendships. Ultimately, having a strong social network and core community of good friends can be very rewarding for parents and their little ones.

title.en-US: How mindfulness can help with postpartum stress

content.value: In a word: Yes! Rebecca Callahan, a Women's Health Nurse Practitioner at Maven Clinic and mom of two, shares her mindfulness tips for coping with the chaos.

You had a baby. You survived labor and delivery. And now you brought that baby home. What could be more blissful? Oh wait—you are sleep deprived, your baby won’t stop screaming, and there is poop everywhere! Motherhood is certainly full of ups and downs, extreme highs and rock-bottom lows. I’ve been there. And while mindfulness may seem like just a buzzword these days, I’ve experienced first-hand the benefits that come with it—especially in the postpartum period.
First, what is mindfulness and how can it benefit new moms?

Mindfulness is a state in which you focus your mind on the present moment. You can practice mindfulness in many ways, including deep breathing and sitting in meditation. And in the process, you learn how to feel different emotions and embrace what is going on around you without reacting. The benefits of meditation and other mindfulness practices are countless. Meditation helps reduce stress, improves your mood, allows you to get better sleep, and helps you to remain calm in the face of a baby crying ceaselessly at 3 AM. During the postpartum period, you are on an emotional roller-coaster, in part due to your dramatically shifting hormones. Meditation can help keep you stay centered and prevent you from being too reactive in triggering situations (like during an argument with your partner or a difficult moment with your little one).
How can a beginner learn to meditate?

There are a million ways to meditate. While escaping to a meditation retreat in India for three months may not be on the menu at this point in time, there are quicker, easier mindfulness fixes available to you in your own home. Deep breathing is a good place to start. You might want to associate this practice with something like diaper changing time (something you can do in little bursts of time throughout the day) or put up sticky notes around your living space to remind you to breathe. The technique can be very simple—such as taking several slow, deep breaths and focusing fully on what you’re doing (yes, even changing a diaper). The increased oxygen intake decreases your stress hormones and allows you to think more clearly. After your breathing break, stop and reflect for a moment. Notice the sensations in your body. Guided meditations (you can find them via apps or on YouTube) are also very helpful for the novice practitioner. If you fall asleep while meditating, that’s OK! It just means you were tired and your body is repairing itself.

Speaking of sleep, when you lie down to take a nap or turn in for the night, doing a body scan is a nice mindfulness practice. Start with your toes and work your way up to the top of your head. Pause to feel each body part and silently state, “Toes, relax.” “Ankles, relax.” Let go of any control over your breathing and just let your body breathe naturally. Imagine your physical form melting into the mattress.
The bottom line:

Meditation is really not as scary as it sounds, and you can start small. You can always reach out to me on Maven’s platform for a face-to-face training or tune-up session anytime. I would enjoy hearing about how your mindfulness practice is going and can answer any questions you have.

title.en-US: 6 ways to trust yourself as a parent—and tune out the haters

content.value: Let Danika Severino Wynn, a Certified Nurse Midwife and International Board Certified Lactation Consultant on Maven, help you deal with all of your (perfectly normal) parenting insecurities.

Pregnancy and becoming a parent attract a ton of advice and an absurd amount of judgment. With so much coming at you about how to be a “good” parent and so many differing opinions on how to raise your child, how does one know what is right or wrong for you? Should you breastfeed? If so, for how long? Do you introduce solids at 4 months or 6 months? Can you take your baby out in public when they're first born? How will you know what your baby needs when they cry? Is sleep training OK? It can all be a bit overwhelming.

The good news is there is no “right” answer; there are many ways to raise a healthy, happy child. Plus, if you're questioning how you'll raise your baby, that likely means you care a whole lot—a great indicator that you're going to be just fine at this parenting thing! Here's some advice I like to share with new parents about trusting themselves to make great decisions and coping with the judgment they may encounter.
1. Remember, no one knows your baby like you do

You'll be surprised at how quickly you're clued in to exactly what your baby needs based on their cries, their favorite way to be held, what makes them sleepy, and what they need to thrive and grow. Anyone telling you how you “should” do things isn’t privy to all these unique attributes of your baby.
2. Feel free to ask people to keep their opinions to themselves

Know someone who likes to dole out unsolicited advice and judgment on the regular? Even if it’s a close friend or family member, there's a nice way to ask them to pipe down. Simply tell them that it's a bit overwhelming to get so much advice and you'll be sure to ask them for their opinion if you need it. That often gets the message across that uninvited “guidance” isn't welcome.
3. Read some books if you’d like—but don’t take any of them too seriously

There are thousands of parenting books geared at teaching parents the “right way” to take care of and raise their children. My advice? “Take what you like and leave the rest.” In other words, take what makes sense to you and works for your family, and leave what doesn’t behind.
4. Talk to your friends who have older kids or find a support group

Friends who experienced some of the same issues you're facing—but have some distance from them now—can be a helpful resource. Support groups for new parents are also a great place to share ideas. It can be helpful to hear the diversity of their experiences and solutions—another reminder that there isn't just one way to parent!
5. Use your pediatrician as a resource

Pediatric health care providers can give guidance using evidence-based research—instead of popular opinion. It can be reassuring to hear an expert’s advice if you're unsure about the best decisions to make in caring for your child.
6. Create a judgment-free zone for playdates

It’s so wonderful to have close friends who are in in the same life stage that you're in. It can also be incredibly challenging when these close friends parent their children in a very different style than you do. When you and your friends spend time together with your children present, refrain from creating a competitive environment or dwelling on how your parenting styles conflict. Try to find similarities in your parenting styles instead of focusing on the differences.
Bottom line:

Babies don’t come with an instruction manual but the good news is your instincts as a new parent are likely your best guide. Trust your gut and do what is right for you and your family, because the rest is just noise.

title.en-US: How to make peace with a delivery that didn't go as planned

content.value: Having a lot of feelings surface after an unexpected birth experience is common. Here, Danika Severino Wynn, a Certified Nurse Midwife and International Board Certified Lactation Consultant on Maven, offers her perspective to help you come to terms with how things turned out.

When women come to see me for their 6-week postpartum visit, we talk about their birth experience and how they are feeling emotionally. Often new parents describe their awe at how different the experience was from what they thought would happen. Some feel grief, others are angry, some simply laugh as they think back to what they expected. Many people need a lot of support processing what exactly happened, and it’s important to know that whatever you are feeling is normal, valid, and deserves serious attention.

I try to help new parents remember that birth can be a blur, and giving them a chance to recall their experience from their own point of view (either telling it or writing it down) can help bring clarity to a confusing situation. Often they have questions about the order in which events occurred or why something happened. I remind them that adrenaline, hormones, and the inevitable sleep deprivation from a long labor can make the details hard to remember—but over time, things might make more sense. I’ve found that as time passes, most people have an easier time accepting their birth experience as uniquely their own. But in those first few months, when the baby blues and the postpartum hormonal roller coaster are in full effect, accepting what happened is harder to do.
If your own birth didn’t go as planned, and you’re struggling to make peace with that, here’s what I recommend:
1. Talk to your birth team.

Your doula, partner, or other support person may have a very different point of view than you do and may shed light on parts of the experience that you may not recall clearly or feel upset about. Sometimes speaking with others helps you to better understand and process your feelings.
2. Forgive yourself.

There is no “perfect birth” and there is no “right way” to have a baby. Don’t let other people’s judgments or expectations tinge your experience. Babies come into the world in many different ways and what keeps them healthy and happy is your care and love.
3. Write down your birth story.
It can be cathartic and can help you see more clearly how powerful you were as you labored and birthed your baby.
4. Share your feelings.
Join a new parents’ support group or open up to your close friends and family. You may find that just talking about what happened instead of keeping it bottled up brings you relief.
5. Ask for help if you need it.

Sometimes these feelings can be overwhelming and can be a sign of postpartum mood disorders. Birth trauma is real and can impact a person’s life significantly. If your emotions are feeling too overwhelming, talk to your healthcare provider about screening for postpartum mood disorders and/or book an appointment with a Maven therapist for additional support.

title.en-US: Why babies go on a nursing strike—and what to do about it

content.value: Why would a baby refuse to nurse when breastfeeding has been her favorite source of nourishment and comfort day and night? As hard is this can be for a new mom, Maven Lactation Consultant Nina Wilson, IBCLC, offers the reassurance that a feeding strike is usually a temporary setback. Here, Wilson explains some common reasons babies refuse the breast and how to help get your breastfeeding relationship back on track:
Pain

Babies often refuse the breast when they are experiencing pain, like when they are teething or have an ear infection. An infant pain reliever can be helpful; just check with your doctor or a Maven pediatrician before you give an infant any medications, as dosage and type are very important to get right with a little one. A “popsicle” made of frozen breast milk is another way to offer relief from teething pain.
Illness

When a baby is congested or has a cough, breastfeeding can become difficult and tiring—mostly because your little one could have difficulty breathing during this time, so nursing doesn’t interest him. Before a nursing session, you could try using a nasal aspirator on your little one. Placing a few squirts of saline solution in each nostril first can loosen secretions and offer temporary relief so your baby can breathe easier at the breast.
Stress

Stress from changes in routine or when your baby reaches a new developmental milestone can cause your baby to temporarily refuse the breast. Spending time with your baby in a relaxed, calm environment or taking a warm bath with your baby can encourage baby to relax and return to the breast.
Distraction

Around the 4-month mark, many babies become distracted by their environment and have trouble focusing on the task at hand: eating! Even simple objects like a bright lamp can take your baby’s focus away from nursing. This can also happen as babies become more mobile and can’t sit still long enough to nurse. If you find yourself with a distracted nursling, find a quiet, dimly lit place to nurse, or try nursing your baby when he is sleepy and less likely to become distracted. Make an effort to minimize the distractions in your environment as much as possible.
Changing scents or tastes

Babies become accustomed to mom’s scent, so you may find that wearing a strongly scented lotion or perfume confuses your baby and causes a disruption in breastfeeding. Save your perfume for date night and keep things natural while you are nursing. The taste of breast milk can also change with your diet or from herbal supplements or some medications. Don’t let this deter you from having a varied diet. Interesting tidbit: Babies have been found to prefer stronger flavors such as garlic in breast milk. Pregnancy and hormonal changes associated with the return of your period can also change the taste of your milk. Most babies do not mind this change but for some it can cause a disruption in breastfeeding which is often only temporary.
Decreased supply

Getting pregnant again or seeing your period return after birth can also cause a drop in supply. To help prevent this drop during their period, some women take a calcium and magnesium supplement during the second half of their cycle. During pregnancy, staying hydrated and eating oatmeal may help a bit, but since this drop is driven by hormones, there’s no guarantee that these attempts to increase supply will work.
Introduction of solid foods

Even as new foods are being introduced, it is important to make sure that milk is still the main source of calories for your little until his first birthday. Always offer breast milk before offering solids. If your baby seems less interested in nursing after starting solids, you may need to decrease the amount of solid foods or cereals you give him during the day.
Bottom line:

The most important thing during any feeding strike is to stay calm and continue feeding your baby. This may mean pumping and bottle or cup feeding until the strike ends. If you have a low milk supply, it may mean supplementing with formula. Babies sense our stress, so if you are feeling stress, your baby will pick up on it as well. Take measures to decrease your stress as well as your baby’s. Dedicate time for skin-to-skin contact with your baby near your breasts, and get in lots of snuggle time. Offer the breast while your baby is sleepy or in a relaxed way when your baby isn't too hungry. Remember that with some patience, your baby should be happily nursing again soon. If you need additional support,book an appointment with a Maven lactation consultant.

title.en-US: The best ways to spend your last week on maternity leave

content.value: Amy Brandon, MD, a Maven pediatrician and mom herself, shares her advice for making the most out of the last few days at home with your little one.

Yikes.... already?! No matter how short or long your maternity leave is, it goes by fast—much faster than you'd think for having been awake for most of it! Odds are, you've stressed enough about your re-entry date, so try and give yourself this last week free and clear of any worrying.

There may be a few tasks you’d like to get done—like another brunch with grandma, an afternoon filling out that baby scrapbook, a mommy & me yoga class that they somehow only hold during normal workday hours. But try not to overdo it. You’re gearing up for some significant changes in your routine, and you don’t need to add unnecessary pressure right now. Besides the basics—which I’ve listed below—make your main goal to relax.
Make sure you are all set with childcare.
This includes ensuring your partner is also involved with all the arrangements and ready to tag-team on logistics.
If you're breastfeeding and plan to pump at work, make sure you have all your the gear you will need.

This includes pump parts, nursing bras (I’m a fan of the Pumpease pumping bra), cleansing wipes, maybe some reading material, and definitely photos of your babe on your phone to help stimulate letdown and supply! You should also be aware of how your employer meets legal requirements for accommodating you (contact a Maven Lactation Consultant if you need guidance on these!), as well as how you plan to fit pumping and storing your milk into your workday.
Get your little one comfortable with taking a bottle.

Hopefully you’ve already introduced your baby to the bottle, but this week is a good time to practice that a little more often. It’s also smart to have someone else feed the baby while you're out of the room so he can get used to being fed by caregivers.
Do some kitchen prep.
Think about freezing meals you can eat later.
Stock up on necessities.
Set up recurring orders on Amazon (can't run out of diapers or mama snacks!).
Spend an hour or so planning out how your first weeks back will go.

Try to hammer out a specific schedule for certain recurring chores/events (laundry, house cleaning, yard-work, grocery shopping, other errands and upcoming appointments). A little thought up front will pay off with more time you can spend snuggling with your baby when you get home from work!
Take tons of photos and videos of your baby.
Trust me, these will get you through the commute and workday.
Soak up the love.

Your little one will never be this little again, and if you spend an hour just smelling his sweet head, that’s productive! If your baby has older siblings, try to spend some quality one-on-one time with them, too, as well as with your partner. Even if it seems impossible now, everything will work out, so trust yourself and enjoy your family.

title.en-US: Baby teething: What you need to know

content.value: Amy Brandon, MD, a Maven pediatrician and mom herself, shares her advice for getting through the dreaded teething phase.

Just when you finally figure out a routine, BAM: Teething. Not to worry—it doesn’t have to send your family into a tailspin. First, be aware that there is a huge range of variability in when babies start teething, how long it lasts, and how they tolerate it. That means it’s a good idea to avoid comparing your little one to other people’s babies. (That’s a good rule in general, by the way!) It's typical for first teeth to erupt sometime between 4 and 7 months, but this may happen earlier or later and still be totally normal. Some babies get several teeth at once with almost no fuss, whereas others take more time with each tooth and make sure they let you know about each and every minute of it. Gather your tools (see below), your partner's help, and get your game face on. Remember, sometimes the only way through... is through.
What can you do when teething starts?

Relax. It really won't be that bad. Make sure you have a couple of tools handy. Teething babies love gnawing on cold items, so have some clean washcloths ready to soak in cold water and let baby chew away. Other old favorites include frozen fruit chunks (banana, melon) or even frozen cubes of breast milk in mesh teether pouches. You may have also heard about teething necklaces made of silicone—this is jewelry you can wear that babies can safely chew.

Don't be afraid to go for the OTC meds—especially at bedtime—as long as you have your pediatrician’s approval. (Ibuprofen is approved for babies 6 months and up, while only Tylenol is considered safe for younger infants.) These can head off some overnight pain and be a real sanity-saver! Lastly, steer clear of numbing gels, "teething tablets", and amber necklaces; these have not been proven to work and can pose risks to your baby.
What else do you need to know?

Usually the major indicators of a teething baby are drooling, fussiness, and the drive to cram everything in reach into their mouths. Some babies may get a low-grade fever (up to 101F or 38.3C) with teething, and some may have looser stools than usual and/or a diaper rash. They may or may not have a tougher time sleeping, or they may or may not nap more than usual. This description of a teething baby may also fit any number of healthy, non-teething little ones with various viral illnesses, changes in daily routine, or just an average day in the life of normal babyhood.

As a parent, whether you prepare or don't for various stages, what your baby always needs most is your patience and understanding, your snuggles and your love. Try to keep in mind that this phase shall pass—and be sure to reach out to a Maven provider if you have any concerns or worry that teething might never end!

title.en-US: Are the benefits of breastfeeding overblown?

content.value: Nina Wilson, MSN, CNM, IBCLC, sets the record straight on “breast is best.”

I’ve worked with moms and babies for 18 years as a labor and delivery nurse, certified nurse-midwife, and IBCLC (International Board Certified Lactation Consultant). And having a lot of mom friends myself, the conversation in my personal life often turns to breastfeeding. In these conversations with my girlfriends, sometimes it is tough to separate truth from exaggeration regarding the real benefits of breastfeeding.

Here are just a few of the claims I’ve heard flying around: One of my girlfriends is convinced her baby will be a Harvard scholar because she breastfed for three years. Another mom is worried she should be saving for a tutor because she was unable to breastfeed (and therefore is concerned her child will be at an intellectual disadvantage). Another friend whose little one is suffering from ear infections feels guilty that she caused them by giving her baby formula; someone in her inner circle claims her toddler has “never been sick” because she has been exclusively breastfed.

With all these claims and opinions flying around out there, it’s easy for moms to feel like “breast is best”—and anything else is bad! Yes, breast milk is the perfect food for (most) babies; it contains all of the nutrients needed for optimal growth and development for the first 6 months of life and beyond. But the truth is it is difficult to prove the exact benefits which breast milk offers over formula. There are so many variables involved in caring for a baby and a baby’s environment, that giving all of the credit for good outcomes in a child’s life to breast milk is impossible.

So what are the proven benefits of breastmilk? When my pregnant friends ask me this question, I tell them a few things. First, we do know that breast fed babies have fewer gastrointestinal infections and eczema during the first year of life. There also seems to be a modest increase in cognitive ability and a small boost in IQ in breastfed children, but the specifics are still unclear. These benefits alone would seem to make breastfeeding the obvious choice, and in a perfect world all babies would be exclusively breastfed for 6 months or more. But my friends and I live in the real world where low milk supply, cracked nipples, mastitis, lack of maternal support, and insufficient maternity leave happen and breastfeeding is not always possible. It’s really important that we start having conversations that factor in these realities for all women.

Although we may not always agree on feeding preferences, we can all agree that as parents we control the most important variable in our babies’ development—giving them a loving and nurturing environment.

title.en-US: This is how much exercise you need to have an easier labor

content.value: New research makes another compelling case for hopping on that elliptical machine.

A May 2018 study of around 500 women in Spain adds yet another reason to dust off your gym shoes during pregnancy. For the study, which was published in The European Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology and Reproductive Biology, women were divided into two groups. One group participated in a moderate exercise led by an instructor three times per week. The other group was simply educated about the importance of physical activity during routine prenatal visits, but wasn’t involved in the exercise program.

So what were the results? The first stage of labor was an average of 53 minutes shorter for the exercisers. In fact, they had shorter labors overall and were less likely to get an epidural. The women non-exercisers also reported more weight gain during their pregnancies than those who consistently broke a sweat.

According to the CDC’s guidelines, healthy moms-to-be should get at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise per week, barring any pregnancy complications. Of course, you should talk to your doctor or Maven physical therapists are also available to help you develop a plan that works for specifically for you and your needs.

title.en-US: Is cramping after an orgasm normal while pregnant?

content.value: If your doctor gave you the go-ahead to have sex during pregnancy, there’s no reason to skip out on the bonding op with your partner. But what happens when you realize you’re cramping after an orgasm? That’s more common than you’d think, and don’t let it dampen your sex life. The truth is, cramping after sex doesn’t cause harm to your baby or you.
Your entire pelvic region, including your uterus, is more engorged with blood during pregnancy. So when your uterus contracts during orgasm, you naturally feel it a lot more.
