If you do start cramping after sex, just relax for a bit and see if it goes away. You only need to worry if the cramps get worse, or if they come and go on a consistent basis, since that could be a sign of preterm labor.

title.en-US: What you need to know about headaches during pregnancy

content.value: Another not-so-fun side-effect of pregnancy—you don't say?

According to Maven OB-GYNs, headaches are a common complaint in pregnancy. Wondering why? Well, the ever-changing hormones of pregnancy can play a big role in bringing on the ache. Headaches may also be due to emotional tension, lack of sleep, dehydration, and even bad posture. And if you were chugging coffee all day and have had to cut back, the caffeine withdrawal could also be a culprit.

So what can you do to cope, or even prevent them from coming on in the first place? Finding ways to keep stress in check, taking a daily walk, drinking plenty of water, and staying on a consistent sleep schedule are just a few ways to stay in the healthy lane and steer clear of headaches. But if these lifestyle changes don’t help, you might want to try keeping a headache diary. Write down the characteristics of your headaches, how frequently they’re occurring, and how long they last. Discussing the details with your doctor or a Maven provider can help you get to the root cause and find relief.

As for medications, most pregnant women can safely take acetaminophen (Tylenol) to treat the occasional headache, but always check with your doctor before popping any pills. PS: Aspirin and ibuprofen (Advil and Motrin) are usually not recommended during pregnancy.
If your headaches persist, become severe, or they’re accompanied by changes in your vision or difficulty speaking, call your doctor right away.

title.en-US: How to have a safe pool or beach day when you're pregnant

content.value: Advice to help you stay healthy and enjoy the down-time when you’re water-bound.
Be smart about the sun.

The dark patches many women develop on their skin—also known as melasma—are triggered by sun exposure. So find your happy place under an umbrella. Reapplying SPF is also key, since pregnancy hormones make you more sensitive to the sun. Experts recommend physical sunscreens (which reflect UV rays using ingredients like titanium dioxide or zinc oxide) over sunscreens that contain chemicals; check the label before slathering it on.
Own your bump.

Pregnancy may change your beach uniform—but it doesn’t have to. Wear a bikini (or don’t). Ditch the sarong (or don’t). Basically, wear whatever makes you feel the most comfortable in your body, whether that means baring less or baring it (almost) all.
Sip water; repeat.

When the mercury soars, it’s especially important to make sure you’re drinking enough water. After all, hydration in pregnancy goes well beyond quenching thirst—it's essential for the health of you and your baby. The lesson: Pack plenty of H20 in your cooler.
Get some water therapy.

You already know that exercise during pregnancy comes with many benefits. But water activity may feel especially great, because of the buoyancy and cooling it provides. If you’ve been starting to experience some of the aches and pains that are common during pregnancy, a light swim can help relieve sore joints. Foam noodles optional.

title.en-US: Too busy to cook? Tips to choose healthy when eating out

content.value: Let’s face it, just because good nutrition is a must during pregnancy doesn’t mean you’re always going have the time to whip up an organic meal from scratch. That’s OK! Use our guide to finding the best and worst choices whether you’re dining out or ordering in.
At an Italian restaurant

Sorry, but creamy pastas and thick-crust pizzas aren’t exactly the healthiest pregnancy food. Luckily, you can usually find plenty of nutritious—and still satisfying—options at your favorite Italian restaurant. Minestrone soup makes a good starter; it’s broth-based, and loaded with veggies and beans—which makes it a fiber all-star. If nothing will do but the pasta, go for it, but be smart about the sauce. While you probably already know that Alfredo sauce isn’t the wisest choice, you might be surprised to find out that even pesto can be a fat bomb unless you’re careful about the portion size. A 1/4-cup serving provides about 270 calories and 23 g of fat, thanks to a medley of high-cal ingredients: pine nuts, olive oil and Parmesan. A tomato sauce is your best bet, and keep your pasta portion to about a cup. (Fill up on salad and veggies.)
For dessert, skip the tiramisu or cheesecake, and go for a single scoop of sorbet. Sorbet doesn’t contain contains cream, so it can be a slightly better choice than gelato.
At a Chinese restaurant

A typical stir-fry could pack more than 4 tablespoons of oil (not to mention sugar—there can easily be 5 grams of sugar in a measly teaspoon of stir-fry sauce). Instead, scan the menu for the steamed dishes, and order fiber-rich brown rice instead of plain white rice when it’s available.

Choose main courses that contain plenty of vegetables to avoid a carb or meat overload; a typical meal at a Chinese restaurant is often enough to feed two adults. If you’re having a craving for a splurge meal, your best bet is to split it with a friend. And eat with chopsticks—they’ve been shown to help slow down your eating. The result: Your brain has time to catch up with your belly and you’re less likely to overeat.
At a Mexican restaurant

You probably already guessed that a tower of cheesy nachos isn’t exactly nutritionist-approved, so you’re better off skipping this appetizer. The good news? Guac is allowed. Avocados are packed with heart-healthy fats, and when you’re splitting this app with a few friends, you can enjoy without guilt. The real trouble is the chips; ask for a side of sliced veggies for dipping instead.

For an entrée, you can’t go wrong with shrimp or veggie fajitas. Just be sure to ask for plain beans instead of the refried variety, and skip the cheese in favor of an extra dollop of salsa. Go for corn tortillas instead of those made from processed white flour. Sadly, desserts at Mexican restaurants, such as churros and flan, are usually high in fat and calories. Save your sweet tooth for later or keep your indulgence to a bite or two.
Need more guidance about healthy eating on the go during pregnancy? Book an appointment with a Maven nutritionist.

title.en-US: Is it OK to sleep in separate beds during pregnancy?

content.value: Is it a do or a don’t?

As your pregnancy progresses, you might find that you’re willing to do (almost) anything to get an elusive good night’s rest. For some women, that means sleeping in a separate room from their partner. The reason may have to do with a partner’s snoring, or simply a growing bump that makes you feel like your bed isn’t big enough for two people.

Whatever the reason, you may be wondering what sleeping in separate beds could do to your relationship. While every couple is different, odds are this isn’t going to damage your bond. Remember, pregnancy is temporary—albeit challenging—and you and your partner can work together to get through it in a way that keeps you both happy, healthy, and—yes—rested!

The important thing is to look for ways to stay connected to each other throughout your pregnancy. Some couples opt to start the night together in one bed before one partner moves to another room—then they reunite for some skin-to-skin contact in the morning before going about their days. It’s the next best thing to investing in a California King.

title.en-US: What to do with maternity clothes after kids

content.value: If you’ve completed your family and are itching to get rid of those drawers full of pull-on pants, you’ve got a few options.
Donate them to charity.

It doesn’t get any easier than this. Wash your clothes, pack them up in bags or boxes, then hand them off so someone in need can benefit. Donations are tax deductible (check out www.IRS.gov for details), so remember to ask for a receipt. A few charities to consider: Goodwill, The Salvation Army, and any local women’s shelters.
Consign/sell them.

Try online marketplaces that do all the work for you while you’re busy, you know, raising a baby. ThredUP.com, for instance, will mail you a package for you to bundle up your stuff and ship it over. The staff will then inspect your items, take pictures of whatever they accept, and post them on their site. (You’ll be paid up to 70% of the resale value of the clothes.) Tradesy.com is another option, but you’ll have to do a bit more of the legwork, like snapping pictures of your items, and shipping items to individual buyers.
Offload them through your social network.
Prefer to have fewer degrees of separation between your clothes and where they end up? Try Facebook Marketplace via the Facebook app; it’s a ways of selling to friends and neighbors in your area.
Give them to your besties.
Friends don’t let friends spend money on maternity clothes. If you have a ready-made wardrobe to pass down, and your pals are expecting, share the goods.
Repurpose them.

Wrap dresses and cardigans can easily pass as everyday wear— just take your favorite pieces to your tailor adjust them to fit your post-pregnancy shape. If the price is right, you may find yourself with a brand new wardrobe, for a fraction of the cost of a shopping spree.

title.en-US: Life after baby: 4 ways to get more out of therapy

content.value: People often seek therapy when significant events happen in their lives: marriage, divorce, a career switch, the death of a loved one. Giving birth is just as life-impacting, and having an outlet for support, can make a big difference as you navigate your new “normal.” And you don’t have to be in a full-blown depression to seek counseling; therapy often gives you tools that can improve your relationship with yourself, your partner, and your baby—and any new mom can benefit from that. What’s more, couldn’t we all use an objective audience to help us with our daily challenges and worries?
If you’ve taken the big step to see a therapist (in person or online through Maven), congrats. Here are four little tips to help you make the most out of each session.
1. Be honest.

Therapists have heard it all (and everything you discuss is confidential), so don’t hold back. Research has found that sometimes people lie to a counselor out of shame or embarrassment, but being as open as you can be will help you in the long run. Once a therapist really gets to know, she can offer better reflection and guidance.
2. Focus on short-term goals.

Often, people get frustrated in therapy because they expect to feel 100% better overnight. But progress takes time. Ask your therapist to help you identify ways to gauge the micro-steps you’re making; keeping tabs on these little improvements will help you feel better about the process and keep you motivated.
3. Remember that it’s OK if therapy doesn’t always feel great in the moment.

You may feel uncomfortable or sad at times, or even dread the video calls (at first), but it’s part of the process. Hang in there, and always let your therapist know if you ever need to back off a topic if it gets too intense. You always have a voice.
4. Prepare, but don’t stress too much about it.

If you’re worried you’ll forget what you want to discuss, spend a few minutes jotting down some thoughts in a journal before you and your therapist connect. But don’t worry if nothing big comes to mind—sometimes it’s the little things that weigh on you day-to-day that you need to air out in therapy.

title.en-US: 4 no-brainer ways to save money when you’re having a baby

content.value: In addition to the immense joy you’ll feel when you hold your little one for the first time, you’ll also soon start to feel the sticker shock when you realize just how expensive having a baby can be. Here are a few strategies to help you start saving now.
Get savvy about the nursery.

Sure, it’s tempting to furnish your nursery with all brand spanking new items, but if it’s a stretch for your budget, think creatively. One resourceful mom we spoke with realized that her old horizontal wood filing cabinet was the perfect height for a changing table, so she topped it with a changing pad and used the ample drawer space for diapers. A simple lamp that got little use in the corner of her kitchen was also moved to the nursery; an inexpensive lampshade in baby blue made it the perfect old/new item.
Cut back on eating out.

The average household spends an average of $3,008 per year on dining out, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. While you may not have the energy to cook from scratch every night right now—and that’s OK—making some simple meals for work lunches and dinners at home could be a huge money-saver over the long haul. If the nesting instinct strikes in the third trimester, try to cook in big batches so you can freeze some meals to defrost and eat—faster than it takes for the delivery guy to arrive.
Hunt for coupons for everyday baby items.

You’ll eventually need diapers and baby food, and even if you decide to breastfeed, formula might become a necessity at some point. Search out coupons online, highlight the expiration dates, and stick them in a folder. That way, you’ll have them ready-to-go when you need them.
Choose items that grows with your baby.

You’ll hear it again and again. “They grow so fast!” With that in mind, shop for things that can conform to different stages of your child’s life. For instance: cribs that turn into a toddler bed; high chairs that transform into toddler-friendly booster seats, etc. The same goes for baby clothes—your baby may grow out of 3-month-sized clothes after just a few weeks, so consider buying things that may be a smidge big until your baby grows into them. The more use you can get out of anything baby-related, the longer your dollars will stretch.

title.en-US: 3 women share what they were doing when they went into labor

content.value: Even if you’ve completed the nursery, wrapped up things at work, and packed your go-bag with everything you could possibly need at the hospital, there will always, always be surprises when the big day finally arrives. We asked three moms to share how it all went down:
Cristina, Nurse, Manhattan, NY

“About a month before my due date, I was at home with my older child, just folding up the last of the new baby clothes and sliding them into the Ikea dresser. I remember having major nesting feelings around this time, and I was bugging my husband to assemble the Ikea dresser we had just bought for the nursery. He told me me it was fine and to stop stressing out because we still had a whole month to go. But, believe it or not, as soon as I finished putting away the last onesie, my water broke. I made it to the hospital and was still in triage. I hadn’t been seen by a doc yet when my friend’s friend (who happens to be a doctor at the same hospital) stopped by just to say hello. Little did he know, I was already quite far along—and he literally ended up catching Sophia my daughter as she was coming out!”
Nora, Lawyer, Brooklyn, NY

“I had the day off work, and suspected that something was going on, but the baby was taking his time. So I went out and got a foot massage and acupuncture. That evening, my husband and I headed the hospital so I could be checked out, but we were told to go home. It was the worst–the train was not running at our stop, so the platforms were packed. I was terribly and grossly pregnant and we had to walk almost 20 blocks in New York City humidity in order to get our train. Yuck! After we got home, it took me a while to wind down and finally fall asleep--only to wake with ripping pains down my back three hours later. I knew this was it! But I also thought it could probably take a while. I had just dragged my husband into the Manhattan on a wild goose chase, so I didn’t want to do it again, particularly in the middle of the night. I paced the length of the apartment, took three showers, and let him sleep—until exactly at 6:30 AM, when I woke him and told him to get out of bed and take me to the hospital. He tried to take a shower, but the second I heard the water running I demanded that he get out so we could get a taxi. Neither of us realized that my that water broke in the cab on the way to the hospital. (I still feel really bad about not tipping that guy better!) When we finally got there, we were in business, and before I knew it, I had an epidural in me and was ready to deliver.”
Brittany, Corporate training executive, Attleboro, MA

“With my second child, I started having contractions around 1AM, 10 days before my due date. I hadn’t showered that day and I knew it would be a while until I’d get another chance, so I woke up my husband and hopped in the shower. He called his aunt to come watch our then two-year-old as my shower contractions were getting closer together. His aunt came right away, and we gave instructions on how to drop our toddler off to school. By the time we got in the car and started heading to the hospital, my contractions were about two minutes apart. I called my mom to let her know we were on our way. (She later told me that she thought it was false labor because I was able to have a full conversation with her, which she didn’t think was possible at this stage—but it was!). I had to wait in the ER for a few minutes before being admitted. Finally, a doctor was assigned to check in on me. When she realized I was 9 cm dilated, she called another doctor. She later admitted that in her 10-year career she never had another doctor check her work—but I was just too calm to be that far along. After verifying I was at the 10-cm dilated mark, both doctors jumped into the elevator with me and my husband and brought a birthing kit along just in case I had the baby in the elevator. An epidural, a few pushes, and a little while later we welcomed a healthy 6 lb, 2 oz little girl into our lives.”

title.en-US: What to know about the first 48 hours of breastfeeding

content.value: The first few days of your baby’s life can be a doozy—especially when it comes to feeding. Researchers at the UC Davis Medical Center surveyed 418 first-time mothers and found that almost all of the women said they intended to breastfeed, but three days after giving birth, 92% of them were having problems doing so. Keep reading for advice that could make those initial hours as a nursing mom a little easier.
The first milk that the mom produces is called colostrum.

Think of it as an uber-milk—highly concentrated in fat, protein, and other nutrients new babies need to build up their immune system. If your baby hasn’t quite learned to latch on yet, don’t worry. Squeeze a little colostrum from your nipple into your baby’s mouth. Just a couple of drops can help maintain your babies blood sugar—it’s that potent.
If possible, try to start nursing within an hour or two of your baby's birth.
She might not feed just yet, but simply nuzzling and licking will get her acquainted with the idea. Bonus: This will stimulate milk-producing hormones so your breasts are ready when she is.
Every two to three hours after birth, serve up the breast.
Skin-to-skin contact can help encourage feeding (and helps a baby feel less sleepy), so in the first 24 hours, try to establish a routine of snuggling without the onesie on.
Look for clues that your baby’s ready to latch.

When babies are in distress, they may to want to nurse but can’t calm down enough to latch on. That’s why it can help to look for signs that they’re hungry before the crying fits begin. Your baby might put her fist to her mouth or make sucking noises. Or she may start rooting and opening her mouth wide.
You may be calling for the nurse every time you give the breast.

As one mom told us, “I remember being at the hospital those first two days and beckoning for the nurse every single time my son wanted to eat. Whether she was helping me get into a comfortable position, checking to see if there was a good latch, or just helping me feel less alone, it was so helpful to have hands-on assistance.” The lesson: Rely on the hospital staff as much as you need to, and remember that lactation counselors can be the same source of support when you’re back at home with your little one.

title.en-US: 9 money mistakes new parents make and how to avoid them

content.value: Funny how a tiny baby can so dramatically shake up every aspect of your life—from your sleep schedule to what you eat to how you spend your free time. But perhaps even more so, a baby can increase your household expenses, and they’ll only continue to balloon as he grows older. Experts say avoiding these common money mistakes can alleviate a lot of financial stress later on.
Mistake #1: Not fully understanding your employer’s maternity leave policy.

If you’re entitled to paid sick/personal days and have been saving them up, make sure you’re using them to maximize your cash flow during your time away from the office. Check your HR policy on batching together PTO days with your leave benefits.
Mistake #2: Not adding your baby to your health plan immediately.

Though you may have a month or two to add your baby to your healthcare policy, as new parents, each day will feel busier than the next, and you definitely don’t want to forget to do this. Many healthcare plans require documentation and paperwork within a certain period in order for the cost of your baby’s medical care to be covered retroactively.
Mistake #3: Not shopping around during open enrollment.

When you don’t have kids, it’s easy to ignore your benefits department’s pleas to take a look at your current policy and make any adjustments—and just default to what you already have. But with a child, there’s more to consider; for starters, you’ll want a health insurance plan with a good network of pediatricians and pediatric dentists. You may also want to sign up for a flexible-spending plan to include child-care costs.
Mistake #4: Not starting a 529.
College is expensive, and it will only get more expensive 18 years from now. Check out the
U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission’s site
to start learning how to start saving now.
Mistake #5: Spending on baby items you don’t need.

Honestly, designer diaper bags, onesies, and furniture are more about making the adults happy than the baby. (All she’ll care about is having people that make her feel safe and loved.) If those status purchases are within your budget, and it’s genuinely what you want, by all means splurge. But if the price tag makes you wince a little, then you’re probably better off with a more economical choice (assuming, of course, it’s just as safe for your baby as the more expensive option). We promise your baby won’t hold it against you.
Mistake #6: Ordering in too much.

It’s tempting when you’re exhausted—pizza one night, Thai the next. But ordering in racks up your credit-card bill (not to mention your caloric intake). Think ahead, and make big batches, and freeze—so you cook only once but get two or three meals out of it.
Mistake #7: Not adjusting your budget.

An extra human being in your household adds to your expenditures, especially if you factor in childcare costs. So have a sit-down with your partner early on (before the baby arrives) and discuss where you can cut costs, whether it’s spending less on gifts or re-thinking your cable and phone plans.
Mistake #8: Buying baby items you don’t need just yet.

Would-be parents often spend tons of time and money on items that sit in storage for months (or even forever). For instance, you won’t be using a high chair for a good long while. Be practical about your needs before you shell out the cash.
Mistake #9: Flaking out on retirement saving.

Saving for college is important, yet so is saving for your own retirement. After all, your child can take out a loan for higher learning, but not so for the quality life you’re envisioning for yourself once you stop working. It’s normal to experience a shift in priorities when a baby enters your life, but don’t forget about yourself.

title.en-US: How to handle baby name regret

content.value:
You agonized to find the perfect name. Now you’re not so sure.
As they say, hindsight is 20/20. But when you settled on what to call your little one, you may not have been thinking about factors that could lead to name regret. For some parents, that oversight involved how a child’s initials are put together. Naming a baby Bradley Anton Dizik, for instance, leaves a son vulnerable to the nickname B.A.D.—maybe not the most ideal monogram for his preschool backpack one day. Then there’s the pronunciation issue: You assumed everyone would be able to say your child’s unique name, but everyone butchers it.

Other times, the source of naming regret can’t really be avoided—like when a negative association pops up. Say, for example, you named your little one Katrina months before hurricane Katrina occurred. Seeing “Deadly and Destructive Katrina” in the news headlines might not bring a new parent the warm and fuzzies. Or what about giving your child the name of a beloved relative, only to become estranged from that family member in the future? (Hey, it happens.)

In less dramatic instances, sometimes you simply fall out of love with a name, or wish you went with the second choice on your list (the one your partner voted for but you vetoed). Or you realize that literally half of the children at you kid’s daycare share the same name.

Your options? Well, you could change your baby’s name if it really bothers you (and, yes, some parents do go to those lengths). You could also accept that it may not be perfect, but your child is, and that matters more than any awkwardly monogrammed diaper bag. Lastly, you don’t have to keep your name regret to yourself or feel embarrassed about it. It’s OK to share your feelings with your partner or close friends. You’ll likely find that you aren’t the only one who thinks babies should be issued a temporary name for the first few months—until mom is 100% sure it’s a good fit.

title.en-US: Yet another reason to make eye contact with your baby

content.value: You’re probably already spending a lot of time gazing into your baby’s eyes. Now science says the benefits go beyond just bonding.

Not many parents can resist fixing their gaze on their little one, especially when that adorable little being stares back. You know your heart skips a beat during those, um, staring contests, but what happens to your brain? A 2017 study found that when a baby and an adult make eye contact, their brain waves sync up.
For the study, babies and adults wore headwear covered with electrodes that measured their brain behavior. The experiments included having an adult sing a nursery rhyme to a baby either while maintaining eye contact or looking away (like with head turned at a 20-degree angle).

The result: When people looked directly at the infants, babies' brains showed activity that closely mimicked that of the adults. However, when an eye lock didn’t happen, brain activity didn't sync up.

You may be wondering, What difference does it make if your brain waves match up with your baby’s? Well, being in “neural sync” (there’s a term you probably didn’t read in the pregnancy books!) may help your baby with vocalization and communication. In the study, babies made more sounds when eye contact with an adult was maintained. Drawing from other research, the experts also speculated that this insight could also have implications for your child’s learning abilities. In studies involving classrooms, when student's brain waves were synced up with their classmates, they had better concentration and engagement in the lessons being taught.
Isn’t it nice to know that something as easy as making eye contact with your child can have such a positive impact?

title.en-US: Why new moms should “eat like a baby”

content.value: Kendra Tolbert, a Maven practitioner and Registered Dietitian Nutritionist, shares her advice for learning from your infant’s noshing and nibbling habits.

The list of things you’ll someday teach your child is a mile long. How to spell their name, talk, read, brush their teeth, ride a bike. The list goes on and on. But if there’s one thing infants can teach you, it’s how to eat. Use these baby-inspired eating tips to nourish yourself as well as you care for your little one.
Have fun with your food.

Watch any baby eat and you’ll notice they’re not shy about expressing pleasure or enthusiasm about food. Observing them as they delight in meal-time reminds us that food is and is meant to be so much more than fuel for our bodies. Take a cue from your baby and relish your meals. Try adding herbs and spices that kick up the enjoyment factor; experiment with a a new cuisine; give yourself time to savor every bite.
Follow your internal cues.

Little ones are amazing at listening to and honoring their hunger and fullness cues. When they’re hungry, they let you know. And when they’re satisfied, they stop eating. Simple as that. Adults, especially busy moms, don’t always have an easy time spotting their own hunger and fullness signals. It can help to ask yourself questions like: “Am I truly hungry? Do I feel lightheaded because I haven’t eaten for a while? Does my body need this second helping?” Playing detective with yourself can help you tap back into your body’s innate wisdom.
Keep it balanced.

Our first food, whether it’s formula or breastmilk, is incredibly well-balanced. Filled with protein, fat, carbs, water, and micronutrients galore, it provides a beautiful example that healthy eating does not need to be complicated or cut out certain food groups. When you aim for balance in your meals and snacks, you’ll feel as content and satisfied as a “milk drunk” baby.

title.en-US: 3 ways to feel better in your postpartum body

content.value: Kendra Tolbert, a Maven practitioner and Registered Dietitian Nutritionist, shares an antidote to trying to erase the signs of pregnancy from our bodies: radical self-care.

Seriously, you and your body deserve an award. But instead of a gold medal, you’re likely being met with pressure (internal or external) to get your pre-baby body back. But you know what? That body hadn’t spent months and months giving tirelessly of itself to a growing little human inside it. That body didn’t change and grow in preparation for its new role as nurturer and protector. That body didn’t need time to head and recover from the Olympic-level sport called childbirth. So, rather than try to return to that body, let’s build this new one up. Simple self care is a surefire way to do that. These 3 tips can make a big difference as you get acquainted with this “today” version of your body.
Seek out body-positive inspiration online.

Social media can have a huge impact on how we feel about our appearance. That’s why it’s so important to fill your feeds with supportive messages and realistic images of women after having children, instead of photos that lead to harmful expectations or shame. Search #takebackpostpartum and #plusmommy to find accounts and posts of women who are learning to embrace their postpartum bodies.
Focus on healing instead of “fixing” your body.

Your body doesn’t need fixing—it needs TLC and nourishment. Knowing you’re giving yourself what you need to thrive can go a long way in helping you feel your best and giving you the energy you need as a new mom.
Be sure to incorporate foods into your diet that are rich in nutrients; a few not to miss: protein, zinc, vitamin C, and iron. Filling your grocery cart with beans, lentils, lean meat, fish, poultry, eggs, nuts, seeds, and a variety of colorful fruits and vegetables is a great act of self-care.
Practice self-compassion.

Take note of any automatic judgmental thoughts about your body. If a thought doesn’t pass the, “Would I say this to a friend test?” test, it’s something worth challenging when you hear it in your inner voice. Treat yourself as you would a person that you hold dear, because you are also deserving of that same acceptance and unconditional love.

title.en-US: 3 foods to help your mood after having a baby

content.value: As your post-pregnancy body goes through changes and you adjust to life with the new addition, it’s not uncommon to feel drained or a little down. In addition to talking to your healthcare providers and support team about how you might be feeling, you can use your diet to your advantage. Keep reading for the mood-boosting foods Kendra Tolbert, a Maven nutritionist, recommends to new moms.
Omega 3s

Making sure you get these essential fatty acids is just as important after pregnancy as it is when you’re expecting. Omega 3s are involved in many aspects of health—including brain health and mood. In fact, a low intake of omega 3-rich foods has been linked to an increased risk of postpartum depression. Eating fish low in mercury a few times a week is one great way to provide your body with these healthy oils; sardines, salmon, and tilapia are all good options. Walnuts, flaxseed, and omega-3 fortified eggs are other ways to get your fill.
Dark chocolate

If your postpartum cravings have led you to nibble on a square or two of dark chocolate a day, you may be satisfying more than just your taste buds. Cocoa has been linked to a boost in brain serotonin, the happy chemical. Not to mention, dark chocolate is loaded with other health-boosting properties like antioxidants and magnesium.
Aromatic foods

The scents of food can have an impact on your mood. A citrus snack, for instance, could provide a little pick-me-up when you’re low on energy; just the act of peeling an orange may boost alertness. And if you tend to feel anxious before bed and experience new-mom insomnia, a warm milk spiced with nutmeg may make falling asleep easier. Some people find that the spice helps them doze off.

title.en-US: How to handle the dreaded separation anxiety as a new mom

content.value: Tips to help you cope when the going (literally) gets tough.

One minute your little one is dozing happily in her Pack 'n Play, barely stirring when the phone rings; the next minute she’s wailing because you walked away. Child development experts call this phenomenon separation anxiety, but moms call it downright brutal. Some babies show early signs of it, even as young as 6 or 7 months (others don’t go through it until they’re a little older). Whenever it strikes, it can be that much harder to leave for work or run an errand. The good news? Separating yourself from your baby gets easier with practice. Here are a few tips you might want to try:
Leave your baby with someone she’s familiar with.

This could be your partner, Grandma or your best friend who’s been around a lot helping out since you gave birth—anyone who knows how to entertain and soothe your child and who won’t seem like a total stranger. If there hasn’t yet been a regular presence in your child’s life besides you, don’t worry. Have the caretaker over for just a visit, while you’re at home, so your child can get acquainted with her.
Start small.

Leaving your baby with another caregiver for a quick outing—like to go to the gym or grab a coffee—may help your child adjust to longer stretches without you. Soon enough, she’ll learn that even if you disappear from sight, you always come back.
Resist the urge to secretly slip out.

For many parents, the “she’s too young to notice I’ve left” exit strategy ends up backfiring. Many experts say it’s even more disorienting and anxiety-producing for your child if she doesn’t see you leave.
Make goodbyes short and sweet.

Prolonging the time you spend consoling a child who’s upset about you leaving will only make matters more difficult. She may even figure out that the harder she cries, the longer you’ll stay (kids are smart like that). Give her a hug and kiss, then make your exit. It’s OK if mom cries, too, but if you can, try to wait until you’re inside the car to unleash the tears.
The bottom line:

As hard as it is, separation is an important part of a child’s development. When kids feel cared for and nurtured by multiple people, they begin to learn that the world is a safe place. That said, if the struggle becomes overwhelming, always remember that Maven mental health counselors are available to chat with you anytime.

title.en-US: Can post-baby waist training help you slim down?

content.value: Celebs claim that corset-like contraptions have helped them “bounce back” quickly after having a baby. Read this before you strap or zip yourself in.

One of the most surprising things about giving birth is that your belly does not immediately go back “down” post-delivery. But as surprised as you may be when you look down at your midsection, that’s totally normal: Your baby may have vacated the premises, but your uterus remains stretched and needs a few months to shrink back to its regular size. Some inquiring (and impatient) minds who keep up on Hollywood’s latest fads have wanted to know: Will a waist trainer speed up the shrinking process?

First, here’s what you need to know about waist trainers: Depending on the type, a waist trainer could act like a corset on steroids, equipped with not just control-top fabric but a support structure made of steel “bones” or plastic. (Ouch!) The contraption redistributes squishy belly fat to create a slimmer appearance, and is also said to act like an external LAP-BAND (or, a tight pair of jeans), which discourages wearers from overeating. The premise: By constricting the stomach and leaving you feeling full after just a tiny meal, you’ll practice portion control without even trying.

The problem? That’s not likely to last. A few years ago, a team of researchers actually studied the effect of corsets on weight maintenance. The result? Inconclusive—the vast majority of subjects dropped out because the corset was too uncomfortable to bear over the course of the study. And these were subjects who had the wherewithal to already to lose weight on a very low-calorie diet!

In any case, there’s a whole slew of other reasons not to waist train the weight off, and most health experts are decidedly not fans. Bruising your internal organs or restricting your breathing—yes, these are real risks!—isn’t exactly the definition of healthy weight loss. Long-term use is associated with gastrointestinal issues (acid reflux, heartburn, and gas), nerve issues (in particular, tingling and numbness in the thighs), skin rashes, and varicose veins.

If you’re struggling with your weight or body image, there are safer—and saner—ways to get back on track after having a baby. Maven’s practitioners (nutritionists, therapists, OB-GYNs) can work with you to tackle the issue from every angle. Bottom line: Spanx for a special occasion (if they help you feel more confident) are fine. Living in a corset every day? Skip it.

title.en-US: Do you need preventative mental health care during pregnancy?

content.value: Why some experts think therapy should be prescribed to all moms-to-be.

A lot of the actions women take during pregnancy are preventative: Eat healthy foods to prevent conditions like gestational diabetes. Exercise to prevent labor complications. You get the idea. But when it comes to mental health, many women don’t seek the support of a practitioner until there is a problem.

Interestingly, some experts argue that there is no better time to consider counseling as a preventative measure than during pregnancy. In other words, you don’t have to wait until things feel too overwhelming, the stress becomes crippling, or prenatal depression is full-blown to benefit from therapy.

After all, you’re embarking on a major life transition, and the impact of bringing a baby into your world can be a lot to process on your own. Case in point: Maternal mental health disorders affect 15 to 20% of women during pregnancy and the postpartum period—and those stats don’t reflect the large numbers of women who aren’t formally diagnosed.

If you need a sounding board, or think it could help you to have an emotional support system in place during your pregnancy, don’t hesitate to reach out to the therapists in Maven's network. They’ve worked with countless moms-to-be (and many of them are mothers themselves) and know exactly how complicated this journey can be. And the beauty of an ongoing relationship with a provider you trust is that they can spot changes in your mood before you even do.

We have 1,400+ practitioners in 18 specialties including egg freezing and IUI/IVF experts, OB-GYNs, mental health specialists, back-to-work coaches, pediatricians, and more. I used Maven’s sleep coaches for help getting my daughter on a sleep schedule which was so helpful before I returned to work.
2. Same-day virtual appointments

When my sciatica acted up, I jumped on a video chat with a physical therapist. When I had heartburn, I messaged a nurse practitioner for safe ways to alleviate it. I loved not having to put everything on hold to get advice I could trust immediately.

title.en-US: What every new mom wonders about sleep training

content.value: If you’re a new parent who hasn’t slept for longer than a three-hour stretch since giving birth, you may be looking for the bible on baby sleep. There are many different ways to teach a baby to doze off so everyone in the family can get a little more rest, but—here’s the tough part—not everyone agrees on these interventions. Here’s what you need to know before making your sleep training decision.
First, does everyone have to sleep train a baby?

No, there are no musts here. And there are definitely parents who opt out and their children go on to learn how to sleep through the night on their own. But if you don’t want to “wing it,” sleep training your infant is an option.
If there are many acceptable sleep training methods, how do I choose the best one?

The best method is the one you can sustain—sticking them out is key to making sleep strategies effective. Some styles, like “extinction sleep training,” require letting your baby cry it out with no intervening to soothe her. If you know that your threshold for hearing your baby cry is low, and after a certain amount of time you won’t be able to cope with your baby’s tears any longer, this probably isn’t the best approach for you. (Experts say it’s better to rush in to comfort your baby quickly rather than caving and going in to swoop her in your arms after, say, a half hour—which may backfire by reinforcing the crying.) In this case, a gentler tactic may be a better fit for your family. One example you may have heard about is the Ferber method, which promotes checking on your baby at timed intervals when she’s crying during sleep.
When can you start sleep training?

The timing of sleep training is as hotly debated as which method is best. Conventional parenting wisdom says sleep training before four to six months is a no-no. But there are doctors who advocate for an earlier initiation—like around 8 weeks. Whatever you decide, talk to your pediatrician before you begin just to make sure you’re on the same page and she doesn’t have any concerns about kicking things off in the Zzz’s department.
Need more advice?
Book an appointment with a Maven sleep coach who can introduce you to different sleep training methods and get you on the right track.
Book with a sleep coach

title.en-US: One woman’s story of single motherhood through IVF

content.value: Maven Real Talk with Christina on IUI/IVF
39 years old
Higher Education Administrator
Washington, DC
Why did you decide to do IUI, and how old were you when you started the process?

At age 38 I did IUI as a first step in the process of trying to get pregnant without a partner. I began with IUI because it’s less invasive and far less expensive than IVF, and also much less demanding physically than IVF.
Was the sperm donor a romantic partner, or did you go to a sperm bank?

The sperm came from an anonymous donor that I identified through a sperm bank. I had a few basic criteria I was looking for in a donor. Pretty quickly, I came across the profile of a man who not only met those criteria but inspired me with his view on life and how he had lived. I knew I would be proud to tell a future child about who they came from. Finding him was a gift, and it helped build my courage for single parenthood.
How long did you wait in between selecting a sperm donor and using that sperm to try to get pregnant?
1 year
How many rounds of IUI have you done?

I completed 4 rounds of IUI, 4 months in a row, but the IUIs were not successful. After 4 IUIs, I took a break to enjoy life outside the fertility clinic and to think about whether I wanted to continue IUIs or move to IVF. During that break, friends introduced me to a great guy that I dated for several months. But he and I soon realized we didn’t have enough in common to build a future. Once he and I ended the relationship a few months later, I decided to throw everything I had at getting pregnant. I wanted to find my way out of what had been 3 years of contemplating, planning, trying for a baby, and the emotionally complex navigation of stops and starts in dating relationships as pregnancy became an increasingly high priority.
My best chance for getting pregnant was IVF using frozen eggs I had retrieved at age 36. At age 39, I was fortunate to get pregnant with my first IVF cycle. I’ll be 40 when the baby is born.
What did it feel like to undergo fertility treatment?

The more challenging part of the cycles was juggling all the timed components—clinic visits that needed to happen on specific days in my menstrual cycle, daily ovulation testing at home at the right time, and once the ovulation test signaled a “surge”, the last-minute clearing of my work schedule to get to where I needed to be at the precise time I needed to be at the clinic for an IUI.
What was the most emotional or difficult part of this journey?

About three days after my first IUI, a guy I had liked for years, but hadn’t spoken to in months, very randomly asked me out. At that moment, I deeply wished I wasn’t waiting to find out if I was pregnant. He and I met up and had a great time. A few days later I learned I wasn’t pregnant, but he never asked me out again. That simple sequence of events highlighted for me that I had entered a very intentional season of my life. As I moved forward with monthly pregnancy attempts, I became less distracted by men who were only casually interested in dating me.
What would you like other people to know about what it’s like to have a baby on your own?

At 3 and a half months pregnant, perhaps ask me in a year...
But there came a moment in my life when I realized I might have the ability to fill it with love, to pour my life into someone in a way I had always longed to. In short, I didn’t have to be lucky in love to build a home full of love. For me, pregnancy has been an overwhelmingly joyful time of celebration with family and friends and anticipation of what is to come.
Is there anything else you wish we had asked you, and how would you answer?

The people in my life who have had the most tentative reactions to my decision to have a child on my own are women around my age or older who feel enormous pressure to make a decision to try to have a baby or not. Many of them do not look forward to raising a child alone. I’ll just add my voice to a chorus that reassures women that either path is valued and respected.

title.en-US: How to choose an OB-GYN, midwife, and doula

content.value: While no practitioner can guarantee you an easy 9 months free of complications, a good practitioner can make a huge difference in your pregnancy journey. Before you choose a provider, it’s important to look into their credentials, availability, and hospital affiliation. Read this cheat sheet from Maven Medical Director Jane van Dis, Midwife Danika Severino Wynn, and Doula Qef Johnson on what to ask doctors, midwives, or doulas before deciding to work with them.

If you have a longtime obstetrician-gynecologist, then it might make sense to stick with them for your pregnancy journey. But switching things up is also totally OK. After all, that person you see just once a year for a quick exam may not turn out to be the person you want guiding you through the months-long pregnancy and childbirth process. Finding the right provider—someone who’s both knowledgeable and who’ll make you feel good about the whole experience—takes some time and thought. You might want to change providers altogether. Or you might like to build a whole support team, with an OB-GYN, midwife, and a doula. Whatever the case may be, finding a good match can get confusing. At Maven, you can book instant video appointments and message with practitioners of various specialties, including OB-GYNs, midwives, and doulas to feel out whether a particular provider is right for you. To get started, check out these insights from three members of our network.
Maven provider Jane van Dis, M.D. on finding an OB-GYN:

OB-GYN is a commonly used abbreviation for an obstetrician/gynecologist—it refers to a physician who both delivers babies and supports a broad spectrum of issues relevant to women’s reproductive health.

OB-GYNs have a minimum of four years of obstetrics and gynecology training in addition to four years of medical school. We sometimes share the medical care of a woman during pregnancy and birth with family practitioners (who have also attended medical school) and midwives.

The most important aspect of choosing a provider is your overall safety. If you have a history of a medical condition, it's best to find an OB-GYN who understands your unique pregnancy circumstances. Whether you have diabetes, hypertension, you’re carrying multiples, or you have a history of seizures—just to name a few examples—ask questions to make sure your provider is skilled in handling these issues.

Beyond adequate training, you should ask your potential OB-GYN about their philosophy on the birthing experiences—then ask yourself: Do their philosophies correspond with yours? Do you feel this provider is someone who will listen to you and integrate your desires into your care plan? Does the doctor ask you open-ended questions or does she make you feel like Patient No. 952, with generic care and advice?

In my opinion, it’s important to find a doctor who brings evidence-based medicine to their practice. That might mean she may not give you exactly what you want in the moment, but she’ll give the best outcome for you and your baby. Patients come into the birth experience with expectations—for instance, an unmedicated birth or a vaginal delivery. But this may not always be medically sound for some patients. For instance, you may not want your doctor to use a vacuum during delivery, but if there is concern about the baby's oxygen supply, it may be needed for their safety. I always explain why I'm making a certain recommendation. Be sure that you have a provider who will listen to you and communicate with you, but who is also committed to the highest level of care for you and your baby.

Lastly, my advice to women looking for an OB-GYN is to keep in mind where you’ll be giving birth. The hospital, in my view, plays one of the most important role in terms of the C-section rate—and since doctors in private practice can’t be there 24-7, they’ll rely on the nurses to help manage the labor process in their absence. I work in a hospital that has a 15-percent C-section rate, which is very low. The staff here values the idea that C-sections shouldn’t be performed unnecessarily—but that isn’t the case everywhere, so make this a part of your search criteria.
Maven provider Danika Severino Wynn on finding a midwife:

It’s such a personal choice when it comes to picking a provider. Of course, being a certified nurse midwife myself, I’m a bit biased, but midwives focus on physical and emotional support, and can be a great option for any woman who has a low-risk pregnancy and doesn’t have serious health problems. Our model is set up to assume that a pregnancy and childbirth are normal events. Any opportunity I get, I try to dispel myths about midwives. For instance, over 95 percent of midwives attend births and care for patients in hospital settings; our patients can use epidurals and other types of pain relief if they choose.

If you’re considering working with one, note that midwives have varying amounts of training and schooling. CNMs (certified nurse-midwives) are registered nurses with advanced training in obstetrics and gynecology as well as specialized midwifery training; they've passed a certification exam and are licensed to practice in all 50 states. CMs (certified midwives) have gone through a similar certification; the main difference is that they don’t have a nursing degree.
(Keep in mind that “lay midwives” don’t have formal medical schooling or credentials.)

I always recommend visiting your potential midwife in person if you can for an informal visit. When you meet, ask up front about her perspective on C-sections and unmedicated births. (I like using the term “unmedicated” as opposed to “natural”; “natural” makes it sound as if a birth that doesn’t involve medication is somehow better than one where an epidural or other medical assistance was used—and that’s not the case!) It’s important to see if she aligns with your birth plan and what’s important to you.

Other questions to ask: What will you do to support me in breastfeeding?; When will I see you postpartum?; How many extra visits are included in your fees?; What kind of availability do you have to take calls after hours? Who covers your call and who will be attending my birth? The idea is to get to the root of the kind of care you’ll be receiving.

I tell women they should feel very comfortable with the person who’ll be attending their birth—that provider is going to be there for the most intimate moment of their lives. Find out more about a midwife by asking other patients that have received care from her. Your provider may have privileges at a certain hospital; make sure you’re comfortable with the place she attends births.

And remember, if you choose a provider and later start to see red flags, switch. It’s never too late—many providers take new patients late in their pregnancy. Advocating for yourself at any stage is an important part of pregnancy.
Maven provider Qef Johnson on finding a doula:

Contrary to popular belief, anyone could work with a doula—not just women set on a “natural” birth; doulas work in hospitals and support women in medicated births, too. Some doulas (like me) are also nurses and/or come from nursing backgrounds. Doulas have training in different comfort techniques and knowledge of the childbirth process. They also understand the healthcare system. So a doula can support you through birth as well as be your advocate.

The best way to find the right doula for you is to talk to other women who’ve used this type of provider. Ask these references what, specifically, they liked about their doula. A lot of it is word of mouth. Your OB-GYN or midwife may also be able to recommend doulas she’s worked with. Most doulas will offer a free one-on-one session, so you can get to know them a bit before signing on. If a doula doesn’t work out of a birthing center, she might suggest meeting at a coffee shop or other public place.

When you meet, ask about her background and training. There are several doula certification programs, including DONA international and Doula Trainings International. You should ask about any areas of specialty. Some doulas, for instance, have massage expertise, others might use yoga poses, breathing techniques, essential oils, or Chinese medicine. Whether you want a medicated birth or not, ask the doula about her opinions on it. You can also ask her about what she thinks about pain medication and C-sections. You want to see if she has an open mind about these issues and whether your perspectives align with hers.

In addition to finding out how many births a prospective doula has attended, be sure to mention your due date. The reason: A good doula will know what her limitations are—she might not want to take on more than 4 births a month, for instance.

Each doula will have her own contract, and it will involve a specific number of sessions. You may have three sessions dedicated to the kind of coaching you’d find in a birthing class, but it will be one-on-one and personalized to your needs. Then, around six weeks before your due date, your doula will be on-call for you. After the birth, she’ll provide coaching sessions on caring for the baby.

Once you become a doula’s client, she should definitely respond to your emails or calls within 24 hours. She should also have a back-up plan in case she can’t be available to you—i.e. another doula whom you might want to meet, to make sure you like her as well. There’s a doula for every personality, and you’ll likely find one that’s right for you if you follow your intuition.

title.en-US: How to power through pregnancy fatigue

content.value: Fatigue is a common side effect of pregnancy. Hormones, especially increased progesterone levels, are often to blame for that non-stop sleepy feeling. While you may not be the perkiest version of yourself during these nine months, here are some simple self-care acts from Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone and Career Coach Mary Beth Ferrante to help you avoid feeling like a zombie and stay productive at work.

Of course you’re tired—you are growing a human! Even though that human may only be the size of a pea, your body is in overdrive as it supports another being. “A combination of hormones, increased blood volume, and disrupted sleep marked by more vivid dreams and nightmares” are often to blame for increased fatigue during pregnancy, says Maven OBGYN Dr. Jackie Stone. Exhaustion may keep you from being 100% on your game at work and in life. Here are some strategies from Dr. Stone and Maven back-to-work coach Mary Beth Ferrante that may help you keep your focus—or at least your head up.
Do your best to get more (and better) sleep at night.

Whether it’s nausea, vivid dreams, or getting up to pee every hour, sleeping during pregnancy can be a roller coaster. Dr. Stone notes that women often start having trouble in the first trimester as their bodies undergo major changes, and then feel better in the second trimester. But by the time the third trimester rolls around, you start feeling tired again because it can be tough to find a comfortable position.

Some tips to get a better night’s sleep? Rearrange your schedule or get some extra help with housework so you can get to bed earlier. Buy a body pillow or specialty pregnancy pillow to help you get comfortable. Avoid large meals right before bedtime. Try sleeping propped up at a thirty degree angle to keep nausea and acid reflux at bay. Try drinking most of your water earlier in the day to minimize middle-of-the-night bathroom runs. (Dr. Stone cautions that you may still have to get up and pee in the middle of the night. “This can happen as early as the first trimester due to increased blood flow,” she explains “then later because the baby is putting pressure on your bladder.”). If all else fails, and your sleeplessness is getting out of hand, talk to your doctor about pregnancy-safe aids such as some over-the-counter medications.
Embrace the power nap.

Unfortunately, not everyone can doze off for a quick power nap at the snap of a finger. “Some women have a really hard time napping, especially if they have other children around,” says Dr. Stone. But if you’re among the lucky ones and have the opportunity to sneak in a quick snooze in the middle of the day, take it! “I’ve had clients sleep in their cars on their lunch breaks, or close their office doors and get 15 or 20 minutes of shut-eye between meetings,” says Ferrante.
If you can’t nap, get moving.

Standing up often and taking a quick, energizing walk—even if it’s from your desk to the bathroom—may give you just enough of a boost to power you through the day. Even though you expend energy walking, you get more back than you use. You might try setting aside time for a power walk outside (bonus: fresh air helps with nausea). While you should always check with your doctor, especially if you have a high-risk pregnancy, Dr. Stone recommends getting 30 minutes of moderate physical activity each day during pregnancy. Breaking a sweat not only boosts your energy, it may also help with weight management, reduce your risk of gestational diabetes, enhance your psychological well-being, and help your body get ready for labor. “Labor is like running a marathon,” says Dr. Stone. “It takes a lot of stamina to push out a baby. And if you’ve been sitting on your butt all day, you’re not ready to run a marathon!” Scared you might overdo it? “You should be able to speak a sentence aloud while exercising. Avoid contact sports,” advises Dr. Stone.
When all else fails, reach for the coffee mug.

Check with your doctor first, but almost all medical professionals agree that consuming small amounts of caffeine while pregnant is safe. “You don’t have to give up your morning coffee,” says Dr. Stone, noting that while too much caffeine has been linked to preterm delivery and miscarriage, up to 200 mg per day—about the amount in one or two cups—is not associated with adverse pregnancy outcomes. If you’re crashing in the afternoon, time your coffee breaks accordingly, maybe skipping your morning latte and going for a P.M. fix instead. (Just don’t drink caffeine too late in the day, or it will interfere with your sleep.) And make sure you know how much caffeine is in your cup, because caffeine content can vary widely by brand, cautions Dr. Stone.
Don’t overdo it on the sugar.

“Be wary of sugary drinks like Gatorade. They’re not helpful in fighting fatigue, because too much sugar can lead to crashes,” warns Dr. Stone. Most artificial sweeteners are no better: “They are processed in your body similarly to sugar and can increase your risk of insulin resistance and diabetes,” she notes. If you’re craving something sweet to get you going, she recommends trying Stevia, or having one regular Coke instead of a steady lineup of diet colas. “Don’t drink a lot of regular Coke,” she says, “but one won’t harm your baby.”

title.en-US: Practical tips for morning sickness

content.value: When nausea strikes during pregnancy, an activity as boring as making breakfast can feel like pure torment. The term "morning sickness" is a misnomer, actually, because the nausea and vomiting can occur at any time—day or night. Medical professionals call it “Nausea and Vomiting of Pregnancy,” or NVP—which sounds like “MVP,” yet there’s nothing “most valuable” about suffering through it.

NVP is one of the most common pregnancy symptoms, affecting as many as 50-80 percent of moms-to-be. (Cold comfort, we know.) According to Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, NVP often sets in around week five or six, just around the time that HCG—the so-called “pregnancy hormone”—kicks into high gear, when most women find out they’re pregnant. While this unfortunately common symptom typically improves by around 16-20 weeks, some people aren’t in the clear until much later in their pregnancy.

NVP might not be all bad news, though. Interestingly, studies have shown a link between nausea and vomiting during pregnancy and a lower rate of miscarriage, says Stone. Of course, many women have healthy pregnancies without experiencing morning sickness. In other words, if you're not feeling ill, don't panic. While no one knows for certain what causes morning sickness, Dr. Stone notes it may result from a combination of pregnancy hormones like HCG and progesterone, increased blood flow, and slower digestion. Women who experienced morning sickness in past pregnancies or who are carrying multiples may also be more susceptible to it.
Luckily, there are a few things you can try to make the experience easier to get through.
Avoid triggering smells and foods

While everyone is different, some common triggers for morning sickness include spicy or greasy foods and anything with a strong smell. If you notice that catching a whiff of your partner’s egg-and-cheese sandwich in the morning sets off your gag reflexes, take note, and ask them to either change up the menu or get it to go so the smell doesn't linger at home. Your partner likely isn't aware just how triggering food smells can be right now so have a conversation about it so they know to avoid cooking up certain foods for the time being.
Opt for bland, simple foods

Steer clear of heavy condiments, dressings, and spices that can make you queasy. Dr. Stone suggests the BRAT diet: bananas, applesauce, rice, and toast. Other experts recommend opting for cold foods such as fresh salads, sandwiches, veggies, fruit (especially lemons), and Jell-O. If you crave a hot lunch or dinner, try some chicken soup or a plain baked potato with a side of almonds—the protein boost may also help put your tummy at ease. Of course, everyone is different. The key is to figure out what works for you and stick to it. If you find that a lunchtime chili bowl is what you crave, by all means go for it. But something a little milder like oatmeal may be all you can stand for the moment.
Eat smaller, more frequent meals

Both an empty stomach and a full one can trigger morning sickness, says Dr. Stone. Pregnancy hormones like progesterone slow down your digestive tract, causing heartburn and nausea. Likewise, when you go too long without eating, the acids sitting in your belly can make you feel sick. To give your system time to digest while ensuring that your stomach never goes empty, she recommends having five to six small meals a day instead of three large ones. You can also try keeping a few “safe foods” on hand—and on your nightstand!—for a nosh-as-needed basis throughout the day and night. Wondering what to munch on? Many women swear by simple, refreshing snacks like popsicles, plain yogurt, saltine crackers, pretzels, and fresh or frozen fruit.
Avoid the heat

Whether it’s a stuffy subway car or just a hot summer day, many moms-to-be find that heat exacerbates their nausea. There may be a medical explanation—pregnancy raises your core body temperature, and the extra weight can trigger extra sweat, making you dehydrated, which is also a known nausea trigger. If the summer heat is keeping you down, try carrying ice water in a temperature-controlled bottle, wearing breathable fabrics such as lightweight cotton or linen, investing in a small personal fan or cold compress (though a cool wet towel will do), or swapping your outdoor power walk for a swim or session on an indoor treadmill. If the temperature outside is over 90 degrees, try to stay indoors—with air conditioning!—as much as possible.
Take your prenatal vitamins at night

For some, swallowing a big pill first thing in the morning can be pure torture and leave them feeling ill for the rest of the day. If this is you, Dr. Stone recommends switching to a chewable prenatal vitamin and taking them at night with a snack. If that still doesn’t cut it and you’re early in your pregnancy, talk to your doctor about temporarily switching to a prenatal vitamin without iron. “Often, it’s the iron that makes women feel sick,” says Dr. Stone, adding that while extra iron is necessary in pregnancy, it may be okay to do without until the second trimester. Just consult your provider first.
Drink plenty of water, but not during meals

Staying well-hydrated is crucial when you’re pregnant, says Dr. Stone, especially if you’re throwing up or feeling overheated. Many people also find that sucking on ice chips and drinking water throughout the day helps alleviate their nausea. That said, pregnancy hormones such as progesterone tend to slow down your digestion, and drinking too close to meals can slow things down even more, making morning sickness worse. To keep your gag reflexes in check, wait at least half an hour before or after eating for your next H2O fix.
Try some OTC remedies

Peppermint or ginger tea may provide some relief to drink (plus, having one of these flavored tea bags on hand to smell can actually help alleviate nausea). If peppermint and ginger aren’t cutting it, Dr. Stone recommends talking to your doctor about over-the-counter remedies such as Tums, Pepcid, and Zantac to help neutralize your stomach acids and keep nausea at bay. Always talk to your doctor first, but some women have also found a combination of ginger and vitamin B6—which can be found in supplements or candy form—to be effective. If you’re wary of any drugs or supplements, try Preggie Pops, which come in a variety of flavors including ginger, mint, and lemon and are free of drugs or added vitamins.
Know when to call your doctor

If you can’t keep any food down, and especially if you can’t tolerate liquids for more than eight or twelve hours, it’s important to alert your doctor. Depending on the severity, a doctor might prescribe an anti-nausea medication or recommend IV fluids for dehydration.

title.en-US: The pros and cons of your childcare options

content.value: We know what you’re thinking—childcare planning, already?! Trust us, it’s never too soon to start. There’s a lot to consider: if you and your partner will return to work at the same time, what’s offered in your area, costs, waiting lists, and a slew of other factors. Right now is the perfect time to start investigating. Here’s a helpful guide from Maven Nurse Practitioner Jennifer Uzzell on how to choose the best option for you.
Nanny
Pros

Many parents dream of engaging the perfect nanny for their little one, a sort of real-life Mary Poppins meets Mrs. Doubtfire meets Nanny McPhee. Nannies come with some undeniable perks, including one-on-one attention for your child. Highly qualified nannies take the time to know your child intimately, and that means they’ll soon be picking up on your child’s hunger and sleep cues, which in turn could lead to a happier baby and a less-stressed you. You’ll have the added peace of mind that comes from knowing your child is being watched in your own home. At the end of the day, the nanny will most likely be able to give you a detailed report of your baby’s behavior and development. “Nannies give a child a personal touch, lots of interaction, outings to the park or library, and individual help with skills such as potty training,” says Uzzell.
Cons

The downsides of hiring a nanny include the cost (they’re at the higher end of the spectrum of care) and scheduling issues. If your childcare needs are being met by a single individual, you’re left more vulnerable to cancellations and last-minute scrambling than if you opted for a daycare center with a large staff and predetermined business hours. Nannies are human. Like you, they get sick. Like you, they might need time off to tend to familial or other obligations, and then it’s up to you and your partner to fill those gaps, says Uzzell.
Nanny Share
Pros

Perhaps you love the idea of finding a nanny for your baby, but, at the same time, you’re nagged by concerns not only about cost but the possible ramifications of not socializing your child early and often. In that case, you might consider sharing a nanny with another family or small group of families. The typical nanny share has each family contributing to the nanny’s salary in an equitable fashion, and the nanny watching the kids at an agreed-upon location, usually at one of the family homes. “Nanny sharing can be awesome,” says Uzzell. “You share the cost and have built-in playmates for your child, all in a home environment.”
Cons

Since there are no set rules for nanny sharing, it’s up to the families to hammer out the details, and that’s where things can get messy. Who, for instance, decides how much each family pays? What if one of the family homes doesn’t meet your safety standards? Perhaps you have concerns that the nanny is favoring another child over yours. Uzzell recommends that you only enter into a nanny sharing arrangement with people you know well and who share your values and priorities, and that you make sure to have protocols in place for handling conflicts when they do arise.

“What if a certain problem in the arrangement only negatively affects one family?” she asks. “Say one family doesn’t like what the nanny makes for lunch. Or what if the hosting family's child is sick? What do you do then?”
Daycare
Pros

Working families often turn to daycare centers and in-home daycare providers as a practical and affordable alternative to a nanny. Most daycare centers employ large staffs; maintain regular hours; help children develop social skills; and devote a portion of the day to educational activities. The latter will make sending your child to school that much easier.
Cons

When you opt for a daycare center you’re forgoing one-on-one attention for your little one, and you might worry that your child’s needs aren’t being met as quickly or thoroughly as they would be if the adults in the room weren’t in charge of a large number of other children. For Uzzell, a mother of seven, in-home daycare made the most sense. It was the happy medium between the nanny option and a daycare center. “I felt good about having one woman looking after a small group of kids that included my own,” Uzzell says.
Family Member
Pros

If you decide that you’d like your child to be looked after by family, there are definite advantages, including a chance for your child to bond with the people you love most and the comfort that comes with knowing your provider intimately.
Cons

Uzzell says you need to be aware that there are downsides to what might initially seem to everyone to be a win-win. “Some people have grandparents who can’t wait to watch their kids and they’re ecstatic about that,” Uzzell said, “and some people don’t want Grandma in their business. It just depends. And remember that kids often repeat everything they hear, and it’s one thing for them to tell a daycare full of strangers things you wouldn’t want anyone to know. It’s a whole other level for your family to suddenly be in on all your secrets.”

Another issue with enlisting family can be the possibility of hurt feelings should you opt, at a later date, to have your child watched by someone else. “That’s not really something you have to worry about when you go with a daycare center or in-home provider,” said Uzzell. “They won’t take things as personally if you decide to make a switch.”
The Interview Process

Regardless of whether you opt for a nanny, a daycare center, an in-home provider, or a family member, Uzzell suggests you sit down with potential providers and have a series of in-depth discussions about what you’re looking for in childcare.
Here are a few possible questions to ask during the interviews:
What sorts of food will the child be fed?
What sort of protocols are in place in the event of an emergency or injury?
What’s the policy regarding sick children?
How do you handle potty training?
What sorts of age-appropriate educational play do you like to organize?
What is your approach on discipline?

Keep in mind that the provider might not necessarily give you perfect answers to all your questions. Part of the process of choosing childcare, says Uzzell, is deciding what you’re willing to compromise on and what issues are your deal-breakers.

“My older three children went to the same in-home daycare for a number of years, and one thing I thought was odd is that they when I picked them up, they were always very clean,” Uzzell says. “Their faces didn’t have a speck of food on them. My provider was feeding them herself, rather than letting them feed themselves. I didn’t love that approach, but I was willing to let it go because it wasn’t something harmful. I could live with it.”
The Tour

Where your child will be spending her time away from you is almost as important as who she’ll be spending it with, and so tour every facility you’re considering. “I remember touring one in-home daycare and all the toys were broken,” says Uzzell. “The toys didn’t have batteries, and I thought, Why would my kid want to come here and play with a bunch of broken toys?”

Other red flags to look for? Outlets that aren’t properly covered, choking hazards on the floors, and a general lack of cleanliness. “You need to be comfortable with where you’re sending your children, and you want to know your kids will be comfortable there, too,” says Uzell.

title.en-US: When to secure childcare based on where you live

content.value: When it comes to childcare options in your area, no one knows the scoop like local mom groups. Get in touch with the groups in your area for advice. In Brooklyn, New York, local moms share you can usually find a nanny in a month. In Charlotte, North Carolina and Vancouver, Canada, local moms advise looking in the first trimester.
Maven CEO and founder Kate Ryder has lived through the ups and downs of looking for a caregiver fit. In this Q&A, she shares her secrets to make the process a little easier for you.
How many kids do you have, and how old are they?
2 kids: 2 years old and 5 months old.
What type of caregiving do you rely on for your child/children? (Formal child-care center, family day care in someone’s home, nanny, nanny-share, or relative/friend.)
We used to be in a nanny share when we had one child, and now we’ve just started with a new nanny who is exclusively working with our family.
How did you make your childcare decision? What was the most stressful part?

I asked around from other moms in our neighborhood, and realized that a nanny share was a popular choice in Brooklyn and also the least expensive. I posted on a mom group to see if I could find another mom who was also interested in a nanny share and got incredibly lucky in that I met a wonderful woman named Jess who had a son one month older than our son. We shared a nanny for two years and it was a great experience - our sons are best friends.

How soon into your pregnancy (or how long after you gave birth) did you make your childcare decision? Looking back, was the decision well-timed, or do you wish you had made these arrangements earlier?

I started trying to figure out childcare about 6 weeks before our baby nurse left our home (so when our son was 6 weeks old). We sorted everything out in 3 weeks - our nanny share family, and our nanny. That’s probably unique to New York!
What’s your best advice for moms-to-be who are about to make a childcare decision? What have you learned from your own process that you wish someone had told you?

The most important thing, in my opinion, is to feel 100% comfortable that your child is happy and supported while you are gone. I loved a nanny share for our first child because he was able to flourish socially, and we had a great nanny who was very active and took the kids all over New York City. They loved her and my son was never upset when I walked out the door to go to work. That was a great feeling! Now that we have two children, we’re more scheduled (my son goes to preschool) but we found a wonderful new nanny who plays with the kids and is very active. Also, one other piece of advice to new moms: references can be hit or miss. It’s all about the culture fit with your family so one mom that you might trust can give a great reference on a nanny, but they might not be right for your home.
Have things worked out, or have you had to find a new caregiver (daycare/nanny/etc.) over time? What was the reason for the switch and how did you cope?

We had a misstep for 3 weeks with one nanny. I got a great reference on her from a friend of a friend, but ultimately she wasn’t a great fit with our family.
