My son is rambunctious and likes to play a lot, but the new nanny didn’t get on the floor and play with him as much. She also didn’t like to be out of the house more than a few hours per day, which was not a fit with my son who always wants to be outdoors. It was obvious it wasn’t working because my son wasn’t comfortable when I left the house in the morning. That was a horrible time and affected every part of my life.

What were your top three non-negotiables in a childcare provider? (i.e. proximity to your home/office, speaking a second language, outgoing personality of caregiver, ratio of caregiver to children in a daycare center, etc.)
My three non-negotiables in a nanny would be: joyful/fun, safe, healthy.
Did you experience separation anxiety when you first left your child with a caregiver? Have things gotten easier, and if so, what helped you adjust?

Yes! It was terrible but when I started to see how much my son loved his nanny, I felt a lot better. By the time he was 1, he would visibly get excited when his nanny arrived each morning and I tell myself it’s probably healthy for him to have so many people in his life that love him.
How you ever needed backup childcare and if so, what did you do?

Yes! That is a tough part of having a nanny - sometimes they are sick. My mother is amazing and is our go-to, and when my mom hasn’t been available, we’ve used care.com. I’m not going to lie - I don’t love care.com and we didn’t have a good experience with the person who came to our home. I recommend asking people around you who they’ve used on care.com so you can at least get references on someone.
How much do you pay for your childcare?
We paid $12/hour for each family in our nanny share situation and now we pay $19/hour for two kids. It’s brutal!
What are things you wish you negotiated with either your daycare or nanny?

I wish I was more upfront about cleaning. Our old nanny got into bad habits where she never cleaned strollers, dishes, etc. It was hard to undo that so in our next nanny, I was very clear about cleaning strollers, cleaning bottles, etc.
Does your employer offer any childcare benefits, including subsidized care or access to an on-site center? What workplace benefits do you wish existed to ease the burden of childcare on parents?

My employer does not offer any childcare benefits. I don’t know if my employer could really help me find nannies given that so much of that is through local mom groups and referrals. They could be better with helping me manage back-up childcare (beyond care.com) or helping me understand my local ecosystem in terms of hiring nannies, finding daycares, etc.

title.en-US: How to tell your boss you’re pregnant

content.value: You're pregnant! And while you couldn’t be more excited, you’re likely a little nervous about breaking the news to your boss. Maven career coach Sara Daly-Padron has been both the expecting mom and the manager being delivered the news.

First, let’s address why it’s so challenging to have The Talk. Daly-Padron—who spent three years in management at Goldman Sachs—agrees that it’s delicate. “Many women don’t want it to be a red mark next to their name,” she says, “or a question of their commitment. There’s also a fear that it will affect their compensation or the assignments they receive.” Perhaps you’ve heard the term “benevolent discrimination,” where people withhold assignments, opportunities, and even travel, because they assume it will be better for you. Even if it is well-intentioned, this is still discrimination. Fortunately, the Pregnancy Discrimination Act (PDA) is in place to protect women from pregnancy-based discrimination. Depending on where you live, many states have additional laws to protect pregnant women, so look into those, as well as reading this list of do’s and don’ts.
DO (with exceptions) wait until your second trimester to break the news.

At the end of your first trimester, your risk of losing the pregnancy goes down, which is why most people wait until then to inform their boss. That is assuming you don’t work in an environment that can be harmful to you and your baby. If your job involves moving furniture, break the news early. Also, if you’re missing work due to morning sickness, confiding in your boss might be the right move.
DON’T speak to your boss before knowing your policies.

Dust off that old company handbook and familiarize yourself with maternity leave policies before talking to your boss. You want to go into your meeting knowing what the company offers so that you can convey your plan with confidence. Some people talk with HR before their boss—this is a personal decision. If you decide to go that route, schedule the talk with your boss shortly after your meeting with HR, and don’t tell any other colleagues until then. The last thing you want is for your boss to hear your news through the grapevine.
DO pick the right time.

Unless you work remotely, this is a meeting that you want to have in person. Be thoughtful around the timing: If you know your boss has an executive committee meeting every Monday, and he or she comes out with a giant to-do list, don’t schedule it for a Monday.
DON’T break the news with guilt or apologies.

This is exciting news! Set the tone for a positive meeting. Don’t downplay your pregnancy or apologize. Don’t begin with statements like, “I know this isn’t a good time, but I’m pregnant.” Your boss will feed off of your energy, so bring a positive mindset that will ensure him or her that together, you will come up with a plan that works for everyone.
DO come prepared to answer these four questions.
Four questions will be at the top of your manager’s mind:
When are you due?
Are you planning to work right up until the baby comes?
When are you aiming to return?
What’s going to happen in the meantime?

The conversation can go like this: “I have great news to share. I’m expecting a baby, due in March. I understand our company policy. I will be taking a maternity leave, and I anticipate working until my due date. In the interim I’ve started compiling a list of my responsibilities, and I’ve started to think through who could cover those tasks until I return. I’d like to schedule another meeting with you to talk through more of the details.” The goal of this meeting is to convey that you are organized, willing to help, and thinking about the future.
DON’T take things too personally.

In a perfect world, every boss would leap from her chair to give you a big hug and tell you how excited she is for you. While this might happen, it’s also a good idea to prepare yourself for any possible reaction. A warm-but-not-exuberant congratulations may simply mean that your boss is dealing with his or her own set of work pressures.
DO follow up with a thank you.
A quick email after the meeting to let your boss know you appreciate his or her support will go a long way.

At the end of the day, these tips are meant to lend you confidence in advance of a talk that gives many women pause. But remember: Being pregnant is not a problem to apologize for. You and your boss will figure out the best way to adapt, through your maternity leave and beyond.

title.en-US: Your first trimester work checklist

content.value: Working while pregnant can be challenging. Not only are you dealing with morning sickness and fatigue, scheduling doctor visits, preparing your home for the baby’s arrival, and researching what kind of cheese you can have in your sandwich, you also need to plan for your upcoming maternity leave while staying on top of current projects. If this all sounds a little overwhelming, you’re not alone. Many people worry about how impending parenthood will affect their career. Here are some steps you can take to set yourself up for success at work while protecting your sanity.
Give yourself some grace

According to Maven Career Coach Mary Beth Ferrante, it’s important to let yourself off the hook and acknowledge that pregnancy and motherhood will require flexibility at work. “People who are pregnant often put a lot of pressure on themselves to approach work as if nothing has changed, sometimes even feeling that they have to over-perform in order to prove to themselves and their colleagues that they remain just as committed to their careers,” says Ferrante. But this approach can be counterproductive. Even if you’re among the lucky few who enjoy an easy, symptom-free pregnancy (fingers crossed!), nearly all pregnancies will require some accommodations—to visit the doctor, run baby-related errands, and recover from childbirth. The best way to approach this reality is not by trying to be super human, says Ferrante, but rather by ensuring that you and your team are ready and empowered to tackle the challenges that may arise as you prepare for parenthood.
Be explicit about your career goals

Many new parents drop out of the workforce, as many as 43 percent, so don’t be surprised if some colleagues and your manager assume you’re not planning to return after the baby. The best way to deal with this is to be explicit about your intentions. “When you tell your manager that you're pregnant, come armed with a loose plan for when you’ll be out on leave, and how you intend to transition your work. Reiterate that it’s important for you to remain engaged and involved in critical work throughout your pregnancy,” says Ferrante, noting that it’s crucial that “they understand your goals and your ability to commit to projects and new opportunities now, even in the midst of a life change.” And remember, actions speak louder than words. Think of concrete steps you can take to set yourself and your team up for success, such as working with your manager to divvy up your responsibilities, or volunteering to hire and train a temporary replacement for your time away.
Don’t be afraid to speak up against pregnancy bias

If you detect any signs that you’re getting “mommy-tracked,” speak up! Ferrante recommends that you bring your concerns directly to your manager, but notes that this depends “largely on the company you work in and the environment.” If you feel you can’t trust your manager, find an ally in your organization, and discuss the best way to approach the situation. And don’t forget to document everything. “Pregnancy discrimination happens,” says Ferrante, “and it’s always a good idea to have a paper trail of occurrences.”
Don’t make permanent career adjustments based on current assumptions

Quitting your job may be tempting when you’re in throes of morning sickness or dealing with a serious pregnancy complication. You may also have doubts about whether you’ll be ready to return to work after your maternity leave. But no matter how stressed you feel right now, Ferrante cautions against making permanent career decisions to deal with what may just be a temporary situation. “You can’t plan for how you will feel after the baby is born,” she says. Instead of switching jobs, passing on a promotion, or quitting, she advises asking for temporary adjustments. For example, if pregnancy fatigue is keeping you down, ask to work remotely or for some flexibility in your hours (for example, your morning sickness may pass after 10 am making it a better start time). Make sure to emphasize that this only a temporary arrangement until you feel better.
Give your workspace a pregnancy makeover

Of course, no matter how committed you are to your job, it’s hard to prepare for a client meeting when you constantly feel like throwing up or crawling into bed. While there’s no magic pill for pregnancy nausea or fatigue, you can take some simple steps to make yourself as comfortable as possible at work or in your home office. Keep a water bottle at your workspace to stay hydrated and curb constipation. (It happens.) To keep your energy steady throughout the day and help combat nausea and heartburn, eat healthy snacks, such as almonds or fruit. Upgrade to a more comfortable chair (some work places will allow you to expense this). You can also try propping a pillow behind your back for added support, and adjusting your chair to keep your knees at a 90-degree angle to keep your spine comfortably upright. If your feet are killing you, switch to more comfortable shoes (or slippers at home!). And don’t be afraid to ask for help if any aspect of your job—like lifting or being on your feet for many hours—feels unsafe.
Take deliberate steps to stay focused and productive

Between deciding what stroller to buy, planning your baby shower, and preparing your baby’s nursery, pregnancy can be full of distractions that can make it difficult to remain focused at work. According to Ferrante, the best way to stay productive (and sane!) is to prioritize and set timelines, both at work and at home. Develop a plan for what you need to accomplish before your maternity leave, and set personal deadlines to help you stay on track. Likewise, make a list of what you need to do at home before the baby is born, bearing in mind that all a newborn really needs is a place to sleep and some diapers—and the hospital will give you some of those! Everything else is just icing on the cake. If you have a partner, figure out what they can do to take some of the burden off your shoulders.
Find a coach, mentor, or friend you can rely on

Finding someone you can trust can be a lifeline, says Ferrante. While you may be tempted to confide in your office bestie, the ideal confidant is someone who’s been through a similar experience, such as a co-worker who’s more advanced in their pregnancy or has recently returned from maternity leave. Ask how they dealt with the struggles of working while pregnant or returning to the workforce, and how receptive management was to her requests. And if you need some extra guidance or don’t have anyone you feel you can trust, the career coaches on Maven’s platform are pros in this area, and can help you navigate the tricky terrain of balancing your career with the demands of pregnancy and parenthood. Book a video appointment to chat any time, day or night.

title.en-US: How to build your pregnancy support network

content.value: Does it seem like everyone has an opinion on what you should eat, how you should sleep, and what you should buy for the nursery? The noise can be overwhelming if you listen to everyone. That's why it's important to build a trusted support system that you'll actually want to rely on and get ideas from when you're a new parent. Here are some tips on how to start building one now from Maven Mental Health Practitioner Mercedes Samudio.
Q: Are there any ways you recommend parents work to build up a support system prior to giving birth?

We definitely have those systems in place before we become parents. The trick is to realize that you have those supportive people once you give birth, too. New parents tend to isolate once they have a baby because they feel like they're a burden on others. So even though they have family and friends who want to help, I've heard new parents tell me that they don't want to wear out their friends and family with their issues. Or they feel like they should be able to handle these issues on their own.

I encourage you to reach out first, and assess the nature of the support later. Ask for help and see who can help with what. Then, instead of determining that someone won't help, decide who helps with what and go to them for that specific need.

I use this analogy to help conceptualize this: You don't go to Jiffy Lube for a head of lettuce then yell at the mechanic for not helping you get fresh produce. Once you know who can help with what, adjust your expectations and use your support system to help you maintain a healthy state of being.
Q: How do you suggest new parents utilize their support network during pregnancy and after baby?

Everyone in your life has a purpose, whether they are teaching you, nurturing you, helping you build resilience via a rough interaction, or just being present for you. When a new parent realizes that they don't have to raise her child alone or go through their pregnancy alone, they can fully embrace that truth: that each person in their support system is there to help them learn, grow, and get closer to being healthy for themselves and their child.
Q: Any examples from your practice that you've seen where your patients have brought together dream support teams? How did they do that?

What's interesting is that sometimes new parents don't always realize they have their dream support team until we start looking at who is around to support them. One example that happens often is a parent who realizes that they have friends who just show up to help at the right moment, and that can just be through a text, a call, a gift in the mail. New parents can have tunnel vision, especially in the early days caring for a baby 24/7, so when I work with them we start to shed light on some of the lesser-known ways their support system has been there for them all along. I do this to encourage real-time awareness about how resourceful they've been in the past about getting support, and this can help encourage them to feel confident about being able to recreate this when they need it.
Q: What if someone is struggling to find support? Maybe their family is far away. Any advice?

The best advice is to ask yourself, What do I need to feel supported? I encourage new parents to be honest about that. A support system can include interactions with friends, family, or other new parents (even just virtually), as well as services that help you. Even a grocery delivery service can be a huge support if you can't get to the store or Maven where you can literally get support anytime you need it. The idea isn't to recreate someone else's support—or to envy someone else's support—but rather to be honest about what you need to feel replenished and supported, and seek that out.

title.en-US: What you should know about depression during pregnancy

content.value: By some statistics, postpartum depression affects more than 20% of new mothers. But did you know that depression often begins during pregnancy? Moms-to-be are told they’re “just being hormonal,” but if something more serious is at play, it’s crucial to get care. Learn the signs and symptoms from Maven Mental Health Practitioner Mercedes Samudio and share them with the people closest to you so they can be there to spot when somethings’ wrong.
The risks are real.

Depression causes stress hormones such as cortisol to rise. Cortisol can cross through the placenta into the fetus, which could affect your baby’s development. And since depression can also get in the way of self-care, other fallouts may include missed doctor’s appointments, unhealthy eating habits, and new smoking or drinking habits. All of those behaviors raise the risk for pregnancy complications.
Medication is not your enemy.

There are many ways to get help: The important thing is to open up to a professional who can work with you on the best course of treatment. In some cases of prenatal depression, medications shouldn’t be ruled out. A woman and her doctor have to weigh the risks of the drugs against the effects of untreated maternal illness, says Samudio.

“The first step is to talk to your physician. If you’re already on medication for depression, you might take a slightly lower dose, or you and your doctor might decide it’s best for you to titrate off your medication slowly. Every woman is different, and every case is different. If you decide to go off your medication, talk to your doctor and do not go cold turkey, as the withdrawal could hurt your baby, as well as yourself. And then there are the pregnancy hormones. Your body is adjusting to some major changes. You don’t want to mess up your system by going off your meds too soon.”
Talk it out.

Samudio is a big believer in open lines of communication. It’s essential, she says, for pregnant women to talk about how they’re feeling, and to get help if they’re concerned about their mental health. Too often Samudio has seen women suffering from depression isolate themselves from friends and family out of concern for burdening loved ones.

“Isolation makes depression worse,” she said. “I tell my patients to connect with their friends and family as much as they can, even if it's just virtually. It’s good to connect with other women who are going through the same stuff as you are, to see that you’re not abnormal, so looking into online mom groups is a great idea, too. At the same time, if a member of your support group sees that you’re dealing with a more serious mental health issue, they can recommend to you that you get the help you need.”

Samudio also suggests you get your support group talking to one another. This includes the doctors you see on a regular basis. At some point during your pregnancy, you will most likely be given forms to sign in which you can opt to release your records and medical history to other medical professionals involved in your care. Samudio highly recommends you sign those releases.

“That way everyone is talking to everyone and your circle of care knows what’s happening,” she said. “Multidisciplinary care is key during pregnancy. This is especially true if medication and mental health treatment is involved. You want your OB-GYN and psychiatrist and therapist and, yes, even your acupuncturist, to be talking. If you sign those release forms, everyone can talk freely without breaching any confidentiality or running into any ethics issues.”
Be on the lookout for other mood disorders.

Prenatal depression is serious and widespread, but Samudio says that expectant mothers should also be aware of other mental health issues that often strike during pregnancy, including eating disorders in response to one’s changing body and pregnancy-induced psychosis.

“Some women have strong reactions to the weight they gain during pregnancy and can’t wait to take it off,” Samudio said. “Societal pressures about bouncing back right after birth don’t help that issue. And I’ve had mothers suffer from hallucinations brought on by changes in sleep patterns and chemicals in the brain. Some even think they hear their baby crying inside of them. When these sorts of things happen, just know you’re not crazy and you’re not alone, either.”
Samudio has noticed that anxiety is perhaps the most common reaction to pregnancy, which is, after all, a condition rife with unknowns.

“A lot of my patients develop anxiety during pregnancy because literally nothing is certain about being pregnant or raising kids. This is especially true of Type A personalities. It’s difficult to have something happening to your body you can’t control. I tell women dealing with anxiety to stay away from Google and WebMD, because those sites are only going to increase your anxiety. Maybe you have some unexplained pain you’re dealing with or some spotting. Don’t jump to the worst case scenario. Talk to your doctor. When in doubt, always, always, talk to your doctor or to a provider on Maven. We're always here to help ease your mind." You can also take
this questionnaire
to see how severe your symptoms are and share the results with your provider.

title.en-US: Estate planning basics for new parents

content.value: There’s so much to think about during pregnancy—finding an OB-GYN, managing nausea and fatigue, getting ready for maternity leave, and preparing for childbirth—that it can be easy to forget about what comes after the baby’s born, let alone planning for things like your child’s college education or designating a caregiver should anything happen to you and your partner. But while estate planning doesn’t rank among the most pleasant aspects of becoming a parent, it’s necessary, and you’ll feel better knowing you’re prepared.

“You should start thinking about this as early as possible,” advises Maven Career Coach Mary Beth Ferrante. “As soon as you’re pregnant, figure out what assets you have, start a conversation with your partner about getting a lawyer involved, and start drawing up a will and trust.”

Not sure where to start? Ferrante has some tips to get you started. Just note that she’s not a lawyer or financial adviser. Think of this as a first step as you plan for your family’s financial future and protection.
Figure out the basic rules in your state

Estate planning is the process of designating who will inherit your property and look after your children in the event of your death or serious disability, and often encompasses the creation of legal documents such as a will or trust. While you don’t need to get a law degree to navigate the tricky terrain of planning your estate, it helps to know the basic laws in your state. Ferrante, who is based on the west coast, notes: “In California, everyone with property should have a trust, otherwise everything will go through probate, which is a complicated process.” She adds that in some states, a piece of paper stashed away in your desk counts as a legal will as long as it meets certain requirements, such as using certain language that is readily available online. “Of course you want something more formal,” she says. “Your accountant, financial planner, and/or lawyer should have a copy. But it helps to know what you can do in a pinch.”
Designate a legal guardian for your children

Deciding who should care for your kids may be one of the most difficult parts of estate planning. “It’s such a personal decision. I don’t think you can tell people whom to choose, or why you should choose them. Consider the relationship that the guardian will have with your child. Typically, it’s a family member, but not always. Every family situation is unique,” says Ferrante.

Tips for things to take into account? “Consider the age of your guardian—e.g., an aging parent, though if that’s your choice, that’s fine, too,” she says. “Have a chain of command—backup guardians that should step in if unforeseen things happen.” She adds that you can write letters to explain your wishes about how certain situations should be handled, but she cautions that “if you’re feeling the need to micromanage, you probably haven’t chosen the right person. Choosing a guardian has to be a leap of faith. It’s sort of like a birth plan. You should select someone with your values who you think will raise your child the way you’d want them to, and trust that they will.”
Talk to your partner

Ferrante notes that it’s typical—and even helpful—for parents to take on different roles as they prepare for the baby. “You can divide and conquer,” she says. “One partner can look into the financial stuff, while the other one can manage doctor’s appointments and get the home ready for the baby’s arrival.” But when it comes to guardianship and estate planning matters, both parents need to be involved.

She offers some advice for starting the discussion: “Have the conversation at the right time. Don’t do it in the middle of dinner while you’re squabbling over something else. For these bigger discussions, let the other person know that you want to have this conversation, and set up a time. Remember that they may not realize that this has been stressing you out.” If things don’t go as planned, consider booking a session with a Maven practitioner or an appointment with a couples counselor. “It can be helpful to get a third party involved,” says Ferrante.
Find an attorney

“Estate planning is a really hard conversation to have with your partner, especially when you’re getting ready to bring in a new life. A lawyer is helpful,” notes Ferrante. For example, it’s easy to fall into a rabbit hole of what should happen if your designated guardian is unable to look after your children. “The guidance of your lawyer becomes really helpful in figuring out what’s typical, and how to address it.” If you don’t already have a family lawyer, she recommends finding someone who specifically focuses on estate planning and guardianship matters.

She adds that, depending on your financial situation and the number of assets you have to protect, you might also consider speaking with a financial planner and accountant: “The more assets you have, the more you need other players involved.”
Know what resources are available

Of course, not everyone can afford a posse of professionals to get their affairs in order, and even if you can, it’s difficult to know where to find them. Ferrante notes that your bank or investment institution may offer financial planning services at a reasonable cost. If you already have a financial adviser, make sure to ask them what changes need to happen as you get ready for parenthood. She also recommends websites such as Wmn/Wrk, which specifically matches women to vetted financial and legal professionals. You may also want to research savings plans such as 529s, which can help you save for your child’s education.
Plan ahead, ideally before the baby’s born

“If you think things are crazy now, wait till you have a newborn,” says Ferrante. “Things only get crazier. The more you can do upfront, the better.” Don’t worry if you’re too busy to get all the details ironed out just yet. “The most important thing is to start the conversation,” she says. “Know that it’s fluid and ongoing. If you want to write something down and change it later, that’s okay. Remember that none of this is permanent unless something happens. You can change your mind.”

title.en-US: How pregnancy changes your brain

content.value: When pregnant women have bouts of forgetfulness or wild mood swings, it’s often due to changing hormones or biochemistry. Understanding some of the science behind this phenomenon can be empowering, and a relief. Maven OB-GYN Jan van Dis, MD, explains the biochemistry.
What are the most important things to know about the pregnant brain?

Pregnancy impacts hormones and neurotransmitters in the brain, and the way the neurotransmitters and hormones communicate with each other. Pregnancy-induced changes to one category causes changes in the other.

From a scientific standpoint, there’s still a lot we don’t understand about how hormones and neurotransmitters affect each other. We are just beginning to understand some of the key physiologic changes of the maternal brain.

An interactive center in your brain called the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis (HPA axis) is in part responsible for making sure your body does not reject your fetus. When you become pregnant, you are suddenly carrying 23 chromosomes inside of you that are not your own. The immune system’s typical response to such foreign material would be to attack it. This is when the HPA axis steps in and works to dampen the immune system to protect your unborn child. A dampening of your immune system does, of course, leave you more vulnerable to infection, allergies, and other ailments.

We’re designed to support new life, and the crazy and odd things that happen in pregnancy are often highly functional. Our anatomy is so interconnected that brain changes will bring about physiological changes. So there are unintended consequences to the intricate nature of this highly functional system, like mood changes and a decreased ability to combat depression. There are serious side effects to being a pregnant person.

Pregnancy and postpartum depression and mood changes are an integral part of pregnancy and the changes your mind and body undergo. Please reach out for help if you are feeling helpless or alone, sad or angry, and if you can't sleep or you're consumed with anxiety. You can also take
this assessment
to see if you're experiencing symptoms of perinatal depression or anxiety.
What is a common complaint you get from your patients about their mindset during pregnancy?

I think the biggest change patients have shared with me are related to short-term memory issues. Patients state that they can't remember where their car keys are or what day of the week it is or the name of a book. I don't know if these are memory lapses are related to changes in hormones or grey matter, as they could be attributable solely to the consequences of interrupted sleep and sleep deprivation.
What sort of misinformation is out there about the pregnant brain that you would like to see corrected?

In terms of misinformation, I would just like to share with women that the memory issues or brain fuzziness they feel in pregnancy does get better with time. And, if they can imagine that their brain is changing in order to prepare for becoming a mother, then these temporary changes can be perceived as belonging to a greater and exciting purpose.
What advice do you have for women who suffer from mood disorders while they’re pregnant? And what treatments do you recommend?

I’ll be honest with you. I’m afraid that if you suffered from depression or another mood disorder before you became pregnant, chances are good that those issues will worsen. That’s the unfortunate truth for many women, and that’s why it’s so important that they talk to their doctor early and often about how they’re feeling and what might be an effective treatment plan for them. Some women take SSRIs (Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors) or drugs like Wellbutrin to stabilize their mood. But that’s a decision you’ll want to make with your doctor’s help.

Something else to know is that one in seven women will suffer from some form of depression in the first year after giving birth. When you feel depressed during pregnancy, or are overwhelmed with a sense of anxiety when you think about caring for your newborn, it’s human to think that it only affects you. But these issues are so widespread, and there are obvious physiological bases to them. Normalizing these issues should provide solace to women. Women need to know that it’s something that’s happening inside of their body instead of thinking it’s something that they should try to control.
Are there any upsides to the changes your brain undergoes during pregnancy?

Oh, definitely. There is an expression of those substances in the brain that lend themselves to the happiness that comes with preparing for new life. There’s a spiritual element as well, especially for those who might struggle with fertility, since having a child and starting a family can be at the core of how people express their humanity.

title.en-US: How to read baby's cues

content.value: At this point, you’re settled at home with your baby. Perhaps the visitors are thinning out, and your new family life is starting to feel real. And then baby starts crying...and doesn’t stop! Is he hungry? Wet? Wanting some comfort? We talked with Maven Pediatric Nurse Practitioner (and mom of seven!) Jennifer Uzzell about navigating newborns, and a few tips for meeting your own needs.
What to expect those first days at home?
3 a.m. wakeups:

You’ll have to start thinking of time on 24-hour cycles, as your baby doesn’t care if it’s day or night. Generally, newborns eat every two hours, produce 6-8 wet diapers, and likely sleep the rest of the time, gradually staying up and sleeping for longer stretches.
Bathroom talk:

You’ll soon find yourself preoccupied by your tiny human’s bowel movements. Breastfed baby poop is generally a softer consistency than formula-fed. Frequency varies: Some babies poop eight times a day, and some poop every 3-4 days! Color ranges widely, with lots of greens and yellows.
A silver lining:

Rest assured, this insane routine doesn’t last forever. By around six weeks, babies tend to go 3-4 hours between feedings. By 3-4 months they will be sleeping longer at night, and you shouldn’t have to wake them up to feed.
What should a new mom know about breastfeeding?
Things start slow:

The first three (or so) days will be spent waiting for your milk to come in, and you have to keep nursing through it. Your baby will be getting some high-calorie colostrum (pre-milk) during this time, too, so she won’t starve. If three days have passed and you’re not feeling the flow (literally), it’s worth calling your healthcare provider.
Reach out when you need help:

Lactation consultants are basically angels on earth. There are a number of ways you can find one. You may have had a session with a lactation consultant before you left the hospital; she may have given you her information. A great resource with chapters all over the country is the La Leche League (LLLI.org), an organization full of women who are passionate about breastfeeding and willing to do a phone call or consult 24/7. You can also speak to a Lactation Consultant over video chat on Maven anytime you need to.
Is baby getting enough to eat?
Don’t panic
: All newborns lose an average of 10 percent of body weight in their first few days, mainly because they are waterlogged when they’re born, and not eating at first.
Trust your pediatrician:

Baby’s weight is carefully monitored at the pediatrician’s office. The rule of thumb is she should be back up to her birth weight at around the two week mark. If she’s not gaining, then your pediatrician will work with you on a game plan.
Supplement with care: If you’re breastfeeding and opt to supplement with formula, start pumping once a day so your body gets the memo that it needs to make milk.
When does colic start, and what does that look like?
Timeline:
Colic usually rears its head in the second week and tapers off around the three month mark.
Calling card:
Colic is characterized by crying, lots of it—three hours straight. All babies cry. If you can’t get them to stop, it’s likely colic.
Mystery condition:
The jury is out on what causes colic and why some babies get it. Some experts blame gas; some chalk it up to baby’s nervous system being out of whack.
Soothing strategies:

You can try comforting techniques like white noise, swings, rocking, car rides, yoga ball bounces...everyone will have an idea, and it’s all worth trying. Before giving your baby over-the-counter gas drops or gripe water, check in with your doctor.
What are some tips for moms to make sure their own needs are being met?
Work smarter, not harder:
Make peace with a messy house.
Cut corners in your meal planning. Delivery is your friend.
Shop for staple items online.
Stock snacks and water at your baby feeding station/rocking chair, so you can keep yourself fed and hydrated, too.
Say yes to help:

Your loved ones keep saying, “Let me know if I can help!” Now’s the time to take them up on it. Get okay with asking for help with household stuff like taking the dog for a walk, or holding the baby while you take a shower, or folding laundry with a close core group if it's safe to do so.
Take a timeout:

People will tell you to “nap when the baby naps,” but of course that’s the only time you can get stuff done! Before you burn out, however, set limits on how much you take on. One to three tasks a day (aside from basic care of baby and yourself) is generally as much as you’re going to accomplish. Congratulate yourself for those small wins.
Any overall advice for new moms?
“Sleep deprivation hit me hard. I don’t know why I didn’t seeing it coming,” says Uzzell. “Realize from the outset that your world’s going to turn upside down.”

title.en-US: When work reaches out during maternity leave

content.value: Being a new parent can feel all-consuming. Between breastfeeding, changing diapers, and keeping your house in order, it can be easy to forget what’s going on at work. But while it’s important to disconnect and spend those first few weeks after giving birth bonding with your baby, that doesn’t mean that work will totally go away: you may face requests from managers or direct reports, and you may even toy with the idea of heading back to the office early.
If you’re struggling to figure out the right balance, follow these tips from Maven Career Coach Sara Daly-Padron on handling work requests while adjusting to your new role as a parent.
Have a plan

Work out a communication plan with your boss before you go on leave. “What’s really difficult for people is the ambiguity of not knowing if or when they’ll hear from you, or whether it’s ok to ask questions,” says Daly-Padron. She recalls the frustration she felt when her own manager had a baby: “She would log in every once in a while about doing this or that, and it was unclear if I was supposed to be checking in regularly. I’d ask her questions, and by the time she responded, they had usually been answered.”

Instead, tell your boss if and how you want to hear from her under different scenarios—client requests, changes to your team, etc. “The goal is to reduce the questions percolating through your manager’s mind,” says Daly-Padron. And if you didn’t have a chance to get a plan in place before you gave birth, don’t panic. “It can just be an email or quick call with your manager—hey, I’ll take X amount of time to be with the baby, and these are the situations when I’ll check in and want to be checked in with. It’s okay to do it post baby.”
Be realistic

“Where new parents often get in trouble is when they put these unrealistic expectations on themselves of what they will be able to accomplish when they’re on leave. I work with clients that say, ‘when the baby sleeps, I can take some work calls.’ But no! The baby wakes up! It’s so unpredictable,” says Daly-Padron. Setting up unrealistic expectations of your availability, and then being unable to follow through, damages your credibility and leads to frustration in your team. Sticking to your plan also shows that you trust your co-workers and gives them stretch opportunities to prove that they can do things themselves. “If you set up the expectation that you won’t butt in and then you do, it’s worse. It makes people think you don’t trust them. In my second maternity leave, I left everything pretty much to my team and told them: ‘I trust you and expect you to do this,’” says Daly-Padron.

But what if you’re struggling to figure out what’s realistic? “Ask someone who just went through the same experience. Find a friend in the hospital if you need to. Talk to other new parents in your industry to see how they handled it,” she says. And remember to be honest and direct with your manager if things don’t go according to plan: “Tell her—‘I made these plans before the baby, but now the baby’s here and has a plan of his own. So this is what I’d like to do.’ It’s worse to try to keep up with something that you can’t. As soon as you realize it’s not feasible, talk to your boss. Don’t apologize for it. Just be direct.”
Don’t go totally dark

Plan to have at least three check-ins with your manager during your leave—first to quickly let her know you’ve given birth and all is well, a second one about halfway through to see how things are going, and a third near the end to make sure you’re on the same page regarding your return date and any potential changes to your schedule. Beyond that, your availability should depend on your own preferences and what’s realistic in your industry. “For some, being completely checked out isn’t really an option. But it might be feasible for others, like if you’re a teacher and have a substitute covering your time away,” says Daly-Padron.

Also note that checking in doesn’t just benefit your manager—it benefits you, too: “You want to stay top of mind with your team. You’ll need some of this info when you come back, so it’s in your best interests to get a sense of any major updates.”
Defend your boundaries
If your team doesn’t respect your communication plan, you need to defend your boundaries. How you respond may depend on who’s making the request:
Someone you manage

: “Be direct, give them ownership, and keep your message consistent: ‘I’m excited to discuss this when I return, but right now I’m fully focused on my new baby. I have faith that you can handle this,’” says Daly-Padron.
Boss

: “It may not be comfortable, but you still need to be direct. Let them know you’re focused on the baby and the healing process. And remind them that you’re looking forward to your return—it will allay any fears that you’re not coming back.”
Client

: “Don’t get into a conversation with your clients. Instead, set an out-of-office directing them to the right contact while you’re away. If they still reach out, ask your manager if they can help mitigate the situation.”
Consider the impact

While you’re entitled to have no work-related requests while you’re on leave, Daly-Padron recommends considering how following through may affect both you and your team before saying yes or no: “Ask yourself: are you the only person who can answer this question? Is it a good stretch opportunity for someone in your team to be resourceful? Can that client meeting go through without this information? Likewise, will responding to the request put your day over the edge?” Don’t forget to keep things in perspective—after you return, no one will recall if you replied to a random request. But they might remember if you promised to follow through and then couldn’t do it.
Think carefully about the conditions under which you would go back to work early

“I have a client who’s about to give birth and has a 12-month maternity leave (in Canada!), but she was up for a potential promotion, and if it came through, she was willing to go back super early,” says Daly-Padron. She notes that being a new parent can be isolating, and many people crave going back to the office. But you need to think carefully about what it would take for you to cut your leave short, both at work and at home: “You don’t get many of these opportunities in your life, on either side—to bond with your baby, or to get this promotion. Think it through before you jump, because once you’re back, you can’t dip out again. Think about the ecosystem of support you’ll need back home—from your partner, parent, or hired help—and figure out if there’s an in-between, like going in part-time at first, that might make you happier.”

title.en-US: What to ask at your first postpartum checkup

content.value: Due to COVID-19, your doctor and hospital's policies around in-person versus virtual appointments may differ from the information below. Consult your doctor or hospital if you have questions about their COVID-19 policies and procedures.

Remember the slogan, “If you see something, say something”? Same goes with your postpartum care. Now’s not the time to be a hero! If something doesn’t feel right, you need to speak up, says Maven advisor and OB-GYN Jane van Dis. She provides an overview of possible red flags to look out for. She also gives a rundown of frequently asked questions, so you’ll have some ideas of what to discuss with your practitioner.
When to make the appointment?
Newly released guidelines

from the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) recommend that all women see their healthcare provider within three weeks after delivery (replacing the commonly used six-week appointment), and have a comprehensive check-up by 12 weeks postpartum. The idea is to catch possible postpartum issues early. While it may take some time for providers to start following these guidelines, you can be proactive in scheduling your appointment and bringing up any concerns you may have.
Who should see a doctor before three weeks postpartum?
If you have a chronic disease or condition.

According to van Dis, women with certain pre-existing conditions need to be closely monitored in the first weeks after delivery. For instance, those with a seizure disorder or someone who is diabetic may experience some fluctuations that require medication adjustments.
If you have high blood pressure.

Women who developed high blood pressure, preeclampsia, or HELLP during pregnancy are still considered at high risk for complications such as stroke, and need to be checked within the first seven days postpartum, says van Dis.

If you think you might have an infection. All women after birth are at risk for a variety of infections. If you are breastfeeding, you have a chance of coming down with mastitis. If you had a C-section, or stitches from a vaginal birth, there’s a possibility of infection. If you have a fever or shortness of breath, call your doctor immediately and ask if you should head to the emergency room. Infections can turn serious quickly, and this is nothing to mess with.
If you think you might be having blood clots.

All postpartum women are at increased risk for deep vein thrombosis, aka blood clots, says van Dis. (You may have heard of tennis player Serena Williams’s near-death experience.) Look out for warmth, redness, and/or pain in your lower extremities, or shortness of breath, she says, and alert your practitioner if something seems off.
If your mental health is suffering. Six weeks is too long to wait if you are crying nonstop, or feeling worthless, suicidal, or overly anxious, says van Dis.
If something simply doesn’t feel right.
While it might be tempting to brush away any concerns, you owe it to yourself and your baby to get yourself checked out.
Appointment FAQs

According to the new ACOG guidelines, your first postpartum visit should include a full assessment of physical, social, and psychological well-being, including the following domains: mood and emotional well-being; infant care and feeding; sexuality, contraception, and birth spacing; sleep and fatigue; physical recovery from birth; chronic disease management; and health maintenance.

Keeping that in mind and knowing that each individual situation is unique, your practitioner may not hit on all points in your check-up. So be prepared to bring up questions you may have, which could include:
Is it OK to resume intercourse?
Your doctor will likely suggest you wait until the baby is six weeks old, if you feel ready. For those first few times, lubrication is your friend.
What kind of birth control should I go on?

Ideally, your physician or midwife started this conversation while you were pregnant or in the hospital. It’s often a good idea to discuss with your partner whether you plan on having more children, and when. The answer will determine what form of birth control you choose, whether it’s a pill or something longer acting like an IUD, says van Dis.
When can I start exercising again?

You can start walking right away with vaginal birth or Cesarean. If you had a C-section, your provider will likely have you hold off on abdominal crunches for awhile. Ask your doctor about your specific exercise regimen and when it’s safe to return.You might also ask about
abdominal separation
When will my period return?

If you’re not breastfeeding your period can return soon after giving birth. You’ll release an egg before your first period, so make sure you have a plan in place. If you’re breastfeeding, your period may disappear the entire length of breastfeeding, or may come back near 6 months postpartum.
Is it normal to still be bleeding?

It’s normal to bleed on and off for 2-6 weeks postpartum. Sometimes the blood is bright red, but other times it’s dark red or brown; sometimes clots and sometimes not. All is normal. If you soak a pad in 30 minutes or less, head straight to the emergency room.
If breastfeeding, is it OK to take certain medications or supplements?
There are many prescription and over-the-counter medications that are safe with breastfeeding. Ask your doctor or consult this handy article from
Mayo Clinic
I’m having trouble with
(think: breastfeeding, or other baby-care issues).
What about this pain I’m having?
Think urinary incontinence, numbness, hemorrhoids, or painful intercourse. It’s all stuff you should bring up with your doctor.
Is it normal to be crying all the time, feel emotionally unstable, or unusually tense or irritable?
If you haven’t already, take an online assessment tool for postpartum mood disorders (like
this one
) and bring the results to your appointment. Your provider will help determine what’s “baby blues,” and what’s a more serious condition requiring treatment.
Sources
National Institute of Mental Health. Postpartum Depression Facts.
https://www.nimh.nih.gov/health/publications/postpartum-depression-facts/index.shtml.
. Accessed January 15, 2020.
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Reproductive Health: Depression Among Women.
https://www.cdc.gov/reproductivehealth/depression/index.htm#Postpartum
. Accessed January 15, 2020.
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Prevalence of Selected Maternal and Child Health Indicators: Selected 2016 through 2017 Maternity and Child Health (MCH) Indicators by State.
https://www.cdc.gov/prams/prams-data/mch-indicators.html
. Accessed January 15, 2020.
American Psychological Association. Postpartum Depression.
https://www.apa.org/pi/women/resources/reports/postpartum-depression
. Accessed January 15, 2020.

title.en-US: Your postpartum body, explained

content.value: The first few weeks of having a new baby are a blur. But eventually you start to settle into your new routine and, yes, your new body, which can feel like an entirely new place to live. How much of this new body is permanent, and how much is temporary? Maven OB/GYNs Jane van Dis and Jacqueline Stone lend some insight on what physical changes to expect in the first six months, and the best ways you can take care of the new you.
What’s the most surprising thing about physical changes in those first few months?
van Dis

: I would say that you have to expect the unexpected. There will be women who will tell you, “It’s so much easier than I anticipated, and I got my body back right away, and I’m doing all the things that are important to me!” And then, another woman with the same set of birth circumstances will say “I am so wiped out, and I’m not back to normal at all.”
I want to open up the space for women to know there is not one way to experience this postpartum time. You need to find the path that feels right and supports your healing.
Stone

: Don’t forget that it can take at least six weeks for your uterus to go down to your pre-pregnancy size, so a lot of women still look pretty pregnant for the first few weeks. A lot of women deal with hemorrhoids in the first month or so, and that’s because they might have had internal hemorrhoids that literally get pushed out of your body when you’re pushing the baby out. An over-the-counter or prescription cream (often with a numbing agent) can help with that. Those are things that I hear from women all the time that they are shocked to discover.
Recovery from a C-section can be particularly rough, physically. What should C-section moms expect?
van Dis

: The pain might really wax and wane for a lot longer than you’d imagine. You could have days when you think you’re getting back to normal, and the next day you have a lot of pain. The most important thing is to listen to your body.

There are three things that are essential to healing from a C-section (and frankly are beneficial for all women): rest, hydrate, move. Rest is essential for recovery because it decreases steroids and cortisol, both of which interfere with physical healing. Drink as much water as you did when you were pregnant. It’s essential for the healing process and for your milk supply. And the third is to exercise a little bit. I’m talking about walking, not hitting the gym or lifting weights. Not only does it help you physically recover, it gets air into your lungs and helps prevent blood clots.
When do periods come back, and when should women think about birth control?
Stone

: If you don’t want to get pregnant again, you should probably think about birth control sooner than you’d imagine! Breastfeeding raises your progesterone levels, which keeps you from ovulating and getting your period. Some women don’t have a period or ovulate until they wean; for some it happens when they start supplementing. If you don’t breastfeed, you can ovulate within four weeks of giving birth.

If you are exclusively breastfeeding on demand, including overnight, you probably won’t ovulate for six months, but that’s not what you want to rely on for birth control. Breastfeeding women can use birth control pills without estrogen (which can decrease your milk supply), or any progesterone method, such as the shot or implant.
We don’t recommend an IUD until at least six weeks, in order to wait for your uterus to go back to its normal size.
What’s the deal with all the hair that comes out?
Stone
: At some point between four and six months, all the luxurious hair you grew when you were pregnant will fall out. You won’t go bald, and it will come back to normal by about a year after pregnancy.
How do breasts change when nursing?
van Dis

: I was flabbergasted at how big my breasts were with the milk inside. I truly felt like the mammal that I am! It’s normal for some women to have their breasts get big and stay that way—like from an A to a C, and some might start a C and end up an A after they wean.
Will sex be uncomfortable for a long time?
Stone

: If you’ve had a bad tear, sex can be painful for a long time. Breastfeeding, because it lowers your estrogen levels, can also lead to vaginal dryness that often won’t even respond to regular lubrications. Your doctor can prescribe an estrogen vaginal cream that can really help.

title.en-US: How to let go and let people help with the baby

content.value: Do you ask for help only to find yourself saying, “Nevermind, it’s easier if I just do it”? They may not always do things the “right” way (a.k.a. your way) but it’s important that you let your partner, friends, or family help—for you, them, and your baby. Try these strategies from Maven Mental Health Practitioner Mercedes Samudio and Maven Career Coach Mary Beth Ferrante on how to let go and let other people step in so you can take some much needed time for yourself.
You’re not the only one who feels this way...

Samudio, sees this type of pattern all the time: the person who gave birth to the child is often the one with the baby most, so over time,and understandably, they think that they're the one who can take care of baby the best. Their partner gets shut out, stops trying to help, those roles get solidified, and both sides get resentful.

“Sometimes it’s true that one parent is better at things because often they're the one taking care of the baby for a greater amount of time, and sometimes they just thinks ‘it’s easier for me to do it,’” Samudio says.
... And there may be some legitimate reasons behind this phenomenon

There is some biology at play, as pregnancy does change the brain and impacts the intensity of emotional responses the person who gave birth to the baby can feel towards their baby, says Mary Beth Ferrante, a Maven counselor who specializes in working with parents as they adapt to their new roles in work and relationships.

There are cultural factors as well. Ferrante says many of her clients many of her clients have progressive “50-50” relationships where they split responsibilities more evenly when they are dating and married, but things shift when baby comes. Then there are interpersonal pressures. Most couples having a child have usually been together for long enough that they think they’ve tackled the basics of good communication, says Samudio. But once baby comes, they realize there might be more ground to cover.
“Couples often make a lot of assumptions about who is going to do what once the baby comes,” Samudio says. “When the other person doesn’t match that assumption, you run into difficulties.”
That said, you must learn to give up some control
Just as there is science behind maternal attachment, there is also emerging research about the importance of your partner’s involvement.

“The more your partner gets to bond with your baby, the more they take on the same protective tendencies you have,” Ferrante says. Finding ways to strengthen and nurture bonding by the parent who didn't go through physical childbirth is always going to be a good thing. And if that partner has a different way of doing things—all the better. The way you might help your baby calm down could be different from your partner’s method but both outcomes are, well, a calm baby.

Ask yourself: Is this something that really matters? Hint: If it’s brand of formula that doesn’t give him gas, or the rash cream that works with her skin type, let your partner know why that one is the better choice. If it's criticizing the way they hold the baby, or rechecking to see if the diaper bag is stocked—see if you can let it go.

“That can actually be a benefit. As a child growing older, they are more flexible and they can adapt and get to the same solution in a few different ways,” says Ferrante. “My partner and I have totally different playlists that we play at night, and they may be different but they are still great. My older one is three now, and he’ll break into Billy Joel and I’ll get to watch them have those moments and be excited that he gets to be the dad he wants to be.”
How do you learn to let go? Practice, and a little bit at a time.

“I say this to working parents all the time: you have to separate yourself and trust that everything is going to be fine, that two people can do things differently and still be loving,” Ferrante says.

Start small, Ferrante advises. “Leave for a few hours to go to a class or lunch with a friend, and don’t turn on the monitor and listen in on everything that is happening and judge,” she says. “If you physically need to remove yourself to stop yourself from stepping in, go for a walk until you get into the flow and it’s more natural and normal.”
Let your partner “fail” a bit. Remember, If they forgets the wipes, it’s not the end of the world, Ferrante says (and next time they’ll probably remember the wipes.)
To keep communication flowing, make it a priority

Getting good at switching off takes time and a good connection between partners. Every day or so, try to take 15 minutes to really talk to each other, Samudio advises. It seems basic, but those types of check-ins often get left behind in the daily grind. “At night is probably easier because no one is rushing around to the next place.” Really listen to each other and talk about your day, and ask about your partner’s day.

“Too often we wait to have these conversations until we are crying on the kitchen floor feeling overwhelmed,” says Ferrante. And at that point, your partner may feel the impulse to just “fix it” and say “What do you want me to do?”

“A lot of people really need to take that step back and say, ‘This is not about just doing something right now, it’s about sitting down and talking for 20 minutes about how we can better plan for the next week,’” Ferrante says. One of her clients found success in catching up and planning while they were driving with their partner. “He was sort of a captive audience in the car.”

If you find that communicating with your partner—whether it’s about taking over for a few hours, or any aspect of child-rearing—is becoming more difficult, don’t hesitate to bring in some outside help. That holds doubly true if your communication problems are exacerbated by some postpartum blues or depression.
“Sometimes it’s a great idea to look to a therapist or a counselor to help you navigate these times,” says Samudio.

In the end, it really truly will be okay, even if it’s not 100% okay. Ferrante recalls the time she was away and her partner was the one home for the two-hour crying jag and the diaper explosion and the eruption of spit-up. So what do partners do in those situations?

“They just have to go through the same struggles that you do,” she says. In his case, it ended with them both covered in bodily fluids, asleep on the couch. “It allowed them to have that same moment that I might have had. And they were both fine.”

title.en-US: The real deal on new parent loneliness

content.value: By now, you may be feeling like you’ve got your groove, but with that can come feelings of monotony and loneliness as you face endless diaper changes and feedings. Are you longing for some stimulation? Adult conversation? Sounds like you need to shake things up and get out of the house! Maven Mental Health Practitioner Mercedes Samudio gives some advice on how to break through feelings of isolation.

To start, you’re not the only one going through this, says Samudio. New parents can feel cut off from people and activities they used to enjoy due to the duties that come with taking care of babies and children. Often, new parents feel like they shouldn’t ask for help when they need it, because we see asking for help as a sign that we’re not able to “do it all.” The good news? You’re not alone, and you can start find the support you need in just a few easy steps.
Step 1: Start by soul searching

“One of the most important things to do is realize what you need,” says Samudio. 
Ask yourself a few basic questions:
What do I need? (Comfort? Fellowship? Connection? Wine?)
Who can meet these needs for me? (Partner? Family member? Other moms?)
How can I make it happen? (Plan a date night with your partner? Call a friend to reconnect? Look online for new parent groups to join?)
Step 2: Find your tribe
For many first-time parents, there’s a lot of solidarity to be found by
joining a new parent group

. Being around others who are “in the trenches” can help you feel less alone and give you the confidence or companionship you might be looking for. “It’s really important to get out and seek support,” says Samudio. “Again, it’s important to keep in mind your needs, how often you’d like to get out, and what types of moms you want to connect with.”
Step 3: From URL to IRL

As it turns out, “parent dating” is not unlike couples dating, where many start online first. Since new parents don’t have the luxury of time to “play the friend field,” Samudio recommends going through a vetting process before meeting up in person. Start by joining a few new parent groups online via Facebook or other online communities. From there, try to spark up some one-on-one connections with people who seem to share your parenting approach/values. When you’re ready, ask to do a phone or video call before setting up coffee meet-ups or baby playdates. “That way you get to know who this person is before you spend time with them,” says Samudio.
Troubleshooting
Here are some common trouble spots you might encounter in your new endeavors and tips for working through it.
Issue 1: Getting out the door is hard.
Solutions?
Ease into outings.
Try starting small with a stroller walk or quick trip to the store and build up from there. Find some new parents to walk with for a double win of exercise and bonding time.
Practice makes perfect.

When you first come into parenthood, you are still getting to know your child and what they're like, says Samudio. Once you’ve gone out with them a few times, you’ll get a stronger understanding of what to expect, such as recognizing the warning signs that come before a crying jag or cues for when baby’s getting hungry. As you gain confidence, getting out of the house will seem easier and feel like less of a hurdle to overcome.
Issue 2: Super fussy baby.
Solutions?
Have them come to you.

Maybe you simply don’t have the energy to get out to a mom group but still crave connections. Try doing a video chat so you can still connect with people in a way that feels real. If you’re up for it, create your own group and try hosting mommy and me playdates at your house.
Go solo.
Maybe you need to slip out and check out the new parent group sans baby. If you have the ability, see if someone can come by for a few hours so you can get out on your own.
Issue 3: Too much clique.
Solution? It’s OK if it’s not for you.

Feeling like you are cast as an extra in “Mean Girls”? Just remember, your time is precious and you don’t need to waste on it on stuff that doesn’t feel right. You’re better off finding people that you have things in common with, or maybe new parent groups aren’t your thing. Either way, it’s OK. “Joining a new parent group isn’t mandatory,” says Samudio. Instead, look for some other way to meet your self-care needs. Maybe it’s joining a book club or checking out a yoga class or some other activity that isn’t as parent-centric.
Issue 4: The struggle is real
Solution? Seek professional help.

If you are noticing that your fears, stresses and feelings of overwhelm are getting in the way of getting of living your best life, then it’s a good idea to reach out to your health care provider. “Don’t be afraid to get out there and get the help you need,” says Samudio. “Say ‘hey, I’ve been noticing this about myself’ and get an evaluation or ask for a referral for a therapist. Do what you need to do your mental health.”

title.en-US: How to prepare for your work check-in

content.value: After several weeks of bonding with your baby (and perhaps living in your PJs), work can seem like a distant reality. But as your first day back draws near, it’s important to check in with your manager to make sure you’re on the same page regarding your return date, get up to speed on major updates, and negotiate any potential accommodations you might need as you adjust to your new role as a working parent. “This check-in is an opportunity to instill confidence in your return, and also to gain perspective on what has transpired while you’ve been out,” says Maven Career Coach Sara Daly-Padron, who’s also a mother of three girls. She prepared a list of questions to consider before chatting with your boss to ensure you’re set up for success as you transition back to work.
1. Do you have childcare to look after the baby during your check-in?

“Don’t rely on the baby napping to conduct this conversation! Babies have agendas of their own,” says Daly-Padron. The last thing you want is to have to soothe a crying infant while trying to assure your boss that you’ll be just as productive if you work from home on Fridays. So line up a baby-sitter or have your partner look after your little one while you chat with your manager—you’ll be less stressed out and better able to focus on your call.
2. Are you clear on your return date?

The foremost question on your manager’s mind will probably be: when are you coming back? And that’s a good thing—it means you’re a valued member of the team and they miss you! “If you’re not clear on your exact return date, that’s ok,” says Daly-Padron. Try to work it out during this conversation, and if you can, arrange to come back on a Wednesday or Thursday instead of a Monday. The first week can be tough, and having the weekend just a couple of days away will make your transition much easier.
3. What is your vision of life as a working parent? Does it match what you’ve told your manager?

You should leverage your check-in to instill confidence in your return and commitment to the company. But it’s equally important to think about how you wish to balance work and family. Ask yourself: what is your vision of life post-baby? In her experience with clients, Daly-Padron finds that parents often need to think a lot more carefully about what they want their day-to-day to look like: “You often hear people say that they want to work part-time. But they don’t think through the details of what that means, or what being a working parent means: what train you need to take, what time you need to wake up, etc.”

“Once you have clarity on your vision, ask yourself if it matches what you’ve told your boss, or if you need to negotiate some changes,” she says. While she doesn’t recommend giving anything up before the baby arrives—because it’s difficult to predict how you’ll feel a few months down the line—by the time you’re halfway through your leave, you may have a much clearer idea of what you want. “The check-in is an opportunity to put a stake in the ground and convey what’s important to you—both in terms of your schedule, and in terms of work, like what clients/projects you intend to take back. I’ve heard of parents coming back and being told that someone else has been handling this client, so they’ll keep this account. Think about your priorities, and be clear about what your intentions are,” she says.
4. Who’s the ultimate decision-maker, and what is most important to them?

Does your manager have the power to grant your requests, or will they need approval from their own boss? If it’s the latter, don’t simply ask for your manager’s support if you need an accommodation to ease your transition—ask how the two of you can work together to make sure others in the company are on board. “Think through the biggest concerns that the ultimate decision-maker will have. Is it client coverage? Project coverage? Then try to answer that question in advance,” advises Daly-Padron.

And remember—the company wants to retain you, so if granting you short-term flexibility makes it more likely that you’ll stay, it benefits them as well as you. “It helps to keep your employer’s perspective in mind when you frame your requests,” says Daly-Padron. “Don’t say that modifying your hours will help you get more sleep—say it’ll ease your transition and allow you to be more focused and present when you’re in the office.”
5. What are you willing to give up?

“Know your walkaway point,” says Daly-Padron. “If you want to go in only part of the week and your boss says you can’t, but you can leave at 3pm every day—will that work for you? And think about what paid and unpaid options you’ll consider. If your boss won’t give you Fridays off, can you use vacation time? Would you do it if it’s unpaid?” Also consider how your requests might affect your bonus, managerial responsibilities, and eligibility for promotions. “It’s unrealistic to think you can work less and everything will continue in the same trajectory,” notes Daly-Padron.

She advises parents to ask for temporary flexibility (like work-from-home Fridays, or coming and leaving earlier) before requesting permanent changes like going part-time, for several reasons: Part-time staff are at higher risk of getting laid off during downturns; you may not be able to go back full-time later if you change your mind; and you might get reduced pay and benefits while still doing the same amount of work. She recalls her own experience going part-time: “I stayed home with my twins on Fridays, but the rest of the week, I worked so hard! And many of my colleagues worked from home on Fridays anyway, so it wasn’t that different from what I was doing. I was taking a 20% pay cut but not a 20% reduction in work. So I switched to Tuesdays.”

She adds that temporary accommodations may be extended if you prove you can still get your work done: “I first went back with a flexible work arrangement—I asked for six months, my boss agreed to three, and when the three months were over, my boss was like, of course you can keep it! I didn’t even notice!”
6. Are there parent groups or mentors at the company you can reach out to?

Think about others at your company who’ve gone through a similar experience or who might be able to mentor you and help you adjust. “A mentor can provide you with valuable intel on what’s acceptable and what’s frowned upon,” says Daly-Padron. She relied on a mentor in deciding to extend her own maternity leave by tagging on vacation time: “Having the mentor perspective is so important. It helped me realize that a longer leave was better than coming back and then taking a series of days off that no one had planned for.”

title.en-US: Getting your childcare and back-up options set

content.value: Having childcare that you feel good about is the most important factor when you return to work. If you haven’t secured childcare yet,
start here

. Then use these tried and true steps from Maven Career Coach Mary Beth Ferrante to transition your baby (and more importantly you!) into a new schedule with your childcare provider. And don’t forget to sign up for back-up care. Things happen and you don’t want to be left scrambling at 6:30am on a Monday.
What are some things to be thinking about as the back-to-work date gets closer?
The answer partly depends on what type of childcare situation you have.
For those in the daycare or homecare route
Check in:

Start by touching base to reconfirm your spot and start date. Meet with someone to go over any last-minute questions, and run through how they communicate back to the parents. You’ll want to make sure their lines of communication are really open.
Ease in:

Give yourself at least a week of transition time to slowly ease into it. For example: The first time you stay with baby. Next time leave baby for a few hours, and gradually build up to leaving baby the full day.
If nanny or grandparent (or other family member) are doing home care
The transition:

Even if the care will be happening at your house, it’s still helpful to ease in the new provider in the last week or so of your maternity leave. It will give the provider time to get familiar with baby and your house, and for you to get comfortable having them in your home.
Figure out a system:

Whether it’s writing things down in a notebook or using an app, you’ll want the provider to track daily milestones and info such as naps and feeding times, what baby ate, etc. It will make those morning and evening transition times simpler and easier. Be sure to loop your partner in on baby’s schedule and preferences as they change.
Iron out the details:

If you haven’t already, flesh out what “extras” the provider will be responsible for with baby’s care. Should they be picking up the messes? Doing the laundry? Also, if they are watching baby in your home, offer to stock the cupboards with some of their favorite snacks or coffee. It will help them feel welcome and make your relationship stronger.
If the childcare provider will be driving:
Take a test drive:
To make sure you’re comfortable, you may want to go for an outing with provider and baby and have the provider drive. You’ll also want to make sure the car seat is safely installed and ready to go.
What are some tips for getting mom and baby into a new schedule?
Trial run:
Every family is different, but whatever your situation is, do at least one trial run. Time it out, so you feel comfortable with what the structure is going to be.
Involve your partner:

Keep in mind you’re also transitioning your partner, especially if they are taking on a new role in the morning routine. Chances are, they’ve been back to work already, so their routine will be changing, too.
It’s OK to put baby down:
Don’t feel like you have to rope baby into every little detail. Put her in a swing or bouncer so she can have a little downtime while you get ready.
Pre-game the night before:

It’s the little things that can derail you, so take a bit of time to pack lunches, work bag, diaper bag the night before. Pick out yours and baby’s outfits. The fewer decisions you have to make in the morning, the better it will go.
Keep track of essentials:
A small tip: Use a small bag for your important things—wallet, keys, phone, sunglasses. It makes it easy to keep track of stuff when switching between your work bag and your diaper bag.
Streamline whenever possible:
Look for ways to simplify the routine. For example, as baby starts eating food, they can eat the same thing for breakfast every day.
What to consider when thinking about back-up care?
Employer-backed options:

If your employer (or partner’s employer) offers back-up care as a benefit, sign up for it and make sure you stay current on getting them information they might need, such as medical records and contact information.
Emergency contacts:
Get a plan in place for who you can call in a pinch. Is it a neighbor? Friend? Family member? Communicate that to your primary provider, too.
Run through worst-case scenarios:

Have a conversation with your partner on what happens when baby’s sick and can’t go to daycare or the nanny calls out. While often the assumption is that mom stays home, you have a job and a career too, and it’s better to talk through the logistics before it happens at 6 a.m.
Keep daycare informed:
