Make sure daycare has easy access to both parents and emergency contacts. One thing that can be helpful is have them communicating with both you and your partner, copying you both on the emails, texts, etc. It takes training, but it also takes some of the pressure off mom as the default parent.
What if mom has last-minute jitters or is second-guessing her decision?
This concern can fall into a variety of categories:
Is it anxiety that you’re feeling?

If so, and it’s debilitating to the point where you don’t want to leave the house, or are having overwhelming negative thoughts about leaving your baby, you likely should seek some mental health help.
Are you concerned about baby’s safety?

Let’s say you are transitioning into your childcare situation and observe your provider practicing unsafe methods: pull the plug immediately. If it doesn’t feel right, trust your mom gut and go with a different option.
Is it a sadness about the separation issue?

If it’s a more emotional feeling (which is perfectly normal and understandable!), try to not to let yourself get too worked up before the big day. You might end up surprising yourself on how fast the workdays will fly by.
Are you questioning whether your childcare situation is a good fit?

If you are otherwise feeling OK, try giving it a week or two to see where your misgivings are coming from and whether it’s just unease about the disruption and change. If you still aren’t happy with your situation, see if you can adjust your budget/plan and try something else. By all means, don’t feel like you are stuck with something that’s not working.
Are you having second thoughts about returning to work?
Try talking to work and see if you can start part-time and ramp up the schedule. Or do a few days a week remotely to ease the transition.

In all of these scenarios, give yourself some grace and remember: This period of change is temporary, and over time you will adjust to the new normal. In the meantime, don’t be afraid to ask for help and go easy on yourself.

title.en-US: 6 rules for returning to work

content.value: You may think you’re done with major life changes for a while now that you’ve survived pregnancy, childbirth, and the first few months of new parenthood. But according to Maven Career Coach Mary Beth Ferrante, becoming a working parent is as much a transition as becoming a parent in the first place—you’ll soon be responsible for feeding, clothing, and caring for not only your baby but also your boss, clients, and direct reports. (Fine, they can feed and dress themselves, but they’re still a lot of work!) If you’re feeling a little overwhelmed, you’re not alone. Ferrante recommends following these six rules to make your transition back to work less daunting.
1. Start mid-week.

Remember the Monday blues? When you have a newborn, it’s easy to lose track of what day of the week it is (your baby’s 6am feeding holds whether it’s Wednesday or Saturday!). But when you’re working, Mondays can be especially tough. To ease your transition back, Ferrante recommends starting on a Wednesday or Thursday instead: “Having only two or three days to get through before the weekend feels a lot less overwhelming.”
2. Set boundaries.

“One of the hardest parts of coming back to work after a baby is resetting expectations,” says Ferrante. “We come back expecting to be exactly as we were before we left. But our schedule has changed. If you were the type of person that stayed at the office until 9 p.m. every night, and that’s no longer possible or desirable, the question becomes: how do you still get your work done? Part of it is being more efficient (e.g., cut down on the water cooler chat)—and research shows parents are great at that. But you also have to set boundaries.” Perhaps you need to start your day earlier so you can be out by 5 p.m. to pick up your baby from daycare. Or maybe you leave earlier but commit to logging on for a couple of hours every evening after putting your baby to sleep. Whatever it is, take the time to think through your new schedule to make sure it works for both you and your team.

Some tips for setting and protecting your boundaries? “Once you’ve established them, stop talking about it,” says Ferrante. “Don’t remind your manager you’re leaving in 30 minutes. Instead, block your calendar so people will notice if there’s a conflict.” And think about the impact on your direct reports—if you’re leaving at 5 p.m. every day but logging on later that evening, let them know you’re not expecting a response at 10 p.m. Or consider using a tool like Boomerang to delay your emails.
3. Communicate—with your boss, team, and direct reports.

Ferrante recommends approaching your first few days post-maternity leave almost as if you were starting a new job: “Go in with curiosity. What has changed? Use the time to reorient yourself. Schedule 10- to 15-minute check-ins with people. Figure out where everything stands, and prioritize what projects you should take back immediately and where you’ll need guidance from your co-workers. Catch up with your boss on the best way to move forward.”

Hopefully, by the time your first day rolls around, you’ve already established any major changes to your schedule with your boss. But if you haven’t, now’s the time to do it. “Sit down with your manager and run through how everything is going and how you’re feeling. Reiterate that you’re committed to being back, but make sure you’re realistic about your new normal,” says Ferrante. And once you’ve touched base with your manager, make sure you communicate any major changes to your team and direct reports. “People don’t want to be blindsided,” she says, adding that you may need to circle back with your boss after talking to your team to make sure everyone’s on the same page.
4. Leverage your partner and/or support network.

Before you negotiate changes to your work schedule, sit down with your partner and figure out who will handle tasks such as daycare, drop-offs, pickups, dinner, and coordinating with the nanny or other hired help. Ferrante recommends being strategic about how you split up responsibilities: “Look at your goals and your partner’s. It doesn’t have to be that you always do pickups and he or she always does drop-offs. Instead, find a balance, and be open to changes as you go along.” She suggests sitting down each Sunday to figure out what days of the week you need to be home for pickups and bedtime, and which day(s) you can work more like “your normal self” and go to happy hour, a client dinner, or a networking event. “Don’t forget to discuss what happens if the nanny cancels or your baby is sick,” she notes. “Have backup options, and have a backup to your backup. Establish with your partner who will handle certain situations so it doesn’t always default to you.”

If you don’t have a partner, make sure to leverage your support network—relatives and friends—and assess what additional resources you may need to balance parenthood with your career, whether it’s having your nanny stay overtime certain evenings, or relying on backup child care such as Urbansitter or Care.com.
5. Focus on getting things done rather than being perfect.

Ferrante is a firm believer in one of Sheryl Sandberg’s favorite mottos: “Done is better than perfect.” “Remember, your old work self may have been operating at 120 percent most of the time, but that doesn’t mean that your 100 percent isn’t okay,” she says. “Trying to be perfect will exhaust you. A lot of people love being really busy, and doing work ‘extracurriculars.’ If you still love doing that, you should definitely try. But there are areas in your career that don’t require as much perfection.” If you’re feeling overwhelmed, think about what’s most important in your line of work, and focus on that.
6. Expect the unexpected.

Ferrante warns that your first day back at work is a little like a birth plan—even the best laid plans can go awry. “Don’t come in with zero expectations, but remember that every person is really different. You may walk in and feel really happy to have adult conversations again. Or you may come in and cry every 10 minutes. Either way is okay. If you feel the tears coming, remove yourself from the situation and go for a walk, or maybe check in with your nanny.” And if you really feel you need to, be upfront with your manager and see if you can go home early.

title.en-US: Need-to-knows about your postpartum body

content.value: It’s not your imagination, your hair is falling out in larger clumps and here’s why you don’t need to worry: this is just one of the many changes your postpartum body is still working its way through as you near the six-month mark. Here’s what else you can expect and why it’s important to keep—or start!—giving your health the attention it deserves.
Your body is still in recovery

It can take a year or longer for your body to recover from pregnancy and childbirth—it just performed a pretty amazing feat, after all! And while some things may begin to look and feel more familiar with time, other changes can linger or be permanent and these changes are both unique to every woman and every pregnancy. For example, some women may continue to have heartburn or hemorrhoids for several years after birth. If you are having any health concerns, talk to your doctor or an 
OB-GYN on Maven.
Your pelvic floor is also still in recovery

Your pelvic floor helps to hold your bladder in place. Pressure from pregnancy on the pelvic floor and pushing during labor can impact how well your pelvic floor does its job after. According to Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, “If you’re having problems with incontinence when you laugh or sneeze, that can be a sign of pelvic floor weakness. An OB with a special certification in pelvic floor issues or a physical therapist can not only help you exercise properly, but can also provide treatments that can help your pelvic floor recover.”
You may not have lost the “baby weight”

While we watch celebrities “bounce back” in just a few months after pregnancy, showing off washboard abs, what we don’t see is everything else happening behind the scenes: personal trainers, nutritionists, live-in nannies (...really good lighting). In other words, a lot of help that most new moms don’t have. Try your best not to compare yourself to others and instead talk to a Maven Nutritionist for help creating a personal health plan that works for your lifestyle.

According to Maven OB-GYN and Medical Director Jane van Dis, “As we get older, we may have to exercise more to see the same results. I often tell new mothers in their 30s that 30-45 minutes of cardio exercise 4-5 times a week can help but, understandably, this can be hard to do with an infant.” Luckily, there is a lot of research about the benefits of high-intensity interval training. Speak to a physical therapist about ways to make the most of a short workout.

If you find that the exercises you did pre-pregnancy don’t seem to have the same effect, a Physical Therapist can help with that as well. For example, if you have a lingering stomach “pooch,” it may be related to an underlying condition, such as diastasis recti (when the abdominal muscles separate during pregnancy). A physical therapist can assess and provide tips on the right exercises to strengthen your core, instead of possibly making the condition worse.
Your period may have come back

At this stage, some women may have had their period return, though if you are exclusively breastfeeding, it may take longer. It will become more regular over the months ahead but may remain heavier than pre-pregnancy. If your period is very heavy, talk to your OB-GYN to ensure that you don’t become anemic from low iron.
You may have stretch marks and that is a-okay

Some women get stretch marks and some do not. The discoloration of stretch marks can be bright right after birth and fade with time or they not. According to Maven OB-GYN and Medical Director Jane van Dis, “You can be 5’3” and have twins and not have stretch marks while another woman can be tall and lean and have one baby, and they get stretch marks. It’s really just genetics.” Think of them less as an eye-sore and more as a mark of how amazing your body truly is! If your stretch marks really bother you, van Dis doesn’t recommend over-the-counter creams as they are not proven to work. Talk to a dermatologist for recommendations instead.
You still may not be sleeping, but now’s a great time to start!

The solution to so many problems seems to be sleep, yet many mothers find it impossible to get the rest they need. Six months postpartum can be a great time to connect with a baby sleep specialist who can help you sleep train your baby so you can both get the rest you need. At six months of age, many babies are developmentally ready to sleep for longer periods of time. And sleep training doesn’t have to mean “crying it out.” You can video chat with an Infant Sleep Coach on Maven for help putting together a plan that works for you and your family.
And finally, you may be hesitant to talk to your OB-GYN, but please don’t be

There is absolutely no conversation that is off-limits with your OB-GYN and chances are that there is a solution for the problem you’re experiencing. As Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone explains, “I’ve had so many patients come in with problems—painful sex, chronic yeast infections—that they assume they just have to deal with them. But there are things that can be done to fix these problems if you share them with your doctor.”

If you feel uncomfortable talking to your OB-GYN because of a negative experience in their care, it may be time to find a new OB-GYN who will better help and support you. And if you have trouble finding the time for an in-person appointment (working mom much?) remember that you can always speak to an OB-GYN on Maven within 10 minutes—from home, work, or anywhere in-between.

title.en-US: How to handle the second shift

content.value: The second shift is all the work that needs to be done for your baby and your home, after a full day’s work. As a working parent, bedtime routines and endless laundry can pile up on top of the normal housework. Many new parents find themselves scraping together dinner at 9pm, so you’re not alone. Try these tips from Maven Career Coach Mary Beth Ferrante to help you split duties and prioritize.
1. Talk to your partner

Going back to work is a major transition not only for you, but also your entire family. Ferrante recalls, “I had a client say to me: ‘I didn’t expect my partner to be so traditional.’ What tends to happen is that you’re on maternity leave longer than your partner, so traditional gender roles tend to fall into place. You’ve been making dinner, keeping the house put together, and caring for the baby. So when you go back to work, it’s almost the time when your partner's life really changes. Even your own vision of what parenthood is supposed to look like may change.”

She notes that her most successful clients are those who speak openly with their partners (if they have one) and have a plan in place before their maternity leave ends. “So many couples don’t have these conversations until they’re basically freaking out,” she says. “If you have a partner, sit down with them and figure out who will do what. People have a tendency to just do without having actual conversations. But this leads to disaster.”
2. Make your partner a co-owner

The person who gave birth often doubles as the CEOs of their household and babies—tending to be the ones thinking strategically about what they need to do themselves, what they can outsource, where a partner can help, and what needs to happen if things go wrong. But all this planning and worrying—what Ferrante calls the “mental load”—can be just as exhausting as actually doing the tasks at hand. The best way to share the load with your partner? Make them a co-owner. “Let them take over completely,” Ferrante advises. “If you agree that they’ll do the grocery shopping and they forget the milk, they have to be the one to run out and buy it. If you’re still responsible for making the list and checking through the fridge to make sure it’s all there, then it’s not really on their plate.”

If you’re splitting responsibilities like drop-offs and pick-ups, make sure you’re both included in communications from the school. And if you’ve been managing any services at home, say a cleaning service, during maternity leave but your partner is taking over now that you’re going back to work, make sure they knows that they will now communicate with your partner directly. “It may take more work to do all this reminding and reshuffling in the beginning,” says Ferrante. “But eventually it pays off.”
3. Use your weekends wisely

“This is often the hardest thing for dual-income families,” says Ferrante. “After a week of work, you just want to have fun and relax when the weekend comes around. But maybe you can set aside Saturday mornings to run all your errands, or Sunday evenings to do meal prep for the rest of the week so you’re not exhausted and scrambling to get dinner together on Thursday.” Plus, there are advantages to getting things done on the weekend—you’re probably less stressed, and if you have a partner at home, one of you can look after the kids while the other one does a few loads of laundry or refills a prescription.
4. Outsource what you can

A new study shows that working parents who outsource household tasks—by ordering in, paying for a cleaning service, or hiring a dog walker, for instance—are happier than when they spend that money on material goods (shocker!). And perhaps most interestingly, hiring help isn’t just a solution for the wealthy: the correlation between outsourcing and happiness is even stronger among the less affluent. “If you have the financial wherewithal to hire help, do it,” says Ferrante. Reflect on what would make your life easier—whether it’s having someone deep-clean your home once a month so you only have to do light cleaning the rest of the time, or paying the nanny to stay late some evenings or help around the house. Ferrante notes that “a lot of people also have nannies do laundry or light meal prep. Some care providers do it naturally, but not all do, so don’t make assumptions. When you work out your contract with your nanny, the tendency is to focus only on the child. But if your time is worth more than what you’re paying the nanny, it makes sense to pay extra to take some things off your plate.” And the next time you’re tempted to splurge on a nice pair of shoes, ask yourself if you’d be happier spending that money on a babysitter so you can enjoy a night off.
5. Embrace life hacks
Even if you can’t afford to hire a full-time nanny or a cleaning service, Ferrante has a list of so-called “life hacks” to save you time (and buy you happiness):
Get an Insta-Pot
“You can make a chicken casserole in 20 minutes using this pot. It’s really easy. And unlike a Crock-Pot, you don’t need to do meal prep the night before—you can start at 6pm and eat by 8.”
Put anything you can on a subscription service
Think: diapers, formula, dog food. It’s usually cheaper, but more importantly, it’s less to think about.
Order your groceries online through providers like Amazon Fresh, Instacart, Shipt, or Fresh Direct
You might pay a little bit more, but there are often introductory deals, and you’ll save money on transportation and childcare.
Leverage pick-up services at stores like Walmart and Target

“You can pre-order everything, and then show up and they’ll put it in your trunk. You don’t even have to get out of your pajamas,” says Ferrante, adding that these services are often free, since what the stores are really interested in is getting your business.
Use Maven and other technology to “hack” your health

Whether it’s having a video chat with a therapist through Maven, or using apps like Heal for on-demand house calls from a doctor, it’s never been easier to get your medical questions answered without hauling yourself to the doctor’s office.

title.en-US: Dealing with working parent guilt

content.value: Studies show that the children of working mothers may actually fare better than those whose mothers stay home—they exhibit lower rates of depression and anxiety, have more open attitudes toward gender roles, and tend to be high achievers in school. Daughters of working moms are also more likely to be employed, earn more, and hold leadership positions when they grow up. But these stats may offer little consolation when you drop off your crying toddler at daycare or miss your baby’s first steps because you were at the office. If you’re wracked by working parent guilt, read on for some tips to help you cope from Maven Career Coach Mary Beth Ferrante and family therapist Mercedes Samudio.
Remind yourself why you work

“When my clients feel guilty over leaving their children, I always start off with their vision and goals for going back to work,” says Samudio. “If they need to go back to support the family financially, I remind them that they’re not leaving their kids because they don’t care about them, but rather because they need to make sure everyone has enough to eat, clothing, a good education, etc. For moms who don’t need the money but crave that professional identity, we talk about the importance of that goal to their own well-being and ability to set an example for their children. And we figure out how much they need to work to maintain that identity while also being present as a parent.”
Tune out other people’s expectations

Over 40 percent of adults in the U.S. say that the increase in working mothers is bad for society, and “it’s this societal pressure that lies at the crux of working parent guilt,” says Samudio. She notes that as women have come into the workforce in increasing numbers over the past 30-40 years, it’s been difficult for us as a society to figure out “what families are supposed to look like when both parents work.” Ferrante recalls a conversation with a client: “She asked her husband: why is dad guilt not a thing? He said it’s because no one at work and no one around him is putting guilt on him. It’s important to understand that we may be feeling this way because of the expectations of others, not our family. Trust yourself and your decision process and do as much as you can to tune out other people.”
Stick to your schedule

“Block your calendar with a buffer,” advises Ferrante. “If you have to leave the office at 5:30pm to get your kid from daycare, block it at 5pm and give yourself half an hour to walk out the door. And own up to the fact that your schedule is your responsibility. If you have a 4:30pm meeting, you have to be the one that says, I have a hard stop at 5pm. Don’t apologize for it. And consider if it’s better for you to actually take that meeting from your car so there are no interruptions.”
Outsource what you can

Samudio recalls one client’s solution to maximizing quality time with her child: “She was really stressed out by everything she had to do when she came back from work before she could spend any real time with her daughter—cleaning, getting dinner ready, etc. So we worked on having the nanny stay longer doing chores so the mom could spend this time with the baby. She told me this was something she didn’t think she was allowed to do—she thought she had to come home and do everything.”
Don’t stress over missing milestones

Missing your baby’s first words or steps can be devastating, but remember—“milestones don’t happen until Mom sees them. Your baby will take another step, and it’ll be the first time you see it, and that’s what it’s important,” says Ferrante. It’s also helpful to remind yourself that you might miss important moments even if you were home. “I missed my daughter rolling for the first time simply because I was in the kitchen,” notes Ferrante. You can also leverage technology to stay up to date while you’re away—by Facetiming with the baby during your lunch break or getting regular updates from the nanny, for example. “If you still feel bad about missing out, give yourself space to grieve. But then remind yourself why you work—you missed that first word or step because you were out there working for your family’s well-being,” adds Samudio.
Teach your kids to help themselves

Working parent guilt often reaches a peak at those chaotic moments when unforeseen circumstances bring your plans to a halt—maybe your baby won’t stop screaming the night before a big work presentation, or you’re on your way to an important meeting when you find out your son left his science project at home. “Teach your kids to be responsible—they need to learn to problem solve and come up with their own solutions,” says Ferrante. “With a baby, it might be something like sleep training. In my working mom classes, 90% of the moms sleep train. You need to be able to function.”
Trust your team—both at work and at home

“With the exception of breastfeeding, there’s nothing else where Mom has to be there. Kids always cry out for Mom, but your partner can be just as good,” notes Ferrante. “If you have a critical meeting at work and your child comes down with a cold, trust that your partner or nanny can handle it.” Likewise, if your child is in the hospital and you need to be there for her, trust that someone else can handle the meeting—“if someone else can step in, it means you’re a good leader and have set your team up for success,” says Ferrante.
Take care of yourself

When you’re juggling work and motherhood, it’s easy to forget those activities you enjoyed before the baby—like exercising or seeing your friends. But it’s important to set aside some time for self-care so you can recharge and be fully present at home and in the office. “Don’t feel bad if on a day you’re not working, you go to yoga or have lunch with a friend,” says Samudio. “I tell my clients to proactively schedule one or two things for themselves each week. Have that time for yourself, so when you’re home, you can focus on your baby.”
Talk to someone

“It’s always a good idea to bounce ideas off a friend or coach, especially if you’re struggling with feelings of shame or don’t know how to address an issue with an important person in your life,” says Samudio. If your husband or mother is making you feel guilty about going back to work, book an appointment with a therapist on Maven. “You don’t want to be on bad terms with your partner, parent, or colleague, but you also don’t want them contributing to your guilt. Talking to a coach can help you figure out what to say to them in a way that is clear and effective rather than a ball of angry emotions.”

title.en-US: Are you just adjusting or is it postpartum depression?

content.value: Fact: Postpartum depression or anxiety can occur anytime in the 12 months after giving birth. Adding the stress of work can trigger additional anxiety and many moms feel especially overwhelmed in the first few weeks back in the office. But how do you know if what you’re feeling is more than an adjustment period?

Having a new baby is a joyful, magical time—except when it’s not. Postpartum depression (PPD) is the most common complication of pregnancy, yet the desire to just try to muddle through remains strong. Most women will experience postpartum “baby blues” (feeling a little sad, especially emotional or irritable) and those blues tend to go away in about 4-6 weeks after birth. But an estimated 1 in 7 new moms experience symptoms of postpartum depression at some point up to a year after childbirth according to the American Psychological Association (and depending on the state you live in, it can be as high as 1 in 5).
Women who experienced PPD with one pregnancy are more likely to have it again, and women who have dealt with depression or anxiety prior to pregnancy are about 30% more likely to experience PPD.
The warning signs of postpartum depression

If you’re wondering about the difference between the “baby blues” and postpartum depression, Maven OB-GYN and Medical Director Jan van Dis explains, “I talk to women about the difference between the blues and PPD being a case of persistence and severity. It’s when those postpartum blues don’t go away—when the crying, irritability, or sadness become more persistent and severe.”

For example, a mother who is experiencing the baby blues may feel anxious that something bad could happen to her baby. A mother with PPD might feel crippled by that feeling. Baby blues can make you feel crabby, while PPD feels more like being extremely irritable most of the time.
If you're concerned that you may be experiencing symptoms of PPD,
this assessment
can help you understand where your symptoms fall in severity.
Postpartum depression can happen at any time, up to a year after childbirth

While we tend to think of PPD as a feeling that sets in right away, postpartum depression can come at any point during the 12 months after birth. While you take your baby to the doctor multiple times in the first two months, you yourself don’t see a provider until three or six weeks postpartum. At that visit, your provider will give you a postpartum depression screening test—a brief set of questions about your mood and feelings. But by that time, many women with PPD have already been suffering from it.

On top of this, many women go back to work after a few months of maternity leave (some after a few weeks). Often, they haven't had a chance to connect with a mental health provider to address their emotional state. According to Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, “Going back to work can make PPD worse because you have that separation from your baby in addition to the added stressors that come from working. They still feel like the primary caregiver, and they have a job. If they’re pumping, that’s even more stress.”
The brain chemistry behind PPD

To understand PPD, it’s good to know some of the science behind it, says van Dis. To start, the very condition of pregnancy means that you have foreign genetic material (yes, your baby) inside your body. In order for your immune system to not consider the fetus a threat, the hypothalamus in your brain makes extra steroids to suppress your immune system’s response so that it does not reject your baby.

But what researchers are discovering is that steroid response also affects your brain’s neurotransmitters—those crucial chemicals associated with your mood. After birth, your body’s chemistry starts to return to its pre-pregnant state, but for many women those neurotransmitters don’t return to their baseline.

“A lot of women feel that there is something wrong with them as a mother,” says van Dis. “But if your gallbladder malfunctions, you don’t feel like a bad person. It should not be any different for PPD.”
Getting professional help is crucial

The very nature of depression makes it difficult to seek help but it is so important that you do. “It might feel impossible to make an extra doctor’s appointment when you are caring for a baby and don’t feel like you can get out of bed. And it can be hard to talk to a provider about whether you’d benefit from taking an antidepressant if you’re blaming yourself for the way that you’re feeling,” van Dis says. According to both van Dis and Stone, therapy can help and if therapy alone isn’t helping, your doctor can recommend an antidepressant medication that is safe to take while nursing.

Between caring non-stop for our children, feeling guilty about feeling depressed, and struggling to find enough hours in the day, it’s easy to put ourselves last. But as van Dis says, “I always go back to the airline oxygen metaphor. We have to put the oxygen mask on ourselves first if we want to be able to help anyone else.”
For emergency support:

If you are struggling with postpartum depression or anxiety, please speak with your doctor or a Mental Health Provider on Maven for help. If you are having thoughts about harming yourself or your baby, please call the
National Suicide Prevention Lifeline
at 1-800-273-8255 or message the
Crisis Text Line
(text HOME to 741741). In the event of a life-threatening emergency, contact 911 or go to the nearest emergency room.
Sources
National Institute of Mental Health. Postpartum Depression Facts.
https://www.nimh.nih.gov/health/publications/postpartum-depression-facts/index.shtml.
. Accessed January 15, 2020.
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Reproductive Health: Depression Among Women.
https://www.cdc.gov/reproductivehealth/depression/index.htm#Postpartum
. Accessed January 15, 2020.
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Prevalence of Selected Maternal and Child Health Indicators: Selected 2016 through 2017 Maternity and Child Health (MCH) Indicators by State.
https://www.cdc.gov/prams/prams-data/mch-indicators.html
. Accessed January 15, 2020.
American Psychological Association. Postpartum Depression.
https://www.apa.org/pi/women/resources/reports/postpartum-depression
. Accessed January 15, 2020.

title.en-US: Simple and quick self-care ideas for new parents

content.value:
Whether it’s putting in a few extra hours at work or figuring out how to put together the playpen, we do it all. We become experts at caring for others, but what about us? The not-so-surprising fact is if new parents don’t care for themselves, it’s impossible to adequately care for their baby. So what’s do you when you need a break? Maven Mental Health 
Practitioner Mercedes Samudio shows us how we can insert some necessary self-care into an already packed schedule.
Q. First, why is it important to take time for self-care?

Mostly, a general sense of sanity. New moms underestimate how much time it takes to care for a baby, so it’s imperative to get away and re-energize. Self-care also gives you the energy and focus to make clear decisions.
Q. What are the biggest reasons we don’t do it?
Generally...
Guilt and feelings of selfishness
We think we’re the only person capable of caring for our baby, even if we have a partner
We don’t check in with our body
We feel we don’t have time
Q. What are the signs that it’s time for some self-care?
Forgetfulness and an inability to make clear decisions
Feeling sluggish and low of energy
Lack of patience and a snappy attitude
Tension in the body
Insomnia
Anxiousness
Q. How can new parents incorporate self-care into an already packed schedule?
Start by making a list of the things that re-energize you.
Decide from that list the things that you can insert into your daily schedule. It could be something as simple as a walk around the block or a hot cup of tea in the morning.

Once you’ve incorporated the smaller things that you can do on your own, think about the bigger things that you will need support on. Perhaps you want to get away for the day, join a weekly yoga class, or maybe even start going on work trips again. Communicate this to your partner and support system to see how to make it work.
There are also some practical self-care go-to's like:
Get organized by clearing out the clutter at home, the office, and in your schedule. The idea is to create some space.
Exercise by taking the stairs instead of the elevator, and consider walking to your destination whenever possible.
Meditate for 5-10 minutes a day, or sit in silence for a few moments daily to collect your thoughts.
Q. What are some self-care actions that we don’t usually perceive as self-care?
Eating balanced meals daily
Showering
Exercising
Spending time with friends
Reading a book
Sitting in silence
Watching a TV show
Spending time with just your partner
Q. What advice do you have for people who don’t like to ask for help?

You can send a group email or text to your friends asking for help if calling is too hard. Ultimately, you want to remember that self-care is for you and the baby. Also, looking into the future, you want to serve as a good role model for your kids, and taking care of yourself sends a powerful message.

title.en-US: Is staying home after baby right for you?

content.value: By now, you’ve probably been inundated with stories from the media and well-meaning friends and colleagues about the difficulties of being a working parent. If you’re getting cold feet about your ability—or desire—to juggle parenthood with your career, you’re not alone: 40% of mothers drop out of the workforce after having kids. But while what you may be feeling is normal, quitting your job can have long-term and sometimes unforeseen consequences for both you and your family, so it’s important to consider your options carefully before taking the plunge. If you’re thinking about quitting or hitting pause on your career—even if just for a few years until your little one is off to school—take a moment to consider this list of questions from Maven Career Coach Sara Daly-Padron.
What is your vision of life and work?

“Ask yourself: how long have you been thinking of quitting? Is this something you’ve thought about for a while, perhaps before you were even pregnant? Or is this a knee-jerk reaction to your current situation?” says Daly-Padron. If you’ve always dreamed of being a full-time parent, staying home will definitely help you realize that vision. But if you’re simply exhausted and can’t imagine being functional while working, there may be other solutions besides quitting. “Think about your vision of work and life, and consider all the ways that vision may be realized. Maybe quitting is the answer, but maybe not,” says Daly-Padron, noting that you may want to consider options like a transitional ramp-up period, going part-time, or switching to a different department before deciding to leave your job.
What resources can you leverage—both at work and at home—to help you achieve your vision before you quit?

“I’m a big proponent of not quitting until you’ve given it a try,” says Daly-Padron. “If you just can’t imagine balancing the commute and the baby, you can solve this by working remotely, or having the right kind of childcare. Do it for a few months, not just a few weeks, to see if the challenges you anticipated in your head are real. Maybe your boss is more flexible than you thought she would be. Maybe your partner can help more.”
What kind of support will you need if you stay home?

It’s tempting to think that quitting your job will allow you to become a super parent at home and do everything yourself—shuttle your kids to the doctor, make dinner, read bedtime stories, clean the house, do the laundry, walk the dog. “Parents often forget that they’ll need a mental and physical break from their kids. You have your own doctor’s appointments and errands to run, and you crave adult conversations,” says Daly-Padron. “I work from home, and I’m long overdue for a mammogram because I have no time for it! It’s harder to find childcare when you only need it occasionally—it’s messier than having regular childcare, because neither you or your baby will be happy with a random person.”

If you’re thinking of quitting, consider what support you’ll need to maintain your sanity—whether it’s a regular babysitter, a cleaning service, or joining a new parent group to trade parenting tips and stay social. Daly-Padron recommends having a standing appointment with a caregiver once or twice a week so you can get out of the house and run all of your errands—or have lunch with your friends! “If I have childcare from x to x time, I’m guaranteed to get stuff done. But with kids around, it’s tough,” she says.
Can you afford to make this change financially?

People can often underestimate both the short-term and long-term costs of staying home. “Think about the standard of living you want to maintain—like having a cleaning service or a regular babysitter—and whether you’ll be able to afford it if you quit. And think about the long game,” advises Daly-Padron. While your salary may barely cover the nanny right now, your kids will eventually grow up and go to school, so childcare costs will decrease significantly. And by staying in the workforce, you keep your skills current and keep yourself in the running for a promotion and higher salary down the line. “Plus, when you stop working, you’re not just giving up your salary, but other benefits, too—health insurance, a retirement plan, etc.,” notes Daly-Padron. “Think about how you’re going to save for retirement. Can you continue contributing to your IRA through your spouse?”
Do you intend to go back to work later?

If you want to take a temporary break—say, until your child is in preschool—make sure you have a plan. “Parents often think they can just come back after a year, but then they have another baby, and eight years go by,” says Daly-Padron. “Don’t underestimate the effort that it takes to come back. If you want this now but think you may want to go back in a year or five, ask yourself: what will things look like then?”

She recalls her experience working with a woman who was part of a returnship program aimed at mothers who’d taken time off: “She’d been a VP, then left for 10 years when she had kids. She told me that getting back into the pace and demands of the role really took her by surprise. And the technology—getting ramped up on all that had changed and platforms that didn’t even exist when she’d left the workforce. She recognized that if she hadn’t been part of this program, it would have been really difficult for her.”
Tips to keep your options open if you’re considering going back?

“Keep your skills current—whether it’s going to a conference, volunteering, or taking an online course,” says Daly-Padron. “Keep up your network—people get jobs through their network, so keep your LinkedIn profile up to date. It may be the last thing on your mind right now, but it’ll be even harder three years down the line. Figure out the two or three thing you want to put on your resume for this time—maybe it’s consulting, a freelance project, or joining the school board.”

Finally, think about how you’ll explain your time off to a future employer. “Instead of saying, ‘It was too hard to be a parent and work' position it as a choice you made,” advises Daly-Padron. “You do have to build a strong case to compete against others that didn’t take time off, but employers don’t hire on past experience alone. Show them what your wealth of knowledge from before can propel you to do for them. Look into companies with on-ramping programs to help get parents back into the workforce. What kinds of experiences do they offer? Even if you don’t get into one of those programs—they can be competitive—how can you get those benefits to help you get back into the swing of things?”

title.en-US: Why parents make great employees

content.value: Forget “mom brain”—the absent-mindedness and mental fogginess that supposedly besets pregnant women and new moms. A lot of the sluggishness you’re feeling is likely not due to diminished brain capacity, but rather to obvious factors like sleep deprivation. In fact,
studies show

that parts of your brain actually grow to support your new role as a parent in the first few months after your baby’s born, helping you develop your instincts, bond with your child, regulate feeding, and make better decisions. In other words, you’re actually increasing brain power during your maternity leave, not diminishing it. “It’s really impressive,” says Maven Career Coach Mary Beth Ferrante. “This may be one of the only times that your brain significantly changes in your adult life.” Ferrante notes that this extra gray matter—or at the very least, everything you learn during your crash course in parenthood—can be harnessed to not only be a better parent, but also a better employee.
Still skeptical? Here’s a list of skills you pick up as a new parent and how you can leverage them to advance your career.
Emotional Intelligence (your “EQ”)

“You have to learn how to navigate life with your child. If you can negotiate with a three or thirteen-year-old, you can negotiate with anybody,” says Ferrante. “You develop a way of interacting with this little person who will push you in every way possible. You figure out how to motivate them.” And while you may feel like your new negotiation skills work only with your two-year-old (after all, it’s unlikely that your manager will respond well to being bribed with candy or an extra bedtime story), Ferrante notes that these skills are applicable at the office: “At work, people communicate in different ways. What works for one person may not work for someone else, just like what works for your toddler one day may not work the next. Living with a toddler is a lot like living with five different people in your house! And it helps you adapt and understand what others may be thinking or feeling at work.”
Resilience

Ferrante is a firm believer that while you may be able to have it all—a family, career, and maybe even a social life—no one can do it all. Parenthood forces you to figure it all out with limited resources, like finding an affordable caretaker, leveraging your support system, and splitting tasks with your partner. “No two weeks are the same with kids. You figure out how to work under stress and chaos, and that makes you adaptable,” says Ferrante. She notes that this resilience—the ability to get things done despite rapidly changing and often less-than-ideal circumstances—is “huge in today’s professional environment.” Whether it’s a new technological change, a particularly onerous client demand, or a difficult co-worker, parents are uniquely able to rise to the occasion and get the job done.
Efficiency
If you weren’t familiar with
Parkinson’s Law

—the idea that “work expands so as to fill the time available for its completion”—before becoming a working ;parent, you probably are now. “Babies function on routines, and when you have a routine in your home life to make sure that your baby sleeps and eats well, it makes you more efficient at work, too,” says Ferrante. “If you know you only have from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. to finish that presentation, you figure out how to get it done in that timeframe.” And it’s not just a matter of getting the same amount of work done while juggling what often feels like a second full-time job (parenthood).
Research shows

that, in the long run, working parents are in fact more productive than their childless peers. So the next time you feel like you need an extra hour in the day to get it all done, rest easy—you’re already ahead of the game.
Ambition
There’s a common misconception that having a baby makes you less ambitious professionally. But
research

shows that the opposite is true—working parents tend to have higher career aspirations than their childless counterparts. “Becoming a mom has made me more ambitious in my career,” says Ferrante. “I never saw myself as a stay-at-home mom. Part of that was financial—I have to work. Also, role models—the women in my life, like my mom and my sister, were all working parents. What changed for me was the way I worked and what I wanted to be doing. I wanted my work to matter more. If I was going to be away from my baby, I was only going to do it for something I was excited about.” For her, that meant quitting her corporate job and launching her own business as a career coach. And while she doesn’t think that leaving their day job is feasible or even the right career step for many women, she notes that having children made the risk worth it for her.

So there you have it: spending all those months breastfeeding, changing dirty diapers, and wiping snot off your baby’s nose hasn’t turned your brain to mush. If anything, it’s actually made you a better employee.

But remember—at least some of the habits you pick up from parenthood shouldn’t make their way to the office. Having a baby may give you superhuman powers, but “there’s still a level of professionalism that you have to maintain. When you’ve been out for an extended period of time, it can be easy to forget the professional you once were and show up with a top knot, stretchy pants, and a sweatshirt,” says Ferrante. “It’s okay to talk about kids and relationships, but use common sense about what’s suitable for work and what isn’t. Make sure it’s a comfortable environment for everyone, especially if you’re in a leadership role.”

title.en-US: Sharing the mental load of parenting

content.value: Why it matters

*Are you constantly running through the list of things to do at home and for your baby? We call this “the mental load.” If you’re in a household where both parents are working, you’re hopefully splitting the “second shift” responsibilities but too often the planning, scheduling, and remembering falls on mom.
According to a report

by Modern Family Index, one parent tends to be responsible for not only their half of parenting and household duties, but also organizing, remembering, and planning virtually all family matters. Even when they are the primary breadwinners, their responsibilities only increase. Fifty-two percent of these parents say they are burning out from the weight of their household responsibilities, which could lead to stress, less focus, more mistakes, increased time off from work, sickness, and depression. And while alarming, the good news is you don’t have to carry the mental load all by yourself. Maven Career Coach Sara Daly-Padron and Maven Mental Health Practitioner Mercedes Samudio are here to give us tips on how to reduce the mental load.
Assess where you are

Mercedes Samudio: Start by having an honest conversation with yourself about the mental load and the impact it’s having on you. Do you constantly think about your baby and your to-do list? Is it stressing you out? Once acknowledged, you can address it.
Lighten your load

Sara Daly-Padron: First, make a list of all your responsibilities and see if anything can fall off. There’s a concept that parenthood is like juggling rubber and crystal balls. Parents must figure out which balls are rubber and can fall to the ground without any or much repercussion, and which balls are crystal, and therefore, way too important to let fall. Second, go through your list of responsibilities and see where you can get help from your partner, nanny, friends and/or family. You may want to enlist outside help such as a cleaning lady, and there are also apps that help with things like running errands, grocery shopping and laundry.
Make time for self-care

Mercedes Samudio: A lot of new parents put off downtime, playtime and self-maintenance because they’re too busy caring for the baby and others. Write down a list of things that you enjoy and see what you can incorporate into your schedule. It could be as simple as going to a yoga class once a week or meeting up with a friend for coffee. This way you’re not just working and parenting.
Incorporate Regular Family Meetings

Sara Daly-Padron: Family meetings that take place once a week at a convenient time for you and your partner are a great way to discuss what’s working and not working, goals for the upcoming week and sticky situations that come up like who will take off of work for a sick baby. Meetings also provide a safe space to discuss issues without coming off as a nag.
Have regular check-ins with yourself

Sara Daly-Padron: Since change doesn’t happen overnight, it’s important to have regular check-ins with yourself to see how you’re doing. Psychiatrist Dr. Dan Siegel came up with 7 daily mental activities to do that can literally serve as a guide or checklist to keeping a healthy mind. Ask yourself, “Did I have any creative or playtime today? Am I getting enough sleep, exercise, time with friends, time to myself?”
Expand your support system

Mercedes Samudio: Joining a new parent group in your area or online is a great way to meet like-minded women who share your same interest. If you’re having a hard time connecting with friends, consider seeing a therapist so that you can communicate your feelings without feeling judged or like a burden.
Have a running to-do list and a family sharing app

Sara Daly-Padron: Keep a running to-do list to literally dump things out of your brain. It frees up mental capacity and helps you get back focused on whatever task is at hand. Family sharing apps are a great way to let everyone who has responsibilities with the household and baby know what is expected of them and when. This way, you’re not the only one holding the bag.

title.en-US: How not to get mommy-tracked when you return to work

content.value: By now, we’re all well acquainted with gender discrimination in the workplace—the belief that women aren’t as capable professionally as men. Sadly, the bias may be even stronger against women with children. The maternal wall—a term
a term coined back in 2004

by UC-Hastings law professor Joan C. Williams—refers to the belief that women can’t be both good mothers and good employees at the same time. “There’s a bias where working mothers are seen more like housewives than businesswomen—they’re expected to be gentler, warmer, more feminine, that is, more like a mom than a business person,” says Maven career coach Mary Beth Ferrante. The result is a catch-22 for moms who remain committed to their careers: “They’re judged for going home early, but also for working too long and being away from their children,” says Ferrante, noting that working mothers are less likely to get hired or promoted and face a wider wage gap than other women.
So what should you do if you feel like you’re being mommy-tracked? Ferrante has a few tips for overcoming the maternal wall and making sure your career stays on track post-baby.
Realize that discrimination can be subtle or overt.

In some cases, discrimination against mothers is explicit and hard to miss, such as when women are passed up for a promotion or asked to take on a lower position because they have children. Ferrante recalls the story of a client who came back from maternity leave to find that her entire team would now be reporting to someone else. But she notes that the bias is often much subtler than that. “The maternal wall is hard to crack because people really do believe that they’re doing a good thing,” she says, noting that “40% of Americans believe that women should stay home with the children, and 80% believe that only one parent should be working full-time.”

The result is that bias against mothers is often shrouded in good intentions or assumptions about what the woman wants from her career. “I had one client whose manager said he had the perfect role for her—it was more flexible, she could work remotely, but it was a title level down. He was honestly expecting her to be excited,” says Ferrante. “But she was angry! She hadn’t asked for this. She’d been proving herself, and becoming a mom didn’t mean that she wanted to take a step back.” She recalls another situation where the company was reorganized, and her client got pushed into a support role: “Were they trying to hold her back because she was a mother, or was it simply a function of the reorganization?”

Ferrante notes that subtle bias is often the worst kind—and worth reflecting on and investigating to see if you should do something about it. She describes some common types to help you assess the situation:
The prove-it-again syndrome.

Whereas men—and women without children—are presumed to be devoted to their careers, working moms often have to prove their commitment to work over and over again. “Consciously or subconsciously, managers may demand that you prove your commitment to work when you return from maternity leave. Maybe they ask you to stay later, or take on a stretch assignment or a promotion right away,” says Ferrante. But she cautions that sometimes women put the pressure on themselves: “We want to prove to ourselves that we’re committed, and we become unwilling to take anything off our plates in order to show that we can do it all.”
Tight-roping.

Women often have to find a balance between being feminine enough to be likable and assertive enough to be effective. “When they’re too blunt or direct, women get dinged for it, whereas men are seen as leaders,” explains Ferrante.
Off-ramping / down-shifting.

Ferrante notes that while women sometimes choose to get off the leadership track when they have children, they often find themselves involuntarily “steered” into positions with lower pay and leadership potential, often by well-meaning managers and colleagues.
Be direct.

Whether it’s subtle or explicit, “if you feel like you’re getting passed up for opportunities, it’s important to have a conversation with your manager from the start and be direct about your intentions,” says Ferrante. She recalls a client who worked as an attorney and sat down with her boss right after her maternity leave. “She’d done a lot of extracurriculars at work before the baby, and when she came back, she said: ‘I want you to believe and understand that I want to do everything I was doing before. Until I tell you that I need something to change, you have to believe that I’ll get it done.’”
Frame requests for flexibility as a trial.

Even if you remain committed to your career, you may require some accommodations as you adapt to your new role as a working mom—like cutting back on travel or rearranging your schedule to pick up your child from daycare. Ferrante advises asking for accommodations on a temporary basis. “Three months is a good rule of thumb,” she says. “If you ask for permanent changes, you put yourself on the mommy track.” Besides, it’s impossible to know how you’re going to feel in six months or a year—by then, your child might be in full-time daycare or school, and you might be craving to get back into your old work mode.
Find a mentor.

If your manager isn’t supportive or you don’t feel comfortable speaking to her, find a mentor and ask for advice. Even if you have a good relationship with your boss, mentors can offer a great second opinion. Ferrante notes that the ideal mentor is someone a rung above you whom you feel comfortable with and perhaps has faced similar challenges. She cautions that while it’s important to “recognize that what is right for one person isn’t right for someone else,” speaking to a mentor can help your process everything and figure out the best way to approach it. If you don’t have anyone who can fill that role, or if you feel you need additional support, book a session with a career coach on the Maven platform.
If necessary, go to HR.

“Document everything,” says Ferrante. Even if you’re unsure if there was bias at play or you’re not ready to go to HR, it helps to have everything written down so you can step back later and assess the situation. “If it’s anything overt, go right to HR.”

title.en-US: How to deal with work travel as a new parent

content.value: Maternity leave has ended, and you’re back at work. You’ve gotten into a breastfeeding groove, and everything is falling into place. Now you’re ready to take on more work responsibilities, and that includes travel. However, you’re not sure how to make it work. We reached out to Maven Career Coach Sara Daly-Padron and Maven Clinic’s VP of New Products, Kristy Catsouphes, who set up Maven’s new breast milk shipping service, to help us figure this out.
Bringing baby and a nanny on your work trip
As more companies see the unique value of having parents in
leadership positions

, they are doing more to support those who need to travel for work, including making it possible for parents to travel with their babies. In fact, Credit Suisse Bank recently began paying for nannies to accompany parents who wish to bring children under a year old on business trips, and working parents just scored a win in the midterms when a House candidate from New York got the Federal Election Commission to use her campaign funds to pay for childcare-related cost. If you have the opportunity to bring baby along on your work trip with a nanny, you want to make sure you:
Sit down with your nanny and be very clear about her responsibilities on the trip.
Pay for all of her expenses such as airfare/travel, hotel, and money to eat.
Outline what you will pay for overtime and give her a payment date.

In terms of what you may be able to get covered for expenses from work, it will be workplace-dependent. Career Coach Sara Daly-Padron advises, “Leverage your Employee Assistance Program (EAP) to help with resources. If your company doesn’t cover the cost of a separate room for the nanny, perhaps they will pay for a suite. Have a conversation with your employer, because companies are doing more to help working parents.”

There’s also the option of bringing your baby along on the trip and arranging local childcare. Daly-Padron recommends speaking to your EAP to help give perspective on what childcare is available in that area. Also, hotels can offer recommendations, and some bigger hotels have on-site babysitting.
Leaving baby at home

If you decide to leave your baby at home, “you’ll want to consider getting some fill-in help, especially if your partner works full-time as well,” advises Daly-Padron. “Look at your ecosystem of support to see who may be able to help in the mornings and evenings until your partner gets off of work.” There’s also 24-hour care options if you need it or you can use a trusted nanny for the duration. Some companies now reimburse employees for childcare cost incurred during business trips, including subsidies for overnight care. While others will pay for a grandparent to come from out-of-town to stay with a child. Once again, have a conversation with your employer.
Pumping on the road

“Fortunately, breastfeeding parents no longer have to ‘pump and dump,’ like I used to on business trips,” says Kristy Catsouphes, Maven Clinic’s VP of New Products who set up Maven’s new shipping service, Maven Milk. Though not offered to the public just yet, it may be available through your employer. Sign into the Maven site with your travel details, and you’ll receive a box and shipping label with your address on it. All you’ll have to do is get the box to FEDEX, and your milk will make it home.

If you're traveling internationally, however, there’s a slightly different process. “While Maven doesn’t ship milk internationally just yet, we do offer a cooler that can keep milk for up to two weeks. Customs will not be an issue if you check your frozen milk on the plane with you—in that case, you will go through the customs checking point as you return home from your trip, and it won't be a problem. I have never heard of a parent having trouble getting through customs with their breast milk,” explains Catsouphes. If you’re wondering about the boxes being used to keep your milk secure, Catsouphes gives them a huge thumbs up. “Most breastfeeding shipping companies use lab-grade, temperature-controlled boxes called
NanoCool
that are easy to use and incredibly reliable.”
Now that we know getting milk shipped home won’t be a problem, Catsouphes has some tips to make pumping-on-the-road easier.
Wear something like a poncho or cape, or bring a nursing cover that will allow you to pump underneath in case you need to go pump in a corner.

Get a good portable hand pump, especially for international trips, because it doesn’t require electricity. You can only pump one breast at a time, so it’s not as fast. They run about $30. If you really like your double electric pump, get one with a battery pack so you don’t have to rely on power outlets. If traveling internationally, make sure you have the right international plug adapter.

Pump right before you leave the house for the airport so you don’t have to pump until you’re on the other side of security. In the US, breastmilk is exempt from the 3-4 ounce rule, so you can bring as much as you want. Internationally, breast milk is treated like any other liquid, and you can’t bring it through. Research the airport you’re going to because many have nursing and baby rooms throughout certain terminals, or they have nursing pods through
Mamava
. Otherwise, you may have to pump in a bathroom.

On an airplane, try moving to a row that has an extra seat, and if it’s not making too much noise, and you’re wearing a poncho, you can pump right there. If you’re going to pump in a bathroom, flight attendants are usually super supportive and will make sure no one bothers you.
Be sure to pack:
An insulated lunch bag or cooler and some good ice packs. We recommend foam ice packs because, unlike ice packs, TSA won’t take them away for being slushy if they start to melt.
Extra bottles. (more than you think you need), a travel brush, and soap for your bottles.
Pump cleaning wipes. Medela makes wipes to clean your pumps without water.
Extra burp cloths, because you don’t know when you may need to wipe up extra milk.
Nursing bra.
Extra gallon zip lock bags. They come in handy for storage, and to keep things separated, clean and sanitary.
Hand sanitizer
Extra breastmilk storage bags. They can be filled with ice and used as a backup ice pack.

When at a hotel, call ahead to make sure you have a fridge, not a mini-bar, that will keep things cold. Ask for the latest check out possible so you can pump one last time before going to the airport. Sometimes a hotel may be able to give you a conference room to pump.
If you’re traveling to an event for a conference or going to a new office, call ahead to secure a place to pump so you’re not spending your break looking for a place to pump.
Finally, if it becomes too much of a hard time, just keep up your supply and take a breather. It won’t be the end of the world.

title.en-US: One mom's story of career success after kids

content.value: Succeeding in your career and being a great mother aren’t mutually exclusive. But it does require planning, support at work and at home, clear goals, compromise, and the ability to define your own path. Read this interview with Maven Founder & CEO Kate Ryder about how she personally juggles the craziness of starting and building Maven while raising two small children.
You’ve had two children since launching Maven in 2015. How did you juggle becoming a mom with starting a company?

Not gracefully! But seriously, the secret to starting a company while raising a family—and not losing your sanity—is to have a good support system. For me, this has meant a great partner, parents, friends, and the resources on Maven. My husband is amazing and had a generous paternity leave. My mom and dad live nearby and often take the kids when we need help. We befriended another family in the neighborhood—we had a nanny share at one point, and still help each other out with small things. I also have an amazing group of friends who all had babies around the same time, and I was the last one to join the party, so I’ve benefited from their advice. We have a group chat and text each other feverishly all the time.

And finally—Maven! I’m a walking example of my own product. Each of my pregnancies had its own challenges. I used Maven to find my doctor, and I use it about once a month now for quick check-ins or a video chat with a pediatrician.
You were lucky to have so many friends who could show you the ropes. What advice did you find most helpful?

The best advice I got is that you need to learn and trust your own maternal instinct. You need to learn how to filter what other people say and make your own decisions. It could be something basic, like your kid throws up all the time—is that a problem? There are ten different opinions out there. But you have to trust your maternal gut; it’s a muscle you didn’t have before that you build over time. That’s why Maven is so important. There’s no one right answer, but having so many experts at your fingertips can help you build confidence in your instincts.
What was your partner’s role in your transition to becoming a working mom? Did either of you have to make any major compromises?

With the first baby, it was a relatively easy pregnancy, and we were so busy that we didn’t really prep for the postpartum. We’d had a pretty equal marriage up until then, but when our son was born, we were both shocked by how much work fell on me versus my husband, between the physical recovery, breastfeeding, and sleep deprivation. We also experienced things differently. For us, it was really about navigating a new reality. Parenthood brings new identities to people, and we had to figure out what it meant to each of us and to our marriage. We were lucky to have a great support network so we could balance our new roles as parents with our careers.
What were some of the major challenges you faced when you became a parent?

Because I was CEO, I could make things work for me when I had my son—I was on email, and I was able to have different departments come to my house on different days after my son was born. But when I started doing full days at work, it was terrifying! I hated travelling and never wanted to be away from my baby. Separation anxiety hit me really hard. I had great childcare that I trusted—this really helped me get over it and made things easier the second time around with my daughter.
There’s so much talk about how difficult it is to balance parenthood with a career. Are there any ways in which being a parent has made you a better CEO, and vice versa?

Studies show that working parents are more efficient, and it’s true. I have a low BS meter. I’m hyper-focused, and always ask myself: Do I need to be here? Is this the best use of my time? Becoming a parent has also made me a more empathetic manager. Several members of my team are pregnant or on maternity leave, and I think a lot about how tough it must be to be in that situation and work for someone who doesn’t know what it’s like. So I try to be supportive. I think there’s this fear that people don’t want to work after having kids, but it wasn’t true for me, so I assume it’s not true for my teammates, until they tell me it is. When you become a parent, you realize how important it is to invest in the best people—both in your company and your support network at home. There are times when I’m burnt out, and I need to rely on my colleagues. And even if they’re recent parents themselves and are going at only 80 percent, it’s fine, because their 100 percent is so good.

My career has also made me a better mother. I have a daughter and a son. I believe that it’s good for my daughter to have a role model, and for my son to know that both parents work. I’m building a company in a culture where working parents can thrive, and that’s good for everyone, including children. Just make sure you work your schedule so you can dip out in time for that parent-teacher conference!
Any advice for working parents out there?

Prioritize your relationship—it often falls by the wayside when you’re juggling career and kids. Have date nights, or enjoy a weekend away—my husband and I are doing that this weekend. And here’s a very specific tip: when we first started doing date night, we’d go out after putting the kids to bed. But we were exhausted by then and usually returned within the hour. Now we sometimes ask our nanny to stay later and go out from 6:30-9pm, and it’s really made it more worthwhile.

If you’re dealing with working parent guilt, make sure you trust your care provider. It also helps to know that infants really have no sense of time, and by the time they’re older, it’s actually great for their independence to explore the world without you.

Finally, if you’re dreading going into work, talk to a career coach or a friend. Is it that you really hate your job, or do you just need to have an open conversation with your manager to figure out an arrangement that works? It’s no joke to leave your kids at home, so it’s important to feel that you’re doing it for something worthwhile.

title.en-US: Making a career change after baby

content.value: Making a career move takes time, patience, and often a strategy. Many new parents love the idea of starting in a new company where they aren’t comparing themselves to their “pre-baby professional self.” But while there can be benefits, it’s important to know what to look for and what questions to consider before making a leap. Here’s a guide to get you started from Maven Career Coach Sara Daly-Padron.
When are you most fulfilled professionally?

“Ask yourself: when are you happiest? When are you in a state of flow, those periods when you lose track of time and space and forget to eat and go to the bathroom?” says Daly-Padron. She recommends writing down what you enjoy about your current job, what you don’t, and what type of professional experiences, skills, and accomplishments you’re seeking over the next few years. She recalls her own decision to become a career coach after having her daughters: “I was at the same company for 17 years. After my second maternity leave, there was a big restructuring, and I was faced with the question—do I stay on this path and find the same type of job in a different company? The commute was killing me, and one of my daughters had severe food allergies. I could have found a similar position elsewhere, but I realized I didn’t want to. I went through this process—what I am really good at? What do I enjoy? What do I get the most personal satisfaction from? For me, it was watching other people grow in their career. I had a lot of ad hoc experience in this, and I wanted to see if I could turn it into my profession.”

While you may realize that you want to change paths, you might also find that you can achieve what you’re looking for within your current organization by switching departments, location, or asking for certain accommodations. “It might be that you’re actually already having a lot of these experiences you crave, but what’s really tough is taking the subway every day—that’s what’s killing you. If you’re, say, a marketing manager and you love the pace and nature of it, but hate the commute—does your company have an office closer to home where you can do similar type of work?”
Are you on a path to where you want to be in your career in two or three years?

“If you had a magic wand and could change anything about your career right now, what would it be? Bear in mind that every job will involve something you don’t enjoy, such as filling out timesheets or doing expenses. But for those things you dislike—will you still be spending a substantial amount of time doing them in a few years?” says Daly-Padron. “I spoke to a client yesterday—she thought, I’m killing myself, and I saw the next step ahead looks even worse. So what am I striving for? I have no interest in the political fight it’s going to take to get to the next level.”

If you’re having trouble figuring out your goals, talk to a friend or coach—“I’m a firm believer that people know what they want, it just often hasn’t surfaced for them. Being able to articulate in very clear language for yourself what you desire is the first step in all of this,” says Daly-Padron. If you can, find a mentor at work to help you visualize what your future at the company might look like: “Talk to someone who’s ahead of you and understand what their role is. Are they experiencing the types of things that you want? Do you want to invest in your current situation so you can get to where they are?”
Have you spoken to others in your potential new company or industry?

If you find that your goals are not achievable within your current company, speak to others to understand what a new role is really like. And be open to the idea that some benefits—like working from home—may have downsides. When Daly-Padron left her office job to become a career coach, she didn’t realize how much she would miss the office camaraderie: “I was like, I can’t wait to work from home 100%. But I underestimated how much I’d miss having colleagues—someone to ask a quick question or chat with. I have to find ways to bring that to myself now. Working from home can be great, but it’s also hard—you have no separation, no shuttle, between your work and your kids.”
Does a career switch work for you and your family?

If you’re considering a major change, think through the basics like your family’s financial stability and health benefits. It might be that you really want to become an entrepreneur, but you need to save up for another year before you’re in a position to take that leap. And remember, most changes don’t have to be permanent. “Have a timeline,” advises Daly-Padron. When she first became a career coach, she gave herself two years to see if she could make it work: “By the end of that timeframe, I told myself I had to be bringing in some revenue for my family. And if I can’t meet that, I’ll change again. I had worked in one place for 17 years before breaking out on my own. But I had to understand that the next timeline was flexible.”
Do you know how FMLA and leave policies work at a potential new company?
Figure out what leave policies you’ll be entitled to under a new employer if you have another baby or need to take time off to care for a sick family member (or yourself). A quick search online will help you determine if you’ll be protected under the federal FMLA, which usually covers employees who’ve worked a minimum number of hours for at least twelve months in a company that employs 50 or more individuals. You may also have additional protections under your specific state and company policies. “I wouldn’t ask those questions of the hiring manager unless there’s nothing on the company website and no one else to ask,” says Daly-Padron. “Instead, work through your recruiting agency or HR department. And ask it as part of a long list of benefits, like health membership, commuter benefits, etc.”
Do you understand the new company’s views towards flexible work arrangements?

If the flexibility to work from home or arrange your schedule is important to you, make sure you understand the company culture beyond what’s written in the employee handbook. “I worked with a client whose company had flexible policies, but the culture of her particular group really didn’t support it,” notes Daly-Padron. “When you chat with team members during the interview process, say—I understand the policy to be X. Is that done in practice? How many people do it?”

title.en-US: Maven's guide to working motherhood

content.value: They call it the rush hour of life: having children just as your career is ramping up. Our program, developed by Maven Practitioners, was designed to help women prep for the joys and challenges of working motherhood. Each week, you'll be guided through essential topics often left out of doctor's visits, from how to avoid episiotomies to why Thursday is the ideal day to return from leave. With Maven's guide, you'll feel empowered to take what lies ahead, head-on.

title.en-US: 4 surprising things about intrauterine insemination (IUI)

content.value: Intrauterine insemination, or IUI, is just what it sounds like: a procedure that involves placing semen inside a woman’s uterus. But despite being pretty straightforward, there are still some aspects of the fertility treatment that might surprise you.
You don’t need to lie back with your feet in the air after treatment.

A lot of people have a fear that if they stand up after IUI, the semen will fall out—but that’s a myth. A study out of the Netherlands randomly assigned 479 women receiving IUI to two groups: The first group got 15 minutes of bed rest after treatment, while the second group was instructed to get up and move around right away. Get this: 40% of cycles that involved immediate movement resulted in pregnancy, while 32% of the bed-rest group had success. Your doctor will probably have you rest for 10-15 minutes after the procedure, but not to prevent leakage.
It’s over in minutes.
