As far as fertility treatments go, IUI is lightning fast. The actual procedure can take under two minutes—and doesn’t require anesthesia or recovery time at the clinic. Many women are surprised by how easy—and quick—it goes.
Sex is allowed—and sometimes even encouraged.

An IUI is typically scheduled 36 hours after the woman receives a “trigger shot”—which triggers the egg to reach final maturity and move into the fallopian tubes. If you’re doing an IUI with your male partner (and aren’t using donor sperm), your doctor may ask that you abstain from sex between the trigger shot and the insemination to make sure that your partner can produce a good sample on the day of the IUI. But besides this restriction, there’s usually no reason you need to avoid sex during a treatment cycle. In fact, sex is often “prescribed” after the IUI to increase the total amount of sperm in the uterus and up your odds of success even more.
You may feel some cramping afterward—but it doesn’t always mean you’re pregnant.

Some women experience cramping after an IUI, as the catheter can irritate the uterus. Cramping a few days post-IUI can sometimes signal implantation, but it can also be a sign that a period is coming. As hard as the wait can be, try not to read into your cramps (or any other symptoms) too much. Roughly two weeks after your IUI, your doctor will ask you to go back to the clinic for a pregnancy test, and then you’ll know for sure.

title.en-US: How to deal with baby showers during infertility

content.value: A no-guilt guide to handling this tricky situation.

When you’re dealing with infertility, baby showers can be one of the most emotionally difficult things to navigate. Unless the baby shower is for your best friend or your sister, give yourself permission not to go if you think it will be too challenging. And frankly, even if it is your closest pal or sibling who’s having a baby, you deserve the opportunity to decide for yourself what you can and cannot handle.

Exactly how you decline an invitation depends on your relationship with the person being showered. If it’s someone close to you who you’ve opened up to about your struggles, it’s perfectly fine to be honest and explain that you’d love to be there, but things are just too tough right now. When the baby shower is for a coworker, a casual acquaintance, or that third cousin you see at Christmas, feel free to make up a reason you can’t attend.

Whatever your relationship, sending a thoughtful card and gift is always a good idea. And if you can’t bear to look through the baby registry yourself, ask a friend or your partner to help choose something.

As for the friends who don’t invite you to baby showers (or kids’ birthday parties) because they fear upsetting you: Most women agree they’d like to be given the choice to attend or bow out. Feel free to communicate that simply receiving an invitation would help you feel like you’re a part of their lives, even if you don’t have the emotional bandwidth to attend.

title.en-US: 3 things to rethink during fertility treatment

content.value: It’s OK for business-as-usual to take a back seat.
Your wardrobe

If you’re using hormones to stimulate the ovaries (whether you’re doing IUI or IVF), you may notice that the skirts and pants that fit you perfectly are suddenly very snug. Unfortunately, many women experience bloating or a bit of weight gain during treatment. To make things a little easier on yourself, invest in a fertility wardrobe (just a few inexpensive pieces to get you through—you don’t need to shell out a lot of money). Or simply move the constrictive clothes to the back of your closet (see you later, skinny jeans) and push the wrap-dresses and stretchy pants up to the front.
Your schedule

When you’re in the midst of fertility treatments, a schedule that once seemed manageable may start to feel really hectic. Besides the fact that you may be constantly racing to the doctor for a hormone injection or ultrasound, all your head space may be consumed by what you’re dealing with. This may require a ruthless approach to your calendar: Take a look and think about what’s essential, and what you can let go of for now. Feel free to keep things “penciled in” that you may or may not want to attend. On any given day, book club might either feel like a welcome relief or a total burden. Give yourself permission to change your mind as needed.
Your social media M.O

You can’t really control what ends up in your face when you’re scrolling through. If seeing a steady stream of pregnancy announcements or photo albums from baby showers/kids’ birthday parties/etc. is going to leave you in a dark place, do yourself a favor and take a break from Instagram or Facebook. Or adjust your feed accordingly. The “stay friends but unfollow” button may be a sanity-saver—for now.

title.en-US: 6 must-ask questions at your first fertility clinic appointment

content.value: Once you’ve tracked down a couple of clinics you’d like to look into, the next step is to set up an in-person consultation with a reproductive endocrinologist and infertility specialist (REI). You’ll want to be as prepared as you can be for this initial appointment. That means going in with your medical records (as well as your partner’s), and being ready to give the doctor a clear picture of your journey trying to get pregnant so far, as well as your general health history, lifestyle, etc. But an equally important part of this meeting is the question-asking that you will do. Not all clinics operate the same way, so consider this a fact-finding visit. Here’s a list of Qs to bring with you as you play detective.
How many assisted reproductive procedures does this clinic do each year?

This will give you a clue into their level of expertise. And when the stakes are high, as they are in reproductive medicine, experience can make a big difference. For this reason, you should also make sure that all the providers there are board-certified, and look into how long they’ve been at the clinic. A high turnover of the staff could signal operational problems at the facility.
Do you have the latest technologies available in your lab?

And what kinds of ovarian stimulation protocols are used? Quick primer: Conventional ovarian stimulation protocols for IVF are longer and use higher doses of drugs; in recent years, “mild stimulation IVF” has become popular. Both protocols are associated with benefits and challenges, so there’s no one right method for everyone, but in deciding what’s best for you, start to gather info on whether your clinic and doctor takes an aggressive approach or a gentler one.
How many embryos (on average) are transferred in a typical IVF cycle?

More and more research is highlighting the importance of quality over quantity—which is why many clinics now do a single transfer rather than transferring multiple embryos. You should also ask: How many pregnancies here have resulted in multiple births vs. single births?
Can you help me better understand your success rates?

The reason this is important is because many clinics use their pregnancy rates to attract clients. The more important data includes birth rate per treatment cycle and per embryo transfer—so you’ll have to do some digging to find out the metrics that matter.
What tests will I need to have before treatment begins, and why are each of those tests important?
While you’re asking this question, make sure you also find out the related costs—and what’s covered by your insurance.
Do you see patients every day?

Figure out what kind of access you’ll have—will the clinic be closed on weekends, bank holidays, etc.? Will you be assigned a nurse that you can reach out to anytime? Going through these treatments can be a very stressful experience, and feeling like you’re all alone or waiting days for a response to a call or email may make the journey harder than it needs to be.

title.en-US: 5 questions to make sure a fertility clinic is right for you

content.value: A fertility center may check all the right boxes and look great on paper, but your gut sense can be as important as the technical factors. After all, feeling positive about a clinic may make your treatment less stressful and easier to stick with. Once you’ve had your initial consultation appointment, be sure to take a step back and assess the experience you had. Here are five questions to ask yourself before you green light a clinic. You can also revisit this list if you’ve been a patient for a while and something starts to feel “off.”
Did the doctor give me the time and attention I deserve?

If you felt rushed by the REI (reproductive endocrinologist and infertility specialist) or your questions were answered with one-word answers, you may be treated in a similar manner once you become a patient. Ideally, your concerns were addressed with patience, sincerity, and candor.
Am I being forced to do the most expensive treatment?

Sure, IVF may be the best option for you from the get-go, but make sure you’re given a chance to explore all the possibilities. And if you are being guided down the path of IVF, make sure you’ve been given an explanation about why that’s the right course of treatment for you.
Does this clinic feel “right” to me?

Only you can decide what “right” means. Not everyone needs warm and cozy office vibes, but if you’re the type of person who does better in a nurturing environment, a sterile/impersonal atmosphere or rude/cold receptionists may not be the best fit.
Do I feel like I’ll be emotionally supported here?

Cutting-edge technologies and up-to-date labs are important, but if you’re looking for a holistic experience, you may want to choose a clinic that considers your physical and emotional journey. Do they have an on-site counselor? Do they facilitate support groups with other women going through treatment?
Am I hopeful but realistic?

This is the magic combo—understanding the realities of what you’re signing up for (and what your odds of success are), while also being optimistic. The fertility journey often requires a tremendous amount of resilience, so if you leave the clinic feeling energized and empowered, that’s a good sign that you’re in the right hands.
For more help finding a clinic that will be a positive partner on your fertility journey, talk to your Maven Care Advocate for personal recommendations.

title.en-US: Do you really need to lose weight before IVF?

content.value: The truth about the scale.
As if the fertility/IVF journey wasn’t already emotionally fraught, many women have to contend with another loaded issue that affects matters: their weight.

The truth is, we know that being at a healthy weight puts women at an advantage when it comes to getting pregnant. Just to state the obvious—this doesn’t mean that the number on the scale guarantees conception, but here’s some of what the research shows: Having a high BMI (body mass index) negatively impacts live birth rates. Obesity can affect egg quality and may make it harder to have success with IVF. And the actual egg retrieval process can also be more of a challenge for overweight and obese women. (The ovaries have a tendency to move higher up the body because of excess fatty tissue in the pelvis, which means it’s harder to use a needle to get the eggs out.) Not to mention the additional concerns if IVF is successful. For instance, “obesity increases the risk of congenital anomalies (birth defects) such as cardiac defects (heart defects) and spina bifida, blood clots (deep venous thrombosis), the need for Cesarean section, and the odds of postpartum wound infection,” notes Jackie Stone, M.D., a Maven OB-GYN. There’s also a higher risk for pre-eclampsia and gestational diabetes during pregnancy.

For all these reasons, patients are often encouraged to get to a healthy weight before starting IVF. If your reproductive endocrinologist has suggested that trimming down can impact your success with IVF, you may be feeling overwhelmed or wondering where to begin. After all, weight management is hard, and for many people, it’s a lot more complex than just a calorie game. First things first: If you can, try to approach any weight-loss effort with some self-compassion. And whatever you do, don’t try a crash diet; a 2006 study actually found that severely restrictive diets had a negative impact on IVF.

A slow-and-steady approach is always a safer bet. But here’s where things get complicated: You may also be getting messages that “advanced age” can impact your success with fertility treatments—which is true. That’s why personalized care is so important in reproductive medicine. Make sure you have a doctor who is looking at you as a unique person, considering all the factors in your life (your age, weight, medical issues, emotional wellbeing, etc.), and recommending a plan based on what makes the most sense for you.
If you have questions about your weight, diet, or any other factors related to your fertility journey,
Maven practitioners
are available to chat with you anytime.

title.en-US: What’s a “fertility vacation” and should you consider it?

content.value: You’re probably familiar with babymoons, but you might not have heard about IVF holidays. That’s when women and couples take their fertility issues on the road (er, in the air) and seek treatment overseas in places like the Czech Republic and Cyprus instead of choosing a domestic clinic. And the hospitality industry is getting in on the planning, with IVF brokers taking the place of travel agents and offering deals on “all-inclusive” packages.
Research suggests fertility holidays are increasing in popularity—so what’s the draw?

For one, treatment overseas tends to be significantly cheaper. By some estimates, it may cost about a third of a domestic treatment package, especially for women who are considering using a donor egg. What’s more, some clinics are taking liberties with their marketing messages and giving women the false hope that their chances of conceiving are greater than they really are.

But the decision to take an IVF holiday isn’t always a matter of believing it will work better abroad. As couples acknowledge that having a baby with the aid of reproductive technology is a gamble, some of them have this mentality: If I’m going to roll the dice, why not get a vacation out of it?
Does that mean you should pack your bags?

Not so fast, caution experts. As appealing as jetting off to another country may seem in the midst of a stressful fertility journey, there’s no evidence that the quality of the technology that’s available abroad is any better or leads to greater success rates. In fact, it may not be as advanced (or regulated) as what you’ll find on your home turf. Whether you pursue treatment under the sunny skies of Michigan or the Mediterranean, make sure you’re going in with your eyes wide open and with the most realistic expectations. And while everyone hopes IVF will work on the first attempt, it often takes several cycles to work. You may want to establish a relationship with a local clinic and doctor who can follow your journey from the beginning.

That said, if you’re set on a fertility holiday, doing your research will be key. You should ask if the international infertility clinic is accredited—and if so, by which organization. Where did the reproductive endocrinologist receive his/her training? And make sure you put them through the same vetting process you would when looking at domestic clinics: Discuss their success rates, practices, technologies, etc. This is one vacation you don’t want to book on a whim.

title.en-US: 5 things not to say to couples struggling with infertility

content.value: The comments you might encounter—and really wish you wouldn’t have to.
“Just relax."

If getting pregnant boiled down to chilling out, then women would spend their money, time, and emotional energy on, say, yoga retreats—not grueling reproductive technology. This advice just isn’t helpful or realistic.
“I know the grass seems greener over here, but being childless really has its advantages.”

Just because someone who is a mom tells you that she “envies” your childless lifestyle, and that you should just “enjoy” this time without kids, are you supposed to suddenly feel grateful that you haven’t been able to get (or stay) pregnant? Of course not. File this one in the Clueless Comments Folder.
Everything happens for a reason.

If you believe that everything is happening (or not happening) at the right time, by all means, keep up that perspective. But if this view is imposed on you by someone who has never struggled to conceive, it can feel very patronizing.
Have you considered surrogacy or adoption?

There are many ways to start a family, but the decision is personal—and weighing your options is up to you, your partner, and, to some extent, your doctor. The rest of the world doesn’t get to have an opinion unless you invite it.
Take one of mine!
Being offered someone else’s kid = not a funny joke, ever. End of story.

title.en-US: Can my partner do anything about his sperm count?

content.value: Lifestyle changes that actually make a difference.

You often hear about what women can do to impact their fertility, but there are things men can do, too. Also noteworthy: Men produce new sperm every 70-74 days, so after making some changes for just three months, they could see a difference.

So what changes could your partner make? Well, if he’s smoking, getting support to quit is a good first step, since cigarettes are toxic to sperm. (If you do end up down the path of IVF, it’s important to know that male smoking is even associated with decreased IVF success rates.)

And while he doesn’t have to skip happy hour altogether, drinking alcohol in moderation is a good idea. Some experts say a drink or two is fine, while others advise an upper limit of three to five drinks per week for guys trying to boost their sperm count—so check with your fertility specialist.

And while a lot of attention has been paid to women’s waistlines when it comes to fertility, maintaining a healthy weight matters for men, too. Studies looking at obesity and male infertility found that obese and overweight men have a higher incidence of low sperm count.
Lastly, encourage him to chill out—literally. Too much exposure to high temps—like lingering in a sauna, or even the heat created from laptops resting on a guy’s lap—can affect sperm.

One thing to note: Everything we just mentioned is worth a shot for men in general to try to give their sperm counts a boost. But for guys who are known to have abnormally low sperm counts, recommendations for treatment would depend on the cause, notes Jackie Stone, a Maven M.D. Some men with a decreased sperm count can be treated medically or surgically, and a urologist can direct your partner down the right path.

title.en-US: What is ovarian reserve testing?

content.value: The 411 on this popular blood test and who should—and shouldn’t—consider it.

There are a few ways to test your egg situation before beginning fertility treatment, but one of the most common methods is to check the levels of AMH, or anti-mullerian hormone, in your blood. In a nutshell: A higher AMH level indicates a greater number of eggs. Your doctor will analyze the results and tell you if your egg supply is on par for your age, or if it’s on the low or high side.

So is the test a good predictor of your ability to get pregnant?
That depends. If you haven’t tried to get pregnant yet and you’re simply curious about whether or not you’re fertile, it may not be very helpful. A 2017 study by the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill looked at 750 women between the ages of 30 and 44 and found that those with test results showing a limited ovarian reserve were no less likely to conceive naturally within six or 12 months than women whose tests didn’t indicate a low egg supply. Basically, women who want to predict the likelihood of getting pregnant on their own shouldn’t place too much stock in the ovarian reserve test.

But here’s the upshot: The blood test is helpful in predicting how well a woman will respond to fertility interventions. For that reason, your reproductive endocrinologist may use the test to determine which ovarian-stimulation protocol will get you the best results possible, or how well IVF may work for you. With the right information—derived from tests like these as well as many other personal factors—specialists can tailor your treatment and increase the odds of pregnancy.

title.en-US: IVF success: Are two embryos better than one?

content.value: More than 40% of IVF deliveries in the U.S. are of twins or other multiples. The reason comes down to the common practice of transferring more than one embryo to the uterus in an effort to up the chances of a successful pregnancy. But does it actually help your odds? And can it do more harm than good? Keep reading for the answers.
Who is driving these multiple-embryo transfers?

Sometimes it’s the doctors who advocate for it to make sure their clinics can boast higher success rates. But sometimes it’s the patients themselves, who—in considering the physical, emotional, and financial investment involved in IVF—want to do whatever they can to maximize their odds of having a baby and avoid additional cycles. Their concerns that the cycle may not work with one embryo—or even a desire to conceive twins to “complete” their family in one cycle—leads them to push for a multiple transfer.
Isn’t it true that you’re less likely to get pregnant if you only transfer one embryo?

Actually, there’s promising research indicating that’s often not the case. A large study of women younger than 38 who underwent IVF in the U.S. in 2013 found that transferring multiple embryos did not result in significantly higher overall birth rates—just higher rates of twins, triplets, and other multiple births.
So what’s considered the best practice?

If you have more than one good quality embryo available, it’s now best practice for most women to have only one embryo put into the womb (and freeze the others). This is to reduce the chance of a multiple birth, which can pose serious risks to moms and babies.

In fact, the American Society for Reproductive Medicine (ASRM) made an official recommendation to encourage doctors and patients to choose single embryo transfer when appropriate—like anytime a woman doing IVF has what’s called a euploid embryo. (Quick science lesson: a euploid embryo has a normal number of chromosomes and has a greater chance of implanting successfully, higher odds of resulting in a successful pregnancy, and reduced chance of miscarriage.) The ASRM does say, however, that doctors can consider transferring additional embryos depending on special circumstances—such as when a woman doesn’t meet criteria for good prognosis, or she has good prognosis but been through multiple cycle failures.
What specific health risks are involved?

When transferring more than one embryo, the rate of twins and other higher order multiples increase. Twins, triplets, and other higher order multiples are more likely to be born prematurely, have a low-birth weight and respiratory issues. Meanwhile, moms carrying multiples don’t have it easy, either; their risk of pre-eclampsia, C-section, gestational diabetes, and other medical hardships also rises significantly.

title.en-US: She had her tubes tied at 20--then wanted to have a baby

content.value: Maven Real Talk on IVF with Kimberly
35 years old
Stay-at-home mom
Canada
Why did you decide to do IVF?
When I was 20 years old, I made a rash decision to have my tubes tied. IVF could allow me to get pregnant because the procedure bypasses the fallopian tubes.
How many times have you done IVF?

I’ve done one IVF cycle with two rounds of FET (frozen embryo transfer). 27 eggs were retrieved, and we ended up with 7 embryos. On my second attempt of FET, I became pregnant. Having heard how long it’s taken other people to conceive, that’s pretty quick!
How did you choose your clinic?
Proximity.
What surprised you most about IVF, and what could have made your patient experience better?

How emotional the whole process was! Honestly, I wish someone had fully warned me about the emotional part so I could’ve been in therapy while going through it. The most difficult part of the process was losing my first pregnancy.
Any tips for managing when going through IVF?
Just keep in mind how much your emotions are being affected by the medications. Fertility treatment involves lots of hormones, and it’s good to remember this when your mood is “off.”
Any tips for managing the stress that IVF can put on a relationship?

Yes. Look at each other and decide from the very start the maximum amount you will spend on fertility treatment. And be gentle with each other. Remember that the money involved with IVF causes stress, on top of other stress-causing factors—like the hormones you’ll be pumping into your body and all the commuting to and from the clinic. It’s a lot to deal with.
Did your insurance cover IVF?
No. We spent around $15K.
Do you have any plans to do IVF again?
I will do the FET procedure again to try to have a second child.
If your best friend was about to go through IVF, what would you want her to know?
Actually, my best friend did go through IVF! (This experience is more common than you might think.) She is currently awaiting her second baby via her second successful IVF attempt.
Is there anything about your IVF experience you wish we had asked?

I wish you’d asked me if I had any pregnancy complications after IVF. My answer would be yes. I had two large subchorionic hematomas that threatened my pregnancy. Once that was detected, I had to have a very low-key (almost bedridden) time.

title.en-US: Surviving the holidays when you're dealing with infertility

content.value:
Holiday gatherings are supposed to be happy occasions. But when you’re having trouble conceiving, they can be a mixed emotional bag. 
Psychologists who work with infertility patients say that family- and kid-focused holidays like Christmas, Hanukkah, and Thanksgiving are often a major pain point on the TTC (trying to conceive) journey. Shopping for gifts for your nieces and nephews; fielding questions from your insensitive relatives about when you’re “finally” going to have a baby; feeling pressure to be “on” when merriment is the last thing you feel—situations like these can easily make the holidays the most depressing time of the year.
How can you cope with the holidays when you’re TTC?

Unfortunately, you can’t eliminate all of the potential triggers, but you can have a game plan. If you’re attending (or hosting) a gathering with lots of kids or pregnant women, considering inviting someone who can be a source of comfort for you. Maybe it’s another friend who has struggled with infertility in the past, or is going through a similar experience right now. Then, when the party starts to feel like Gymboree hell, you and your pal can have your own conversations. If this isn’t an option, remember that you can always excuse yourself if you’re having a hard time. (This may be a great year to declare yourself on dish-duty and escape to the kitchen as often as necessary.)

It’s also a good idea to think about how you might handle the “when’s baby coming?” questions—will you address them directly? You could simply respond by saying something like:”We're having a hard time trying to get pregnant, and it's been stressful. Thanks for your support." If the shut-it-down method feels like a better approach, go for it. You can simply ignore the question, or have a go-to witty response to prevent any further prying. (One of the sassier comebacks we’ve heard: “I’m happy to give you my OB-GYN’s phone number so you can get all the specifics.”)

Remember, you can always enlist the help of one or two trusted family members to serve as a buffer between you and any particularly nosy or obnoxious relatives. Let them know you’re feeling a bit anxious about the holiday gatherings, and ask if they can help steer conversations away from sensitive topics on your behalf.

title.en-US: 4 easy ways to boost your mood during infertility treatment

content.value: When you’re going through something as challenging as infertility, there’s no one single way to feel better. And some days, unfortunately you may have to just sit through the pain. But there’s still merit in having some go-to strategies to elevate your mood and help you stay calm. Here are four easy tips to keep in your sanity tool-kit.
Get some green in your life

Studies have shown plants can have stress-reducing effects by calming the sympathetic nervous system, and also give people a mood boost. If you’re the most stressed at work—the hours of the day where you may not be able to access the support of your inner circle—consider buying a few desk plants.
Surround yourself with nature.

It’s natural to want to crawl under the covers when you’re feeling bad. Give yourself permission to do that, but know that getting some fresh air is an easy way to feel a little better. Research shows spending time around nature can have a positive effect on both your mood and energy levels. Sit on a park bench for a few minutes during your lunch break, or take the scenic route to your fertility clinic appointments. Even better if it’s a sunny day out; there is some evidence that suggests a connection between vitamin D levels and a happier mood.
Make a “fertility playlist.”
Listening to music is one of the fastest, easiest ways buoy your emotional state and fend off the blues. It can even lower your levels of stress-related hormones like cortisol. How can a
Spotify playlist
do so much good? Music seems to trigger neurochemicals systems in the brain in ways that have positive ripple-effects for your emotional state.
Just go to bed.

Here’s how quickly your emotions can plummet if you don’t prioritize sleep: University of Pennsylvania found that people who got only 4.5 hours of sleep per night for just one week reported feeling more stressed, angry, sad, and mentally exhausted. Those are the exact things you want to avoid during this trying time. So even if it means letting go of one last thing on the to-do list, try to turn in a little earlier each night.

title.en-US: Study says: Most relationships survive infertility struggles

content.value: A lot has been written about the relationship strain involved when a couple is going through infertility. That’s why we’re stopping to celebrate some hopeful news.

A large nationwide study involving more than 40,000 women in Denmark found that fertility treatment did not increase the risk of divorce. Looking at two populations—women who had assisted reproduction treatment (ART) and those who didn’t—the researchers found no difference in the odds of splitting. The researchers hope that this knowledge will help support patients’ commitment to treatment if they’re not ready to give up on their desire to have a child. Every couple must decide their own limits with ART, of course. But knowing that your relationship has a good chance of surviving may make it easier to stick with IVF when things get tough.
How is it possible that relationships aren’t doomed to crumble?
Going through ART isn’t easy, but in the process, you and your partner may be forced to communicate better than you ever have before, and to learn coping strategies as a team.
What if you don’t end up with a child, despite how long you persevere?

Interestingly, while this study didn’t see a link between undergoing fertility treatment and an increased risk of divorce, it did find that those who remained childless were more likely to call their relationship quits. Previous research showed a similar trend—in an earlier study, more than 25% of people who were unable to conceive via ART ended up splitting from their partners. The reasons for separation are complex. For example, the relationship can be a daily reminder of an unfilled dream to have a child—and for some people, parting ways seems less painful than staying together. The takeaway: It’s a really good idea to seek support during treatment. Individual and/or relationship therapy can help you and your partner cope with all the ups and downs.
But isn’t counseling only for couples with “bad” marriages?

Definitely not. A lot of people in healthy relationships pursue couples counseling. Sometimes you just need someone objective to help you communicate with each other or learn ways to deal with challenges that buoy (instead of break) your bond. Joint therapy can also make it easier to talk about difficult emotions, and give you a constructive plan for tackling the pain of infertility. Maven providers have expertise in this area, and they’re available anytime you want to chat.

title.en-US: Does the Mediterranean diet boost IVF success rates?

content.value: It’s sometimes called the anti-deprivation diet, and we can definitely get behind that. But what help, if any, does it offer for fertility? Get the facts here.

By now you’ve heard the praises that health experts sing about the Mediterranean Diet—a delicious eating style which emphasizes foods like nuts, fish, vegetables, fruits, legumes, nuts, and olive oil, and limits intake of red meat, processed grub, and added sugar. Now there’s evidence that adhering to the diet may have benefits for fertility—specifically when it comes to in vitro fertilization, or IVF.

In a 2018 study from Harokopido University of Athens published in the journal Human Reproduction, researchers recruited 244 non-obese women attempting pregnancy via IVF. They analyzed their eating styles during the six months before treatment—specifically looking at how closely (or not) they followed the Mediterranean diet.
What were the results?

Among the group of women who stuck closest to the Mediterranean diet, 50% got pregnant—and 49% had a live birth. That’s half of the group! Meanwhile, the pregnancy rate and live birth rate fell to 29% and 27% respectively for those who didn’t follow the diet closely at all.
Were there any limitations to the study?

Yes. First, the findings do not apply to obese women, as only non-obese women were included in the study. Also, the researchers did not find any association between diet and the chances of live births among those who were 35 and older, possibly because of other reproductive factors that play a larger role in fertility as women age. Further, some experts who weren’t involved with the study say that we don’t know for sure if the diet led to greater IVF success or if something else was at play. For instance, it is possible that patients with a healthier diet also didn't smoke and had other healthier lifestyle factors that could have affected their fertility.
So what’s the takeaway?

Though this study doesn’t prove that what a woman eats determines her IVF success, it does suggest that diet could play a role in outcomes. Further, it adds to the growing body of evidence showing that lifestyle habits matter when you’re trying to conceive. Considering that some aspects related to pregnancy will always be out of a woman’s hands, it’s nice to know that some environmental factors like diet are within anyone’s control. If you need help finding a healthy eating plan that works for you,
book an appointment with a Maven nutritionist
; our Care Advocates can help you find one who specializes in fertility.

title.en-US: Getting pregnant while already pregnant: Say what?!

content.value: The truth about those crazy news stories you might have read.

These are the kinds of headlines that make you wonder if you’re reading fake news: Woman Gets Pregnant Twice—with Babies Who Are 10 Days Apart. What makes these stories so hard to believe is that pregnancy is birth control. When you’re “with child,” your body produces hormones that shut down the baby-making processes. Whether you conceive naturally or with the help of IVF, ovulation is impeded once you’re pregnant. But there’s some data suggesting that in very rare, fluke, can’t-really-explain-why instances, a second pregnancy occurred days or weeks after the first.
It’s a wacky—and controversial—phenomenon—called “superfetation.”

Here’s some twin science 101: Getting pregnant with identical twins occurs when one egg is fertilized by one sperm, but that embryo splits into two after the transfer. Fraternal twins results from the transfer of two or more embryos. Twin embryos have the same gestational age.

Superfetation is different. In this case, a second, new pregnancy occurs during an initial pregnancy. Another egg is fertilized by sperm and implanted in the womb.
When conception happens through superfetation, the two fetuses don’t have the same gestational age and will develop at different rates (even if they’re born on the same day). The phenomenon is known to occur in other animal species such as badgers and hares.

Well, it seems that this rare medical fluke can happen in humans. In 2016, one California mom agreed to be a gestational carrier (surrogate) for another couple. A few months into that pregnancy, she got the surprising news from her doctor that she was carrying two babies. The second baby turned out to be her own biological child, conceived naturally, after the first embryo she was carrying for the couple had been implanted.

For superfetation to occur, a woman has to ovulate and the egg she releases must be fertilized by sperm (via intercourse). Despite the reported cases—like that of the woman in California—not everyone is convinced that this reproductive abnormality is possible in humans. Their view is that there must be something else going on to explain why one fetus may have a younger developmental stage in the womb compared to its sibling. For instance, if each fetus is getting a different amount of nutrients and growing at a different rate, it could lead to what seems like superfetation but isn’t.

Either way, this probably isn’t something you need to worry about. According to a 2008 research paper published in the European Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology, 10 cases of this happening—ever—had been reported. A few more claims have been documented since then, but it’s still mostly unheard of.

title.en-US: My fertility clinic recommended I take Vitamin D. Why?

content.value: Maven practitioner Nicole Avena, Ph.D.— a neuroscientist and expert in nutrition—explains why “the sunshine vitamin” might be beneficial during IVF.

Vitamin D is a fat-soluble vitamin that is found in some foods or produced in the skin during UV exposure. While you may have mostly heard about its impact on your bones, Vitamin D is also believed to play a role in reproduction and reproductive health, but the mechanism is unclear. Although the research is inconsistent, some studies show more positive outcomes—such as an increase in the clinical pregnancy rate—for women taking vitamin D while undergoing IVF.

For instance, back in 2014, researchers in Italy looked at the success of IVF in 154 women with a D deficiency compared with 181 women who got adequate amounts of the vitamin. Those who met their vitamin D requirement were twice as likely to get pregnant, according to the study, which was published in the Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism.

Although randomized clinical trials are needed, some clinics like yours may recommend that women undergoing IVF take a pill if they’re short on the vitamin. If you’re not clear on whether supplementing is right for you, or the correct dose, definitely ask your RE to explain things further.

As for other sources of D? You can find the vitamin in swordfish, salmon, tuna, sardines, fortified orange juice, fortified milk and yogurt, beef liver, eggs, and fortified cereals. Sunlight also helps you synthesize vitamin D, but depending on where you live, the time of year, what you wear, and how much sunblock you put on (wearing it is also important!), each person’s ability to make sufficient vitamin D will vary. Talk to your doctor about whether you’re meeting the daily recommendation (600 IU of vitamin D per day for most healthy adults) or if you should take a supplement.

title.en-US: 3 tests for male infertility your partner should know about

content.value: Yes, he needs to get checked out by a doctor too. Here’s the 411 on how those evaluations typically go down.

Unfortunately, when couples have trouble conceiving, women often bear the brunt of the load. They’re the ones who are usually at the clinic, answering a full battery of questions, having blood drawn, getting poked and prodded by ultrasound technicians—all in the name of figuring out “what’s wrong with them.” In fact, some doctors don’t even bring up the idea of having a male partner evaluated until any female causes have been ruled out. Here’s why that’s a problem: Though it's commonly believed that infertility is a "woman's problem," this thinking is just plain wrong. Roughly a third of infertility cases are due to male factors.

So when you’re trying to determine the best course forward for fertility treatment, it’s important that evaluation isn’t one-sided. As you’re talking to your doctor and a reproductive endocrinologist, your partner should simultaneously see his doctor about getting tested, too. Chances are, he’ll need to see a urologist, who might try a number of tests, including some common ones below:
Semen analysis

Your partner might do this in a cup at the doctor’s office or at home into a special condom. By looking at the semen, a doctor can detect any problems with sperm quality—how they look and how they move. This test can also assess the semen for, say, infection and sperm count. Usually, if the semen seems normal, the doctor might want to wait and see what your doctor turns up before performing additional tests.
Blood tests

If your partner’s semen analysis is abnormal, his doctor might recommend further testing. A blood test can confirm if azoospermia, or a lack of sperm in the ejaculate, is what’s standing in the way of conception. (Men can have normal semen volumes but no sperm in that fluid, so only a blood test would tell you.)
Ultrasound

A scrotal ultrasound is a type of image test that’s more detailed than what an X-ray could do. It’s done to look at the scrotum and the testicles within this pouch and help identify things like swollen veins and other issues that could be affecting sperm quality and production.
Bottom line:

There are lots of ways to diagnose—and treat—male infertility, depending on the cause. Making sure that your partner is being screened for any issues at the same time that you’re being evaluated could prevent you from going down the wrong path. What’s more, it could save you months or even years of trying to have a child without knowing what’s really getting in the way of your goal.

title.en-US: Did being on birth control mess with your fertility?

content.value: If you’re having trouble in the baby-making department, you may be wondering if the birth control method you used before you started trying could be to blame. Here are the facts.

There are lots of myths and misunderstandings surrounding birth control, but perhaps the most rampant are those concerning its effects on fertility. Stories from “I got pregnant the second after I got off the Pill” to “I couldn’t have a baby after I stopped taking it” are rampant. So, what gives? While every woman will respond differently to going off birth control, research shows that infertility is not one of the risks posed by being on it. Here’s what to expect once you stop the following contraception methods:
Combination-hormone methods (such as the Pill or Patch).

If you were on one of these methods, you can get pregnant as soon as you start ovulating, and for most women, that could happen in about two weeks (although don’t panic if it takes a couple of months). Some women worry that if they took hormonal contraceptives prior to conceiving, any lingering exposure to the hormones could lead to a miscarriage. But rest assured, this is a myth. Being on birth control just before getting pregnant does not cause early pregnancy loss.
Birth control implant.

This progestin-only method (aka Nexplanon) is implanted in your arm and prevents pregnancy for up to three years. But if you want to get pregnant before then, you can have it removed. Depending on where you are in your cycle, you can get pregnant as early as the first week after removal.
IUD (aka intrauterine device)

IUDs prevent pregnancy by either releasing a hormone into your uterus to halt ovulation or by releasing copper to make the uterus a hostile environment for sperm. The good news is that one you take it out, an IUD shouldn't impede your chances of conceiving. Doctors once blamed them for higher rates of pelvic inflammatory disease, which is associated with a higher risk of infertility. However, more recent research suggests that this isn’t true and most experts now agree that having an IUD does not increase the risk of pelvic inflammatory disease. Once you have the IUD removed, your fertility could return within a month. If it’s a hormonal IUD that’s being taken out, you may need a few months for your cycle to regulate.
Depo Provera

Also known as the “birth control shot,” this method prevents ovulation—just as the Pill does. However, because these hormones are injected into muscle tissue, you’ll have to wait 9 to 10 months (or even longer) for the compounds to leave your system so that your cycle returns to normal and you’re able to conceive. That’s why doctors say it’s not the best birth control option for women who want to delay pregnancy for only a few months.
So what’s keeping me from getting pregnant?

Just because you’re fertile pretty soon after you stop birth control doesn’t mean you’re certain to get pregnant. Several reasons can explain why women don’t become pregnant right away, even with regularly-timed sex. Women in their 20s have only a 20 to 25% chance of pregnancy each month. By 35, the likelihood is less than 10% in a given month. Translation: It could take time, and you have to consider that you’re older now than you were before you started taking birth control. Keep in mind, too, that if you had irregular periods before going on birth control, then you might still have them once you get off—and this fact alone could make conception more difficult for you than someone with regular cycles. Conventional wisdom says that you don't need to see a fertility specialist until you've been trying for a year with no luck (or 6 months if you’re over 35), but if you’re concerned, definitely talk to your doctor or a Maven provider to see if there’s a reason to get evaluated sooner.

title.en-US: How to ask your boss for time off for fertility treatments

content.value: Get the answer from Maven Career + Executive Coach Hana Ayoub.

Talking to our managers about anything personal, especially our health, can be uncomfortable. Kudos to you for initiating communication around taking time off for fertility treatment, as speaking up is a direct path to getting the support you need. Here are some tips to navigate the dialogue:
Determine the setting.

Depending on your relationship with your manager, you may opt to either schedule a coffee meeting out of the office or bring this up during a weekly one-on-one meeting. Nobody knows your boss better than you, but the factors to consider are whether an email heads-up would be appreciated, and if you both will be more comfortable having this type of conversation outside of an office setting or in a conference room.
Take the lead.

Remember, this is your news to share so be sure to drive the conversation. Lead with the punchline so she’s not left wondering what you’re there to discuss—a very direct statement like “I want to talk with you about taking time off for fertility treatments” is a good idea. Keep in mind your boss may not have prior experience managing someone in your situation. Even if they are a parent or have undergone fertility treatment themselves, they may not be quick or confident in their response. That’s okay. This initial conversation is more about you sharing the news than getting a specific reaction on the spot. There is time for follow-up talks to work toward the outcome you want. Also, make sure you come prepared with a sense of what you’re comfortable talking about and what you do not want to discuss. If your boss asks something you’d rather not disclose, a simple “I prefer to keep those details private for now; I hope you understand” should do.
Help them help you.

This is your opportunity to ask your boss for exactly what you need. Are you asking for a week off, a shortened workday, and/or the flexibility to work from home? Be specific with your ask. To the extent you are comfortable, perhaps share a short and simple explanation of the treatment, such as “I’ll have doctor appointments every morning for blood tests and monitoring.” Or, “I’ll have a procedure done and will need about a week for my recovery.”
Think through how others may be affected.

Come with a proposed plan and expected timeline. Acknowledge any impact that any time off you take may have on the business, including how this may affect your clients or other team members. If delegating some of your work to others is in order, ask your boss if now is the time to dive into the game plan or if you should circle back by a specific date to discuss the coverage details. (She may want to lead on this, but it’s a good idea to let her know you’re a willing team player.)
Close strong.

As you wrap up the meeting, check in with yourself to make sure you’ve hit all your key points. Thank your manager for her time and support, and reiterate any next steps (make sure it’s crystal clear who does what and by when).

title.en-US: How to keep fertility treatment from affecting your career

content.value: Get the answer from Maven Career + Executive Coach Hana Ayoub

Undergoing fertility treatment is an endeavor that’s really hard to put in a box and separate from the rest of your life. Given how time-consuming, expensive, and emotionally challenging it is, it’s natural to worry about the toll on your work life. There is no easy answer here—the key to staying on top of your career goals is to focus on the support you have available in the office, at home, and within yourself. Read on for three tips that can help.
Ask yourself, “What would this look like if it were easy?”

If you’re familiar with self-help guru Tim Ferriss, you may have heard that by asking himself this question, he’s able to take actions he might not even consider as possibilities when “this has to be hard” thinking takes over. If you’re rolling your eyes at the idea that you can apply this tactic to where you are right now, I get it. Your internal voice may be yelling: “If this (i.e. getting pregnant) were easy, I wouldn’t be in the throes of fertility treatment.” But here me out, because there’s value in considering the question.

By focusing on how hard it is to manage infertility and work, you may feel helpless or even paralyzed to find actionable solutions. So, if you had a magic wand, what specific part of your work situation would you wave the “make life easier” wand over? Here are some ideas:
If it’s the pressure of keeping infertility treatment under wraps at the office,
consider telling your manager.
If it’s the demand of your busy season at work,
time your fertility treatment accordingly
(if you have flexibility).
If it's the burden of keeping track of all your to-dos during various phases of the treatment process,
create a dedicated calendar and set reminders for appointments and injections.
(Then share it with your tribe, such as a partner or a supportive friend.)
If it’s the weight of too many outside responsibilities, such as involvement in a nonprofit or grocery shopping for an elderly neighbor,
delegate
. Making temporary alternative arrangements allows you to focus on your priorities of creating the family and career you desire.
Be as informed as possible.
Here are a few key areas that you’ll want to understand:
Know your rights in terms of any paid or unpaid leave for fertility treatment.
Determine your health benefits plan coverage.
Research state laws around infertility coverage.
Understand common practice flexibility for your schedule at work.

Don’t know where to begin? Start by reaching out to your benefits representative within your employer’s Human Resources department. Depending on the size of your organization, this person may have already gathered relevant fertility resources and save you some time during your search.
Consider a reframe.

Many people look at both fertility treatment and their career as competing priorities, like a tug of war where any time or effort spent on one area takes away from the other. Embrace a new way of looking at this situation where each can
add
to the other, offering some integration and synergy between the two. Here are a few ways you might do this:
Take a moment of gratitude
for any employer-sponsored health benefits that are made available to you. Research shows that a little gratitude goes a long way.
Utilize your professional strength

s in the fertility process. Are you known in the office for diligent research chops, or your ability to bring levity to a tense boardroom? Identify your skills and natural talents, and apply them to your approach in navigating medical information and treatment options.
Use work as an outlet

to channel the emotional uncertainty of the treatment process. “Flow” is the term used by researchers for the state of consciousness when you’re so absorbed in something that “self” vanishes. Find a work project you want to sink your teeth into, and find your flow. Even just 30 minutes of being in flow state on a work project can be energizing and fulfilling.
Need more advice on managing your work life while undergoing fertility treatment? Book a video chat with a Maven career coach.

title.en-US: The pros & cons of opening up about infertility at work

content.value: Advice from Maven Career Coach, Mary Beth Ferrante

Any type of personal crisis or health-related challenge—and infertility definitely counts as one—could affect your work life. When you’re in the throes of IUI or IVF, everything from your job performance, hours of availability, attitude toward work, and your energy levels may be impacted. Making matters harder, deciding whether or not you should tell your boss what’s going on can increase the stress and anxiety you are already feeling. I know because I’ve been there. I’m a work coach on Maven (and I’m now a parent), but I’ve had my own struggles with trying to conceive and have had to navigate these decisions for myself. Hopefully my experience—as both a patient and a career expert—can help you decide what’s right for you.
The pros of staying quiet

One hesitation women have about opening up about their infertility is that their end goal—having a baby—will also require time off. (Maternity leave isn’t something to ever feel bad about, but it’s not uncommon for women to fear resentment in the workplace.) So you may be concerned that your manager or team may see you as already less committed to your work—and start to steer you towards the “mommy track.” These are all valid reasons to stay mum.
The pros of opening up

With the number of appointments and the emotional and physical effects of undergoing fertility treatments, the reality is this: Work tends to get interrupted—a lot. For this reason, many women feel compelled to share something with their managers. Opening up to your boss (even if you don’t get into the details) may help her understand what you are going through and convey the fact that you’re not slacking off. Not to mention, the pressure of keeping it under wraps and coming up with excuses for missing work or coming in late may be more stressful than just being honest.
How I chose to handle it

I chose not to divulge the details to my manager or team members. At the time, I had a corporate job working on a distributed team—and my manager sat in an office across the country. This made it much easier to duck out of the office for appointments, although I did sometimes have to make it known that I wouldn’t be available for meetings because of doctor visits.

When I finally broke the news of my pregnancy, I decided to tell my manager that infertility was the reason for all of the frequent doctor visits. His reaction? He said he was so glad I was “just pregnant” and did not have a serious illness! Knowing that he was, in fact, concerned for my well-being has made me realize that perhaps I could have shared a bit more about what was going on!
What should you do?

The truth is, there is no one right answer. Each employee has to decide for herself whether or not to tell her boss. Your decision may boil down to these two main factors: 1) Your relationship with your manager and team. (Do you work in a supportive environment? Is your boss someone you trust?) 2) Your comfort level sharing about the challenges you are having with infertility. (Some people are just more private than others.)

If you do decide to open up—or if you eventually find yourself in a position where you need time off and have no choice but to share—use these tips for discussing infertility with your manager and coworkers.
1) Review and understand your sick policy.

How much paid time off do you have in case of illness? Are you able to take unpaid time off if you run through all of your sick time? It may be helpful to have a conversation with your HR team so that you are armed with complete and correct information before talking to your boss. This is important so that you feel confident if questions arise about the time off you are requesting.
2) Determine how much you are willing to share.

For most of my clients, the biggest concern is that by sharing this information, they will derail their career trajectory. However, the reality is that you are going to need some time off during treatment. Even if you don’t get into the specifics, it can be very helpful to disclose to your manager that you are dealing with a health-related issue. And while it’s not exactly black and white, according to The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC), refusing to give off time for fertility treatment is considered a violation of the Pregnancy Discrimination Act. In other words: It may be in your best interest to disclose more details in order to protect the time off that you require.
3) Use the sandwich approach.

Whether you simply say that you are dealing with a health issue or you reveal that you are undergoing fertility treatments, it’s important to share that information sandwich-style! What do I mean by this? You sandwich the news in between two pieces of positive content: Start with reiterating your commitment to your work/ project/ team, or highlighting a recent accomplishment at work. Then transition into stating that while you are extremely committed to your work, you need to share a personal situation that may impact your availability in the office. (During this middle part of the conversation, it’s also important to ask for any accommodations you may need—flexible hours on the days of your appointments, ability to work remotely if you are not feeling well, etc.) Then close the conversation by again reiterating your commitment at work.
4) Be specific about how you’d like your manager to share (or not share) this information with the team.

It’s understandable that she may need to answer questions about your absences or have teammates cover your work, so be clear about what information you’re okay disclosing. For example, you may reveal to your manager that you are dealing with infertility but ask that, when telling other team members, she simply shares that you have a personal situation that requires some time out of the office. If you are comfortable, it’s best to have a conversation directly with the people most impacted by your time off.
5) Protect your emotional, mental and physical well-being.

Using your sick days may be more obvious when you aren’t feeling well physically during treatment. But it’s also important to recognize when you mentally just need a break. Whether it’s avoiding yet another office baby shower, or dealing with the heartbreak of a failed transfer during IVF, give yourself permission to take time off for your emotional well-being. Too often women are so concerned about being out of the office for all of the appointments that they force themselves to “power” through these extremely tough days—but doing so can lead to more stress, fatigue, and challenges at work with fertility. Giving yourself a day (or several) to re-group may be a win-win all around.
6) Build a support network.

You need at least a couple of trusted confidants in your life who know what’s happening! If you’re lucky enough to have a team member or two that you’re close with, consider opening up so you can lean on them when you need a hug, some extra motivation to get through the work day, or just an ear to listen to your concerns during a lunch break.
7) Try not to plan around what might or might not happen.

This is easier said than done, but fertility treatment takes time. There are no guarantees about when you will get pregnant—and even then, you still have nine months of pregnancy before the baby arrives. So for now, try not to let your future circumstances dictate your career choices or trajectory.
Managing these conversations at work is definitely tough, but you are not on your own! Reach out to a
Maven Career Coach
for more tips on talking with your team and manager and help putting a game plan together.

title.en-US: I’m in my early 40s and IVF hasn’t worked. Should I give up?

content.value: Answer from Maven Reproductive Endocrinologist Scott Morin, M.D.

One Maven member came to me with this concern: “I’ve heard that birth rates for women undergoing IVF decline dramatically with age; by age 43, the chance of becoming pregnant through IVF is less than 5%—not much higher than the chance of natural pregnancy! I’ve been pursuing IVF with my own eggs (I want a biological child) but it hasn’t been successful. Should I keep going?”

This is a common conundrum. While many women are successfully achieving a healthy pregnancy in their 40s through IVF, it is undeniable that the likelihood of success diminishes as women get older. As a result, many women in this age group are confronted with the difficult decision of whether it is worth it to continue with fertility treatments after their initial attempts are unsuccessful.

Like many decisions in fertility medicine, this one is complicated and depends on your individual situation. National and clinic-specific registries such as the SART or CDC databases are helpful in providing general information about the chances of success in a given age category. But it’s important to remember that these are population-based metrics and miss the subtleties of each situation. Translation: Every woman is different.
With this in mind, here are some of the important things to factor in when evaluating whether it makes sense to continue IVF after a failed cycle in your 40s.
1. How did your previous cycles go?

IVF is first and foremost a treatment modality, but it also provides some very important diagnostic information. One of the biggest predictors of IVF success is the response to a previous IVF cycle. The likelihood of success in the second cycle is much higher if there were many eggs (>10) retrieved in the first cycle than if there were very few retrieved (<4). If the response was good in the first cycle, it is more likely that there will also be a good response in the next cycle. More eggs equals a greater chance that there will be at least one healthy embryo in the bunch next time.
2. Does your clinic have a high performing embryology laboratory?

The biggest difference between IVF clinics is not in the medical protocols chosen for a given cycle, but in the quality of the IVF laboratory. In other words, a given egg retrieved in one laboratory may be more (or less) likely to produce a healthy embryo than if it was retrieved in a different laboratory. When you are confronting what might be your last shot in treatment, you want to maximize your chances by being in the best possible lab. Ask your clinic about the performance of their laboratory; they all track metrics such as fertilization success rates, what percentage of embryos make it to day 3, as well as day 5 (aka blastocyst survival rate). You should insist on seeing these metrics to make sure you’re in good hands.
3. Carefully consider whether or not to try a laboratory with different protocols.

Not only do labs have different fertilization and embryo survival rates, they also have different philosophies on when to perform embryo transfers. Some labs perform transfers on day 3 of an embryo’s development (or the cleavage stage). Other laboratories perform embryo transfers on day 5 or 6 of development (or the blastocyst stage). Some favor transferring the embryos in the same cycle as the ovarian stimulation (fresh embryo transfer). Others prefer freezing the embryos first and transferring them in the next menstrual cycle (frozen embryo transfer). Some do very little preimplantation genetic testing. Others use this test more liberally. If you’ve failed multiple cycles in a lab with one philosophy, it is reasonable to try a lab with a different philosophy. While there are no guarantees, this could give you the small edge that you need to tip the scales in your favor.
4. How are YOU doing?

The fertility treatment journey is an emotional rollercoaster. It is physically and emotionally taxing. The choice to continue in treatment is very, very challenging as a result. While it is incredibly difficult to do, make time to take stock of how you are doing. The message from fertility specialists is always that time is at a premium. But taking a month off to carefully consider your options and the best step for you is something that patients rarely regret. It can be very valuable.

title.en-US: The connection between past eating disorders and infertility

content.value: Get the answer from Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, M.D.

This is a great question—and yes, there is an association between all types of eating disorders (including anorexia, bulimia, overeating, and binge eating) and future infertility. In fact, some research suggests that up to 18% of patients seen in infertility clinics had an eating disorder at some point. Another study found that 60% of women with infertility related to ovulation problems had an eating disorder. So what could explain this connection?
Anovulation

: This is the technical term for when your body doesn’t ovulate. Anorexia, bulimia, and binge eating can interfere with hormones in the pituitary gland (part of the brain) that are necessary to maintain normal ovulation and menstruation. Almost all patients who are anorexic and about half of patients who are bulimic become amenorrheic (read: lose their period). This is thought to be due to poor nutrition, low body fat, and low estrogen levels.
Excessive exercise

: Many women with eating disorders also exercise excessively in an attempt to lower their body fat or as a way to “purge” after binge eating. While some exercise is good for you, excessive amounts have been shown to cause disruptions in ovulation and menstruation. Even if you aren’t at a low body weight, over-exercising can still interfere with your menstrual cycle.
Overeating

: Eating too much can result in obesity—and obesity triggers hormonal imbalances that can make it hard to conceive, including irregular periods and anovulation. After all, it’s difficult to get pregnant when your body won’t release an egg.
Is it all bad news?

No! If you have an eating disorder and seek appropriate treatment, there is a good chance that your periods will resume within 6 months. This also means that your chances of pregnancy will increase. However, if you have not conceived within 12 months of trying (6 months if you are 35 or older), your OB-GYN may refer you to a fertility specialist. If you haven’t talked to your provider openly about your struggles with eating and/or exercise, it’s important to open up. You may also want to reach out to a Maven mental health provider. In addition to helping you cope with any issues around infertility, they can provide support during a future pregnancy—in case issues related to eating or body image flare up.

title.en-US: Why your friend’s IVF protocol is different than yours

content.value: Answer from Maven Reproductive Endocrinologist Scott Morin, M.D.

Quick refresher: All traditional IVF protocols use medications called gonadotropins to stimulate the maturation of multiple eggs in one menstrual cycle. Gonadotropins (FSH and LH) are hormones that a woman’s body naturally makes to cause eggs to reach full maturation prior to ovulation (release of the egg from the ovary). However, in a natural menstrual cycle, the level of gonadotropins produced is relatively low—so only one “dominant follicle” reaches full maturation and releases an egg. In an IVF cycle, the dose of gonadotropins that a patient takes is much higher. As a result, additional eggs that needed a stronger gonadotropin message to reach full maturation are “rescued”—which means that multiple eggs can be released (typically 8 –15, but as many as 30 – 40).

When we talk about IVF “protocol,” we are referring to the different medications that patients take to stimulate the ovaries to produce multiple eggs. While there are slight variations, in general there are three basic structures upon which all protocols are based.
1. Antagonist Protocol
In addition to gonadotropins, the antagonist protocol uses a medication called a GnRH antagonist. The purpose of the antagonist is to prevent the eggs from being ovulated before the egg retrieval.
Why it’s used:

The advantage of the antagonist protocol is that it can significantly decrease the risk of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome—an excessive response to taking the medicines used to make eggs grow. So, it is often used in patients who are expected to produce many eggs (although it can be used in any patient). The other advantage is that a patient will take fewer injections than with other protocols because the GnRH antagonist starts about 5 days after gonadotropin injections begin. These two advantages make the antagonist protocol the go-to choice in most IVF clinics.
2. Long Protocol (also called the Down Regulation Protocol)

This protocol was the most popular protocol prior to the introduction of GnRH antagonists. Here’s how it works: Patients start a medication called a GnRH agonist at the end of their menstrual cycle. They continue the agonist through the end of that cycle and into the IVF cycle (around 18 days in total). The agonist serves the same function as the antagonist—it eliminates the chance of premature ovulation before the egg retrieval.
Why it’s used:

This is preferred by some clinics who are simply more comfortable with the agonist protocol due to having a longer experience with it. Some clinics also feel safer knowing that a patient is already taking the medication that will eliminate the chance of premature ovulation, rather than having to remember to instruct the patient to start the antagonist to "turn off" the ovaries after starting gonadotropins. Many times, this protocol will be used as a plan B if the results of the initial cycle with an antagonist protocol didn’t go as well as the clinic had hoped.
3. Flare Protocol (also called Microflare protocol)

The flare protocol uses a GnRH agonist, but at a lower dose than the long protocol. The agonist starts on day 2 or 3 of the stimulation cycle and is intended to jump start natural gonadotropin production from a patient’s own body (in addition to the gonadotropin medications that she is taking). The idea here is to get as much gonadotropin as possible to the ovaries to stimulate the most number of follicles to mature.
Why it’s used

: This protocol is typically used in patients who are expected to produce fewer eggs (aka “low responders”). The clinics hope that a combination of natural gonadotropin production plus gonadotropin injections will maximize the response to the IVF cycle and up the production of eggs.
Bottom line

Ultimately, the job of the clinic is to choose the best protocol for each individual in order to optimize the number of retrieved eggs and provide you with the greatest possible chance for a healthy pregnancy. And if the regimen differs from your friend’s, that’s okay. Be sure to check out
MavenRx
, Maven's partnership with leading fertility pharmacies offering you discounts on your medications, one-on-one support, and more.

title.en-US: Help! I hate my fertility clinic. Can I switch?

content.value: Answer from Maven Reproductive Endocrinologist Scott Morin, M.D.

There are many factors that contribute to a successful patient experience in a fertility clinic. In some areas of the country, the nearest clinic may be a short flight away. This fact alone may make it more difficult for someone to switch from one clinic to another. However, in major metropolitan areas, there are often multiple options within driving distance. And when this is the case, patients should feel empowered to make sure that their clinic is a good fit for both their medical situation and their personality. Here are a few things to consider before making a move.
How long will it take to get an appointment at another clinic?

As more employers are covering fertility treatments, patients in many major cities are confronted with long waitlists for certain doctors in some clinics. Because the passage of time can decrease the odds of success, patients should be wary of moving to a new clinic if they can’t be seen for 3 or 4 months.
Do you have embryos that were created in a prior cycle that would need to be shipped to your new clinic?

There are a few reasons why moving your embryos from one clinic to another clinic may not be in your best interest. First, clinics follow different methodologies for freezing embryos. The device used to freeze the embryo can be different (a straw versus a loop, for instance). And an embryologist in your new clinic may be less familiar with the device used at the previous clinic. The protocols for thawing the embryos are also carefully calibrated by each clinic. Moving to a new clinic may mean having lab staff that is less familiar with a certain thawing protocol. Finally, while most clinics are experienced in accepting eggs or embryos from outside clinics, moving eggs or embryos means that they are literally put in tanks and shipped to another location. This introduces unforeseen risks in transit.
What is the clinic’s “style” for patient care?

While all fertility clinics are trying to accomplish the same goal (the delivery of a healthy baby), their methods for achieving that goal can be very different. Some clinics use a team-based approach, whereby you may only see your doctor for your initial visit and never again. Other clinics will go to great lengths to ensure that your doctor will be present for your ultrasounds, egg retrieval, and embryo transfer. The same distinctions are seen at the nursing level—being assigned an individual nurse is unique to some clinics and not others. While there are many advantages to having your doctor and nurse present at each step of the process, some patients prefer the idea that multiple people are actively involved in their care and reviewing their case. If the workflow at your current clinic is not ideal for you, make sure to pay attention to how it’s different at any new center you’re considering.
What does your gut say?

The fertility treatment journey is a deeply personal one. Unfortunately, patients carry a significant burden of responsibility when making decisions—including their clinic preference—because each choice impacts their goal of having the family that they’ve dreamed of. If your gut is telling you to switch to another clinic, it is certainly worth it to at least look around. Your clinic may put the full-court press on to keep you, but it is your life and your decision. If you think you might have a better experience elsewhere, don’t feel bad about gathering more information and following your instincts.

title.en-US: Is it normal to resent friends who got pregnant without IVF?

content.value: Answer from Mercedes Samudio, Maven Mental Health Coach and Licensed Clinical Social Worker (LCSW)

This is a common issue among friends, actually. And it's nowhere near abnormal to be jealous or resentful that our friends haven’t had to go through the same hardships that we have had to experience in order to get pregnant. Having a feeling, acknowledging it, and them moving past it is nothing to feel bad about—in fact, it could be a part of your healing process and moving on. Where I see this getting people into trouble is when they stay in that place and simmer in resentment and jealousy for too long, never being able to let go of it. That’s when it can become toxic. Here’s some advice to help you process your feelings and get to the other side:
1. Give yourself space to grieve.

It really does suck when you are going through something that no one close to you has dealt with. Give yourself time and space to be sad, angry, resentful, and even jealous. You can do this by journaling, seeing a professional to air out your feelings, or just some good, cleansing crying sessions. During this phase, there's no need for guilt or shame—it makes sense to feel this way, and by simply allowing these emotions to be there, you can make room for them in a healthy way. The alternative is to suppress them, and if you do that, chances are they will bubble up and spill out an inopportune time.
2. Be conscious about your "why."

After moving through the negative feelings, ask yourself why you went through the difficult process to conceive. This will put you back in touch with the reasons you decided to endure fertility treatments to grow your family—and by remembering these reasons, you shift your focus from others back to yourself. This may help minimize the resentment you feel by bringing you to a place of gratitude, joy, and forgiveness. Yes, the journey was long and hard, but now you’re looking forward to welcoming a baby into your life, and that’s what really matters.
3. Talk to someone about how you're feeling.

Conceiving a baby—whether naturally or through fertility treatment—is a time when lots of changes are going on in your mind and body. Don't be afraid to talk to a professional to sort through the feelings that you may experience during your pregnancy. Being resentful isn't concerning by itself, but coupled with other challenging emotions that may come up, this could be a time of a lot of stress. Having someone to talk to can help lessen the mental burden.
4. Don't go it alone.

Often, we want our friends to go on each of life's journeys with us, but that's not always possible. If you're conception journey is different than your friends', then look for support in a community that is experiencing the same things you are going through. Find a group—online or in person—where you can share your feelings and experiences with like-minded people. It doesn't mean that you need to sever ties with your friends; it just means you may need some support that they can't give you at this very moment, and that’s OK.

title.en-US: “Help! Infertility has shattered my self-esteem at work”

content.value: Get the answer from Maven Career + Executive Coach Hana Ayoub
