One Maven member came to me with this dilemma: “I used to be a very confident employee, but since struggling with infertility, my self-esteem has taken a hit and it’s affecting how I show up at work. Do you have any advice on getting my confidence back?”

The truth is, any type of health issue, especially one that directly affects your future and your sense of identity, is bound to take a toll on your self-esteem. Struggling with infertility means navigating limits within your body which is a humbling experience for many people. The good news is that you have a positive reference point: you’ve been in a position before of experiencing confidence at work. And it’s also an excellent sign that you’re actively seeking tools to get back on track. Read on for a few tips to start turning things around.
Let yourself process the infertility experience.

Going through such a big life event warrants some real support to fully process your beliefs and emotions about what’s going on. Dedicate time to acknowledge and unpack what infertility means to you. Whether you leverage the support of a therapist, your partner, or family, do the introspective work to understand the significance of this so that you can move forward both personally and professionally.
Build your own case.

Remind yourself that the root of this temporary setback in your self-esteem at work is not a result of lack of competence. You’ve got achievements under your belt, so reconnect with the times when you felt confident. Do so by taking inventory of your contributions. What are your professional wins this year? What impact did they have? The task of gathering evidence of your accomplishments at work can interrupt the negative thought loop and help you objectively see (and feel) that you have earned every right to be a confident employee.
Check your body language.
It’s no wonder
Amy Cuddy’s 2012 Ted Talk on power posing

has been viewed nearly 50 million times. Cuddy, a social psychologist, shares that altering your body language in specific ways can actually make you feel more confident. Check out her video, and adopt one of her poses—like the "The Wonder Woman" stance, where you put your hands on your hips, and tilt your chin upward. Think of this as a physical hack to “fake it until you make it” and remember that, yes, you are a wonder woman!

title.en-US: What you should know if you’re hesitant to use a donor egg

content.value: Advice from Maven Mental Health Practitioner Kristen Routh, a licensed marriage and family therapist

Choosing to use an egg donor can be difficult for many women for individual and varied reasons. When I work with clients who are facing this dilemma, many express feeling selfish for wanting a genetically-linked child, and I always reassure them that there is nothing wrong with wanting a child from your own genetic line. That said, I encourage them to explore their reasons for not wanting to use a donor—beyond their knee-jerk “no” reaction.
General responses I hear include: “I worry the baby won’t feel like mine”... or “a child from my own egg would be more like me, and a child from another egg would not.”

Next I ask clients to describe a child who is “like them,” other than physical features. Women are able to list personality traits, talents, interests, skills, and other desirable characteristics they hope would be reflected in their children.

This opens up a discussion about what birthing and raising a child truly means. For one, the mother-child bond that is created during gestation goes far beyond DNA. The uterine environment, a mom’s lifestyle (including diet and exercise), and even her emotions can influence the way a baby’s genes are expressed. We then discuss how nurture and upbringing play an equally important role in the development of personality and other characteristics they want to pass on to their offspring.

When I ask women to define what motherhood means to them, they’re often able to reflect and see that the fertilization of an egg is actually the shortest step of this entire experience—whereas raising a child and helping them become a happy, healthy, and functioning adult is a decades-long process. Through open dialogue, we define what is more important to the woman: creating a baby from her own egg or raising a healthy child no matter where the egg comes from.

I always urge clients to talk to other women who’ve faced this decision to hear about their experiences. Although some moms who’ve done donor-egg IVF say they still have a curiosity about what a child from their own eggs would be like, I have never met one who resented using donor eggs once her baby is in her arms. Women will often tell me they now realize the mom-child relationship they craved was not dependent on a genetic connection. What’s more, they usually comment on how they see “many pieces of themselves” in their children.

Bottom line: If you are struggling with the decision to use donor eggs, I would encourage you talk with a trained therapist or counselor—in your fertility clinic or on Maven’s platform—to discuss your feelings in a full and honest way. With support, you will be able to make a decision that’s right for you—whether that’s egg donation or exploring other paths to parenthood.

title.en-US: Dealing with partner resentment when you can’t get pregnant

content.value: Advice from Maven Mental Health Practitioner Kristen Routh, a licensed marriage and family therapist

The best thing to do in this scenario? Ask him directly how he’s feeling. Too often, we hide our true feelings from our partners because we’re scared of feeling even more rejected by them. But the truth is that holding onto a thought that is causing fear and sadness is not healthy for you or for the relationship. Once you open up to your partner, you not only step out of fear and into reality, but you also give him a chance to support you. Chances are, he’s going through his own difficult emotions; he could even be feeling helpless and “defective” himself, and struggling to communicate that to you.

If your husband does reveal he is carrying some kind of resentment, he most likely is feeling frustrated with the infertility journey, rather than harboring blame toward you. It would be good to openly discuss the hard feelings you both are having in the safety of a therapy or counseling session, where a professional can help you sort out where your true angers and frustrations are coming from and how to move past them.
Bottom line: You cannot be responsible for another person’s feelings, but you can have ownership of your own, and take steps to help alleviate any distress they’re causing you.

title.en-US: How to manage job stress during fertility challenges

content.value: Get the answer from Maven Career + Executive Coach Hana Ayoub

Stress management is a challenge that plagues many people, regardless of job industry and career stage. But when you’re going through a demanding/challenging time in your personal life, coping with workplace stress can be even harder. Read on for a few tips to help you get through this tough time and beyond.
Accept that you can’t do everything yourself.

This is critical first step to delegating, a practice that will serve you well now and throughout your career. Ask yourself, “What can I get off my plate, and who has the right skill set to help?” Start with small tasks, then work your way up to slightly more substantive work. This will likely require some time up front in handing off the project and overseeing progress, but it’s better than owning the task entirely and not having anyone else involved. When people say, “I can’t think of anyone to help,” I encourage them to look a little harder. You might be surprised. For instance, perhaps another manager is looking to diversify the scope of work for someone on their team. Or perhaps a peer has been eager to get involved in something outside of their wheelhouse. Don’t assume nobody has the bandwidth.
Let go of perfect.

Many of us give 110% on every single thing we touch at work, to a fault. While I’m all for upholding a high standard of excellence, look for areas in your work where you’re deploying too much time and energy for the task at hand. For example, it’s unnecessary to quadruple read an email before hitting send. A simple second glance should do for most internal correspondence. Challenge yourself to find at least one thing each day where you can loosen the reins on perfectionism. Just this one habit can offer some relief to on-the-job stress.
Tune in to patterns.

Take inventory of the sources of stress at work. This is a great exercise to gain an understanding of where, exactly, the stress is coming from, and see if there are any patterns or themes that emerge. For example, maybe you’ll realize that you’re most stressed by unknowns, like when a team you work with fails to keep you in the loop on projects you’re involved in. That could be a quick fix in asking them to notify you of important developments. Or maybe you’ll notice you’re overwhelmed on days when you’re trying to multitask, like abandoning a presentation you’re working on in mid-sentence to Google a fertility clinic’s reputation. In this case, cutting down on the distractions can help you feel more in control of your workday.
Make your downtime count.

With all that’s on your plate, you might have very little time to yourself these days. The key is to make the most of your downtime. Are you spending it in a way that helps you recharge your internal batteries, or do you emerge more exhausted and anxious? Sometimes all it takes to feel less stressed is carving out a half hour to prepare a nourishing meal, finding 20 minutes for a nap (instead of, say, tackling the laundry), or doing a short, gentle yoga session in your living room when you return from work. Now more than ever, it’s important to take actions that replenish you, and steer clear of anything that will deplete you.

title.en-US: I’m exhausted from IVF but afraid to take a break. help!

content.value: Advice from Maven Mental Health Practitioner Kristen Routh, a licensed marriage and family therapist

Fertility treatments can be taxing on so many levels—emotionally, physically, spiritually—not to mention the toll they take on relationships and finances. If you are feeling exhausted and depressed, then you may be at a point where taking a break from fertility treatments is not only valid, but also necessary for your wellbeing.

If you need help validating the fact that IVF can throw your life into upheaval, consider the advice you would give a friend if she was in your place right now. Your body has been unsettled by hormones and medications. Your emotions have been on a rollercoaster of hopefulness and disappointment. Your time has been centered around treatments and doctor appointments. Even when this all happens for the well-intended reason of growing your family, it’s normal to reach a breaking point. The exhausted and depression you’re experiencing could be your body’s way of telling you to hit the pause button on your parenthood goals and prioritize self-care.
What should you do during an IVF break?

Take time to restore your general health and wellbeing. Allow yourself to exercise (with your doctor’s OK) and reconnect with your body. Let yourself catch up on sleep. Do things to remind yourself that your body is strong and capable (something that’s easy to forget in the throes of fertility treatment). This is also a good chance to nurture your relationships: Spend time with friends and family talking about things other than fertility and reproduction. Go on dates with your partner, doing things you used to enjoy before IVF took over your life.

Lastly, I recommend speaking to a counselor who can support you and help you assess your emotional needs. Depression can be the result of chronic stress and repeated disappointment, and talking with a trained professional can help you make peace with things that are out of your hands (as well as find more joy with things that are in your control). Another benefit of therapy is that you’ll have an opportunity to mindfully and consciously choose your next steps—which is very difficult to do in the thick of an IVF cycle. By taking a break from fertility treatments, you can reassess your desire for a biological child from a more neutral stance.
Bottom line:
IVF breaks are part of the process. Give yourself permission to take one, and strive to give yourself as much nurturing as possible during this time.

title.en-US: How to open up about infertility in a mostly-male workplace

content.value: Get the answer from Maven Career + Executive Coach Hana Ayoub

Talking about infertility in the workplace can be challenging, whether you’re sharing with a man, woman, or non-binary person. It’s normal to feel vulnerable, and doubt that others hearing the news will be able to understand. I admire that you have the courage to initiate the dialogue. The truth is, doing so can be a direct path to finding support, compassion, and a deeper connection with your boss and colleagues. Here are of few tips that may help you feel less stressed about opening up.
Understand
why
you’re sharing.

I can imagine various reasons why you may want to open up, such as having a confidant at work to turn to, or getting help with your workload while you undergo treatment. Before you have the conversation with your manager and colleagues, reflect on the reason you’re doing so and get clear on an ideal outcome. If you simply want your manager to understand that you’re going through a personal challenge, that’s valid. But if you’re hoping to get some specific support or ask for certain accommodations, be clear about those needs, too. Once you connect with the upside of opening up, you can keep it in mind as you navigate the conversation. Check out these
additional tips
on preparing for and managing the conversation.
Remember, everyone struggles with something.

Take a moment to reflect on all the times you’ve been able to support someone going through a major challenge that you haven’t been through—divorce, the loss of a parent, traumatic financial crisis, and so on. Even if you work with men who don’t have personal experience with infertility (although, to be sure, infertility is not just a woman’s problem; it affects men too), they may be able to relate to having a life event rock their world. Hopefully your boss or male colleague will be able to draw on personal experience—as well as his professional training as a manager—to respond to you with warmth and compassion.
Be the change.

Think of this as an important opportunity to interrupt the trend of leaving men out of the conversations about reproductive health. These are medical situations that guys should be aware of, and ultimately the lives of women will not change until men are fully informed and invested. We must have these conversations if we wish for greater understanding and connection with each other.

title.en-US: How to tell your boss you’re overwhelmed at work during IVF

content.value: Here’s help from Maven Career + Executive Coach Hana Ayoub

You are not alone. One of the most common themes I hear in my coaching practice is that professionals feel like they are carrying the load of two or more jobs these days. Between a more-than-full workload and maintaining other priorities outside of the office—especially in dealing with a critical health issue like infertility—it can feel like too much at times. It’s hard to find the time or energy to navigate next steps in our career when we are so busy keeping our heads above water, but here are a few tips that might help.
Seek guidance.
Run your situation by a trusted peer or a mentor within your company. Chances are they’ve felt overwhelmed at times and can offer personal and organizational insight that can help.
Take inventory of your workload.

Before speaking to your boss, carefully analyze everything that’s on your plate. Make sure there isn’t low-hanging fruit that can be eliminated or easily delegated. It’s critical to confirm that the problem is indeed too much work, and not inefficiency. Evaluate and prioritize all of your responsibilities. This will show your boss that you’ve prepared for the conversation in a thoughtful and strategic manner.
Be solution-oriented.

Note the difference between telling your boss you have too much work, period, and telling your boss you have too much work, and.... The next part of the conversation is essential. Bring a few suggestions for how you’d like to realistically address the issue so that you don’t stop with the problem but offer a solution. This doesn’t mean you have to have it all figured out—it only means you can show your boss you’re being thoughtful about the matter. Consider practical resources that exist within the company, such as suggesting a new timeline for lower-priority projects and optimizing processes, as well as potentially outsourcing some work to a contractor or hiring a temporary employee.
Ask open-ended questions.

A conversation like this can easily veer toward very specific details—who does what, how, and by when. While that’s critical in bringing you some relief, take a moment to slow the conversation down. Ask your boss a simple open-ended question to get her perspective on the situation at large. A prompt like, “How do you see my workload?” is a benign invitation to get a sense of her perspective. Ideally, this two-way communication will help manage expectations for both of you, and get you aligned in your shared goal: to keep the business operating smoothly.
Bottom line
: I always encourage people to have this talk, because the worst case scenario is that you’ll learn that your boss isn’t all that supportive—frankly, that too is helpful information for you to know.

title.en-US: One woman shares what she did after 3 failed IVF rounds

content.value: Maven Real Talk on IVF with Amy
63 years old
Health Education
California
Why did you decide to start IVF?
I had already tried artificial insemination, and IVF was the next step. I was 35 years old at the time.
Did doctors diagnose the exact reason you couldn’t become pregnant?
No, I had unexplained infertility.
Had you ever been pregnant before, at the time you started IVF?
No.
How many times have you done IVF?
How did you choose your clinic?
It was recommended by my OB/GYN.
What surprised you most about the procedure?
The cost, and the lack of preciseness—specifically with regards to gauging how much of the fertility drugs to use and how many days I would have to take them in order to stimulate the ovaries.
What could have made your patient experience better?
Having a facility closer to my home. I spent a lot of time on the road commuting to daily appointments and then driving back to work.
What was the most difficult part of your IVF experience?
Having it fail each time, and not having the emotional or the financial resources to repeat it again.
Any tips for managing the emotional stress of IVF?
Build a strong support network and find a good therapist.
Did your insurance cover IVF? If not, how much did it cost each time you did it?
No, it did not. It cost about $15,000 each time.
Do you have any plans to do IVF again?
No.
If your best friend was about to go through IVF, what would you want her to know?

I’d want her to know that I’d be there for her, drive her to the doctor, give her shots if she couldn't self-administer them. I’d be there when the call came in with the results of the pregnancy test—positive or negative—to help her celebrate or help her grieve. This is a hard process to go through alone, and it helps to have someone by your side.
What did you do when IVF wasn’t successful after the third time?
We pursued (and succeeded in) adopting a child!

title.en-US: Let’s get to the bottom of the sex-after-IVF debate

content.value: Should you, shouldn’t you? That’s the million-dollar fertility question.

Abstaining from sex after an embryo transfer is the popular opinion. Some clinics advise not having sex for a full two weeks after the transfer, until a pregnancy can be confirmed. Others give sex the green light after 2 to 4 days. The theory is that intercourse—and orgasms specifically—may affect implantation by causing contractions.

That said, there’s been some conflicting research, leading some experts to disagree with this recommendation. One older study out of Australia actually found that couples who had intercourse in the days just after IVF had higher pregnancy rates, possibly because exposure to semen around the time of embryo transfer positively affects the environment for implantation.

Making decisions when the medical community is still debating matters can be frustrating and tricky for patients. Until experts get on the same page, you’ll probably want to play it safe and follow the advice of your own reproductive endocrinologist—who is hopefully someone you trust. But feel free to initiate a dialogue with your provider and ask why she thinks that’s the best approach for you. Many doctors and patients simply don't feel comfortable discussing sex during treatment, so open discussions don’t happen as often as they should.

title.en-US: 1 woman talks honestly about 6 years of IVF

content.value: Maven Real Talk on IVF with Margaret
53 years old
Teacher
Long Island
Why did you decide to start IVF? And how old were you when you went through your first cycle?

The first fertility specialist I went to told me I’d never be able to conceive, and that I should adopt. I wanted to explore all my options to have a biological child before adopting. I sought out a second opinion, and that specialist said I might be a good candidate for IVF. I was 28 years old when I went through my first cycle.
Did doctors diagnose the exact reason you couldn’t become pregnant?
The second fertility doctor diagnosed me with POD (polycystic ovarian disease).
How many times IVF cycles have you done, and how long did it take to get pregnant?

I went through 7 IVF cycles in total. The first time I did IVF, I got pregnant with my son during the 4th cycle (the process took about 3.5 years). The next time around, I got pregnant with my daughter during 3 cycles (about 3 more years).
How did you choose your clinic?
My gynecologist recommended it. I interviewed the staff before deciding, and found them to be compassionate, supportive, and optimistic.
What surprised you most about the procedure?

Our biggest shock occurred during the very first IVF cycle. They discovered that even when my eggs were put in direct contact with the sperm, in the Petri dish, my eggs were impermeable. At the time, a new procedure called “microinsemination” was starting to be used. It involved cutting a tiny slit into each egg, so that the sperm could penetrate easily and increase the likelihood of fertilization. And it worked!
What could have made your patient experience better?

I wished that I lived geographically closer to the facility that I had to report to for daily blood tests and ultrasounds. I’d have to wake up at 3 or 4am in order to get to my appointments before showing up to my teaching job. This routine made me very fatigued.
What was the most difficult part of your IVF experience?

The most difficult part was remaining patient when we wanted a baby so desperately. We’d have to wait weeks, and sometimes months, in between each cycle for my body to be ready for another chance. Watching family members and friends around me easily get pregnant was frustrating.
Any tips for managing the emotional stress of IVF?

I knew women who completely shut down through an infertility experience. They'd quit their jobs. They avoided gatherings like baby showers and baptisms. They never wanted to talk about their pain. My advice would be to stay busy, and not let your infertility define who you are as a woman. Surround yourself with babies and children to remind you of your dream, so as not to give up. Communicate your feelings to gather strength and support from others. Stay optimistic in the face of defeat.
Any tips for managing the stress that IVF can put on a relationship?

The IVF process actually brought my husband and me closer. At first, he felt helpless. But I couldn’t do it on my own, and this gave him an opportunity to get involved. He administered the numerous shots required for me to produce several eggs per cycle. He loved how needed he was. He accompanied me to every ultrasound where they monitored the development of follicles and determined when my eggs were ready for retrieval. He was also there for every transfer. I never felt alone during the disappointments. Every step of our journey was taken together, and it made our successes even sweeter.
Did your insurance cover IVF?
Yes, we were fortunate enough to have all of our IVF cycles covered by our insurance.
Do you have any plans to do IVF again?
No.
If your best friend was about to go through IVF, what would you want her to know?

First, I would encourage her to really educate herself. Then, I’d want her to know that there’s nothing “wrong” with her body—it’s just that she needs to get pregnant in an untraditional way. There’s so much technology to help her!
Is there anything about your IVF experience you wish we had asked, and what would your response be?

I wish that you had asked me, “At what point did you know that choosing IVF was the right decision for you?” My answer would be, “When my husband and I first saw my son’s tiny, precious heart beating on the ultrasound screen!”

title.en-US: Is it true that babies born via IVF have more health issues?

content.value: We answer a Maven user’s question. Read on for the reassuring answer.

You probably have very little to worry about. But your nervousness is understandable, given some of the alarming studies that have popped up in the news over the years. For instance, a meta-analysis found that birth defects are more common in IVF pregnancies, with 1.4 times the risk seen in naturally conceived pregnancies, says OB-GYN Jackie Stone, M.D. Older research published in 2013 followed 4,795 babies born via IVF and 46,025 infants who were conceived naturally and found that birth defects were higher for infants born after IVF: 9% versus 6.6%.

More recently, one small 2018 study out of Switzerland looking at the health of 54 teenagers conceived through assisted reproductive technologies versus 43 of their peers who had been conceived naturally and found that the IVF teens were more likely to have high blood pressure.

Despite these and other studies (again: all of which are inconclusive) observing that IVF babies could be at a slightly higher risk for health conditions later in life, people who are conceived through IVF are generally healthy. As one researcher told The Guardian: “By and large these children are just fine, it’s not like they have extra arms or extra heads, but they have a small risk of undesirable outcomes.”

And here’s the thing: What’s not clear from the studies is whether any potential problems among IVF babies are related to the IVF procedure or a product of infertility itself. Factors which lead to infertility in the first place–such as being older, having pre-existing health conditions, or exhibiting certain lifestyle habits—could also be responsible for some of the differences we’ve seen so far.

Keep in mind, too, that as the technology keeps evolving, we may see that health outcomes become even less of a concern. For instance, there was a time when doctors routinely transferred multiple embryos at once in the hopes of increasing a woman’s odds of getting pregnant. This practice led to a significant increase of twin- and triplet-pregnancies—which are associated with adverse health outcomes for both the mom and the child. But improvements in the IVF process have made it more possible to transfer only one embryo without compromising a woman’s chance of success.
The bottom line: In general, babies born via IVF grow into healthy adults. But definitely have an open conversation with your doctor to ask specific questions and get the reassurance you need.

title.en-US: How to mentally prepare for your second IVF cycle

content.value: Tips to get your head—and heart—back into the fertility treatment game when you’ve just been through a major disappointment.

“It was a walk in the park,” says no one ever about an IVF cycle. And while you probably knew that going into treatment, it’s hard not to feel crushed when, after weeks of injections and procedures and anticipation, the pregnancy test comes back negative. We get it—staring down at a second cycle can feel like you’re going into battle against something formidable. But the truth is, you can prop yourself up and and approach the second (or third, fourth, etc.) round with the same resilience that got you through the first. Here are 6 tips that might help.
Remember that IVF is a process.

That means there are multiple steps to it, and, yes in most cases, multiple cycles. Take, for instance, women between 35-37 who are starting IVF. Around 30-33% have a baby as a result of their first cycle—but that number increases after more rounds. Understanding these odds is important so you don’t become too discouraged after one failed attempt.
On your rest month, really rest.

There are exceptions depending on your individual situation, but typically your doctor will suggest taking a break from IVF for at least a month. Use this time to restore your body and mind as much as possible. Bond with people who you can be yourself around, and make time each week for activities that calm you as well as bring you some joy. This could mean attending a meditation class, painting, baking, or watching your favorite rom-coms.
Relish what you’ve learned from the first cycle.

From a practical standpoint, the second time is easier. By now you know the drill and you can inject yourself like a boss. Be proud of yourself; you’re literally taking a difficult matter into your own hands with every prick. And if you know friends who will be starting their first cycle, share any helpful strategies you’ve picked up from the experience. Not only will your friend be grateful, you’ll feel good about paying the knowledge forward, too.
Go ahead and skip your friend’s baby shower (or anything else you don’t have the energy for).

It’s natural to feel especially low after a failed cycle. And anyone who is a good friend will understand that party games like “Guess that baby food” or oohing and aah-ing over cute onesies may be too triggering for you right now. PS: If you’ve been invited to something by a pal who hasn’t been privy to your struggles and you want to decline, you can simply say you have family matters to tend to and leave it at that.
Plan to take some time off during your next cycle.

As you know from that first cycle, the schedule gets hectic, especially if you work. Figure out the windows that were especially challenging and consider using some of your paid time off to tend to your self-care, whether it’s a post-egg-retrieval mental health day (slash-Netflix-binge-fest) or an inexpensive long-weekend getaway at the end of your two-week wait.
Focus on the things you can control.

No one can control the outcome of each cycle—not your doctor, not your nurse, and not you. What healthcare professionals focus on is what they can do differently the next time—which might include adjusting their protocol recommendations based on what they learned the first time around. And the same applies to you: If you see any opportunities to practice more self-care, take them. This could mean prioritizing a healthy diet that gives you more energy instead of making you feel slugging, or simply focusing your efforts on staying positive and instead of falling too deep into online message boards that instill fear.

title.en-US: “It’s my fault”: Coping with self-blame in infertility

content.value: Here’s how to spot a guilt trip and learn how to ease up on yourself.

It isn’t uncommon for a reproductive endocrinologist and infertility specialist (REI) to hear a patient in her office say something like, “It’s all my fault” or “My struggles must be a punishment for something I’ve done—like waiting too long to have kids.” Not all women utter these thoughts out loud, but they may still be mentally berating themselves for some “misstep” related to their fertility.

If self-blaming is a tendency of yours, it can be really hard to just stop that thinking. But here’s why you might want to get some help to address it: An inclination to go into excessive self-blame is a key factor in depression. In other words, staying stuck in these thought patterns could send your mental health spiraling downward.

Something called “overgeneralization” is another common habit that may make the self-blame issue even worse. This plays out when you take something very specific (i.e. “I can’t get pregnant”) and use it to start making all-encompassing generalizations about yourself (i.e. “I’m a total failure”).

If you’re reading this and thinking, “I totally relate,” it’s important not to beat yourself up. (That won’t help matters!) Try to offer yourself some compassion, and recognize that you are not alone. It’s natural to experience a range of feelings, including less pleasant ones, when going through something as hard as infertility.

And here’s some good news: Seeing your thought patterns is often the first step in changing them. Maybe the next time you catch yourself in a self-blame cycle, or overgeneralizing, you can simply acknowledge the thoughts you’re having. Even better: Break out a journal. Some experts say that simply writing down negative thoughts can help release them. Try it and you may notice that after a short journaling session, you feel less weighed down.

Of course, therapy is often needed to learn to replace destructive thought patterns with new, more productive ones. Maven’s mental health counselors specialize in fertility issues, and can work with you one on one. Reach out to your Maven Care Advocate for help finding the right therapist for you.

title.en-US: If an embryo doesn’t implant, what happens to it inside the body?

content.value: IVF and natural attempts to conceive have at least this in common: There are never any guarantees. In the case of IVF, even the most promising-looking embryos can disappoint once transferred into the uterus. Here are some of the questions Maven members had about what goes down when implantation fails.
If the embryo doesn’t implant, what happens to it?
When embryos are transferred to your uterus, they’re tiny—just a 0.1 millimeter ­bundle of cells. So when they fail to implant, they simply die and disintegrate. (Cells die in the body all the time.)
What if my doctor transfers two embryos and only one implants itself?
The body’s normal clean-up system ushers out the one that didn’t stick—it’s the same process that occurs in a failed single-embryo transfer. Don’t worry—it can’t harm the embryo that does implant.
Why did implantation fail in the first place?

There are a lot of factors that could play a role in an embryo’s ability to implant. Often, the body rejects an embryo if it’s destined to be chromosomally abnormal; the uterus senses something isn’t right and won’t prepare it’s lining for pregnancy. Other times, you can have a genetically normal embryo that still doesn’t burrow because of uterine wall issues. Frustratingly, sometimes the cause may never be determined.
If you have more questions, or need some guidance at this point in your fertility journey,
book an appointment with a Maven provider
. Our practitioners are available to video chat anytime, and can be a source of knowledge and support during a confusing time.

title.en-US: Can Chinese herbs help make fertility treatment successful?

content.value: When you’re having trouble conceiving, it’s understandable that you may be tempted to try anything that may help increase your odds of getting pregnant. And plants have been used medicinally for thousands of years—so they must be safe, right? Here’s what you need to know.

Unfortunately, any claims you’ve heard that combining medicinal herbs with Assisted Reproductive Technologies like IVF can yield higher pregnancy rates are lacking in scientific evidence. Supplements generally aren’t subjected to the same scientific scrutiny as other medications. Until more studies are done, many experts remain skeptical.

But beyond just lacking proof of their effectiveness, they may not be safe. Herbal supplements have limited regulation by the Food and Drug Administration, or FDA. This raises questions about the quality and purity of what you’re getting. But even if the herbs aren’t contaminated, diluted with other ingredients, or falsely labeled, they’re not necessarily without risk. That’s why you should never add them to your treatment protocol without explicit consent from your reproductive endocrinologist, since there’s a chance that they may interact with other medications and hormones you’re prescribed.

title.en-US: When do you transition from your fertility doctor to an OB-GYN?

content.value: After what seems like hundreds of needle pricks and countless anxious days, every woman going through IVF anticipates the day when her doctor says the words, “You’re pregnant!” But you may be wondering what happens next. Read on for answers to some common questions.
When will I transition to an OB?

You’ll “graduate” from your reproductive endocrinology and infertility (REI) doctor's office at around 8 to 10 weeks of pregnancy. At this point, there is a high degree of confidence that a pregnancy is healthy and viable, and your REI will likely refer you to a general OB-GYN. This is the doctor you’ll work with for the remainder of your prenatal care and, of course, the eventual delivery of your baby.
Should you go back to the same OB-GYN you saw before you got pregnant?

Not necessarily. If the care you were receiving wasn’t meeting your needs, it’s certainly valid to consider finding a new provider. (You can also make the switch later on during a pregnancy—for any reason. One example: Your OB-GYN doesn't support your preferences for birth.) If you decide to make the switch, you can have all your medical records transferred so your doctor and/or midwife will know everything there is to know about your history.
What is the transition like when you stop seeing an REI?

It’s different for everyone, but it can be as stressful as it is exciting. On the one hand, it’s an important step to celebrate—a reflection of getting that much closer to your goal of having a child. On the other hand, you may have developed a bond with your fertility care team, especially if you’ve struggled for years to get pregnant. What’s more, you may be used to a certain level of attention. As one Maven member says, “After all the close monitoring during IVF, I felt so out of the loop during my pregnancy. Every little twinge frightened me, and I didn’t have that regular contact anymore that I’d gotten used to with my REI and fertility nurse.”

But remember, whether you’re zero months pregnant or 8 months pregnant, you should never feel like your doctor is out of reach—even if you’re only seeing her once or twice a month. Anytime you have concerns or questions, you can also
reach out to a Maven provider
and video chat or message almost instantly.

title.en-US: The downside of the “as long as it takes” fertility advice

content.value: There are many paths to parenthood, and IVF is just one of them.

You’ve likely heard the stat that only about 30% of fertility patients, on average, end up with a baby after their first IVF cycle—and that if you want to increase your odds of success, you may have to stick with the problem for many, many rounds. In fact, when the press reports on IVF studies, many of the headlines essentially tell women that most people don’t stick with IVF long enough for it to work. They might “throw in the towel prematurely” after three or four cycles, when it could take six, seven, even up to 9, before a baby is in their arms.
Is there truth to those claims?

Yes, the cumulative chance of having a baby does go up with additional cycles. But it’s important to get very specific about your situation, since the odds aren’t the same for everyone. For instance, one large study in 2015 gathered data on 156,947 women in the UK who had undergone IVF and found that women under 40 who were using their own eggs had a 68% chance of having a baby by the end of 6 IVF cycles; after 9 cycles, their cumulative odds of having a baby were 72%. But since age is the biggest factor in success, there were diminishing returns for older women. Those between 40 - 42 had a 33% chance of a live birth after 9 IVF cycles, and women older than 43 had a 16% chance of a live birth after 9 cycles.

While age is the biggest factor, there are other variables that modify IVF success rates, too—such as ovarian reserve, response to stimulation (number of eggs that are able to be retrieved), quality of eggs/embryos, and the cause of infertility, says Maven OB-GYN, Jackie Stone, M.D.
So is the message that women should stick with IVF for “as long as it takes” really helpful?

It’s true that you need to have a fair amount of hope, optimism, and—yes—perseverance when pursuing IVF. And data like this is an important reminder that your “stick-with-it-ness” may pay off if the first few cycles don’t take.

But it’s equally important to go into treatment with your eyes wide open about the potential for IVF not to work—and not feel guilty at all if the time comes for you to pursue other options. The physical, financial, and emotional toll of IVF is significant, and it’s up to every woman to decide how much of her body, money, and soul she wants to invest before trying something else. There are many roads to parenthood including IVF, IVF with donor eggs, surrogacy, and adoption. Deciding when to get off one path and onto onto another is hard, but if it’s ultimately the right decision for you, trust yourself if you should ever need to make the leap.

title.en-US: How celebrities in their 40/50s *actually* have IVF success

content.value: Nope, celebs aren’t reproductive unicorns. So here’s what’s going on.

The right to privacy when it comes to how people expand their families is a choice everyone—including those in the public spotlight—should have. But there is one fallout of the tendency for celebs to stay mum about their fertility: A lot of women see older celebrities having babies later in life, and think getting pregnant with IVF will be easier than it is. The truth: IVF is an amazing technology, but it cannot ultimately sidestep the reality of reproductive aging.

It is a biological fact that female fertility declines with age–in assisted reproductive technology as in natural conception. The Centers for Disease Control reported in 2015 that for women 35 and under using IVF, the live birth rate was about 40%. For a 40-year-old women, it was about 14%—and that number continues to decline with each passing year.

So what’s likely going on here? Celebrities might not talk about it openly, but donor-egg IVF is probably used a lot more in Hollywood than most people believe. That’s when an embryo is produced from the egg of a younger donor before it’s implanted into the uterus of the mom carrying the child. This can be a wonderful option, but when you don’t hear about it, you may not be as prepared to let go of the idea of having a child with your own DNA.
Bottom line: When it comes to fertility, celebrities really are just like the rest of us.

title.en-US: These questions can keep you sane during infertility

content.value: Just because sadness and anxiety are common among people struggling to get pregnant doesn't mean you should ignore the signs that something is off.

People often talk about the toll that infertility treatment takes on the body. But for some, the mental angst is even harder to deal with. In fact, one study from Harvard Medical School found that women with infertility felt as anxious or depressed as patients with cancer or heart disease. 
While everyone reacts differently to challenging life situations, it’s important to recognize when you need some extra support. First and foremost, trust your instincts: You don’t have to be in a full-blown depression or exhibit the signs of generalized anxiety disorder to tend to your mental health. Here are some questions to help you keep tabs on your emotions; if you’re nodding your head or answering yes to any of these, let your doctor know or book an appointment with a Maven provider.
Do you feel isolated a lot of the time?

One survey found that 60% of infertility patients hide the struggle to get pregnant from friends and family. Whether you’re cutting yourself from your network or you feel alone even when you are surrounded by friends, it’s important to know that a chronic sense of loneliness can be linked to depression.
Are you constantly wracked with guilt or feelings of worthlessness?

Infertility is a condition that can happen to anyone, but it’s not uncommon for women to feel guilty or blame themselves. Guilt often manifests as anxious thoughts. For instance, “I’m the cause of this and my partner will leave me.” Therapy can help you reframe these thoughts and deal with deep-rooted feelings of guilt.
Have you lost all interest in your usual activities?

Thinking a lot about having a baby, or feeling sad about not being pregnant yet are normal. But be on the lookout for infertility interfering with your desire to think about or do anything else. People who are depressed often show a sudden lack of interest in other things, especially activities that once brought them pleasure.
Do you have a hard time tackling everyday tasks?

Sometimes the problem isn’t that you don’t have a desire to do things, it’s that you feel you “just can’t.” When you’re in the throes of depression, it can be hard enough to tend to even the most basic acts of self-care, like showering or eating.
Has your weight or eating patterns changed dramatically in a negative way?

Weight changes during fertility treatment aren’t always a sign of mental distress; sometimes the medications you’re taking or an altered exercise regimen may lead to fluctuations on the scale. But take note if your eating habits have done a drastic 180. Loss of appetite is a common depression symptom for some, while feelings of anxiety or worthlessness can make others overeat.
Do you have a hard time sleeping, or do you sleep too much?

With all the uncertainty involved in fertility treatment, it’s normal to lie awake some nights, ruminating about what might happen (or what went wrong in the last cycle). However, if you find that your sleep is disrupted on a regular basis, it could be a sign that something more serious is going on. (For people affected by depression, restless nights and insomnia can go hand-in-hand.) Similarly, it’s a good idea to watch out for a tendency to want to sleep more than usual. Maintaining a healthy amount of sleep is important to keeping you healthy overall and optimizing your chances of getting pregnant. If you’re not sleeping in such a way that lets you feel refreshed in the morning, talk to your doctor.
Are you abusing drugs and alcohol?
Obviously, this is dangerous for you and it dramatically affects the chances of conceiving. Talk to your healthcare provider immediately to get help.
Do you have thoughts of dying?

Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, M.D., has heard patients voice beliefs such as, “I think my significant other/family/friends would just be better off without me." Even if you don't recognize any other symptoms of depression in yourself, thoughts of suicide or just generally contemplating death are indicators that it's time to reach out for help. Contact your health professional or call the National Suicide Prevention Helpline: (800)273-TALK. And remember, the people who love you want to help. Sometimes opening up to someone can help you see the reasons for living—even when you’re living with a lot of challenges—that have been there all along.

title.en-US: I’ve heard of “coasting” in IVF—what does this mean?

content.value: Read on to decode the lingo.

Coasting is a technique used to lessen the risk of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) in some women doing IVF. A small percentage of patients going through IVF get severe OHSS, and when this occurs, serious complications can arise that usually require hospitalization. These include severe abdominal pain, persistent nausea and vomiting, blood clots, and shortness of breath.

If your doctor anticipates that you have high odds of developing severe OHSS, the “coasting” method may be used to lower your risk without seriously decreasing your chances of successful pregnancy. Essentially, “coasting” means that your fertility specialist would lower the dosages of ovulation induction medications or stop giving you stimulation medication altogether for a period of time. Your doctor may also delay the HCG trigger shot until your estrogen levels decrease to a safer level, says Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, M.D.

title.en-US: How to deal with acne caused by fertility treatments

content.value: Fact: Your skin is the last thing you need to stress about right now.

Your ovaries may not be the only thing that’s feeling out of sorts during an IVF cycle. Your complexion may start acting out, too. Some women going through treatment find that their usually clear skin suddenly gives way to the kind of acne they haven’t seen since high school. Here’s the situation:
You’re using hormone treatments that can cause acne.

For instance, Follistim, an injectable drug that helps stimulate the ovaries to produce more eggs, includes acne as a possible side effect. The same is true for drugs called GnRH agonists (aka Gonadotropin releasing hormone agonists), which may be prescribed to suppress ovulation so that your doctor can control ovarian stimulation and maturation for optimal outcomes in IVF. Since they mess with your hormones, these can also be acne culprits in some women.
You stopped birth control.

Some contraceptives not only prevent pregnancy, they also put the brakes on acne. So, naturally, once you stop using birth control in order to get pregnant (whether you’re doing IVF or not), blemishes may start surfacing again.
You’re stressed out.

Stress hormones can exacerbate inflammation and promote sebum production—not great for a clear complexion. And IVF can be a major stress trigger, which may explain why you’ve gone from getting little blemishes you barely noticed to significant breakouts.
How To Treat Acne When You’re on IVF

When you are trying to conceive or are already pregnant, always check with your doctor before taking any medication, including acne fighters. You obviously want to steer clear of anything that would be toxic to your potential fetus, but you also want to avoid any drug interactions with the hormone treatments you’re currently taken.

If you’ve noticed that certain hormone treatments are causing bothersome flare-ups in a past cycle, ask your reproductive endocrinologist about whether it’s possible to make substitutions in your next cycle without compromising the results of the protocol.

As for adding acne medications to your list of prescriptions during this time, this may be a trickier proposition. The truth is, many have not been tested on pregnant women, much less on women undergoing IVF. So we can’t know for sure if they’re safe. The American Academy of Dermatologists (AAD) advises women to talk to their fertility doctor and dermatologist about medication with salicylic acid, glycolic acid, azelaic acid, and even benzoyl peroxide—they may be OK in small amounts, but some doctors suggest avoiding them altogether. Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, M.D., suggests avoiding retinoid compounds (Retin-A)—even in OTC products that treat acne: “These compounds aren’t recommended for use during pregnancy as there have not been sufficient studies in expectant women.”

As for the oral antibiotics that are used to treat acne, these are usually considered safe, but it’s worth telling your dermatologist that you’re trying to get pregnant. (A few women using these medications have given birth to babies with defects, but there’s no evidence that the association was caused by the antibiotics.) Besides medications, a few lifestyle adjustments may help diffuse the breakouts, while keeping your body safe for baby-making. If you’re prone to acne, try these tactics:
Avoid high-glycemic foods (such as processed foods high in starch and sugar). These food cause spikes in your body's insulin levels that exacerbate inflammation, a factor in breakouts.

Don’t cheat yourself of sleep. Seven to eight hours of sleep can minimize the levels of stress hormones coursing through your system, which means less of those pesky compounds around to wreak havoc on your complexion.

Ask your doctor about fish oil supplements, which can be found in some prenatal vitamins. Fish oil contains omega-3-fatty acids which may not only be helpful to your potential new baby, they may also reduce the inflammation that leads to acne.

title.en-US: “I got pregnant with IVF. Then we had a baby naturally”

content.value: Maven Real Talk On IVF With Leila
40 years old
Entrepreneur
Brooklyn
Why did you decide to start IVF? And how old were you?

For two and a half years, my partner and I tried to have a baby but weren’t having any luck. First we tried naturally, and then with the help of intrauterine insemination (IUI). When that wasn’t successful, we started IVF. I was 32 years old.
What was the cause of your infertility?

After all the diagnostic tests to determine the cause, my doctors told me I had unexplained infertility. That said, there was some suspicion that there were "killer cells" in my body getting in the way of pregnancy success. We tried to treat that with steroids.
How many times have you done IVF?
One.
How did you choose your clinic?
We did our homework and found out it was reputed to be the best—meaning the clinic with the highest success rate—in London, which is where we lived at the time.
What could have made your patient experience better?
It would have been valuable to have some kind of support group and connection with others during this time.
What was the most difficult part of your IVF experience?
The time commitment. I was surprised by how much is involved in this process.
Any tips for managing the emotional stress of IVF?
To be honest, I didn't feel all that stressed; I just focused on the end goal and that helped me. I strongly believed IVF would work and kept my thoughts positive.
Any tips for managing the stress that IVF can put on a relationship?
Approach it like you would take on any other project—moving, planning a trip or a wedding, etc. Focus on the logistics at hand, not the emotions or fears.
Did your insurance cover IVF?
No.
If IVF was successful, how quickly did you get pregnant?
We got pregnant on the first try.
Do you have any plans to do IVF again?
No. Following my pregnancy via IVF, we had another child naturally!
If your best friend was about to go through IVF, what would you want her to know?
It's worth it. Be focused. Be positive. Don't dwell on the potential failures. Feel confident in the doctor/clinic you choose. Ask questions, but not so many that you drive yourself crazy!

title.en-US: I've heard that IVF can lead to a high-risk pregnancy. Why?

content.value: Get the answer from Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, M.D.

It’s true that there are certain pregnancy risks associated with IVF, but that doesn’t mean you can’t still have a perfectly healthy baby. Some things to be aware of include an increased risk of birth defects (1.4 times the rate in naturally conceived pregnancies); a higher rate of preterm birth (IVF “singletons” are about twice as likely to be premature as singletons conceived naturally); and an increased risk of low birth weight. There’s also a link between IVF and an increased rate of pregnancy complications including preeclampsia.

It's important for people to be informed about any possible risks of treatment, but—understandably—hearing things like “twofold risk” can be very alarming for any woman or couple doing IVF. Keep in mind that the starting risk for many of these individual problems is is relatively low. And with the right care from a fertility provider and an OB-GYN, you’ll receive the screenings and support you need every step of the way to keep you and your baby healthy.

If your pregnancy is high-risk, here’s what you might expect for your prenatal journey: At some point in the first trimester, when your infertility doctor feels comfortable, she will transfer your care to a general obstetrician, who will be qualified to handle your pregnancy resulting from infertility treatments. Your general obstetrician can take care of your pregnancy and deliver your baby. However, she will likely refer you to a perinatologist or maternal fetal medicine specialist in the second trimester for your anatomy ultrasound. You will get a specialized (Level 2) ultrasound to make sure that your baby does not have any birth defects. You should also get a fetal echocardiogram (special ultrasound of the baby’s heart) to make sure that there are no heart defects. This is usually performed around 24 weeks of pregnancy. Your doctor may also perform monthly ultrasounds in the third trimester to check the baby’s growth and carefully monitor you for preterm labor and high blood pressure.
Your treatment plan isn’t a punishment—just a way to keep you and your baby healthy.

title.en-US: Is there a higher chance of miscarriage for IVF pregnancies?

content.value: The facts that will hopefully ease your mind about fertility treatment and pregnancy loss.
Women undergoing IVF have a lot to worry about—and one Maven user doing it wondered if the method of conception plays a role in pregnancy loss.

Overall, there appears to be a slightly higher risk of miscarriage in IVF pregnancies—in the ballpark of 2 to 5%—than in pregnancies that occur naturally. The exact figures will vary depending on which research study you’re looking at, and more importantly, the rates of miscarriage will look a lot different if you don’t lump all women together.

That’s because the reason for any elevated risk of miscarriage seems to have very little to do with the IVF procedure itself. Instead, it’s likely due to the underlying reasons that a woman needed fertility treatment in the first place. For example, we know that the risk of miscarriage increases with maternal age—and women who undergo IVF, on the whole, tend to be older than those who conceive naturally. Likewise, if you had an underlying health condition that led you to IVF, that could also play a role in your risk for miscarriage.

So while you can probably stop worrying about fertility treatment raising your risk of pregnancy loss, be sure to have an open line of communication with your doctor about this and any other concerns you may have. It’s always important to know your personal risk factors, and what might be done to increase your odds of a successful pregnancy.

title.en-US: What's the deal with GIFT and ZIFT treatments for infertility?

content.value: IUI and IVF are the fertility treatments that get the most air-time and women know the most about. But they aren’t the only ones. Here are two technologies that may be an alternative for those who haven’t success with other options.
Gamete intrafallopian transfer (GIFT

) involves collecting multiple eggs from a woman’s ovaries, placing them into catheter along with a guy’s sperm and immediately inserting them into a fallopian tube via a laparoscopy procedure. The goal is for one of the eggs to become fertilized inside the fallopian tube, then implant in the uterus and develop into a fetus.
Zygote intrafallopian transfer (ZIFT)

also involves retrieving a woman’s eggs, which are then mixed with sperm in a lab. Next, the newly fertilized egg (which is called a zygote at this stage) is laparoscopically returned to the fallopian tubes. Transfer of the zygote is typically done about 24 hours after egg retrieval, to allow time for fertilization to first take place in the lab.
How are these procedures different from IVF?

With IVF, a doctor places an embryo (one that’s been allowed to grow in a lab for 3 to 5 days) directly into a woman’s uterus. With GIFT and ZIFT, the gametes (eggs and sperm) and zygotes are placed into the fallopian tubes. And GIFT is also different in that fertilization takes place in the body rather—not a petri dish.
Who's typically treated with GIFT or ZIFT?

The main candidates for these fertility treatments are women with a least one working fallopian tube who haven't had success with traditional IVF; some patients who’ve experience implantation failure in IVF (a.k.a. the embryos don’t “stick”) have been able to conceive with GIFT or ZIFT. GIFT may also be an option for infertile couples with religious objections to IVF on the basis that fertilization occurs in an “unnatural” environment (a.k.a. a lab).
Are there any downsides?

Transferring zygotes to the fallopian tubes requires invasive surgery, unlike IVF—which is why some clinics don’t even offer it these days. (It’s also more expensive than GIFT or IVF). And one of the downsides with GIFT is that the doctor can’t confirm that fertilization will, in fact, take place before placing them into a woman’s body. And both GIFT and ZIFT come with a higher risk of twins and other multiples.
Have more questions about these alternative fertility treatments? Talk to your doctor or
book an appointment
with a Maven provider.

title.en-US: Why do men handle infertility differently than women?

content.value: It's clear that infertility affects women on an emotional level, but you rarely hear about the impact that it has on men. Keep reading for important insights.
Their self-esteem may take a hit.

A lot has been said about women feeling “broken” or “defective” when diagnosed with infertility, but it turns out that male counterparts can relate. Asked to describe their emotional reactions to being diagnosed with infertility, some men highlight their feelings of inadequacy. As one guy put it: “It’s part of our biological functioning to make babies, so I felt worthless when I was told my sperm issues meant I couldn’t have kids.” Other men shared a similar sentiment, with comments like: “I thought less of myself as a man” and “I felt like something was wrong with me.”
They may handle stress differently.

If you’re having a hard time focusing on work (or any area of your life other than your fertility) and your partner seems to be going about his life with ease, you may be wondering if he’s affected by this ordeal at all. The truth: Probably, yes! It just might be that he has a different way of coping in times of distress. Sometimes men compartmentalize their feelings in an effort to get away from what’s bothering them.
They may have a harder time opening up.

While both sexes often have a reluctance to talk about infertility, men may be even more inclined to keep their struggles bottled up. Sometimes they want to “keep it together” for their partner. Other times, they’re embarrassed to share because they feel infertility is somehow a reflection on their masculinity. Whatever the reason, men’s silence can have harmful effects: One study of men found that a lack of openness about fertility issues was associated with a higher risk for depressive symptoms. And it’s worth mentioning: Until men get more comfortable opening up, infertility will continue to be seen primarily as a “woman’s problem.”

title.en-US: The link between adenomyosis and infertility

content.value: You may have heard Gabrielle Union share about her adenomyosis diagnosis, and the many miscarriages she experienced as she tried to grow her family. So what’s the link? Keep reading for the 411.

Celebrity moms (like the rest of us) are entitled to keep their medical and reproductive issues private. But stars who have chosen to come forward about their experiences play a big role in helping to destigmatize infertility and shed light on some lesser-known aspects of the journey. That was the case when Gabrielle Union revealed in 2018 that she had a condition called adenomyosis—a close cousin of endometriosis that you rarely ever hear about—which she says contributed to her trouble getting pregnant. The actress had multiple cycles of IVF and miscarriages until she finally welcomed a baby girl to her family, with the help of a surrogate (gestational carrier). Here’s what you should know about the condition.
What Is adenomyosis?

To understand adenomyosis, it helps to understand the anatomy of the uterus: It consists of the lining, called the endometrium, and a muscular region called the myometrium. A thin wall separates the two. But when you have adenomyosis, the endometrial tissue infiltrates the muscle of the uterus, which can result in heavy/painful periods and an enlarged uterus. As you might expect, adenomyosis can affect the chances of the embryo implanting and sticking to the uterine lining. In fact, a September 2017 Fertility & Sterility paper reported that the rate of implantation and live birth are much lower than in women without the condition.
How is it different from endometriosis?

Women with endometriosis have endometrial tissue that grows outside of the uterus, on other pelvic organs, such as the ovaries or fallopian tubes. With adenomyosis, the displaced endometrial tissue remains in the uterus—growing deep into the muscular wall. This fact actually makes adenomyosis harder to detect, so doctors sometimes miss it.
How is adenomyosis treated?

That depends on how severe the condition is. Medications to alleviate the pain are often necessary. Some women have hysterectomies to remove the womb, and eliminate the problem altogether, but obviously this isn’t a good option for anyone trying to conceive. “The Mirena IUD can also be helpful for symptoms while preserving the uterus, but this obviously prevents conception,” says Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, M.D. So as part of your fertility treatment, a doctor may prescribe hormonal contraception for several months to help get overgrowth of the endometrium under control, leading to less endometrial tissue extending into the myometrium. This could potentially make it easier to get pregnant after you stop the birth control. Other treatments involve taking a medication called GnRH agonist, short for gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonist, before an IVF cycle, or having surgery to remove the abnormal tissue without removing the uterus. If you’re open to the option that Gabrielle Union chose, an embryo can be created via IVF using your eggs and sperm of your partner (or a donor), and then transferred to a gestational surrogate.
Figuring out the path to parenthood that’s right for you can be difficult whether or not you have hard-to-treat medical conditions. An array of Maven providers—including
reproductive endocrinologists
OB-GYNs
counselors, and relationship therapists
—are available anytime you’d like some support during this journey.

title.en-US: Do guys with smaller penises have fertility problems?

content.value: What you need to know about that study linking penis size to baby-making issues.
In October 2018, preliminary research from the University of Utah found an association between a shorter penis size and fertility problems in men.

The study looked at data from 815 men—including 219 guys seeking help for infertility—and discovered that guys with fertility issues had penises that were roughly .4 inches shorter than men without reproductive problems. Infertile men had organs around 4.92 inches in length when erect, while those without reproductive issues measured in about 5.3 inches.

This isn’t the first study to suggest that length matters when it comes to fertility, says Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, M.D. She notes that an earlier study found that a measurement known as anogenital distance, or AGD, was also linked to fertility issues. AGD measures the distance from the anus to the underside of the scrotum, and men whose AGD was shorter than the average—around 2 inches—were found to have higher rates of subfertility, including semen volume and sperm count.

Still, there’s no reason to jump to conclusions—a shorter penis doesn’t necessarily mean your partner is infertile. Studies like this that show a link don’t prove that a smaller-than-average penis size cause infertility, and a lot more research is needed to shed light on what the connection really is.

The good news is more attention is being paid to men’s role in infertility, with more people starting to recognize that it isn’t just a woman’s problem. In the past, when a couple had trouble conceiving, the woman was likely to be put through a full battery of fertility tests before her male partner was checked out. But since the cause of infertility can result from a female factor or a male factor, evaluating both possibilities at the same time is important.

title.en-US: Should I take COQ10 supplements to help me get pregnant?

content.value: Find out if there’s any truth behind the rumors.
What is CoQ10 anyway?

CoQ10 is an antioxidant found naturally in every living cell of the body, but especially in the heart, kidney, liver and pancreas. It helps generate energy in our cells while tempering the aging effects of free radicals, but it does decline in our bodies as we get older. There’s some evidence that CoQ10 supplements might be beneficial for treating conditions such as congestive heart failure, migraines, and Parkinson's disease. And some researchers have wondered whether the supplement could also have benefits for reproductive health—specifically in improving egg quality.
Will it improve the chances of IVF success?
File this one under “inconclusive” for now. Earlier this year, in a Chinese
study

, 76 women under 35 with reduced ovarian reserves took CoQ10 for 60 days before undergoing IVF. Compared to the control group, the CoQ10 group (who received a dose of 200 mg three times a day) produced more eggs with fewer hormone injections, experienced fewer cancellations, and had better quality embryos. However, when it came to live births—where it really counts—there wasn’t a statistically significant difference in outcomes. An earlier Canadian
study
was also unable to reach a statistically significant difference as far as live births were concerned. So while the supplement has some enthusiasts championing for it, the evidence just isn’t there.
But taking it can’t hurt, right?

Many clinics don’t recommend it, but some women take it anyway, given that it’s water-soluble and any excess is excreted out. In addition, no serious adverse effects have been associated with using it—at least not yet. Still, that doesn’t mean you’re in the clear. CoQ10 is a supplement, and as such, it’s not regulated by the Food and Drug Administration with the rigor that a prescription drug would be. As with any form of medication or supplementation, it’s important to discuss it with your doctor if you’re considering using it. “So many patients don't mentions supplements when we ask them about medications, and this is risky because supplements can cause drug interactions,” says Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, M.D.

Your best bet may be to try to boost your CoQ10 by relying on dietary sources such as such as meat, fish, peanuts and pistachios. The amount of CoQ10 in food may not boost your levels like a pill can, but at least you’ll be on the safe side.

title.en-US: Plastics and fertility treatment: What you need to know

content.value: The truth about whether you need to be careful with BPA.

There has been an ongoing debate about whether exposure to BPA (Bisphenol A) poses a health risk. The compound is found in many plastics, but also in other products you may interact with every day, including the linings of food cans and even cash register receipts. Regulatory agencies—including the Food and Drug Administration—have stated that BPA is safe for humans at the levels people are exposed to. But plenty of medical experts disagree, saying that overexposure to such toxins could act as an endocrine disruptor, and potentially disrupt conception and implantation of a fertilized egg in the womb. Animals exposed to BPA develop abnormal reproductive systems, and many experts worry that these detrimental effects can also impact humans. Jackie Stone, M.D., a Maven OB-GYN, also points to a 2017 meta-analysis where “the study authors looked at data from 35 studies and said that ‘BPA has a direct negative impact on maternal, fetal, and neonatal outcomes, including birth weight, rates of preterm birth, developmental defects, and recurrent miscarriage.’”

While this is an areas that needs more research before everyone can agree, it’s a good idea to play things safe in the meantime and try to limit your exposure whenever possible. The good news is that it’s easier to stay away from BPA today than it was years ago; some manufacturers trying to get away from the bad rap of BPA have scrambled to remove the compound from their products. But BPA definitely still exists; plastics with the recycling code “7” often contain BPA, so steer clear, says Stone. Some other ways to cut down on your chemical exposure include ditching canned foods in favor of fresh or frozen alternatives, making sure you don’t leave plastic water bottles in the car or the sun (heat can release the chemical), and never microwaving plastic. Better yet, go for glass and steel containers whenever possible.

title.en-US: Is preeclampsia more likely if you conceive through IVF?

content.value: We tackle one Maven member’s question.

Preeclampsia—a serious pregnancy complication characterized by high blood pressure—can occur in any woman during pregnancy, but it’s true that there are some risk factors that can make a woman more likely to develop the condition. Conceiving a baby through IVF is one of those factors that’s been linked to an increased risk for the condition; others include having had high blood pressure before conception, obesity, and carrying carrying twins or other multiples.

The exact association between preeclampsia and IVF is still not well understood, but given how stressful fertility treatment can be as it is, it’s important not to work yourself up worrying about the “what-ifs.”

That said, it's a good idea to be as healthy as you can be before you become pregnant. And if you're concerned about developing preeclampsia, the best way to find relief from the worry is to bring it up with your doctor—or a Maven practitioner. Discuss your personal risk factors, how best to keep yourself healthy, and how to keep an eye out for telltale symptoms during pregnancy.

title.en-US: Yes, there’s a black market for fertility medication

content.value: The high cost of a treatment cycle often leaves people without affordable access to medication, so some patients are taking matters into their own hands—and clicks—on the internet.

IVF and sticker shock often go hand in hand. The cost of just one cycle can range from $10,000 to $15,000—not including the cost of medications. The drugs themselves could tack on an extra $3,000 to $5,000 per cycle—or even more for older women who may need higher doses of meds to stimulate the ovaries and ensure more eggs are available for the procedure. (Check out
MavenRx
, Maven's partnership with leading fertility pharmacies offering you discounts on your medications, one-on-one support, and more.)

Given that patients may require several rounds of treatment, the costs can become a huge burden. With insurance coverage seriously lacking in many states, some parents are forced to get extra creative about cost-savings. Enter: a black market for fertility drugs. Buying other women’s leftover fertility medications online—a solution that some patients have resorted to—may seem like a good way to cut some corners, but it’s simply too risky.

After all, there’s far more at stake here than turning to eBay to place a bid on an expensive eye cream or vintage dress. Even if the sellers’ market their old meds with tremendous appeal—half price! free shipping!—you don’t know what you’re getting. Aside from falling for outright scams, you may be at risk for buying drugs that haven’t been stored properly (many require refrigeration), or ones that are past their expiration date. So in the end, it may cost you more to repeat another round of IVF if faulty meds sabotage your cycle.

Bottom line: The fact that fertility treatment is prohibitively expensive is a reality that needs to change. But in the meantime, it’s important to keep yourself safe and stick to legit, licensed pharmacies for all your prescription meds.

title.en-US: Should you get the flu vaccine during fertility treatment?

content.value: We get it, the last thing you want is another shot. Here are the facts you need to know.

This may not be the answer you wanted to hear, but, yes—you should get the influenza vaccine. The flu shot is safe for anyone undergoing IVF or other fertility treatments. And getting it is crucial for your health (as well as your future baby’s health) if you do become pregnant during flu season. In fact, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) includes both women who are pregnant and women who will be pregnant during the flu season on its list of high-risk groups.
What happens if you’re undergoing IVF and come down with the flu?

It depends on the severity of your illness, but it’s possible that your cycle will need to be delayed or cancelled. While that’s the last outcome you want, it’s important to let your reproductive endocrinologist know if your primary doctor does diagnose you with influenza. Keeping your care team informed about all aspects of your health is the best way to make sure you get the treatment you need.

title.en-US: Study says IVF isn’t as successful for Black women

content.value: A 2018 study examined outcomes from over 36,000 IVF procedures performed between 2004 and 2016 in one D.C.-area clinic. According to the study, the live birth rate was 14% lower for black women compared to white women. Black women were also more 24% more likely to experience clinical pregnancy loss. “This is similar to findings from previous studies,” notes Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, M.D.

What’s baffling about this current study is that black women actually responded better to ovarian stimulation protocols than white women did. This means that they had more eggs retrieved, and more embryos were created as a result. If IVF is a numbers game, you’d think that this fact alone would have contributed to greater success, but that’s not what panned out. And given that this study focused on women at one fertility practice, the difference in outcomes couldn’t be attributed to lab techniques. So something else is at play.

"A second study on this same IVF cohort showed that black women were three times more likely to deliver very preterm (28-32 weeks) or extremely preterm (<28 weeks),” notes Stone. This shows that the problem is not just attributable to differences in access to care, but could be due to uterine factors.

Meanwhile, black women are woefully underrepresented in clinical trials. What this as well as previous studies make clear is that in order for black women to have greater success with IVF, more research is needed about their unique experiences—including any biological barriers that prohibit better outcomes.

title.en-US: What to do if a fertility clinic rejects you due to your age

content.value: Answer from Maven Reproductive Endocrinologist Scott Morin, M.D.
