You’re not alone. Unfortunately, some women have experienced situations in which a fertility clinic has refused to initiate treatment because of age. In truth, this is a very controversial topic and there are reasonable arguments on both sides of the debate. 
That said, a clinic should never reject a patient from having an initial consultation due to age. Fertility specialists should be prepared to discuss options for all patients seeking pregnancy because there is almost always a treatment pathway available for any circumstance. Refusing to see a patient without hearing her story and her goals for building a family is completely unjustifiable. Here’s what you need to know.
Understanding the success rate when using your own eggs

Unfortunately, fertility treatment utilizing a woman’s own eggs at age 45 or older has a very low likelihood of success. Whether the treatment strategy involves IUI or IVF, pregnancy rates are well below 5%. Because infertility can take a significant emotional toll, patients are often may cling to any hopeful message. Unfortunately, this creates a situation in which patients may continue to proceed with expensive treatment despite extensive counseling that the likelihood of success is low.

This is a classic ethical debate between which consideration is more important: patient autonomy versus a desire to avoid taking advantage of a vulnerable patient. Honoring patient autonomy would dictate that patients should not be stopped from pursuing treatment as long as they fully comprehend the very low likelihood of success. Conversely, placing a greater priority on protecting patients from their desperation to conceive would mean declining to treat a patient based on 1) age or 2) a history of multiple failed cycles. The latter option removes the decision making power from the patient, which is less desirable.
What about donor eggs?

The story is dramatically different for women who pursue treatment with donor eggs. Donor egg IVF success rates are not significantly impacted by the age of the woman carrying the pregnancy. In other words, embryos made from donor eggs are just as likely to result in a live birth whether the recipient of the embryo transfer is 35 or 45 years old.

However, using donor eggs is not a decision that many women take lightly. It is often difficult to accept using another woman’s eggs to achieve pregnancy. Still, all women should be counseled regarding this option. Studies have shown that women using donor eggs experience equivalent levels of parental satisfaction and fulfillment as women who get pregnant with their own eggs.
What should you do if you’re turned away from a clinic?

If you haven’t even been seen for your initial consultation, you should either escalate this issue up the chain of command until they’ve agreed to schedule your appointment or move on to another clinic (if geography allows and you have options to choose from). There is no justification for a clinic not discussing success rates and the various options available.

If you are being denied treatment at a clinic due to age, you should ask them to explain their rationale. Once you are fully informed of the likelihood of success and the cost of treatment and would still like to proceed, you should push back. Often this process of informed consent and full disclosure will prompt a clinic to feel compelled to treat a well-educated patient. If they still refuse, you should seek out an alternate clinic. You will very likely be able to find the care that you desire in another setting.

title.en-US: IVF constipation: Help!!!

content.value: Find out why fertility treatment has you feeling all stopped up, and what you can do to find relief fast.

Being backed up isn’t something we typically talk about in polite company, but among doctors and patients and fellow IVF-ers, it really should be. That’s because it’s quite common for women who are undergoing fertility treatment to experience constipation. And, let’s face it, you have enough discomforts to deal with during this time; no one needs to add bathroom troubles to the mix.
So, why am I so constipated with IVF?

Constipation occurs when stool moves too slowly through the digestive tract and cannot be ushered out of the body effectively. A range of factors during a fertility treatment cycle can cause this to happen. For one, hormones—including those taken during the stimming part of your cycle—can have an impact on your gastrointestinal (GI) system. In particular, progesterone is thought to relax (instead of contract) the bowel muscles. Exposure to anesthetics during an egg retrieval procedure as well as reduced physical activity may also contribute to constipation. What’s more, sometimes stress can wreak havoc on your digestive system.
What’s the best relief for constipation during fertility treatment?

Anytime your GI system is acting up, it’s a good idea to be mindful of what you're eating and drinking. Specifically, make sure you’re getting enough fiber (aim for at least 25 grams per day) and prioritizing water intake throughout the day. Stress reduction techniques like a regular meditation practice can also help if you have a hunch that being emotionally wound up is contributing to your bathroom irregularity. While your doctor may have advised avoiding strenuous workouts during an IVF cycle, a brisk walk or other low- to moderate-impact activity could help get things going again. As for OTC meds, such as stool softeners, there may be some safe options. But, as always, talk to your doctor before hitting the drugstore to make sure you’re in the clear.

title.en-US: Does using an egg donor affect your confidence as a parent?

content.value: The truth about that study you may have read.

One woman considering egg-donor IVF confessed that she started to have second thoughts about her decision. The reason? She’d seen the results of a 2018 University of Cambridge study looking at how mothers who use donor eggs interact with their kids compared to mothers who had children using their own eggs. If you only read the headlines or the first lines to the news reports, you’d probably jump to conclusions. After all, sentiments like “mothers who give birth using donor eggs may react less sensitively to their babies” don’t exactly comfort the many women for whom donor eggs are the only real chance of success with IVF.

So what did the research actually find? It’s true that in the study, moms of donor children made slightly less eye contact with their babies and responded a bit less to their playfulness. But these differences were subtle. What’s more, the study authors themselves say that all of the parents had strong, loving bonds with their kids. As OB-GYN Jackie Stone, M.D., notes, “All of the scores were at the upper end of the spectrum (making these subtle differences less meaningful), and all of the moms rated their bonds with their infants as good.”

It’s also important to keep in mind that being a new mother comes with challenges no matter how your child was conceived. Figuring out how to take care of a human—especially if you’re older and haven’t had children previously—can make anyone a little anxious or lose confidence in their parenting chops. While there’s a myth that the mother-baby relationship has to be one of those “love at first sight” experiences, the truth is that bonding is often a gradual process that takes time.
Egg donation is not for everyone doing IVF—which is why it’s very important to make use of third-party genetic counseling at your clinic if you’re thinking about it. But if you’ve decided it’s for you, you can rest assured that a strong connection to your child is totally possible.

title.en-US: How to survive the two-week wait

content.value: Take that anxiety you’ve felt waiting to hear about something you really, really wanted (a job offer, a house, etc.) and multiply that by 100. That may give you just a glimpse into what the 2-week-wait feels like—that’s the part of an IUI or IVF cycle that involves sitting through an uncomfortable 14 days (on average) to see if the procedure resulted in a pregnancy. We’ll be honest: It can be excruciating. But there are some ways to make the waiting a little bit easier.
De-catastrophize.

One thing we know about the fertility journey is that treatment usually isn’t a one-attempt-and-done deal. So as much as you can, try not to anticipate the results with a feeling of “it’s the end of the world if this round fails.” One (or several) unsuccessful attempts at treatment doesn’t mean you’ll never be a mother. If you work on believing this now, any “bad” news—if it comes—may not feel like such a crushing blow.
Don’t clear the calendar.

Your instinct may be to cancel all social plans and just become an expert at clock-watching and counting the minutes till your 2-week pregnancy test. But this will make the waiting period seem about a million times longer than it is. Go on a movie date with your partner, invite a friend over for dinner, do anything that will give you even a brief reprieve from obsessive anticipation.
Stay away from message boards.

At many times during your journey, hearing other people’s experiences through infertility may provide a great sense of comfort. But during this two-week wait, you may be extra vulnerable, and going down the rabbit hole of “this happened to me” stories could cause you more anxiety. While you’re taking a break from online forums, you might want to briefly step back from social media, too. Any kid- or pregnancy-related posts from your circle may be too triggering.

title.en-US: 6 things you should know about a chemical pregnancy

content.value: A chemical pregnancy (also called a biochemical pregnancy) is an early miscarriage that happens within a few weeks of implantation. An initial positive beta pregnancy test (detected by hCG levels) is followed by a subsequent failure of the pregnancy to progress to an ultrasound confirmed pregnancy. It’s normal to feel disappointed and sad when this happens—but there are plenty of reasons you shouldn’t get too discouraged. Here are a few helpful things to understand about the causes, risks, and what it means for your chances of having a baby in the future.
Who does this happen to?

It’s hard to know exact numbers, but chemical pregnancies are thought to involve as many as half of all pregnancies (and by some stats, even more). While any woman can experience a chemical pregnancy, conceiving through IVF makes it more likely that you’ll realize it happened. That’s because you’ll be getting more early monitoring to see if the implantation stuck. (25% of pregnancies fail before women even know they’re pregnant.)
Maybe the pregnancy test was simply a false positive?

In the case of a chemical pregnancy, it isn’t that the wrong lines showed up on the pregnancy test. For a brief time, the embryo did stick, and your body made enough human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)–a hormone produced after implantation—for the test to detect as a sign of pregnancy. But the embryo detached before it had a chance to really grow. That’s why the ultrasound, usually performed at 5 or 6 weeks, found no evidence of a pregnancy.
Is it normal if it causes you a lot of grief and sadness?

Absolutely. For someone who’s experienced a chemical pregnancy during fertility treatment, the emotional roller coaster ride can be especially intense. Even if you’ve been cautioned to delay your excitement until the pregnancy is further along, you can’t help but feel elated when a home-pregnancy test or blood test reveals a big fat positive (a.k.a., BFP, as it’s often referred to in TTC community-board terminology).
Will it affect your chances of a future pregnancy?
Here’s some good news: A chemical pregnancy (also called biochemical pregnancy) won’t impact your fertility or future chances of conceiving.
What caused this to happen?

Doctors can’t always say for sure, but there are a couple of possible explanations. If you have pre-existing uterine issues, like a thin lining of the endometrium, the embryo may be more likely to detach. The same is true for embryos with chromosomal abnormalities.
Is there anything you can do to prevent a chemical pregnancy?

Unfortunately, no. As hard as the waiting game is when you’re trying to have a baby, your body does quite a good job in knowing when an embryo has what it takes to grow into a happy, healthy being. So other than taking care of your health and steering clear of the usual things you should avoid when trying to conceive (i.e. drugs, cigarettes, alcohol, excessive caffeine), there’s not much you can do to determine the fate of an embryo.

title.en-US: Why so many people stay silent about their infertility

content.value: The reasons for the secrecy, plus the benefits of opening up.

Get this: One survey found that a whopping 60% of infertility patients hide their struggles from friends and family. Depending on your own approach to your journey, you’ll either count yourself as part of that group, or wonder why so many women would go through something so difficult without opening up.
Well, the reasons for staying silent are myriad and complex.

Some people say that the devastation they feel during every failed attempt to conceive is hard enough without having to manage or take on other people’s disappointment and sadness, too. This is why some women say they don’t even share their infertility struggles with their own parents and siblings. Others want to protect themselves from someone saying the wrong thing. When you’re already having a hard time keeping it together, an insensitive comment or question (i.e. “Why did you wait so long to start a family?” or “You could try to adopt”) can tip you over the edge.

Still, others don’t believe that sharing will ever truly convey what the experience is really like to someone who hasn’t gone through it. “No one gets the despair I feel” or “people won’t understand the grief I live with every day” are some of the sentiments we’ve heard. And then there’s the shame factor—sometimes women feel they’re somehow to blame, and decide battling infertility in silence is better than letting others see their “flaw.”
What’s the problem with too much silence?

While every woman deserves to go about her journey in whatever way is best for her, it’s important to know that if staying quiet is making things harder on you, opening up is an option. It may not be easy, but it can help you get the support you need. What’s more, once you start sharing, you may realize how common infertility struggles are, and the stigma you feel around it could lessen.

Of course, you don’t need to share your story with everyone in your life, but if there are friends and relatives who have proven to be supportive and nurturing in the past, start there. And be sure to communicate what you need. You could say things like, “This is really hard for me to talk about, and I’m not really looking for advice at this point—I just need someone to listen.”

And remember, if opening up to people in your inner circle feels too challenging, you can always connect with a Maven therapist. They’re happy to video chat with you anytime, and they may be just the (non-judgmental) sounding board you need.

title.en-US: Navigating the cost of fertility treatments: 3 top tips

content.value: Assisted reproductive technology can be an amazing gift for people struggling to conceive naturally. But it’s also incredibly expensive—especially IVF, which can tally upward of $12,000 per cycle. Given the high costs, it might seem tempting to bury your head in the sand and not think about money matters at all. But taking that approach could lead to more stress later—exactly what you don’t need. Use these tips to stay informed and in control.
Tip #1: Make your provider’s office an ally.

Fertility clinics have departments dedicated to billing and financing. Your job: Get to know someone on that team who can be a partner as you navigate the tricky world of paying for treatment. You’ll want to find someone here who can help you make sense of the prices quoted to you, and who will be patient as you ask questions. You can also try negotiating with a clinic if you’re offered a better deal from another clinic but prefer the pricier one.
Tip #2: Get clear about exactly what’s included in the price of your care.

When you make a financial plan for treatment at your clinic, do some extra legwork upfront to prevent sticker shock later. If, for instance, you set a budget for a maximum of four rounds of I.V.F., be sure you’re factoring in all the costs involved in each cycle—such as medications, storage cost for freezing embryos, etc. And find out whether the fees include any blood work, ultrasounds, or other routine tests—or whether these things are considered a la carte. Fact: Add-ons add up very quickly. (Check out
MavenRx
, Maven's partnership with leading fertility pharmacies offering you discounts on your medications, one-on-one support, and more.)
Tip #3: Understand the ins and outs of your health plan.

If your insurance company offers coverage for fertility treatment, find out exactly what’s included. Some plans provide coverage only for the tests involved in diagnosing infertility, but not for the treatment itself. Others pay for treatment such as IVF, but cap it after a certain number of rounds. You should also do your homework before filling any prescriptions your doctor gives you; insurers will often foot the bill for certain brands of fertility drugs, while denying claims for others. Making these calls to understand your benefits is never a fun way to spend an afternoon, but it can save you a lot of money—and just as important—cut down on financial stress.

title.en-US: 3 relationship-ruining fertility money mistakes to avoid

content.value: The financial strain involved with fertility treatment definitely isn’t easy on a relationship. But there are a few things you can do to sidestep unnecessary friction, starting with avoiding these three common money mistakes.
Mistake #1: Not being honest with each other about sacrifices you’re willing to make.

For many couples, the high cost of fertility treatment requires making some financial adjustments. So it’s important to discuss how, exactly, your spending habits will change. For instance, will you consult each other before making any significant purchases, even if you didn’t do that before? Will you put your annual vacation on hold in favor of more saving? Initiating these conversations—and then having check-ins to decide if your plan needs reevaluating—can prevent the kind of misunderstandings and resentments that can be detrimental to a relationship.
Mistake #2: Not thinking through your borrowing decisions.

Once you take stock of your finances, you may need to get creative to afford treatment. While borrowing money from relatives isn’t a possibility for everyone, some couples take a family loan to pay for fertility-related expenses. Before you go down this road, have an open conversation with your partner about the ins and outs of this—and how you’ll navigate issues that have the potential to put a strain on your relationship. For example, if you’re borrowing from two sets of in-laws, whose family will be repaid first? Or will you slowly reimburse both parties at the same pace? Many people think they can cross these bridges later, but the “we’ll deal with it when the time comes” approach isn’t a great way to safeguard your relationship.
Mistake #3: Not getting on the same page about how much you’ll spend on treatment.

One of the hardest decisions couples may have to make is when to stop treatment. And for many people, finances may play a big role in that decision. Sitting down to set limitations from the start is key. No one wants to break out the calculator on date night, but avoiding these discussions could lead to issues later on, especially when one partner wants to continue treatment and the other wants to quit.

title.en-US: Why the “what went wrong” appointment is so important

content.value: Peace of mind starts with explanations.
You already know that fertility treatment is described as a journey. And, for most people who try IUI or IVF, that means being prepared to do more than one round before a successful pregnancy.

And while you may never know the exact reason that a treatment cycle failed, you deserve to have a thorough download with your fertility specialist after the procedure. So if all you get is a phone call from the clinic’s nurse telling you, “You’re not pregnant—let’s schedule your next round,” it’s important that you advocate for yourself and ask for a debrief with your doctor—in person.

When you meet with your doctor for this “What Went Wrong” appointment, don’t settle for a blanket explanation such as, “Sorry, this happens.” Ask questions that will bring you some peace of mind before you begin another emotional, exhausting, and expensive journey. Nothing is off the table, but here are some Qs to get you started: Did it have something to do with the quality of my eggs? Or my partner’s sperm? Did you notice any reasons why my uterus may have “rejected” the embryo? Should I repeat the same treatment, or is it a good idea to alter the protocol? When do you recommend I try again?
Bottom line
: Don’t be afraid to dig deep. And if you’ve met with your doctor and felt rushed, or you have any lingering concerns, book an appointment with a Maven practitioner.

title.en-US: How to handle unsolicited advice during infertility

content.value: How to deal with people who “should” all over you.

You know that feeling when you call the cable company to tell them your TV isn’t working, and they say you should try turning it off and on? If you’re struggling with fertility, you may be dealing with these kind of (mostly useless, often “I-didn’t-need-someone-to-tell-me-that”) suggestions.
And nothing is more frustrating than when the advice is completely unsolicited. After all, it takes a lot to let someone into your experience, and usually what you want is a compassionate ear, not a list of opinions. You should really try acupuncture. You might want to get your husband’s sperm tested. Have you considered adoption?
So how can you handle receiving advice that you don’t really need or want?
1. Remember that it’s not about you.

The first coping strategy? Try not to take things too personally. Some people love to dole out their own opinions, regardless of who their listener is. Simply keeping this in mind might make the situation easier to deal with.
2. Take only what feels useful and ignore the rest.

While 9 out of 10 times the advice may be useless, once in a while you may hear a suggestion that resonates with you or gives you a new perspective. This, of course, will depend on whether or not the giver has any authority to speak from. If a friend is making a suggestion on, say, switching to a different fertility clinic and she’s been through this journey herself, that will make the suggestion a lot more palatable than hearing it from a pal who has never struggled to conceive.
3. Don’t engage.

You may be tempted to get into a debate with someone whose advice conflicts with your own views, but engaging in a conversation about it probably isn’t worth it. The decisions you make during your fertility journey are between you, your partner (if you’re in a relationship), and your doctor. So what Aunt Sally thinks you should do with your remaining frozen embryos really isn’t a matter worth debating. A simple, “thanks for the suggestion”—and then quickly changing the subject—should get the message across in a polite but clear way.

title.en-US: Why doesn't anyone talk in my fertility clinic waiting room?

content.value: #Awkward

One Maven user wanted to know if the deafening silence she encounters at her fertility center is normal: “I always feel really awkward because no one even looks at each other.” The truth is, while there may be some clinics’ waiting rooms that are buzzing, most have a reputation for being a quiet-zone.

Some women confess that they’re hesitant to strike up a conversation with someone because they worry that they’re having more success with the treatment and don’t want to trigger anyone who’s struggling. They also want to avoid comparisons that could lead to stress. For instance, “So how many eggs did you get?” Others say they don’t talk about their infertility—period—so opening up with anyone (in or out of the waiting room) isn’t something they’re used to. Meanwhile, there are those who explain their decision to stay mum by the fact that they’re just in too much pain—and they’re trying to “keep it together” and not have an emotional breakdown before their appointment.

If it feels right to you to make eye contact or say hello to someone in the waiting room, it’s definitely OK to do that. There’s no rulebook saying that smiles and niceties aren’t allowed. You may be surprised to find that another woman is also eager to break the “taboo” (aka speaking). And if your attempt to connect isn’t received very well, just know that there could be a million reasons for her silence, and they have nothing to do with you.

title.en-US: You can choose your baby's sex through IVF—but should you?

content.value: People who do IVF and want to test the embryos’ sex have that option. When Chrissy Teigen revealed that she chose the sex of her baby, critics quickly took their fury to the internet. What is it about sex selection that’s so divisive? And how does sex selection actually work? Here’s what you need to know.
How does it work?

There are a couple of methods doctors use to pick a baby’s sex, or at least to shift the odds. The one that’s most prominent in IVF relies on a test some couples use to assess the genetic makeup of an embryo. In order to look for mutations that increase the risk for diseases, Preimplantation Genetic Diagnosis (or PGD) does a complete chromosomal analysis of each embryo. If the screening indicates that a woman has both male and female embryos that are healthy, parents-to-be can choose which sex to implant.
What’s the controversy?

Some parents would love the chance to decide on whether they bring a boy or a girl into their lives, while others don’t want to interfere with nature. The medical community is split, too. Proponents say it’s fair that a couple who already has, say, two boys, be given the option to select a female embryo—calling it “family balancing.” But many experts say IVF should stick to what it was created to do: help people give birth to a healthy baby. Countries like England and Canada have already explicitly banned sex selection for reasons beyond avoiding devastating diseases (like if a woman is at risk of having a child with a genetic disorder linked to a particular sex). There’s also concern that sex selection could lead to a slippery slope of pre-selecting a child’s characteristics. For instance, will we one day be debating whether it’s OK to select an embryo that will have blue eyes and brown hair?
Are couples leaning one way or the other?
No. So far people are choosing male embryos as frequently as female embryos, which is why some doctors say they aren’t too worried that this practice is going to skew the balance of a population.
The bottom line

: A lot of personal—even ethical—decisions may arise during your infertility journey. Make sure you have the support and sounding boards you need to make choices that are right for you and your family. Tap into your clinic’s counseling center, and always feel free to reach out to Maven providers.

title.en-US: How to help your friends help you through infertility

content.value: Raise your hand if you’ve ever wished that more people would get a little training on infertility etiquette? The fact is, unless people have had to deal with infertility themselves, most don’t even have a basic understanding of what you’re going through. That can leave even those who care about you the most at a loss for how to support you. As a result, they’ve probably said something hurtful without even realizing it. Here are some tips on helping your inner network help you.
Give them the Idiot’s Guide to Infertility.

In other words, clue them in on the IUI/IVF process, or whatever treatment protocol you’re undergoing. If they just knew how time consuming and physically exhausting it is, they might stop saying things like, “Don’t stress” or insisting that you make social plans. Just as important, giving them a sense of your emotional pain can curtail comments that make light of your experience—like joking about giving you their own eggs or sperm.
Don’t be shy about accepting help.

Your closest pals and family want to help. When they ask what they can do for you, make it easy for them to pitch in by identifying your needs. That might mean driving you to a doctor’s appointment, picking up meds at the pharmacy, helping you make a healthy dinner when you’re too exhausted to cook, or simply providing a ear when you want to vent.
Let them know when you need to opt out.

If close pals and relatives are pregnant or raising children, it’s OK to set some boundaries around events that are too triggering. This doesn’t mean you have to sever ties or cut people out of your life, but if you can’t bear to attend a baby shower or kids’ birthday party after another failed cycle, say so. Be sure to say that you wish you could be there but worry that the gathering might make your grief worse. Reiterate that you are truly happy for them and would love to celebrate when you’re ready. Close friends will understand, and even if they don’t, you don’t need to be guilt-tripped into attending.
At the same time, communicate when you’re feeling isolated.

Sometimes when people don’t know what to say to a friend who is infertile, their solution is to create the distance themselves. If you’ve been feeling left out or haven’t received invitations to important events in close pals’ lives, that could make a lonely experience even more isolating. In this case, you might say that you appreciate their sensitivity to your situation, but would prefer to be given the choice about whether or not you can “handle” an event.
Tell them how much you love it when they simply listen.

Explain that stories about other people’s IVF “miracles” (using some treatment method that sounds sketchy) just stresses you out. Let your friends know that sometimes you just want someone to acknowledge your sadness and fear and hear you vent. No advice, suggestions, or miracle sagas needed.
Explain that you want to see where
this
path to parenthood takes you.

That should give them the hint to stop suggesting adoption or IVF or whatever you don’t happen to be trying at this instant. Remind them (gently) that this is a journey that you and your partner are going through together, and that the two of you will change course only when you’re ready.

title.en-US: The #1 thing you can do for your sanity during fertility treatment

content.value: No matter how antsy you get to find out the results of your fertility treatment, here’s why you should resist the urge to pee on the stick during the two-week wait.

Home pregnancy tests work by detecting whether or not your urine contains human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), aka the pregnancy hormone. But here’s the thing: Many fertility treatments involve a trigger shot, which is an injection of hCG. So if you still have traces of hCG in your system, the test could pick it up and register as positive—even if you aren’t actually pregnant.

There’s also the possibility that you are pregnant but you could take the test when the levels of hCG in your body are still too low—so you’d incorrectly get a BFN (or big fat negative, as it’s often called).

Another reason to try to avoid testing too early is that, sadly, very early miscarriages called chemical pregnancies do occur more frequently than anyone wishes they would. This would mean that an at-home test is positive, a pregnancy is indeed initiated, but it doesn’t “stick” long enough to even be confirmed by an ultrasound.

The bottom line: As hard as waiting is, you’ll ultimately fair better by leaving the pregnancy test in your doctor’s hands. You’ll be sparing yourself an emotional roller coaster that just isn’t worth it.

title.en-US: When a failed IVF cycle feels like you lost a baby

content.value: It can seem like a part of you is gone—even if you were never pregnant.

By the time you make the decision to do IUI or IVF, you may have already felt one form of grief in learning that you can’t conceive on your own. And of course, a reproductive loss—when you do get pregnant during a treatment cycle but have a miscarriage—can bring on more mourning.

But what about when a cycle simply fails to result in a pregnancy? If you’ve been through this and felt true grief, you’re not alone. “Getting the call from my reproductive endocrinologist’s office with the news that the embryo transfer wasn’t successful was devastating,” one woman told us. “I had been through a miscarriage at 8 weeks in my twenties, and the similarities I experienced shocked me. There may not have been a heartbeat this time, but it still felt like a major loss.”

Counselors and therapists who see patients struggling with infertility say a failed IVF cycle can be particularly hard because your emotions—and expectations—are running very high leading up to the transfer. Every stage of the process—the harvesting of eggs, creation of embryos, and transfer back to the womb—fills you with more hope that you’re inching closer to your dream. And then, with one phone call, the dream is gone.

The bottom line: Every woman’s emotional experience during fertility treatment is different. The key is not to judge yourself or feel like you “should” or “shouldn’t” be having certain emotions. If you need extra support, look into the counseling services at you clinic or book an appointment with a Maven therapist. Whether it’s related to starting a family or any other part of your life, grief is a difficult thing to go through alone—and you don’t have to.

title.en-US: The 4 hardest things to accept when you’re struggling with infertility

content.value: And tips that can help you change your mindset
1. That it isn’t personal.

It’s easy to fall into a “why me?” (or “why us?”) mentality when you can’t conceive a child. But it may help your sanity to remember that infertility is a medical condition, and not a case of the universe conspiring against you. One sobering stat that won’t remove the pain, but will remind you of just how not personal it is: 1 in 8 couples have trouble getting pregnant or sustaining a pregnancy.
2. That is can be just as hard even if you already have a child.

Research indicates the emotional effects of secondary infertility—that’s when you can’t get pregnant now even if you were able to before—are identical to those of primary infertility. Stress, anxiety, and grief are all part of the process. What’s more, people with secondary infertility may struggle to get the support they need because they feel like society wants them to “just be grateful” they already have a biological child. If you’re in this situation, and need some extra support owning your emotional experience, book an appointment with a Maven therapist.
3. That you’re not in control.

Are there things you can do to increase your odds of success with treatment? Sure. But one of the hardest things to come to terms with is that, when it comes to fertility, there are never any guarantees. One women going through IVF said that’s the reason she hates being called an “infertility warrior”: “Every time someone calls me a fighter or a warrior, I feel like if I just ‘give it my all’ I can achieve the outcome I want—and I know that’s not the case.”
4. That your inner circle may change.

People with strong social circles have less risk of depression—and when you’re going through something as difficult as infertility, you need the benefits of friendship more than ever. But remember that some of your friendships formed when you were in a different place in your life, and it’s possible that some of them won’t be able to nurture and sustain you now. If you’ve outgrown certain relationships and need to press pause on them, it’s important to look for other ways to tap into social connection. Some people find it helpful to discover new pals in support groups with others who are also experiencing infertility; ask your doctor for recommendations for local support groups.

title.en-US: The mental health tip you need during fertility treatment

content.value: And the best part? It’s totally free.

Getting lost in thought is normal. But when you’re struggling with infertility, that mental wandering can take some devastating twists and turns. For one, there’s all the thinking about the past—which usually involves a lot of “what ifs” and regrets. For instance: What could I have done differently to avoid being in this position now? I wish I didn’t wait too long to start trying. Maybe if I had seen my OB-GYN more regularly, she would have picked up on problems sooner.

Then there’s all the anticipation/worry/fear about the future: What if this IVF cycle doesn’t work? What if I end up with twins? What if my clinic drops me? Even anticipating the future with blind optimism instead of worry (i.e. This treatment is going to work on the first try—I just know it!) can be problematic by leading to false hope.

The specific thoughts running through each woman’s mind might sound a bit different, but the impact is the same for everyone: Being too focused on the past and the future (two things you can’t control) can make a difficult experience like infertility even harder.
How mindfulness can help

That’s where mindfulness comes in. Even if you aren’t familiar with “practicing mindfulness”—that’s the way most people refer to it—you’ve probably heard of “living in the moment.” And that’s the basic gist.

There are lots of ways to go about practicing more mindfulness in your life. You could simply sit quietly for a few minutes and count your inhales and exhales—focusing on the breath instead of the mental chatter; you could follow guided meditations online; or try another approach entirely. Whatever method works best for you, the idea is to step out of the looping stories and focus on right now.
The benefits go on and on

People who’ve practiced meditation when struggling with infertility say the benefits include more acceptance of the ups and downs, a greater willingness to forgive themselves (or a partner), and an ability to handle the unknown. Mindfulness can also be a great way to relieve tension during treatment: Meditation has been shown to help the parasympathetic nervous system, and in turn, curb the body's stress response.

To be clear, practicing mindfulness isn’t about self-improvement; it isn’t even about “positive thinking” or dismissing the complex and entrenched problems you may be facing. It’s simply to get off the carousel of obsessive thoughts—if only for a few moments of relief from the unhelpful inner dialogue.

title.en-US: Can you find hope after an IVF miscarriage?

content.value: Here’s a study to remind you that pregnancy loss does not mean all hope is lost.

Miscarriage is devastating experience for any woman or couple, but if you’ve already struggled to conceive naturally and had to pursue fertility treatment, it can be even more physically and emotionally overwhelming.

One 2017 study published in Human Reproduction offers hope to anyone in that situation. Researchers from the University of Aberdeen in the UK looked at data involving more than 100,000 women who underwent IVF treatment. In their first attempt at IVF, about 25% of the women had a miscarriage. It turned out, those who miscarried during their first IVF cycle had a 40.9% chance of having a baby over two further cycles of IVF. In fact, the chances of achieving a live birth in subsequent cycles was 10% higher for those who miscarried than those had not become pregnant at all.

More evidence that an unsuccessful first round of IVF doesn’t mean being “doomed to fail” again, regardless of the outcome: In the study, women who didn’t get pregnant at all in their first IVF cycle still had a 30.1% chance of having a baby over two additional cycles.

Sometimes when you’re going through something as challenging as fertility treatment, you need science to remind you that the low points don’t mean you’re at an end point. You may just need some extra time—and, yes, hope—to get up the next hill.

title.en-US: 3 ways to help your relationship survive infertility

content.value: Fact: All relationships have rough spots. But adding infertility to the mix can test a couple in new ways, and for a prolonged period. Use this advice to get through the hard times with your bond intact.
Accept that you might not always be on the same page.

Just because you’re going through the same experience together doesn’t mean you’re going to experience it in the same way at the same time. Try to accept that your partner may be in a different mindset now, but remember that infertility is a process, and his or her mindset may change. In other words, yesterday’s “I don’t want to try another IVF cycle” may be tomorrow’s “I want to be a father/mother and I’ll do as many rounds as it takes!” The lesson here: Be patient with each other as you navigate circumstances that are hard and unfamiliar.
Spell out your needs.

Shhh... Hear that? Nope? Exactly. That’s the sound of silence, otherwise known as a passive-aggressive approach to getting your needs met. Unfortunately, it doesn’t work. Instead of hoping your partner can guess how you’d like to be supported, try to be clear. The first step in doing that, of course, is to recognize how, exactly, you’d like him or her to show up for you. Maybe that means being accompanied to more of your fertility appointments, or handing over the needles for your hormone injections during treatment and asking your partner to administer them to you. Or maybe it’s simply being held when you’re in a low point. Whatever the case, a direct style will help you avoid misunderstandings and resentment.
Get in the car.

Communication is essential, and psychologists have observed that sometimes the best way to have a difficult talk with someone is to take a drive with them. It could be that sitting side-by-side eliminates eye contact, so people feel more comfortable taking risks and saying things they’d otherwise be scared to admit. And let’s not forget the symbolism of being “in it together”—in a car, no one can run to the living room or turn on the TV when they want to escape. The effect may be that you feel more bonded. Lastly, the setting of a car ride is pretty informal, so it can tamp down the intensity of hard conversations. And let’s face it: When you’re discussing things like biological limitations, a lighter mood and seeing some blue skies ahead can’t hurt.

title.en-US: The truth about spontaneous pregnancy after infertility

content.value: Another reason to be hopeful.
People typically think of fertility in terms of two categories: Those who are able to have kids, or those whose chances of that happening are zero, zilch, nada.

But here’s some hopeful news: Even if you’re diagnosed with infertility, the condition isn’t always black and white. In fact, research shows that it’s possible for moms who gave birth to a child previously with the help of IVF to later conceive on their own. There are even cases when IVF proves unsuccessful (translation: no baby), yet couples goes on to have a child naturally.

One older study from France followed 2,100 couples who had started IVF. About 1,300 of those duos were able to have a baby with the help of treatment. Years later, the study authors checked back in with everyone via a survey to see if their families had expanded. Among the patients who did get pregnant through IVF, 17% later had another child without any assistance. And get this: Among couples who originally failed to have a baby with the aid of fertility treatment, 24% went on to have a child on their own, from what the researchers called a “spontaneous pregnancy.
That said, the odds are better for some than for others.

Obviously, no one can count on this outcome happening. And it appears that younger couples and those with “unexplained infertility” (that’s when a clear cause can’t be identified) may have better luck achieving a natural pregnancy post-IVF. It makes sense, given what we know about the age-related decline of fertility, as well as certain physical problems (like blocked fallopian tubes) that make conception highly unlikely.
The lesson?

If you’ve started a journey of fertility treatment and you’re feeling discouraged about your chance of “ever” having a baby, try to take the long view. Even if you can’t see the exact possibilities that might exist further down the line, a little hope might be just the thing to carry you through.

title.en-US: The truth about how infertility can affect your sex life

content.value: Real talk that can keep your relationship healthy.

Many aspects of the infertility journey are shrouded in silence. But sexual problems are almost never talked about. The result? Too many people suffer alone, thinking their own sex and intimacy issues are abnormal. Even worse: They simply don’t feel empowered to get the help they need to keep their relationship healthy.

To be sure, every duo is different, and some couples say their sex lives didn’t take a significant hit during their infertility journey. But for a lot of people, the sexual struggle is real—and a major source of stress in their relationships.
Who is most impacted?

Men and women may have different struggles, but they’re both affected. In one survey by Indiana University’s Center for Sexual Health Promotion, almost 70% of male and female respondents said that IVF hurt their sexual relationship.
What causes sexual issues?

Most often, it’s a number of factors. For instance, feeling exhausted and uncomfortable in a body that’s pumped full of fertility hormones isn't exactly a recipe for romance. (It’s no wonder that 51% of women in the Indiana University study reported reduced arousal.) And if many attempts to conceive have been futile, “performance issues” may surface—particularly for men (regardless of whether male or female factors are the cause of infertility). What’s more, after a certain point, both parties may feel that sex is just a reminder of their baby-making challenges, so they begin to associate nocturnal bonding with negative feelings instead of enjoyment.
What can you do to get the spark back?

While there’s no easy fix, it’s a good idea to address any intimacy issues that arise in your relationship—after all, staying connected with your partner is more important than ever right now. Interestingly, some experts recommend that couples take a brief time-out from fertility treatment when problems in the bedroom become too stressful. You might think you have “no time to spare,” but getting back in touch with your bond can help remind you while you’re working so hard to build a family together in the first place.

Of course, there are many other ways to bounce back, including seeking out the guidance of a Maven sex coach. While this may seem like a scary or even wacky prospect if you’ve never tried it before, the truth is that a sex therapist or coach may simply help initiate an open dialogue between you and your partner. And research says getting comfortable talking about sex is directly linked to sexual satisfaction. Sexual communication is a skill, but luckily it’s one that can be learned.

title.en-US: How my partner helped me through the stress of infertility

content.value: 3 women reflect on the support that really made a difference.

Infertility isn’t exactly an egalitarian process for couples. It’s the woman going through treatment who is getting poked and prodded at the doctor’s office, jumping through painful hoops, and pumping herself with hormones. But that doesn’t mean they have to bear the emotional burden on their own. Here, three women share how their significant others stepped up.

“Whenever I felt that not being able to have a baby was my fault, my partner would immediately go into ‘we-mode.’ He would say: This is OUR problem; WE want to have a child, and it will be the two us US who figure out how we’ll get through treatment or decide how else we might expand our family. That was the best gift he could’ve given me.”—L.V.

“My husband went to every appointment with me, including the check-ups during the ovarian hyperstimulation phase—which would take place every other day or so at 7:30AM. I was the bio major in college, and he was the liberal arts guy, but he watched the instructional videos our reproductive endocrinologist recommended diligently and managed to give me the multiple injections that were prescribed daily like a pro. I never felt for a second that I was going through the fertility treatments alone.”—J.C.

“My partner didn’t come to most of my fertility clinic appointments with me, but I definitely felt supported. Self-care became hard for me, and he stepped in to make sure I was eating healthy by preparing my meals—even packing my lunches for work the next day. And every night before it was time for my shots, he’d give me a foot massage to try to relax me.”—Y.O.

title.en-US: Will you experience postpartum depression after IVF?

content.value: The truth about how concerned you need to be about your mental health after fertility treatment.

There are many underlying drivers that could lead to postpartum depression (PPD). Everything from a sudden drop of hormones post-delivery, to the extreme lack of sleep that comes with having a infant, to the newness of the entire situation may play a role in a woman’s mental health after having a baby. In fact, anxiety and depression affect as many as one in seven new moms, according to the American Psychological Association.

IVF comes with its own set of physical and emotional challenges along the way, but how susceptible are you to these effects after getting pregnant? Some people think if you manage to have a baby with the help of fertility treatment, it’s very unlikely that you’ll need to be concerned about “the blues” or a more serious toll on your emotional health. After all, they assume that after all the struggle to get pregnant, all the waiting, all the anticipation, only joy awaits. But that’s not always the case.

Studies have found that the incidence of new moms suffering from postpartum depression (PPD) after infertility treatments is at least equal to that of the general population. In fact, some recent research suggests that that women who conceived through IVF and other forms of assisted reproduction have a higher risk for postpartum depression.
The bottom line

: Experts want women to recognize the need for emotional support that may arise after getting pregnant—regardless of the method of conception. Once you transition out of the care of reproductive endocrinologist and start seeing an OB-GYN for your prenatal care, make sure you remind your provider or your history with infertility. You can also reach out to a Maven mental health provider at any time—during treatment, while you’re pregnant, or after you have a baby. Sometimes having the support you need is the best way to prevent a problem.

title.en-US: Can fertility treatment lead to PTSD?

content.value: Another reason to prioritize your emotional health during this journey.
What is PTSD?

Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a mental health condition that's triggered by a traumatic event. According to the Mayo Clinic, symptoms may include flashbacks, nightmares and severe anxiety, as well as uncontrollable thoughts about the event.
How could fertility treatment contribute to something similar?

Sometimes, the infertility journey is so distressing that these kinds of symptoms show up after a woman is done with treatment. For instance, women may have recurrent, unwanted distressing memories of being at the fertility clinic, or undergoing the procedures. Or they may be intensely triggered by something that reminds them of the difficulty they had conceiving, such as a commercial for baby diapers. In one older study, researchers at Spalding University in Louisville surveyed 142 people who had undergone fertility treatments and discovered that nearly half—a whopping 46%—met the criteria for PTSD, meaning they could be diagnosed with the condition. Compared to the lifetime prevalence of PTSD in the general population of women–10-12%–that’s a big difference.
Is there anything you can do to take care of your emotional health and avoid any traumatic aftermath?

Some research has shown a correlation with the development of PTSD and “avoidance behaviors”—for instance, doing things to run away from hard feelings, or trying not to have them. Interestingly, by attempting to avoid emotional pain, it’s possible to bring on longer-term suffering. While it’s natural to want to escape feelings that are difficult, you may benefit from giving yourself permission to let them be there without pushing them away. Some people call this “inviting the pain in”—which sounds more unpleasant than it is. You could even try setting a timer for, say, 10 minutes, and in that time, allow any emotions you have to surface without pushing them down.

Remember, it’s normal to need extra support during life events that are this challenging. If you’re having trouble sitting with what arises—grief, anger, loss, loneliness, etc.—reach out to someone in your network or book a video chat with a Maven mental health provider.

title.en-US: The best answer to "when are you going to have a baby?"

content.value: Also known as the question no woman with infertility wants to hear—ever.
Struggling to have a baby is hard enough without having to answer this all-too-common question: “When are you going to get pregnant?”

Although it may feel like a gut-punch, it often stems from others’ cluelessness—not a mean-spirited intention. Then of course there’s that whole issue of societal entitlement to ignore women’s personal boundaries.

Leave it to straight-shooter Chrissy Teigen to put things into perspective for the nosy, oblivious people in the world. As she admitted publicly a few years ago: "I will say, honestly, John and I are having trouble. We would have kids five, six years ago if it'd happened, but my gosh, it's been a process! And we've seen fertility doctors. So, anytime somebody asks me if I'm going to have kids, I'm like, 'One day, you're going to ask that to the wrong girl who is really struggling, and it's going to be really hurtful to them. And I hate that. So, I hate it. Stop asking me!'"

By all means, feel free to be as blunt as Chrissy was in your shut-it-down method. Other people use humor to deflect the question (i.e. “Let me check. How about August 15 at 8pm? Does that work for you?”). Of course, a simple, “I’ll be sure to let you know when I have news” is another perfectly appropriate response.

Do you have to tell people you’re struggling with infertility? No. It’s no one’s business unless you want to share. But if you think you have a sympathetic audience, and the person inquiring is someone close to you, you can consider opening up to get some support. Even something like, “We haven’t gotten past the ‘trying’ part yet” may let someone know where you stand—and hopefully inspire them to be a bit more thoughtful/sensitive in the future.

title.en-US: IVF study shows that a man's age makes a difference

content.value: Lessons from 40-year-old sperm.

Women are sometimes made to feel like they come stamped with a “best before date”—because the research for a long time has focused solely on the female biological clock. The truth: While there are many male factors that play a role in whether or not a couple gets pregnant, “advanced paternal age” is one that hasn’t been well examined or understood. Thankfully, that’s starting to change.

A 2017 Harvard study suggested that the success rate of couples going through IVF may be dependent on the age of the man, and not only the woman. For the study, the scientists examined nearly 19,000 IVF cycles performed with more than 7,700 couples in Massachusetts. They looked at different age groups:
Under 30
30 to 35 years
35 to 40 years
40 to 42 years
And for men, 43 or older

As expected, the live birth rate was lowest in couples where the female was 40-42, regardless of a guy’s age. That just highlights what we already know—that a woman’s age is a major factor in IVF success.

But the study did shed light on how we often underestimate the role of male age in reproduction, even when assisted reproductive technologies are used. For younger women, a guy’s increasing age was linked to a negative impact on the outcome of IVF. Take the females in the under-30 group, for example: When these women had male partners between age 30 to 35, they had a 73% chance of a live birth. That success rate fell to 46% with male partners who were 40 to 42 years old.

The association between a guy’s age and a lower live-birth rate isn’t 100% clear, but it seems that sperm DNA can have a higher chance of breaks and other problems as men get older. In other words, while men can remain fertile and make new sperm throughout their lives, the quality of sperm when they’re in their 40s and 50s isn’t the same as that of a 20-year-old. And of course, you need healthy, capable sperm for optimal fertilization, implantation and embryo development during IVF. It’s worth noting that even the American Society of Reproductive Medicine now recommends that sperm donors are ideally under 40 years of age.

Experts say that these findings shouldn’t discourage older couples who want to have children from trying to do. It’s just about bringing more balance into the fertility conversation, and understanding that men and women both play a role in baby-making matters.

title.en-US: 8 times when IVF might be the solution to fertility problems

content.value: There are lots of reasons people need help conceiving, and the best treatment option for each woman and couple depends largely on the cause of infertility. So who’s a good candidate for in vitro fertilization (IVF)? Read on for the answers.
1. You have fallopian tubes issues.

Baby-making is all about producing an egg and moving it to the uterus where it can be fertilized. And the fallopian tubes are your eggs’ access road from ovaries to uterus. Without a clear thruway, your egg and his sperm need to meet up at some other mutually convenient spot, like in a petri dish. IVF steps in by retrieving the eggs directly from your ovaries and fertilizing them in a lab.
2. Doctors can’t figure out the root of the problem.

“Unexplained infertility”—which means there’s no clear answer to the “Why can’t you get pregnant?” question—usually puts treatment options on a continuum. Women typically start with the least invasive (and least expensive) options. After things like lifestyle changes, timed intercourse, and IUI with hormone treatments prove unsuccessful, a reproductive endocrinologist may bring up IVF.
3. You’re not in your 20s.

When you’re older, every egg isn’t a winner. Being under 30 gives you about a 30% chance of becoming pregnant over the course of any given menstrual cycle. That number drops to about 5% at age 40. If other attempts to resolve age-related fertility issues fail, a woman may decide to pursue IVF.
4. Your partner’s sperm need a little help.

If they can’t swim to meet the egg, or there aren’t enough of them, a doctor can combine IVF with a technology that gives an assist to the sperm: This is called IVF with intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI), a procedure that involves injecting a single healthy sperm into an egg in the laboratory.
5. You’re in a same-sex relationship.

While insemination with donor sperm is more common, some lesbian couples prefer to do what’s called reciprocal IVF. Here’s how it works: One partner provides the eggs, which are inseminated with donor sperm, and the embryo is then implanted into the other partner. The idea is that both women in the relationship contribute—physically—to the baby-making process.
6. You and/or your partner are carriers of a genetic disease.

Couples with a high risk of passing on a genetic disease might consider IVF with preimplantation genetic screening (PGS)—that’s when an embryo is tested during IVF treatment to screen for chromosomal abnormalities. This way, a doctor can implant only the ones that can lead to a viable pregnancy.
7. You put your eggs on ice when you were younger.
Women who use their frozen eggs to attempt a pregnancy must do so with IVF. After the eggs are carefully thawed, they mingle with sperm in a petri dish and hopefully get cozy and fertilized.
8. Your uterus needs a sub.

Sometimes women have no problem producing healthy eggs but medical conditions in their uterus aren’t conducive to hosting an embryo. IVF makes it possible to use your own eggs, fertilize them with sperm (from a partner or a sperm donor), and create an embryo that can be implanted in the uterus of a gestational carrier, aka a surrogate.

title.en-US: Timing an IVF embryo transfer: The day-3 vs. day-5 debate

content.value: You’ve come a long away and all your efforts have culminated here in a lab, where egg and sperm have fused into an embryo (or several). Your doctor has one last decision to make: when, exactly, to put the embryo back into your womb.
Embryology 101

To understand the options your doctor is considering, it’s worth a quick biology review. After the egg retrieval, the egg and sperm are placed together in a petri dish in the hopes that the sperm fertilizes egg and they turn into a single cell. Once merged, they divide every 12 to 24 hours, spurred on entirely by the mighty egg. By day 3, one cell has turned into 4 and maybe as many as 8. By day 5, you’re looking at 70 to 100 cells!

Somewhere between day 3 and day 4, the embryo itself takes the wheel and activates its own genes. It begins to differentiate itself into the two portions that will eventually become the fetus and the placenta. And by day five of an embryo’s development, you have what’s called a blastocyst.

When does the transfer happen?
Many clinics today offer a blastocyst transfer—meaning that they allow the embryo to develop in a test tube for five days before they implant it into the woman’s uterus. The other option is to have the transfer during the cleavage stage (that’s at day 2 or 3). Until a few years ago, most embryos were transferred at cleavage stage. But there’s been a trend recently to transferring embryos at the blastocyst stage.
The case for day-5 transfers

The protocol can differ depending on your clinic, your age, and your situation. But typically, your doctor won’t transfer more than two (in some cases, three) embryos. So if you’re lucky enough to end up with a good number of embryos, then your doctor has to decide which to pick. Waiting to see which embryos become blastocysts makes it easier to choose the ones that have a greater chance of leading to a pregnancy. (And if more than two become blastocysts, testing can be done via an embryo-grading process in order to give your doctor additional insights about the best embryos to transfer.) What’s more, a 5-day embryo enters the uterus right within the window when it’s ready to adhere to the uterus and the uterus is ready to receive it. (a.k.a., endometrium-embryo synchrony).
Are there times when day-3 transfers are the way to go?

In general, blastocysts have a better chance of implanting successfully. Unfortunately, not all embryos will progress to this stage outside of the body. So some experts feel that the case for a 5-day transfer is more convincing if you’re a “good prognosis patient”—meaning IVF resulted in a significant number of quality embryos, and you have nothing to lose by seeing how they develop. But if you ended up with very few embryos, or an embryologist doesn’t think your embryos have great odds of surviving in the laboratory until day 5, your doctor might go ahead and do the transfer at day 3 so they can settle into their natural environment sooner.
Are there any other options?

Researchers continue to study the results of embryo transfers at different stages. In a 2017 Gynecology and Reproductive Endocrinology review paper, scientists reported that day-4 transfers may be a way to hedge your bets. By assessing the data from day-4 transfers that have been performed, the authors concluded that, compared to day 3 or 5 transfers, this “happy medium” produced a higher live birth rate and a lower rate of miscarriages. However, as the researchers also point out, the positive results may simply reflect the fact that embryos that develop into “early blastocysts” by day 4 are stronger candidates to begin with.
The bottom line

: The choice to transfer embryos on day 3 or day 5 is one that requires careful thought. A reputable clinic will keep up with the ever-evolving area of reproductive technology and take emerging evidence into consideration—along with your own unique patient profile—before they make this important decision.

title.en-US: The lowdown on assisted hatching during IVF

content.value: Welcome to the world of infertility treatment—where previously unknown, wacky terms become part of your daily lexicon. So what the heck is assisted hatching, anyway, and do you need to spring for it?

If you’re doing IVF, your doctor might suggest a procedure called “assisted hatching”—which, just as it sounds, helps that embryo shed its shell so its cells can merge with those in your uterine wall and start a pregnancy.
Hatching 101

To understand assisted hatching, it helps to get to know the structure of the egg. When an egg is still in its follicle, secretions from the follicle and the egg itself form a shield around it called the zona pellucida. It’s this thick protein-carbohydrate shell that the sperm needs to penetrate to fertilize the egg and form an embryo.

After the sperm manages to fertilize the egg, the zona pellucida sticks around to protect the early embryo as the cells start to divide. By day 5, in the blastocyst stage, the embryo has three distinct structures: the trophectoderm (these are outer-layer cells that ultimately allow the embryo to implant), the ICM (the inner cell mass, which eventually becomes the fetus), and the blastocoel (a fluid-filled cavity in the middle). As the cells expand, they outgrow the zona pellucida and “hatching” naturally occurs. This allows the cells of the trophectoderm to bind to the cells in the lining of the uterus.
How assisted hatching works

Assisted hatching is a process between embryologist and embryo—which means (hooray!) it's one of the few IVF procedures that does not entail you getting poked or prodded. It happens in a lab, and instead of waiting for the embryo to grow out of the zona pellucida on its own, the embryologist gives it an assist before your transfer day. The hope is that by helping the embryo hatch out of its shell, it can be introduced to the uterus quicker and may be more likely to “take” during implantation. The embryologist makes a small puncture in the zona pellucida using laser technology (or, sometimes, an acidic solution or micro-needle).
Does it actually lead to more success?

A big review of studies found that assisted hatching slightly improved clinical pregnancy rates but not live birth rates. While it may up the chance of pregnancy by making the embryo more “implantation-friendly,” the odds of having a baby in your arms nine months later are what really matters. Experts say more studies need to be done to determine who might benefit the most from this technique. In the meantime, some clinics use assisted hatching across the board to try to increase pregnancy rates, even as the American Society of Reproductive Medicine (ASRM) doesn’t recommend that this technique be used routinely—simply because there hasn’t been enough data to show that it has benefits for everyone. And there’s also evidence that assisted hatching is linked to an increased chance of having twins—which could mean a riskier pregnancy.
Bottom line:

Keep in mind that assisted hatching is considered an “add-on” in fertility treatment—so it can cost you an extra $500 or more. Make sure you have an open conversation with your reproductive endocrinologist to discuss the risks and benefits before you decide to get hatched.

title.en-US: Can IVF work with my own eggs if I’m over 40?

content.value: We tackle a Maven member’s question: When it comes to reproductive health, is 40 the new 30?

That’s the million-dollar question. (Or, more precisely, it’s the $12,000 question—a.k.a. the approximate cost of a cycle.) The truth is, every woman is different and it’s hard to make predictions. Still, we won’t lie: Getting pregnant after 40 with IVF can be challenging--at least more than if you were under 40. Of course, exactly how challenging depends on your health history, current health status, your partner’s sperm quality, and your genes. To give patients a general idea, SART (Society for Assisted Reproductive Technology) and ASRM (American Society for Reproductive Medicine) created a tool for predicting your chances of success based on your age and other factors. You can try it out
here

What you’ll discover as you play around with the tool is that the numbers will vary depending on different parameters. For example, if a woman is 41 years old, has never been pregnant, is within a normal weight range and has unexplained infertility, her chances of a live birth after one IVF cycle is 20%; after two cycles it’s 32%; and after three cycles it’s 42%. However, if that same woman has been diagnosed with diminished ovarian reserve (meaning the cause of infertility has been traced back to her ovaries having lost their reproductive potential), those probabilities decline to 13%, 22%, and 30% respectively.
Your eggs after 40

IVF success depends on the quantity and quality of your eggs, and, unfortunately, both typically dwindle with age. The decline happens more gradually before your 35th birthday, and more precipitously after that. In fact, your chances of conceiving through IVF with your own eggs will differ greatly at age 40, 43, and 45. As you get older, your doctor may therefore recommend higher doses of gonadotropins (hormone treatments) in order to produce a sufficient quantity of eggs during the egg retrieval process. You might also find that you end up with not a lot of good-quality embryos (because good-quality embryos come from good quality eggs), and they may not stick to the uterine wall very easily. The chances of miscarriage is also increased.
It should also be noted that using an egg from a donor can help you maintain the higher pregnancy rate seen in younger women (30-35 percent) and the reduced risk of miscarriage.

All this is not to say a live birth won’t happen with your own eggs, but we can’t ignore biology or IVF statistics. Ideally, you and your doctor are weighing your odds carefully before each IVF cycle so you can make informed decisions.

title.en-US: Should you do genetic testing before IVF implantation?

content.value: It sounds like an irresistible proposition for women undergoing IVF: Run a test and you’ll all but ensure that the embryo you choose to transfer will be free of chromosomal abnormalities and grow into a live, healthy baby. Now some experts are saying that this routine test is flawed, and putting too much stock in it could be robbing women of the chance to get pregnant. We get to the bottom of the controversy.
How PGS works

PGS, or preimplantation genetic screening, is a test offered at most IVF clinics to help identify “viable” embryos before they’re transferred. It should be noted that while you’re still likely to hear the test referred to as PGS, the official name got an update, and the procedure is now technically called preimplantation genetic testing for aneuploidy (PGT-A).

That’s a mouthful, but basically what happens is that a few cells are plucked from the outside of a five-day-old embryo and analyzed in a lab. A cell sample that shows a healthy genetic makeup (2 pairs of 23 chromosomes, 46 in total) suggests—at least in theory—that the entire embryo is healthy and therefore a good candidate for transfer and implantation. Having even one extra or one missing cell gives the embryo an abnormal status.
Why abnormal embryos are ruled out

The main reason doctors have traditionally avoided transferring “abnormals” is the risk that these embryos won’t implant at all, or if they do, the pregnancy could end in a miscarriage. There’s also the fear that if a pregnancy is sustained, it would result in a child with a genetic disability. PGS (or PGT-A) “is most commonly offered for women over 38, as studies have shown that this test is most helpful at improving IVF outcomes in this population,” says Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, M.D. “It does not increase live birth rates but can decrease the number of cycles needed to produce a live birth by decreasing the number of miscarriages in this age group.”
Pros and cons of PGS

If the test turns up one or several normal embryos, the decision is easy: The viable embryos are put back into the womb. But when the screening determines that most or all of a patient’s embryos are abnormal—which definitely happens, especially for older women—making a choice on how to move forward based on PGS results could mean letting go of the chance to have a biological child.
The current controversy

Here’s where things get tricky: Some couples have chosen to implant “abnormal” embryos anyway and gone on to give birth to healthy babies. How is this possible? It turns out that PGS testing could label an embryo as abnormal even if it has some potential. In recent years, researchers have found that about 20% of embryos created through IVF are so-called “mosaic embryos”—meaning they have both normal and abnormal cells. And while we don’t know exactly what percentage of normal cells are needed for a successful pregnancy, we do know of cases where “mosaics” turned out to be perfectly viable: Studies suggest that they develop into a healthy baby about a third of the time. One explanation is a process of self-correction—that is, the abnormal cells could die off, or wind up only in the placenta and not affect the fetus.

Given these new understandings, there’s been some controversy about what to do with abnormal embryos during IVF. The big question: Should they be ruled out, or transferred in the hopes that a normal pregnancy might be achieved?
No easy answer

Some clinics still have policies against doing IVF with mosaic embryos and stand by the reliability of PGS. Other doctors are willing to do it, saying that they don’t want to deny would-be parents even a small chance of having a baby.
The decision, when left in the hands of a couple, can be a very difficult one to make. That’s why genetic counseling is essential—to understand the risks (i.e. miscarriage) and discuss what choices might have to be made later (like if a pregnancy is achieved but a genetic disease is detected at 10-weeks gestation during first-trimester screening).
Should you or shouldn’t you?

As is the case with all issues in IVF, the right answers to these questions depend on each individual’s situation (if there are any right answers at all). To make a decision about whether to have PGS testing—and how you’ll use the results—discuss the pros and cons with your doctor, and get a second opinion if you’re unsure. If you need help finding an expert you trust, contact your Maven Care Advocate for guidance.

title.en-US: 5 common questions about fertility drugs, answered

content.value: Ask any woman who’s done IVF, and chances are, she’ll tell you that the least invasive part of treatment was often the most nerve-wracking. This is the phase of IVF where a portion of your fridge and medicine cabinet gets stocked with so many meds and syringes that it looks like an urgent care facility. To help calm your nerves and learn exactly what you can expect, we tackle some common questions.
What fertility drugs are typically used during IVF?

Every treatment path is different, and the exact drugs or combo of drugs depends on which IVF protocol your doctor decides is best for you. That said, in what’s considered “Standard IVF,” a couple of different types of fertility medication are used. The catchy name “gonadotropins” refers to medications that are used to stimulate the ovaries to mature multiple eggs at one time. (Even if ovulation isn’t necessarily the cause of your infertility, gonadotropins help ensure that sufficient eggs are available and can produce viable embryos.) Another drug type—you may have heard of something called Lupron—is used to prevent ovulation from occurring naturally before your doctor has a chance to retrieve the eggs. (Check out
MavenRx
, Maven's partnership with leading fertility pharmacies offering you discounts on your medications, one-on-one support, and more.)
How long do I have to take the fertility hormone injections?
Typically, patients receive injections for 8 to 10 days, but some take them for a little longer. A week or two is pretty normal.
Are pills an option or do I have to take injections?

Clomid, or Clomiphene Citrate, is an oral fertility medication, but it tends to be used only as a first line of treatment. Clomid can be useful in helping women who do not ovulate regularly to produce an egg. But if your doctor feels that you need more help in the hormone department—as is usually the case when you’re doing IVF—injections are typically the only option.
What can I do if I don’t like needles?

The needles you’ll be using every day are small, but every woman’s comfort level will be different. If self-administering the injections is too difficult, you could have your partner or a friend do it for you. Your provider will train you (and your partner) so you’ll both feel more confident before beginning the treatment, but let your clinic know if you need a little extra training. They might suggest that you practice by inserting a needle into, say, a piece of fruit. You could also try relaxation techniques (like taking a full inhale, and then exhaling deeply just as the needle goes in) to help you cope. As with anything else, it’ll likely get easier with practice. One little tip to minimize any soreness in the injection site: Try to shift your target spot slightly with every injection.
Are these hormones going to make me feel, um, hormonal?

Many women undergo IVF and feel completely like their usual selves (beyond the normal anxiety of going through the process, of course). But others don’t feel that way at all. As is the case with other drugs, how you’ll react depends on your body’s unique response and the dosage of the drugs being used. Even if being moody, bloated, and irritable is “normal,” don’t assume you have to suffer in silence. Whatever your experience, let your doctor know—chances are, she’ll be able to tweak your treatment if you’re feeling really awful.

title.en-US: 7 things you should know about embryo transfer day

content.value: Embryo transfer—when your most promising embryos are moved from petri dish to uterus—can be exciting, stressful, and all-out overwhelming at the same time. Funny thing is, the procedure itself is quite straightforward. Some women who’ve been through IVF even describe it as “a walk in the fertility park” compared to what they’ve already experienced by the time they get to this step in the process. Here’s what you should know about the big day.
Drink lots of water before the procedure.
