A full bladder improves the imaging on the ultrasound, which your doctor uses to guide her during the implantation process. It also keeps your uterus from contracting. For these reasons, your clinic will likely recommend that you drink water consistently before going in, and that you try not to pee 30 to 45 minutes before the actual procedure. (Tip: Avoid coffee that morning—it’s a diuretic so it’ll make you feel like you have to pee much quicker than H20.)
You’ll have to fill out some paperwork.

Only the best of the bunch will be implanted, so you’ll need to let the clinic know what to do with the remaining embryos that are still viable. Discuss this issue with your partner beforehand so you’re not making a decision this big on the spot.
You won’t need anesthesia.

Embryo transfer is a lot easier than the egg harvesting. All you need to do is lie back on the examining table and think good thoughts. You might be given a sedative, if you need one, but generally speaking, you won’t.
The whole process lasts about five to 10 minutes.

Seriously, it’s that fast. With a fine transfer catheter and the help of ultrasound, the doctor guides the embryo (or embryos) through the cervix and into the uterus. After that, you’ll hang out for a bit (that amount of time varies, depending on your clinic—it could be anywhere from 10 minutes to about a half an hour), and then you’re free to go home.
There’s no “down time” for recovery.
You won’t feel groggy, since there’s no anesthesia to recover from. Many women feel just fine after the procedure, while others report temporary cramping.
The post-transfer bed-rest advice is a myth.

It used to be standard practice—women had been known to stay in bed for around five days. But it turns out, there’s no difference between bed rest and no bed rest, and taking gentle walks may actually be your best bet. A 2013 paper in the journal Fertility and Sterility reported that live births were “significantly higher” (56.7% vs 41.6%) in the no-bed-rest group. Nevertheless, it’s not a bad idea to take the remainder of the day off (most people do) and queue up the Netflix!
You’ll be reminded to take your progesterone.

This hormone keeps your uterus implantation-friendly by promoting a thickening of the uterine lining. Research has found that using progesterone after embryo transfer can increase the likelihood of a successful pregnancy.

title.en-US: Understanding IVF: Why some embryos implant and others don’t

content.value: For any IVF patient, the embryo transfer procedure is an exciting milestone—but it’s not quite the finish line. After an embryo is placed in the uterus, one last thing must happen: implantation, a.k.a. the process of an embryo finding a cozy home, which is necessary for a successful pregnancy. Here’s what you need to know about how things go down in the womb.
What happens to the embryo after the transfer?

The embryo hanging out in your uterus has a sticky surface and, if all goes well, it will eventually attach to the lining of the uterine wall—usually within 1 to 5 days. The embryo will also produce a chemical called trypsin, which signals the uterus to prepare itself for implantation. (Research has indicated that if the chemical is at the right level, the womb is more inclined to “accept” the embryo.) Once the embryo sticks, cells on its surface send out finger-like extensions that will hook up with your own blood supply. This outer layer eventually becomes the placenta.
In the cases when an embryo doesn’t attach, what’s going on?

Well, the first thing you need to initiate a pregnancy is a healthy embryo. Many implantation failures are due to chromosomal abnormalities in the embryo, which explains why implantation rates decrease as a woman ages. (Embryos with genetic mutations sometimes do implant, but result in a miscarriage later.) But not all high-quality embryos stick, because how “welcoming” the uterus is also matters. If the lining of the uterine wall, or endometrium, is too thin, it could reject the embryo. “Inflammatory disorders including endometritis, endometriosis, and hydrosalpinx can cause difficulty with implantation, “says Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, M.D. “Lesions in the uterus such as fibroids or endometrial polyps would also be cause for rejection.”

Other times a technical issue is to blame, such as a slightly-off placement of the catheter in the uterus during the embryo transfer. The fact is, not all reproductive endocrinologists (REs) are equally skilled, and these errors do happen.
Bottom line

: Unfortunately, factors that prevent implantation or lead to a failed IVF cycle are not always issues that can be “fixed”—but that doesn’t mean you and your doctor shouldn’t sit down to thoroughly review every attempt. Ask as many questions as you can to learn what (if anything) should be done differently if you decide to try again.

title.en-US: How long does an IVF cycle really take?

content.value: We’d hate to use the overused term “journey,” but frankly that’s what IVF is. It’s a process—and a little knowledge about what you can expect goes a long way.

It all starts with a flurry of appointments, blood tests, and health exams that determine your precise plan. Once these are complete—and how long that takes is different for everyone—your doctor may get you started on birth control pills to regulate your cycle and help the ovaries respond better to the stimulation medication. Day 1 of week 1 starts with the arrival of your period. Here’s what typically happens after that.
Week 1:

You’ll get your “baseline pelvic ultrasound” when your period begins so your doctor can examine your ovaries. Then you’ll start stimulating the ovaries with hormone treatments. These are usually daily or twice-daily doses by injection. Expect to go to the clinic every two or three days for a blood test and ultrasound to track your progress. After each monitoring visit, you’ll receive a phone call with instructions from a nurse; your medication dosage may change from day to day, depending on your body’s individual response to the hormones.
Week 2:

Brace yourself for an eventful week! You’ll finish up your hormone treatments, likely around midweek (for a total of about 10 to 12 days of treatment)—at which point your doctor will let you know when, precisely, you’ll need to give yourself the trigger shot. With this injection of hCG (the pregnancy hormone), your eggs are released, and you’ll be scheduled to have them harvested within a 34–hour window. At the same time, your partner’s sperm will be collected and washed. Finally, eggs and sperm will be united in an IVF lab. Fertilization isn’t a sure thing. But if it happens, your fertility team will be tracking the progress of the resulting embryos. The best one or two of the bunch will be transferred into your uterus (a no-anesthesia process that takes minutes). If you have remaining embryos that are considered viable, those are typically frozen.
Week 3-4:

The longest two weeks ever. At this point, you need to wait and see whether the embryo or embryos that were implanted will stick to the uterine wall. You’ll also take progesterone medication to keep your uterus in top shape for hosting an embryo.
Week 5:

Show up at the clinic–finally!–for your pregnancy test. If the result is positive, you’ll return in a few days to make sure things are going well. Chances are, you’ll be monitored for four to eight weeks before being referred to an OB-GYN.

title.en-US: What to expect on egg retrieval day

content.value: It's a crucial step in IVF, but not as scary as you might think.

Doing in vitro fertilization (IVF) with your own eggs means undergoing an egg retrieval. First you take medication to stimulate the ovaries for a week or two—to maximize the number of mature eggs that can be fertilized. Then you go in to have those egg removed. But what’s that process really like? Here are answers to a few common questions.
How long does it take?

The actual egg retrieval procedure lasts around 5 to 15 minutes. Instead of making an incision, the doctor takes a needle to guide a thin catheter through the vagina and into the ovary to suction out the eggs and collect them in a test tube. This happens quickly, so you can have 10, 15, even 20 eggs extracted in less than 20 minutes.
Will I be knocked out out?

Typically, yes. Protocols may differ by clinic, but the majority of the patients have the procedure done under sedation or anesthesia. Sure, this means you may be a little out of it when it’s over, and you’ll need to take the rest of the day off. But an anesthetic can turn an excruciating few minutes into something that’s, relatively speaking, no big deal.
Will I feel any pain afterward?

You might feel some discomfort similar to period cramps. Your doctor can prescribe something a little stronger, but she’ll usually just suggest an OTC pain medication for any cramping. Keep in mind, your ovaries remain enlarged for a while after the procedure, so it’s normal to feel some extra pressure in that area for even a few weeks.

title.en-US: Can this test help IVF patients who have repeat failures?

content.value: What you need to know about the “ERA” procedure.

During IVF, sperm and egg combine to create an embryo, which is then transferred into a woman’s uterus at a specific time. As you probably know, even when embryos look promising and have the right number of chromosomes, there are no guarantees that the embryo will be “accepted” by the uterus and a woman will get pregnant.

Well, some experimental scientists wanted to dig a little deeper into why some women fail to get pregnant after multiple rounds of IVF when there was no clear explanation (i.e. good-quality embryos were produced). They developed something called the endometrial receptivity array (ERA), which is a test that tries to determine when a woman’s body is most receptive to embryo implantation. (It also goes by the name endometrial receptivity testing, or ERT.) The procedure involves taking a biopsy of the endometrium and analyzing the tissue, looking specifically at the genes that play a role in how welcoming the uterus is when the embryo is introduced.
What do doctors do with this information?

The first thing to know is that doctors have traditionally done embryo transfers on the basis that implantation will occur 8 to 10 days after ovulation in all women. But if the test suggests that a woman has a “non-receptive” endometrium and a different implantation window, doctors can take a more personalized approach and time the embryo transfer more specifically—in the hopes of decreasing the chances of another implantation failure.
Can shifting the window of implantation definitely increase your chance of getting pregnant if your uterus is deemed “unreceptive”?

That’s what experts are still trying to figure out. Early data shows some reasons to be hopeful, and you may even hear stories of women in your network who say they’re glad they did the test and were able to get pregnant afterward. But the truth is, samples of women in the studies done so far have been very small and most experts say that the findings are inconclusive. Also keep in mind that the test can tack on another $1,000 to your IVF bill.
Where does that leave you?

Right now, ERA isn’t a standard test given to all patients doing IVF. (Not all clinics even offer it yet.) The test may become more popular in the future, as more evidence in favor of it mounts. For now, have a thorough discussion about the pros and cons with your doctor, and reach out to your Maven Care Advocate if you want to talk to another expert for a second opinion.

title.en-US: Could gene-editing become a game changer in IVF?

content.value: Some experts called it ground-breaking research; others called it incredibly controversial. Here’s what you need to know about DNA “correcting” in human embryos.

The nonstop needle-pricking and ultrasound probing are a drag, but the worst part about IVF is how little control women, their partners, and even their doctors have over the outcome. Ultimately each cycle often feels like a turn of the roulette wheel—with (if you’re not covered by insurance) ten grand as the starting bet.

But the good news is that IVF is constantly evolving. There are technologies doctors use today in fertility treatment that didn’t exist years ago. And there are breakthroughs underway now that may soon make baby-making less of a gamble. At least that’s the hope.
How could gene-editing tools make IVF more successful?

Genetic abnormalities are one reason that embryos may fail to grow or implant. And these DNA goof-ups—which turn up more often in the embryos of women older than 35—are also a common reason for miscarriage. So, at least theoretically, if you could edit out these genetic abnormalities in the lab when embryos are created via IVF, you could potentially make the “unviable” viable, so they lead to live births.
How close are we to this happening?

It’s not likely to be offered at your fertility clinic tomorrow, but what some experts call an important breakthrough occurred in 2017 when University of Oregon scientists reported that they were able to perform genetic editing to erase a genetic heart defect in human embryos. The research was very preliminary, since the intention at this point wasn’t to go one step further and implant them to create a pregnancy. But it gave researchers hope that in the future gene-correcting might be a game-changer for some people using IVF.
So how does it work, exactly?

The laboratory tool is called CRISPR (or Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats). It’s a mouthful, but just think of it as a pair of smart scissors that can track down a bum sequence of DNA (aka the root of abnormalities that arrests the growth of embryos) and fix them. What’s more, it can do this quicker than the less sophisticated gene-editing tools that came before it. Once the mutation is sliced out, an embryo can use the healthy copy of the genes supplied by the other parent to repair itself.
Is it ethical?

That’s up for debate. One Pew Research Council study found that 72% of respondents think changing an unborn baby’s DNA to treat a serious disease would be an appropriate use of gene-editing technology. Still, the research has drawn a fair amount of criticism. Some worry that outsmarting Mother Nature in this way could potentially lead to sketchier practices down the line. It’s one thing to sidestep a devastating infant disease, or to simply give an otherwise discarded embryo a chance at life. But where do you draw the line, and will editing out characteristics that some parents find undesirable be next? To complicate matters, a team of Australian scientists duplicated the experiment on mouse embryos and found that larger swaths of DNA were cut out, beyond the mutated sequences. While the Oregon team reported no excess deletions in their embryos, the possibility of unintended deletions is troubling. “This is an area where you need to be 100 percent confident in the results,” Paul Q. Thomas, a University of Adelaide professor, told the Wall Street Journal.
The bottom line

: Researchers need to overcome at least a couple of big obstacles before gene editing becomes commonplace. Among them: the lack of federal funding for research using human embryos and the Food and Drug Administration’s decision to not pursue clinical trials involving human gene-editing. That said, there are scientists who are committed to overcoming these challenges and pushing for further research to continue.

title.en-US: How should I choose between an anonymous vs. open egg donor?

content.value: Advice to help you sort out your options.

Once you’ve made the big decision to do donor-egg IVF, you have another significant choice in front of you: seeking an anonymous donor through an agency or through your fertility clinic, or finding a donor who has agreed to be known (or asking someone yourself). The truth is, this is a very personal decision that requires a lot of contemplation.

Keep in mind, however, that you likely won’t have to make it alone. The fact is that most clinics require that all couples or individuals using an egg donor go through fertility counseling. One advantage of talking to a therapist about the anonymity factor is that you’ll get guidance on factors that may be important to you down the line.

For instance, your counselor may ask you if you’d like to be able to tell your future child about having met his/her egg donor. In that case, you may decide that a known donor is important to you. On the other hand, many parents are more comfortable with an anonymous donor. In some cases, they simply don’t want to complicate their decision by worrying about, for instance, a personality fit. They prefer to rely on the screening processes put in place to vet donors. (Different egg donor programs have different requirements, but most conduct extensive screening on the background and health of donors.)

The emotional impact of third-party reproductive decision can be intense, so make sure you’re getting the support you need from your fertility clinic, or schedule an appointment with a Maven mental health provider who can be an added source of guidance during this time.

title.en-US: 4 ways to make IVF shots less painful & stressful

content.value: Oh, THE SHOTS. Unless you work in a pharmacy or hospital, it’s natural to be a little overwhelmed by the vials, needles, and alcohol swabs that end up in your home during an IVF cycle. Use these tips to make the injection process a little easier.
Give yourself plenty of time for the shots.

How long could it possibly take to prick yourself with a tiny needle? It may seem like something you can do in a hurry, but when you’re a newbie who is still getting used to the protocol, it could take a while. After all, not only will you need to get comfortable with the injections, but also the mixing of medications, which tend to turn your kitchen counter into a science lab. The drugs come in separate parts—i.e. needles, syringe, powder that becomes the hormone injection once mixed with the sterile water, etc. If you’re trying to squeeze in this process minutes before you have to run out the door for work, it will be more stressful than it needs to be.
Take steps to minimize soreness.

Repeatedly injecting the same small area can become uncomfortable. Find a spot to inject that’s at least an inch or two away from the last one. Placing in ice cube on the site before the shot can also make it hurt less. Tip: Put a small bandage where you just injected so that you know to avoid it the next time. It also helps to apply pressure to the site and rub gently right after injecting.
Don’t freak if you see blood.
Chances are, you inadvertently pierced a small blood vessel. It’s OK. Apply a little pressure with your alcohol swab, wipe the blood away, and cover with a bandage.
Ask for help with the trigger shot.

This is the final step in the stimulation phase of treatment—an injection that helps the developing eggs complete the maturation process and triggers ovulation. Since it’s intramuscular—it goes into the muscle, not just under the skin like the shots you take leading up to this—some women find it a bit more intimidating. Plus, there is specific area where it must be administered. But there are ways to stress less about this step. For one, during your last visit at the fertility clinic before your trigger shot, ask the nurse to use a special skin marker to indicate the spot where the needle should be inserted. Depending on the timing, you can also just ask the nurse if you can plan to come into clinic and have her administer it—or ask your partner or a friend to help.
Consider outsourcing the progesterone shots, too.

Not every fertility practice prescribes progesterone shots during IVF, but if your doctor requires them, know that these are also intramuscular, and need to be injected intramuscular into the hips or butt. Some people choose to do it themselves, but many will make their partner the shot-giver on this one, too.
Be sure to check out
MavenRx
, Maven's partnership with leading fertility pharmacies offering you discounts on your medications, one-on-one support, and more.

title.en-US: Does bed rest after IVF improve success?

content.value: Read this before you put your life on hold.

For a long time, women were prescribed a period of bed rest following an embryo transfer. And some IVF patients still think they should take to bed after a cycle. No getting up to shower, no venturing outside, no movement whatsoever (except maybe from the bed to the couch).

But here are the facts: Bed rest after IVF transfer isn’t necessary—there’s simply no evidence that it helps an embryo implant successfully. And get this: One Egyptian study found that women who were on 24 hours of bed rest after a transfer actually had a lower success rate compared with resumed their normal activities.

So if your fertility clinic encourages bed rest, find out why. It could be that they want you to take it easy and manage your stress—but, let’s face it, being on lockdown for 2 or 3 days may not be the best way to deal with your anxiety. By all means, take it easy—but if a stroll through the park helps you de-stress better than planting yourself on the couch, make sure to communicate that to your doctor.

title.en-US: Should IVF ever be the first line of treatment?

content.value: While IVF (in vitro fertilization) is often seen as a treatment of last resort, under certain circumstances, it can be the most logical first step. After all, you might think of the perfectly cultured petri dish as a stunt double—at the ready when your own uterus is out of commission or out of reach. Here are five times doctors might recommend jumping straight to IVF.
The pathway from ovary to uterus is blocked.

When your fallopian tubes aren’t an open thruway, the sperm can’t get to the egg and fertilize it. This is why women with damaged fallopian tubes or scarring from endometriosis can often be helped by IVF.
Your partner’s sperm has serious limitations.

Male-factor infertility due to mild or moderate sperm abnormalities can sometimes be successfully treated with IUI, or intrauterine insemination. But if your partner has severely low counts of sperm or very slow-moving swimmers, IVF may be considered a first step.
You want to make use of frozen eggs.
Whether you froze your eggs to defy a ticking biological clock, or to avoid any damage from, say, cancer treatments, you’ll need to fertilize them in vitro before your uterus enters the picture.
You need a surrogate.

If your uterus can’t carry a pregnancy and you want a biological child, IVF enables you to create an embryo with your egg and your partner’s sperm in a lab, and then have it implanted in the womb of a gestational carrier.
You have a known genetic disease.

Yes, some parents choose to do IVF even if they don’t have fertility issues. By growing the embryos in vitro, a doctor can test for genetic abnormalities before implantation occurs. If it’s disease-free, she’ll do the embryo transfer. If not, she’ll move on to a different embryo.

title.en-US: The truth about unexplained infertility

content.value: How the heck do you treat a problem when your doctor doesn’t know what’s wrong?

Fertility treatment is far from easy, but the path to get there is a journey of its own. To diagnose the cause of infertility, you’re subjected to a fair amount of blood work, ultrasounds, and other not-so-pleasant procedures. The hope, of course, is that at the end of this process—combined with any tests done on your partner, if you’re in a relationship—you’ll know exactly what’s keeping you from having a baby and can set a course forward rather than take shots in the dark.

So imagine the disappointment when the tests result finally arrive, but with nothing conclusive to show. This is the case with “unexplained” infertility. If you’re one of the 20% of infertility patients who receive this diagnosis, the usual culprits that prevent a couple from conceiving aren’t detected—things including advanced maternal age, underlying medical conditions, ovulation problems, sperm issues, etc. Basically, you’re left in the frustrating position of not knowing why you aren’t able to get pregnant.
Does it mean there’s nothing wrong?

No, it just means that doctors don’t know what the problem is right now. For instance, you may have tubal blockages even if the test to detect it came back normal; in reality, it simply may have failed to pick up certain problems—like blockages in the farthest reaches of the uterus, or problems in the oviducts. Likewise, when it comes to infections that could play a role in infertility, diagnostic tests tend to zero in on the big culprits, such as STDs, but less common infections can also wreak havoc on the reproductive systems. And what about the reasons that could explain infertility but aren’t at the core of the infertility evaluation? For instance, studies have found an association between celiac disease and infertility. While your clinic may be savvy enough to screen you for celiac disease if you have any of the classic symptoms, the truth is that you might not be showing any signs of celiac at all even if the condition exists.
Should you be discouraged?

No. Experts say that couples often feel discouraged when they hear there is no defined problem because they assume it means there won’t be a treatment available to them. But that’s not the case. You can still move forward with fertility treatment, and there’s even a chance you and your doctor will learn more as treatment progresses.
What are the treatment options for unexplained infertility?

There’s no one-size-fits-all approach. Your doctor will recommend the best course of treatment based on your unique situation. Options include ovulation induction, insemination (IUI) and in vitro fertilization (IVF). Generally, IVF is considered more effective, but it’s also more physically demanding—and expensive. If you’re just starting treatment, you may not need to jump to this step. Remember, no matter what your fertility specialist recommends, you’re always entitled to a second opinion by another doctor.

title.en-US: Confusing male infertility jargon—explained

content.value: Women have their own share of confusing terms that become a part of their daily life during IVF. But when it comes to male infertility, the words coming out of your doctor’s mouth—or your partner’s urologists’—can be even more baffling. Not understanding what’s happening can make the process even more overwhelming, so here’s a quick cheat sheet to help you decode the lingo.
Aspermia.
No semen is produced.
Azoospermia.
A guy can produce semen but there’s no sperm in that fluid.
Asthenospermia.
There’s sperm in the semen but most of them don’t swim well.
Oligospermia.
There’s sperm in the semen but they’re in low numbers.
Necrospermia.
There’s sperm in semen but they’re dead or motionless.
Pyospermia.
There’s sperm in the semen but they’re swimming amid white blood cells, which is a sign of infection.
Hypospadias.
The opening of the penis is not at the end but on the underside of the shaft, which could lead to problems with intercourse.
Retrograde ejaculation.
The semen enters the bladder (and creates a cloudy urine post-sex) instead of being ejaculated out of the penis.
Epididymitis.
An inflammation of the epididymis (the duct behind the testis).
Orchitis.
An inflammation of the testicles.
Varicoceles
Enlarged veins in the scrotum. In some cases, they’re benign, in others, they can be the culprit behind low sperm production and poor sperm quality.

title.en-US: Are sore breasts a sign of pregnancy after embryo transfer?

content.value: We tackle a Maven member’s question about the 2WW (two week wait) in IVF.

Given everything you’ve gone through up to this point, it’s normal to wonder if there are any signs you can look for that might mean you’re pregnant. But unfortunately any early clues—such as sore or tender breasts—aren’t a reliable way to predict the results of the pregnancy test. Remember, the process of IVF involves taking a number of hormones and medications, so some of what you’re feeling immediately after the transfer may simply be a result of things leveling out in your body. Progesterone hormone therapies can lead to breast changes whether there is a pregnancy or not.
This might sound like a bummer, but it isn’t to discourage you—it’s simply to help you avoid false hope. As hard as it is, waiting for your pregnancy test in the doctor’s office at the 2-week mark—and trying your best not to read into your body’s quirks—is your best bet for avoiding an emotional roller coaster right now.

title.en-US: IUI tips to increase your chances of pregnancy success

content.value: In an IUI, or intrauterine insemination, sperm gets an assist—being deposited into the cervix as opposed to the vagina. But the sperm still has to swim up to meet and fertilize the egg. That’s why some women wonder if there’s anything they can do to boost the chances of that happening. It turns out, there are a few things worth trying.
Avoid lubricants during post-trigger-shot sex.

A trigger shot is a hormone injection that gives follicles a final boost. It will cause ovulation approximately 36 hours after, allowing your doctor to better time the insemination. Depending on your situation, your doctor might suggest having sex after you receive the trigger shot to boost your chances for conception. If you get the green light for sex, you may want to skip the lubricant. According to a Cleveland Clinic study, certain popular brands (including K-Y Jelly, Replens, FemGlide, Astroglide) can compromise sperm’s ability to move and function properly. Four out of the five commercial lubricants tested in the study impaired sperm’s overall motility, and this effect was seen whether or not a product contained spermicide. Non-commercial options (such as glycerin, olive/vegetable oil) are also no-gos. Only one product the team tested seems to have little effect on guy’s swimmers: Pre-Seed Lubricant.
Stay hydrated.

Your body makes sure that your vital organs get enough water first, before it starts hydrating things like hair, skin, and, yes, your cervical mucus. Here’s why you want to make sure there’s enough H20 to go around during an IUI: It turns out that high water content can make cervical mucus more “sperm friendly.” With the right composition—something like the consistency of egg white—your mucus can help those swimmers move along around the time of ovulation.
Limit processed foods.

Always a smart thing health-wise, but it’s especially helpful when you’re trying to conceive. Sperm are partial to cervical mucus with a pH level of around seven—and sticking with non-sugary, non-processed foods will help keep mucus to sperm-friendly territory instead of making it too acidic.

title.en-US: Read this to avoid IVF medication mistakes

content.value: Must-read advice before taking your fertility meds.

Chances are, you’ve picked up medications at the local pharmacy—or arranged for them to be delivered to your home—countless times over the years. But with IVF, this process is a little different. You’ll likely be juggling close to a half dozen meds (if not more), not to mention all the needles and syringes. Given the high cost of fertility drugs and everything that’s on the line, it’s important to avoid medication mistakes—which, sadly, do happen. This advice can help.
Choose your pharmacy wisely.

Not all pharmacies carry the drugs that you need for an IVF cycle. Fertility clinics often have a list of recommended pharmacies; if it works with your insurance, try to pick one of those so that you’re working with a place that’s well-versed with fertility-related prescriptions. Check out
MavenRx
, Maven's partnership with leading fertility pharmacies offering you discounts on your medications, one-on-one support, and more.
Get a print-out of your Rx for your own records.

Chances are, your clinic will send an electronic prescription directly to your pharmacy, but it’s crucial that you know exactly what you need to take, too. Review each item with your nurse and make sure you understand the purpose of each medication. Ask for a copy of the name and dose of every med you need to take. You’ll use this to make sure you’ve received all the right things at the pharmacy.
Open the box or bag of IVF meds before you leave the pharmacy.

Check that your name is on the label. Believe it or not, medications do get doled out to the wrong recipients. According to an Institute for Safe Medication Practices study, this happens in about 1 out of every 1,000 prescriptions filled—but you don’t want to be that 1! Then, check to see that the drugs and doses match the list that was given to you by your clinic.
Rely on your pharmacist to translate anything that’s confusing.

If the instructions on the label have left you scratching your head, ask your pharmacist to decode things for you. They can help you understand how to take medications properly and how they need to be stored.
If your stuff is delivered to your home, open the bag as soon as you receive it.

Don’t wait till next week or when you think you’ll need it. Again, confirm that everything on your list was sent and in the proper doses, paying special attention to drug names (many can appear similar), units, and the precise placement of decimal points. If you catch any mistakes, call the pharmacy to let them know right away.
Before you actually use the medicine, check its appearance.

Is it similar to how it was explained to you in your practice session? (For instance, is it a pill and not a liquid?) Take a picture, so that if you need a refill in the future, you know exactly what to expect.
Be on high alert for any adverse reactions.

Of course, if this is your first cycle, it’s hard to know what to expect. But if something feels off, don’t assume that “this is what’s supposed to happen.” If you experience discomfort or notice any peculiar responses after taking a drug, call your doctor.

title.en-US: What should I do with my leftover fertility medication?

content.value: Whether you’re pregnant from IVF, taking a break from the process, or going another route, it’s common to wonder what the heck to do with the sheer quantity of fertility meds that remain. Here, we tackle some questions about your options regarding those leftovers.
I spent hundreds of dollars on these meds. Can I return them for a refund?
Unfortunately, no. By law, prescription medications can’t be returned, period (unless, of course, the pharmacy made an error in filling the Rx).
I noticed a website where people have posted their leftover meds for sale online. Can I off-load my drugs in this way, too?
This one is a firm no! The truth is, people are selling drugs online at the risk of a felony conviction, since this practice is illegal.
Honestly, I’d hate to have these medications go to waste by throwing away. Can I donate it them somewhere?

Possibly. Ask your clinic if they’re part of a donation program and if they can take them off your hands. If not, you can look into finding such a program yourself. Several states have enacted legislation addressing drug donation and reuse, with the goal of getting medication to people in need. To see if your state participates—and what the protocol entails—visit the National Conference of State Legislatures site. If you can’t participate in donation program and need to dispose of the drugs, bring your medication to a “Controlled Substance Public Disposal Location.” Click on this tool to find a drugstore near you that can help you out.
These meds are taking up an entire cabinet and I need to clear up the space ASAP! Can I just throw them out?

No, sorry. You never know who or what will get into your garbage. You have to follow the Food and Drug Administration’s guidelines for disposing drugs with the household trash. Rip off any labels with personal information on it and mix the meds with something that’ll deter tampering—such as used coffee grounds and kitty litter. For detailed instructions, visit the FDA site here.

title.en-US: IVF & insurance coverage: 4 tips to help you lower cost

content.value: The number of people turning to fertility clinics for help getting pregnant is on the rise. At the same time, hopeful parents are often left to discover that a treatment such as IVF (in vitro fertilization) may be
prohibitively expensive

. Each cycle could tally $10,000 to $15,000, and multiple rounds may be needed before one results in a baby. Keep reading to understand how insurance might help you keep costs down—and how to maximize your benefits.
Get to know how insurance coverage differs across state lines.

According the National Conference of State Legislators, only 16 states require insurance providers to cover infertility treatments as of 2018—and only a handful of those states require that insurance providers cover IVF treatments specifically. To keep up on the laws in your area, you can go to the website of RESOLVE, a fertility patient advocacy group, and use their handy state-by-state look-up tool. It provides a list of states, their policies, and exemptions. If your state’s paltry benefits make you want to consider relocating (#half-kidding), where should you go? According to RESOLVE, the most treatment-friendly states include Connecticut, Illinois, Maryland, Massachusetts, New Jersey, and Rhode Island. And hopefully the rest of the country will soon start to follow their lead.
If you’re lucky enough to be covered, read the fine print.

Take a good look at your plan to see exactly what’s listed under “infertility services.” There may be stipulations. For instance, you may be required to undergo a less expensive treatment first—i.e. several round of IUI—before you’re eligible for IVF coverage. You may also need to use only certain brands of fertility medication, or select the insurer’s “preferred” labs. What’s more, certain insurance plans might cover IVF but set a ceiling—make sure you understand what contributes toward that upper limit. Check out
MavenRx
, Maven's partnership with leading fertility pharmacies offering you discounts on your medications, one-on-one support, and more.
Double (or triple) check with your provider before making medical decisions.

If you’re still a little unsure about your benefits after reading the fine print on your policy, you’re not alone; the language insurers use can be incredibly confusing. Don’t assume anything. After you’ve done your best to digest the info, call your carrier and confirm your coverage. If what’s being relayed to you doesn’t seem to match what your state mandates, press for details. Ask your insurance rep to explain the reason for any discrepancies (for instance, your employer or insurance carrier meets an exemption).
Look for loopholes or workarounds.

Even if the actual IVF procedure isn’t covered by your insurance, other aspects of your medical care (such as certain drugs, diagnostic exams, and blood tests) may be reimbursed. Don’t be afraid to ask questions and figure out the best way to keep costs down. If you have an HSA (health savings account) or an FSA (flexible savings account), these are also options you may want to consider; using pretax dollars to cover fertility expenses can save you money at a time when every penny matters.

title.en-US: How much does IVF really cost?

content.value: As any woman who has undergone fertility treatments such as in vitro fertilization will tell you: The emotional and physical challenges can be immense. But equally enormous is the financial toll. One survey found that 44% of people incurred more than $10,000 in debt to pay for treatment. Another study zeroing in on women aged 25 to 34 found that that 1 in 4 women people took on over $30,000 in debt. But where does that money go? Here’s a breakdown of how IVF costs shake out.
A basic IVF cycle costs tens of thousands of dollars.

On average, an IVF cycle hovers around $12,000—not including diagnostic exams. (Before you even start IVF, doctors must perform a battery of tests to confirm that you’re a good candidate.) Then there are the additional costs for fertility medications, with injectable drugs costing anywhere between $1,000 and $3,500 or more. (Check out
MavenRx
, Maven's partnership with leading fertility pharmacies offering you discounts on your medications, one-on-one support, and more.)
Add-ons increase the price tag.

If you need extra procedures, or choose to do them electively, those will definitely tack on extra costs. Here are some examples and how they might affect the final bill:
ICSI, a lab technique to help fertilization occur by injecting a sperm into the egg: Roughly $1500.
PGD, or preimplantation genetic diagnosis, a procedure used prior to implantation to help identify genetic defects within embryos: Could run about $1400.

Embryo storage—because if you’re keeping any remaining embryos “cryopreserved”—aka frozen—to potentially use in future cycles, you have to pay to store them: Costs vary, depending on the facility, but a rough average is about $800 per year.
You might need to multiply these figures if the first try doesn’t work.

Keep in mind, for women under age 40, there’s only a 32% chance that the first cycle will be successful; for those age 40 to 42, the odds are only 12%. That means most women will have to do more than one round of IVF—and double, triple, or quadruple the bill—if they want to increase their odds of bringing home a baby. As if this wasn’t breaking the bank already, there’s another reason additional treatment cycles could become more costly as you go along: If a previous round of IVF didn’t work, your doctor might prescribe higher doses of fertility drugs in the next go. And more medication = more money.
The bottom line

: You can't put a price on the joy of having a baby. But you can’t ignore the very real cost barriers involved with fertility treatment. Sadly, as of 2018, only a handful of states required insurance providers to cover IVF. That means people who decide to undergo treatment are forced to make hard decisions—including how long to try, and what lengths they’ll go to to stick with the protocol. Some people clean out their savings accounts or borrow against their retirement; others rack up credit card debt or take out loans. Proponents of increased insurance coverage hope that the rest of the states will start to catch up soon—because removing the financial concerns from baby-making decisions can only lead to better outcomes. We couldn’t agree more.

title.en-US: 4 sneaky ways IVF might make you feel bloated

content.value: If you’re doing IVF and your jeans start to become a little snug, don’t freak out. While not everyone will feel as if they’ve gained weight, many women do notice some extra puffiness or poundage while undergoing fertility treatment. It’s normal and, chances are, your body will shift back to its regular size once you’ve ended your cycle—unless, of course, you get pregnant (in which case, you can joyfully look forward to trading in your clothes for a maternity wardrobe. In the meantime, though, here are a few explanations for the bloat.
1. Your ovaries got bigger during the ovarian stimulation phase.

With hormones, your ovaries expand from the size of a walnut to the size of an orange or grapefruit-size. Naturally, your belly might be a bit extended during this time, making it hard to zip up. Our advice: Make stretchy pants your friend.
2. Your follicles remain full (for a while) after the eggs are removed.

Unfortunately, your ovaries don’t snap back to normal size after the egg retrieval. In fact, after the procedure, the bloating may get worse thanks to blood and hormones which fill the follicles once the eggs vacate. The result: more bulge. But the good news is that you should gradually start feeling better in about a week or so.
3. You’ve given up exercise.

Typically, women are advised to keep exercise moderate during IVF, and they may be asked to pause their workouts completely for a while. If you’re used to doing lots of calorie-burning exercise and you suddenly take things down several notches (while your eating remains the same), that might be explain why a few extra pounds show up on the scale. Try not to stress about this—you’ll be back on track shortly. And in the meantime, ask your doctor about low-impact exercise options if you’d like to stay a little more active.
4. You’re stress-eating.

In taxing situations—and IVF definitely qualifies as one—many of us may find our hands reaching for snacks more often, or taking a little too much comfort in comfort foods. Cut yourself some slack (this is not the time to go on a restrictive diet and cut out entire food groups!), but try to focus on nutritious foods that will keep your body strong through this process.

title.en-US: How to stay focused at work when going through infertility

content.value: Client meetings. Quarterly reviews. Expense reports. Whatever work tasks demand your attention, it can be hard to focus on them when there’s so much going on in your personal life right now. What can you do to tame the mental distraction and feel more productive during an infertility journey? Try these strategies.
Schedule mental health breaks throughout the day.

Focusing on your work will be easier when you can look forward to set times for “planned distraction.” Block out one or two breaks during each workday—perhaps 10 minutes in the morning, a half hour lunch break, and 10 minutes in the afternoon (whatever works with your company culture and policy). You can use this time to let your mind wander, make any necessary calls to your fertility clinic, call a friend, etc.
Make a daily checklist before you get to the office.

The idea is to arrive at your workplace ready to execute, rather than still be deciding what you are going to do. It’s much easier to lose focus when you’re in indecision mode. Remember, your focus will be terrible if you create a list that’s unrealistically long. Boil it down to the essentials. You can also set a timer for each task and tell yourself, “I’ll give myself 15 minutes to do whatever I want to do when each task is done, then dive back into my list.”
Remove online distractions.

When you’re diagnosed with a fertility issue, it’s normal to want to connect with other people going through something similar and hear their stories. But when you’re diving into online forums or falling into other Internet rabbit holes during the work day, it can be hard to get anything done. If you find yourself wasting too much time online, consider looking into services that work with your internet browser to block the tempting websites.
Wear noise-cancelling headphones.

If you’re trying to head home (or to the fertility clinic) at a set time, you may need to take steps to minimize distractions from your coworkers. If you’re constantly being interrupted by colleagues who simply want to chit-chat, considering wearing headphones—otherwise known as the universal sign for “I’m busy right now.”
Get to the office early.

The truth is, you may be used to getting up early if your protocol involves early-A.M. visits to take note of your treatment’s progress. (For instance, during ovarian stimulation, your doctor will need to monitor the development of the follicles.) Since you may be growing accustomed to waking up at the crack of dawn, consider getting to the office before your usual start-time (if you have flexible hours). Tackle the tasks that require the greatest amount of focus before the rest of the team arrives.
Meditate.

Do this for 10 minutes before you go to bed, when you get up, or (if you’re not driving) even on the way to work. Many studies have suggested that meditation or similar mindfulness practices can help you stay in the the moment and focus. Bonus: You may feel calmer and less stressed—and ready to take on whatever comes your way.

title.en-US: How your job could affect your chances of getting pregnant

content.value: Does the success of infertility treatments depend on the field you work in? Maybe a little. Let’s explain.

Some jobs offer better perks than others, but you’ve probably never thought “helps you get pregnant” could be an employee benefit. Well, a study by FertilityIQ analyzed data from over 1,000 women and found some surprising trends in the work/fertility connection. It turns out that certain professions were linked with better IVF outcomes. Teachers, for instance, were two times more likely to achieve IVF success.

What could it be about teachers’ day-to-day life that gives them an edge in fertility treatment? They pointed to a work environment that was conducive to prioritizing their care: “Colleagues are happy to talk openly about their fertility experiences, are able to offer suggestions for better doctors, and teachers can use the summer months to undergo multiple cycles of treatment,” the report said.

Don’t worry—having a job where you don’t get a few months off doesn’t put you at a disadvantage. In the study, women with careers in sales, marketing or public relations also showed success rates similar to teachers—presumably because they also found social support (they expressed being able to talk about infertility with their colleagues) within the workplace.

Meanwhile, those who held jobs in investment banking or engineering were nearly 60% less likely to report success with IVF than their peers in other occupations. According to Fertility IQ’s analysis, these workers often said they felt they had to keep treatment a secret from their bosses and colleagues. And, let’s face it: Considering that an IVF cycle requires being on a tight timeline, sometimes the only way to adhere to the protocol is to make adjustments (even if they’re very temporary) in your work schedule.

It’s important to note that this is just one study, and IVF success certainly has to do with many variables. (Translation: No need to quit your job and become a teacher!) But if you’re finding that your job is becoming a hindrance in your treatment plan, know that you can get support. Maven career coaches are available to chat with you anytime; they can give you pointers about how to juggle clinic appointments with your work schedule, and also help you navigate relationships with your boss/colleagues. Bottom line: Balancing your treatment and your livelihood can be tricky, but it doesn’t have to be impossible.

title.en-US: Trouble losing weight for IVF? these tips can help

content.value: Struggling to get pregnant isn’t easy, and finding out that your weight is a factor can make things even more devastating and confusing. If your doctor has suggested that you lose weight before you start treatment, you might naturally be feeling overwhelmed. Maven practitioner Nicole Avena, Ph.D.— a neuroscientist and expert in nutrition—says that women often feel so overwhelmed that they don’t know where to start. Luckily, this process doesn’t have to be so daunting. Here, she offers four tips to get you on the right track.
Keep a food diary

It sounds tedious, but logging your food and beverage intake has proven benefits. Research shows that people who maintain food journals are more likely to be successful in losing weight. Just make sure that you don’t rely on “mental notes”—use your phone or a piece of paper. The good news is you don’t have to write things down obsessively or log into a food-tracking app every time you take a sip or bite. Even recapping your meals and snacks once at the end of the day can keep you on track. The most important thing is to be honest with yourself and be willing to look at the food choices you’ve made (without judgment, of course). Consider recording how you felt each time you reached for something to eat, too. This may also help you understand your relationship with food, which is just as important for weight loss as the quality of your diet.
Stock up on healthy snacks

Let’s face it: Hunger doesn’t warn us when it’s about to strike. It could hit at any time, and if you don’t plan for it, you’ll be left wondering what you should eat. To make sure that a snack attack doesn’t sabotage your weight loss efforts, try to stock up on healthy options that you can grab without much thought whether you’re in your car, at your desk, or lounging at home. This will help prevent the lure of the vending machine at the office, the fast-food drive through on the road, and any processed foods hiding in your kitchen pantry. Some good snacks to keep around: low-sugar protein bars, fruit, Greek yogurt, and string cheese. And you can never go wrong with veggies like cherry tomatoes or pre-cut carrots and red peppers, plus a bit of hummus for dipping.
Break down a bigger goal into smaller ones

Sometimes losing weight can seem like an impossible task because our goals are too big or too vague. If your doctor has recommended you try to lose some weight, your thinking may only go this far: “I want to lose 15 pounds.” OK, you want to lose 15 pounds, but how? What will you do to get there? A good doctor will be a teammate, but not every practitioner knows how to arm her patients with both the moral support and the how-tos. My advice: Set small, attainable, and measurable goals on a weekly basis will make it that much easier to achieve success. For example, “I will prepare my breakfast the night before work so I can eat something healthy when I get to the office each morning.” A goal like this is measurable—you either packed your breakfast or you didn’t. And it’s also realistic—so you’re not setting yourself up to “fail” and throw a wrench in your morale.
PS: Sometimes you know what to do, but you still need some extra support.
Book an appointment
with a Maven provider if you’d like some one-on-one coaching during this time.

title.en-US: Can infertility support groups help you get pregnant?

content.value: They may not change the situation in the IVF lab but they can help you cope with everything that comes up during treatment.

Let’s face it: As much as people want to help, if they haven’t experienced infertility themselves, they may come up short. Hence all the advice to “just relax” or “stop thinking about the problem and you’ll get pregnant.” In addition to giving you a safe space to vent about other people’s cluelessness, infertility support groups can be an important lifeline—but one that many people don’t take advantage of. Skim this list and you may be inspired to join one today.
1. You’ll be reminded that you’re not alone.

When you’re at that age when it seems that “everyone” around you is pregnant or raising kids, it nice to have a crowd of women reminding you that, no, in fact, not everyone is popping out babies easily. You’ll see living examples of people like you who need some extra help in the conception department.
2. You’ll be more in-the-know.

Think of your support group as another potential source of helpful information. Of course it’s always best to ask your provider about any medical questions, but if you want to learn practical tips or ask what it really feels like to go through IVF, there’s no better expert than a woman who’s in the thick of it herself. Trading information and advice may provide you with a sense of control and reduce any feelings of helplessness.
3. You’ll send away the blues.

Often, we feel we need to keep fertility struggles quiet, so we may limit our social interactions and become isolated—and, in turn, depressed. Belonging to a support group can motivate us to get out of the house and speak openly and honestly, even when we’d rather not chit-chat with people who don’t understand. Just this act of maintaining a connection to others can enhance your mood and overall well-being during treatment.
4. You’ll feel validated.

When you’re in the throes of infertility, you may have days where you wonder: Am I right to feel sad? Is it OK to feel angry? Does it make sense to feel out-of-this-world exhausted? Support groups allow people to share feelings and experiences that may seem too strange or too difficult to reveal to even your partner or your closest friends. And when you do that, you’ll likely get a lot of reassurance that what you’re experiencing is 100% normal. As one woman put it: “Sharing my bottled-up and sometimes dark thoughts helped me release my negativity and made each day happier.”
Want to get connect with other women going through infertility but don’t know where to start? Go to the website of
Resolve: the National Infertility Association
; there you’ll be able to check out in-person meet-ups in your community or clinic-affiliated hospital.

title.en-US: The (new) facts about acupuncture for fertility

content.value: Get the scientific scoop before you get pricked.

Acupuncture has become a popular treatment that women turn to before and during IVF. The reasons? Both to increase the chances of a successful IVF cycle (leading to a pregnancy and birth), as well as to keep stress levels in check. Previous research including some smaller studies suggested that acupuncture could be a worthwhile effort and improve outcomes.

But a recent study—a randomized clinical trial including 824 IVF patients in Australia—found that the procedure does not improve pregnancy rates. In the study, scientists gave half of the group traditional acupuncture treatments, while the control group received “sham acupuncture” (needles weren’t fully inserted and were not placed in real acupuncture points). As for the timing of the treatments: Women received acupuncture a week before their follicle stimulation, and then again before and after their embryo transfer date.

The results: There were 74 live births among those who received acupuncture treatments, and 72 births in the control group. In scientific terms, this was called “statistically insignificant”—meaning that the acupuncture didn’t make a significant difference in live birth outcomes.
Does that mean you should skip the needles?

Not necessarily. Acupuncture can still give you a well-being boost—helping you feel calmer and less stressed. Considering the emotional highs and lows involved in a fertility journey, this may be reason enough to get poked. Still, it’s important to know the science about what will and won’t help you achieve a pregnancy and live birth.

title.en-US: Are "baby or your money back" deals a good idea?

content.value: IVF is a gamble. But here’s what you need to know before you place a bigger bet than you need to.

IVF and “bargain” were rarely uttered in the same sentence until some fertility clinics started getting savvy about their marketing. “Baby or your money back” deals usually work like this: The patient pays a big, flat fee up-front (say, $50,000), and in return, the doctor agrees to do as many rounds of IVF as it takes for the couple to have a baby. If the couple doesn’t end up with a child, a full refund is issued.

To understand why this might even appeal to fertility patients, you have to remember that IVF is often a numbers game. You may have success on the first try, or you may need four, five, six (or more) cycles to have a baby. The price per cycle varies, but with an average cost of $12,000, four rounds of IVF tallies close to $50K. Of course, if you do have a baby on your first, second, or third attempt, the catch is that the lump sum you forked over initially is lost. But if it does take you seven or eight rounds, you could end up with a sizable savings.
If it seems too good to be true, it probably is.

Don’t forget, the people offering you these deals know a lot about you. They also likely know more about your odds of IVF success than you do. It’s the reason that not everyone qualifies for these offers, and typically women who have the best chance of IVF success are the ones that are eligible (which of course makes the most business sense).

Restrictions will vary, but one clinic, for instance, offers patients the option to pay a flat-fee for up to six IVF cycles on the condition that women must complete all cycles cycles by age 40. Those who are 41 and older can participate if they are using donor eggs (but donor eggs aren’t included in the cost). Of course, it’s women over 40 using their own eggs who have the greatest risk for IVF failure and who would benefit most from the money-back option.

Another factor you might not realize until you read the fine print: The flat-fees may not include everything involved in a treatment cycle. For instance, diagnostic assessments, drugs, and other procedures could be an extra cost.
The bottom line
: While some women might benefit from these deals, the odds aren’t great. Sadly, the House usually wins—even when the casino, in this case, is your fertility clinic.

title.en-US: How to cope with being exhausted during fertility treatment

content.value: You often hear about pregnancy fatigue—but there’s also such a thing as trying-to-conceive exhaustion. Here, Maven practitioner Nicole Avena, Ph.D.— a neuroscientist and expert in nutrition—explains what’s happening, and how to stay awake.
The connection between fertility treatments and fatigue

The side-effects of fertility treatment are individual to each woman, but being more tired than usual is a common complaint. Some people feel fatigued because of hormone changes and all the running around they’re doing, like to-and-from the clinic. Others are driven to exhaustion simply by having a lot of difficult emotions to process. Making matters worse, the stress of trying to conceive can rob you of shut-eye—and even if you do manage to doze off, getting quality Zzz’s could be a challenge.
Is caffeine the answer?

The obvious solution to feeling lethargic all the time may be to reach for an extra cup of coffee (or two, or three...) every day. But regularly upping your caffeine intake can backfire over time—both by increasing anxiety and disrupting your sleep.
How much caffeine is OK?

The advice will differ for everyone, so check in with your doctor to find out what’s right for you. Some reproductive endocrinologists recommend capping your intake at around 200 mg of caffeine a day. Caffeine levels can vary widely based on the type of bean and brewing method, but to give you an example, a 12-ounce dark roast coffee at Starbucks contains just under 200mg. Keep in mind that learning to cut back on caffeine now may make it easier to wean yourself off when you do become pregnant. Most medical professionals agree that consuming small amounts of caffeine while expecting is safe, but large quantities should be avoided.
Any advice to cut down on the extra sips?

Try swapping coffee for some herbal tea, especially after midday. Tip: The scent of peppermint tea may help you feel more awake. And make sure you’re drinking enough water, since dehydration can make you feel more tired. If these tactics don’t work, remember, a “nappuccino” is always an option.

title.en-US: Does drinking soda affect fertility treatment success?

content.value: Get the scientific lowdown before you sip.

For those working hard to curb their sugar consumption, artificial sweeteners often seem like a godsend. But it turns out that using faux sweeteners in coffee and tea and replacing “real” soda with the diet kind isn’t a great idea—especially when it comes to fertility-treatment success.
A 2016 Federal University of Sao Paulo study of 524 women undergoing IVF showed a connection between artificial sweeteners and lower rates of implantation.
Does this mean real sugar gets the green light?

Not exactly. While embryo deformity was more strongly related to consuming “fake” sugars, a woman’s eggs don’t discriminate: In the study, sipping soft drinks of any kind—whether they were made with sugar or artificial sweeteners—was linked with poorer egg quality.
What’s the bottom line?

This is one of those “more studies need to be done” scenarios where scientists don’t feel comfortable drawing any hard-and-fast conclusions. But based on mounting evidence over the past decade, many experts agree that limiting the amount of diet soda, sweeteners, and sugar in your diet is a worthwhile goal overall—and it certainly can’t hurt your chances of becoming pregnant.

title.en-US: How to survive IVF: Tips from women who’ve been through it

content.value: As they say, IVF is a journey—an often bumpy, winding road of a journey. Your best resource may be another woman who’s been through it, and through experience, managed to find tricks that make the wild ride a little more manageable. Here, 6 of the best little tips we’ve heard.
Let the nurse’s call go to voicemail.

Once you start taking injectable medications, you’ll have daily or almost-daily ultrasounds and blood tests to check the number and size of your follicles. After those crack-of-dawn doctor’s visits, you’ll get a call from the nurse, usually in the afternoon, with detailed instructions about the exact dosage of each injectable drug that you should take the next day, based on the monitoring results. One woman told us that answering those calls was too overwhelming, even if she was just sitting at her desk at work. And if she happened to be out and about running errands or on her way to a meeting, then forget about it. Letting these calls go to voicemail proved much less stressful—she was able to listen (and re-listen) to the info, and not worry if she heard everything right.
Clear your schedule.

Injections every day. Running to have bloodwork and ultrasounds done every other day. A few not-exactly-comfortable procedures in between. IVF is both physically draining and time consuming. Many IVF veterans’ solution to this has been to keep life really simple during each cycle. That means not over-packing your schedule with too many social or business commitments. A hectic couple of weeks will only make an already exhausting experience more exhausting. You’re better off using any “down” time to fit in a restorative class, meditate, or just plain relax.
DIY your own medical binder.

You’ll be surprised by how quickly health documents start to accumulate, and many IVF patients have found it helpful to keep all their paperwork organized and in one place. Stick any printouts, your treatment protocols, doctors’ business cards, pharmacist numbers, and any other informational papers in one section of the binder or folder. Then stash all billing-related paperwork and receipts on the other side. Besides helping you keep a paper trail, this will also make it easier to access anything you may need to submit to your insurance company later. Extra credit for fun folders. A Wonder Woman fan? Go for it. Women have also reported covering their binder with fun, uplifting colors and designs. “I’d draw a sun and happy flower—always just hoping for the best possible news,” explains one woman who is now a mom to two little girls conceived via IVF.
Get a fridge bin.

This helps you keep chilled meds in one place in the refrigerator. “It beats searching behind the take-out cartons for that last vial Menopur you thought you had,” says one woman who underwent two IVF cycles and now has a young son.
Keep a notebook specifically for IVF notes.

Bring it with you to your doctor’s visits. You can use it to jot down any questions you have beforehand, and also take notes during the appointment. Keep this notebook handy so you can reach for it anytime you get a call from your RE or nurse.
Stop Googling!

Turning to Dr. Google in the midst of an IVF cycle is just a recipe for accessing confusing, unhelpful, and just-plain panic-inducing information—or, in many cases, misinformation. “I wasted so much time searching for hints as to whether my hormone numbers were promising or not,” confesses one woman. “It made me so anxious that looking back I wish I would’ve cancelled my internet service during my cycle.” You don’t have to go to that extreme—but do know that if you’re wondering about something and want an immediate answer or just some support, you can always text or video chat with a Maven practitioner. They’ll help you gain some perspective without inducing “cyberchonrdia.”

title.en-US: I’ve smoked for a long time. Should I still quit before IVF?

content.value: Is the damage is already done, what’s the harm in continuing to pick up the cigs? Let us explain.

Studies show that it takes longer for women who have a history of smoking cigarettes to conceive, and smokers also have lower pregnancy rates with fertility treatments. (Side note: Puffing up impacts men’s fertility too—with decreased sperm counts and lower sperm motility affecting male smokers.) Unfortunately, some damage can’t be undone. Smoking accelerates the rate of egg loss—a supply that’s finite. But luckily it’s not all bad news, and creating healthier habits now will help reverse some of the negative effects of being a former smoker. What’s more, stopping now will prevents years of further damage to your ovaries, and decrease your risk of miscarrying after getting pregnant.
How soon before beginning fertility treatments should I stop?

The sooner the better. While no one can put a finger on exactly how long it takes after quitting smoking for fertility levels to “bounce back” (at least as much as they can), your doctor may recommend a period of being cigarette-free before doing IVF or another treatment. Depending on your age and other factors, delaying treatment for too long may not be ideal.
What if I’ve had trouble dropping the habit in the past?

You’re not alone. Despite the “just quit” messages out there, abandoning long-held habits cold-turkey can be very difficult. Case in point: Smokers make an average 15 attempts before they become ex-smokers. If you’ve tried to ditch the cigs and are having difficulty, talk to your doctor or book an appointment with a Maven provider to discuss a cessation plan that includes the right kind of support.

title.en-US: Can your ovaries really twist if you exercise during IVF?

content.value: Get the facts you need to know.

While it’s very rare, it’s true that you can end up with a twisted ovary. Fertility treatments cause the ovaries to grow in size, and the larger your ovaries are, the greater chance they have of twisting (doctors call this “ovarian torsion”). Vigorous activities—for example, running, bouncing, or doing headstands in yoga class—can increase your likelihood of experiencing a torsion.
Why is a twisted ovary such a big deal?
When torsion occurs, the ovary cuts off its own blood supply—and that can cause the ovary to die.
How is a twisted ovary treated?
In some cases, the ovary “untwists” by itself. But more often than not, immediate surgical intervention is required to flip the ovary back to its normal position.
What are the symptoms?
Severe, sudden pain in the lower abdomen is often a big clue. Cramping, nausea, and vomiting may also occur. If you experience any of these symptoms, call your doctor or get to the E.R. right away.
This sounds scary–should I avoid exercise altogether?

We won’t downplay it: Having a twisted ovary is a big deal. But remember that it’s a rare condition. Your reproductive endocrinologist will likely put some limits on your fitness routine to keep you safe and prevent this from happening—especially around the time of your egg retrieval and embryo transfer. But as long as you follow your doctor’s workout advice and use common sense (i.e. no trampoline class or training for a marathon), you can usually stay moderately active through most phases of fertility treatment.

title.en-US: 12 smart rules to follow if you’re traveling during IVF

content.value: Whether you’re traveling for business or for fun, stuffing your essentials into an approved carry-on is always a Rubik’s cube of a feat. Now add your IVF paraphernalia to that, and you’ve got a real puzzle on your hands—and you haven’t even made it past security yet! Fortunately, there are a few sanity-saving tricks and tips that’ll get you on your way—and in step with your cycle once you’ve arrived. Check this list out before you check in.
1. Plot out each day.

Jot down every dose of every medication you need onto a calendar, and confirm with your doctor what you need to bring. Gather it all up into a container. Pack a few extra doses, just in case you lose something or your doctor tweaks your medication amounts while you’re away. (Check out
MavenRx
, Maven's partnership with leading fertility pharmacies offering you discounts on your medications, one-on-one support, and more.)
2. Don’t forget to bring the stuff you need to take your injectable medications.
Think sanitizer, syringes, needles, sharps container, alcohol swabs, bandages.
3. Call the airline to explain what you’ll need to bring, and why.
Record the time of your call and the name of the person you spoke with. Bring that info to the airport in case you run into any problems.
4. Get a permission slip from your clinic.
You know, so you can wave it in front of security while you and your drugs sail right on through.
5. Keep your healthcare provider’s phone and email address handy.
This way, you can easily get in touch if you have questions while away.
6. Ask your doctor to recommend a fertility clinic, pharmacy, and hospital in the city you’ll be staying in.
Do this just in case you need monitoring or an emergency arises (better safe than sorry!). Tip: Don’t forget your insurance card.
7. Get a portable cooler for meds that need chilling.
Before your trip, test it out to confirm that it indeed maintains its content at the right temperature.
8. Stay at a place that has a fridge in your room.
It will beat hunting down an ice machine (and, Murphy’s Law, there’s a chance it will be broken).
9. Bring your trigger shot.

Also bring the trigger-shot needle (which is a different needle than the one used to take your other medications). You may need to administer the trigger-short earlier than expected, so do this even if you’re not scheduled to give yourself this shot while you’re away.
10. Confirm your dosage schedule.
Ask your provider how to handle a time difference if there is one.
11. Program an alarm in your phone to remind you to take your meds every day.
It’s easy to get sidetracked when you’re on vacation or attending a work conference.
12. Avoid the alcohol.

It’s so tempting to knock a few back when you’re on vacation or when your colleagues are imbibing on a work trip. But studies suggest that alcohol during a cycle may lower the odds of pregnancy. It’s so easy to go overboard on vacation that it may be better to abstain altogether.

title.en-US: Does IVF produce more baby boys than girls?

content.value: Pop quiz: In all matters of conception, you have a 50/50 chance of giving birth to a boy or a girl—just as you have a 50/50 chance of tossing a coin and getting heads instead of tails, right? Not exactly. Keep reading for a few interesting facts.

In a spontaneous conception, you have a 51% chance of giving birth to a boy and a 49% chance of having a girl. This is considered the normal “sex ratio”—aka Mother Nature’s way of keeping things interesting.
If you conceive via IVF, those stats skew even more male than female. A 2016 review looking at the percentage of boys and girls born from IVF found that 53.1% were boys.

Set on a baby girl (or boy)? The same test that’s designed to increase the chances of a successful pregnancy by screening for chromosomally abnormal embryos can be used to tip the odds in favor of having a girl. It’s called preimplantation genetic diagnosis (PGD), and while it screens for extra or missing copies of chromosomes, it also tells you if you ended up with healthy embryos of both sexes. If you did, you could select a XX embryo (girl) to be implanted instead of an XY (boy). Side note: Yes, sex selection in IVF is controversial, but it’s done.

title.en-US: Is there a link between celiac disease and infertility?

content.value: Maven practitioner Nicole Avena, Ph.D.— a neuroscientist and expert in nutrition—explains.

When we hear the words “celiac disease” we tend to think of the gut and digestive system. This makes sense considering that celiac disease is an autoimmune intestinal disorder (meaning it develops in genetically susceptible individuals). As you may already know, the recommendation for people with celiac disease is a gluten-free diet. In people with this condition, eating gluten (found in wheat, barley and rye) triggers an immune response that attacks and damages the intestines. Eventually this damage leads to poor nutrient absorption and may also cause a variety of problems such as iron-deficiency anemia, joint pain, liver disorders, and missed menstrual periods—just to name a few.

Well, it turns out that undiagnosed or untreated celiac disease may also be a cause of otherwise unexplained infertility in both women and men. And the reproductive impact doesn’t end there: Research suggests that women with undiagnosed celiac disease who later received a diagnosis were 12% more likely to have a miscarriage and 62% more likely to experience a stillbirth than moms-to-be who never develop the condition.
How might celiac disease affect fertility and pregnancy?

It's not totally clear what the link is. Several theories point to a variety of ways that the autoimmune response to gluten may somehow interfere with the reproductive tract. Meanwhile, some experts suggest a simple explanation: malnutrition. After all, it’s a known fact that celiac disease can cause nutrient deficiencies, and growing babies require plenty of nutrients to grow and develop properly in the womb. Not only does undiagnosed (or untreated) celiac disease lead to iron-deficiency anemia, but it could lead to deficiencies in other key pregnancy nutrients such as folic acid, zinc, and selenium.
What does this mean for you?

Celiac disease certainly isn’t the cause of every woman’s unexplained infertility, but if you’ve had trouble conceiving and the cause of your fertility issues hasn’t been determined, it’s a good idea to ask your doctor to do a celiac disease screening. It’s important to point out there may not always be obvious symptoms if you have celiac disease. You may have what’s known as “silent celiac disease,” which is when you don’t show any symptoms but any and all consumption of gluten still wreaks havoc on your intestines.

The good news: Research shows that those with celiac disease who follow a gluten-free diet reduce their the risk of infertility and other celiac-related pregnancy issues significantly. So if you do test positive for celiac disease, it’s important to start eating a gluten-free diet right away to minimize any further damage on your body. Since cutting out any foods has the potential to lead to nutrient deficiencies, it is best to consult with a Maven nutritionist to help you with your new diet.

title.en-US: You need *this* much sleep during fertility treatment

content.value: Grab a pillow and keep reading.

Much of what determines your chances of conceiving with fertility treatment is out of your hands. Your age, for instance, isn’t exactly something you have the power to change. But shutting down the laptop early, or getting your Jimmy Kimmel fix the next day instead of watching it late-night? Totally in your control. And, it turns out, removing these or any other barriers to good sleep may help boost your odds of pregnancy success.

A Korean study found that women who had the best outcomes from IVF treatment got between 7 and 8 hours of sleep a night. In fact, these “moderate sleepers” had better pregnancy outcomes than people who sleep for more than nine hours or fewer than six. In other words, there might be a sweet spot for shuteye—and more or less could be detrimental.
Does this mean that good sleepers are guaranteed fertility success?
