Of course not. These observations are what researchers call “associations” and don’t prove “cause and effect.” In other words, there could be other variables affecting the IVF success rates that the researchers didn’t study.

Still, there’s ample research that maintaining a healthy lifestyle can have a positive effect on fertility. And this study is evidence that good sleep (among other habits) is worth prioritizing. Some doctors go so far as to prescribe it—recommending that any patient attempting to get pregnant hit the sack. As the saying goes: “Nothing gets worse with better sleep, and a lot of things get better.”

title.en-US: Can taking a daily aspirin improve IVF success?

content.value: The headache medicine is rumored to be a pregnancy aid. Read on for the need-to-know facts.

Some fertility researchers have looked into whether popping a low-dose aspirin—by increasing blood flow to the ovaries and womb—might increase the chances of a woman getting pregnant in combination with IVF treatment.
What the research says:

One older study (it was published in 1999) in the journal Fertility and Sterility compared two groups of 149 women. One group took a daily dose of 100mg of aspirin in addition to their IVF medication to stimulate the ovaries; the second group took only the IVF drugs. 45% of the women who took aspirin got pregnant, compared with 28% of the control group. The women who took aspirin also produced more eggs during their retrieval. Based on these findings, the researchers felt that a low-dose aspirin could have a triple-whammy effect: improving ovarian response, implantation rates, and pregnancy rates in patients undergoing IVF.

But the truth is that experts are divided on whether aspirin is really the wonder drug it seems to be from tiny studies like these. What’s more, larger studies suggest there that aspirin doesn’t make a big difference in pregnancy outcomes. One meta-analysis in 2007 found that “low-dose aspirin has no substantial positive effect on likelihood of pregnancy and, therefore, it should not be routinely recommended for women undergoing IVF.” Another analysis was published in the Cochrane Library of Systematic Reviews in 2011 (this one included data involving over 2,500 women) and concluded that the “use of aspirin for women undergoing IVF cannot be recommended due to lack of evidence from the current trial data.”
The bottom line:
Check with your doctor, but for now, a low-dose aspirin regimen is not a routine recommendation for everyone doing IVF.

title.en-US: Can diet help with depression during fertility treatment?

content.value: We answered a Maven member’s question—see if the advice can help you with your own emotional health.

The first thing you should know is that you’re not alone. Fertility struggles are high up there on the list of extremely stressful life situations, so it’s no wonder that depression and anxiety are commonly reported by patients undergoing IVF.
Can diet make a difference?

The truth is, it can’t hurt and it might help. If that sounds vague, it’s because there isn’t enough evidence yet to recommend a change in how people are treated for depression and anxiety—so your grocery cart shouldn’t replace the things you do at your doctor’s suggestion to take care of yourself and feel better. That said, there’s preliminary research showing that a healthy diet may be a useful part of a comprehensive treatment plan for mood issues. Scientists are hoping we have more large, randomized studies in the future to back up the (promising!) findings from smaller and/or observational studies.
Here’s what we know now.

Experts in the growing field of nutritional psychiatry say that there’s a strong link between what people eat and how they feel. One analysis concluded that “a dietary pattern characterized by a high intake of fruit, vegetables, whole grain, fish, olive oil, low-fat dairy and antioxidants and low intakes of animal foods was apparently associated with a decreased risk of depression. A dietary pattern characterized by a high consumption of red and/or processed meat, refined grains, sweets, high-fat dairy products, butter, potatoes and high-fat gravy, and low intakes of fruits and vegetables is associated with an increased risk of depression.”
Why might this connection exist?

That’s still being worked out. One theory points to the gut-brain connection: Our “gut microbiome” is made up of countless different species of microbes that release substances and chemicals into the body, affecting everything from inflammation to our immune response to—potentially—our mental health. And there’s evidence that a diet rich in sugar, meats and processed foods may adversely affect this balance of microbes in the gut.
The bottom line

: Dealing with mental health issues is complicated and involves much more than your dinner plate. (That’s true whether it’s infertility or something entirely unrelated that’s triggering your depressed mood.) But a healthy diet could be considered a supplemental treatment with no side effects—and a big potential upside for both your mental and physical well-being. Talk to your doctor or a Maven provider for more specific nutrition advice and other ways to manage your emotional health during treatment.

title.en-US: How to love your body during infertility treatment

content.value: Loving, trusting, or even accepting your body can be very difficult when it won’t seem to cooperate with what you want the most—a baby.
Here are some of the sentiments we’ve heard:
“After every failed round of fertility treatment, I hated my body more.”
“When I couldn’t get pregnant, I blamed my body for my unhappiness.”
“IVF has made me feel very negative toward my body. How can I feel positive about something that continues to let me down?”

The problem with body-hating during infertility is that dwelling on negative thoughts can lead to a harmful self-talk cycle. And when you get stuck in that kind of pattern, it’s easier to become depressed. What’s more, self-criticism requires a ton of energy—so you may end up even more exhausted than you already are when you’re trying to conceive. While there’s no easy way out, here are a few tips to help you repair the relationship you have with your body.
Honor your feelings.

Fact: Telling yourself you “shouldn’t” feel a certain way never works. In fact, it usually just makes you feel worse. Only once you accept your feelings in a non-judgmental way are you able to work on introducing more helpful thoughts. So the first step is to simply acknowledge how you feel and not label it “wrong.” Remind yourself that it’s natural to be angry at your body.
Appreciate what your body can do for you.

You might not be able to “be positive” all the time—and that’s OK. But you can minimize the negative thoughts. If you're constantly telling yourself, "My body is such a failure," search for evidence to the contrary. You could say phrases like: “My body is strong—it has endured so much (injections, hormonal swings, etc.) during this journey.” Use your own words to develop a script you can actually believe. Finding gratitude for your body—even for its basic functions like your legs carrying you where you need to go—can help heal your relationship with it.
Try some self-care.

If you can’t imagine saying loving thoughts toward your body right now, start with loving actions. What could you do to affirm that your body is worth being kind to? Get a massage, take a nap, go for a gentle swim at the local pool? Self-care and hating your body are virtually incompatible, so these actions may work their way into your mind and change your thinking over time.
Need more help? Maven therapists are available to chat with you anytime you could use some extra support during this journey.

title.en-US: Myth or fact: Stress lowers fertility treatment success

content.value: Anyone who has had a hard time trying to conceive has heard some version of, “Just relax and you'll get pregnant.” And many women are left to wonder: Does stress undermine the success of fertility treatment?
Here’s the reality: While living with lots of tension is never good for your overall health, the research we have to date indicates that stress likely has little impact on IVF success.

Several years ago, researchers did what’s called a “meta-analysis”—that is, they didn’t look at one study, but instead reviewed the data from 14 studies involving 3,583 infertile women from many countries including the US, Australia, Belgium, Canada, Denmark, Sweden, and the UK. The results showed anxiety and stress before treatment did not affect a woman’s chances of becoming pregnant.

The idea that stress plays a role in IVF success may stem from studies that didn’t fully examine the indirect associations between stress and fertility. Here’s an example of how that could play out: When the pressures of juggling work and attending clinic appointments every day get too intense, a woman’s stress may lead to other choices that don’t optimize her chances of success. For one, she may drop out in the middle of a treatment cycle. In this case, you could say that reducing stress might keep you in treatment longer and help you get pregnant. But that’s a lot different than saying being stressed will inherently make your IVF success a failure. That’s an important distinction. Likewise, the effect of stress when embarking on IVF may lead some ex-smokers or ex-drinkers to pick up cigarettes again or up their alcohol consumption—two lifestyle behaviors that are linked to negative pregnancy outcomes.

If you’re feeling a little confused, know that many scientists are continuing to scratch their heads, too. More research is needed to keep teasing out the complicated/controversial questions about stress and fertility.
Bottom line

: Even if emotional distress does not cause infertility or lower IVF success rates, keeping stress in check is still important. We know that living with too much tension can impact your wellbeing in lots of negative ways, and learning to manage stress will help you cope—emotionally and physically—with what may be a difficult journey through fertility treatment.

title.en-US: “How I dealt with the stress of fertility treatment”

content.value: Maven Real Talk On IVF With Shauntae
40 years old
Self-employed
LA
Why did you decide to do IVF?
I was 38, which is considered “advanced reproductive age” and I’d already had multiple miscarriages trying to conceive. My husband and I desperately wanted a baby.
Did you have any biological kids before you started IVF?
​No. We started IVF in 2015, did one cycle but it failed. Then we spontaneously got pregnant in early 2016 (naturally), and had our daughter later that year. We started another IVF cycle this year.
How did you choose your clinic?

​I was referred by a doctor who happens to be a friend of mine. We were working out together one day and I started opening up about my fertility challenges, and that’s when she recommended her reproductive endocrinologist. I’m glad I got a personal referral from someone I trusted—I had a positive experience.
How much have you spent on IVF?

$20,000—all out of pocket. There were extra costs that added up. For instance, we did “preimplantation genetic screening,” or PGS on all of our embryos. It was pricey, but worth it—we learned we had some abnormal embryos, some really good ones, and others that were really great. It helped me to know that the embryos we’d implant were the ones with the highest possible chance. And not everyone knows that it’s costly to store embryos; we pay $500 per year. ​I wish that IVF were a less pricey procedure. Even if you have a two-income family, it’s a financial stress.
What surprised you most about the procedure?

​It’s so much to think about emotionally. I was working full-time while going through it, my husband was traveling a lot for work, so it was just a lot to process. Also, I wasn’t prepared for the number of hormones I had to take and what these hormones did to my mood and my skin. My skin went crazy, acne-wise.
What was the most difficult part of your IVF experience? ​
The fear of the unknown and the devastation when it doesn't work.
Any tips for managing the emotional stress of IVF?

​I worked out a lot! Everyone has their own way of managing stress, but exercise was key for me. Another thing that’s helpful: Try to find another woman who’s gone through it so you can ask questions and get support.

Editor’s note: Some women are advised to stay away from certain fitness regimens during treatment, while others may be able to safely continue what they’ve been doing. Talk to your doctor about what’s considered a safe exercise routine for you during treatment.
If your best friend was about to go through IVF, what would you want her to know? ​

Get a support group. Your partner may love you and want to help, but sometimes men don’t get it. Prioritize managing your stress, and try not to think too much about the cost because if you get a baby out of it, you don't really care.
Do you have any plans to do IVF again?
​Fingers crossed, probably not. I'm technically 12 weeks pregnant now (from the last IVF cycle I did). We haven't told anyone yet, but things are looking good so far!

title.en-US: How to stop criticizing your body during fertility treatment

content.value: Answer from Danika Severino Wynn, a Certified Nurse Midwife on Maven
Trying to become pregnant can be a long journey, but hopefully this advice can help you with those difficult emotions that come up.
Find a community.

Remember that you are not alone. About 10% of women in the United States have difficulty getting pregnant or staying pregnant, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). One of the best things you can do during this time is find a community of people in a similar situation who can relate to your experience. Seek out support groups, online forums, or a empathetic friends who have experienced fertility challenges. You’ll probably be surprised to find out that many, many people share this sentiment of their bodies being “defective.” What’s more, sometimes the way to start offering compassion to your own body is to begin offering that same compassion to someone else.
Remember all the things your body can do.
This isn’t always easy, but if you can, try to keep in mind all of the amazing things your body is capable of. Reminding yourself of your body’s strengths can be a huge confidence boost.
Consider therapy.

Therapists are not only great sounding boards during times of great stress, but they can also help teach you coping strategies. If you’re looking for someone to talk to, Maven has mental health specialists who specialize in fertility struggles, and you can always reach out.
Journal.

Sometimes it feels hard to speak to your partner, close friends, or family members about your struggles—especially as time goes on. Even when you’re not in the mood to open up to someone else, journaling can help you get your feelings out and be a tool for you to process your emotions.
Let yourself off the hook.

You’re allowed to wallow in self pity from time to time or have tough days! You also fully deserve to pamper yourself. Get a massage; go on a long walks and turn off your cell phone; use some paid time off from work to take a mental health day and see a movie in the middle of the afternoon. Sometimes unplugging from day-to-day stressors can be just what you need to get through a rough patch.

title.en-US: How age affects your chances of IVF success

content.value: Lots of factors can affect IVF success rates, but age is a biggie. Here’s what you need to know.

The knowledge that a woman’s fertility declines with age—with a steeper drop after 35—is nothing new. With IVF, you can increase your chances of having a baby, but age is still a factor. The Society for Assisted Reproductive Technology (SART) is the primary organization of professionals working in the area of in vitro fertilization and other fertility techniques. Every year, SART puts out a report that includes IVF success rates. (As of this writing, the most recent completed report is for 2015). These numbers reflect the percentage of new patients who eventually achieved a live birth (you can also visit
SART’s website
to view more details, like the average number of egg-retrieval and egg-transfer attempts before a live birth).
Percent of live births achieved by new IVF patients:
Under age 35: 68.6%
Over age 42: 6.3%
Why does a healthy 30-year-old trying IVF have a better chance of success than a healthy 40-year old doing the procedure?

Again, age isn’t the only factor affecting IVF success rates, but here’s how it relates: With IVF, hormone treatments are used to stimulate the ovaries to grow and release more eggs for each cycle. However, the success of IVF still depends on the quantity and quality of the eggs a woman has available in the first place. At the start of her reproductive age, a woman has 300,000-500,000 eggs, but by the time she’s in her 40’s, that number is only about 25,000. What’s more, older eggs don’t tend to fertilize as well as younger eggs, and they are also more prone to having chromosomal errors.
So how much weight should you put in these stats?

When doctors say that a healthy, fertile 30-year-old has a 20% chance of getting pregnant, what does that mean exactly? It means that for every 100 healthy, fertile 30-year-old women trying to get pregnant in a particular month, 20 of them will succeed. So, as you can see, the statistic merely gives you an idea of your odds, but it doesn’t necessarily predict your personal chances. That goes for fertility treatments like IVF as well; every woman is different, so it’s best to consult with a reproductive endocrinologist about a treatment plan that maximizes chances for your particular situation.

title.en-US: How to get pregnant when you have PCOS

content.value: PCOS (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome) is incredibly common, affecting as many as 10% of reproductive-age women. The hormonal condition can lead to irregular cycles, no period at all (aka amenorrhea), and—no surprise—difficulty getting pregnant. Fortunately, there are a few ways to jump the hurdles of getting pregnant with PCOS.
First, know when to seek help.

You might have heard that you can wait for up to a year of trying to have a baby before you seek the help of a fertility specialist (or 6 months if you’re 35 or older). But if you know you have PCOS (even if it hasn’t been diagnosed but you have irregular periods) and you’re having trouble conceiving, that time timeline doesn’t apply to you. You should see a doctor ASAP. This doesn’t mean that you’ll necessarily have to start fertility treatment—many women with PCOS end up getting pregnant on their own—but you’ll be in the right hands to receive guidance and get you on the right track.

PCOS is linked with hormonal issues that can interfere with baby-making. Problems might arise from an overproduction of testosterone, and inappropriate amounts of FSH (follicle-stimulating hormone) and LH (luteinizing hormone)—both of which are needed for the follicles in the ovaries to develop and produce eggs. Sometimes a few lifestyle shifts—such as weight loss, a healthy diet, and exercise—can rebalance your hormones and spark ovulation. But if those tweaks don’t help or your doctor feels more needs to be done, that’s where these treatments come in:
Hormonal medication

The most common oral medication is clomiphene citrate (Clomid), which lowers estrogen to increase FSH, and—you guessed it—get a follicle or two going. Depending on how your body responds to that medication, your doctor might introduce metformin next. Metformin is a drug that enhances insulin sensitivity and lowers androgen levels (high levels of androgens interfere with ovulation).

If clomiphene and metformin don’t work for you, the next step is usually an injectable medication to try to up the ante. Gonadotropins, as they’re called, are pharmaceutical forms of FSH AND LH, taken as a shot.
IUI

Your doctor may also suggest medications in conjunction with intrauterine insemination (IUI). In this case, you’d take the hormone treatments over the course of a week or so to stimulate the ovaries to produce more eggs. Then, once the follicles are sufficiently developed, you’ll be given a different injection (called hCG hormone, aka the “trigger shot”) to release the eggs into the fallopian tubes. This is followed by the insemination (from your partner or sperm donor).
IVF

If ovulation induction with timed intercourse or a few attempts at IUI aren’t successful, or if you have other issues in addition to your PCOS (like blocked fallopian tubes), your doctor may recommend in vitro fertilization (IVF). When you have PCOS, hormonal imbalances don’t just mess with ovulation, they can also interfere with your body's ability to support a developing embryo. In vitro fertilization (IVF) addresses the issue by taking matters outside of the body—using lab techniques to give things a kick-start. After taking medication to stimulate ovulation, your eggs are harvested and then placed in a petri dish with the semen in hopes of fertilization. If all goes well, you’ll end up with at least one good-quality embryo, which is later transferred into your uterus. A pregnancy test two weeks later will confirm whether it “stuck” and, hopefully, it can be on its way to becoming a baby.

title.en-US: How fertility treatments affect your hunger levels

content.value: When undergoing IVF, you may be prescribed a slew of medications to help facilitate the process. Unfortunately, not only do you have to pop (or inject) several drugs, but many can come with undesirable side effects, including messing with your appetite. Here, Maven practitioner Nicole Avena, Ph.D.— a neuroscientist and expert in nutrition—breaks things down and helps you cope.
First, here's a primer on common fertility drugs, and some of the side effects that come with them
Clomiphene citrate (CC)
- CC is a drug that helps you ovulate, and you may recognize it by its brand names such as Clomid or Serophene. Some side effects include upset stomach, nausea/vomiting, and headaches.
Gonadotropins

- This refers to follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH). Together, these stimulate follicular growth and ovulation. Some medications contain a combination of the two (like Menopur and Repronex), or FSH may be given alone. There are several types of FSH medications out there, and common brands include Bravelle, Fertinex, Follistim, and Gonal-F. Some side effects of these types of medications include stomach pain, abdominal discomfort, bloating, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea—not to mention mood swings and depression.
Gonadotropin releasing hormones

- As the name suggests, these hormones stimulate the pituitary gland in the brain to secrete LH and FSH. Name brands include Factrel and Lutrepulse. These medications may cause abdominal pain, bloating, nausea, and headaches.
Bromocriptine and Cabergolin

e - These substances affect the amount of prolactin released by the pituitary. Brand names for these drugs are Parlodel and Dostinex, respectively. Side effects can include nausea, vomiting, headaches, and dizziness.
How do these medications mess with your appetite and/or diet?

The side effects mentioned for each of these have the potential to affect your eating habits from both a physical and mental standpoint. For instance, if you become moody and depressed, you may be more prone to reach for comfort foods. And if you’re constantly nauseous and bloated, vegetables probably aren’t the first thing calling your name. Considering that fertility treatments involve multiple drugs—and you may have to endure multiple cycles—things might take a turn for the worse when it comes to your diet.
So how can you maintain a nutritious diet during treatment?
Remember, you don’t have to do this perfectly, but here are a few tips to help you stay on track with healthy eating even if the medications aren’t making you feel your best.
When you’re feeling nauseous...

One of the best things you can do when you’re feeling nauseous is drink ginger tea; ginger’s medicinal effects include alleviating nausea and an upset stomach. During meal times, take small bites of food and small sips of water (no big bites or chugging liquids). If you’ve lost your appetite for a full meal, try to have small portions of calorie-dense foods throughout the day so your calorie intake doesn’t dip too low.
When you’re feeling bloated...

Firstly, avoid bubbly drinks because gulping down extra air will only make you feel worse. Instead, try sipping on peppermint, ginger, or chamomile tea. These teas can help get things moving in your system and alleviate gas. You might also try foods like yogurt that contain probiotics, which may help with discomfort or gas.
When you’re feeling down...

Often times we look to food for comfort, and it’s easy to see why you may need extra soothing during a challenging infertility journey. Instead of using food as a way to cheer yourself up, think about other activities you like that tend to make you feel better when you’re feeling low. Calling friends, listening to music, or watching a movie that always makes you laugh are all worth a try. Although junk food can sometimes bring momentary relief from difficult feelings, it rarely decreases stress or fatigue over the long haul, and some people become more upset when they continuously indulge their junk-food cravings.

title.en-US: Should you take melatonin when doing IVF?

content.value: Before you run to the supplement aisle to buy it in bulk, here’s what you need to know.

Given that many people think of melatonin as a sleep aid, it’s probably not the first thing that comes to mind for help getting pregnant. But there have been rumors that the hormone can make IVF more successful. What’s up with that?

Let’s backtrack for a second: One of the factors that has been associated with poorer egg quality is something called oxidative stress. Oxidative stress happens when too many harmful substances called free radicals float around your body, including your reproductive tract. Interestingly, some preliminary research suggests that melatonin might play a role in improving egg and embryo quality during IVF, possibly by blocking damage from free radicals.

That said, the research is very limited, so experts caution that it’s too soon to make conclusions, even if early findings seem promising. One small Japanese study involved about a 100 women who had a previous failed round of IVF. Before a subsequent cycle, half the women were given melatonin and half weren’t. Nearly 20% of those who took melatonin got pregnant, while only 10% of those who weren’t given the supplement became pregnant. The melatonin group also had more success with fertilization—50% of the eggs they produced could be fertilized, compared with 23% for the control group.

Other studies have had similarly positive results, but the fact remains that larger-scale, carefully-controlled research is needed before fertility experts feel confident drawing conclusions about the role of this hormone in IVF. The bottom line: Definitely talk to your RE before you start popping melatonin.

title.en-US: Can this diet treat PCOS—and end your infertility struggle?

content.value: Maven practitioner Nicole Avena, Ph.D.— a neuroscientist and expert in nutrition—gets to the bottom of things.

PCOS, or polycystic ovary syndrome, is an all-too-common hormonal disorder and a leading cause of infertility. It’s typically characterized by irregular periods, ovarian cysts, and higher-than-average androgens. If you have PCOS, you may be familiar with the potential side effects, like fatigue, sleep problems, mood swings, and yes, weight gain. So if your doctor suspects that your weight is connected to your inability to get pregnant, you may be wondering which diet is right for you.

Some studies have found that with any diet that leads to weight loss may be beneficial. However, a low-carb diet may prove to be more helpful—and here’s why: Thanks in part to those pesky androgens, the majority of PCOS patients also have insulin resistance, which causes them to store more fat.
That’s why this food group is so important.

A high-carbohydrate diet in general—and lots of sugars and refined carbs specifically (white bread, pasta, and anything made with refined white flour)—can spike insulin levels. Low-carb, ketogenic-style diets, on the other hand, help to keep things in balance. (If you're not familiar, a ketogenic eating style is essentially a high-fat, very low-carb diet that puts your body into a state of ketosis, where it uses fat for fuel instead of carbs.)

Other reasons that limiting carbs could be the way to go if you have PCOS: Insulin resistance may increase the risk for type 2 diabetes and—if you do get pregnant—complications such as gestational diabetes.
So what does a low-carb, ketogenic diet look like?

Carbohydrates are typically reduced to anywhere between 20 to 60 grams a day—although it’s different for everyone, and you should consult with your doctor or a Maven nutritionist before you get started to find out the right carb goal for you. Stricter versions don’t just limit refined carbs, but also grains, legumes (i.e. beans, lentils, and peas), starchy vegetables, fruit and processed items with added sugar like yogurt, snack foods, flavored and even regular milk. Cutting back on carbs means it’s necessary to up your intake of protein and fat (meats, fish, cheese, eggs, nuts, seeds, avocados, and oils) and make sure you’re getting enough calories.

Keep in mind that lower isn’t necessarily better—and you definitely don’t want to go no-carb. Instead, the idea is to lower carbohydrate intake just enough in order to lower insulin secretion in your body and force the body to burn stored fat for energy.
The bottom line:

If you have PCOS and doctor has suggested that you try to lose weight, you may be successful no matter which diet you follow. (And remember that if you can’t adhere to a low-carb diet, it could backfire and lead to weight gain.) However, the research is promising that following a low-carb diet may be slightly more beneficial than other eating styles because of the potential effects on improving insulin sensitivity. Long-term effects of a low-carb diet like this have not been thoroughly researched, but for now it seems there is no harm in giving it a shot.

title.en-US: The truth about alternative medicine and fertility treatment

content.value: There are a host of complementary and alternative medicine techniques out there. Read this before you choose your own adventure.

Wondering if trying an alternative therapy will boost your chances of IVF success? Good luck finding an answer. The truth is, more scientific research is woefully needed. Controlled studies (clinical trials) are the best way to find out if a treatment works, but alternative medicine isn’t an area that has many of these studies to show for it. There could be lots of beneficial effects, but unless they are studied scientifically, it’s not possible to say which methods are effective. Some experts worry that too many people are investing money, time, and blind faith in alternative therapies—and they may be left to believe that, say, just because their coworker and her eight best friends got pregnant after hypnotherapy, so will they. Even when these stories turn out to be true, anecdotal evidence can't be thought of as proof.

At Maven, we always want to present you with evidence, and above all keep you safe—while also giving you the information you need to make your own decisions. Undergoing fertility treatment is hard, and some people are willing to try things that just might help their body, mind, and spirit. If it can't hurt you (or your wallet), and your doctor can get behind it, too, our practitioners don’t want to dissuade patients who want to take the “worth a shot” approach to holistic medicine.
So what are some of the things fertility patients have tried? Keep reading to find out.
Mind-body exercises

If you look up the definition of mind-body medicine (MBM), you’ll find that it “uses a variety of techniques designed to enhance the mind's capacity to affect bodily function and symptoms.” That explains why your fertility clinic’s pamphlets or website might promote MBM alongside your treatment: When these interventions can be used to, say, improve your mood, cope with side effects of medication, and reduce stress, you just might stick with treatments such as IVF long enough for them to work. One older study published in Fertility and Sterility found that women who participated in mind-body training had a 52% pregnancy rate, compared to a 20% success rate among women who didn’t. This stress-management “toolbox” included things like meditation, progressive muscle relaxation, yoga, body-scan relaxation (i.e. tensing and relaxing of your muscles while lying in bed), and recasting negative thoughts into more empowered, hopeful ones.
Acupuncture

It’s not uncommon to find a fertility clinic that offers acupuncture, even though the jury’s still out on its IVF effects. A 2018 paper in the journal JAMA comparing regular acupuncture with “sham acupuncture” found no significant difference in live birth rates—so if you’re counting on it to improve success rates, the science is seriously lacking. That said, if you’re simply looking for ways to tamp down on anxiety during treatment, and getting poked makes you feel calmer, you might want to incorporate it into your self-care routine. Acupuncture may have an effect on the body's stress response system, which could explain why many infertility patients turn to the needles.
Virtual Reality

You may have heard about doctors and psychologists using virtual reality (VR) in recent years to address some challenging problems in healthcare. Here’s how the technology works: You wear a head-mounted gadget with a special video screen inside the device, and a professional trained to give a VR session controls what you’re looking at, immersing you in a peaceful virtual world. The idea is that mental exposure to an alternate environment—one where your anxieties cease to exist—might help make real-life situations a bit easier. A small experimental study led by Belgium researchers used VR—one simulation was a virtual underwater walk cut off from all ambient sound—on 100 women going through IVF. Promisingly, the participants reported a significant decrease in their anxiety after the session. While you probably won’t find this technique at a clinic near you quite yet (and let’s face it, many people will simply find the idea too wacky), the takeaway here is that seeking out healthy ways to escape your day-to-day may be very useful when you’re going through treatment. Getting lost in a movie, a good book, or a podcast may be just the “VR” you need to redirect your attention.

title.en-US: How far would you drive for a fertility clinic?

content.value: One hour? Five? Across the country? These are the decisions some women are forced to make. Here’s why.

People often talk about the cost barrier involved in having a baby with the help of assisted reproductive technology (ART). What you don’t hear about as much: The actual lengths some patients have to go just to walk through the door of a fertility clinic.

According to a study published in the journal Fertility & Sterility in 2017, about 40% of women in the U.S. have limited or no access to ART clinics, where procedures like IVF take place. The data revealed that a full 18 million women live in parts of the country where there are no ART clinics, and another 6.8 million women live in areas with just one ART clinic. As you’d expect, metropolitan areas are more likely to provide patients with clinic options, while less-urban communities often go underserved.
While one clinic is, at least theoretically, better than none, it doesn’t leave women with much choice. And considering that all fertility centers are definitely not created equal, this is a problem.
So what’s the solution?

This, of course, is highly personal. It depends on many factors, including money, time, and willingness to travel to get to a clinic that may be better than the one closest to your home. Some women say that if they have to trek an hour or two to see the top specialist in their area versus driving 20 minutes to a so-so doctor, they’ll happily go the distance.

One way that some people get creative is by splitting their treatment between a facility near their home­ and a further-away clinic with a better reputation. For instance, you may choose to have the ovarian stimulation for your IVF cycle monitored locally, and arrange for the results of the ultrasound and blood test to be faxed to your “main” clinic each day. (During IVF, daily monitoring is necessary to give your doctor feedback on how your follicles are growing and determine how to adjust the dosage of your medication.) This may spare you having to take several long trips during the stimulation phase, and save your travel days for the egg retrieval and embryo transfer.
Bottom line

: There’s no denying that where you live could be a source of additional anxiety during an already stressful time. But we’re here to help. Remember, your Maven Care Advocate can point you to a highly-vetted list of clinics that makes the most sense for you geographically. And if what you’re struggling with is how to juggle treatment with your work schedule, our career coaches can help you expertly navigate conversations with your boss or HR department.

title.en-US: Coping with an IVF miscarriage

content.value: Wondering if your emotions are normal?

Miscarriage is common even for those that aren’t facing infertility. But for anyone who has been through months or even years of trying to conceive with the help of fertility treatments, pregnancy loss can add yet another heartache to an already difficult experience. In the midst of it all, you may wonder if your emotions are “normal,” or how long it will be till you feel like yourself again. Here are a few things to keep in mind as you navigate this challenging time.
1.There’s no one-size-fits-all response.

The truth is, there isn’t a blueprint for the emotional aftermath of a miscarriage—every situation is unique, and some women have an easier time moving on than others. Sometimes the mourning period feels just like the grief you experience when a loved one dies—you may be depressed, anxious, irritable, and angry. Whatever your response to the loss, honor it.
2. Be discerning about who you spend time with.

Hard truth: Not every person in your life is going to be able to comfort you when you’re going through a rough time. One woman told us she received comments that blatantly dismissed her grief—such as, “At least you got pregnant!” This is not a reassuring reminder for someone who has just lost a pregnancy. The bottom line: If certain interactions with people in your life leave you feeling worse, not better, it’s OK to take a step back from those relationships while you focus on your own healing.
3. Know your triggers.

Unfortunately, we can’t go through life censoring ourselves from everything that may bring up the painful reminder that we’ve experienced a loss. Seeing babies, preggo friends, or even ads for diapers can stir up emotions. Know that it’s normal to experience waves of more intense sadness, and have a plan to reach out for extra support during these times. And if you need to take a pass on attending a baby shower or a first birthday party, give yourself that permission.
4. Tell your partner/friends what you need.

Fact: Often, people want to be there for you, but they don’t know how. If you wish your inner circle would give you more support than they’re offering you, communicate your wishes. Even if all you want them to do for you is listen and check in with you from time to time, let them know.
5. Healing takes time—sometimes more time than you’d expect.

You may be asking yourself things like “How long will my grief last?” or “When will I feel ready to do another round of IVF?” The truth is, the distress may lift quickly, or it may stick around. In fact, some women experience depression and anxiety for several years after a miscarriage—even if they’ve gotten pregnant again and given birth to a healthy child. The key thing, if it feels like the sadness is lingering, is to get support. Opening up to your doctor is a good first step. You can also book a video appointment with a therapist in Maven’s network; these are psychologists and counselors who specialize in reproductive and pregnancy related issues, including pregnancy loss.

title.en-US: My IVF cycle was canceled and I got pregnant anyway

content.value: One Maven member shares what happened when her IVF cycle was canceled—twice—because she was a “poor responder” to fertility meds. What happened next can give any woman hope.

“I never technically did IVF all the way though. The first time I tried to do it, they canceled the procedure. When an IVF cycle gets canceled for not making enough eggs (I made only two, and at my clinic, the minimum was four), they can use the eggs to do an IUI (kind of a Hail Mary pass!). I was lucky and it worked—and that's how I got my son! My doctor was floored—my AMH was a .1 (that's point 1 on a scale of 0 to 5) and they told me that my chance of success with the IUI was miniscule.
After having my son, I tried IVF again hoping to have a second child, but once again they had to cancel it because we didn’t retrieve enough eggs. Unfortunately, this time the IUI didn't work.

I was going to try IVF a third time, and this time, my doctor decided to go through with it no matter how few eggs I'd produce. When the time came, however, my insurance ran out so this time I was the one who canceled the IVF. I didn't want to shell out $10K for a very slim chance of having a baby. Weirdly, I got pregnant on my own a few months after that but it didn't stick. We were told it was probably because the fetus had a chromosomal abnormality—a common thing with older moms (I was 43 at the time).

Today, we are a family of three, and I'm OK with that. We're able do things—travel, sign my son up for various after-school programs and summer activities—that we might not have been able to afford if we had more kids. And, to be honest, I love being able to really focus on my son when we spend time together.

Ever since we started trying to conceive the first time around, I was constantly reminded that I had a lower-than-average chance of getting pregnant and a higher-than-average risk of something going wrong if I did. And yet, I had a son who entered the world alert and healthy, and continues to flourish every day. So when people ask me now if I ever regret giving up on fertility treatment and not continuing to place bets on IVF, I tell them no. I already hit the jackpot.”

title.en-US: The pros and cons of “mini-IVF” vs. traditional IVF

content.value: If you’re considering fertility treatments, you may have heard of mini-IVF—or “minimal stimulation IVF.” Instead of stimulating the ovaries with the high doses of medication, mini-IVF keeps medication to a minimum. Read on for the advantages and drawbacks.

Proponents of mini-IVF say it can be a good option for older women and anyone with a low egg count—also known as a diminished ovarian reserve. The idea is that pumping these patients with max doses of IVF medications won’t impact the number of usable eggs produced by their ovaries anyway—so if high dosages are a wasted effort, why not use fewer drugs in an effort to make the treatment less taxing on the body?

The less-is-more approach to treatment can also be a good option for those who are at a higher risk of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS), a condition where the ovaries become extra swollen. In its most mild—and common—form, OHSS symptoms include bloating and discomfort. More severe cases of OHSS are extremely rare, but they do happen and can lead to serious, life-threatening complications that require hospitalization.
So if there’s less risk involved with mini-IVF, why doesn’t everyone do it?

If you don’t have a low ovarian reserve and your ovaries aren’t likely to respond poorly to stimulation in traditional IVF, the gentler approach may not lead to the best outcomes. One 2016 study in American Journal of Obstetrics & Gynecology looked at 564 couples who were randomly assigned to mini-IVF or conventional IVF. (Women in the study were 39 years old or younger.) The results? Live birth rates were 49% with mini-IVF group, and 63% with those who did conventional IVF.
What about costs?

Because mini-IVF uses lower doses of hormones, you do spend less money per cycle. But if you don’t get the optimal number of eggs and end up needing to do additional cycles, the long-term cost may be the same (or greater) than going the conventional IVF route.
The bottom line:

Mini-IVF remains a rather controversial procedure among many in the medical community, and research suggests that it may not be the best choice for all women. But you should always discuss your options with your provider (and get a second opinion if you remain uncertain about the advice) before launching into a treatment regimen.

title.en-US: Two baby boys through IUI

content.value: Real Talk on Fertility with Maven Nutritionist Lisa Moskovitz

“One thing I wished people would stop telling me when I was struggling with infertility was, ‘Stop stressing about it, it’s only going to make it harder. The stress is why you’re not getting pregnant.’ That can be really tough to hear when you’re going through this.”
Name:
Lisa Moskovitz
Age:
Q: When did you realize you would need help getting pregnant?

I was on birth control for about 10 years, since I was a teenager. When I turned 30 and my husband and I got married, I stopped the pills and started trying to get pregnant. At an OB-GYN appointment, my doctor did a sonogram and told me that I had cystic ovaries and it was possible I wasn’t ovulating regularly, or my eggs weren’t the healthiest. The official diagnosis was a hormonal imbalance called PCOS (polycystic ovary syndrome) but they were very flip about how they tell you. They're just kind of like, "Oh, well you have PCOS. You're going to probably have trouble getting pregnant."

At first, I was pretty relaxed about things, but when it sank in that it might be hard for us to have children, I started feeling anxious. My husband didn’t want to force it, and that caused tension, but eventually he came around. I consulted with a reproductive endocrinologist. I may have waited longer if I hadn’t had the PCOS diagnosis, but knowing the chances of conceiving naturally were lower for me gave me a sense of urgency.
Q: How did your infertility treatment journey begin?

After some blood tests, I took Clomid (used to stimulate the ovaries to produce more eggs) for five cycles where we were just having regular sex. But the side effects were awful—I was very irritable and emotional. We traded the Clomid for another medication, Letrozole, which had much more limited side effects. We tried one cycle with just regular sex, and then we moved on to IUI.
Q: How did you feel going into the IUIs?

Well, I really did not want to do IVF. IVF felt invasive, and our insurance didn’t cover it, so money was a big thing. Spending $20,000 seemed crazy, especially since my husband didn’t even want to do the IUI to begin with. So I knew that if the IUIs didn’t work, it was going to be a very long journey. I didn’t even want to think about the what ifs, but sometimes I did catch myself having thoughts like, “If the IUI doesn’t work, what’s wrong with me?” I knew I was not alone and a lot of women struggle with infertility, but you still can’t shake the feeling of why me? And of course while you’re going through this, you’re seeing women posting about their pregnancies on Facebook. You want to be happy for them, but it’s hard. At one point I stopped going on Facebook.
Q: What happened after the IUI?

I got my period after the first IUI, but when they ran some blood tests, they saw that I had my levels of HCG (the pregnancy hormone) were elevated. Because of this, they assumed I had a chemical pregnancy that didn’t implant. I decided to up my chances the following month by going back on the Clomid, because despite the side effects, I was getting much better eggs on Clomid—three good ones versus one or two, max, on the Letrozole. We did a second IUI with the Clomid, but I didn’t have any home pregnancy tests left at that point so I waited for my follow-up with my doctor to do the pregnancy test. The blood test showed my HCG levels were super high—beyond the normal range, which often signifies twins. I thought, “Okay, well, we wanted one kid, but maybe we’re getting two!” I had a twin pregnancy that went full term to 38 weeks, and we now have two sons.
Q: As a nutritionist, did you change your diet before or during your pregnancy?

Yes, I did. There’s actually not that much scientific research on whether foods have an effect on fertility. But when I was trying to get pregnant, it can help you emotionally to know you’re at least trying. I was eating gluten- and dairy-free, lots of omega-3s like salmon, and mostly organic foods. I also limited alcohol and caffeine and took several supplements like maca root, green tea extract, zinc, and vitamin C. They are very expensive and time-consuming to take, and normally I wouldn’t waste my time on them, but I really wanted to do everything I could. I was like a 90-year-old grandma, with pills laid out from Monday to Sunday.

I even had my doctor prescribe Metformin, a medication that they normally give to diabetics. One of the causes of PCOS is an underlying insulin resistance, so a lot of women who go on to develop diabetes start out with PCOS. I did my own research and read that Metformin can help women with PCOS get pregnant and lowers their chance of miscarriage. My doctor didn’t think I needed it yet, but he let me take it.

Once I got pregnant, I started eating dairy and gluten again, because at that point it’s important to have a balanced diet and not restrict yourself too much. I made sure I got my omega-3s, folic acid, and fiber; I had lots of lentil soups and fish at least once or twice a week.
Q: How do you think the fertility industry can better support the patient experience?

There needs to be more focus on the emotional part of it. Specialists need to be more empathetic. They were just like, “You have PCOS, so you’ll probably need help getting pregnant.” Labels can be so harsh. Instead of coming right out and saying you’re infertile, they could say something like, “There’s a bit of a hormonal imbalance, which we can totally treat.” That’s the approach I take when I see clients as a nutritionist.
Q: Is there anything you wish someone had told you before you started this process?

One thing I wished people would stop telling me was to not stress out. They’d be like, “Stop stressing about it, it’s only going to make it harder. The stress is why you’re not getting pregnant.” That can be really tough to hear when you’re going through this.
Q: Why did you want to share your story with Maven?

Most of the time I don’t disclose personal information with patients, because I don’t think it’s professional, and I don’t want them to feel sorry for me. They’re the patient, after all. But a few weeks ago I was speaking to a client on Maven who was struggling, and I really wanted to tell her that I struggled, too. After our conversation, I wondered if telling her my story would have made her feel better. This seemed like a good way to share without telling people one-on-one.
Q: Looking back, is there anything that makes you laugh about this experience?

Yes! I couldn’t believe that after a year of trying to get pregnant, when I finally did, my due date was smack in the middle of my sister’s wedding and my best friend’s wedding—and I was going to be in both wedding parties. God was just like, “This is when it’s going to happen—right in between two major events in your life.” Well, I went to my sister’s wedding, and had a C-section two days later. About a week after the babies were born, I went to my best friend’s wedding. It was crazy, but somehow everything worked out in the end.

title.en-US: IVF after tubal ligation

content.value: Real Talk on Fertility with Maven Pediatrician Katie Zeigler

“The IVF process, as painful as it’s been, has made me step back and prioritize what matters in life. I’ve started working part-time, which is a big shift because I used to work a billion hours a week. So my kids are actually spending more time with me. It’s pretty funny when your five-year-old reminds you to take your shots.”
Name:
Katie Zeigler
Age:
Q: What has your fertility journey been like?

I have four sons from my first marriage who were conceived without intervention. Then I had a tubal ligation, a surgery where they cauterize the Fallopian tubes and/or remove a portion of them on both sides. Word to the wise: Don’t do it unless you’re positive you don’t want any more children, because they can be difficult or impossible to reverse.

My first husband and I got divorced three and a half years ago, and soon afterward I started dating my now-husband. While we both already had kids (he has a son from his previous marriage), we started talking about having children together. About a year ago, we saw a fertility specialist and learned that our options were for me to have surgery to try and reverse the ligation, or go straight to IVF. We decided to try the reversal first, but it wasn’t successful; there just wasn’t enough healthy tube left after the ligation. Now we’re doing IVF.
Q: Did you discuss your chance of IVF success with your doctor?

Yes. We did a full fertility workup and discovered that I have a low ovarian reserve. So IVF may not work for us, but we’re giving it a try. We started on fertility medications in December and are doing our first embryo transfer this evening. If this round doesn’t work, we plan to save up for a second attempt. Then, we’ll move on to adoption if we need to.
Q: What fertility medications have you taken, and what was that like?

I took an oral contraceptive pill for a month to reset my ovaries, which is a pretty standard thing to do before starting IVF. Halfway through that, I started injecting Lupron, which is a medication that suppresses your ovaries for a period before they rev them up. Then I took Menopur and Gonal, both of which stimulated my ovaries to produce more eggs, and finally the HCG trigger shot to get my ovaries to release the eggs for harvesting. At one point, I was taking five shots a day. The Lupron and Gonal shots are administered subcutaneously (aka just under the skin), so I could do those myself. But the Menopur is intramuscular—and it feels like you’re stabbing yourself in the buttocks. I used to be in the army, so I’m pretty hardcore, but I wasn’t hardcore enough for that! My husband administered most of those. He was a little freaked out at first, but one of the nurses had him practice with a saline shot, and he got over it.
Q: Did you have any side effects?

I did experience headaches and nausea. I also had some mood swings, but they weren’t as bad as I anticipated. I expected to be yelling at my husband and kids all the time, but instead I just cried a lot, which I think was better. I could tell that it was just the hormones and I wasn’t actually sad, so often I’d be laughing and crying simultaneously.
Q: Have you told your kids what’s going on?

Yes. Our sons are five, six, nine, 10, and 14 years old, and telling them was probably the biggest decision we’ve made throughout this journey. Ultimately, we decided we wanted them to be part of the process so they could understand why we might be on edge some days or why I was crying for no reason. We reassured them that we were doing this not because they weren’t enough, but because we think we have such a neat family that we want to bring a baby into it. They had lots of questions. Our five- and six-year-olds were worried that this meant I wouldn’t have time for them. But the IVF process, as painful as it’s been, has made me step back and prioritize what matters in life. I’ve started working part-time, which is a big shift because I used to work a billion hours a week. So my kids are actually spending more time with me. It’s pretty funny when your five-year-old reminds you to take your shots.
Q: What have been some of the emotional difficulties of going through fertility treatment?

I’m 37, which I feel is young, so I was shocked to find out that my ovarian reserves are low. They had to keep ramping up my hormones to near maximum doses to get any kind of response from my ovaries. My husband is not the type to yell, “Give me a kid!” But I do have moments where I feel like I’m letting him down.

IVF is also incredibly expensive, and my insurance doesn’t cover it. I’m blessed to have a well-paying job and be part of a two-income family. One of the biggest marital stressors has been trying not to put a monetary value on something as sacred as having children while accepting that, realistically, we can only afford to do this a certain number of times.
Q: How have you and your husband coped with these difficulties?

Our saving grace has been a sense of humor. We also have been able to step back and put things into perspective. We’ve made an effort to give each other the space to have a bad day, and do nice things for one another, even when we don’t feel like it.

I’m also a firm believer in therapy. If there were enough therapists in the world, I think every human should have one. My husband has been seeing a counselor to help with the process of blending our families. I’ve spoken to a psychologist regularly for years to get through issues in my previous marriage and my divorce, now our fertility struggles are part of those discussions. It’s been incredibly helpful.
Q: What has surprised you most about this experience?

I’m shocked by how isolating IVF can be. I’m a pretty open person, but I debated whether to tell my parents and sisters, with whom I usually share everything. I felt this inherent shame that my body isn’t working the way it’s supposed to, and I’m afraid people might be less understanding because my husband and I already have five children. I didn’t tell anyone when I had the tubal reversal surgery. But the isolation was a killer. This process is already emotionally challenging and taxing, so to have to hide it from my family was too much.

In the end, I decided not to tell people at work, but I opened up to my family and friends. I was nervous about it, and I got some mixed reactions from people who were like, “Are you sure? You have a hundred sons.” But my husband and I made it clear that we’ve thought this through, we’d made our decision, and we’d appreciate their support. For the most part, people have been great. Our parents, in particular, are elated. They’re always bending over backwards to help us in any way they can.
Q: Is there anything you wish someone had told you before you started this process?

I wish someone had told me to be more open about everything from the beginning, and that struggling with fertility isn’t a marker of being less human. In retrospect, I know my parents wouldn’t have disagreed with what we’re doing. And even if they had, they would have probably kept it to themselves. I can only imagine what it’s like for people who struggle on their own for a long time. The whole experience has made me so much more empathetic and mindful of how people talk about things like baby showers, and how they throw around questions like, “So when are you having a baby?” Those kinds of comments are just not helpful.
Q: How has this experience affected your work as a pediatrician?

I’ve always tried to be a kind and respectful provider, but having experienced firsthand some of the isolation and emotional turbulence of infertility has allowed me to better understand what some of these parents are going through, and how the fear of caring for a baby might be magnified for them. So when I get called over and over again about the same thing, and the kid just needs Tylenol, I get it. This baby cost thousands of dollars and countless shots into your behind! It’s a rare, fragile thing, and now I can come at it from a more empathetic place and say, “I hear you. Having a baby is the most amazing and terrifying thing. Let’s get through it together.”

title.en-US: Why I chose to adopt

content.value: Real Talk on Fertility with Maven OB-GYN Audrey Lance

“On our second round of IVF, we had one embryo implant, but at 10 weeks, there was no heartbeat. I decided to go into work that day, and it was the hardest thing I’ve ever done—delivering other people’s babies right after losing mine.”
Name:
Audrey Lance
Age:
Q: When did you start trying to get pregnant, and when did you realize you might need help?

I was 32 when I went off birth control and my husband and I started trying to conceive. We bought some ovulation kits and had timed intercourse. As an OB-GYN, I knew it could take up to a year, so I didn’t freak out when I got my period every month. But as it got closer to a year, I started getting pretty bummed out. I was like, “I’m healthy—I don’t smoke; I don’t do drugs; I’ve never had an STD. I have no reason to think I would have infertility.” But I was also under a lot of stress, because my mom was sick and I was going back and forth between Michigan and Pennsylvania to spend time with her, so I thought maybe the stress had something to do with it. In the end, we tried for about 14 months before we went in for a fertility workup.
Q: As an OB-GYN, do you think stress can impact fertility?

Stress may impact an individual cycle. So when I was going through those stressful times, I thought, “Okay, there were a few months that were really difficult, so we’re not even going to count those, because the stress may have thrown everything off.” But stress did not cause my AMH
to be low, or my FSH

to be high, or my tube to be blocked. I get very upset when I hear people tell patients who are struggling to conceive that they’re “too stressed out”—because it’s essentially blaming them. I had the medical knowledge to know that it wasn’t my fault, but my patients don’t. So you get patients thinking that they could get pregnant if only they weren’t so stressed, and it’s really not the case. It’s just a total myth that only serves to blame women, and I hate it.
Q: What did you discover from your fertility workup?

My husband’s semen analysis was normal. I had some blood work done, an ultrasound, and an HSG, which is a special X-ray where they put dye into your uterus to see if your fallopian tubes are open. They found that one of my tubes was blocked, but if it’s only one, that shouldn’t cause infertility. My hormone levels were normal but borderline (my AMH was on the lower end and my FSH was on the higher end). But even though the lab said my results were normal, I’m a doctor, and I’m used to ordering these tests for patients, so I knew that those numbers were not exactly typical for a healthy 33-year-old woman.

I suspect that I have endometriosis. The only way to truly know for sure if you have endometriosis is to have surgery, but I had some of the tell-tale signs, including significant menstrual pain that is relieved with birth control. I have a friend who’s an infertility specialist, and I learned from him that endometriosis can cause decreased ovarian reserve. Surgical treatment of endometriosis can provide pain relief, but my doctor didn’t believe it would help me get pregnant, so I decided against it.
Q: How did you decide to proceed with having a baby?

My doctor didn’t think an IUI would work, so we went straight to IVF. I took hormones to boost my egg production, but they got only two eggs on our first attempt. One of them fertilized, only to stop developing by day 3. I remember talking to my husband about this little thing we had created, and how it was dead and was just going into the trash. It was a very weird feeling, and I was really taken aback by how sad it made me.

On our second round of IVF, we had one embryo implant in my uterus successfully, which was exciting. But then we did an ultrasound at around 10 weeks, and there was no heartbeat. I decided to go into work that day and the following, because I didn’t want to just lay in my couch and cry, and it was the hardest thing I’ve ever done—delivering other people’s babies right after losing mine.
Q: Knowing what to do after a couple of failed rounds of IVF can be a challenge for many people. How did you choose your next step?

I consulted another doctor at the hospital where I worked, and I asked her, “Do you think this is going to work for me? Because I am not one of those people who wants to spend my entire life savings trying IVF until I’m blue in the face.” She said she didn’t think our odds were great, but she suggested another medication regimen that might work. And I tried it, but about 10 days in, I get a call from the doctor, and she told me, “Audrey, your ovaries aren’t responding at all. Nothing is happening, and I think you should stop.”

I was on the maximum dose of the stimulation medication, and I remember telling my husband when we first started IVF that I didn’t understand the terrible side effects that people complained about, because I felt fine. The reason I felt fine was that the medications weren’t doing anything. If the medications are working, they make your ovaries pop with a lot of follicles, which makes you bloated and nauseous and very uncomfortable.

It was really hard to hear my doctor tell me to give up on IVF, but I appreciated her honesty. She was very nice and compassionate. At that point, we very quickly decided to go down the adoption route and adopted our daughter, who is now 13 months old.
Q: What was the experience of adopting like?

We’d always talked about using adoption to build our family even before we knew we had infertility. We got very lucky because we didn’t have to wait very long. Within two or three months of getting on the agency’s website, we got a call that a mom had selected us, and she had the baby two weeks later. We were absolutely floored. I remember crying and being so overwhelmed with emotion when we got that call. We didn’t have a single thing in our home for a baby, so we went to Target and bought some onesies, wipes, a car seat, a stroller, and some other bacis.
Q: What do you think are some common misconceptions that patients struggling with infertility have to contend with?

I think people don’t know how to talk about women’s reproduction in general. I often have people tell me, “Who knows, you might still get pregnant one day!” But I’m on the NuvaRing to control my endometriosis and my AMH level is 1, so that would be a miracle. And I don’t even want to be pregnant anymore; I’ve moved on. I have a beautiful, amazing daughter, and we’re going to adopt at least one more baby. I know people think they’re saying the right thing, but sometimes they really have no clue why you can’t get pregnant or even if it’s what you want anymore.

title.en-US: Early menopause led me to donor eggs

content.value: Real Talk on Fertility with Maven Mental Health Provider Bette Galen
“This was in the early 90s, and a colleague and I thought that my twins might be two of the first 200 egg donor offspring in the country.”
Name:
Bette Galen
Age:
Q: Why did you decide to start fertility treatment?

I had three miscarriages prior to the birth of my oldest son, who was born when I was 38. When he was about 3, my husband and I started trying to have a second. We finally went to a fertility clinic, did tests, and found out that I was actually going through menopause. They told me if I wanted another child, I would need an egg donor. Looking back, I would have asked many more questions and done more research. But a part of me didn't want to hear any negativity, so I just moved forward. I believe my OB-GYN would have been more helpful to me if he transferred care earlier to a reproductive endocrinologist.
Q: Was the decision to use an egg donor difficult for you to make?

Not for me—and I'm aware that this is highly unusual. My family was instrumental in my having this attitude. I am the youngest of four children and was extremely close to my brother who was closest in age to me. So I didn't want my son to be an only child. My husband initially thought adoption would be a good solution, but I wanted to have his genes in my child. And by using a donor, I would have the opportunity to carry the pregnancy.
Q: What was the process of finding a donor like?

The wait to be matched with an egg donor in the Northwest was 1.5 years, and because we didn’t want to wait, we traveled to a clinic in the South. I got very little information about the donor; just one page. That's the way this clinic worked back then. I was 43 when my twins—a boy and a girl—were born. This was in the early 90s, and a colleague and I thought that they might be two of the first 200 egg donor offspring in the country.
Q: Did people have awareness about egg donors at the time?

Not really. I remember going into the playground when my son was around 4 and asking people if they had ever heard of egg donors, and they said, “What are you talking about?” I was looking for someone to say they knew about it.
Q: How did you approach telling your kids they came from an egg donor?

I approached it as a parenting/family story primarily. I told my kids when they were 7 years old. We talked about all the different kinds of families—those with two moms or dads, kids being raised by grandparents, etc. Then we explained that making a baby requires a part from a man and a part from a woman and that my part wasn’t working so we asked a nice lady to help out. They weren't so interested, and when I was done talking, my son asked if he could go play video games.
Q: Did they have more questions as they got older?

My son has only mentioned being a donor offspring twice. My daughter and I talk about it all the time. In middle school, she had to do a family tree project and asked if she should put the donor on the tree because, genetically, the donor would belong on it. But I wanted to find out if this was an emotional question or a strategic question. So I asked her if she liked the teacher and the kids in her class, or if there was anyone she didn't like or who might make fun of her. I told her to think about it, and she came back and said she wasn’t going to put the donor on the tree. When she was a bit older, we were sitting in the kitchen and she said, out of the blue, “Mom, do you think I’ll have big breasts like you?” I was totally taken aback and trying not to cry because I wasn't prepared for this kind of question. And I said, “Honey, I really don’t know. You could have grandma’s or the donor’s, but whatever you have, we’ll go bra shopping together.” She smiled a huge smile! There are lots of stories like that.
Q: Today you work as a therapist counseling women with reproductive issues and also leading support groups. Why do you think it’s important for women to have help during fertility treatment?

Women are out there by themselves. They might have a husband who’s on board, but it’s always good to talk to a third party. Some clinics offer support groups, but not all places do that. I think it helps for women to know what they’re facing. My group is all about women supporting women. We talk about what they can do to take care of themselves. Like, do you need to go to birthday parties and baby showers? If you can’t do it, don’t go. It can feel like a long road when you’re in treatment, so I say prepare for a marathon and hopefully it will be a sprint. It’s also a place where women can exchange information—about doctors, practices, procedures—and also get support and understanding about what it's like dealing with infertility.
Q: Do you think there needs to be more awareness about egg donation?

Yes. I remember so clearly when I was counseling a woman years ago and I said, “Do you think celebs having babies in their late 40s and early 50s aren't using egg donors?" Tears started rolling down her face as she thought, “If they can do it, so can I.” Celebrities don’t have golden eggs—they have the same fertility profiles as you and me. After 35, our reproductive possibilities begin to diminish. You have to assume that if a woman is over 45, there’s a good chance she used an egg donor. I think more women will start talking about it as they get more comfortable with the fact that there are many ways to become a parent, even if it’s not the way they envisioned.

title.en-US: A partner's experience of IVF

content.value: Real Talk on Fertility with Maven Mental Health Provider Gerardo Sorkin

“I’ve treated men going through infertility, and I’ve found that they feel the same isolation I felt going through IVF. The emotional needs of male partners are often not seen or acknowledged, and I think that providing support can be helpful to not only the men, but also the women undergoing treatment as well as the children that may result.”
Name:
Gerardo Sorkin
Age:
Q: What was your experience with infertility treatment?

After we got married, my ex-wife and I tried to get pregnant for almost a year with no success. We explored several fertility treatment options, and considering our age and what we learned from our research, we decided to go directly to IVF. We just thought those alternatives might take time, and felt that the best option for us was IVF. My ex-wife got pregnant with twins after our first round, and we’re the proud parents of a boy and a girl who are now 13 years old.
Q: Did doctors diagnose the cause of your infertility?
It was unexplained infertility. We underwent some testing, and they found that my sperm count was reasonable, and also could not pinpoint anything specific on my wife's side.
Q: How did you choose your fertility center, and what was your experience like?

We chose the University of Connecticut Medical Center because it was close to us and had a good record of success, and we had a terrific experience. The head of the center was originally from Argentina, which is where I’m from, so we had a cultural connection, and our medical team was very professional. We were also invited to be part of an experimental study that subsidized some of the drugs that were not covered by insurance.
Q: Carrying twins can be risky. How did things go during pregnancy and delivery?

It was okay until my ex-wife’s water broke a month early. We ended up going to the closest hospital in an ambulance rather than the center where we were planning to deliver. One the twins were born, they had to go into the NICU. It was a very dramatic and intense situation, but the support we got from our medical team, and specifically our nurses, was out of this world. It was truly one of the most gratifying medical experiences of my life. They taught us how to take care of the babies, and one nurse was by our side 24/7.
Q: How did IVF impact your relationship with your wife at the time?

It was stressful on us as a couple. I was the one administering the daily injections to stimulate her ovaries. The injections really weren’t a problem for me once I learned the technique. But the hormones did affect my wife’s mood, so I had to provide a supportive environment while also being the designated nurse. I had to keep that in mind throughout this whole process—that these were side effects of the shots—and remain focused on the path we had selected. Overall, it was difficult but manageable.

There was also the stress associated with the pregnancy, the delivery, and the months after the babies were born, which isn’t necessarily related to the IVF process itself. The stress associated with parenting wasn’t different from what any other couple would face, no matter how they conceived, but it was real.
Q: What was your biggest source of support throughout this process?

I have a few colleagues who’ve become friends, and we’ve developed a relationship where we can share honestly and disclose personal matters to each other. I relied on their support during this time. I also felt I could be open about our fertility struggles with my friends and family even though it wasn’t something I was advertising to the world. Culturally, I find that people from other countries like Argentina are more open about these things than people in the US, so that was an advantage for me.
Q: What else do you think may have been helpful in overcoming some of the emotional difficulties of undergoing IVF?

I wish we’d had a more formalized system of support. Our fertility center may have had mental health services available, but I don’t remember them being advertised much. I didn’t really think about it at the time, but looking back, it would have been great for my ex-wife to have been part of a support group of other women who were going through a similar experience. Support for fathers was nonexistent, so I had to rely on my training as a psychologist in Argentina and a clinical social worker in the US to work through my emotions.
Q: What are some of the emotional struggles faced by men that people may not realize?

Men are expected to be—first and foremost—supportive of their partner while the woman is the one bearing the brunt of treatment and going through these hormonal fireworks that can really affect her mood. So I think the first challenge for us men is how to deal with this overwhelming emotional weight. I also think that men worry about things like, How are we going to support these kids? What’s going to happen to our family finances? How are we going to make sure the house can accommodate these newcomers? But we have a tendency to keep these worries to ourselves rather than finding an outlet for them. In my case, I found that there were a lot of unexpected emotions and stress that I had to resolve on my own, because support for fathers was basically nonexistent.
Q: As a mental health provider, how do you think the healthcare industry can improve the patient experience for prospective fathers?

I’ve treated other men going through this in my practice, and I’ve found that they feel the same isolation I felt going through IVF. While many medical centers do provide emotional support services for the woman, I see so many men who don’t have access to any kind of support. It’s almost like their emotional needs are not recognized or acknowledged. Mental health services like the ones offered through Maven and other online services can help fill these gaps in care. And I think that providing psychological support to the man will have a positive impact on the woman as well as the children that may result from the fertility treatment. The stronger the parents are at the end of this process, the better they can be for the kids.
Q: What advice would you give to other men going through this experience?

I’d tell them that they shouldn’t feel excluded, because we are 50% of the child or children who are coming, so we are an extremely valuable part of the process. And we don’t need to wait until the children are born to be involved. We may have different emotional needs and process things differently than women do, but mutual support is key.

title.en-US: Recovering from loss at 32 weeks

content.value: Real Talk on Fertility with Maven Mental Health Provider Allison Yura

“It’s hard to know how to support someone who’s lost a baby, and there really is no right thing you can do.
