But I’ll remember the people who’ve shown up and been there for us for the rest of my life—whether it’s bringing groceries, sending dinners, making a donation in our daughter’s name, calling on her due date, or checking in during the holidays.”
Name:
Allison Yura
Age:
Q: When did you realize you might need help getting pregnant?

I have a history of ovarian cysts, so my husband and I knew from the beginning that we might need help. I was diagnosed with dermoid ovarian cysts when I was younger, which is very different from PCOS (polycystic ovarian syndrome), the hormonal condition you often hear about. Dermoid ovarian cysts can grow to be quite large and usually require surgical removal. I had to have laparoscopic surgery to remove them from both ovaries when I was 20, and again at 30. Unfortunately, one of the risks of the surgery is that healthy ovarian tissue—where potential eggs live—can also be removed along with the cysts, leaving you with a decreased ovarian reserve. After my last surgery, my husband and I tried to get pregnant on our own for a couple of months, but we started noticing that my periods were coming too close together. That’s when we turned to a fertility specialist.
Q: What was your experience with infertility treatment?

Because my husband and I were both so young—I was 30, and he’s a bit younger than me—our fertility specialist was hopeful that we might still get pregnant naturally even though I had a lower ovarian reserve. She recommended timed intercourse, but after after six months of that with no success, we turned to IVF. To prepare for the IVF, I was taking a combination of different medications to stimulate the ovaries, but I didn’t have a lot of eggs growing, so my doctor had me stop. On my next attempt, I was on a higher dose of hormones, and they got six good eggs during the retrieval—five matured, and three fertilized. Two of those three stopped developing, but they transferred one, and I got pregnant. But unfortunately, my daughter was stillborn at 32 weeks this past August, which was devastating. We gave my body some time to heal and just completed another round of IVF at a different fertility clinic this month.
Q: What was the experience of losing your daughter like—did you sense that something was wrong?

Our daughter was very active, kicking a lot during my pregnancy. I was at work one day and noticed I hadn’t felt any movement in a few hours. I’d heard that sometimes babies slow down as they get bigger, but I called my doctor to tell her what was going on and she had me come in. They looked for the heartbeat with a Doppler, and there was nothing there. When they pulled up an ultrasound, it was pretty clear to them, and to me, that the baby wasn’t moving at all. She had died before I got to the hospital. They induced me right away, and I was in labor for a little over 24 hours. They did an autopsy and found that there was likely a constriction of the umbilical cord, like a straw that gets bent, which made it hard for nutrients and oxygen to get through.
Everything had been fine with my pregnancy until then, so it really felt like it was completely out of nowhere. I remember calling my husband on my walk to the hospital and telling him, “I’m going in, but don’t leave work yet.”
Q: How did you cope with the grief of losing your baby?

It was the hardest thing I’ve ever done. The hospital had a social worker on staff to help us cope, and the nurses couldn’t have been more wonderful. We spent some time with our daughter at the hospital, which was really therapeutic, and we had them take pictures. In our city in Illinois, you need to have a proper burial for a stillbirth, so we had a funeral. My husband and I both took some time off work, and we’ve been spending as much time as we can with people who support us. We also opened a fund in her name at an organization that supports other families going through the devastation of pregnancy loss. We’ve been doing everything we can to honor her life, as short as it was.
Q: After your loss, you made the choice to try another round of IVF. Are you and your husband open to other options, like adoption or surrogacy, if IVF doesn’t work out?

That’s something we don’t see eye to eye on right now. We’ve discussed it, but we haven’t agreed on when would be the right time to pursue those alternatives. We started couples therapy during our first round of IVF last fall, and he’s continued seeing her weekly while I now meet with a different therapist. Then we go in to the couples therapist together every once in awhile. Counseling has been an incredible tool for us. Things have been stressful, but between therapy and our own persistence, we’ve managed to learn how to support one another. In terms of next steps in the near term, we’re lucky enough to live in a state (Illinois) where insurance covers four egg retrievals, so we’ve had relatively low out-of-pocket expenses so far. If this cycle doesn’t work, then we’d like to do one more retrieval of my eggs before moving on to donor eggs. And then we’ll see.
Q: Given your own training as a mental health provider, is there anything you think could make the patient experience better at fertility centers?

I was baffled by the lack of empathy I encountered with the IVF doctor at my first clinic—especially considering my provider had been through IVF herself. I think fertility centers need to provide patient-centered care, which boils down to responsiveness, empathy, and taking the time to listen to the patient. The specialist I’m seeing now suffered a pregnancy loss at 24 weeks; there’s this level of understanding and empathy that I’m really happy with. But the clinic itself is more disorganized than the previous one we went to. For instance, there hasn’t been a specific coordinator or nurse assigned to us like we had in the previous practice, so that’s been a headache. I’ve definitely had to advocate for myself more.

Q: Sometimes it’s hard to know how to support someone going through something as difficult as what you experienced with the loss of your daughter. Is there anything other people have said or done that has been particularly helpful to you?

I’ve been through this, and I still don’t know the best way to offer support. It’s hard to know what to do, and there really is no right thing you can do. People don’t want to make you sad by bringing up a painful subject, but the thing about grief is, you’re already sad. Someone talking about it is not what makes you said; rather, it’s an acknowledgement. Say her name; let's recognize her. That’s how I feel, although it’s a little different for everybody. I’ve been in touch with other moms who went through something similar, and they don’t want to talk about it. But I think there’s nothing wrong with simply asking, “Do you want to talk about the baby?”

It’s not great to say, “Well, let me know if you need anything.” Just offer what you want, and let the other person take you up on it if they need to. I’ll remember the people who’ve shown up and been there for us for the rest of my life—whether they brought us groceries, sent dinners, made a donation in our daughter’s name, called me when her due date approached, or checked in during the holidays. The problem with any grief is that you think people are better in time. Time heals, but it doesn’t make the pain go away.

title.en-US: Becoming pregnant with an egg donor

content.value: Real Talk on Fertility with Maven Midwife Nicole Marshall

“I feel so grateful to this nameless, faceless woman. She gave me such a gift, and there’s no shame in it. There’s only shame if we let there be shame. People use sperm donors all the time, and nobody thinks twice.”
Age:
Name:
Nicole Marshall
Q: When did you realize you would need the help of fertility treatment to get pregnant?

The first time around, I was 31 when my husband and I tried have a baby. After 10 months, I had a fertility workup because I was starting to panic. But all the numbers were fine. My husband’s sperm had a morphology issue (which refers to the size and shape), but the quantity and volume were fine, so they weren’t too concerned. And then we got pregnant within the next couple of months without any intervention. I was 33 when my daughter was born, and had a completely normal pregnancy and delivered a healthy daughter.

Things changed when we started trying for a second child a couple of years later. After 12 months of not getting pregnant, I had another workup. They said my numbers were all still normal given my age, which was 36. I nursed my daughter for two years so I was a bit underweight, which I don’t think helped my situation. That’s when my 2-year journey with infertility treatment began.
Q: Once you decided that you would pursue fertility treatment, how did you decide to go straight to IVF?

I was told to skip IUI because I was a great candidate for IVF. My doctor thought I would be an easy case because I already had a child and I was in good health. On my first round, we got three or four embryos. Because I was over 35, they convinced me to do PGS (preimplantation genetic screening) on my embryos. It’s a good thing we did, because they were all abnormal, so we didn’t implant any of them. That was a huge bummer. At the outset, my husband and I had said we would try IVF once, and if it didn’t work, we would move on to adoption. But the doctors suggested we try again, explaining that we would likely get at least one or two normal embryos next time. Desperate to be pregnant, we did a second round, but the exact same thing happened.
Q: What did you decide to do next?

We started looking into adoption. At the same time, one of my friends had recommended another fertility specialist that I should consult, so I went to see him. We decided to go through a third round of IVF, but I only got one embryo so we didn’t bother testing it before doing the transfer. It implanted, and then I miscarried at eight weeks. The heartbeat was too slow at six weeks, so I knew it was going to end in a miscarriage. I ended up having to do a dilation and curettage (D&C) to empty the uterus, and had the procedure done at an abortion clinic surrounded by much younger women with unintended pregnancies, which was a sobering experience. Since we had already filled out the adoption paperwork, we put it in the mail after leaving the clinic.
Q: What considerations did you have to make before starting the adoption process?

We decided to do a domestic adoption because international is near impossible right now for a combination of reasons, mostly political. For example, Russia banned adoption a few years ago in response to sanctions by the US, and other countries have done the same. When considering adoption, you have to ask yourself a lot of questions as a person, as a couple, as a family. Will we adopt a baby that’s been exposed to opioids or cigarette smoke? Are you open to a different race? It was a lot of soul-searching.
Q: What did the adoption process entail?

First, we had to go through the vetting process required of families seeking to adopt, including home visits and background checks. Once that was done, we got into an adoption pool for prospective parents. We paid $20,000 to our agency and got picked by a birth mother pretty quickly. She was very early in her pregnancy, and we had some phone calls to start to build a relationship with her. Immediately it seemed like something was off, but our agency said there were no red flags. You’re vulnerable and desperate, and they’re the experts, so you believe them.

Long story short, months into the process, we found out the birth mother had a history of picking multiple families, who are all giving her money for rent, food, and medical expenses. Each family believed that they were the only adoptive family chosen, fully expecting and preparing for a baby. This was her seventh baby, and fifth that she would be putting up for adoption. We couldn’t prove she was repeating this cycle in our case, but knowing that she had a history of deceiving families was enough for us to pull out. And while we understood that a birth mom can change her mind, this was different, and we couldn't bear the thought of that level of heartbreak.
Q: That must’ve been a hard to decision to make. How did you cope?

IVF is physically and emotionally awful, but this particular adoption put me over the edge. I felt like I didn’t know myself: One morning I would wake up feeling like I was making the worst decision, and then I would talk myself into it, saying, “Who cares if she’s a con artist if we get a baby out of it?” And then I was like, “No, this is insane.” The way the pendulum would swing was so uncharacteristic of anything I’ve ever experienced in my life.

I knew I needed professional help. I had never in my life seen a therapist before, but I recognized that this was something my friends and family couldn’t help me with. I found a social worker whose specialty was fertility and adoption. I only met with her a handful of times, but in seeing her, I was able to come to terms with the fact that no matter what happened, it would be okay. The minute we pulled out of the adoption, I felt better and knew it was the right thing to do.
Q: If you could go back in time, is there anything you would’ve done differently?

We ended up picking an adoption agency that a friend of a friend had used. In retrospect, they were horrible, but they had access to birth moms throughout the country, so their wait time for a baby was faster than others I looked into. I was so focused on the timeline, but if I could do it again, I would have picked differently. It’s better to focus on finding a reputable agency than obsessing over how quickly you’ll get your baby. The really good agencies will also have social workers that can help you through this very hard process.
Q: At any point during the process, did you try to come to terms with the idea of only having one child?

People would say to me, “You’re so lucky to have Eleanor.” And there’s not a minute that goes by that I don’t feel lucky to have her, but it doesn’t change wanting her to have a sibling, and really wanting to have another baby. I wanted to be okay with just having one child, and I couldn’t do it. Each time IVF failed I felt so selfish because I have this perfect child, but I want her to have siblings. And then I would think, Maybe this is all happening because we’re not meant to have another child. Maybe this is supposed to be it for us. There are so many concrete benefits to only having one, but I couldn’t come to terms with it. My husband said to me, “I will be happy with one child, I will be happy if we adopt a child, and I will support you if you want to do IVF again.” Of course it was an ongoing conversation that consumed our lives. We were 100% in this as a team. There was negotiating, but it was all with love and care.
Q: Where did you go from there?

When I was going through my second round of IVF, my doctor brought up the possibility of using a donor egg instead of my own. I shut down and said we’d adopt before we did that. Everyone draws their own line, and at the time it seemed like too much science. It also felt selfish, considering there are babies who need homes. But we tried to adopt and it didn’t work for us. And during that process, I had worked through the emotional part about having a child not genetically related to me. We were about to adopt a baby outside of our race with completely different DNA. Suddenly an egg donor didn’t seem like that crazy of an idea anymore. So that’s what we did.
Q: How did you find your egg donor?

A midwife I used to work with told me she had successfully used an egg donor in Europe. She said she spent a fraction of what it would have cost her to do this in the US, and she was pleased with the high quality of care she received. I trusted her opinion, and decided I too would do IVF with an egg donor abroad. We went with a clinic that’s based outside of Prague. Once we narrowed down the donor, the clinic emailed us to let us know when the egg retrieval would need to happen, and we booked our flights. I had to take birth control pills and then hormones in advance to suppress my ovulation so I could sync up with the donor. She had her eggs retrieved, my husband gave his sperm to fertilize them, and then—once the work was done—we had a fabulous vacation. On day five, they had three perfect embryos, and we implanted one. As we speak, I’m pregnant—and at the end of my second trimester!
Q: Were you open with your friends and family about using a donor?

Everybody knows. Otherwise, I believe it does a disservice to women. I’m not being judgmental to women who choose not to tell. I think society tells us not to tell. But I refuse to succumb to that. I’ll shout it from the rooftops. I feel so grateful to this nameless, faceless woman. She gave me such a gift, and there’s no shame in it. There’s only shame if we let there be shame in it. People use sperm donors all the time, and nobody thinks twice.

title.en-US: IUI with donor sperm

content.value: Real Talk on Fertility with Maven Nurse Practitioner Shana Spitzman

“We wanted our biological children to come from the same donor, so the most difficult part of the process for us was figuring out how many vials of sperm to buy. They’re expensive, and we didn’t know how long it would take us to get pregnant, so there was always a chance that if we bought too little we wouldn’t get pregnant from the donor we’d selected.”
Name:
Shana Spitzman
Age:
Q: What’s your experience with fertility treatment?

I got pregnant after IUI; I'm gay and used an anonymous donor from a cryobank. My wife also conceived using IUI. It was fairly easy for us because neither of us had serious fertility issues. In my partner’s case, it was discovered that she had a number of uterine fibroids, but the fertility clinic was able to connect us with a surgeon who specialized on surgical fibroid removal to preserve fertility when possible. (She had the surgery and luckily it was successful.) But beyond that, all we had to do was use ovulation tests to track our cycles. When we saw an LH surge, we’d do the IUI within 24-36 hours.
Q: Why was it important for you and your wife to have biological children?

We had already adopted a child before we started this process. But on a personal level, I always wanted to know what it felt like to be pregnant, give birth, and breastfeed, if possible. I didn’t think of it as being better or worse than adopting, I just knew that I wanted to have that life experience, and my partner had the same desire.
Q: What was your clinic experience like?

Well, before we went to the clinic, we tried to do IUI at home with midwives who advertised this as part of their practice. They come into your house and use the exact same supplies they use in a fertility clinic, but they don’t require all of the testing that you would do at a clinic. I liked the idea of getting pregnant at home and doing things in a cozy environment. I also thought that not being in a sterile, medical situation would be less stressful and boost our odds. I don’t think there are any medical studies to support this; it was just my intuition. That said, my partner and I took turns and each tried several times without success. For each attempt, you use a vial of sperm, which is expensive. So for financial reasons, we ultimately decided to go to a clinic, in case that made the process faster.
Q: What was it like switching from at-home IUIs to being at a fertility clinic for the procedure?

In the end, doing the IUIs at the clinic really wasn’t that big of a deal—it’s a very easy, quick, and painless procedure. As a nurse, I’m very familiar with medical environments, but it was also pretty straightforward for my partner, who’s much less familiar with that setting. I got pregnant on my second attempt at the clinic, and, after a successful myomectomy fibroid surgery to remove uterine fibroids, my partner got pregnant on the first try. I gave birth to a boy who is now four years old, and my partner gave birth to a girl who’s now three. I can’t really explain why things happened quickly once we were in the clinic settling. It may have had something to do with the way we were thawing the vials at home, but I’m not 100% sure.
Q: How did you choose your sperm donor bank and fertility clinic?

We chose a sperm bank that had a large number of donors from diverse racial backgrounds, because we are an interracial couple. We found a fertility doctor who had been advertising her services to lesbians in the DC area, where we were living at the time. She came to a number of conferences and support groups that my wife and I were involved in, and she seemed responsible, knowledgeable, and open-minded. So we decided to start the process with her. She was very responsive and easy to work with.

Q: Overall, how would you describe your patient experience?
I feel lucky that we had such a good experience. I know a lot of people who’ve been treated really badly in the health care system, and I always tell them that if they don’t trust their providers, find someone else right away. We were very picky in finding the place with the best reputation, where we thought we’d receive the best treatment.
Q: What was the most difficult part of the process?

Figuring out how many vials of sperm to buy. My wife and I wanted to have the same donor for both children, so it was important to get the right amount. But they’re expensive, and we didn’t know how long it was going to take us to get pregnant. If you buy too little, you may not get pregnant from the donor you selected.
Q: The two-week wait to discover whether you are pregnant after an IUI is challenging for a lot of women. How did you deal with it?

Waiting to find out if we were pregnant after each insemination—and the disappointment of finding out it wasn’t successful—was hard. I’m sure this is something others can relate to: When you’ve never been pregnant before, you wonder if every little ache or pain means you’re pregnant. And since we tried at home before going to the clinic for the IUIs, and waited a few months between each attempt, we ended up spending at least a year or two trying to conceive. The process definitely felt long and all-consuming. You’re going through the normal motions of life, like working and sleeping, while your focus is on getting pregnant and trying to be as healthy as possible in the hopes of boosting your odds.
Q: What was it like to be a partner to someone going through IUI after having experienced it yourself?

I definitely felt better able to support her. But the fact that we already had two kids by the time my wife got pregnant also meant we were both busy taking care of our children and less focused on my wife getting pregnant and the pregnancy itself. We also had a better idea of how to prepare and how we wanted to do things, so we didn’t do all the prenatal reading and classes we did in anticipation of my pregnancy.
Q: What issues did you have to navigate that straight couples don’t normally face?

There are obvious first-step decisions that straight couples don’t have to make, like choosing a sperm donor (unless there are issues with using a male partner’s sperm). And certain people were less understanding of our situation than they may have been of a straight couple trying to conceive. We’d get confused reactions from family members and employers about bringing up a child without a father figure given the discrimination that still exists in our society. On the flip side, it is more readily understood why LGBT people would be using the services of a fertility clinic, so we rarely received any intrusive questions.
Q: How do you think going through this experience has affected your practice?

I work with babies and prospective parents in my practice, and I’ve found that I’m better able to advise and help patients trying to get pregnant. Thanks to this experience, I’m more comfortable discussing things like ovulation testing and the best time to have sex or inseminate in order to conceive. As a nurse, any time you go through something yourself, you become better able to treat others with a similar problem.
Q: Was there anything about this experience that, looking back now, makes you laugh?

When we were doing the at-home IUIs, the sperm tank would be delivered to our house. But it’s pretty difficult to find midwives who will do IUIs in a non-medical environment, so one time, we had to meet the midwife in Philadelphia rather than at our home. So we had to pick up the sperm from a New York City cryobank storage facility. We have some pretty funny memories of driving around with this big sperm tank and trying to figure out what backpack the sperm could go in and how to carry it through the streets. It was a totally crazy experience that didn’t end up helping us get pregnant. It would’ve been very simple to just have the tank shipped to the clinic where we actually ended up getting pregnant. Live and learn!

title.en-US: Pregnant after stopping treatment

content.value: Real Talk on Fertility with Maven Psychologist/Neuroscientist Nicole Avena, Ph.D.

“A lot of times it can be overwhelming and you feel like you have to do something. But you can put the breaks on at any time. Over the years, I’ve known people who have gone right to IVF, and that can be upsetting when it doesn’t work. There are lots of things you can do prior to IVF.”
Name:
Nicole Avena
Age:
Q: When did you first decide to see a fertility specialist?

I was 30 when my daughter was born, and was able to get pregnant relatively easily. We gave it a couple of years trying for our second, and then got to the point where we decided it was best to talk to somebody. Around the time that we were starting to think about seeing a doctor, I had a miscarriage at about eight weeks, and that encouraged me to finally find out what was going on.

I saw a reproductive endocrinologist who confirmed that I had PCOS. I knew I had it, but I was asymptomatic. Because I have PCOS, one of the first things often prescribed is Metformin, which is a drug that can help women with this condition ovulate more regularly. As my treatment progressed, I ended up going through a couple of rounds of Clomid, one cycle of IUI, and one cycle of IVF. They were all unsuccessful, but I became pregnant with my second daughter naturally four months after we decided to stop treatment. She was born when I was 37.
Q: Were there any particularly tough moments during your infertility treatment journey?

Yes. It was when I was taking Metformin in conjunction with Clomid, and managed to get pregnant. I was happy and excited. When I went to the initial appointment, they discovered it was an ectopic pregnancy, where the fetus implants outside of the uterus. It can be dangerous because it can cause internal bleeding and rupture the fallopian tube, so the pregnancy needed to be terminated right away. I was totally taken aback.
Q: How did the ectopic pregnancy compare to the miscarriage you had experienced?

They’re obviously both traumatic, but for me, the miscarriage was a much quicker process. I started bleeding, and I knew something bad was happening. It was confirmed immediately, and it was over. Plus I had some personal time to grieve because I was alone when it started. It was still upsetting, but I was able to move on a bit quicker.

The ectopic pregnancy, on the other hand, hit me like a truck. I was not bleeding, and I didn’t have cramps—I was just this happy girl who had a positive pregnancy test. So there was this element of surprise—going in and having the doctor say there’s a problem when you’re not at all expecting to hear that. It’s one thing to find out you thought you were pregnant and now you’re not, but now I had the added worry concerning medical complications.

With an ectopic, there are additional steps that are taken to end the pregnancy. I had to take a drug called methotrexate, which stops the fetal cells from developing. I actually had to take it twice because it didn’t work the first time. It ended up taking about 3 weeks to completely be over. It was such a dragged-out process. I recall being in New York City for a work meeting, walking around and thinking, “What am I doing here? I’m having a miscarriage right now.” It was a very strange time in my life because I knew the pregnancy wasn’t working out, and that I had to move on, but was I supposed to stay home and wait for it to be over?

It was such a dragged-out process. I recall being in New York City for a work meeting, walking around and thinking, “What am I doing here? I’m having a miscarriage right now.” It was a very strange time in my life because I knew the pregnancy wasn’t working out, and that I had to move on, but was I supposed to stay home and wait for it to be over?
Q: How did you handle the grief from the ectopic pregnancy?

I have an educational background in psychology, so I’ve studied ways to cope when life throws you these types of challenges. As much as I could, I relied on my training to think about things differently so I didn’t get depressed. There’s a lot of talk in psychology about a growth mindset versus a fixed mindset. If you think you’re not going to get pregnant, that’s a fixed mindset. A growth mindset is when you look at challenges as an opportunity to learn and move forward. That is what I would often turn to when I wanted to give up and crawl up into a ball. It wasn’t always easy, but I tried to look at everything that came at me as something I would grow from. But I also leaned on my husband; he was my support system through everything. And I had my daughter. She was six years old when it happened, and I looked to her as my inspiration to stay positive and keep moving forward.
Q: Many women describe their infertility journey as the most isolating time in their lives. Was this true for you?

I never felt lonely in the sense that I was the only person this was happening to. But, especially with the ectopic pregnancy, I did feel like people didn’t understand it. We told our parents, but I didn’t really open up about it to friends at first because there wasn’t anything they could say to make me feel better.
Q: What was the most difficult part of your fertility treatment experience?

One thing I was a little shocked by was how regimented it was, in the sense that you walk into the clinic and it’s all mapped out in terms of what will happen and when. I get that it’s a medical situation, so there have to be formulas involved, but I think that can be scary for a lot of people. You want to feel like you’re getting personalized care and sense that your treatment is evolving in an organic way, and that’s hard when you’re on such a strict schedule.
Q: What advice would you give someone going through fertility treatments?

Because everything is so prescribed, a lot of times it can be overwhelming and you feel like you have to do something. But you can put the brakes on at any time. I was vocal about my situation and felt comfortable talking about it. The doctors had suggested we do an IUI right away, and I said no. I asked about trying something else first, so that’s what we did. Women should feel empowered to have those types of conversations with their doctors so they don’t feel rushed into something they don’t want to do. Over the years, I’ve known people who have gone right to IVF, and that can be upsetting when it doesn’t work. In many cases, there are lots of things you can do prior to IVF.
Q: Is there anything you think doctors could do to make the patient experience better?

From the perspective of providers, people come to them because they want a baby and they want it now. I think there’s this balance between giving people what they want—which is a baby, in the fastest way possible—and understanding the nature of each couple’s situation. The fact that we already had a daughter didn’t mean that we were trying any less. But I also didn’t feel this immediate rush. It would help if doctors had these conversations with each person or couple who walks in the door. They could ask, “If this takes you three years, will that be a problem?” Then they might not push everyone to do more aggressive treatment right away if that’s not the mindset or situation they’re in.
Q: How did your experience affect your relationship with your husband?

It certainly didn’t hurt our relationship. If anything, he was able to see a more vulnerable side of me, with the grief of the losses. And now that we’re on the other side, I think it helped our marriage because it allowed us to go through a crisis and get through it together.

In the thick of it, we talked to each other a lot about what was going on, and it was important for me that he was comfortable with what we were doing. A lot of times the male partner feels like he can’t speak up, or he might be shy because he doesn’t want to upset his wife. I think it’s important for both people to be able to talk openly about any reservations or concerns they have.
Q: Have you changed any aspect of your practice as a result of your fertility journey?

Prior to going through it, I was sensitive to these issues, but it wasn’t on my radar as much. Having a personal experience with something changes your ability to relate and allows you to understand it on a completely different level. It doesn’t mean you’re more or less good at your job if you haven’t gone through it, but now I can offer a different perspective.

title.en-US: Becoming a mother after loss

content.value: Real Talk on Fertility with Maven Nurse Practitioner Dana Carter

“It’s important to keep everything in perspective and see the bigger picture. I have a supportive husband and two healthy children. Things aren’t perfect, but this whole experience has made me a better practitioner, and there’s certainly a lot to be thankful for.”
Name:
Dana Carter
Age:
Q: When did you realize you would need help getting pregnant?

My husband was in the military when we got married. He got deployed to Iraq about two months after our wedding, and right before he left, I found out I was pregnant. But I lost the baby at about seven weeks, while he was overseas. He came back after a year, and we got pregnant again after three months of trying. But it ended up being a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. (This is when an embryo implants itself outside the uterus, in one of the fallopian tubes; as it grows, it caused the tube to rupture.)

I had to have emergency surgery and lost my left tube. We kept trying to conceive for a year and a half after that, and nothing happened. No chemical pregnancies, nothing. Being in the field I’m in, I knew we needed intervention, but I really never thought I’d do IVF—I’ve seen what my patients go through, how emotionally taxing and expensive it is. I was also very okay with the idea of adopting, even though adoption is also very expensive.
Q: What did you do next?

We spoke to a fertility specialist to see what our options were. I was 29 at the time. They ran tests on my husband, and he was totally fine. But on my end, they found some autoimmune conditions and basically said, “Your body is fighting every opportunity for you to get pregnant.” They also saw signs of endometriosis, and told me not to waste my time with an IUI (intrauterine insemination) or anything low-tech like that; IVF was our only option. This was horrible to hear. Women already have a tendency to blame themselves about issues related to conception, and there I was being told that it was basically my fault because my body wasn’t cooperating.
Q: When doctors told you IVF was your best bet, how did you become ready to do it?

I battled with the decision for a while, because after two losses, I wasn’t sure I could face the financial and emotional toll of going through IVF only to lose another baby. I reached out to one of my favorite physicians that I work with, and he said, “Would you feel okay if you didn’t try this?” I thought about his question, and through that self-reflection, I decided to try it at least once. And I’m so glad we did. We had eight embryos after the first try. They put two back in my uterus, and we got my son Nicholas. Then they froze the other six. My daughter Anna came from two more of those.
Q: Is there anything you wish you’d known before you went through treatment?

The hardest part has been deciding what to do with the frozen embryos that remain. I didn’t predict this being a problem at all. We were just going to do IVF once, and if it didn’t work, we were going to adopt. The last thing we expected was to be in a situation where we’d have too many embryos. Many people in the medical community think you should donate them to scientific research (which results in their destruction) or just trash them. But that’s not the way I see it. To me, those are my babies.

The thing is, I had very high-risk pregnancies: With my daughter, I started dilating at 12 weeks and was at risk for uterine rupture, so I was put on bed rest. So I’ve been advised not to get pregnant again. Meanwhile, my husband and I pay for those embryos to be stored on a monthly basis, and I just don’t know what to do with them. If my uterus ruptures in another pregnancy and I die, what will my husband tell my kids? “Mom chose those embryos over her life of being a mom to you.” There’s surrogacy, but it’s like $50,000, and it’s money I’d be taking away from my children’s future. The one option I’ve read about that I might do is something called “compassionate transfer”—this is where they basically put the embryo in your uterus at a time that you can’t get pregnant.
Q: How did you cope with the stress of pregnancy loss and infertility?

My husband has been incredibly supportive through all of this. Still, he’s not an emotional person, so it helped to have others I could turn to as well. A friend of mine was also going through infertility at the same time that I did, so I called her whenever I needed someone to talk to. I was also seeing a therapist before this whole journey even began, and she taught me a lot about stress management, meditation, and yoga. Something as simple as taking 20 minutes to do some deep breathing exercises and reset can make a big difference! I also make sure I get in my three days a week at the gym.
Q: As a medical professional, how do you think the healthcare industry needs to change to better support the patient experience?

I’m always surprised that mental health support is not a bigger part of the process. Often people with a history of anxiety and depression are worried about being on any type of medication because it might interfere with getting pregnant. But I tell them that it’s not good to go into this process feeling overwhelmed, because after a pregnancy, you’re going to be even more overwhelmed. You’ve waited for this for so long and you think it’s going to be butterflies and rainbows, and it’s not. Whether it’s low-dose medication, therapy, yoga, or meditation, it’s important to learn how to manage anxiety upfront—it can only help you get pregnant.
Q: What advice would you give to women who are going through this journey?

To keep their faith. Throughout this whole thing, I knew that if I wanted to be a mom, I would get there somehow, and that’s what I tell my patients. I say something like, “If you truly feel like you are meant to be a mother, it will happen. It may not happen the way you thought it would. You may need IVF or a donor egg or donor sperm, or you might have to adopt. But you need to know that if you really want this, it will happen in some way.”

title.en-US: Multiple miscarriages before pregnancy

content.value: Real Talk on Fertility with Maven Ob-Gyn Teresa Perretta, M.D.

“People think it’s easier to deal with pregnancy loss and infertility as an OB-GYN. But when you’re in my field, and going through these gut-wrenching scenarios, it can be hard to go to work and discuss things like pregnancy and miscarriage with patients all day long. You can’t avoid these topics, so you have to find a different coping mechanism.”
Name:
Teresa Perretta
Age:
Q: What was your experience getting pregnant with your first child?

We had no issues the first time around. My husband and I got married when I was 35, and we knew we didn’t want to wait too long to have a baby. I had been on birth control pretty much nonstop since college—close to 20 years! I took my last pill on the day we got back from our honeymoon. There’s some data suggesting that when you first come off birth control, you’re almost hyper fertile. But given that I was 35 when I got off of it and my periods were irregular before starting the pill, I went into this process assuming it would take a while to conceive. But my period returned as soon as I came off the pill, and I got pregnant immediately. It was insane how quickly it happened.
Q: Were things different the second time around?

Yes. We started trying again before my daughter’s first birthday. In about six months, I got pregnant. And that’s when this whole infertility journey started. I went to the doctor around the 10-week mark, and there was no heartbeat. Talk about a sense of loss and loneliness. It didn’t take long to get pregnant again, but I had a second miscarriage. The fetus just stopped growing, and we had to do a D&C

I was 39 years old at this point, and I started to freak out. After six months, we saw a fertility specialist for a full evaluation. It also helped that some of my best friends and colleagues were also OB-GYNs, because it was easy to do curbside consults with them. Everything looked normal with my bloodwork, so we started off with Clomid. This fertility drug is frequently the first drug used in treatment, and we used it to boost my ovulation. But Clomid caused some visual disturbances—which can be one of the side effects—so I had to stop using it after a couple of cycles. We moved on to IUI, which involved injecting a cocktail of hormones, monitoring my ovulation, and inserting the sperm at the right time.

After our first IUI attempt, my doctor came in one afternoon and said, “Teresa, you’re pregnant.” I was like, “Peter, I just got my period.” It turns out that my pregnancy hormone levels were high enough that the pregnancy test came back positive, but they weren’t so high that anything had actually implanted in my uterus. We had to treat it as an ectopic pregnancy (which is when the embryo implants outside the uterus).
Q: What did you do when IUI didn’t work?

By then, I was emotionally and physically drained. So we took a break for a few months before starting IVF. On our first try, nothing took. Then the second time, the day before Christmas Eve, we found out I was pregnant! It was an excellent Christmas present, and nine months later, my son was born.
Q: With your knowledge as a physician, was there any way you could have predicted that you were miscarrying?

No, there was absolutely no way. If you’re having issues in your first trimester, there’s no way to tell unless you’re having ultrasounds every day. Which is very unsettling. As a pregnancy progresses, especially once you start feeling the baby move, you have a physical way of knowing. But before that point, every day you’re just like, “I hope everything is going okay in there.”
Q: Do you think going through this journey of pregnancy loss and infertility made you a better doctor?

People always say to me, “Oh, you went through all these experiences. It must have made you a better doctor.” But it actually made it harder for me. As a physician, you have a wall of defense. You have to tread a fine line between being empathetic with your patients while not conveying false hope. The reality is, 30% of pregnancies end in miscarriage, and there’s nothing we can do to change that statistic. It’s a taboo subject that no one talks about. Chances are, if you have three friends, one of them has miscarried. But if no one has ever talked about this with you, how would you know?

In the first trimester, we refer to it as all or none: You’ll either miscarry or you won’t. I can’t tell you how many times these words came out of my mouth: “If you bleed, there’s nothing we can do.” Because there isn’t. And as a doctor, you have a responsibility to convey the right information—you’re talking to a patient, not your best friend. But having gone through it myself, when I had to tell a patient who came in for her first visit or a follow-up that there was no heartbeat, it was like a knife in my heart every single time. You come at things very differently when you’ve been through them yourself.
Q: As a medical professional, how do you think the healthcare industry needs to change to better support the patient experience?

Oh, my God, there’s so much! The fertility industry is all about making money and can feel very factory-like. I don’t want to make a blanket statement because I know some lovely people who are fertility specialists and are very empathetic and understanding. But in general, it can feel very numbers-driven. There are many specialists out there who don’t have the best bedside manner. I think that in addition to telling women that they need to take this estrogen and this progesterone, maybe part of that initial packet could be: “Oh, by the way, most women who get to this point find that they benefit from talking to someone about what they’re going through emotionally.” So that once a patient decides she’s having a hard time, she at least has a plan to help her cope.
Q: One last question: Why did you want to share your story with Maven?

I saw a testimonial from a patient saying that it made such a difference to her knowing that her doctor had gone through something similar. In the past, I haven’t openly shared about my experience. It’s not easy. I get very emotional and tend to cry easily. But I feel it helps a patient when they know you can relate to what they’re saying beyond having read about it in a book.

title.en-US: Staying hopeful through 9 IUIs

content.value: Real Talk on Fertility with Maven Mental Health Provider Jessica Hegedus
“After going through infertility during the holidays, Christmas will never be the same for me, because in the back of my mind I know that for some people it’s the saddest time ever.”
Name:
Jessica Hegedus
Age:
Q: When did you first realize you were going to need help getting pregnant?

Having a baby was really important to me. I always knew I wanted to have kids, and I also knew getting pregnant as I got older could potentially be a problem, so my partner and I started trying the year before I got married. A year went by, and nothing happened, so I began to think, “What’s going on?” When I was 35, we made an appointment to look into our situation, and we were told everything looked good. Doctors didn’t know why we weren’t getting pregnant.
Q: Once you were evaluated, how did you decide to move forward?

Even though they couldn’t give us a reason for our difficulties, we decided to start fertility treatment. At the time I had student loans and wasn’t in a position to do IVF, so we tried IUI. We had IUI after IUI, and they were all unsuccessful. I was feeling out of control, and we felt very confused about whether to keep going or go to IVF. But after doing so many rounds, we thought we should just keep going. After every failed cycle, there wasn’t a lot of hand-holding at the clinic. It would have been helpful for someone to help me think through what decisions to make and how to make them. As a last ditch effort, we decided to do a more intensive IUI, with injectables instead of oral medication. I think I made seven eggs, and even that was not successful. It was also incredibly expensive, around $5,000. We had depleted our savings, and said, “What now?”
Q: How many IUIs did you do in total?

We did nine rounds of IUI over a two-year period, which, looking back, was insane. After our ninth round, we finally reached a point where we couldn’t do it anymore. It wasn’t good for our mental health. We knew IUI has lower success rates than IVF, and when we saw that IUI wasn’t working for us, we should have stopped and jumped to IVF. But the cost was such a hurdle for me.
Q: How did the financial considerations hold you back from doing IVF?

I kept imagining myself sitting at the kitchen table paying my credit card bill and writing a check for $500 for literally nothing, and thinking about how that would feel. That gave me an idea of what it might feel like to do IVF and make a big investment if it didn’t work. I don’t think I could survive that. Infertility is a medical issue that affects women from all economic backgrounds, and treatment should be covered by insurance. It’s not fair that some women who can be helped by IVF get to pursue their dreams and other women don’t.
Q: What did you do after you stopped treatment?

We decided to be that couple who travels and just doesn’t have kids. We took a few months off from work and went to Europe. We were in Armenia, where there is a lot of poverty yet people still have lots of children, and I had this realization that money doesn’t mean anything in the bigger picture. So it was a big switch in my thinking, where I said to myself, “I’ll take out loans and do IVF, and I don’t care if I lose everything and I’m in debt. I just have to try.” We came back and switched clinics to a teaching hospital, which was the best thing we ever did. At the private clinic, I felt like they didn’t have any incentive to get me pregnant. The first thing my new doctor told me was, “We’re going to get you pregnant.” I didn’t believe her at the time, but it worked on the first try.
Q: What was your pregnancy like?

It was very difficult because every sensation I felt made me wonder if we were going to lose the baby. Even though the fertility treatment ended, the anxiety didn’t stop; it only got worse. I still had this negative attitude that it wasn’t going to be okay, that we worked so hard to get to this place and it could be taken away. Everything was out of my control. It literally wasn’t until the day our daughter was born three years ago that I felt like it was really happening.
Q: Have you done another round of IVF since your daughter was born?

I have frozen embryos, and we tried to implant one a year ago, but it failed. That was hard because you have to stop nursing in order to do a cycle, so I weaned prematurely, which was hard on my daughter. And then it failed. We still have these embryos, and I have to decide what to do with them. I don’t want to discard them, but I also don’t want to donate them. At the same time, I’m over 40, and I’m afraid of having another failed cycle.
Q: What feelings did you struggle with the most during your journey through infertility?

The jealousy, and feeling different from other women. I’d have moments of thinking, Why do their bodies work and mine doesn’t? Looking back, I wish someone would have told me that jealousy is a huge part of the fertility experience, and that it’s totally normal. I had to go off Facebook because I just couldn’t go where I knew I’d see yet another picture of another pregnant belly. And at one point, my best friend had a baby, which was so devastating because you’re feeling so jealous and angry—but this was my best friend and at the same time I was happy. It was confusing to be having such an intense mix of feelings; it was isolating.

I remember Christmas that year—we didn’t reach out to anyone, and even avoided going on walks because there were so many strollers and moms on the street and a playground nearby. Meanwhile, you’re getting all those holiday cards. After going through infertility during the holidays, Christmas will never be the same for me, because in the back of my mind I know that for some people it’s the saddest time ever. I can’t help but think about those women—you have no idea who they are, but they’re out there, and they’re struggling.
Q: Did doctors diagnose the exact cause of your infertility?

I did have some polyps, but I had a procedure—a hysteroscopy—to have them removed and was told there was no blockage. (Polyps can block the opening of the cervix as well as the fallopian tubes.) The other thing is that I am overweight, so that was a factor that was always present. The first clinic told me I needed to lose weight to conceive, but the doctor at the second clinic (where I did IVF) said my weight wouldn’t stop me from getting pregnant. That was something unique about my experience; none of the other people I knew who were struggling to get pregnant were overweight.
Q: Did you ever seek out therapy or other support?

I started going to therapy after my first or second failed IUI. I realized this whole experience was bigger than me, and I couldn’t deal with it on my own. Every time you do a cycle, there’s worry and then hopefulness and then disappointment and grief and anger, and then it starts back again with hopefulness. But I didn’t want to go to therapy and be analyzed. I had so much stress, and I wanted to deal with that. I wanted someone grief-centered who could sit with me and normalize what was going on. The most comforting thing my therapist said was, “This is a medical issue, and I’m supporting you through this.” It was about helping me deal with the most horrific thing that I felt my body could do to me. I already had so many doctor’s appointments, and to have one more could have been annoying, but during that hour I felt supported and nurtured.

I also did weekly group therapy while I was going through the IUI cycles. It was essential—just having a place to be with other women who could relate. People had all different approaches to their fertility treatments, and we were mostly at different clinics. I think I was the only one who had done IUI, but it was still so valuable. If you can meet other people and hear their stories, it doesn’t make you more depressed—it makes you feel like you’re not alone.
Q. Have you changed any aspect of your practice as a result of your fertility journey?

As a mental health provider, I’m trying to start a support group for people going through infertility. It’s been hard getting the clinics to be more active in encouraging women to go. It’s a group that nobody wants to be a part of, because they think next month they’ll be fine.

title.en-US: Second-child infertility

content.value: Real Talk on Fertility with Maven Nurse Practitioner Tina Rose
“After they put in four embryos in my third and fourth IVF rounds, I remember praying, ‘Dear God, please let this lead to at least one baby, but not more than two.’”
Name:
Tina Rose
Age:
Q: When did your struggles to conceive begin?

The first time around, I didn’t have any trouble at all. I was 29 and in my first marriage, and I got pregnant with my daughter right away. When I was 37, I married my second husband, who had two daughters of his own, and we tried for about six months to get pregnant on our own, but didn’t have any luck.

My husband had had a vasectomy eight years prior, which he reversed before he proposed to me because we wanted to have kids. Unfortunately, there can still be sperm motility issues afterward. His semen analysis showed a high sperm count, but his swimmers were sluggish because they had been stuck for so long. On my end, there wasn’t anything specific that could explain my fertility issues, but I was 38, so age was a factor.
Q: What fertility treatments did you do?

We started with an IUI. At the time, I was employed by a Catholic hospital group, and IUI was the only thing my insurance would pay for; it wouldn’t cover IVF or anything where fertilization took place outside the body. My husband had gotten laid off ten days before our wedding, so he was on my plan. This was back in 2000 and 2001, and we were living in Massachusetts, where infertility coverage was mandatory unless you were employed by a religious organization.

After our failed IUI, we were invited to do IVF as part of a research study. That round failed, but by then, my husband had a new job and we were on his insurance plan, which covered fertility treatment. So we did another cycle where they put in two good quality embryos, and I got pregnant but miscarried at six weeks, which was horrible. In my third and fourth cycles of IVF, they put in four embryos each time. They were B quality, which is pretty good. I remember thinking my chances would be so great in my third cycle, but nothing took. Then in my fourth cycle, I got pregnant with twins, but lost one at 13 weeks. My son was born 11 days early, just before I turned 40.
Q: Today, transferring multiple embryos—especially more than two at a time—is controversial because of the risks involved. How did you make the decision to transfer four embryos?

The IVF process has evolved over the years and the success rates have improved. But back when I did it, the success rate was lower, and fertility clinics didn’t set the same limits that they have in place now. Also, because of my age, they didn’t know how many would take.
Q: Were you nervous about ending up with more than one baby?

Petrified. I’m very petite. When I was pregnant with my daughter, I’d say to her, “Listen kid, I have to manage this. Seven and a half pounds and you’re out, cooked or not. Tiny Tina can’t do anything bigger than that, you hear me?” She was born five days late, at seven pounds two ounces. I thought to myself, “Good girl.” (Side note: She’s now 28 and six feet tall!) So after they put in those four embryos in my third and fourth IVF rounds, I remember praying, “Dear God, please let this lead to at least one baby, but not more than two.”

When I found out we were having two, I have to admit that even though I was nervous about physically carrying twins, I was ecstatic. My daughter was a baby when her father and I divorced, and I really wanted to have the experience of raising two children with the same person.
Q: Did you find that being pregnant after IVF was different from being pregnant the first time around?

The truth is, I was really miserable during my first pregnancy. I had hyperemesis (aka hyperemesis gravidarum, which is characterized by extreme nausea and vomiting) for about 14 weeks. During that time, I lost 12 pounds. I was working at an OB-GYN office and was convinced that anything that could go wrong, would. I’m a control freak, and I didn’t like being pregnant because I felt like the pregnancy was in control of me.

Despite the challenges I had conceiving the second time around, being pregnant with my son was really easy. It was difficult to lose the twin, and I was a little worried about my age, but I was working in a new group and was really close to all my colleagues, so I felt supported. Plus, I’d been through pregnancy once before, and I knew more about what to expect.
Q: When did you realize you had lost one of the twins?

Since I worked at a hospital, I’d check their heartbeats every Thursday. I’d have my medical assistant, whom I was very close to, come in and hold my hand for each ultrasound. And every week, there were two good heartbeats. At twelve weeks, I told my assistant, “Okay I’m good, you don’t need to hold my hand.” Then the following week, I was like, “Okay, hold my hand one more time.” I’m so thankful I wasn’t alone when I realized there was no second heartbeat. My emotions were so complex. I didn’t know how to grieve the loss of one baby while still being grateful for the other one. And I was so worried that whatever happened in my body that led one baby’s heartbeat to stop would make the other one stop, too. That loss was still early enough that I didn’t need a D&C
or anything; we just waited for the tissue to be reabsorbed. That made things hard, too, because every time we did an ultrasound up until 28 weeks, we could see the other sac.

When I lost one of the twins, I felt like all my knowledge as a nurse had failed me. I had this idea that if I made it through the first trimester, things would be okay. I was kind of iffy for those first 12 weeks, and didn’t really relax, but by week 13, I went into that ultrasound feeling confident and just wanted to see my two babies. And there was only one.
Q: How do you think going through infertility and pregnancy loss has affected your work?

I’ve been in this business for 28 years, and some of my patients today are women whose heartbeats I listened to while they were in utero, because I took care of their mothers when they were pregnant. Many have gone through IVF, gotten pregnant with multiples, had miscarriages, struggles with divorce, etc.—and whenever I can share my own experiences with them, I do. I love that I have this kind of relationship with my patients.

Even when I was in the thick of my troubles, I knew it was going to be my job to tell the women I take care of what had happened to me, if ever I could help them. In fact, when I went in for an ultrasound six weeks after that second round of IVF and was told there was no heartbeat, I remember crying and saying to my husband through my tears, “This is just one more way I can relate to my patients. I’ll never tell another patient that she’s miscarried without understanding exactly how she feels.”

title.en-US: How medication helped me conceive

content.value: Real Talk on Fertility with Mary Beth Ferrante

“I feel like I'm an in-betweener, like my story isn’t as important to share. But there are a lot of people who fall somewhere in the middle, who didn’t get pregnant right away. It's still an emotional struggle.”
Name:
Mary Beth Ferrante
Age:
Q: Were you trying for a while before you realized you needed help?

I was 31 and had been married for a year and half. After I stopped birth control, my cycles were all over the place. I was at a bachelorette party, and I was sure I must be pregnant because I hadn’t had a period in 40 days. Then I got my period that same day.
I started tracking my cycle with an app. Once I had six months of data, I was up for my annual checkup, and my doctor agreed it was time to take some tests. I spent a whole summer going to appointments, having tests done, getting my follicles measured, using prescription estrogen creams to balance my hormones. I was also tested for PCOS, and I didn't have it. My husband was evaluated as well.
Q: What were the results?

They told me that everything looked fine and I should be getting pregnant. But even through the three months of timed intercourse where they were measuring my follicles, I wasn’t. It was frustrating trying different things without knowing what the problem was.
Q: When timed interourse didn’t work, what did you do next?

I started taking Clomid, which is typically the first intervention. Clomid puts your cycle on a very regulated schedule. It's very easy to time everything, and I got pregnant on the first try. When I was ready to have my second baby, I went back to the doctor and started back on Clomid.
Q: What was the most frustrating part of this? Any key takeaways?

When I was ready to have a baby, I found myself wanting more education on what changes I should be making in my diet or lifestyle. For instance, what types of food could enhance fertility and boost changes, whether it means more fruits and vegetables, or cutting this or that from my diet? It would have made me feel I was doing something.

I wish all OB-GYNs would—the moment someone starts trying to conceive—give you an overview of things to do to track your progress, as well as things that you should be looking out for, and anything that you can be doing to help your situation. Just providing people with a general education on their fertility is something I feel is very much missing from the doctor/patient conversation.
Q: What did you do when you felt your doctor wasn’t giving you the information or support you needed?

Not knowing where to go or who to ask for advice was frustrating. I only had one local friend that had a baby already, and one night I told her about how we were trying but nothing was happening for me. She gave me a book about fertility and told me about an app that I quickly bagan using to track my cycles. Going forward, I made sure to pass along that info to friends and also my clients when they said they were starting to try. I tell them, "I know you want it to be romantic and lovely, but start tracking right away." They're like, "What?" and I say, "Just keep data, because if you have any problems, it helps to walk into a doctor's office with actual information. They might be more willing to talk to you and take you seriously.”
Q: How did you juggle working with all the tests and appointments when you were trying to conceive?

At first, I didn’t have to worry about ducking out of the office for an appointment or two. But when it turned into four appointments in two weeks, I felt like I should say something, especially because I probably took two sick days total in the previous two years! My new manager was male and didn't have kids. I didn’t feel comfortable sharing details, so I told him I had a bunch of doctor's appointments coming up, because there were some things going on in my body that were “off.” I waited until I was 16 weeks along to tell him I was pregnant. He was so surprised because I had never clued him in to what all those doctor’s visits were about. He said, “Oh Thank God. I thought you were dying.”
Q: As a career coach, what advice do you give your clients who are struggling with infertility, as far as when and how much to share with a manager?

It’s a very personal decision. While I do think it’s a good idea to give some information, I think the level of detail that you provide depends on your comfort level, the relationship with your manager, and if there are any concerns around hitting a maternal wall. Have you seen people in your organization get pushed into the “mommy track,” or derailed in their career because they’re pregnant? Issues like these—such as pregnancy discrimination, and the fact that moms get passed up for career-advancing work—are getting more attention and progress is being made to change these dynamics, but they’re very real.

In my case, I feel that sharing minimal information was the right move for me, given my relationship with my manager. I also worked in a different office/city, and my decision was easier knowing that I wasn't in an office with him or any of my team members on a regular basis.

As a whole, women have a hard time bringing up fertility treatment at work. It’s the same with mental health, and kid-related stuff in general. I've had clients who have told their managers what was going on because their managers were women or had small kids, and they felt they’d be understood. The response they’ve gotten has usually been positive—along the lines of, “Let me know what you need.”
Q: How do you advise clients on handling the emotional stress of fertility issues?

I think the first thing is having people who you can talk to, whether it's your close friends, or a local or online fertility support group. As women get further along in the process of fertility treatment where hormones are taking a toll on the body, some clients take a medical leave because it’s just too much. From a stress perspective, taking that break can be helpful, but every woman responds differently to treatment and therefore will have different emotional needs.
Q: What prompted you to share your story?

I think it's important for people dealing with these challenges—that begin even before pregnancy, when you’re trying to conceive—to have people they can talk to and resources they trust. Some online communities can be super supportive, but you don't really know who's behind the computer.

I also wanted to share my story because I feel like I'm an in-betweener. Since I didn’t have to do IVF, I don't feel like my story is always as important to share, but I think that there are a lot of people that fall somewhere in the middle where it didn't happen right away. It's still an emotional struggle.

title.en-US: Two baby girls through IVF

content.value: Real Talk on Fertility with Maven Physical Therapist Laura Holmes

“We were uncomfortable telling people that this wasn’t happening the ‘normal’ way, and that we needed to go through medical treatment to have children, so we kept it to ourselves. At a dinner party one night, I snuck my injections into the refrigerator and then took them out to inject myself in my friend’s bathroom without anyone knowing.”
Name:
Laura Holmes
Age:
Q: What was your experience with fertility treatment?

We started fertility treatment back in 2008 when I was 32. My husband and I had been trying to get pregnant for almost a year, and our doctors recommended we do fertility testing. They didn’t find anything on my end, but my husband had a low sperm count, so we were advised to go straight to IVF rather than trying an IUI or any other intermediate steps. I got pregnant with twins on our second round, and delivered two healthy girls at 37 weeks.
Q: Did you have a good experience with your fertility center?

Our first cycle was at a hospital that was about two hours away from where we lived, and it wasn’t a great experience. When it was time to start monitoring the size of the eggs, I was driving two hours every day for the ultrasounds, and that included a ferry ride! They also wanted all the women to be on the same schedule, so they put us all on birth control to line up our cycles before we started. I remember they mailed us our drugs so we could start on a specific day, but the package didn’t arrive on time, so my husband and I had to drive out to a UPS facility an hour away to pick up my medication. It may have been because this was a teaching hospital and having a set schedule worked better with the students’ rotations, but it was really crazy. Also, during the egg harvesting, my husband was in a separate room producing the sperm sample, and I was in the OR by myself with a physician. That was really uncomfortable; it felt sterile and medical.
Q: A lot of people struggle with the decision to switch to a different fertility center. How did you decide where you would do your second round of IVF?

IVF is incredibly expensive, so after our first cycle failed, we were like, “We can give it one more try, and then we have to stop.” I went for an annual checkup with my regular gynecologist, and I was in tears telling her what had happened. She gave me the name of a private fertility practice and suggested that we meet with a specific doctor there for our second attempt. Just walking into the new center, we felt an immediate contrast. There were plants and waterfalls in the office, and it was set up to feel more nurturing. And we could pick up our medicine at a local pharmacy rather than have to drive to a UPS facility an hour away!

The second center was five minutes away from my mother-in-law’s home, so we collected the sperm sample at her house (of all places!), when she wasn’t home. This time, my husband could be with me during the egg retrieval. They put me on Valium and had an acupuncturist right next door in case I needed it, and it helped me to relax.
Q: How open were you with others during IVF?

The first time was very isolating. We were uncomfortable telling people that this wasn’t happening the “normal” way, and that we needed to go through medical treatment to have children, so we kept it to ourselves. At a dinner party one night, I snuck my injections into the refrigerator and then took them out to inject myself in my friend’s bathroom without anyone knowing, which was so weird. A few weeks after we found out that the embryo transfer wasn’t successful, a co-worker announced that she was pregnant with her third baby. I really wanted to be happy for her, but I was dying inside because I had been through so much, and felt I couldn’t share it with anyone.
Q: Did the isolation you experienced impact your decision to start telling people what was going on?

Yes, it opened the doors for us to share with more people during our second cycle. We started telling certain family members and friends, which turned out to be a much better approach than keeping everything to ourselves. It was so much more positive when we had people to talk to, and we also got very helpful recommendations. People would say things like, "My friend had to go through a similar thing, and she saw this doctor. Let me put you in touch so you can talk to her." I was really hooked up!
Q: Did you find any coping skills that helped you get through the emotional challenges during IVF?

On our second try, I did a lot of visualization exercises at every point in the process. The idea is to use visual imagery to move your attention away from the worry and, in your mind, create the state or outcome you want. For example: “Okay, my eggs are growing. Now I’m harvesting good eggs. And now these eggs are making good embryos.” I would picture those embryos growing, and I continued visualizing when I found out I was pregnant. I would see those babies growing each week and when we hit 24 weeks—the point at which babies can survive outside the womb—I was like, “Okay, you’ve got to stay in there, but you could potentially make it out here.” Focusing on the positive made the experience a lot less stressful.
Q: How do you think the healthcare industry can improve the patient experience for people facing infertility?

For one, offering better insurance coverage would help. But it’s also important to make sure people have counseling. Things could have gotten very tricky for us if we had frozen embryos and had to figure out what to do with them later. Would we have been okay donating them and possibly having a biological child of ours grow up with another family? And what if all three embryos they implanted in me had taken and one of them had split and we’d ended up pregnant with quadruplets?

Once the twins were born and we had them in our hands, my husband and I thought to ourselves, “What if we had been forced with a choice to selectively reduce the number of fetuses? Now that we have these babies, how could we have lived with the knowledge that there could have been a third or fourth that we chose to terminate?” While we went into IVF with a lot of knowledge, I don’t think we were mentally prepared for some of the ethical questions that could have arisen. These are really tough questions, and the emotional impact of making choices like these can’t be underestimated.
Q: Looking back on your own fertility journey, what was the most surprising thing that happened to you?

When my husband and I felt like we were coming out of the woods after having the twins, we said to ourselves: “We’ve survived nearly a year with twins—we don’t need to go through any more fertility treatments. We’re happy. We’ve got our family.” Little did I know that I was already pregnant at the time! I remember sobbing when I found out I was pregnant again just two weeks shy of the twins’ first birthday—I was just like, “How did this happen? I can’t do this again!” My husband was ecstatic, and of course now I couldn’t imagine it any other way. So we had three girls in less than two years, and that was pretty surprising.

title.en-US: Why I chose surrogacy

content.value: Real Talk on Fertility with Maven Counselor Season Cain

“I couldn’t imagine anyone else carrying my baby because I’m such a control freak. But I decided to put it out there in the universe and spread the word that we were looking either for a mother putting a baby up for adoption, or someone wanting to be a surrogate—and be open to whatever came first.”
Name:
Season Cain
Age:
Q: Why did you decide to start fertility treatment?

When I was 33, I got pregnant with my first daughter with no problem. We started trying for a second baby soon after, but over the course of three years had three miscarriages. My doctor told us to keep trying because I didn’t have trouble getting pregnant; the first two times, we were able to conceive right away. Staying pregnant was our problem.

After the third miscarriage, we decided to start trying IVF. I went through the procedure and they were able to retrieve 12 eggs, and we ended up with six embryos. We chose to spend more money to have the lab do genetic testing on our embryos, and only three turned out to be genetically normal. We also found out they were all female. We just said they could implant whichever was the healthiest.
Q: What were your doctor’s visits like leading up to the embryo transfer?

I’ve had a heart condition since I was a kid, which makes any pregnancies high-risk, so I had to meet with my cardiologist before we did the embryo transfer to make sure that I had the green light to move forward. Well, when I went in to see my doctor a few weeks before implantation, they discovered a new heart condition that was worse than the one I already had. I was told I couldn’t bear children anymore because my body wouldn’t be able to handle the pregnancy. I went in thinking I would be cleared and that we’d be scheduling the embryo transfer soon after; I was never expecting this news.
Q: How did you handle this revelation?

Naturally, we were devastated. But within a couple of weeks, I sprung into action. I said, “We want to have a sibling for our daughter, and we need to get on this fast, so we are going to adopt.” We completed the application process, but the average wait time is two years, which wasn’t ideal. I was opening up to a friend about our situation, and she brought up the idea of using a surrogate. After all, we already had the embryos from IVF.

I had never considered surrogacy before this point; the truth was I couldn’t imagine anyone else carrying my baby because I’m such a control freak. But I decided to put it out there in the universe and spread the word that we were looking either for a mother putting a baby up for adoption or someone wanting to be a surrogate—and be open to whatever came first.
Q: How did you begin exploring the surrogacy option?

I learned that if we found the surrogate on our own, we could save a lot of money by not having to pay agency fees. A friend of mine who is a nurse in the baby unit of a hospital helped get the word out, and right away, someone came forward. It was another nurse my friend worked with who was considering being a surrogate! She called me that day, and we set up a time for my husband and I to go to her home and met her family. It was clear to us all that this was going to be a fit. I felt comfortable with her because she already had kids and she lived nearby, and the fact that she was a friend of a friend helped, too. I also got to see her home, and I knew the baby in utero would be in clean, non-stressful living conditions.
Q: What was the surrogacy process like?

Each party in a surrogacy—the intended parents and the surrogate (technically called a gestational carrier)—is represented by separate surrogacy lawyers before you can move forward with the process. You have to talk about everything up front; our attorneys drew up an 80-page contract! Everyone had to have psychological evaluations—not just me and our surrogate, but both of our husbands, too. But things moved pretty quickly. Within three months after we first met our surrogate, we did the embryo transfer and it was successful—she became pregnant with Sierra, the daughter we have today.

On the cost front, our insurance did not cover surrogacy, so we took out a loan to be able to do it. In addition to the $30,000 base fee, there were extra expenses like attorney fees and medical bills. It was written into our contract that if our surrogate had to miss work we had to pay for lost wages, and that happened three times. We also had to reimburse her for gas when getting to and from doctor’s appointments. In total, the surrogacy cost about $90,000.
