We set up the payments through an escrow agency; our surrogate was paid in monthly installments and if there had been a miscarriage, payments would have stopped. We made the last payment a few months ago.
And after the baby was born, we had to go to court to get the parental rights transferred to us.
Q: How did you deal with any emotional challenges during your infertility and surrogacy journey?

I teach mindfulness, meditation, and anxiety reduction techniques, and I thought those things would help me, but it all went out the window when it was personally me going through these experiences. I felt like I was not equipped at all, like I did not have the tools to cope properly with the stress involved. The IVF clinic did have a support group specifically for women who already had children but were struggling with infertility, and that was really helpful. It was great to get validation from others who could relate to what we were going through, and to know that a lot of people’s relationships were a mess and that everyone else was hearing mean comments all the time. I had people telling me they would never be able to let someone else carry their baby, or asking if I was constantly thinking about what the surrogate was eating and drinking. Not many people focused on the positives or said it was a beautiful thing that we were doing.
Q: What was the experience like at the hospital when your daughter was born?

For surrogates, hospitals have their own rules about who can and can’t be present for the delivery. My husband was not allowed to be in the room, so it was just our surrogate, her husband, and me. She had a C-section because she had one with her previous child. The birth was stressful because we had made a birth plan, and of course the doctors and nurses didn’t follow it at all. As soon as the baby was born, they gave her to me. I was also the one who the umbilical cord.
Q: Did you feel an instant bond with your daughter?

Right after she was born, I breastfed her. I learned that I could induce lactation, so the whole time my surrogate was pregnant I was taking fenugreek and all these herbs to trick my body into thinking I was pregnant so it could produce milk, along with a prescription drug to increase milk supply. To prepare for nursing my child, I had to pump every two hours, 24 hours a day, for two months in advance. I had a full milk supply—and my freezer was fully stocked with milk—before my daughter was born.
Q: Do you still keep in touch with your surrogate?

Just through Facebook. Contact with the surrogate after birth is an entire section of the contract. Ours said we would be in touch for breastmilk only, because we agreed that she was going to pump milk and sell it to me, but I didn’t end up needing it.
Q: What is the one thing you wish someone had told you before going through infertility treatment and then surrogacy?

I really wish they would have stressed how hard it would be on my marriage, so I wouldn’t feel like it was falling apart, or that we were not meant to be. I didn’t learn that until joining the support group. It’s going to be hard, and you will fight, but it doesn’t mean you’re heading for divorce. It’s really, really normal. Going through miscarriages and IVF took the fun out of our sex life, which is quite common. (We still struggle with that because now we have two kids, and we’re just constantly exhausted!) During the surrogacy, we did have opportunities to bond more as a couple. For instance, we took a trip to Austria before our baby was born, when our surrogate was eight months pregnant. Since I wasn’t carrying a child, I was able to travel, and we got to have that time together before welcoming the newest member of our family.

title.en-US: How I got through 7 rounds of IUI

content.value: Real Talk on Fertility with Dr. Nicole Coluccio, M.D.
“The fact that you are infertile makes you feel like you've lost something that you thought you had. It's almost like a death. Why is everyone pregnant but you?”
Name:
Nicole Coluccio
Age:
Q: How did you find out you had unexplained infertility—and how did you cope with this news?

After trying to conceive for a year without any luck, my OB-GYN did a basic infertility workup including an ultrasound and labs, and my husband had a semen analysis. Everything was normal, which means that doctors were never able to find a reason for our fertility issues. To some extent, this made things more stressful. If you're more of a Type A person, you really want something to hang your hat on. You want to know that “this” was the problem, and then you try to fix it. It's out of your hands when it's unexplained. 
So you begin to question a lot of things. My family's never had any infertility issues, but they all had kids in their early twenties. I was in my thirties—it's completely different by then. At times, I had thoughts like, “Why did I take the birth control pill forever? I really didn't need it, obviously. Did taking the pill for so long affect me long term?” I know, as a provider, that it isn't supposed to. But not knowing the cause of your fertility issues can be frustrating, so your mind tries hard to look for an explanation.
Q: Given that doctors didn’t determine a cause, how did you decide what treatment to begin with?

We started with Clomid (clomiphene citrate), which is often the first-line of treatment for unexplained fertility. We did Clomid with timed intercourse for a long time because there was only one provider in my area for infertility and I didn't want to see him. When I was a resident, I rotated with him, and I didn't like his strong opinions about weight. If you're underweight or overweight, he was discriminating. (I’m on the small side.) So I basically took Clomid while I waited for another infertility clinic to open up nearby. Once it did, I had my consultation there. Everything still looked normal, so we did Clomid with IUI for a bunch of cycles, but none of them worked.
Q: What did you decide to do next?

We moved on from IUI with Clomid to IUI with injectables—medication to stimulate egg production that you inject yourself with at home. I used Follistim, a follicle-stimulating hormone. At first I didn't want to do IUI with injectables because it increases your risk of twins and other multiples. It was torture doing all those IUIs and I also didn’t want to do IVF.
Q: How did your knowledge and training as an OB-GYN inform your decision making?

I think in part it hindered it because you know the statistics, and it's pretty darn dismal. I wasn’t sure that I ever would have gone to IVF because I didn't want the complications that come with carrying twins or other multiples (which is a possibility when they transfer more than one embryo at a time). My husband was excited about twins, and I was like, “Oh gosh, all the risks!”
Q: And you ended up with twins anyway!

Yep, because God has a sense of humor. I got pregnant with twins on the third try of IUI with injectables. All the time that I was trying to conceive, I was sick of telling my husband the bad news. That time, I told my doctor’s office to call my husband instead of me when they had the results of my pregnancy test. When my husband called me and told me that I was pregnant, I was like, “You're kidding right? This is a joke?” But it wasn’t. Our twins—a boy and a girl—are now 11 years old.
Q: What was your pregnancy like?

Overall, it was fine, but I delivered early at 33 weeks. When I realized I was going into labor, my husband and I headed to the hospital—after arguing about whether it was actually happening—and about an hour and a half later we had our children. I went from about three centimeters dilated to eight centimeters and then had a C-section, because my son was breech.

Both babies were roughly the same weight at birth—about four and a half pounds each.They stayed in the NICU for 12 days, which is not particularly long for babies born prematurely. I was lucky that there were really no long-lasting medical issues at all. A stressful part of that time was going back to work relatively quickly (after 8 weeks). In my office, I was one of four providers, and they wanted me to come back.
Q: What surprised you the most about your experience with infertility?

How angry I got. The fact that you are infertile makes you feel like you've lost something that you thought you had. It's almost like a death. Everywhere you go, whether you’re walking down the street or looking at the magazines at the supermarket, for example, you’re like, Why is everyone pregnant? Then you question what you've done wrong.
Q: How has your struggle to conceive affected your work as an OB-GYN?

For one, it’s made me more aware of how to spend resources. I'm not going to have people waste their time in my office when they might have very limited insurance coverage, especially if they're getting older. It's not worth it. Even though they might be comfortable doing Clomid, it might not be in their best interest. So I gently tell them that they should go to a fertility specialist sooner than later, or to really look at their insurance. Some insurance plans have great coverage and some have no coverage, so they end up spending more time with me (an OB-GYN) than they should. 
Beyond these practical considerations that I’m more aware of, I think my own struggles have made me a better provider. I spend more time asking patients about their emotional well-being than I would have beforehand. Everything that you go through changes how you practice. Until you've experienced something, it's not quite the same. While I was going through infertility, I didn't share it with anybody, and then it took me a few years before I started opening up about what I had been through with patients. But I started to do that because I want to let them know that they're not alone.

title.en-US: Becoming a foster parent after IVF

content.value: Real Talk on Infertility with Maven Counselor Kristan Torres
“Fostering was a big adjustment, because we went from having no kids to having three.”
Name:
Kristan Torres
Age:
Q: What led you to start fertility treatment?

My husband and I had been married for eight years and I believe I wasn’t able to conceive due to my polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). When we were ready to start fertility treatment, we went straight to IVF. After going through it, we decided we likely wouldn't do it again. The process was expensive and exhausting, and it wasn’t something we were going to do indefinitely.
Q: What was your IVF experience actually like?

The egg stimulation process was more difficult than I expected it to be. My ovaries were over stimulated, and the whole lower half of my body swelled up. Not to mention, my moods were constantly in flux. Those were a really rough few weeks. And then I got the news that the doctor couldn’t retrieve any mature eggs. This was pretty lousy news to receive. My sister happened to be in town when I got the news, and on the spot she volunteered to donate her eggs.
Q: What was your reaction to your sister offering to be your egg donor?

I was touched by her generosity, but I wasn’t sure how I felt about it at first. After talking it over with my husband, we decided to give it a shot; we told ourselves that this may be the closest we would come to having a child with my DNA. So my sister started the process to retrieve her eggs but—just like in my situation—there were no mature eggs. (Interesting, my sister is now pregnant with her first child, which has taught me that a lot is out of our control.)
Q: What’s it been like to cope with the fact that IVF didn’t work for you, especially given the fact that you won’t be doing any more fertility treatment?

I have moments when I feel sad, like when other people are pregnant or having baby showers. But my husband and I made a conscious choice to be around people who have kids instead of cutting ourselves off from these families. It would be easy to withdraw, but I want to stay engaged in the life that’s going on around me. And a big part of why I’m able to cope goes back to my faith. My husband is actually a pastor, and we’re very involved in the community.

I know so many women feel lonely while they are going through fertility struggles, and I did sometimes feel that way. I have a supportive family. They weren’t in the area when I was doing IVF, but they knew what we were going through. It helped me to be honest with people about what was going on. I will say, however, that you have to pick and choose who you open up to. People have tons of opinions, and sometimes they’re not what you need to hear.
Q: When IVF didn’t work, you and your husband decided to be foster parents—how did you make that decision?

We thought fostering would be a good option because we had the love, the space, and the availability to parent. A lot of people at our church had fostered kids, so it wasn’t unfamiliar territory. The licensing process is intense. We had to take a class over a few weekends, as sort of a training to become a foster parent. We also had to submit bank records and pay stubs to show we were not doing it for the monthly stipend. Then we had to go through a rigorous home study interview; they had us write our life stories, asked us a ton of questions, and even photographed every room in our house in evaluating us.

During the classes, we learned a lot about what children might go through before entering the foster system, and how to best integrate them into a family. At one class, they mentioned that it’s great to take sibling groups, if you have the space. These kids have already suffered some trauma, and then to be split up adds to it. We were still finishing the licensing process when we got a call asking if we’d be willing to take three siblings—ages three, five, and eight.
Q: What was your reaction to that call?

We thought, “Oh my goodness, this is happening!” It was surreal, scary, and exciting at the same time. But we decided to give it a shot. We were able to meet the kids in the shelter several times, which is unique. We had them registered in school and preschool, and once we got them home, we tried to create a world of normalcy, routine, patience, and understanding. That was our focus for the little more than a year that they were with us.
Q: What were some of the challenges you faced while fostering?

It was definitely a big adjustment, because we went from having no kids to having three. The biggest challenge was giving up our freedom. Those Saturday mornings where we got to sleep in and take it easy were gone overnight. Also, the kids were more resistant with me than they were with my husband. It made sense to me because they had a mom, whereas their dad was mostly out of the picture. But it was still tough—they gave me a hard time for the first six months.
Q: What advice would you give couples who are interested in fostering?

It’s crucial to check your motives because you can’t go into fostering for selfish reasons. Some of the kids can’t connect well because of their trauma. You need to have patience with the process and remember that the ultimate goal is to do whatever is best for the kids. During training, they always reiterate that the goal is reunification with the birth parents.

If you do go through with it, connect with other foster parents, because that network of support is good for both you and the kids. A lot of agencies will have events and activities and support groups. And make sure to ask a lot of questions. For example, I found out that there were resources I could have used to get clothes and other items (like car or booster seats) for the kids, instead of having to pay.
Finally, it’s so important to ask for help. And there were several times when my mom came to stay with us. But even when she couldn’t, I relied on other parents to show me the ropes.
Q: What’s next for the two of you?

We’re still on the journey and figuring out what to do. We’ve considered fostering again, but would probably foster one child instead of three. And I’m still working with my gynecologist and checking hormone levels to see if I could get pregnant, but I won’t do IVF again. You hear stories of people who are infertile for 10 years and then get pregnant; it’s a reminder that this is not completely in our hands.

title.en-US: How overexercising affected my fertility

content.value: Real Talk on Fertility with Alexandra Rothwell Kelly
“I'd like to have more kids. Now I know what I need to do, and hopefully I’ll be able to ovulate and have a period naturally.”
Name:
Alexandra Rothwell Kelly
Age:
Q: When did you realize you’d need help getting pregnant?

I got married at 28, and when I was 30, we started trying to conceive. I knew I was going to need some kind of reproductive assistance because I hadn't been getting my period. I was originally diagnosed with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), and my primary care physician prescribed me Clomid to get me to ovulate. When that didn't work, I was referred to a reproductive endocrinologist, who diagnosed me with hypothalamic amenorrhea (HA)—which means your hypothalamus has shut down communication to your ovaries. Since the ovaries don’t get the message to produce reproductive hormones, the body doesn't menstruate.

What makes things so tricky is that the diet and lifestyle approach for treating HA is basically the opposite of how you’d treat polycystic ovarian syndrome. With PCOS, the general recommendations are that you should exercise more, eat a lower-carbohydrate diet, and possibly lose some weight. For hypothalamic amenorrhea, your body is in a state of perceived stress or famine, and you need to do the opposite: Exercise less, eat more, gain weight.
Q: Do you have PCOS in addition to HA, or was PCOS a misdiagnosis?

It’s unclear, but it is possible to have both. I think what's happening is that the criteria for diagnosing PCOS isn’t clear-cut at this point, and so many women who aren't getting a period automatically have the PCOS label slapped on them. That is exactly what happened to me. It's unfortunate because I probably could have conceived naturally if I had been diagnosed appropriately.
Q: How did things go once doctors figured out that you had HA?

I made some lifestyle changes, and went from being a daily runner to jogging lightly a few times a week—putting on some weight in the process. I was also prescribed fertility drugs which helped me grow follicles and ovulate. I didn't get pregnant on the first cycle. The second cycle, my body was overstimulated and grew too many follicles, so I had to take a month off from treatment to lower the risk of getting pregnant with multiples. On the third cycle, I took a lower dose of the medication, and was able to pregnant with my daughter, who was born in June of 2018.
Q: Were you underweight before? Was that a concern?

I wasn't; I had a normal BMI, and that's what's confusing about hypothalamic amenorrhea. The reason it's so often not diagnosed is that it's associated with anorexia or athlete triad syndrome, where it's typically a woman who's exercising like crazy and has all these really obvious signs of undernourishment. It's actually much more common than I realized. It can been triggered by exercise alone; it can be linked to psychological stress; it could be a case of not getting adequate nutrition. Any combination of those three things can trigger your body to shut down production of reproductive hormones.
Q: Do you plan to have more kids?

I'd like to have more kids. Now that I know what I need to do, hopefully I’ll be able to ovulate and have a period naturally. I'm still breastfeeding my daughter, and will probably do so until she's a year old. And then we'll see what happens from there.
Q: How did being a dietitian help you with the lifestyle changes you implemented to try to get pregnant?

Sometimes I wonder if being a dietitian made the lifestyle changes a little harder. After all, it’s not like I was underweight or appeared anorexic or that I was over-exercising. I felt like I was doing the things I recommend to my clients. It took a lot of convincing and research for me to get to the point where I was willing to ease up on exercise and make changes to my diet. What helped convince me was a book called No Period. Now What?, which is really the only resource I know of for people with hypothalamic amenorrhea. The woman who wrote it is a PhD researcher and she had HA herself.
Q: Once you had your baby, did your lifestyle and eating habits change again?

For now, I'm just trying to make sure that I'm eating enough. Nobody who knew me while I was trying to conceive would've said I wasn’t eating enough; it’s just that I think I need to be particularly careful. There's a lot of pressure on postpartum women to spring back to their pre-baby body—and as a dietitian I’ve experienced people scrutinizing what I look like and what I'm eating—so I've had to be diligent to make sure I don't fall into that trap of wanting to fit into all my pre-maternity clothes again as soon as possible. I am trying not to think about weight loss as being an objective right now; I’m focused on what foods I can eat to give me energy to take care of my baby and produce enough breast milk to feed her.
Q: Are there any other lifestyle changes you made during this time?

When I was trying to conceive, I saw an acupuncturist, and there were some interesting things that happened. During one of my fertility treatment cycles, my follicles weren't growing and I had to take a break from doing anything that cycle. But after some acupuncture sessions, things started to pick up and my body started responding positively to the fertility medications. It's all very anecdotal, but it makes me feel like acupuncture works and that I should keep going with it.
Q: How does this experience impact your work with your clients?

It's affecting my practice in a big way. I get a lot of women who come to me looking to manage their weight. They want to make sure they're doing everything right nutritionally, and I see my former self in them. I see a woman who is exercising a lot, trying to do everything perfectly, trying to be healthy to the point that it may be detrimental to her health. I think I'm just a little more tuned in to that stuff now and more aware of the consequences of that behavior.

A lot of younger women are on birth control, so it's hard to know if their behaviors are affecting their cycle, but I suspect that their eating and exercise habits may be playing a role. I now think of the menstrual cycle as being a vital sign for health.
Q: Why did you decide to share your story with Maven?
Reproductive assistance is so secretive; nobody talks about it. I wish that I had known more people who had gone through something like this while I was going through it.

title.en-US: How PCOS affected my fertility

content.value: Real Talk on Fertility with Maven Counselor Lisa Fuechtmann

“IVF is still something that women have shame about. I talk to women who hate their body because they feel like it betrayed them. I’ve been through that, and I know that there’s hope on the other side.”
Name:
Lisa Fuechtmann
Age:
Q: When did you first know there may be something wrong with your reproductive health?

I never had normal periods—even when I was a teenager. Sometimes I wouldn’t get one, and sometimes I would bleed for literally two months straight. I didn’t look into it until my late twenties, when I was finally diagnosed with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). (Now I always tell people to get checked out as soon as you start seeing symptoms!) I tried to get pregnant in my 20s (this was before I met my husband), but didn’t have success. So I knew I would need help. When I was 33, my husband and I jumped right into IVF.
Q: How did the IVF process go?

We got 37 eggs from the retrieval, but I developed ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS). PCOS can increase the risk for OHSS, which causes swelling of the ovaries with leaking of fluid within the body. Fluid was traveling to my lungs, and I had to have emergency surgery, which was scary. Because of that, I had to wait a few months to do the embryo implantation. In March of 2017, they implanted two embryos, and we got pregnant with twins.
Q: How did it feel to have a positive test after more than a decade of trying?

Because my period was always so irregular, I had taken so many pregnancy tests in my life, and this was the only time one had turned out positive! When I saw those results, I literally almost passed out. We did blood work to make sure, and during the first ultrasound we saw our twins. The doctor only found one heartbeat, but said it was probably because the second one was hard to measure. But at the eight-week ultrasound, the second one still had no heartbeat.
Q: Was the doctor able to explain what happened?

I asked why, and the doctors just said, “It happens.” They see it a lot—they call it vanishing twin syndrome. I couldn’t stop thinking that I had done something wrong. It was surreal: On every ultrasound after that, we would see our baby, and the other sac getting smaller and smaller until it didn’t show up anymore. It was absorbed back into my body.
Q: Did you have any other complications during the pregnancy?

It was the most complicated pregnancy. The loss of the twin was just part of it. I have panic disorder and agoraphobia, and I couldn’t be on my usual medication while I was pregnant. I was switched to a different SSRI (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor), which didn’t work because I had hyperemesis gravidarum (HG) and couldn’t keep the pill or any food down. HG is what Kate Middleton had; it’s a severe manifestation of morning sickness, with persistent vomiting. I tried not to move, because otherwise I would throw up. I lost 49 pounds during my pregnancy. I was a little overweight before, and was told it was okay as long as the baby was measuring fine. During the second trimester, they prescribed Zofran, a drug to help control HG which is now controversial because it’s been linked to birth defects. It helped a little, but not enough to make me functional.

At five weeks, I had to stop working. We borrowed money from family. I expected that the fertility journey will be hard, but not that the pregnancy itself would be that hard. There were times I should have been hospitalized, but I didn’t have the money to afford the copay.
Q: Was it smooth sailing from then on?

At around 28 weeks, I thought I was having contractions, but they turned out to be gallstones. My doctors recommended surgery to remove them, but I didn’t want to, so they said to cut out all fats and spicy food from my diet. Then, at around 31 weeks, I went to the bathroom and it looked like I had gotten my period. I couldn’t believe this was happening after everything I’d gone through. We went to the hospital where they kept me overnight, and the bleeding stopped. I was told it was a placental abruption, where the placenta detaches from the uterus and can cut off oxygen and nutrition supply from the baby. Luckily it was only a partial detachment. I was released the morning of my baby shower.
Q: How were you able to manage your anxiety with everything going on?

I bought an at-home fetal doppler so you can listen to the heartbeat. I also slept with a pulse monitor on my finger, and I would have to remind myself that my breathing was okay. These are the irrational thoughts you have when you suffer from anxiety. If I had felt better physically and been up to going to therapy, I would have done it. And if I could have, I probably would have done therapy online because it was isolating being stuck in bed, and I was definitely getting depressed and anxious.
Q: How was your childbirth experience?

My anxiety was so bad at the end that I asked for a scheduled C-section at 39 weeks. My OB tried to convince me to try for a natural labor, but I was so mentally drained that I knew I wouldn’t have the physical strength to go through it. I was panicking to the point of not sleeping. I worried that I would have to have an emergency C-section anyway, considering all of my complications. My hospital doesn’t allow the husband in the operating room for emergency C-sections, and he was my only support. I think what convinced my OB to plan a C-section is that I had a full-blown panic attack in her office at about 37 or 38 weeks. The earliest she could do was Thanksgiving Day, and I said, “Sign me up.”
Q: Do you feel like you got the care you needed after your son was born?

I couldn’t believe how little my doctors helped me. I was so anxious after he was born. I was put back on my anxiety meds, which made me so sleepy that I felt unable to care for the baby. I didn't feel capable of ensuring his safety. I had no thoughts of hurting him, but I didn't feel like I could trust myself to care for him without help. I felt like I was failing as a mother. Additionally,18 days after his birth I had to get my gallbladder removed. When I got home from surgery I was in a lot of pain and wasn’t able to walk upstairs to the baby’s room. I felt like he didn’t even know me.

My doctor and my son’s pediatrician both gave me the standard postpartum screening. Though my score was elevated, they didn't offer any resources, because I was already on medication. No one even suggested counseling—I believe, in retrospect, because I am a counselor myself. But they shouldn’t have taken my profession into account. My son recently turned one, and things are better now. I still have days that I need help, but now I know it’s going to be okay.
Q: What advice would you give women suffering from anxiety who are going through fertility treatments?

If it doesn’t feel like a good fit with the doctor, and you’re not getting the care you need physically and emotionally, find another one. My original OB was amazing in addressing my anxiety, but then she got pregnant, and I had to switch. Being pregnant may bring out anxiety even if you didn’t struggle with it before. So when you’ve been previously diagnosed and know it’s an issue, you need a doctor who will be supportive. The mental health of the mother is so important.
Q: Do you think you’ll try to have another baby?

Immediately after I had my son, I said I would never get pregnant again, though I would consider using a surrogate. With everything I went through, I don’t know if I could physically do it again. We still have embryos we can use—18 of them!—but we’re undecided about whether we’re going to have more kids.
Q: Why did you want to share your story with Maven?

IVF is still something that women have shame about. I talk to women all the time who hate their body because they feel like it betrayed them. I’ve been through that, and I know that there’s hope on the other side. You have to learn to love yourself. It sounds cheesy, but it’s true.

title.en-US: IVF with frozen embryos

content.value: Real Talk on Fertility with Dr. Rachna Krishan
“In training to be an OB-GYN, I thought, If I can't get pregnant, I'll just do IVF, and I'll be done. The idea that IVF is guaranteed to work is a total misconception that isn't addressed.”
Name:
Rachna Krishnan
Age:
Q: What did your infertility journey look like?

My husband and I got married when I was 32. He's also a physician. We tried ovulation kits and timed intercourse in our attempt to get pregnant, but didn’t have success. Being an OB-GYN, I had a feeling that we'd need infertility treatment. I self-referred myself to an infertility doctor, and I didn't want to do IUI. I felt like even those six months when we were using the ovulation kits were emotionally trying, and I wanted something with higher chances of success, which meant going right into IVF. We did the first round, and I didn't get pregnant. They ended up implanting two day-three embryos, which were not good quality and didn't take. (In general, blastocysts—or embryos that grow to day 5 or 6 in a lab—have a better chance of implanting.) I was distraught, and took six months off before doing another round of IVF. We got five embryos from the next round, but the resulting fresh embryo transfer didn’t work. We finally did a frozen transfer of two embryos, and they both took.
Q: How did you choose your clinic?

I started out at a large academic center, thinking that it was the best place to get treatment for everything, but I didn’t like it. There were a lot of trainees involved. I was a resident at the time so I understand, but I didn't want to tell my story so many times. The resident or the fellow would manage me, and the attending doctor would be on the sideline. I felt like they were academic, and they weren't addressing my concerns or listening to me. I ended up switching to a private practice, they were more attentive and treated me like an individual, asking me, “What do you want to do?”
Q: What kind of insight did you have into this process, being an OB-GYN?

Not a lot, which I was surprised about. I think the only real insight I had was that I should try to get started with treatment as soon as possible. In training to be an OB-GYN, I thought, If I can't get pregnant, I'll just do IVF, and I'll be done. The idea that IVF is guaranteed to work is a total misconception that isn't addressed. While I think it’s a good thing women are being proactive and freezing their eggs, nothing is guaranteed. You don't know what your egg quality is. I feel, in a way, it's also giving women this false sense of hope. They think, I froze my eggs, so I can get pregnant at 40.
I waited a while to have kids, but I think there needs to be more counseling or more information available to women as they delay starting a family.
Q: What surprised you the most about your experience?

Even being a provider and knowing what to expect, it was a really emotionally trying process with a lot of heartbreak. For a while, I saw a therapist that works specifically with infertility issues. I didn't expect to be so emotional through the whole process, to be questioning so much with thoughts like these: How far are you willing to go? How many times are you going to do this? How much are you going to kill yourself physically, emotionally, financially?
Q: How did the decision to transfer two embryos come about?

It was a tough decision, given all the potential morbidities of having twins and the potential for a preterm birth. Based on my age and the embryo quality, my doctor was okay transferring two. My embryos looked good, but they weren't great, and I had already failed at IVF. I had a good rapport with my doctor, and I trusted him.
Q: Did you have a lot of emotions during your pregnancy?

I had a lot of anxiety during my pregnancy. I would see something sad and scary happen to patients at work and think, “Oh God, what if that happens to me?’” I had bursts of bleeding until I was 15-16 weeks, which was really terrifying. I was always scanning myself with an ultrasound—I bought a Doppler and was listening to the heartbeats every day. My husband thought I was a lunatic. I managed my entire pregnancy. Luckily, my OB was really cool and let me do whatever I wanted. 
A friend of mine got pregnant naturally and we were pregnant at the exact same time. She looked beautiful and was so calm and collected about the whole thing. I was a mess. I think some people embrace it and are totally glowing, pregnant women, and some aren't.
Q: Any plans to have any more kids?

No. We have a couple more embryos, and that puts you in an awkward position, because I don't think I could ever dispose of them. But we're happy with two, and I don't think I could emotionally handle getting pregnant again. I ended up with two healthy kids; that's fine. I don't want to test fate again.
Q: How has this experience informed your professional life?

I think I take the responsibility more seriously than I did before. I address my patients’ concerns and do the infertility workup quicker and refer them out to specialists much quicker. I can relate to my patients about everything—about getting pregnant and about being pregnant. I went through both processes, and that's made me better in caring for them.
Q: From your experiences, are there any changes you think the healthcare industry needs to make in order to better support women going through infertility?

I think it needs to be considered a disease, so insurance would have to cover treatment. It’s unfair that only people with the means can afford it. I work in a county hospital and a lot of my patients don't have the financial resources to pay for IVF. So I can only go so far with trying to help them and it's sad that advanced treatment is not an option.

title.en-US: “Egg freezing made me look 5 months pregnant”

content.value: Maven Real Talk on Egg Freezing With Kirsten
37 years old
Consultant
New York
Why did you decide to freeze your eggs, and how old were you at the time?

I hope to find a man to have a family with someday, but I haven’t yet. When I first started talking to my OB-GYN about egg freezing, she said that any time after 33 and before 37 would be a good time for me to do it if I was still single. I was 36 when I decided to do it. And no, my job was never a consideration in this; I didn’t freeze my eggs for career reasons.
What information do you wish you had about egg freezing that would have made you better prepared?

The hormone injections weren’t that bad. The emotional toll it took on me that was the worst part, by a long shot. Being single at this stage in my life, I had to face the fact that my dream of being a mom might never happen. This realization put me in an awful depression. I’m not entirely sure it’s gone yet even though it’s been several months since I did the procedure.
Was your fertility clinic doctor real with you about the fact that egg freezing isn’t foolproof?
Yes, I felt I was informed about the risks.
How did you choose your clinic? What did you like/dislike about the patient experience?

I went with my OB-GYN’s suggestion for a clinic. I quickly learned that there’s no room for being shy about your body when you’re freezing your eggs. I felt like a pincushion who was constantly being prodded, and didn’t realize a new person would be inserting that awful thing—the transvaginal ultrasound device—inside me every day.
How much has egg freezing cost you?
$4K was my out-of-pocket cost. My employer covered the rest.
How many eggs did you get?
14 eggs were retrieved—and from that batch, 9 were viable and frozen. My doctor was happy but I feel kind of “meh” about the number I ended up with.
What surprised you most about the egg retrieval procedure?

It was so fast! The hard part was putting on 10 pounds of water weight that same day and, because of all that bloating, feeling like my whole body was going to explode. Oh, and looking like I was 5 months pregnant for a few days after. That sucked a lot.
Who did you tell about your egg freezing decision?

I was open with my workplace—they were supportive and accommodating. But in my personal life, I only told my best friends I was going to freeze my eggs. I waited until after it was over to tell everyone else. Frankly, I didn’t want to talk about it or hear anyone’s opinion before I did it.
What advice would you give someone who is considering freezing her eggs?
I would warn her that it can be a lonely and difficult experience. But if you can afford it and there’s a good reason to do it, it’s worth it.

title.en-US: "Too young" for infertility testing

content.value: Real Talk on Fertility with Maven Counselor Wendy Bray
“Physically, I was fine. Emotionally, it was like a bomb went off in my mind and heart, leaving scars that can never be fixed, only hidden.”
Name:
Wendy Bray
Age:
Q: When did your fertility issues begin?

I had my first daughter at 24 and there were no issues getting pregnant. A couple of years later, we started trying for our next baby. After months of trying, we still couldn’t conceive. I was 26 years old, and when I went to see a doctor to get help, I was told that because of my age, they couldn’t do anything for me. They wouldn't run any tests; they wouldn't provide me with any medications—nothing! Instead of taking me seriously, they told me to “just keep trying.” So I did.
Q: Were you eventually able to get pregnant?

Yes, eventually I did, but I became concerned when I noticed spotting in the first trimester. I lived in a rural area and the providers would not see anyone before they were 12 weeks along. I was about nine weeks, so I had to travel almost two hours for an appointment with an OB-GYN who would see me. We did an ultrasound and saw the baby, and everything seemed okay. My provider tried to treat the bleeding by putting me on progesterone. The spotting seemed to go away, but at 16 weeks, I started bleeding again and returned to the doctor. This time when they did an ultrasound, there was no heartbeat. That was devastating.
Q: What was the emotional aftermath of suffering a miscarriage?

I remember my daughter going to her friend’s birthday party, and I couldn’t bring myself to go with her; all I could do was stay in my room and cry. I've never wanted something so badly that I couldn't have. I felt like a failure as a woman. I wondered whether something was wrong with me or if I was somehow to blame. Was it something I ate? Something I did? What did I do in my life to deserve this? These questions come into your mind, even if you know better. 
Q: How long did it take to to have your other children?
It took a couple more years of trying—and several miscarriages—before I was able to carry to term. After having gone through the first miscarriage, I was so terrified. You sit at home with legs crossed, afraid to move. But seven years after my first daughter was born, I delivered a healthy little girl. Then when I was 36, I found out I was pregnant with my son. That time, we hadn’t been trying to conceive and I was shocked, given how hard it had been for me to get—or, more accurately: stay pregnant—in the past. With my son, we started early ultrasounds to make sure everything was okay. I think this was because I was older this time around.
Q: Did doctors ever figure out the reason for your recurrent miscarriages?

Well, when my son was little—he's ten now—I wound up with a pulmonary embolism (PE) a year after being diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). What this means is that the blood clots in my legs travelled to both my lungs. This was the first time a doctor had ever said to me that blood clotting issues may have been linked to the miscarriages.
All that time I was going through my pregnancy losses, there wasn’t much time spent trying to discover why I kept miscarrying. There weren’t any fertility specialists in the rural area I lived in at the time, for one. And at no time was I offered genetic testing.
Q: What was the experience of miscarriage like, physically?

Two of my miscarriages were farther along, so I was given the option to miscarry naturally or have a D&C (dilation and curettage). I chose a D&C because I didn’t want to have to see what came out. I know other women that miscarried naturally, and it was traumatic for them. 
The D&Cs were outpatient procedures under general anesthesia. Physically, I was fine, other than some intense cramping. Emotionally, it was like a bomb went off in my mind and heart, leaving scars that can never be fixed, only hidden. You’re in the hospital to have this procedure, and it’s not the reason you’d want to be at the hospital. Being there should have been a joyous occasion, and it wasn’t. For my second D&C, because I was further along in the pregnancy, the hospital gave me the option of burying the baby. We were able to have a little service at the cemetery. It might sound strange, but doing that was cathartic and healing.
Q: As a mental health practitioner, what’s your advice to clients who are going through miscarriages or other infertility issues?

For anyone going through miscarriages or infertility, I always suggest group therapy—either in person or online. I know the gamut of emotions—the hope, the heartbreak, the frustration, the disappointment, and the anger. It’s an emotional roller coaster. This isn’t something that you want to go through on your own, but not everyone understands. There are some fantastic support groups online. When I was pregnant with my son, I found an online group of older moms, and we still keep in touch. Our lives have all changed since then—and for many of us, a lot of good came after our struggles—but we're still there to support each other.

title.en-US: Infertility at a young age

content.value: Real Talk on Fertility with Katrina Zelenka
”Being a parent is one of the hardest jobs in the world—you appreciate it so much more after having suffered a loss.”
Name:
Katrina Zelenka
Age:
Q: What was your experience with trying to conceive?

I was 23 and had been with my boyfriend for four years. I had just completed my bachelor's degree in nursing, and we decided that we wanted to start a family. I got pregnant the first time we tried. Eight weeks later, I had some bleeding, but I had heard that sometimes happens in early pregnancy and it could be normal. My doctor said to monitor the situation, but that there really wasn’t anything that could be done: The bleeding would either get lighter and go away, or it would get heavier and it could be a miscarriage. So we waited it out. 
My partner worked as a teacher, and the women he worked with had given him books for the baby. There was this excitement in our lives, and all of that was threatened. The next couple of days I had more cramping and more bleeding. I went to the doctor, where they did tests and learned my HCG levels were dropping. It was, in fact, a miscarriage.
Q: How would you describe your patient experience while this was happening?

One of the things I'll never forget was how I was treated by the ultrasound technician. It was an elderly man who performed the exam, and of course it was transvaginal, which made it very uncomfortable. When he saw that the pregnancy wasn't viable he mentioned that something was wrong with my uterus. He was cold and unsympathetic. My OB-GYN said, "Oh, this happens all the time. No big deal. There's nothing wrong with you. This is common." But to me, it was a traumatic emotional experience. Not to mention, there was physical pain as well. So that first miscarriage was extremely difficult for me.
Six months later, I went through another miscarriage. This time I was more guarded and scared because it had happened once before and I knew it could happen again. About six weeks into that pregnancy I had bleeding and sharp pain that shot all the way down to my leg, and I was admitted to the hospital. They had to follow my lab work closely to make sure it wasn't an ectopic (or “tubal pregnancy”), or an ovarian cyst that possibly ruptured.
Again, a male physician came in and when he told me I had miscarried he said, "You're young. This stuff happens." I felt like I was looked down upon for being young, and for being unmarried. So not only am I dealing with this loss and this grief, but I also felt that I was being judged.
Q: After each of your miscarriages, did you take time off, or try again right away?

I had mixed medical advice on that. Some doctors told me to wait three months, and other doctors said it's safe to go ahead and keep trying. I was determined to get pregnant, so I waited for one menstrual cycle, and then resumed trying right afterward.
Q: What was your mental state like in the midst of all this?

Each miscarriage was mentally and emotionally draining and it took several weeks to recover both times, although you’re never quite the same. Then you see other people having children all around you—especially when you spend time on social media—and that made it more difficult. In the beginning, I felt like no one understood what I was going through. I was so surprised to discover how many women have had similar experiences. Because my boyfriend had shared the news of my pregnancies with this coworkers, he had to tell them what happened. All these other stories and experiences of miscarriage started coming out of the woodwork.
Q: What ultimately helped you get through this tough time?

The biggest help after my miscarriages was the online community I found. Women were talking openly about their struggles and their “rainbow babies” (babies born after miscarriages) and I found it to be such a strong source of hope and support. I also started focusing more on my exercise and diet, and found different ways to take care of myself physically and mentally such as yoga and meditation.
Q: At any point during your struggle to get pregnant, did you consider pursuing fertility treatment?

I had that discussion with the first OB-GYN practice that I had gone to. And they said, "You're fine, you're young, you don't need any of that. Don't worry about it now." Later on, I switched practices and voiced my concerns that something serious could be wrong. The new doctor did blood work to make sure that my hormone levels were okay, and did an ultrasound to make sure I don't have PCOS, just to rule out other causes that could be to blame for my issues. And everything came back normal. Because nothing turned out to be suspicious, I just kept trying to conceive on my own.

Ultimately, in the end I tried for another six months after that and at that point I was like, "You know what? I'm done trying." I did the ovulation sticks; I did the tracking; I had the fertility app. I did everything by the book. Finally, I just decided that I would let go. And I was successful—I did get pregnant on my own soon after. To this day, the cause of my earlier miscarriages was never determined. Now I think it was nature's way of saying, "This isn't a good pregnancy," and my body rejected it.
Q: Today you have two kids. What is it like parenting after struggling to conceive?

For one, I do believe that what we went through made the bond with my partner stronger. He took our difficulties getting pregnant as hard as I did. Whenever we had tough times being new parents, he would say, "Remember the two babies that we lost. We tried really hard for this. And this is going to pass, and we're going to miss these moments that we have with her as a newborn." Being a parent is one of the hardest jobs in the world—you appreciate it so much more after having suffered a loss.

title.en-US: Confusing egg freezing jargon—explained

content.value: When you’re a newbie to egg freezing, a lot of the lingo used to describe certain aspects of the procedure can make things pretty confusing. Keep reading for help to decode fertility clinic parlance.
My nurse sometimes talks about “egg harvesting”—what exactly does this mean?

Typically people are referring to the actual egg retrieval. But most medical experts shy away from this reference because it’s not the accurate medical term. What’s more, there could be agriculture associations with the word “harvesting”—and this is a medical choice, not a way of collecting a batch of chicken-laid eggs for breakfast.
What the heck is transvaginal ultrasound aspiration and is it as scary as it sounds?

If harvesting is the least medical term for collecting eggs, transvaginal ultrasound aspiration is the most technical way to describe it. This is the most common egg retrieval method that doctors use, where an ultrasound probe is guided through the vaginal wall. A thin needle attached to the ultrasound reaches the follicles (aka the fluid-filled sac that contains the eggs), and using light suction, the eggs are removed. Don’t worry—you’ll be sedated the whole time.
What’s oocyte cryopreservation?

This is the technical name for egg freezing. Oocytes are your eggs, and cryopreservation refers to the process of preserving biological matter by freezing it for later use. Egg freezing is just one form of cryopreservation; sperm and embryos can also be cryopreserved.
My clinic keeps mentioning an embryologist—is this person also a doctor?

Some embryologists have a doctorate and/or medical degree, but not all do. For instance, they may have earned a bachelor's degree in biology or biomedicine and a master's degree in reproductive/clinical science. Whatever their educational background, they work closely alongside reproductive endocrinologists. Once the egg retrieval is performed by your doctor, the eggs are handed off to the embryologist in the lab. These specialists have gone through training in the actual cryopreservation techniques and other procedures that take place in a fertility lab.
Have more questions?
Book an appointment
with a Maven practitioner who can help you navigate this journey with confidence.

title.en-US: How I chose to move on to IVF

content.value: Real Talk on Fertility with Maven Lactation Consultant & Nurse/Midwife Nina Wilson
“I always tell women that it’s crucial to find coping mechanisms and enjoy life while you’re going through this process, because being hyper-focused on getting pregnant can be counterproductive.”
Name:
Nina Wilson
Age:
Q: When did you realize you would need help getting pregnant?

I got married when I was 26, and we pretty much started trying to have kids immediately. When nothing happened for a few years, I began getting concerned. I worked at an OB-GYN office as a nurse/midwife at the time, and my doctor started me on Clomid (a commonly prescribed fertility medication that helps stimulate ovulation) for about eight months, then switched me to an injectable called Femara for about four months. We did four rounds of IUI (intrauterine insemination), and none were successful.

At that point, we decided we’d try to adopt, but it didn’t work out. Adoption is very expensive, and there’s a lot of paperwork that you have to restart if you move to a new state. Since my husband was in the military and we were moving a lot, it was going to be very difficult for us.
Q: When did you decide to do IVF?

It was after more than three years of trying to conceive. I was 30 years old when I did IVF, and got pregnant on our first try. Afterward, I wasn’t on birth control. You can imagine my surprise when I got pregnant naturally two more times! By the time I was 36 I had three kids. Somehow, my fertility improved as I got older.
Q: Did doctors ever diagnose the cause of your infertility?

They said I had poor egg quality, the lining of my uterus was not ideal for pregnancy, and my cycles were a bit off. The funny thing is, right before I got pregnant naturally with my second child, my endocrinologist told me, “If you want another kid, you need to use your frozen embryos, because you’re not going to get pregnant on your own.” But I did.
Q: What was taking fertility medications like?

It was really hard emotionally, because they altered my hormones. As the woman, I was the one going through it physically. The medications made me have severe mood swings; I often felt crazy and would take things out on my husband, and sometimes it was really difficult for him to understand what I was going through. I wish I’d been better prepared for how emotionally charged this was going to be, because I really didn’t cope well, and it was incredibly trying on my marriage. 
On the physical side, the medications caused a lot of hot flashes. Many of them also had to be injected on a daily basis, which was creepy even for me—and I’m a nurse. My husband could not go near a needle at that point, so I administered the shots myself. I had to inject FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone) daily over eight to ten days, and progesterone daily throughout ten to twelve weeks. It was physically and emotionally draining. Not to mention, once I did become pregnant, I had to have progesterone injected into my bottom each night, which was painful, created huge bruises, and made me super sleepy. My husband actually had to do these shots, because it’s a really hard injection to give yourself.

I think this is something lots of women don’t think about. If you and your partner are both uncomfortable administering shots, you need to find someone to do them for you. I had a friend who was going through IVF at the same time, and I gave her the injections. If you don’t like shots, it can be really upsetting to have to stick yourself with a needle in the stomach every night. I’d bring her a little gift each night, just to make the experience less awful for her.
Q: Did you undertake any lifestyle changes during the process of trying to conceive?
I started doing yoga three times a week right before I got pregnant with my second child. It made me more centered and grounded, and took some of my focus away from my fertility struggles.
Q: What surprised you most about your journey with infertility?

It was much more emotionally and physically trying than I expected. Another thing that people don’t think about—especially young women who are likely to produce a lot of eggs—is what to do with extra embryos. Eleven years after doing IVF, we have three frozen embryos (aka cryopreserved embryos) that I don’t know what to do with. I was thrilled to get six good-quality embryos, and I thought we’d use them all because we wanted to have more than one child and doctors kept telling me that I would never get pregnant on my own. We transferred two on our first try; one didn’t make it; and they were able to preserve an additional three. Since I’ve been able to get pregnant naturally, those three embryos are still on ice.

I ended up being very ill during my last pregnancy—I had very high blood pressure and it was very scary. I remember telling my hypertension specialist, “I need to be pregnant one time because I have these embryos.” And he said, “Don't press your luck, you can't do this again.” I cried and cried—what was I going to do with these embryos? I can’t in good conscience destroy them. We considered a surrogate, but it’s too expensive—basically the cost of one of our kids’ college tuition. I’d like to find someone to donate them to, but it’s a hard subject to broach with people, and I don’t want to just donate them to an embryo center and have some random strangers raise whatever children may come out of them. It’s a big dilemma that weighs heavily on me—definitely a stressor I never anticipated.
Q: How did you cope with the emotional toll of infertility?

Honestly? Not well. During my struggle to conceive, I really felt like the whole world was pregnant except me. I remember one Thanksgiving after I had just found out that one of our IUIs hadn’t worked. My sister-in-law, whom I love dearly, announced she was pregnant, and I ran out of the room crying. You feel terrible, because you love this person, and you want to be happy for them. Some of our good friends also got pregnant in the middle of all this, and going to their baby showers was so painful. It was particularly hard given the industry I’m in. I’d be delivering a baby, and after handing her to her parents, I’d have to run out of the room because it upset me so much.
Q: What advice would you give to other women who are about to embark on the fertility treatment journey?

The main thing I tell prospective moms is to find something good in your life right now—a reason to be positive—because in the end things tend to work out the way they’re supposed to. I know it’s hard to stay optimistic when you’re in the middle of it, but you really need to take care of yourself and make time for the things that make you happy. As for self-care, whether it’s exercise, meditating, or yoga, find an outlet to help you relax and shift your focus, because stress can be counter-productive to your fertility. Some women also find that support groups are really helpful. I was a miserable person for three years, and when I look back on it now, I feel like I wasted some really good times in my life when I should have been enjoying my youth and my marriage. Once you become a mother, your life changes, and you can’t get that time back.
Q: How do you think the fertility industry can better support the patient experience?

It’s important to ensure that women have emotional support throughout this process. Some fertility centers are doing this now; they have a designated person in the office to provide personal support. My reproductive endocrinology office was pretty good about this. Providers also need to make sure they have a good bedside manner and aren’t asking women to explain their history multiple times—recounting all the failed attempts to conceive over and over again can be difficult. This can be a really isolating and lonely time, so this kind of support is crucial.

title.en-US: 4 emotions you have when you freeze your eggs

content.value: As these women will attest to, egg freezing can bring on all the feels.
“I felt lonely.”

“I chose to freeze my eggs at a general fertility center instead of a clinic that focused solely on egg freezing. That meant a lot of people there were doing things like IUI and IVF—often with their partners beside them. Sometimes, I’d look around the waiting room and a sense of loneliness would set in. This caught me off guard because I’m not someone who feels bad about being single—I don’t think that being in a relationship is superior. But freezing my eggs triggered the ‘How did I end up here alone?’ thinking. Luckily, I was talking to a therapist at the time, and was able to work through these feelings.”—Janet, froze her eggs at 38
“I felt sad after the retrieval.”

“Even though I knew there wasn’t a ‘perfect number’ of eggs to strive for, I felt sad when I didn’t up with nearly as many as I’d hoped for. I found myself asking friends, ‘How many eggs did you get?’—and secretly comparing the size of my batch to theirs and feeling as though my body had failed me.”—Felicia, froze her eggs at 35
“I felt more hormonal than I’ve ever been in my life.”

“I only had one friend who froze her eggs before I did, and she never mentioned anything about the emotional roller coaster. Well, I learned very quickly that everyone reacts differently to the hormone injections, because my moods were all over the place. I wish someone had warned me that spontaneously crying at work—or on a date!—was not out of the question.”—Kaitlyn, froze her eggs at 33
“I felt empowered throughout the process—but especially when it was all over.”

“Maybe I’ll thaw the eggs and try for single-motherhood in 10 years, maybe I’ll meet a guy whose kids become my own, or maybe I’ll just get another cat. The bottom line is I have choices, and that’s what’s most empowering about my decision.”—Carolyn, froze her eggs at 31

title.en-US: Is it better to freeze eggs or embryos?

content.value: Just add sperm? Here’s the answer to a not-so-simple question.

Some women have heard that freezing embryos is “better” than freezing eggs, so they’re left wondering if they should be hitting the nearest sperm bank instead of getting their eggs on ice. Is there any truth to this rumor, and what’s the difference, really?
Well, if you’re freezing eggs, they get put on ice right after your doctor retrieves them, and don’t co-mingle with sperm until they’re thawed for IVF (when you’re ready to try to have a baby). If you’re freezing embryos, on the other hand, your eggs will be retrieved and immediately fertilized with sperm. Once fertilized, they’re allowed to develop for a few days in a lab before they’re frozen.

Even though eggs and embryos are frozen using the same techniques, there are some key differences. An egg is a single cell, while a day-5 embryo can have 100 or more cells. That makes a frozen embryo slightly sturdier and less fragile than a frozen egg—so an embryo may have a slight edge over an egg in surviving the thawing process. Also, you’ll know up front how many embryos you’ll have to work with later on. That said, there’s no guarantee that every frozen embryo will lead to a baby—whether you’re freezing eggs or embryos, it may take a few tries at IVF before you end up with a child. Experts point out that no one should consider either option a guaranteed bet.

So where does that leave you? If you’re with a partner you want to have kids with—just not right now—then you might want to fertilize your eggs with his sperm and freeze embryos. But it should be noted that not all experts agree that this is the right, or “better,” choice. Some argue that if a couple splits down the line, a woman might not be able to use the eggs she froze with her current male partner, so freezing eggs might give her more options in the future. Then there’s also the issue of what to do with any frozen embryos you may not end up using; this is an ethical dilemma for some people (much thornier than the question of what to do with frozen eggs), and it’s worth considering how you’d handle it down the line.

One last thing: We know, there’s a lot to think about. If you need help figuring out what’s right for you, book an appointment with a Maven mental health provider or reproductive endocrinologist. They have lots of experience helping people navigate complex fertility decisions, and can help you move forward with greater peace of mind.

title.en-US: How long does it really take to freeze your eggs?‎

content.value: Weeks? Months? Get the straight talk here.
Sure, every woman’s timeline might look a little different. But this overview can help you know what to expect and when you might need to clear the calendar.
Screening and preparation: 1 to 4 weeks

Sometimes the most time-intensive part of the egg freezing process is all the planning and preparation. Even once you’ve done your research and zeroed in on a clinic, you may have to wait to get in for an appointment. (If you haven’t found a clinic yet—don’t worry. Reach out to your dedicated care concierge at Maven for help navigating this step.) Each clinic does things differently but you can usually count on having 2-3 up-front appointments in order for your doctor to assess your reproductive situation and ovarian reserve (and even give you an idea of how many egg freezing cycles should be planned).
Ovarian Stimulation: Up to 2 weeks

Once you’ve completed all the testing and have the green light to proceed, your doctor will likely wait for your period to begin before starting you on hormone medication. This is often referred to as the stimming phase, and it lasts 8 to 12 days, on average. During this time, you’ll be asked to self-inject hormone medications every day so that your ovaries are stimulated to produce multiple eggs (instead of the one that typically gets released in a given menstrual cycle). You’ll also have brief visits at the clinic (roughly every couple of days) for get blood tests and vaginal ultrasounds; this allows your doctor to keep tabs on the growth of your follicles—and dial medication dosages up or down as needed.
Egg retrieval and freezing: 1 day

Once you’ve produced your eggs, the doctor will retrieve them using a needle and suction device (don’t worry—you’ll be sedated, so you won’t feel a thing as it’s happening). This procedure takes less than 20 minutes, and you can head home soon after. Right after your retrieval, your eggs are whisked away by the embryologist so they can be frozen and stored for future use.
Recovery: Up to a week

Recovery time after the procedure is different for everyone. Some women have virtually no discomfort by the next day, while others may take a little longer feel like themselves again. You might experience cramping, bloating, and nausea—and feel a bit wiped out—for several days. If you want to play it safe, it might be best to schedule the retrieval when you know you can have a relatively low-key week afterward.

title.en-US: On egg freezing: “The only thing you have to lose is money”

content.value: Maven Real Talk on Egg Freezing With Kiesha
41 years old
Attorney
New Jersey
How old were you when you froze your eggs?
I did three rounds. I was 37 when I began, and 38 by the time I was done.
Did your career aspirations play a role in your decision?
Not at all. It was completely based on not finding the right partner to have kids with at the right time.
Did your OB-GYN discuss egg freezing with you before you made a decision to do it?
No. I was mainly informed and influenced by friends who had already gone through the process.
What information do you wish you had about your fertility or about egg freezing that was hard to find?

When you’re asking questions on these topics, a lot of the answers are something like: "It depends” or “It's different for every woman." So I think a lot of my dissatisfaction with the information I was able to access was simply a result of the nature of fertility science—it’s not always black and white.
How did you choose your clinic? What did you like/dislike about the experience?

I chose a clinic based on the convenience of the location, mainly. My main complaint about the clinic was just how impersonal it was and how much it felt like a factory. The first time I visited, there weren't enough seats in the waiting room to accommodate the number of women who were there. And no one talked to me about my timeline; it was assumed that I wanted to have a child ASAP at all costs. I would have appreciated more tailored advice.
How many eggs did you get?
24 eggs.
How much has egg freezing cost you?
Approximately $25,000-$30,000—including 3 rounds of egg freezing and all of the drugs. I paid for it out of my savings.
What surprised you most about the procedure? Was it painful?
It wasn't painful for me, and the retrieval itself was very quick. Afterward, I experienced some bloating, and I did feel little crazy while my body purged all the hormones.
Did you have a lot of emotions come up during this process?

It took me a while to psych myself up to freeze my eggs. But once I made the decision, it was very empowering to feel like I was taking charge. The biggest crash for me happened after it was done. I felt exhausted and emotional from the whole process. And my body felt out of whack, so I came out of it feeling a bit fragile.
Who did you tell about your egg freezing decision?
I was very open about it with my friends as well as my employer. The director of my office was very supportive.
Did your fertility clinic talk to you about the fact that egg freezing doesn’t provide a guarantee of having a baby?
Yes. I did feel like they provided me with sufficient information.
If your best friend was thinking about freezing her eggs, what advice would you give her?
I always tell people who are considering freezing their eggs that the only thing you have to lose is money. If you can afford it, then why not do it?

title.en-US: How egg freezing can affect your cycle

content.value: Answers to three common questions.
If my periods have always been regular, should I feel pretty confident that the eggs I freeze will be high-quality?

Unfortunately, a regular cycle doesn’t translate to a greater chance of having high-quality eggs. One reality of egg freezing is that you can’t predict whether an egg will be viable until you actually try to fertilize it with sperm and implant it in the uterus.
I have PCOS and my periods are irregular. Can I still freeze my eggs?

Yes, hormone medications can help you ovulate and prepare for egg freezing. One thing to note is that women with PCOS do have a greater risk of developing ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome, or OHSS, because they can over-respond to the hormones. Even though your doctor will be monitoring you closely while you’re taking the hormone meds, OHSS can also happen after the procedure. Keep an eye out for symptoms like rapid weight gain, abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting—and definitely get medical help ASAP if you spot these signs.
Will I stop getting my period for a while after I freeze my eggs?
No. You should see your period return about two weeks after your egg freezing procedure—and from then on, it’s business as usual in the menstruation department.

title.en-US: Will I be able to drive myself home after the egg retrieval?

content.value: No—you’ll definitely want to arrange for a ride home. Here’s why this is necessary: To prevent you from feeling pain during the procedure, you’ll be sedated. Even if you come out of the procedure feeling like yourself, anesthesia can slow reflexes and hamper your ability to drive. This is why one fertility clinic website puts things rather bluntly when cautioning patients against going back to work afterward: “If you go to work you may be acting like you are drunk and you are very likely to make mistakes in judgment.”
So what kind of anesthesia will my doctor use?

Since egg retrieval is considered a minimally invasive surgery, general anesthesia (like the kind received through a mask) that’s common during major surgery isn’t usually necessary. Most often, intravenous sedation is used instead—where an anaesthetic is given through an IV placed in a vein. This allows you to breathe on your own, and minimizes the risk of post-procedure complications that are more likely with general anesthesia.

title.en-US: How egg freezing gave one woman “peace of mind”

content.value: Maven Real Talk on Egg Freezing With Renee
39 years old
Nonprofit consultant
Washington, DC
How old were you when you froze your eggs, and why did you decide to do it?

I was 37, and I froze my eggs in hopes of preserving the ability to have a family with someone later on. I hope to have children one day, but I want to wait for the right partner. My career didn't play a role in my decision.
Do you feel that your doctor armed you with everything you needed to know to make an informed decision?

My OB-GYN didn’t discuss it with me, but my fertility clinic was very informative and matter-of-fact; they went to great lengths to ensure that it was clear that egg freezing doesn’t come with guarantees.
How did you choose your clinic? What did you like/dislike about the experience?

It was referred to me by a number of friends who had previously frozen their eggs.
I liked that the clinic was reputable and had significant experience. One downside was the feeling I got that I was just another number/patient. Ultimately, however, what was most important to me was that they were good at what they did and got the best results, even if they weren’t the most sensitive and warm in their approach.

My experience was positive overall, but it could have been better with a greater emphasis on the patient experience—sharing clear information, checking in consistently, allowing more time for questions, etc.
How much has egg freezing cost you? And how did you pay for it?
Approximately $10,000, including all the drugs. I paid out of pocket.
How many eggs did you get?
Twenty one. My doctor and I were happy with that number, so I didn’t have to do a second round.
Did you find the egg retrieval itself to be painful?
Not at all.
For some women, egg freezing brings up a lot of emotions. How did you feel?

I was disappointed to be at a place in my life where this was necessary—and I begrudgingly did it. But, now that I'm 2 years away from it, I'm incredibly happy that I made this choice. It helped me to process the decision with friends who had also frozen their eggs.
Who did you tell about your egg freezing decision? And how did people react?

Egg freezing is very common among my social circle as well as in my professional world, so it wasn’t a topic I felt I had to avoid. I told a number of friends as well as some coworkers. My workplace was very supportive.
If your best friend was thinking about freezing her eggs, what advice would you give her?

I would share that it's a decision she has to make for herself—I wouldn't pressure her at all. But I would share what it's meant for me, which is that it has given me peace of mind as I've continued on my dating journeys. I’ve also realized that I wasn't just doing this for myself, but for my future partner as well—given that biological children may be important to him, too.

title.en-US: 3 facts every woman should know about her egg situation

content.value: Let’s debunk some common myths.
Fact: You won’t know the quality of your eggs when you freeze them.

Unfortunately, there’s no way to know if the eggs you put on ice are high quality, aka chromosomally normal. The only way to know if an egg is chromosomally normal is to attempt to fertilize it, and do genetic testing on the resulting embryo. Since you can’t count on every egg leading to a viable pregnancy, your clinic may recommend retrieving 15, 20, or even more eggs—depending on your age and situation.
Fact: Eggs don’t just decline in quantity as a woman ages; they also decline in quality.

And egg quality has a lot to do with a woman’s fertility potential. Since egg quality generally declines more rapidly when a woman reaches her 30s, you can generally assume that the older you are, the more eggs you’ll need to increase your odds of having a baby later in life. Yes, this could mean having to do several rounds of egg freezing to get the supply recommended by your doctor.
Fact: Egg freezing doesn’t rob you of your egg supply.

Egg freezing involves taking medications to stimulate your ovaries to release multiple eggs in one cycle (instead of just the one mature egg that’s typically produced each month during ovulation). There’s a common misconception that stimulation “uses up” your egg supply or diminishes your ovarian reserve, but that’s a myth. The truth is, egg freezing simply “rescues” the immature eggs that naturally die off in any given menstrual cycle.

title.en-US: 4 times you really need your friends during egg freezing

content.value: When to call the squad.

You often hear women talk about how “empowered” egg freezing made them feel. But feelings of loneliness are also common. In fact, a 2018 study published in Fertility & Sterility found that many women wished they had more emotional support during their egg freezing journeys. Whether you’re doing it as a single woman or your partner can’t be there for you in ways you need, this is an excellent time to rely on your friends. Here are three times in particular where you might need a pal:
When you need to give yourself your very first shot.

Bonus points if your friend happens to be a nurse, pharmacist, or some other expert at administering needles or mixing solutions. But really, any un-squeamish, loving BFF will do. Sure, plenty of women do the injections on their own, but if you’re queasy about shots or worried about mixing all the meds correctly, give yourself the permission to ask for help.
When you’re processing the results of your monitoring appointments.

During the stimming process (aka—that period when you take all those shots to stimulate the ovaries), you’ll typically be asked to check in at the clinic early in the morning every other day or so for blood tests and ultrasounds. This is to make sure your follicles are on track for the retrieval. You’ll get a call in the afternoon to let you know how things are looking. Instead of 
obsessing alone over the results, plan to meet up with a friend after work. Just avoid anyone who tends to make you feel worse in high-stress situations and choose someone who always knows the right thing to say and puts you in a good mood.
When you need to be picked up from your egg retrieval.

This one is non-negotiable; you’ll be sedated for the procedure, and perhaps groggy afterward, so the clinic will require that someone is there to bring you home. Ask a pal who won’t mind checking in on you later that day and in the coming week to make sure you’re feeling good and back in the swing of things.
Any other time you’re freaking out or simply need someone to listen.
