Every woman who freezes her eggs will have a different experience. If you’re not the most relaxed about it, that’s OK! Lean on your inner circle, and remember you can check in with the mental health professionals in Maven’s network anytime you need extra support.

title.en-US: 5 questions about the flash-freezing technique

content.value: Get the ice cold facts on vitrification.

After you’ve gone through the process of stimulating your ovaries and your doctor has retrieved your eggs, the actual freezing—or cryopreservation—can begin. So how do those eggs get put on ice? There are two ways to go about it, and they’re both in use by different clinics today. First, there is the older “slow freezing” technique. Then there is the newer—and much more common—method called vitrification, aka “flash freezing,” which is the one preferred by many experts. Here’s the lowdown on what happens:
When does cryopreservation happen?

Right after your eggs are retrieved. As you’re still regaining consciousness from the procedure, your eggs have already been whisked away to be frozen in their optimal state. With vitrification, your eggs can get cooled by hundreds of degrees within a minute.
Why is faster better?

The longer the process takes, the more likely it is that ice crystals will form and cause damage to cell structures, increasing the chance that the egg will be useless when it’s thawed. Vitrification also involves using higher concentrations of substances called “cryoprotectants” than slow-freezing methods; this is yet another way to prevent pesky ice crystals from forming.
Will making a baby later be easier with a “vitrified” egg?

Possibly. A Cochrane review paper found that vitrification led to considerably higher clinical pregnancy rates in IVF than the slow-freezing process. Experts do point out that these studies didn’t look at live births, so more research is needed before the virtues of vitrification are blown out of proportion. But for now, things looks promising.
Does freezing really halt the egg-aging process in its tracks?

That’s the idea. When the egg is frozen, it doesn’t get any older. And once successfully thawed, the egg has theoretically the same potential to produce a healthy live birth as it did just before it was frozen.

title.en-US: 7 life scenarios that may lead to egg freezing

content.value: There’s no one motive—women turn to egg freezing for many different reasons.

In 2018, the American Society for Reproductive Medicine (ASRM) Ethics Committee issued new guidelines that change the way we talk about egg freezing. Instead of “elective” or “social” egg freezing (that’s what they called it when it wasn’t medically necessary before), ASRM now simply uses the word “planned.” It’s a small change, but one that represents an important attitude shift. After all, egg freezing isn’t a decision women are making on a whim. Here, 7 reasons—both medical and non-medical—you might be considering it.
You haven’t found a partner to start a family with.

Many women turn to egg freezing because they’re partner-less and don’t want to approach the end of their fertility window without the option to have a biological child. One study out of New York University Langone Medical Center found that more than 60% of women who went through the procedure said egg freezing decreased the “biological-clock pressure” they felt when when dating.
You’re at risk for early menopause.

Menopause is a natural age-related biological process that marks the end of your menstrual cycles. While the average menopausal age is 51 in the U.S., early menopause can be caused by certain genetic factors, autoimmune diseases, and in some cases, a hereditary predisposition (in women whose moms had premature ovarian failure), says Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, M.D. In these instances, egg freezing can be a way to address an ovarian reserve that is diminishing prematurely.
You’re undergoing IVF but religious or ethical reasons make it difficult to freeze embryos.

What do with unused embryos is a tricky question for some people. If a woman makes more eggs than she needs to fertilize and transplant during an IVF cycle, she can store the leftovers in case she undergoes another round (rather than making embryos to put on ice).
You’re about to undergo cancer therapy.

Chemotherapy and radiation therapy are common treatment options for many types of cancers. Unfortunately, they can also cause damage to a woman’s eggs. That’s why experts say it’s important to consider fertility preservation options before starting treatment.
If you tested positive for BRCA mutations.

Women who have inherited mutations in these genes are at an increased risk of developing both breast cancer and ovarian cancer. So some women with BRCA mutations choose to have their ovaries removed as a preventative measure against ovarian cancer. Freezing eggs for later use with IVF is an option because IVF bypasses the ovaries completely (embryos are implanted straight into the uterus).
You don’t want to rush into parenthood until your career is further along.

While the perception that most people freeze their eggs in order to prioritize their careers has been debunked, it must be acknowledged that some women do make the choice to delay childbearing for professional reasons.
You’re in a relationship but your partner isn’t ready to have a baby or doesn’t want one.

Just because you’re a duo doesn’t mean you’re on the same page about important life decisions like starting a family. Translation: Single women aren’t the only ones exploring their options at egg freezing clinics.

title.en-US: Career advancement isn’t why most women freeze their eggs

content.value: So what is?

As egg freezing became more popular, an interesting debate started to emerge: Should women really be “postponing” childbearing so that they can prioritize their careers? Whether you want to call it leaning in, climbing up, or grabbing on, many people assumed that professional advancement was spurring the rise in egg freezing as a reproductive choice.

But just how accurate is that assumption? Well, according to recent studies: not accurate at all. One 2018 study led by Yale University researchers found that career planning was the least common reason underlying women’s decision to freeze their eggs—and that the lack of a suitable partner to have kids with was their primary motive. 85% of the women who participated in the Yale study were single (most were heterosexual), but even the 15% who were in relationships said, in many cases, that the partner they were with was not ready to have kids or interested in having a family.
A previous study out of the
U.K.

revealed similar findings, concluding that “women’s use of egg freezing was shaped by fears of running out of time to form a conventional family, difficulties in finding a partner and concerns about ‘panic partnering’—together with a desire to avoid future regrets and blame.”
As for why women might struggle to find a suitable partner—it’s a complex question, and the answer can’t be reduced to a single hypothesis. But one argument noted by the
New York Times

relates to a demographic shift: Women in the U.S. and many other developed countries now outnumber men in college and earn more degrees. And for a woman who prioritizes “educational egalitarianism” in her relationship, the numbers may be stacked against her.

The bottom line: Maven fertility specialists say that some women who come to them for egg freezing consultations feel bad or even ashamed that they have not met a partner to have kids with yet; they think they “should” be in a different place in their lives. Studies like these can help women realize they are not alone.

title.en-US: What to do if you screw up your egg-freezing meds

content.value: Read this before you panic.
One day you’re on a roll—expertly injecting yourself like a pro and mixing solutions with the confidence of a chemist. The next, you accidentally miss a step or something else goes wrong.
When mishaps happen, the “fix” depends on your unique situation and protocol. But here’s what your doctor’s guidance might look look in a few common scenarios:
I left my meds on my kitchen counter overnight when they needed to be in the fridge.

Call your fertility nurse ASAP. Depending on which drug you left out, you might not need to ditch it and start your protocol over. A common egg-freezing drug called, Follistim, for instance, 
should be kept in the fridge, but unlike some other meds, the guidelines are less strict when it comes to its shelf life in room temperatures. Your doctor will help you know exactly what to do, but unless you’re in a heat wave without AC, there may be hope of salvaging certain meds.
Yikes! I think I injected myself with the wrong drug.

Call your clinic hotline and explain what happened. Some drugs have similar functions, so depending on the error, you may be able to continue on with your cycle with minor adjustments. However, some mishaps—like, for instance, injecting yourself with the medication that triggers the release of eggs before you’re supposed to—will likely require you to regroup.
Eek, I was so tired, I fell asleep without injecting myself.

Let your clinic know as soon as you wake up. “It depends on the patient, but generally, a few hours won’t make too much of a difference,” says Maven reproductive endocrinologist Scott Morin, M.D. However, if the injection you missed is the trigger shot, unfortunately you might have to reschedule your egg retrieval.
OMG, I think I mixed the wrong amount of Menopur. What happens if I took a higher or lower dosage than prescribed?

If you injected a lower dose than prescribed, there might be a way to compensate. Call your clinic as soon as you realize the mistake, and your doctor will help you know how to proceed. As for taking a higher concentration than prescribed, “it usually takes several days’ worth of overdosing to put you at risk for ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome,” says Morin, a condition in which your ovaries become swollen and painful. That said, every woman is different—so clueing your fertility specialist in is always your safest bet.
The bottom line

: Medicine mix-ups sometimes happen, but you should never determine how you should handle it on your own. Write down exactly what happened, when, and with what particular medication. Then call your clinic hotline, and leave it to your fertility specialist to re-adjust your meds or schedule. The more details you can give, the more effective their recommendation will be. Be sure to check out
MavenRx
, Maven's partnership with leading fertility pharmacies offering you discounts on your medications, one-on-one support, and more.

title.en-US: Two habits that could affect your plans to freeze your eggs

content.value: Improving your overall health is always a good idea when it comes to your fertility. But how important is it to ditch these habits if you’re not having a baby—at least not yet? Read on for the facts.
The habit: Smoking

You probably already know that smoking during pregnancy is a big health no-no. But if you’re not planning to use your frozen eggs anytime soon, do you still need to ditch the cigs? Yes. A 2017 review paper concluded that cigarettes are bad news for fertility preservation. Tobacco smoke speeds up the loss of follicles (the sacs in the ovaries that hold your eggs), keeps them from growing, and messes with the structure and development of the eggs themselves. It’s no wonder, then, as the American Society for Reproductive Medicine points out, smokers end up doing twice as many IVF cycles as non-smokers to get pregnant, and they need higher doses of hormone treatments to get the same amount of eggs.
Bottom line
: Quitting can be difficult, so make sure you’re getting the support you need from your doctor or a Maven practitioner who can provide support and guidance.
The habit: Drinking

You may not need to skip happy hour, but it’s probably best not to overdo it. While the studies aren’t conclusive, binge drinking is likely not a great way to prepare for an egg freezing cycle. Quick science lesson: Anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH) is a substance secreted in the follicles that provides clues to your ovarian reserve. One study that tried to look at the impact of alcohol consumption on AMH levels focused specifically on a population has been under-represented in fertility research: African-American women. In this paper, an association was found between regular binge drinking and lower anti-Müllerian hormone levels. Women who reported binge drinking twice weekly or more had 26% lower AMH levels compared with non-binge drinkers. Alcohol consumption that brings your blood alcohol concentration to .08 grams per deciliter is considered binge drinking—for women, that’s typically 4 drinks or more in two hours. (One drink is 12 ounces of beer, 5 ounces of wine, or 1.5 ounces of distilled spirits.)
Bottom line

: When it comes to drinking alcohol in moderation, different clinics and doctors make different recommendations. Some maintain that there’s no evidence that drinking affects a woman’s egg freezing success rates so they don’t see a need to suggest abstaining before or during an egg freezing cycle. Others take a more conservative, “play-it-safe” approach and encourage patients to avoid alcohol during the ovarian stimulation and egg retrieval phases. If you have questions about what’s best for you, book an appointment with a Maven OB-GYN or fertility specialist.

title.en-US: "This rare egg freezing side effect landed me in the ER"

content.value: What you need to know about ovarian torsion.
When you’re making a decision to freeze your eggs, you want to be armed with all the facts—good and bad—right? As one woman who did the procedure told us,

“I don’t regret going through with it, but I wish I’d been better prepared for all the potential risks—no matter how small. Right after the retrieval, my stomach seemed excessively swollen. The nurse brushed off my concern, telling me it was normal, and suggested I call if things got worse. A few days later, I looked five months pregnant, and felt so physically uncomfortable I had to leave work. Soon, the discomfort turned to sharp pains. Instead of calling my doctor, I headed to the ER and learned I had ovarian torsion—something I hadn’t even heard about until it happened to me.”
What, exactly, is ovarian torsion?
Medications given to stimulate the ovaries cause them to grow in size, and the larger the ovaries are, the greater chance they have of twisting. Doctors call this ovarian torsion.
Why is a twisted ovary such a big deal?
When torsion occurs, the ovary cuts off its own blood supply—and that can cause the ovary to die.
How is ovarian torsion treated?
In some cases, the ovary “untwists” by itself. If it doesn’t, immediate surgical intervention is required to flip the ovary back to its normal position.
What are the symptoms?

Severe, sudden pain in the lower abdomen is often a big clue. Cramping, nausea, fever, and vomiting may also occur. If you experience any of these symptoms, call your doctor or get to the E.R. right away.

title.en-US: Your top questions about egg freezing risks, answered

content.value: We tackle a few common questions to help you know exactly what to expect. Read on for the answers.
Q: My friend felt seriously bloated while giving herself the shots. Is that normal?

Yes, but not everyone reacts the same way. Each woman receives a different cocktail of drugs to stimulate her ovaries to produce multiple eggs. So the hormonal side-effects may depend on the medication type—and dosage—in your protocol. The most common symptoms are bloating and other PMS-like symptoms (think headaches, mood swings, tiredness, breast tenderness). Some people also notice soreness and even bruising around the injection site—aka where the needle enters the abdomen. (Check out
MavenRx
, Maven's partnership with leading fertility pharmacies offering you discounts on your medications, one-on-one support, and more.)
Q: Can anything more serious happen because of those injections?

It’s rare, but yes. When ovaries over-respond to the medication, they can swell up and leak fluid. The technical term for this is ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS). In fact, this risk is one reason you’re so closely monitored during the ovarian stimulation process; your doctor is making sure you’re safely responding to the meds. When OHSS does happen, it’s usually mild—abdominal swelling, bloating, and possibly nausea—and goes away on in its own.

But when moderate and severe cases of OHSS occur, these symptoms are worse, and can also include pain, vomiting, dehydration, difficulty breathing (thanks to fluid building up in the chest), and even life-threatening blood clots. Alert your doctor right away if you suspect something is wrong so you can get the care you need.
Q: Will there be bleeding during the retrieval of the eggs?

It’s a fair question, given the fact that your doctor will use an ultrasound probe with a needle attached to it go through the vagina and get to the follicles (the fluid-filled sacs where eggs are contained). Bleeding can happen, but it’s a rare complication. In fact, one study of several hundred thousand egg retrieval surgeries found that vaginal bleeding occurred in only 0.07% of procedures.
One last thing

: While most people agree that the risks involved in egg freezing are relatively small, some experts think it’s important to remind any woman who undergoes ovarian stimulation that long-term health risks aren’t fully known yet. If you have questions you want to talk through, book a video chat with a Maven fertility specialist; they’re always available to give you the straight talk and peace of mind that you deserve.

title.en-US: Maven's guide to working parenthood

content.value: If you’re having a baby, you can count on changes happening—and it makes a big difference if you’re prepared for them. Maven practitioners developed a program to help moms-to-be prep for the joys and challenges of working motherhood. We’re sharing it with you so you’ll be able to navigate these next nine months (and beyond) together as a duo. Each week, you'll be guided through essential topics, from ways to help your partner avoid unnecessary interventions during labor to how to find the best childcare option. With Maven by your side, you'll feel empowered to take what lies ahead, head-on.

title.en-US: Maven's guide to egg freezing

content.value: More women are freezing their eggs today, but as buzz about the procedure's popularity has gotten louder, honest talk about what the process entails isn’t heard enough. How do you know if you’re a good candidate? What are the real risks, lifestyle changes, and costs? You’ll find answers to essential questions in this guide: Each week, Maven practitioners—reproductive endocrinologists, OB-GYNs, and more—share insights, as well as stories of preserving their own fertility in Egg Freezing Real Talks. With their guidance, you'll be empowered from your first clinic appointment to your last.

title.en-US: Fertility 101: Your egg freezing prep

content.value: To get the most out of your consultation with an egg freezing clinic and those initial appointments before you move forward, use this guide from Maven reproductive endocrinologists Dr. Scott Morin and Dr. Sam Najmabadi.
How to Prepare for Your Egg Freezing Consultation
1. Do some math.

Even in an increasingly competitive market, a single round of egg freezing could tally anywhere between $5,000 to $11,000, plus the cost of medications, which can add another few thousand dollars to the bill, and annual storage fees. (Check out
MavenRx

, Maven's partnership with leading fertility pharmacies offering you discounts on your medications, one-on-one support, and more.) Most patients have to pay out of pocket, but it’s still worth calling your health insurance provider to ask about your coverage. Some plans, for instance, cover the fertility consultations and diagnostic tests, even if they don’t foot the bill for the actual procedure. Before your appointment, try to grasp the financial facts, then do some soul (and bank-account) searching to decide what it would mean for you to make this investment.
2. Gather the results of your last OB-GYN appointment.

Before you can freeze your eggs, you’ll be required to get certain tests—such as a pap smear, a TSH blood test (thyroid stimulating hormone), a CBC (complete blood count), and screenings for sexually transmitted infections. If you’ve already done these tests with your doctor or another fertility specialist, bring the results with you. (You may not have to repeat them.)
3. Talk to your OB-GYN or a Maven provider about getting off birth control.

“Most IUDs don’t need to be removed prior to egg freezing, but other types of birth control, such as oral contraceptive pills and long-lasting birth control injections such as Depo-Provera, do need to be halted,” notes Dr. Morin.
4. If you’ve been playing around with those online egg freezing calculators, try not to put too much stock in them.

These predictive tools attempt to forecast your chance of having a baby if you freeze your eggs. “They’ve taken a lot of data to come up with an algorithm. Sometimes I use them to adjust expectations when patients come in thinking they have an 80% chance of success, but I know their odds are closer to 30%,” says Dr. Najmabadi. That said, Dr. Morin and Dr. Najmabadi both agree that while these calculators can sometimes be a good way to get a general sense of your odds based on your age, they definitely don’t tell the whole story. “There are other factors that don’t get captured, and the calculators should only start the conversation,” cautions Dr. Morin.
What’s All This Talk About Ovarian Reserve Testing?

Reproductive Health 101: You were born with a set number of eggs in your ovaries, and this number decreases naturally as you get older (especially after 35). Your clinic will check the status of your current supply, or your ovarian reserve. What if your doctor tells you that you have a “low ovarian reserve”? This is simply an indication that your eggs are lower in quantity or quality than what’s typical for your age. Here are the ovarian reserve tests you should know about, which can help doctors understand if you’re a good candidate for egg freezing, as well as how much medication you may require to stimulate the ovaries.
1. The Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) Test

This blood test gives your doctor a general sense of the quantity of eggs that you have. It works by looking for AMH, a hormone which is secreted by your follicles—the little sacs on your ovaries that have the potential to release eggs when stimulated. Higher follicle counts correlate with higher AMH levels. According to Dr. Najmabadi, AMH values over 1.5 ng/ml typically indicate that a woman is a good candidate for egg freezing, but women with lower values may also respond well with higher doses of medication—so don’t panic if your AMH is low. It’s also important to keep in mind that AMH levels decline as women age, which means that an AMH level that’s considered normal for a woman at 40 could signal a low ovarian reserve for a 32-year-old woman. (Most women over 40 years of age will have an AMH level that is less than 1.0.)
2. The Follicle-Stimulating (FSH) Test

This blood test (usually taken a couple of days after your period begins) measures how much FSH the brain needs to secrete in order to stimulate the ovaries to release eggs. While the FSH test is considered less reliable than the AMH test, in general high FSH levels correlate with lower egg count: “If the brain has to shout to get the ovaries to do their job, it means the ovaries aren’t working as well as they used to,” says Dr. Morin. During an egg freezing cycle, a synthetic version of the hormone FSH is injected to stimulate your ovaries. But if your ovaries aren’t responding to your natural FSH, they may also be unlikely to respond to these shots. Women with FSH values under 10 are typically considered good candidates for egg freezing, but there can be a range of normal (so don’t jump to conclusions if your FSH is a bit higher).
3. The Antral Follicle Count Test

This test involves your doctor or an ultrasound technician inserting a device into your vagina to count the number of follicles that can be seen on your ovaries. When an average to high number of follicles appear on the ultrasound, that’s a sign that your doctor may be able to retrieve a good number of eggs with hormone stimulation. “I like to see at least six follicles on each side, for a total of 12,” says Dr. Morin, though he notes that women with fewer follicles may still respond well to medication. PS: Follicle counting isn’t a precise science: The number can fluctuate from one cycle to the next—and birth control pills can also decrease the counts. Frustratingly, the outcome may also depend on the lab tech; a less experienced technician may only be able to spot 7 or 8, while someone else could find 9 or 10.
Bottom line
: There’s no one perfect ovarian reserve test, but the results of all three can provide valuable insights about your situation.
3 Essential Question to Ask Your Doctor Before Freezing Your Eggs

After all your anticipation to discuss the results of your fertility workup, you’re finally face-to-face with your doctor. But suddenly your mind goes blank, and you can’t you think of the right things to ask. To make things easier, use this list of questions—and jot down anything else you’re curious about before you walk into your clinic.
1. Are there any risks I should be aware of, given my personal health history?

“Egg freezing is generally low-risk. Very few conditions would be a contraindication,” says Dr. Morin. That said, the procedure does present certain risks for some patients, including those with bleeding disorders and severe asthma. Be sure to ask your specialist if you’re a good candidate based on your overall health.
2. How many eggs are we aiming to retrieve, and how many cycles do you think I’ll need to do?

“There’s no magic number of eggs all women should freeze to ensure a successful pregnancy,” says Dr. Najmabadi. The range you should shoot for will depend the results of your fertility workup and your age. “Since older patients tend to have lower quality eggs, a younger patient whose tests indicate a lower ovarian reserve may have the same odds of achieving a live birth with a certain number of frozen eggs than an older patient whose tests show a higher ovarian reserve,” says Dr. Morin. Make sure your doctor explains what the results of your fertility workup, including ovarian reserve testing, mean for your goals and treatment plan.
3. How much should I expect to pay?

Make sure you understand exactly what’s included in your clinic’s quoted fee, and the factors that may affect your total bill. “If your ovarian reserve is lower, you’ll need more drugs to get results. So if you’re older or have significant fertility issues, you may end up paying a lot more than a younger patient with a better fertility profile,” says Dr. Najmabadi. Once you have clarity on what it will cost you, you’ll be in a better position to decide if egg freezing is too pricey or if doing it will give you a priceless peace of mind.

title.en-US: Egg freezing after a separation

content.value: Real Talk on Egg Freezing with Maven OB-GYN Monica Lee
"Everybody should do it, if they can afford it. You can quote me on that. The earlier, the better."
Name:
Monica Lee
Age:
Q: Why did you decide to freeze your eggs?

I was 37 years old and newly separated. I thought about egg freezing for a long time before the separation because, as with all marriages, once they're on the rocks, you start to prepare for the future. I had one child (at 34), and I'd always wanted two. I knew that after 38, infertility rates were higher, and my chances of getting pregnant would be lower—I’d seen that in my practice. I thought it was important to have an insurance policy for the future in case I ever wanted to have more children, or if my next partner wanted to have children.
Q: Can you tell me a little more about the feelings you had as you made this decision?

For me it was just a practical solution—a risk-versus-benefit decision. It was one of the less complicated decisions for me to make. It’s very matter-of-fact when you're around fertility treatments every day, all day. Especially in Beverly Hills, where I practiced, where people are freezing their eggs and getting fertility treatments left and right. So there weren’t a lot of feelings involved, I guess, considering the divorce. It was just about having choices. My attitude is to always keep doors open and make sure opportunities are available. That's how I live my life: getting into the best school possible, getting the best grades, interviewing for multiple different jobs, staying healthy. Then you're preserving all your opportunities and your choices.

I will say that deciding to freeze my eggs made me feel empowered, because I was doing something to ensure my future when one part of my life was falling apart. That’s life—bad things will happen. Divorce, death of friends and family, losing a job: those are all horrible things. My way of getting through them is to keep moving and look to the future. So this was a way of envisioning my future and the good things that can come. It is a way of coping.
Q: Did you spend time researching clinics?

No, because I have a personal relationship with a reproductive endocrinologist, and he saw me right away. His clinic is five minutes from my house, so I didn't miss any work to get to my appointments. For me, that was very important.

The whole process happened quickly. We skipped the initial consult, where you sit down and discuss why you want to do this, what your chances are, and the whole process. As an OB-GYN, I knew the risks, I knew the benefits, I knew why I wanted to do it, I knew the costs involved. He basically said, "If you want to have another baby, you need to freeze at least 10 eggs." For most people who don't have kids he recommended 20 to get a live birth. But for me, because I already had one child and I wasn't sure if I was going to use the eggs in the future, he said that 10 would be good. And I did get 10 from that one cycle.
Q: Would you have gone on to do more cycles?

Maybe. I was going to see what the side effects were like. But honestly, I didn't have any of the bloating, mood changes, or anything that he warned me about. Yes, I was a little uncomfortable, but I don't remember anything else. I just didn't like self-injecting in the belly. But anybody who's motivated will do it. Insulin-dependent people self-inject all the time. You do what you need to do, and this is for a short amount of time—less than two weeks.
Q: That was nearly five years ago, and now you're 41. Do you think you will use the eggs?

I probably won't use the eggs. I don't feel an urge to have any more children right now, but it's nice to have had the back-up plan. I felt less pressured to find somebody, date and marry again to have another child. It made it not as scary to move forward knowing that your fertility is dwindling every second.
Q: How do you broach the topic with friends in a way that doesn't feel like you’re overstepping?

I have no problem with that. I'm a blunt person. I'm like, "You don't have a partner? Girl, you need to freeze your eggs." That's all I say. Or, "Oh, you guys broke up? You've really got to freeze your eggs. Let me tell you why." When friends reach their mid 30s, I say: "You've got a couple years to do this, do it now before you hit 38. After that, your odds of success will be a lot worse."

Everyone I've told to do this has been very thankful. In fact, I just got a phone call from a friend who said, "Monica, thank god you told me to do this." She just went through surgery for severe endometriosis, and has to undergo IVF. Her doctors have been telling her how lucky she is that she froze her eggs, and she wouldn’t have if I hadn’t suggested it.
Q: Have you recommended egg freezing to any of your patients?

Absolutely. By their mid-30s, if they're single and if it comes up that they want to have kids, I will bring it up at my job. Everybody should do it, if they can afford it. You can quote me on that. The earlier, the better. The earlier you do it, the better quality your eggs will be, and the more eggs you get per cycle.

title.en-US: The ins & outs of egg retrieval

content.value: What do you really go through in order to get your eggs out of your ovaries and into the freezer? Here, Maven practitioners tell you exactly what you can expect—everything from how you may need to adjust your work schedule to what the procedure actually feels like (no sugar-coating!).
First, let’s talk birth control.
Some clinics put women on a short birth control regimen prior to beginning their egg freezing protocol. “This is to help synchronize follicles

and suppress cysts,” explains Dr. Sam Najmabadi, a Maven reproductive endocrinologist. Besides getting follicles in sync so they grow at the same rate, birth control can also manipulate when your cycle starts and aid with overall scheduling.
Next come the shots, AKA ovarian stimulation.

This is the phase that includes daily shots that you’ll inject in your belly for roughly 10 to 12 days; the goal is to get your ovaries to produce enough eggs to collect. During this time, you’ll visit your clinic for monitoring every 1-3 days so your doctor can see—via blood work and transvaginal ultrasound—how your ovaries are responding. The exact drugs you’ll take will depend on your unique situation, but here’s the lowdown on what you might be picking up at the pharmacy:
Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)

FSH is a hormone released by the pituitary gland, and its job is to stimulate the growth of follicles before one egg gets released during normal ovulation. Well, in an egg freezing cycle, you’ll take a synthetic form of FSH, usually starting on day two or three of your period, to encourage your ovaries to produce multiple eggs. In some patients, a combination of FSH and luteinizing hormone (LH) may be used. FSH and LH can be prescribed as once or twice a day injections, and are usually taken for about 8-11 days.
Antagonists

Depending on your body’s response to FSH, your doctor may use an “antagonist” medication halfway through your cycle to prevent your ovaries from releasing eggs too early. Antagonist medications consist of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), which works to halt the release of FSH and LH. Antagonists are typically injected daily for a few days leading up to the trigger shot.
Trigger shot

Once your eggs have reached an optimal level of maturation, you’ll be given a final injection to encourage your ovaries to release the eggs. This trigger shot is usually a synthetic form of hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin), the same hormone produced by your body during pregnancy. Women who are at risk for Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS), a potentially-serious condition where the ovaries become swollen as a result of excess hormones, may receive an injection of a drug called Lupron instead of hCG. (Why doesn’t everyone get a Lupron trigger shot? While it reduces the chance of OHSS, it can also lead to fewer eggs retrieved and hamper the egg maturation process. So experts advise only taking it when needed.)
Finally, you’re ready for retrieval.

Roughly 36 hours after the trigger shot, the actual egg retrieval—a procedure that usually takes 10-15 minutes—will take place. Dr. Scott Morin, a Maven reproductive endocrinologist, explains the process: Doctors use an ultrasound probe that’s inserted into the vagina to see the ​ovaries and locate the follicles. Then a needle attached to the ultrasound probe punctures the follicles and gentle suction is used to remove the egg-contained fluid from within. You’ll likely be under light sedation while this is happening. “We use short-acting drugs that are in and out of your system in a few hours,” says Dr. Najmabadi. That said, you may feel groggy afterwards, and clinics require that a friend or designated driver takes you home.
Your top egg freezing questions, answered

Now that you know what the process entails, you probably wondering what it actually feels like, what lifestyle changes you might need (or want) to make, and any risks to be aware of during and after the procedure. Keep reading, as Maven practitioners give honest answers to your most-asked questions.
Q: I exercise every day—why do I need to put my workouts on pause?

When the ovaries are being stimulated and more eggs are inside them, they grow physically bigger. An enlarged ovary is at a greater risk of “torsion," in which it can twist on itself and require surgery to correct. The odds of this happening are extremely low, but since it can be very serious, you may be asked to curb your workouts for a bit. While you should check with your doctor first, “you can usually do light exercise until a few days before your egg retrieval and resume a few days after. Just don’t jog or do any boot camp classes,” says Dr. Morin. “We help our patients find other options such as walking or riding a bike, activities that can help them cope and get through this process without increasing the risk of their ovaries twisting,” adds Dr. Jonathan Kort, a Maven reproductive endocrinologist.
Q: What do I need to know about Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS)?

OHSS is a condition where the ovaries become painful and swollen as a result of excess hormones. Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain could ensue, but these symptoms are usually mild and last no more than a week. Severe OHSS, on the other hand, affects less than 1% of egg freezing patients, but can be life threatening and is characterized by rapid weight gain, severe abdominal pain, shortness of breath, and blood clots. Your doctor will try to determine your risk of OHSS before starting you on the shots and tailor your medication protocol appropriately; women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), for instance, have a higher risk. Dr. Kort also asks questions like these: “Do you get migraines at certain times of your menstrual cycle? Have you been sensitive to birth control pills in the past?” Patients’ responses to these questions can provide clues about their sensitivity to hormones.
Q: Do I have to avoid alcohol?

Since OHSS is associated with dehydration, some doctors recommend limiting alcohol consumption while you’re taking fertility hormones. “Light drinking—say, a glass of wine with dinner—shouldn’t be a problem,” says Dr. Morin.
Q: Can I have sex during my egg freezing cycle?

Sex during the ovarian stimulation phase cycle and in the first few days after the retrieval is typically not recommended. With the ovaries is overdrive, you’re hyper-fertile, so having sex can put you at risk of conceiving multiples. And the truth is, sex can be uncomfortable due to your enlarged ovaries, so you’ll probably want to avoid it.
Q: What can I do if I’m afraid of the shots?

It might put your mind at ease to know that the injections are subcutaneous—the needle goes in the layer of fat just under the skin, and it’s the same small needle that diabetics use to give themselves insulin, explains Dr. Kort. “At our clinic, we have fake skin that the patients learn on, and after sitting with the nurse for a 30-minute training session, the patient usually feels much more comfortable with the injection process.” You can also enlist a friend’s help, or ask if you can visit the clinic daily for the nurse to give them to you.
Q: Is there any way I can avoid all the probing down there?

“Sometimes people are surprised that we use transvaginal ultrasounds instead of abdominal ultrasounds," says Dr. Kort, adding: “I wish there was another way we could monitor the ovaries so closely.” Most women only experience slight discomfort, but if you have vaginismus—when the pelvic floor muscles tighten uncontrollably in response to penetration—it can be very uncomfortable. Dr. Kort says there are strategies he uses to help patients who have this condition, such as letting them place the ultrasound themselves, and referring them to a pelvic floor physical therapist (PT).
Q: I’ve never had surgery before; what surgical risks should I be aware of?

Egg freezing, like any surgical procedure, however minor, carries a small risk of bleeding, infection, and damage to the organs around the surgery; and anesthesia always carries a low level of risk. “Those risks are not zero with egg retrieval,” says Dr. Kort, “but they're very close to zero, far less than one percent. If someone tells you that there's zero risk, that's not honest.”

title.en-US: What it's like to do 3 rounds of egg freezing

content.value: Real Talk on Egg Freezing with Maven OB-GYN Colleen Denny
"Expectation setting is incredibly important. It’s hard for providers to give you a sense of how many rounds you’ll have to do because there’s no way to know how many eggs you’ll get."
Name:
Colleen Denny
Age:
Q: When did you make the decision to freeze your eggs?

I was 33 and had finished my OB-GYN residency. I finally had a real job, and I wanted to enjoy being done with training for a while before having kids. I didn’t know exactly when I might want to; I just had the sense that by the time I would be ready to start trying, I would be in my late 30’s, when fertility tends to decline the most sharply. In my practice I would see women who were 37 or 38 and having a surprisingly hard time getting pregnant. I’m a risk-averse person, and knew there was the small yet important risk that I could be that person who is 37 and having trouble getting pregnant, or 42 and without a partner. That weighed on me a ton, and those small risks were real to me in a way they’re not for everybody. Given all this, I knew that even if I never used the eggs, I would never regret the money or time spent for peace of mind.
Q: Did you have a partner at the time? If so, did you discuss it with him?

Yes, I lived with my partner, and we had been together for about 2.5 years. I had been thinking about egg freezing since before I met him, when I first started my residency. He was supportive from the start, and came with me to an initial consultation to talk about freezing embryos instead of eggs because there’s a better chance they’ll survive and lead to successful pregnancies. Before freezing embryos with someone, you kind of have to decide how much you really like each other. And it can be a weird thing to talk about, especially when neither one of you is ready to have kids at the time. Then you learn you have to sign all this paperwork about what happens if you break up down the line.
In the end, I decided to just freeze my eggs, and it was a very independent process. I paid for it; I gave myself all the injections.
Q: What surprised you most about going through the process of freezing your eggs?

I was surprised by how upset and sad I was when I only got six eggs in my first round. I was told I would likely get around 15 or 20 eggs, based on my age and my fertility workup. (It’s important to remember that 20 eggs does not mean 20 babies: Not all eggs freeze; of the ones that do, not all thaw normally; some may have genetic problems.) I thought that it would take one cycle and I’d be done. But that wasn’t the case. I had spent so much time and money, and it all felt like a waste. And I had all these irrational thoughts, like, “Maybe there’s something wrong with me and I’m never going to have kids”—even though I know that a small number of frozen eggs for a healthy young person doesn't necessarily mean anything about the possibility of a spontaneous pregnancy. But I regrouped and decided not to give up just because it was expensive. I found a new clinic, and I got 12 eggs on my second try. Finally, I did a third round and got 11 more eggs, so now I have a total of 29 in storage.
Q: What made you go for the third round, if you already had 18 eggs?

As I mentioned before, I tend to be a little more risk averse than most people, and I had a good experience the second time. I also knew that if I had 30 eggs, then my odds of having two kids would go up, and that was worth it to me. Most of the statistics say it takes 8 to 12 eggs for one baby, but I know I’d like to have more than one. I was able to afford it and I had the time to do a third cycle, so that’s what I did.
Q: What made the second clinic better?

The first place was relatively expensive. It was a full fertility clinic, so working with the staff was not nearly as easy, because they deal with a lot of patients coming in for different medical reasons. They were hard to communicate with, and when they called with my results, an administrative staffer told me they had frozen six embryos instead of eggs, even though that wasn’t the case. I decided to switch to a boutique egg freezing clinic where that’s all they do, and it cost about $5,000 less. It was more streamlined. They were accessible via email and phone, and the monitoring appointments in the morning were always pretty fast. So those are the benefits of going to a small clinic that only does egg freezing. Some even have guarantees, so if you don’t get a certain number of eggs, they’ll do the next round for free. You still have to pay for the medication, but if they offer such a deal, they’ll cover the monitoring, labs, and anesthesia during the second retrieval.
Q: What was the grand total you spend on egg freezing?

The first round was $14,000 total, including medication and anesthesia, and the second and third rounds were $9,000 each. Yes, that’s $32,000, which I recognize is a lot. When I went through these procedures, I had disposable income for the first time in my life, and this seemed like a very reasonable way to spend it.
Q: How did the experience impact you emotionally?

It was more stressful than I thought it would be. You’re in a routine of getting up early for monitoring and making doctor’s appointments. And there’s so much unpredictability, which makes the stress worse. It’s hard not to feel like so much of your female identity is based on how many eggs you get and how healthy they are. And the hormone medication can affect your emotional state. It didn’t make a huge difference in me, but it was noticeable in small ways. I remember crying at the end of a sappy movie and thinking to myself, “Why am I crying? Is it because of the shots?”
Q: Was there any aspect of freezing your eggs that you wish you’d had more guidance about going into it?

The medicines were surprisingly expensive and tricky. When clinics quote the cost of egg freezing, they sometimes don’t include the medicine, which can add an extra $4,000 or $5,000. A lot of women end up with extra shots because pharmacies will usually give a discount if you buy a box, but you never know if you’ll use them all. So it’s a crazy balancing act of trying not to buy more than you need and minimizing the number of times you have to go to the pharmacy. The first two rounds, I had extras I had to discard. The last round I was pretty savvy about it, and don’t think I had any left over.
Q: Did you have people in your life you could talk to while you were going through the process of freezing your eggs?

My partner at the time was really supportive. I also talked to my brother and sister-in-law, who froze embryos, and other OB-GYNs at work. A friend went through it after I did, and I tried to support her in turn. It’s important to have someone who can normalize it for you. Like, “Yes, that weird pelvic pain you have after the procedure? I had that too, and it gets better in a few days.” I didn’t tell my extended family. I didn’t want to get questions about when I was going to have kids, so I chose not to talk about it.
Q: What advice would you give a patient or friend who is thinking about freezing her eggs?

I would tell her to make sure this is something that makes sense for her. It might not be for women who wants to start trying for a baby before 35—unless they have a medical reason that could cause problems conceiving. For people who think they won’t start their families until after 35 or 36, it becomes a question of finances and risk aversion. In the end, it’s mostly about the money. 
I also would tell a friend going into this that expectation setting is incredibly important. It’s hard for providers to give you a sense of how many rounds you’ll have to do because there’s no way to know how many eggs you’ll get. All patients are a little different. Sometimes the doctors get the ovarian stimulation protocol right on the first try, but other times they don’t. They can add or change a medication the next cycle and a patient can have completely different results, like I did.
Q: As an OB-GYN, is egg freezing something you proactively discuss with patients?

For patients who have cancer at a young age and are expecting to undergo chemotherapy, 
I will discuss egg freezing, especially if they want the option of having children in the future. But it’s not something I would bring up in a standard exam. The likelihood of a 32-year-old who doesn’t have kids benefiting from egg freezing is pretty low. And, honestly, not too many people have 10K just sitting around, so I don’t want to create medical or financial stress for my patients if there’s no reason for it. On the other hand, you don’t want patients to say, “I wish I knew about this.” So if they ask, I’ll say that it’s better to do it when they’re young, especially if they don’t have the time or inclination to start having kids for a while. I never share my personal story with patients because I try not to influence them with my personal decision.
Q: Have you thought about what you’ll do with the eggs if you don’t use them?

I couldn’t donate them to a bank because the eggs aren’t young enough for that, but I have a fairly large family and if someone I knew was having trouble that would be my first priority. Otherwise I would donate them to research.
Q: And if you don’t find a partner, would you consider having a child alone?

I think I would try alone, if I couldn’t find the right person and got to a place where I was ready. I’m lucky to have lived in San Francisco, where I was exposed to so many different family structures. I had friends and colleagues raising kids by themselves, and I met one woman who found a sperm donor on OK Cupid and has a son by that guy and is super happy. It was refreshing to see all the ways that people can build a family.

title.en-US: Big freeze: Your eggs after retrieval

content.value: From your initial egg freezing consultation, you learn a lot about the injections, the monitoring, the retrieval and recovery. But an aspect of the process that’s often overlooked is the actual freezing and storage of your eggs. You probably know that things are a bit more complicated than simply sticking your eggs in a freezer. But what exactly is involved? And how can you be sure your eggs will be safe and protected until you might need to use them? To shed some light on all the considerations related to long-term storage—including the costs of keeping eggs on ice year after year—we turned to two top reproductive endocrinologists and Maven practitioners, Dr. Jonathan Kort and Dr. Sam Najmabadi.
Q: What does my doctor do with my eggs right after they’re retrieved?

Once your doctor collects your eggs, the go right into an incubator for the embryologist to inspect. The vast majority of clinics have in-house labs, so eggs are simply transferred from the operating room where you have your procedure to the laboratory. There, the embryologist strips eggs of the surrounding cells in order to observe each egg closely and identity which eggs are mature. This step is crucial since only mature eggs have the potential to be fertilized. Usually, out of the eggs retrieved, anywhere from 20 to 40% aren’t fully mature and won’t be frozen.
Q: Once the mature eggs are identified, how are they frozen?

Cryopreservation (that’s the technical term for egg freezing) has made huge strides in the past decade, since the introduction of vitrification. Dr. Najmabadi describes it as a “fast freeze,” and it’s the gold-standard in every reputable egg freezing clinic today. Eggs are tricky to freeze because they’re water-filled cells, and the previous method of slow-cooling made it possible for ice crystals to form. This would frequently damage the cells and rupture them, says Dr. Najmabadi. With vitrification, however, eggs are first treated with high concentrations of cryoprotectants (aka anti-icing chemicals), then rapidly chilled by being plunged into liquid nitrogen. The result is that they’re much less vulnerable to damage.
Q: How much does storage cost?

There’s a big range, with annual fees as low as $300 or as high as $1,100 or more. Note that prices aren’t based on the amount of eggs you’re banking, so how could they vary so wildly from one clinic to the next? Dr. Kort says that market dynamics play a big role, so where you live could dictate how steep your annual storage bill is. New York City, for instance, is one of the priciest cities to store your eggs, with a price-tag of $1,100 per year, on average. If you live in San Francisco, on the other hand, an annual storage fee could be less than half of that amount. “It’s strange that there is such variation,” says Dr. Kort. “I think part of it is just the competitive landscape in places like San Francisco.” After all, while egg freezing is on the rise everywhere, Silicon Valley has been thought of as a “hub” for the growing trend. You can always ask your clinic about ways to bring down costs; some offer financing plans where you get a deal if you prepay for a year or more instead of making monthly payments.
Q: Can I transfer my eggs to a new storage facility if I move out of state?

Yes. You’re not tied to one place for your entire life just because your eggs were frozen there. Note that the Federal Aviation Administration doesn’t allow liquid nitrogen to be shipped (because of potential explosions). Instead, the eggs are transported in a special container called a dry shipper, which keeps the contents sufficiently chilled while in transit. Some clinics handle the shipping logistics themselves, but if yours doesn’t, you can contact a company such as Cryoport to make arrangements.
Q: How long are frozen eggs good for?

In some countries, the length of time eggs can be frozen is limited by law. (In the U.K., for instance there is a 10-year limit, a law that fertility experts are trying to change, saying that the rule doesn’t take into account technological advances that now allow eggs to be frozen, probably indefinitely, without being compromised.) In the U.S., there is no such law. Both Dr. Kort and Dr. Najmabadi say that eggs do not change over time. “When you thaw an egg that was frozen using vitrification, that egg doesn’t know whether it’s been frozen a second, or a year, or ten years,” says Dr. Najmabadi. One caveat: Because the technology is so new, there isn’t a lot of data. But we do know that healthy babies have been born from eggs that have been frozen longer than 10 years. In 2017, one healthy baby was born from an egg that was frozen for 24 years!
Q: What happens when I am ready to thaw and use my eggs to have a baby?

As you probably assumed, the process is a bit different than taking something out of your kitchen freezer and letting it warm up. “You use a rate of thawing that is optimized for the rate at which the eggs were frozen,” says Dr. Kort. Essentially, lab techs move eggs through a number of steps that warm them up and strip the cryoprotectants that were added when they were frozen. After the right temperature is reached, an egg can be fertilized with sperm in a lab using a form of IVF called intracytoplasmic sperm injection, or ICSI. The Cliff Notes version of what happens if all goes well: Once an egg is fertilized, an embryo grows in a lab for about 5 days, implanted in the womb, and pregnancy occurs.
Q: Do frozen eggs have an increased chance of birth defects?

You’re probably tired of hearing the answer, “there isn’t a lot of data,” but it’s the only honest response to many questions about egg freezing at this point. The technology is still relatively new, so there aren’t decades and decades worth of large studies to draw from. The good news is that based on the limited research we do have, things look very reassuring. One 2009 study looked at 936 children who were conceived from previously frozen eggs, and found that, “compared with birth defects occurring in naturally conceived infants, no difference was noted.” It’s also worth mentioning that in 2012, when the the American Society of Reproductive Medicine declared that egg freezing was no longer “experimental,” the data they drew from led the society to believe that the technique is safe—and results in healthy children.
Q: I’m concerned about the safety of egg freezing storing facilities. Should I be?

It’s understandable, given the news headlines that reported mishaps at egg freezing clinics in 2018. These instances are rare, and any clinic worth using has an ironclad system of safeguards in place. “And your doctor should know how the system is monitored and take the time to explain it to you,” says Dr. Kort. Here are a few questions you can ask:
Has your facility had any issues in the past?
Can you explain your clinic’s safeguards that keep the eggs secure?
Does the equipment have independent alarm sensors? Who is alerted when the alarm goes off?
How frequently are the nitrogen tanks checked?
“It should raise a red flag if your clinic doesn’t know the answers,” adds Dr. Kort.
Q: What happens to eggs that I don’t end up using?

Frozen eggs, both Dr. Kort and Dr. Najmabadi agree, do not present the same ethical quandaries to most women as frozen embryos might. But if you’re not comfortable with remaining eggs being discarded, one option is to donate them to research. While you can donate your eggs to a specific person, like someone you know who is doing IVF, you can’t sell them to a bank. That’s because egg donation is highly regulated by the FDA and there are separate screenings you would have to go through (before freezing your eggs) in order to be cleared. If you want to talk through the best options for you, book a video chat with a Maven reproductive endocrinologist to discuss a plan for the future that best puts your mind at ease.

title.en-US: Real deal on pregnancy with frozen eggs

content.value: The point of egg freezing isn't to absolutely use your eggs—it's to have that option in case you need to turn to it. But surprisingly, there’s very little discussion about what happens when women do try to use their eggs and go through fertility treatment later. We sat down with Maven reproductive endocrinologists Dr. Scott Morin and Dr. Sam Najmabadi to learn about what you can expect, and any advances in egg freezing that could be a game-changer down the line.
What Happens When You’re Ready to Use Your Frozen Eggs?

If and when you decide to try having a baby with your frozen eggs, they’ll first need to be removed from storage and thawed. Sperm will be collected from your partner (or a donor) and used to fertilize your eggs. When using eggs that have been previously frozen, Intracytoplasmic Sperm Injection (ICSI) is the recommended form of In Vitro Fertilization (IVF). With this method, sperm gets injected directly into the egg—making it easier to penetrate the egg’s membrane that tends to harden during freezing. If fertilization occurs, a fertilized egg will develop into an embryo, which will be allowed to grow for about 5 days (at this point it’s called a blastocyst) in a lab before it’s transferred to your uterus—the first step in a successful pregnancy. It sounds simple enough to take a frozen egg and end up with a baby in your arms nine months later, but how likely it is that every step in this process is foolproof? Here are a few things to keep in mind:
1. Expect to lose some eggs at every step.

“About 90% of eggs survive the thawing process. Of those, 60-90% will be successfully fertilized. After that, we usually see about a 20% drop-off per day as the fertilized egg develops into a blastocyst,” says Dr. Najmabadi. “We usually tell patients to expect about 20% of frozen eggs to result in an embryo.” Of course, these stats will vary wildly based on every individual’s situation, and may differ by clinic, but the point is to be aware that every egg you have on ice doesn’t have a 100% chance of leading to a baby. In one study of 1,500 women who froze their eggs at age 35 or younger, the chance of live birth increased from 15% for women who froze just 5 eggs, to 61% for women who froze 10 eggs, and 85% for women who froze 15 or more eggs.
2. The younger you were when you froze your eggs, the more likely they are to result in a successful pregnancy.

Egg quality declines with age, so “the percentage of eggs that survive at every stage of the process will be higher for younger eggs,” says Dr. Najmabadi. “And embryos from younger eggs are more likely to lead to viable pregnancies.” Some data suggests that women who freeze 10 eggs at age 36 have anywhere from a 30 to 60% chance of having a baby with them. Those odds go up for younger women, but fall considerably with age.
3. You can do genetic testing on your embryos before implantation, but not on the eggs you freeze.

There are screenings available to help determine which embryos are chromosomally normal (and most likely to result in a healthy pregnancy and baby), but this testing is only available for embryos—it’s not performed on unfertilized eggs.
4. Eggs can be frozen in time, but bodies can’t be.

Eggs are the same quality after being frozen for some time as they are if they’re fresh when used in an IVF cycle. “Success rates depend on how old you were when you froze your eggs, not how long you waited to use them,” says Dr. Najmabadi. (Embryo implantation and pregnancy rates do not differ between IVF cycles using frozen eggs versus those using fresh eggs.) That said, as a woman gets older, her body (not her eggs) can put her at an increased risk for certain pregnancy and delivery complications. Since every woman is different, and may have unique personal risk factors, it’s a good idea to talk to an OB-GYN about a healthy age for you to be carrying a pregnancy.
The Future of Egg Freezing & IVF
So how might egg freezing (and fertility treatment) change in the years to come? Here are some predictions from Maven practitioners that you may want to know about now.
1. Egg freezing will become more affordable.

“The most important change that’s going to happen in the next several years is that egg freezing will become cheaper and more people will have access to it,” says Dr. Morin. “You’re already starting to see this with a crop of lower-cost clinics popping up in urban centers like New York. Like all technologies that are initially novel and expensive, the price of egg freezing will come down as it becomes more prevalent and the clinics start competing on cost.” There’s also a growing trend towards insurance and employer coverage, with companies like Facebook, Apple, Google, Uber, and Yahoo offering fertility preservation as a perk in employee benefit packages.
2. More data will help women make better decisions about their reproductive future.

Figuring out the likelihood of your frozen eggs leading to a viable pregnancy later on may be one of the most frustrating aspects of your egg freezing journey. One reason why these predictions are difficult is that egg freezing data is limited: At this point, there simply isn’t a large cohort of women who’ve gone back to use their frozen eggs. One study of more than 1,400 women in Spain, for example, has already led to some helpful conclusions: “We saw a marked dip in live birth rates among women using eggs frozen when they were 36 or older compared to younger women—23% versus 50%,” notes Dr. Morin. “It’s the best data we have right now for patients to figure out, okay, if I freeze this many eggs when I’m this age, this is my chance of actually getting pregnant using those eggs.” But as egg freezing becomes more common, and as more women use their eggs to become pregnant, we’ll have more—and bigger—studies to draw from.
3. The patient experience will improve.

In some cities, egg freezing clinics are starting to look more like spas than doctor’s offices. “The fertility preservation patient is in a completely different headspace than the fertility patient, and the clinics are changing to reflect that,” says Dr. Morin. But improvements may go well beyond scented candles and waterfalls in the waiting rooms. For instance, researchers are testing a long-acting form of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) which could be given as just one weekly shot instead of the daily dose women typically self-inject when undergoing egg freezing. Other alternatives to ovarian hyperstimulation could also become more mainstream in the future. One procedure that already exists is In Vitro Maturation (IVM) (IVM), where eggs are collected from a woman before they are matured, meaning the retrieval can occur with little to no hormonal injections. So far, pregnancy success rates have been shown to be lower with IVM than when standard protocols are used prior to IVF, but but some experts think that the technology may improve down the line.
4. Advances in IVF may lead to better success rates.

It’s important to note that vast improvements in egg freezing and fertilization techniques over the past several years have already occurred, says Dr. Najmabadi. “The big changes happening now are related to IVF—aka, what you need to do when it’s time to actually use the eggs. Everything is moving towards doing things less invasively, using fewer and better drugs, and with a greater likelihood of a successful pregnancy.” Advancements in the genetic screening of embryos are particularly promising, because embryos with certain abnormalities are less likely to result in viable pregnancies. So far, screening methods have relied on removing a few cells from an embryo so they can be biopsied—a procedure that is generally safe but, according to Dr. Najmabadi, can harm 3-5% of embryos. Scientists are currently keeping an eye on clinical outcomes using a newer technique that doesn’t rely on a biopsy. The hope is that patients will have a less-invasive—but accurate, efficient, and hopefully affordable—way to examine embryos before implantation in the future.

title.en-US: Why egg freezing was a priceless choice for one woman

content.value: Real Talk on Egg Freezing with Maven Career Coach Hana Ayoub
"I went for it well aware that egg freezing gives you hope, not a promise. I now think about it as the best gift I could have given my future self—a gift I hope I never use."
Name:
Hana Ayoub
Age:
Q: When did you first start thinking about freezing your eggs?

It came up in a coaching conversation with a client who worked for Google. She was debating leaving the company, and I asked her if there was anything she wanted to accomplish before she left. I was expecting her to list professional boxes she wanted to check, but she said she wanted to take advantage of the egg freezing coverage in her health benefits plan. I was 35 at the time, and it struck a chord.
Q: Were you talking about your fertility, or what you could do to preserve it, before this point?

No. I was aware that egg freezing was out there, but I had never thought about it for myself until then. I am proactive in every part of my life, so it’s crazy how passive I was in my reproductive health, and how easy it is to take action. Planning for the future was something completely within my control. About five months after that conversation with my client, I went through the retrieval process. It’s one of the best decisions I’ve ever made.
Q: What went into making your decision to move forward?

There were three main “buckets” I looked at. The first was cost. I had a really comprehensive benefits plan that I was hoping would cover it, but I turned out I had to pay out-of-pocket for the procedure. Despite that financial wrinkle, the decision was still a no-brainer for me. I realize that I’m in a privileged position, but I probably would have paid two times what I did. I think it’s worth every penny; I couldn’t put a price tag on the opportunity to possibly create a human life.

The second thing I considered was what the physical process would be like. I didn’t know if I could give myself shots because I can be squeamish; I can’t even look at my arm when I get blood drawn. I rarely take Advil for a hangover, and all of a sudden I’d be picking up a shopping bag full of medications I’m going to inject into my body. But I knew I could handle it, and in the end, the injections weren’t as bad as I expected them to be.

Lastly, I had to come to terms with the uncertainty of it all: not knowing what the results would be, and then having my eggs in some freezer, not knowing what would—or wouldn’t—become of them. That variable was the hardest for me.
Q: A lot of women struggle to make the decision based on this uncertainty—knowing that egg freezing is a gamble. How did you come to terms with it?

I thought, What is my alternative? Not do it and then wonder? I went for it well aware that egg freezing gives you hope, not a promise. I now think about it as the best gift I could have given my future self—a gift I hope I never use.
Q: How did you find your clinic?

I found it on the website of the hospital where my other doctors practice and made an appointment for a consultation. When I went in, the office felt like a factory, so I decided to look for a different clinic.

After talking to some friends who had experience with the process, I was connected to this woman who I refer to as my egg-freezing angel. She and her husband had a hard time conceiving, and were about to start treatment at the Colorado Center for Reproductive Medicine (CCRM), which had recently opened an outpost in New York City, where I live. She encouraged me to go, and soon as I walked in, I could tell it was going to be so different from the first clinic. The environment was warm and friendly, and I ended up with an amazing doctor who spent more than two hours on my first visit answering all of my questions.
Q: What were some of your biggest concerns?

One of my initial concerns was what would happen to any unused eggs when I die, and they advised me to include instructions in a living will if I wanted to do something other than what is standard, which is deciding between destroying them or donating them to research. Further into the process, I remember asking the doctor if I would get fat and crazy from the hormone shots, and if so, how fat and how crazy. I even looked at the calendar, and was like, When can I expect to fly off the handle because of the hormones? I totally thought that would happen, but—spoiler alert—it didn’t. I had just assumed the medications would affect me physically and emotionally, but I didn’t really have any reaction. The only physical reaction I had was after the retrieval, when I had cramps and bloating that felt like five times the pain of a normal period.The doctor had given me a heads-up, so it was no surprise. It lasted a few days, and I took some over-the-counter medication, which helped with the discomfort.
Q: Did you have to make any lifestyle changes during your egg freezing protocol?

My doctor told me to just live my life because he didn’t want me feeling any added any stress. Although he did say not to get drunk during the process! He also said not to have sex because it was too risky to potentially fertilize so many eggs—I actually remember him saying he didn't want me to become octomom!
Q: Did egg freezing affect how you approached dating?

I had actually been seeing someone casually while I was going through the egg freezing process. We had our third or fourth date the day after my retrieval, which is when I told him about what I had just gone through. He was great in terms of asking if I was feeling OK. But an hour later he turns to me and says, “Does this mean I should freeze my sperm?” And another hour goes by and he asks, “Can you conceive naturally even though you’ve done this?” He had good intentions, but I couldn’t help but think how little he knew. Since then, I’ve told guy friends of mine as a way to educate them, like, Here’s something you may not know about the female experience. I don't bring these things up because I'm an oversharer. I just think it's important. I’ve brought it up on dates when I feel like the topic of kids is being approached, even if I’m not directly asked. I’ll volunteer that I froze my eggs when I was 35, and that it left me with options but no guarantees.
Q: Did the doctor tell you the ideal number of eggs to freeze?

Not really. He did say that, statistically speaking, I’d need at least 10 eggs to have a decent chance of having a baby with them, but he never said I had to get to a certain number or push how many rounds I would need to do. It was more about giving me the information and letting me drive the decision-making regarding how many eggs I felt comfortable freezing. I ended up getting 15 mature eggs, which was more than they thought I would get based on the ultrasound before my retrieval. I might have more perspective in a few years, but that was enough to give me reasonable peace of mind.
Q: How much did egg freezing cost you?
All in, with shots and the retrieval, around $13,000. The medications alone were between $3,000 and $4,000. I charged everything to my credit card, and used money I had saved to pay it off.
Q: When friends come to you looking for advice about whether or not they should do it, what do you say?

I don’t necessarily say, “You should do this,” because I don’t think it’s for everyone. But when I do share, I try to push the door open a little because that’s exactly what led me to this process, and I’m grateful for it. Before I knew it, I was in the driver’s seat and taking action on something that, up until a few months prior, I didn’t even realize was something I should be thinking about.
Shortly before the retrieval, I went to see Bob Weir, a founding member of the Grateful Dead. I went alone, and I remember thinking,
This is so cool. There’s a piece of musical history happening right now, and I might have half of my future child inside of me as I’m witnessing it.
In that moment, I knew I was making the right decision.

title.en-US: How a breakup led this woman to freeze her eggs

content.value: Real Talk on Egg Freezing with Maven Registered Dietitian Rachel Harvest
"It feels empowering to have gone through the whole process to give myself more time."
Name:
Rachel Harvest
Age:
Q: How did you make the decision to freeze your eggs?

My previous roommate, who was a physician, was considering egg freezing while finishing her residency. Since she’s done her own research into it, I was able to learn from her experience. She told me that there are certain hormones that doctors measure to see how many eggs you have, and that the quality starts to go down when you're around 35. I decided to have my hormones tested in November 2017, and the doctor told me that I was looking premenopausal, and I had a low amount of AMH hormone (which is an indicator of a woman’s ovarian reserve). I got a second opinion, and that doctor said the same thing. My OB told me that if I want to have a child, I shouldn't wait, and I should freeze my eggs as soon as possible. I decided right then and there to make an appointment, and I had the egg retrieval in February.
Q: Were you single or in a relationship at the time?

I was in a relationship that was not very healthy, and now I see that my decision to be with him was driven by my biological clock. I was staying with him because he said wanted to have kids with me, but he wasn’t the right partner for me. Our relationship ended right as this whole egg-freezing process occurred. I realized I didn't want to have a child with him, and I definitely didn’t want to find myself scrambling and settling for someone because time was running out to have kids. It felt empowering to give myself more time.
Q: What was your end result?

When I went to do the egg retrieval, the doctor told me that it may not go well, because I have such a low reserve. But for whatever reason, I was successful. They extracted 15 eggs, 11 of which were viable. They cryo-froze them, and now I have 11 eggs in long-term storage until I need them. For me, the process of getting those eggs involved a lot of affirmation and a lot of praying and asking myself, “How did I get here?”
Q: What did the medical part involve?

First, I had to do blood tests as well as an ultrasound where the technician visually counted the number of egg follicles that appeared on both of my ovaries. (This can give you an idea of whether you have a poor or good egg supply, and how many eggs can be retrieved.) Then, I started a series of injections of medications, which included follicle-stimulating hormones. I did that for 14 days, which is a little longer than normal, because the follicles weren't growing, and they didn't know if it was going to work. About eight days in, drugs that prevent ovulation were added to my mix of injections; this was to give the follicles more time to grow.

During this whole time, I had to go in to the clinic every other morning and get blood work done as well as ultrasounds to monitor the progress. On Day 13, I took one final shot that releases the eggs from the follicles and makes them come down into the uterus. The next day I had the procedure done under anesthesia, and they retrieved my eggs. 
If this sounds like a lot of shots, it was: I stuck myself with 58 needles over the course of two weeks.
Q: It sounds like you kept records of the process?

As a medical professional, I was interested in writing all of it down and kept a detailed calendar. I did my own research, and they were laughing at me at the clinic because every day I was asking so many questions. In my practice, I tend to focus on nutrition as preventative medicine. I understand that Western medicine is necessary sometimes, but I'm not into medications personally. Putting my body through this and taking so many drugs wasn’t something I was used to and I wanted to feel as informed and in control as I could be.

It helped me to keep a private journal of what was going on, but I also shared publicly about this process, too. I did that through my practice’s Instagram account, where I post a lot about wellness in general. In one picture, there’s a bruise on my stomach from sticking myself wrong, and I looked like I was three or four months pregnant because I was so swollen. It wasn’t a fun photo; it was a "look what I'm putting myself through" photo. I would love to tell my kid in the future: “I wanted to meet you so bad that I went through this.”
Q: How did you choose your clinic?

I went with a clinic that solely does egg retrievals. They're going to be doing in vitro in the near future because some reproductive endocrinology and infertility (REI) doctors—because of malpractice concerns—are not willing to work with eggs they didn’t extract themselves. When I’m ready to use my eggs, I would definitely do IVF there. They were very supportive.
Q: Did you have to pay out of pocket?

My insurance is pretty awesome. They would cover the medications if I was 37 or older, but I didn’t want to wait. So I did pay out of pocket for it all and took out a medical loan to do it.
