The medications are what's really expensive. The egg retrieval procedure was about $5,000, but the medication was around $10,000. That was one round. Some people have to do multiple rounds, but even before I knew I’d end up with a good amount of eggs, I told myself I would only do this to my body once.
Q: Did that add to your stress level, not knowing what the outcome could be, and knowing that you're paying for this all yourself?

I literally just let it go. This is an investment in my future and gives me more options and opportunities. When it's finished being paid off, that’ll probably be the time to use them. Every month I remind myself of that when I make that payment.
Q: As a dietitian, did going through egg freezing have any effect on the advice you give your clients?

I work with a lot of women who are dealing with fertility issues. As a dietician, I know that the food we eat can affect our minds and bodies. If you’re stressed out about your fertility, eating foods that increase inflammation isn’t going to help matters. That’s one of the reasons I tell my clients it’s important to eat healthfully in general, and limit things like fried and processed foods, as well as alcohol.
Q: What surprised you about going through all of this?

The way people reacted. There was a lot of judgement from some of my single friends, and some friends in relationships, too. I couldn't tell if it was resentment, because not everybody can afford to go through it. I’m by no means wealthy, but I decided that this was an investment. I think a lot of people don't think about it being an option.
Going through this by myself felt a little lonely, and I felt distant from friends. That was a surprise. I want to be that connection for others, because it would have been nice to have.

title.en-US: Kate's favorite ways to use Maven

content.value: 1. Dedicated Care Advocate

Your personal healthcare advocate who can answer any question, anytime! They can recommend the best providers on and off Maven who take your insurance and answer questions about your company’s benefits. I actually found my OB-GYN via the Maven network.
2. Every care type

Access to women’s and family health providers in over 20 specialties, including Nutritionists, Mental Health Specialists, Pediatricians, Career Coaches, and more. My husband and I both used Maven’s Career Coaches to help us manage the additional stress that came with planning for a family while having demanding jobs.
3. Unlimited appointments

Video chat and message with specialists whenever you need to, whether it’s 3 PM on a Tuesday or late at night on a Sunday. Within 10 minutes, you can be on a call with a specialist. A Maven Physical Therapist helped me deal with the aches of pregnancy and was available whenever I needed her, including early Sunday mornings! I loved not having to put everything on hold to get advice I could trust immediately.
4. Expert articles
Read expert resources written by Maven practitioners on every topic.
5. Community forums
No more Googling symptoms, ask questions in our practitioner-moderated forums.
Your Maven subscription is private, confidential, and will never be shared with your employer or any third party. Maven is fully HIPAA compliant.
Explore Maven now

title.en-US: Decoding your ultrasound results

content.value: Maven’s Complete Guide to Pregnancy - Pg. 6

Due to COVID-19, your doctor and hospital's policies around in-person versus virtual appointments, who can accompany you to appointments, and who can be present during labor and delivery may differ from the information below. Consult your doctor or hospital if you have questions about their COVID-19 policies and procedures.
Somehow, many moms-to-be have more questions after their mid-pregnancy anatomy scan than they did before this screening. Luckily, we’ve got answers.
I just got (good!) results from my second-trimester ultrasound. How accurate is it?

At this point in your pregnancy, ultrasounds tend to provide better image clarity than the scans you had in your first trimester. But they’re still subject to the interpretation of your doctor or the technician who did the scan. If you have any doubts about your provider, get in touch with your Care Advocate to talk about your options.
My doctor detected a problem—will I need to see a specialist?

Possibly. She may have referred you to a perinatologist or maternal fetal medicine doctor for a more in-depth ultrasound, or just for extra reassurance. If she didn’t, you should feel empowered to ask whether seeing a specialist is a good idea at this point.
What’s the difference between a screening and a diagnostic test?

A screening test is used to “screen” or look for potential risk factors; it is not a diagnosis. If potential issues are found during your second-trimester ultrasound—which is a screening test—then your doctor will likely recommend following up with a diagnostic test. A diagnostic test is used to confirm the potential problem found in the screening, at which point you’ll be able to discuss next steps and treatment options to get your baby the care he or she needs.
One last thing

: If you have any questions or concerns about your appointment, your Care Advocate is always available to help you book an appointment with a Maven Midwife, OB-GYN, or Maternal Fetal Medicine Specialist. Getting in touch with the right provider for a video chat is often the fastest and most reliable way to put your mind at ease.

title.en-US: 3 questions most women have in their 3rd trimester

content.value: Maven’s Complete Guide to Pregnancy - Pg. 9
At this point in your pregnancy, the three Cs take on a whole new meaning: contractions, cord blood, and cord clamping. Read on for need-to-know info.
I’ve heard a lot about Braxton Hicks—how will I know if this is what I’m experiencing?

Braxton Hicks—or “practice contractions”—usually aren’t painful. They feel like a tightening in your uterus that comes and goes a couple times a day, or even once or twice an hour. Drink a large glass of water and try to relax. If they go away after that (or if you can sleep through them), then it’s not the real thing yet. However, if you experience strong contractions that take your breath away 4-6 times per hour for two hours in a row, you may be going into labor and should contact your doctor. Also, if your water begins leaking or breaks (with or without contractions), if your discharge significantly changes, or if you experience any vaginal bleeding, call your doctor or go to the hospital right away.
What do I need to know about cord blood banking and how is it done?

This is a good time to be thinking about cord blood banking. When your baby is born, blood remains in the umbilical cord and placenta. This blood is usually just disposed of but can be a beneficial source of stem cells to protect against certain diseases (such as leukemia). Some parents choose to “bank” their baby’s cord blood, or have it stored as a kind of future insurance. Ask your doctor to explain the benefits to you so you can decide.
What is delayed cord clamping (DCC) and should I request it?

Unless immediate medical attention is needed, there’s some debate about the best time to cut your baby’s umbilical cord to increase their blood volume. The World Health Organization suggests waiting at least 1-3 minutes after delivery, and some providers recommend waiting until the cord stops pumping. Now would be a great time to get your doctor’s professional opinion so you can make a plan for delivery day.

If you still have questions about contractions or want to talk to an OB-GYN or Midwife about your options for delivery day, message your Care Advocate. They’re always there as an additional resource and can also help get you in touch with a provider for a quick video chat.

title.en-US: Kick counting and other 3rd-trimester musts

content.value: Maven’s Complete Guide to Pregnancy - Pg.10

Due to COVID-19, your doctor and hospital's policies around in-person versus virtual appointments, who can accompany you to appointments, and who can be present during labor and delivery may differ from the information below. Consult your doctor or hospital if you have questions about their COVID-19 policies and procedures.
Ever wonder what you’re not thinking about as your pregnancy is progressing—but probably should be? We’ve got you covered! Here are three questions to ask yourself in the third trimester.
1. Do I know the real deal on kick counting?

Throughout the third trimester, moms-to-be are encouraged to keep a daily record of fetal kicks to monitor their baby’s well-being. To start counting fetal kicks, lie down on your left side in a quiet room and see how long it takes for the baby to move 10 times. (Remember: Every roll, hiccup, and kick counts!) The goal is to count at least 10 kicks in 2 hours. If you count fewer than 10 in 2 hours, or if it takes significantly longer than usual to get to 10, you may be going into labor. Call your doctor and if you can’t get in touch, head to Labor & Delivery right away!

To make counting even easier, make sure you’re having three meals a day with some healthy protein-based snacks in between. Have a snack and a tall glass of cold water to help get your baby active, then lie down and begin your count.

Just know that all babies are different and some are more active than others. Just like you, they also have sleep and wake cycles. If you notice that your baby is more active at certain times of the day, try to count during those times (usually after dinner or in the evening).
2. Do I want to work with a doula?

This is a great time to consider and lock down doula support should you want it. A doula is professionally trained to help women physically, mentally, and emotionally during labor. Some studies show that having a doula present during delivery can reduce C-section rates and the need for pain management. But most importantly, a doula can help you feel informed and empowered to be in charge during your experience.
3. Do I have a birth plan I feel good about? And does it include a Plan B or C?

Now’s a great time to make a birth plan or check yours twice. While labor and delivery can be hard to predict, creating a birth plan can help you advocate for yourself and relieve stress, even when things don’t go according to plan. Ask your doctor to help you create a birth plan that includes who is allowed in the delivery room, your pain relief preferences, and more, so that everyone on your care team knows your wishes on delivery day.
One last thing...

If you’re interested in speaking with a doula to learn more about what they do, your Care Advocate can connect you with one on Maven. Care Advocates can also book a birth plan appointment for you with a Maven Midwife that you can do on an easy video chat from your own home. You can then take this plan to your doctor and go over it together.

title.en-US: 34 weeks pregnant: What to know now

content.value: Maven’s Complete Guide to Pregnancy - Pg. 11

Due to COVID-19, your doctor and hospital's policies around in-person versus virtual appointments, who can accompany you to appointments, and who can be present during labor and delivery may differ from the information below. Consult your doctor or hospital if you have questions about their COVID-19 policies and procedures.

Every phase of pregnancy comes with new things to learn and discuss with your providers. As baby’s arrival gets closer and closer, the “hot topics” center around making sure your little one enters the world as healthy as can be—and also setting yourself up for a healthy childbirth and recovery. With that in mind, here are some questions to think about during this stage and to ask your doctor at your next appointment:
What do I need to know about GBS?

GBS is a bacteria that’s present in the vaginal/rectal area in about a third of all women. It’s quite common and you likely don’t even know it’s there, but it can cause serious problems for your baby if left untreated. When a baby comes in contact with GBS while passing through the vagina, they can develop meningitis, a severe brain infection that can be fatal. It’s recommended that every woman, even those with a planned C-section, be screened for GBS, usually between 35-37 weeks of pregnancy. It’s a simple swab test of your vagina, rectum, and perineum (the area between them). If you test positive for GBS, you’ll take antibiotics that will help protect your baby. Be sure to ask your doctor to explain the treatment in detail and any potential risks. For instance, do you have to take antibiotics now, during labor, or both? If at labor, will your doctor have this noted in your paperwork or will you be expected to remind your labor and delivery team?
What are the warning signs of preterm labor?

Preterm birth is when a baby is born before 37 weeks and affects 1 in 10 babies in the U.S. Ask your doctor to go over the warning signs to be aware of, like contractions every 10 minutes, a change in vaginal discharge or bleeding, a low backache, and others.
What is an episiotomy and how common are they?

An episiotomy is a small cut made between the vagina and the rectum to widen the vaginal opening for delivery. While they used to be very common, they are now only performed in about 20% of deliveries. Some studies show that tearing naturally instead of having an episiotomy causes less pain and bleeding, and less damage to the pelvic floor. Ask your doctor for their professional opinion on episiotomies and why they do or do not recommend them.
How can I prep for baby feeding now?

Now’s a great time to start thinking about how you’ll feed your baby. On Maven, we have community forums where moms can ask questions and share their experiences, articles with helpful nursing tips, and Lactation Consultants (LCs) you can chat with anytime. Speaking to a Maven Lactation Consultant before birth can help you start practicing and prepare you for some challenges you might face. It’s also a great way to get to know an LC you can get in touch with right away, if needed, after baby arrives.
One last thing:

If you’re overwhelmed by all there is to think about or would like to schedule a video chat with a provider on Maven, your Care Advocate is just an email away. They can put you in touch with the right Doula, Lactation Consultant, Midwife, OB-GYN or other type of practitioner to meet your exact needs.

title.en-US: The ins & outs of induction

content.value: Maven’s Complete Guide to Pregnancy - Pg. 14

At 38 weeks of pregnancy, you may be thinking you’re so close to a full-term pregnancy that an induction can’t hurt. But if everything is still going well, it’s best to go into labor on your own. Induction before 39 weeks has actually been shown to increase the risk of breathing problems and neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) admissions for baby.
At your next prenatal appointment, bring up these questions to get your doctor’s professional opinion:
1. How long past my due date will you allow me to go?
(Every city, state, and doctor is different, so be sure to ask this question very directly so you know for certain.)
2. When and why do you recommend induction?
3. Are there any risks involved?
4. How does induction affect labor?
5. Can you take me through the process of being induced?

Knowing your doctor’s stance on induction now can help you feel more informed and prepared should they recommend it. Ask them to take you through step by step so you’ll know what to expect and what you might experience.
One last thing...

If your doctor recommends induction, in addition to asking about the risks, don’t hesitate to message or jump on a video chat with a practitioner on Maven if you’d like a second opinion. Your Care Advocate can also connect you with a provider.

title.en-US: A pediatrician’s story of new motherhood

content.value: “Pediatricians are just like us.” That’s probably not a headline you’ve read in your favorite tabloid lately, but it’s absolutely true. Just because they don a white coat doesn’t mean they’re immune to the realities of new motherhood. To help shed some light on what to expect in those early days with an infant, and how to cope with the ups and downs, Maven Pediatrician—and mom of three—Amy Brandon shares her refreshingly honest experience.
Q: How many kids do you have? And how old were you when you had your first?
I have 3 kids—ages six, four, and one. I was 33 when I had my first, 38 when I had my youngest—and we just started thinking about baby number four (#final)!
Q: As a pediatrician who’d been (literally) trained for parenthood, were there many surprises during your first month with a newborn at home?
Yes! There were so many new-mom challenges that no amount of training as a pediatrician can fully prepare you for. I still remember trying to give that first bath and thinking,
how do people do this?
But nothing compared to the challenge of breastfeeding, which was a huge reality check for me with my first child.
Q: What were your breastfeeding challenges, and how did you cope?

I had planned to breastfeed exclusively—and this was much harder than I thought, for much longer than I expected. Like many other new moms, I had no obvious difficulties those first couple of days in the hospital. But once we got home—yikes. I had every trouble you could imagine. At one point, I considered going to see a lactation consultant, but leaving the house with a newborn can be such a pain. And when you don’t know what your return will be on that investment of leaving the house (would they just tell me to “try a cream?”), it seemed easier to just stay home and endure the struggle.

Looking back, I wish I’d sought help. By the time I went back to work at eight weeks, I was still having issues and ended up asking some lactation consultants (IBCLCs) that I worked with for advice. Once breastfeeding started to go better, the day-to-day of new motherhood became a lot easier. And with babies #2 and #3, things were much smoother from the beginning!
Q: What surprised you most about new-mom sleep deprivation?

I think I was surprised by how little/fragmented sleep could be, and I could still more or less function (with lots of coffee)—of course, that’s the optimistic side of reflecting on it! On the flip side, I realized the lengths that parents will go to in order to get their baby to sleep—just so they themselves can sleep. This definitely changed how I related to parents in my practice, as well as friends who were moms.

My college roommate had her first kid before I was married, and when she used to complain about sleep troubles, I’d say things like, “Just put the baby in the crib and she’ll get used to it.” Once I became a first-time parent, however, I thought, “If it were only that simple!” I learned that people (even pediatricians) will do pretty much anything to get a baby to sleep.
Q: Were you prepared with all the right baby gear for a newborn?

Yes. The truth is, the list of “essentials” is probably a lot shorter than a lot of parents think. For the first month, you really just need diapers/wipes, clothes, somewhere safe for the baby to sleep, and all the stuff for feeding. There are so many new products out there on the market, and it can feel overwhelming. For instance, on a lot of forums, moms talk about home apnea monitors to track the breathing and heart rate of sleeping babies. But they’ve been found to cause a lot of false alarms—and a lot of worry for new parents. Plus, research shows they don’t actually help protect against SIDS (sudden infant death syndrome).
Q: Did you find yourself Googling things as a new mom that you thought you knew?
I Googled
everything

—like when I needed a quick answer to “how long can you leave breast milk out on the counter?” And I was suddenly part of a million Facebook groups for new parents. I let go of the guilt of being on my phone all the time while feeding my baby, or while she slept in my arms. It was so helpful to be able to check in with all these moms to see what others did when their baby didn’t sleep, or their nipples were sore, or their mother-in-law said something unwelcome.
Q: What surprised you about bringing your baby to the pediatrician during the first month?

I was surprised by all the things they didn’t ask. As a patient, it seems like you spend your entire day getting yourself and the baby ready for this momentous excursion to the doctor—and then it ends as quickly as it started. And while it’s generally good news that everything is going well, it’s also a little bit anticlimactic, considering all that crazy hard work you’re doing at home to keep
a new little person (and yourself!) alive.

Sure, my pediatrician asked about the basics, like the number of wet/dirty diapers. But I think it’s important to ask new moms more open-ended questions as well, such as “how is feeding going?” There is so much nuance going on in the home of a newborn, so many variables to each family’s dynamic, that it’s impossible for a practitioner to get a sense of what each individual circumstance might be like without becoming more curious.
Q: Did you have any emotional hardships as a new mom?

I definitely had some hard periods. I don’t know how much of it had to do with postpartum hormones or the reality that my husband—who is a Marine—was deployed two weeks after our first baby was born. So there were all the normal “baby blues” combined with the separate stress of saying “see you later” to my husband who had leave for Afghanistan for 7 months. There were moments when everything hit me at once and I’d think, “This house is so dirty. I haven’t slept in days. All of this is happening and my husband is not even here.” I was screened for postpartum depression—two weeks after birth, two months after birth, then again at four and six months postpartum. I didn’t have it, but that didn’t mean I didn’t need support.
Q: What did your support network look like?

Shortly after my husband left, I flew to Chicago to stay with my parents for most of my maternity leave, which was 8 weeks long. My family and friends stepped in and were an amazing blessing, in the sense of providing structure and grounding as well as knowledge and extra pairs of hands. They couldn’t help me at all with breastfeeding, as nobody in my family had done that before, but they could make sure baby was safe while I showered or even took a nap! When I look back on that time, I’m actually surprised I made it through—that’s probably thanks to my parents and the rest of my family and friends who formed my “village” and helped me out.
Q: How has being a mom allowed you to connect with patients on a new level?

I recently saw a patient on Maven who came to me because she was thinking about switching to formula-feeding and feeling a lot of guilt over it. She’d tried everything to breastfeed—even getting donor breast milk from a friend—and it just wasn’t working out. Her maternity leave was coming to an end, and she came to me because she felt she needed “permission” to start her baby on formula. I reminded her that formula is life-saving: “Your baby needs you, and needs you to be happy and healthy and not depressed. And if continuing to try to breastfeed is doing you more harm than good, then formula is the answer,” I said. She felt somewhat relieved but wanted to dissect why she felt so guilty about something that she knew was going to be a good thing for her and her child. As a mother myself, I knew the answer was very simple: “Because you’re a mom. And we moms tend to feel guilty about everything.” She laughed, and seemed to lighten up on herself. That may be the best gift we can give another mom.

title.en-US: Cesareans: Everything you need to know
Primer for your first (of many) prenatal appointments

content.value: Maven’s Complete Guide to Pregnancy - Pg. 1

Due to COVID-19, your doctor and hospital's policies around in-person versus virtual appointments, who can accompany you to appointments, and who can be present during labor and delivery may differ from the information below. Consult your doctor or hospital if you have questions about their COVID-19 policies and procedures.

First, the fun stuff: At this prenatal visit, your doctor will give you an estimated due date (we say “estimated” because babies kind of arrive whenever they want to). At this point, you might get to see your little one for the first time—since some doctors perform an ultrasound during the first appointment—and you may be able to hear your baby’s heartbeat.

You can also expect to be weighed, have your blood pressure checked, and be asked to provide a urine sample. (Those standard checks will happen at every visit going forward.) At this first visit, you’ll likely also get a full physical. Your doctor will go over your general health and discuss any medications you’re taking or specific health concerns. The exam may include a pap smear to test for abnormal cervical cells and blood work so your doctor knows your blood type and can also test for STIs, Hepatitis B, and other infectious diseases.
You may also be asked if you’d like to do genetic testing. There are a lot of options for genetic testing including blood tests for cystic fibrosis, Down syndrome, muscular dystrophy, and more.
Key questions to ask your doctor

An open dialogue is key to getting the care you deserve, so the truth is, you should feel entitled to ask about anything that’s on your mind—no matter how big or small. Here are just a couple of the questions you might want to bring with you:
What are all of the genetic tests and what do they test for?

Ask your doctor to go through each genetic test with you in detail. Then work with your doctor to decide which ones you want to have done. And if you choose not to do any genetic testing, or just some, that’s perfectly okay, too!
What’s covered by my insurance?

Many doctor’s offices can help you figure out which tests are covered by your insurance. For example, if you’re under 35 years old, your insurance may not cover some specific genetic tests. Experts always recommend calling your insurance company directly before you have any testing done (because nobody likes a surprise doctor’s bill!).
One last thing...

It’s very common to leave the doctor’s office and have lingering questions you wish you’d thought of—or had time to ask. You don’t have to wait until your next appointment for answers. Simply message your Care Advocate who can get you in touch with an OB-GYN, Midwife, or other type of provider on Maven for a quick video chat.
Related read
Your guide to Maven's pregnancy providers

title.en-US: Preparing for your second prenatal appointment

content.value: Maven’s Complete Guide to Pregnancy - Pg. 2

Due to COVID-19, your doctor and hospital's policies around in-person versus virtual appointments, who can accompany you to appointments, and who can be present during labor and delivery may differ from the information below. Consult your doctor or hospital if you have questions about their COVID-19 policies and procedures.

Wondering what to expect for your second prenatal visit? Well, you’ll spend a good portion of it going over all the results from your first appointment—including your pap smear, blood tests, urine sample, and any genetic testing you decided to do. (And if you didn’t have an earlier visit, you’ll play catch-up with a general health check and some blood work.)

Remember, each prenatal appointment is an opportunity to ask questions about your pregnancy and give your doctor a chance to demystify anything you’re wondering about. Here are some helpful questions to have in your back pocket for prenatal visit #2:
Should I have an NT scan done?

An NT scan (aka nuchal translucency screening) measures the clear space in the tissue on the back of your baby’s neck to test for Down syndrome (DS) and other abnormalities. If you’d like to do an NT scan, this may be performed at your second prenatal visit. Ask your doctor about whether you should consider one and why.
Do I need to have more genetic testing done?

Based on your results, your doctor may want to discuss further genetic testing such as a CVS (chorionic villus sampling), or more invasive testing such as an amniocentesis that uses a thin needle to take a small amount of amniotic fluid from your uterus. These tests do come with associated risks, so be sure to ask your doctor to fully explain them before deciding.
Do I need to switch my prenatal vitamin or diet based on my results?

Your doctor will likely go over your nutrition levels from your first appointment to look for any deficiencies, like low iron, which can lead to anemia. Ask your doctor to go through the results in detail and recommend an action plan if needed.

PS: It’s normal to feel like there’s so much information coming at you during a prenatal appointment that you can’t fully make sense of it all in the moment. We’ve got you covered! Whether you’d like to speak to a Genetic Counselor, Nutritionist, OB-GYN, or other specialist, just reach out to your Care Advocate who can set up an easy video chat.

title.en-US: 3 big second trimester questions, answered

content.value: Maven’s Complete Guide to Pregnancy - Pg. 3
One trimester down, two to go. And each new chapter of pregnancy brings new questions and concerns. Keep reading for the answers many women want right about now:
I’m about to head into my second trimester; am I in the clear for having a miscarriage?

After 12 weeks, the risk of miscarriage greatly decreases, though it can still happen. If you experience a miscarriage, you’re not alone. Please let your Care Advocate know so she can connect you to support from other women and Maven practitioners who specialize in loss.
Help—I’m confused about my first trimester genetic screening results!

If you decided to have first trimester genetic screening, it’s important to understand what the results truly mean. For instance, a “positive” doesn’t guarantee that there’s a problem. If you’re not getting the advice and guidance you need, remember that you can always email your Care Advocate on Maven who can help give you a referral to a specialist on Maven or an in-person provider.
Should I be thinking about strengthening my body for birth?

As your nausea (hopefully) begins to let up, squeezing in some prenatal exercise is a good idea. You might consider activities like going for short walks, swimming, or doing prenatal yoga. But there are also muscles you can’t see that are just as important to exercise—your pelvic floor muscles! A Maven Physical Therapist can teach you how to do pelvic floor exercises that can help with labor and recovery.
Simply message your Care Advocate if you’d like to video chat with any type of provider or specialist on Maven.

title.en-US: Why your urine is tested frequently during pregnancy

content.value: Maven’s Complete Guide to Pregnancy - Pg. 4

Due to COVID-19, your doctor and hospital's policies around in-person versus virtual appointments, who can accompany you to appointments, and who can be present during labor and delivery may differ from the information below. Consult your doctor or hospital if you have questions about their COVID-19 policies and procedures.

Now that you’re in your second trimester, you’ve probably got the whole prenatal visit routine down: hop on the scale, have your blood pressure checked, provide a urine sample. Ever wonder what they’re doing with those cups?

Well, there’s a lot that little urine sample can reveal. For instance, your urine tests help your doctor look out for bacteria, high levels of sugar or protein, UTIs, and kidney disease. Combined with blood pressure tests, a urine sample can help your doctor spot gestational diabetes or early preeclampsia. Testing urine regularly is also a way to keep tabs on whether you're dehydrated and to what degree.
PS

: If you ever have any questions related to test results or any other aspect of your pregnancy journey, simply message your Care Advocate. They’re always there to be an additional resource for you, and can also help get you in touch with an OB-GYN, Midwife, or other type of provider on Maven for a quick video chat.

title.en-US: Help—need advice after my glucose and anemia tests!

content.value: Maven’s Complete Guide to Pregnancy - Pg. 8

The point of prenatal tests is to catch any potential complications early on. That’s why it’s important to understand what the results actually mean for your prenatal care. Here, two common points of confusion following the glucose and anemia tests—plus the clarity you need.
If I tested positive for gestational diabetes, do I need a follow-up test? What if I tested negative?
If you tested positive, your doctor may schedule you for a more extensive follow-up diabetes test (just make sure to fast after midnight before this test and bring a good book—it can be a bit long).
If you tested negative and aren’t considered “high risk” you may not receive another test, but ask your doctor to be certain.
Remember that no matter the outcome, you don’t have to navigate this journey alone. Maven Diabetes Coaches can explain glucose values, carb counting, and how exercise can impact your glucose levels.
If my iron supplements are causing constipation, what do I do?

Increasing your iron through supplements can help if you have anemia, but it’s true that they do cause digestive issues for some women. If you’re struggling with constipation, looking for an iron supplement or syrup with a boost of vitamin C can help.

Talk to your doctor or a Maven provider about which supplement may best suits your needs. And if you’d like to try eating more iron-rich foods that are safe during pregnancy, Maven Prenatal Nutritionists can help you customize a diet plan. Simply message your Care Advocate if you’d like to video chat with a Maven Practitioner.

title.en-US: 3 things to think about before your delivery day

content.value: Maven’s Complete Guide to Pregnancy - Pg. 13

We know—pregnancy can feel like one big information overload. The good news is that all the knowledge you’re acquiring now—like the answers to these questions below—can help make labor and new motherhood that much easier.
What do I need to know about the mucus plug?

During pregnancy, your body releases mucus and cells from the cervix to cover the opening of your uterus. This mucus plug serves an important function, such as keeping bacteria from entering your uterus during pregnancy. As your cervix begins to dilate in preparation for the big day, you may notice this plug come out—sometimes a little at a time or all at once. Wondering what to look for? Forgive the visual but, some women say it looks like a thick nasal mucus with a tinge of blood. Not the prettiest, but extremely functional! If you do spot this, it’s totally normal and all part of your body getting ready to bring your baby into the world. We wish we could say “you’ll go into labor two hours after your mucus plug comes out,” but unfortunately, the time between is unpredictable. The good news is that you’re headed in the right direction!
Does my insurance cover a breast pump, and if so, how does this work?

Many women are surprised to find out that their insurance fully covers a breast pump and that they will need to reserve one in advance. Give your insurance company a call to ask them for details, what types of pumps they cover (the model and make), and how to begin this process if you’re interested.
What kind of postpartum support should I be thinking about?

Now is a great time to think about (and enlist!) people who can help make your meals, teach you how to swaddle, help you change diapers, and help you take a nap! Having friends, family, your partner, and/or a postpartum doula ready to jump in will help make your postpartum recovery that much easier.
PS:

Wondering about signs that labor may be on the way? Book a chat with an OB-GYN or Midwife on Maven. A Maven Doula can also advise on all the essentials to pack in your delivery day bag, or help you utilize your postpartum support team. Just message your Care Advocate who can set up an appointment for you with any type of provider you need.

title.en-US: Still pregnant at 40 weeks?

content.value: Maven’s Complete Guide to Pregnancy - Pg. 15
We’ve got answers to common questions women have when their due date approaches but labor contractions are nowhere to be found (or felt).
What happens if I’m 40 weeks pregnant and baby isn’t showing signs of making a debut?

Your doctor will probably talk to you about planning a delivery by one week past your due date. It’s generally not considered safe to go two weeks past your due date because it increases the risk of a stillbirth or other complications. While inductions can take longer than natural deliveries, in general, they are very safe.
Is there anything I can do at home to help speed things alone if I’m overdue?

That depends; many “natural” induction techniques aren’t 100% harmless. That’s why it’s always best to check with a provider who can take your unique circumstances into consideration. They may offer a few safe suggestions, or they may simply recommend that you try your best to relax until it’s time to think about a medical induction.
What if my doctor hasn’t brought up medical inductions with me?

If your doctor hasn’t talked to you about the different induction techniques, as well as the benefits and possible risks, now is the time to ask questions. If you want to speak with a provider to learn the facts or discuss what being induced would feel like, your Care Advocate can connect you with a Midwife or OB-GYN on Maven. A quick video chat may be just the thing you need to put your mind at ease.

title.en-US: Postpartum symptoms to call your doctor about

content.value: Maven’s Complete Guide to Pregnancy - Pg. 16

Toward the end of your pregnancy, checkups with your provider were probably happening at least once a week. And now, you may not have an in-person doctor’s appointment until six weeks postpartum. A lot can happen in between delivery and that first visit, so it’s important to keep tabs on how you’re doing and reach out for help if you need it. The answers to these questions can provide clues about when to talk to a provider ASAP.
How do I know if my recovery from childbirth is normal?

It’s totally normal to still feel sore and tired, but if something feels off, it’s a good idea to be checked out. For instance, if you had a vaginal delivery and spot any foul-smelling vaginal discharge or vaginal bleeding that is heavier than a period, definitely call your doctor. If you had a C-section and notice any severe abdominal pain, any redness around the incision, or any pus-like discharge from the incision, definitely call your doctor. If you’re unsure, feel free to have a quick chat with a Maven provider who can give you a professional opinion right away.
How can I tell if breast swelling is normal or if it’s something to see my doctor about?

If you’re nursing, you may get swollen and painful breasts from oversupply, but if you have redness, fever, or warmth in your breasts, you may have mastitis—an inflammation of breast tissue that sometimes involves an infection. It’s important to consult a provider as soon as you suspect mastitis in case you need antibiotics. The earlier the infection is treated, the better.
Bottom line

: In the first six weeks after having a baby, it’s common for new moms to put themselves on the back burner. But taking care of a newborn requires caring for yourself. If you have a question about any aspect of your physical or emotional recovery, contact your provider or reach out to your Care Advocate who can connect you with the right specialist.

title.en-US: Troubleshooting newborn feeding issues

content.value: Maven’s Complete Guide to Pregnancy - Pg. 18
Feeding a newborn can be hard, but it doesn’t have to be impossible.

By now you may be in on a little secret: The images you see on Instagram of women blissfully feeding their baby in a garden are a big leap from reality. Where are the photos of new moms who are half-asleep in the middle of the night while trying to mix formula, or staring down at their cracked nipples wondering how a human that weighs roughly 10 pounds could do so much damage?

If you’re having any trouble at all, know that you’re not alone. Maven Lactation Consultants and Pediatricians are available on demand, day or night. A Maven Pediatrician can provide feeding tips and advice on how to make sure baby is eating enough. If you’re breastfeeding, a Maven Lactation Consultant can help spot issues or help you practice new positions that can make breastfeeding much easier—and they can do all this on an easy video chat without you having to get out of your sweats. Sometimes all it takes is a quick tip on how to form a better latch or identifying an issue with a tongue-tie to make the whole experience different in an instant.
If you’d like some help booking a video chat or figuring out which provider would be most helpful to you right now, your Care Advocate is always happy to help.

title.en-US: Essential kegel exercises for new moms

content.value: Maven’s Complete Guide to Pregnancy - Pg. 19
If you haven’t already met, allow us to introduce you to the Kegel—aka an important part of your physical recovery after childbirth.
Who should do Kegels?

These little exercises can help tone your pelvic floor whether you had a vaginal delivery or a C-section. That said, it’s a good idea to get the green light from your doctor or a Maven Physical Therapist before attempting them, just to make sure you’re in the clear. (If you had excessive tearing during childbirth, for instance, you may need to hold off on Kegels for a bit longer, or possibly benefit from a different exercise.)
Got the green light to do Kegels? Here’s your how-to:

Tighten the muscles you would use to stop the flow of urine (just be sure to place a hand on your belly to make sure you aren’t tightening your abdominal muscles to do this). Hold for 10-15 seconds and then release. Try to slowly work up to 10-15 reps several times per day. A Maven Physical Therapist is always available to provide more tips and help you make sure you’re exercising safely.
What issues can Kegels help with?

Too many to list! But one problem that isn’t discussed often enough is “leakage” after childbirth. These exercises will help improve urinary incontinence caused by pregnancy and prevent pelvic organ prolapse (that’s when the uterus, bladder, or rectum can begin to drop down from their normal positions). In other words, they can help you avoid peeing when you laugh.
Need more advice?

Maven Pelvic Floor Physical Therapists specialize in all issues involving the pelvic floor muscle group, and talking to one may prevent a problem from getting worse. Your Care Advocate can help you book a quick video chat whenever you’d like!

title.en-US: 3 practitioners every new mom needs in her life

content.value: Maven’s Complete Guide to Pregnancy
It really does take a village to raise a child. Here are just three of the many types of providers on Maven you may want to welcome into your village.
Sleep Coach

These are experts who help parents get their babies into a healthy sleep routine with customized plans and advice. Personalized guidance is key—after all, what worked for your friend’s little one may not work for your baby. A sleep coach can also help you find a middle ground with your partner if you’re on a different page about how to tackle infant sleep troubles. For instance, what do you do if you’re not aligned on giving the “cry it out” method a shot?
Lactation Consultant

You might think that these specialists are only helpful for breastfeeding a brand-new newborn, but they can help with lots of feeding issues including pumping, or how to get your little one to take a bottle. Lactation Consultants are also a great support if you’re wondering how to best approach feeding when you’re back at work. Most of all, they’ll help you work within your own goals instead of pressuring you to stick with a plan that doesn’t suit you.
Pediatrician

During these early months, you might have questions about your baby's health and development in between in-person visits with your pediatrician. That’s one way a quick video chat with a Pediatrician on Maven can be helpful. Don't hesitate to book an appointment to discuss your concerns, no matter how minor they might seem.

Need help booking an appointment or finding the right provider for you?
Your Care Advocate can help you book a quick video chat whenever you’d like!

title.en-US: Your appointment is booked!

content.value: Click here to confirm the details, and read on to make sure you're all set for your session.

title.en-US: Maven Wallet FAQ

content.value: General
Q. What is Maven Wallet?

Maven Wallet helps you get reimbursed by your employer for eligible fertility treatment, fertility preservation, maternity, menopause, child care, adoption and/or surrogacy expenses. As long as the expense falls within your company’s reimbursement policy and you have submitted required documentation, the expense will be reimbursed directly to your bank account or via payroll after review.

If you have Maven Card, eligible expenses can be paid for directly using your Maven Card, which reduces out-of-pocket payments. Just swipe your Maven Card and upload required documentation to Maven Wallet within 30 days after your transaction to get it approved. See Maven Card section for more information.
See “How do I get reimbursed?” below for more details on required documentation.
Q. How do I activate my Maven Wallet?

Open your Maven Clinic mobile app or visit mavenclinic.com and log in to your account. Scroll down until you see the “Go to my Maven Wallet” button on your Home screen. You can also tap “Me” in the navigation bar along the bottom of the screen, then click “My Maven Wallet” and “Apply for Maven Wallet” to answer a series of questions for your Maven Wallet Application. Once you apply and are approved based on your employer’s eligibility criteria, you’re ready to start submitting reimbursements.
Q. Who should I reach out to if I have questions?

To get in touch with us, tap “Me” in the navigation bar and click “Messages.” From there, simply select the existing conversation with Maven Wallet to contact the Maven Wallet Team. You should hear back within 1 business day.
Q. How do I find a fertility clinic, adoption agency, or surrogacy agency?

Great question! Finding a clinic or agency that meets your needs can be challenging, but Maven is here to help. Message your Care Advocate for personalized clinic or agency referrals. They’ll talk to you about what you’re looking for and provide a custom list of the best options in your area, based on your needs.

To start a new message thread with your Care Advocate, tap “Me” in the navigation bar, then select your Care Advocate from the “My Care Team” section. If you have an existing message thread with your Care Advocate, you can simply tap “Me” then “Messages” and reach out in the existing thread.
Q. How long can I use Maven Wallet for reimbursements?
As a Maven member, you have access to Maven Wallet starting from when your Maven Wallet is activated until you reach the earliest of the following:
You reach your individual reimbursement maximum
Your employment with the company offering Maven benefits terminates
The date that you are no longer an eligible employee
For more information or details about your Maven benefit, please check your Program Overview for Maven. You can find this on your Maven Wallet Dashboard.
Reimbursement
Q. Which expenses are eligible for reimbursement?
To find out which expenses are eligible for reimbursement, please check your Program Overview. You can find your Program Overview on your Maven Wallet Dashboard.
Not finding the information you need? To reach out to the Maven Wallet Team for help:
Log in to your Maven account
Go to Messages
Send a message through the Maven Wallet thread
Q. When will I be reimbursed?

While the exact reimbursement timing varies depending on your employer, Maven will review and approve eligible reimbursements within 1-2 business days once all requested documentation is submitted. Once your employer gives us final approval, Maven will transfer your funds within 10-14 business days (for members on direct deposit) or your employer will reimburse you via your paycheck in approximately 2 pay cycles (for members who are reimbursed through payroll).
If you have a Maven Card, you can use this to pay for eligible expenses at participating locations, with no need to wait for reimbursement.
Q. How will I get reimbursed if I’m not in the United States?
For international members, eligible expenses will be reimbursed via payroll in approximately 2 pay cycles.
Q. How do I get reimbursed?
In order to be reimbursed for out-of-pocket payments or to get a Maven Card transaction approved, all transactions require documentation in order to be substantiated and approved.
You must upload the required documentation to Maven Wallet within 30 days of the transaction.
After submitting, the Maven Wallet Team will confirm that you’ve submitted the correct documentation or we’ll message you for more information if needed.
Use these documentation tips to help you get your transaction approved:
Submit a copy of your explanation of benefits (EOB) OR a finalized invoice (this is the document that you would receive after the service has been provided).
Make sure your documents include:
The provider’s name
The date of service
A description of the service(s) rendered
The patient’s name
Amount billed and paid
Need help? We're here for you. Log in to your Maven account and visit Messages to reach out to the Maven Wallet Team anytime
Q. How do I upload documentation?
To upload documentation for out-of-pocket reimbursement or Maven Card transaction approval:
Log into your Maven account
Find the card transaction you need to upload documents for (this will be under your “Needs attention” section on your dashboard)
View the transaction details and click the “Upload documents” button
You will be redirected to the Maven Wallet message thread where you can upload your documents
If you want to begin a new reimbursement claim, click on “Submit a receipt” to upload documents via messages
Q. How will I know when my claim has been approved?

We know that waiting on reimbursements can be stressful, and keeping you up to date on your reimbursements is a top priority for us. To view the status of your expenses, tap “Me” in the navigation bar along the bottom of the screen and click “My Maven Wallet.” You’ll see a list of all your reimbursements on the dashboard, along with their statuses. These statuses will update automatically and you’ll receive an email when your expenses have been reimbursed. You can also tap into each reimbursement for more details or message the Maven Wallet Team for help.
Q. Is my process for reimbursement different if I’m on a HDHP (U.S. Only)?

For members on an HDHP, the IRS has set a minimum amount that must be paid out of pocket before you can start being reimbursed through your employer. The minimum statutory deductible is $1,400 for single coverage and $2,800 for family coverage in 2022 and $1,500 for individuals and $3,000 for family coverage in 2023. (Non-fertility related medical expenses can go towards this minimum statutory deductible, too!) To show that you’ve met this deductible, you will be asked to provide your group health plan information so that we can confirm your out-of-pocket spend. You may also be asked to submit a copy of your Explanation of Benefits (EOB) from your insurance portal or send us images of invoices and receipts that prove you’ve paid out of pocket. Maven can reimburse for eligible expenses after the deductible is met.
Maven Card
Q. What is Maven Card?

Maven Card is a debit card that you can use to pay for eligible fertility treatment, fertility preservation, adoption and/or surrogacy expenses. If your employer offers Maven Card, you can use this to pay for eligible expenses at participating locations, with no need to wait for reimbursement. Please check your Program Overview to see if your employer offers Maven Card.
Q. How do I apply for a Maven Card?

If you are eligible for a Maven Card, you can request a card on your Maven Wallet Dashboard. Just look for the message on your Maven Wallet Home screen and follow the steps! You can also find it under Maven Wallet, Settings, "Request a Maven Card".

You will receive a confirmation email once your card is shipped and can follow the instructions inside to activate the card and start using it. For Maven members on an HDHP, you must show that you have met the minimum statutory deductible before being able to request a Maven Card.
Q. How long does it take to receive my Maven Card?
After you have applied and are approved, you will receive your Maven Card via the mail within 7-10 business days.
Q. How do I activate my Maven Card?

To activate your Maven Card, simply follow the instructions you receive with the Maven Card in the mail. You will need to call the number on the back of the Maven Card (866-516-4060) to activate the card.
Q. Where can I use my Maven Card?
You can use your Maven Card to pay for expenses at eligible fertility clinics, speciality pharmacies, and adoption or surrogacy agency locations. Please check our list of
Maven Card Accepted Vendors
to see participating locations, or reach out to the Maven Wallet Team to see if the location you are interested in is eligible.

Please note that the Maven Card cannot be used at generalized provider locations where other services beyond family-building services are offered. This includes general hospital systems and local pharmacies.
Q. Do I need to submit documentation for Maven Card payments?
Yes. All transactions paid for with the Maven Card require documentation in order to be substantiated and approved.
You must upload the required documentation to Maven Wallet within 30 days of the transaction.
After submitting, the Maven Wallet Team will confirm that you’ve submitted the correct documentation or we’ll message you for more information if needed.
It is important to note that if required documentation is not submitted within 30 days of the transaction, the amount of the transaction will be reported to the IRS as taxable income.
Use these documentation tips to help you get your transaction approved:
Submit a copy of your explanation of benefits (EOB) OR a finalized invoice (this is the document that you would receive after the service has been provided).
Make sure your documents include:
The provider’s name
The date of service
A description of the service(s) rendered
The patient’s name
Amount billed and paid
Need help? We're here for you. Log in to your Maven account and visit Messages to reach out to the Maven Wallet Team anytime
Q. When can I use my Maven Card?
You can use your Maven Card to pay for expenses at eligible provider or agency locations after the service has been completed. Services should be completed before using your Maven Card for payment.
It is important to note that In the event the Maven Card is used before the date of the service, the amount of the transaction will be reported to the IRS as taxable income.
Q. How do I upload my documentation for a Maven Card transaction?
All Maven Card transactions require that you submit required documentation
within 30 days of the transaction
in order for it to be substantiated and approved.
To upload receipts and invoices for Maven Card transaction approval:
Log into your Maven account
Visit My Maven Wallet
Find the transaction in Recent Transactions
Click Upload Documents
Upload your documents
Q. What happens if I do not submit documentation for a Maven Card transaction?

If your documentation isn't uploaded within 30 days of this card transaction, your card may be deactivated, pay may be withheld by your employer to repay an unsubstantiated expense, or the amount of the transaction may be reported to the IRS as taxable income.
Q. What do I do if my Maven Card is lost or stolen?
If your Maven Card is lost or stolen:
Log into your Maven account
Visit My Maven Wallet
Tap “Messages” to contact the Maven Wallet Team or call 866-516-4060
Have more questions?
Q. What happens if I have more Maven Card or Maven Wallet questions?
We’re here to help! To reach out to the Maven Wallet Team:
Log in to your Maven account
Go to Messages
Send a message through the Maven Wallet thread

title.en-US: Pump + Check Kit instructions

content.value: Follow these simple steps to pack and check your milk on international flights.
1. Before leaving home
Before you leave for your trip, pack up to 45 of your favorite breast milk storage bags. You'll need them to fill your kit!
2. Freeze cooling pack
For best performance, freeze foam cooling packs for 72 hours before using them to travel back.
3. Pump & freeze milk
Pump and freeze your milk until it's solid before packing it in your Pump + Check Kit.
Freeze breast milk in your own storage bags
Remove all excess air and seal securely before freezing
Freeze bags laying flat
4. Pack kit
Step 1:
Lay a bottom layer of (3) foam cooling oacks.
Step 2:

Fill cooler with your frozen milk bags until 1 in. below the zipper at the top. Fill any excess space with packing material (such as clothing or newspaper). This will prevent the air from warming your milk while traveling.
Step 3:

Important: Lay two layers of (3) foam cooling packs each on top of the frozen breast milk bags. Don't skip this part! Milk on the top is the most likely to thaw. Double check that all excess space is filled with packing material before closing.
5. Check bag
Check your Pump + Check Kit to avoid security issues. Outside fo the U.S., most countries do not allow large amounts of breast milk to be carried on the plane.
6. Wash cooler
Once you and your milk have safely arrived home, be sure to wash out your cooler and save it for next time!
INCLUDES:
(1) Durable Coleman cooler with antimicrobial liner
(9) foam cooling packs
Instructions
NOT INCLUDED:
Breast milk storage bags
DETAILS:
Packs up to 270 oz. of frozen milk - (45) 6-oz. bags
Keeps milk frozen for up to 24 hours of travel
Reinforced bottom
Reusable
Weighs 21 lbs. without milk
Questions? Reach out at mavenmilk@mavenclinic.com or visit our FAQ at
www.mavenclinic.com/maven-milk-FAQ
Order Pump + Check Kit

title.en-US: Pump + Post Kit instructions

content.value: Follow these simple steps to ship your milk safely home to baby within the U.S.
1. Pump & refrigerate
Pump and refrigerate your milk before packing it in your Pump + Post Kit.
2. Arrange shipping
Most reliable: Find your nearest FedEx Office at www.fedex.com/locate/. Use the label provided to drop your package off to FedEx Express (at least 30 min before Express pickup deadline).
Or, work with your hotel or the office you’re visiting to arrange a FedEx Express pick-up (most occur before noon to ensure overnight delivery).
3. Pack kit

To fit all 36 ounces in the kit, fill and label the (6) bags provided with up to 6 oz. of breast milk each. Do not overfill the bags above the 6 oz. line. Remove excess air and make sure it is securely sealed. Then, fold over each bag below the seal. Place in the cooler so each bag overlaps the one underneath it.
4. Activate cooler
Place the cooler foil side down on a flat surface. Firmly press activation button.
In a few seconds, the cooler will feel slightly cool and a blue NanoCool logo will appear. It will reach refrigeration temperature in a few minutes and remain cold for 72 hours.
Please Note: Cold temperatures during transit can sometime make the NanoCool logo appear before activating. Rest assured, your cooling pack is still fully functional and needs to be activated by you.
5. Record & close box
Put the cooling unit back in its original position and press firmly for a snug fit.
Record the date, time, and time zone when you closed the cooler on the label on the inside lid.
Close the top of the box and insert the side flaps into the sides of the box.
Place the 3 security seals on the edges of the front flap of the box, across the areas marked "Tape Here".
Stick the return shipping label on top of the original shipping label on the left side of the box. Make sure to fully cover the original label.
6. Ship!
Drop your kit o at your nearest FedEx Office (recommended) or with the hotel or office where you have arranged pick-up.
7. Unpack & check temperature
Milk should be cold when the kit is unpacked. You are responsible for confirming the temperature of the milk using a digital thermometer immediately upon opening the kit.
8. Refrigerate or freeze immediately
Milk should be refrigerated or frozen immediately after opening the kit.
INCLUDES:
(1) Medical-grade refrigerated shipping container
(6) tamper-proof breast milk bags
(1) extra breast milk bag in case of leaks or spills
(1) Return shipping label
(3) Security seams
Instructions
DETAILS:
Transports up to 36 oz. of milk
Overnight shipping with the U.S.
Up to 72 hours refrigeration in case of delays
Questions? Reach out at mavenmilk@mavenclinic.com or visit our FAQ at
www.mavenclinic.com/maven-milk-FAQ
Order Pump + Post Kit

title.en-US: Why am I showing earlier?

content.value: Congrats on your new pregnancy! This time around, you may notice that your belly is announcing the news before you do, ready or not. Perhaps you wanted to wait to break the news to friends and co-workers, but many second-time moms find that their bump appears sooner than it did in their first pregnancy. Here are six possible reasons why:
Muscle tone

Your first pregnancy effectively stretched out your abdominal and pelvic floor muscles, so now your body is even more ready to go through these changes again. Women with looser abdominal muscles will naturally start to show sooner than women with tighter abdominal muscles. While you may not be rejoicing in all of these body changes, there’s a silver lining: labor is sometimes shorter after the first.
Body type

Each woman’s body is unique, including yours! If you are slender or on the shorter side, the shifts going on in your body to make room for baby might be more noticable sooner than for a woman who is taller (with more room in her torso) or a woman with more weight around the midsection.
Uterus position

Your body has a great memory and knows just what to do. Along with all these changes going on, your uterus is busy taking center stage. How your uterus lines up in your body can factor in, with a uterus that tilts slightly out contributing to a more showy bump.
Bloating

Your body is coursing with hormones and doing some major work to prepare for this baby. As you may remember from Baby No. 1, all of these changes can impact your digestive system, resulting in gas and bloating, which can make it appear as though you have a bump sooner.

Miscalculated due date
If this baby was a “surprise,” there’s a possibility that you might be a bit farther along than you think. Your OB-GYN or midwife can help provide a more accurate assessment based on fundal height (the distance from pubic bone to the top of your uterus) and baby’s anatomy scan.
Twins?
Don’t sound the alarms just yet, but there’s a small chance that your body is making room for more than one baby. An ultrasound will settle the score on this one.

Just remember: Each woman—and each pregnancy—is different, so try not to compare yourself to others or to your previous pregnancies. This bump is one-of-a-kind! If you have any concerns about your baby’s growth, ask your OB-GYN or midwife, or a Maven provider.

title.en-US: Creative self-care tips for moms of multiples

content.value: First trimester symptoms are rough no matter what. But they can be even harder to power through them when you’ve got older kids keeping you on your toes! We know it isn’t easy to make self-care a priority, but it’s just as important to having a healthy pregnancy. Here are a few creative tips from Maven moms to get you through this.
1. Make the mornings yours

We know, the idea of waking up any earlier than you already have to seems just plain cruel—but trust us on this one. Many parents swear that getting up just an hour before their kids do has been their #1 sanity-saver. Even if all you do is have a cup of coffee in complete silence, please go back and reread “in complete silence”.
2. Put self-care on the books

Fatigue and insomnia are common during the first few months of pregnancy (you’re creating a human, afterall!), so getting enough sleep is a must. Ask your partner, family members, close friends, or a sitter to schedule regular outings with your older child so you can get the rest you need. While it would be great to hit snooze through the whole first trimester, even an hour or two on weekends is something!
3. Start a home gym club

Exercise may be the last thing on your mind, but even a quick walk or stretch can boost your energy (and your mood!). Know another mom in the neighborhood? Set up a weekly exercise routine together, alternating between your homes. Bring your kids over for playtime while you two get your endorphins up with a safe and quick 30-min pregnancy workout. (Bonus: Plan your workout on the weekends and have your partners watch the kids in one house while you two workout in the other so you can fully concentrate and motivate each other.)
4. Get your older child on a routine

The truth is, it can be hard to schedule any time for self care if your toddler isn’t on a schedule, too. Now is a great time to set daily nap time, play time, meal time, and a regular sleeping schedule for your children. Even if it takes some time for your little one to adjust, kids thrive on structure. It gives them a sense of stability, can help reduce behavioral problems, and can cut down on your overall stress as well. It also makes it easier for you to make plans for your care if you know when your children will be napping.
5. Promote a little helper

Now can also be a great time to give your little one more responsibility. Helping them learn to be a big kid now can make it easier once baby arrives. Help them learn to put on their shoes, brush their teeth, and clean up their toys. If your child is older, consider asking them to help with household chores. When positioned in a positive way, responsibilities can help your child feel like an important helper for mom and an important member of the family. Praising them for these little chores can go a long way in boosting their self esteem, too.

title.en-US: 5 ways this pregnancy might be different

content.value: Congrats on growing your family! One of the best parts of being pregnant again is knowing what to expect. But while some parts of your experience may be familiar (oh, hello nausea my old friend...) many moms say that no two pregnancies are exactly the same. Here are some ways this time around might be a little different.
1. You may feel less anxious

There are so many unknowns when you’re pregnant for the first time. You may have found yourself Googling “Is this normal?” day and night for nine long months (and yes, that IS normal!). But this time, you have some sense of what to expect at each stage and this can help ease anxiety.
2. You may show earlier

If you couldn’t wait to start showing the first time around, you may be pleasantly surprised to celebrate your little baby bump sooner this time. Because your stomach muscles have already stretched in your former pregnancy you’re more likely to show earlier when pregnant again.
3. You may feel kicks sooner

Many women say that they were able to pick up on those first little butterfly wings or popcorn pops sooner in their later pregnancies than in their first. This one may just be a case of knowing what it feels like rather than it actually happening sooner, but either way, it’s a fun one to look forward to!
4. You may have a faster birth

First-time moms are often advised to wait until their contractions are very close together to head to the hospital, as first labors can take quite a bit longer to progress. This time, don’t be surprised if your OB-GYN or midwife advises you to head in a little sooner. Many subsequent labors and deliveries go faster thanks to a bit of pre-stretching from your first. It’s a bit like muscle-memory—your body knows what to do even more intuitively this time.
5. You may have a totally different experience

Many moms say they were surprised at how different each of their pregnancies were—the good and the less enjoyable. Symptoms such as nausea may be better (or worse). You may have had no sciatic pain with your first, but your second seems to be doing a daily dance on your sciatic nerve! If you experienced certain health complications, such as gestational diabetes or high blood pressure before, you are more likely to experience them again. However, talking to your doctor or a provider on Maven about a healthy diet and exercise plan can help you get ahead of these certain conditions during this pregnancy. And, on the plus side, if your first birth didn’t go according to plan the first time around this one may surprise you by going perfectly!
Have questions about your symptoms? We’re always here for you.
Send a Maven OB-GYN or midwife a message or book a video chat.

title.en-US: Coping with disapproving family members

content.value: You have a baby on the way, and naturally you hope that your friends and family will share in your joy. Unfortunately, that’s not always the case. It can be heart-wrenching to break the big news to people you care about only to hear criticism, disappointment, or a lack of support or enthusiasm in response. Wondering how to react when someone close to you is trying to rain on your pregnancy glow? We’re here to help!

While your first reaction might be anger, there may be some ways to process and talk through this difficult moment. Let’s explore some of the possible roots of what might be causing your loved one’s negativity and some tips for moving forward.
Lifestyle
Sometimes a negative response to a baby on the way comes as a result of our family or friends disapproving of our partner, relationship status, or sexual preference.

How to cope: If you want to continue having a relationship with this person, you may need to find some common ground. On the other hand, if the comments are causing you harm, it’s OK to put some distance between you and them for your wellbeing.

What to say: While it’s understandable to feel hurt and rejected, if you’d like to maintain the relationship it can help to stay positive when trying to reason with your loved one. Here’s an example of how to respond: “You may not agree with my lifestyle, but this is about your new grandchild, and I would hope that you would be happy and celebrate this occasion.”
Age discrimination

Although the average maternal age is trending up compared to generations before, stigmas still prevail in either direction and some may feel strongly that certain ages are “too old” or “too young” for motherhood.

How to cope: Regardless of outside opinions, remind yourself that the family you are creating is intentional and that your children are loved, happy, and taken care of, regardless of what age you are.

What to say: Sometimes it can be best not to acknowledge comments. However, if you choose to respond, you could acknowledge their concerns while using humor in your response: “I thought I’d wait until I’d paid off my student loans before having a kid.”
Family size

The U.S. birth rate has hit an all-time low, with the average woman having 1.728 births. As the average family size shrinks, expectations for how many kids is “enough” is shrinking, too. You might have heard, “Don’t you have enough kids?” or “This one was an ‘oops’ baby, right?” or other potentially hurtful remarks.

How to cope: Start with trying to figure out where these comments are coming from, and whether they are masking a deeper issue. Your loved one could be projecting their personal opinions on you or feel threatened that they will no longer be able to spend time with you as your family expands. They may be concerned about your ability to financially support additional children, or that you may be stretched thin caring for a growing brood.

What to say: If you’d like to respond, reassure them that you are preparing for your new addition. For example: “We’ve put a lot of thought into this decision and we want to have a big family. I hope you will support that decision with your well wishes.”
The takeaway

Honest conversations can help smooth out problems. You may also find that the remarks of others fade once baby arrives. But regardless of the outcome, your mental health comes first. For many women, pregnancy is an emotionally vulnerable time (thanks to all those hormones coursing through your body!) and one that requires self care. Try to focus on your wellbeing and give yourself the space you need. This can mean distancing yourself from the negativity of others. It can also help to get on the same page as your partner before interacting with disapproving family members, so you have a shared game plan for how to handle it (and someone else on your side!).
Remember, if you are ever feeling depressed, anxious, or just need someone to talk to about what you’re going through, we’re here for you. Maven mental health providers are available 24/7.
Click here to talk to someone today.

title.en-US: How to tell your kids you're pregnant

content.value: If you aren’t ready to share the big news yet, your belly may be a few steps ahead of you! Before telling friends, co-workers, or extended family members, a good place to start is right at home with your kids. A new baby on the way is exciting news, but it can also leave your children feeling insecure. Here are some tips on when and how to tell your kids to help them get just as excited as you are.
When to tell them

It’s important to make sure your kids hear the news from you first to ensure that they feel part of this huge family decision. This will also allow you to set the stage that this is positive and exciting news! If you have a younger child, wait until after mealtime or following a nap when they’re rested and in a good mood, as they’re likely to be much more receptive. It can also be helpful to wait until you’re showing. This can help your child understand the concept of a baby when there’s a bump to point to (and hug and kiss).
How to tell them

Before the big announcement, it can be helpful to start “seeding” the idea with your kids. You can prep your child by buying a baby doll and encouraging their nurturing side to begin to create a positive feeling about babies in general. Find opportunities to point out kids with siblings and talk positively about them when you see them together (“Look how great Lizzie is at taking care of her little sister!”).

Next, plan to make your big announcement a fun family event. You can find tons of creative ways moms have shared the news with their kids online or invent your own. One idea is to read a letter “from the baby” introducing him or herself to their big brother or sister and how excited they are to meet their big brother or sister. You could try a scavenger hunt that ends in a gift that says “Big Sis” or “Big Brother” that they can wear with pride. When in doubt, a tasty cupcake with a stork on top could do the trick! If you have multiple kids, it’s a good idea to tell them at the same time so everyone is part of this big event.
How to inspire a positive relationship with baby
Whether your child is lukewarm about the idea of a sibling or already happily sporting that “Big Sis” T-shirt, there are many ways you can help them forge a positive relationship starting now:

Take your child to your ultrasound appointment. Hearing the baby’s heartbeat or watching their little feet dance can help melt a more resistant heart and make the concept of a baby feel more tangible.

Have them talk, read, or sing to the baby in your belly. 
Read baby-friendly books about happy families with siblings.
Shop for baby supplies together and let them pick a few, too.

Have them help decorate the baby’s room or sleep area. 
Talk openly to your child about their feelings regarding the new baby and reassure them that whatever they are feeling is okay. You’re all in this together!
Here’s the key: Don’t push. Every child is different and will respond to the news in their own way. Be easy going about it and know that some of the very best relationships take time.

title.en-US: Should I stop breastfeeding before the next baby comes?

content.value: For many mothers, breastfeeding is not just about delivering quality nutrition to their baby, it’s a special bond they share. And so it’s understandable that the thought of weaning might be bittersweet, even when there’s another baby in the works. Does your new pregnancy mean having to transition your current nurser off the breast? The short answer is: In most situations, the decision to stay or go is entirely up to you.
Is breastfeeding safe to do while pregnant?

Breastfeeding moms release oxytocin during “let down,” and this feel-good hormone can also cause mild uterine contractions (it’s similar to the medication given to induce labor). But studies have shown that the amount of oxytocin released during breastfeeding is too low to pose a threat of preterm birth or miscarriage. In fact, there are no statistical differences in the likelihood of miscarriages between pregnant women who are nursing and those who aren’t.
That said, the American Pregnancy Association (APA) advises women with any of the following conditions to consult with their healthcare provider about whether or not to wean:
If you have a high-risk pregnancy or are at risk of preterm labor
If you are carrying twins
If you have been advised to avoid sex while pregnant
If you are bleeding or experiencing uterine pain
Will my milk supply change during pregnancy?

Some breastfeeding moms experience a drop in milk production during the fourth or fifth month of pregnancy. Depending on the age of your older child, that shift in supply, while temporary, could lead them to lose interest in nursing. If they are still young, you may need to consider working in additional feedings to ensure that they are getting enough to eat.

Another head’s up: Many women report soreness in their nipples when breastfeeding while their pregnancy. This can sometimes lead moms to want to begin the weaning process. If you are experiencing discomfort or have questions about weaning or supply,
book a video chat with a Maven Lactation Consultant.
Are there any specific dietary considerations?

On average, a pregnant woman needs to add approximately 350-450 calories to their diet per day in the 2nd and 3rd trimester of pregnancy. If you are breastfeeding while pregnant, the APA recommends an additional 650 calories per day if your child is exclusively breastfed, or 500 calories per day if they are breastfeeding and eating solids.
How will breastfeeding my newborn affect my older child?

Depending on the age of your child, their nursing may be more for comfort than sustenance—meaning, if they are also eating food, they may not be taking much milk. For this reason, a lot of additional supply may not be needed to nurse both your older child and your new baby. Emotionally, your toddler will likely need time to adjust to having to share mom with a new sibling.

If you choose to continue breastfeeding your older child, it will be important to consider their attachment to nursing and make sure that they get dedicated time with you.
