Even if they’re no longer interested in nursing, your toddler may feel jealous seeing your newborn nurse. This will be a good opportunity to find new ways of connecting with them. For instance, all three of you could cuddle on the couch during your infant’s feeding time and read stories together. You can also look for ways to engage your toddler as “mommy’s special helper” during this transition.
The bottom line:

It’s a big job feeding one baby—and even bigger to feed two. Whatever you choose to do is commendable! If you ever have questions or need more specialized advice along the way, book an appointment with a Maven Lactation Consultant or a Maven Pediatrician for help. We’re here for you!
Sources
American Pregnancy Association. Breastfeeding While Pregnant.
https://americanpregnancy.org/breastfeeding/breastfeeding-while-pregnant/
. Accessed December 17, 2019.
Ishii H. Journal of Obstetrics Gynaecological Research. U.S. National Library of Medicine National Institutes of Health. Does breastfeeding induce spontaneous abortion? October 2019.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20149033
Accessed December 17, 2019.

title.en-US: Best baby gear to reuse or buy new

content.value: With your new little bundle of joy on the way, you may be starting to go through your bundle of old baby gear. Wondering what can make a comeback and what needs to be replaced? We’ve got you covered.
Best gear to reuse:
Reuse undamaged bottles (buy new nipples)

If you have bottles that you’d like to reuse, just check for any signs of damage and sterilize all parts in boiling water first. Because nipples tend to get the most wear and tear, it’s best to replace these for your new baby. With any luck, they will like the bottles just as much but keep in mind that each baby is different, with different preferences, so don’t be surprised if you end up needing to shop around a bit.
Reuse swaddles and burp clothes

If you’re like most parents, you received 101 swaddles and burp clothes at your first baby shower. And it’s a good thing, because you know how many you can go through in a day. Dig out your old ones and give them a quick wash so they’re ready to go for baby number two (or three, or four). There’s no need for them to be spotless because...well, you already know.
Reuse cloth diapers (buy new inserts)

A high-quality cloth diaper can stand the test of time when properly cared for. Take a look through your stash and check for any tearing or mold. Cloth diapers can become less absorptive over time due to detergent buildup so run them through your hottest wash setting a few times without any detergent to help “strip” them. And if you used inserts, consider buying a new stash as this part gets the most use.
Reuse clothing

If you hung on to basics, you’re ahead of the game. As you know all too well, babies go through clothing sizes so quickly, it’s hardly necessary to buy new—not to mention how much you’ll get as gifts. Even if you end up having a different gender, or a significant amount of time has passed, it’s likely that you have plenty of neutral onesies that always stay in style.
Reuse some toys

Take advantage of the fact that your newborn can’t ask for the latest and greatest toys (yet!) and give your first child’s toys a second life. Just make sure that there isn’t any chipping paint or broken parts that could cause harm. If toys are significantly older, they may be more likely to contain toxic materials like lead paint and should be discarded. To check on the safety of reused toys, visit the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission website at <www.cpsc.gov/Recalls>. For toys that are safe to reuse, be sure to sanitize. A safe and natural sanitizer is a 50/50 mix of water and white vinegar. Just spray the toys and wipe dry.
Best gear to consider buying new:
Buy new swings and rockers

It’s a real cost saver when swings and rockers get passed down or resold, but due to ever-changing regulations and recalls, it can become unsafe. Search the product online to make sure it hasn’t been recalled at <www.cpsc.gov/Recalls> or err on the side of caution and buy new.
Buy a new breast pump (or new parts)

Most breast pumps have just a one-year warranty and because they tend to get a lot of use, they can become less efficient over time. In the past few years there are more breast pump options than ever before, including some that are completely hands-free. If you’re planning on pumping often, it may be worth the upgrade.

Remember, your insurance will often cover some (if not all) of your pump purchase for certain models. Call your insurance provider directly for details. If you decide to use the pump you already have, consider purchasing new parts like flanges and tubing so they’re in tip-top shape.
Buy a new car seat

Car seats have short life spans, and if they have ever been involved in an accident, it is recommended that they not be used again. Play it safe a plan to purchase a new car seat. If you choose to use an old car seat or buy used, be sure to check the manual for a warranty or expiration date and visit the National Highway Traffic and Safety Administration (NHTSA) to search for recalls:
www.nhtsa.gov/recalls.

If you’re unsure about the safety of your car seat (new or used), bring it to your nearest child safety seat inspection station where a certified technician can inspect it and alert you to any recalls or defects. You can find your nearest station at: <www.nhtsa.gov/equipment/car-seats-and-booster-seats#install-inspection>. You can also use the NHTSA site for help deciding the best new car seat to buy.
Buy a new crib (if it’s a drop-side crib)

Just like car seats, crib safety changes rapidly. Check the NHTSA site at<www.nhtsa.gov/recalls> to see if your old crib is safe before reusing. Some crib types that were common before, like the drop-side crib, are now considered unsafe and have been recalled.

title.en-US: 3 toddler behaviors to tackle before baby comes

content.value: The third trimester is called the homestretch for a reason—because right about now you’re likely keeping yourself busy getting any last-minute ducks in a row before your little bundle arrives. And for moms with toddlers, there can be a few more ducks keeping you up at night. Let’s call them the three I-N-G’s: breastfeeding, co-sleeping, and potty training. And how you manage the three I-N-G’s now can help determine how smoothly you and your family transition into life with baby number two (three, four, or more!).
Breastfeeding

If you are breastfeeding your toddler, deciding whether to continue after baby number two comes (called tandem nursing) can be difficult. Some moms worry that stopping would potentially break the bond that’s been established with their toddler since birth, while others see a new baby on the way as a good opportunity to begin weaning their toddler.
Here are some common concerns with information to help you decide what’s best for your family:
Will I have enough milk for both of my children?

Breast milk is all about supply and demand. If both your baby and your toddler breastfeed (demand), then your body will likely produce the appropriate amount of milk (supply) to feed both. If you ever have trouble with supply, speak to a lactation consultant on Maven for tips!
Will my toddler be jealous?

It depends. Some moms who tandem nurse say that their toddlers didn’t express jealousy because they were nursing at the same time, and on the contrary, this helped them all form a close bond. Others shared that it did lead to jealousy and that made it hard to nurse both. One thing you can do in advance is to seed conversations with your toddler. Tell them that their new brother or sister will needs lots of nourishment so they can grow big enough to play with them!
Will I have enough energy to nurse both?

Energy is a challenge for most new moms, whether you’re nursing one or two. Following some of the same practices you used in the past may help: 1) Try to get as much rest as you can. 2) Make sure you’re eating well and getting enough calories (doctors recommend an extra 300-500 a day while breastfeeding). 3) Stay hydrated. Having a full glass of water before nursing can help your supply. 4) Keep taking your prenatal vitamins, which are packed with nutrients like iron 
to help boost energy.
If you have questions about tandem nursing or steps to start weaning your child, consider speaking with a Maven Lactation Consultant or a Maven Pediatrician for more personalized advice.
Sleeping in Mom’s Room

If you currently sleep in the same room as your first child, now may be a good time to consider transitioning them into their own bedroom. When baby arrives, you may need the extra space for a bassinet and nighttimes can become disruptive to your old child’s sleep (cluster feeding, anyone?). Here are a few tips that will help your toddler transition into their own bed:
If your toddler nurses through the night, consider reducing the number of nursing sessions or phasing out of night nursing.
Get your toddler excited about moving into their own bed. Shop for fun sheets, pillows, and stuffed animals that will help them forget all about mommy’s old boring bed!
At first, stay with your toddler in their bed until they fall asleep, then gradually move to a chair by their bedside, to a chair by the door, and eventually out of the room.
Play with them in their room as much as possible to create positive associations.

If you’d like personalized tips for creating a sleep routine for your toddler, book an appointment with a Maven Sleep Coach. They can help you create a custom plan that will help your toddler adjust over time so you’re whole growing family is set up for sleeping success.
Potty Training

Potty training is a process that usually starts anywhere between 2-3 years old. If your child falls into this age range, consider working on potty training before your new baby arrives (because every parent can do with a few less diapers to change).
Every child is different, but moms usually know a toddler is ready to begin the process when they:
Are capable of sitting on a potty and getting back up by themselves
They can pull down their diapers, training pants or underwear by themselves
They let you know they’re wet and want to be changed
They want to sit and know more about the toilet, underwear, etc.
They can keep a dry diaper for a few hours at a time

Trying to check off any of these tasks is a great goal to have. But as you start training, don’t be discouraged if your toddler doesn’t take to them right away. Changing behaviors takes patience (and persistence!), but it’s also possible that your toddler may not be ready for them. It’s just as important to know when to let it go for now—as your time may be better spent resting up for baby number two! If you ever need advice along the way, our providers are here for you.

title.en-US: Will my baby & older child get along?

content.value: Seems like just yesterday that you and your partner turned into a power trio, and now you are a rocking quartet. Only problem is, your frontman is having some creative differences with the newest band member. How to get everything back to a more harmonious level? By giving your firstborn some extra TLC, you’ll help ensure a successful bond with their baby sibling.
Here are some steps you can take to ward off potential sibling rivalry:
Be a security blanket

Change is hard for young children. Your firstborn is likely feeling insecure about where they stand in the family dynamic, especially when they see a parade of people bringing gifts and oohing and aahing over the new arrival.

Emphasize the positives about having a sibling: How cool it is to be a big brother/sister, and all the things they will be able to teach their younger sibling. How they’ll have someone to play with when the baby gets bigger.
Explain that babies need a lot of care, which takes parents' time and attention away from them, but that soon baby will be big like they are.

Reassure that there is still plenty of love to go around and having a sibling doesn’t mean mom/dad love them any less than before. Lots of hugs and affection can help ease their fears of being displaced.
Get your older child involved
Envy stems from feeling left out. Make sure your firstborn feels included and part of the new baby celebration.

Heap on the praise. Do a call-out for good behavior, such as practicing patience, helping out and showing affection toward the baby. Give out some small gifts as rewards, such as a notebook and markers to make them feel extra special.

Give them a role/job to do. When visitors come bearing gifts, allow your older child to take part in the present unwrapping. Have them do some small tasks as mother’s helper, such as fetching a diaper or blanket for the baby, or getting their own shoes on to go out.
Try to stick to routines as much as possible. That will help reinforce the idea that “everything’s OK, just a little different right now.”
Make time for No. 1
Even with all the chaos of caring for a newborn, it’s crucial for your older child to still feel important.
Look for small ways to connect. Luckily, newborns sleep a lot, so you can grab some quick moments to read a book, work on a puzzle or make breakfast.
Keep them busy. If your firstborn is older/more independent, see if you can hook up some playdates or outings with a grandparent or trusted friend to help get them out of the house.
Break out the baby book. This will help remind them that they were once tiny and helpless, and also give you a chance to coo over your older child’s adorable baby pictures.
Talk it out
Try to explain as much as possible.
Be clear about what the baby’s needs are and how babies can’t wait like older children to have those needs met.
Acknowledge negative feelings without scolding or passing judgement.
Work through emotional moments and come up with ways for dealing with them. For instance: “When mom is busy with the baby, you can play with your toys or color in your coloring book.”
Already off to a rocky start?

Don’t get discouraged. Look for ways to address potential problem behaviors, such as anger, anxiety, jealousy and sometimes regression. Don’t punish or scold for acting out. Simply acknowledge the feelings behind it, while setting limits and boundaries for what’s acceptable behavior.
Just remember:

Change is hard and everyone in your family is adjusting. If you are feeling overwhelmed or discouraged, don’t be afraid to reach out for help and advice. Maven Care Advocates are available 24/7 to connect you to the care you need.

title.en-US: How to handle attention guilt

content.value: Your firstborn will always be special. They were your first proud belly bump, your first experience of birth, your first tiny hand gripping your finger, and so many more firsts after that. So it’s only normal to wonder...how will that relationship change once you have another child?

Now that you’ll have not one, but multiple children to care for, you may feel like you’re stretched in every direction and that no one is really getting the attention they deserve. “Attention guilt” is a common feeling for parents of multiple children. Your firstborn is used to being the center of your world, so when a newborn comes along it can be a rude awakening that leads to temper tantrums and acting out to regain your attention. Here are some tips to help the whole family adjust to your new addition:
Set aside dedicated time for each child

Even if it’s just 20 minutes at first, let each child know that they will have your undivided attention for a set time every day and try your best to stick to it. This may be tricky with a newborn who isn’t on a schedule, so try to pick a time when they are likely to be asleep. Eventually, this can become more of a set routine that your older child can look forward to—making them less likely to clamor for your attention when you are unable to give it.
Try to choose your words carefully

It’s hard to measure ever word with so much else on your plate, but little ones are listening and words said in a moment of stress can unintentionally create jealousy. For example, saying, “I can’t play with you, I have to feed the baby” can inadvertently cause your older child to feel resentful towards their new brother or sister. Instead, try saying something like, “I can’t wait to play with you! I’ll meet you in your room when the clock says 11:00am. Why don’t you look through your toys and decide what you’d like to play and I’ll meet you there.” (Positive distractions are your friend!)
Give yourself a break

Being a mom of multiple children is hard work. There will be some days where you don’t feel like you’re giving enough to either one of your children, your partner, or yourself. Rest assured that it will get easier as your newborn develops a more predictable routine and all of your children become more independent. And in no time at all you will be able to witness your children developing their own special relationship with each other (no moms allowed).
Want more personalized tips? We’re here to help!
Send a Maven Mental Health Provider a message or book a video chat.

title.en-US: Why this recovery might be different

content.value: Congratulations! Your baby is here and you may have even had a faster labor this time around (woo-hoo!). Now that it’s time to recover, you may be wondering what else might be different from your first time? Here are some changes you can expect so you feel empowered to face them head-on.
Where’d everybody go?

When you were a first-time mom you may have felt that the whole world became friendlier. Family, friends, and even complete strangers offered to help wherever you went. But some second-time moms say that this can change after the first child. There’s an assumption that you’re a pro now and the helping hands that were once lined up may not seem to be as readily available. While you do have this, don’t be afraid to ask for help if it isn’t provided outright, especially in the first few weeks when your body needs extra care to recover. If you don’t have access to help and you’re feeling pulled in two directions, just remember that if your baby is fed, dry, and safe, you can put her down in a crib or bassinet to tend to your older child when needed.
Avoid toddler weight training

When you had your first baby, their weight was safe to carry while recovering. However, now that you will have a baby and older children, you will need to be careful and avoid lifting anything heavier than your baby for the recommended six weeks—this includes your toddler.

Over-stressing your abdominal muscles can lead to a longer and more painful postpartum recovery. Your toddler may not be happy with this, but do your best to explain that mom needs to be careful not to hurt herself and how they can be a big help to you during this time. It can be reassuring for your toddler to hear that this is temporary and that you can’t wait to hold them again soon. Meanwhile, this is a great opportunity for your partner to take over some snuggle duties and help ensure that your toddler gets attention while you tend to baby.
Oh, hello stretch marks

Truth be told, your skin may not revert back to its former tautness after baby number two, three or four. Now that it has accomplished the incredible feat of growing multiple babies you may notice more permanent changes in elasticity or stretch marks that you possibly avoided the first time. Try to focus less on what you can’t change and more on what you can. Maintaining a healthy diet, staying hydrated, and exercising can all improve how you feel about your body. For changes that are here to stay, celebrate them as reminders of how amazing your body truly is.
Incontinence may make an appearance

Though not spoken about often enough by postpartum moms, incontinence is the inability to hold your urine when you cough, run, sneeze, or jump, and is caused when there’s pressure being put on the bladder (and if you’ve ever laughed at your own mother for not being able to hold it in—now it’s payback!). According to a study by Obstetrics & Gynecology, new moms who delivered vaginally are more likely to have urinary incontinence one year postpartum, compared to women who had C-sections. And the chance of incontinence increases with each birth. For help combating incontinence, speak with a Physical Therapist on Maven. They can recommend safe and effective exercises to help reduce the risk.
Bottom line:

While recovery may be more challenging in some ways after the second (or third) birth, you’re also armed with experience. Give yourself the time you know your body needs to heal and find ways to celebrate all that you’ve accomplished.
Sources:
Obstetrics & Gynecology.
Pelvic Muscle Strength After Childbirth.
https://journals.lww.com/greenjournal/Fulltext/2012/11000/Pelvic_Muscle_Strength_After_Childbirth.7.aspx
. Accessed December 2, 2019.

title.en-US: Bedtime tips for moms of multiples

content.value: You made it through the round-the-clock newborn stage and are eager to start your new baby on a bedtime routine (especially if you are going back to work soon!). But how do you fit your wee one into your evening wind-down? Here are some tips for juggling multiple kids’ needs at bedtime and creating a new schedule that works for you.
Formulate a game plan

Babies and young children thrive on predictability. Chances are, you already have a bedtime routine in place with your older child, and it’s just a matter of working your baby into it, too. But if you’ve been winging it up until now, this is a great opportunity to put a plan into action. Here’s a typical post-dinner routine:
Bath (some parents do every other night)
Diaper change or, brush teeth and go potty (for the ones who are ready for it)
PJs
Read a book or sing a song
Lights out
For older kids, additions to this plan might include picking up toys and tidying up. For babies, there might be another feeding and some extra cuddles before bed.
Keep it simple

Modify the plan to make it as easy to implement as possible. Ideally, a routine that one parent can do solo, in case you or your partner tend to work late or travel for work. If it’s easier for you to pick up the toys, or you’d rather get bath out of the way before dinner, there’s no “wrong” way to do things. Ideally, you want to create a plan that can be done in under an hour, so bedtime doesn’t feel like it’s dragging on and on. As your children get older, bedtime routines should get gradually shorter—a half hour, and eventually about fifteen minutes.
Work smarter, not harder

As you get more set in your routine, you’ll quickly find some shortcuts or “hacks” to streamline the operation. For instance, once your infant is big enough for tub baths, you can bathe both kids together. Or if your older child is independent enough to get their own pajamas on, they can do that while you tend to the baby.
Stick to the routine

Easier said than done, that’s for sure, but the closer you stick to doing the same things around the same time each night and in the same order, the more likely they are to become clockwork. When your kids know what to expect each night, bedtime will become less of a struggle. If you experience bumps in the road (daylight savings time and bright summer nights, we’re looking at you), do your best to steer the ship back on course.
Start early

As you ease into this new territory of trying to get more than one child to sleep successfully (and keep your sanity in the process), go at a relaxed pace and pad your timetable with at least an extra half hour to start. As anyone with young children can attest, toddlers and preschoolers don’t like to be rushed and don’t respond well to commands. You’ll be better equipped to keep your patience if you aren’t feeling like you’re up against the clock. If your older child isn’t quite ready to hit the hay, have them read or play quietly in their bed until lights out. This will also buy you a bit of time to get baby nestled down.
Just remember:
If things aren’t working, don’t be afraid to change it up. When making tweaks to the routine try to do so gradually, giving your little ones the time they need to adjust.

title.en-US: Why pregnant women crave sweets

content.value: There you are, going about your business and suddenly...Chocolate. Ice Cream. Chocolate ice cream. With chocolate sauce! You can’t think of anything else. If you’re feeling the urge to eat something sweet at every hour, read on to learn why!
Why do I crave sweets?

The majority of pregnant women (as many as 60-90 percent) experience food cravings, which begin in the first trimester and usually peaks in the second trimester. Sweets and high-fat foods like dairy products (ice cream and french fries!) top the list of popular must-haves, followed by salty foods like pickles, snack foods, and spicy foods. Interestingly, cravings usually show up at the same time as food aversions, which is when the smell of something you used to enjoy (such as meat cooking) makes you want to gag.
What do my food cravings mean?

The fact is, it isn’t actually known what causes pregnancy cravings. Many experts believe that it’s caused by an interplay between hormones that can give you the sudden urge to eat pickles and cheese sandwiches or dip Cheetos into your yogurt. Other explanations point more specifically to hormones playing games with our appetite receptors, and sense of smell and taste. Others still say that the cravings are linked to specific nutritional deficiencies—say salt, iron (which is why you might crave steak) or magnesium (which is why you might crave a chocolate bar).

Interestingly, culture also influences what we crave. For instance, one study of more than 200 pregnant women in Tanzania found that the most common cravings were meat, mangoes, yogurt, oranges, and plantains. These differences could mean that some of our cravings are psychological, in that we end up turning to the foods that both satisfy us and make us feel good, hence the fact that many cravings involve comfort foods.
Is it okay to give in to cravings?

Certainly, to a point. An indulgence now and again is fine, so long as the majority of your meals are made up of healthy, nutritional food with a balance of vitamins and minerals needed to have a healthy pregnancy. You just want to be careful not to over-indulge on sweets and snacks as they can contribute to unhealthy weight gain and possible complications.
Is there a way to manage my cravings?
When you find the urge hard to resist, try these tips:
Portion control
Have a treat on a smaller scale, such as a few squares of chocolate bar rather than the whole bar.
Sensible swaps
Instead of ice cream, give low-fat frozen yogurt a try, or a piece of fruit instead of candy. Seltzers with zero sugar and natural flavorings make a great substitute for soda, too.
Eat frequently
Small, steady meals throughout the day can help keep your blood sugar level balanced, which can help reduce those cravings for sugary treats.
Just remember:

The rule of thumb is everything in moderation. The old adage of “eating for two” isn’t quite accurate. A pregnant woman only needs to add approximately 350-450 calories to their diet per day in the 2nd and 3rd trimester of pregnancy—so it’s important to make those calories count!
Sources

Orloff, N. Hormes, J. U.S. National Library of Medicine National Institutes of Health. Pickles and ice cream! Food cravings in pregnancy: hypotheses, preliminary evidence, and directions for future research. Front Psychol. 2014; 5: 1076.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4172095/
. Published online September 2014.

Blau, LE, Orloff NC, Flammer A, Slatch C, Hormes JM. U.S. National Library of Medicine National Institutes of Health. Food craving frequency mediates the relationship between emotional eating and excess weight gain in pregnancy. Eat Behav. December 2018, ;31:120-124.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/30253292
. Published online September 2018.

Nyaruhucha CN. U.S. National Library of Medicine National Institutes of Health. Food cravings, aversions and pica among pregnant women in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. Tanzan J Health Res. January 2009;11(1):29-34.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19445102
. Accessed December 17, 2019.

title.en-US: What does the size of my bump say about my baby?

content.value: Once it’s obvious there’s a baby in that belly, you may feel like it’s an open invitation for people to weigh in on the size and shape of your bump. Sometimes the attention can be flattering, but there are times when seemingly innocent statements can make you feel sensitive, self-conscious, or even trigger anxiety that your baby might not be growing at the right pace. Understanding how the size of your belly relates to the size of your baby can put your mind at ease (and help you quiet the peanut gallery).
Does the shape or size of my bump mean anything about my baby?

As old wives’ tales go, how your baby fits your body can predict almost anything—including its sex: Carrying high? It’s a boy! Low? It’s a girl! But in actuality, how you carry says more about your genetics and body type than it does about your baby. For example, if you’re on the shorter side or have a small torso, you might look “bigger” or show earlier than someone taller or with a longer torso. If you have a little extra in the middle (don’t we all!) it may take longer for your bump to be noticeable. If you have a six-pack, it may also take more time to show.

In some cases, the size of your bump often isn’t related to the size of your baby at all. For example, women who have had babies before are more likely to have experienced some stretching in their stomach muscles, and tend to show sooner than first-time moms
How will I be able to tell if my baby is growing normally?

Your provider will keep track of your changing body over the course of your pregnancy and the main tool they will use is a simple tape measure. Starting around week 12, your provider will measure from your pubic bone to the top of your uterus. Referred to as the “fundal height,” this measurement is a pretty solid indicator of your baby’s growth and one they will take at every prenatal appointment to make sure you’re growing on schedule (or according to “gestational age”).

Most women receive at least one ultrasound during pregnancy (some receive several) at around 18-20 weeks. This second trimester scan is a biggie: The ultrasound technician will spend time taking measurements of your baby’s major organs and appendages to make sure they are developing on track as well. If you are having a high-risk pregnancy (older than 35, carrying multiples, and/or other health factors), you’ll probably have additional ultrasounds to keep a closer look at your baby’s progress.
What if my bump is measuring small for gestational age?

In general, if the fundal height is off by 3 cm or more than the gestational age, you will likely have an ultrasound to measure your baby and fluid—just to make sure that all is okay. Often, baby and fluid are just fine! But if baby is too small or there isn’t enough fluid, then your pregnancy will be monitored more closely. If your doctor says that there is no cause for concern, remember that plenty of women have had small bumps or very large bumps and delivered perfectly healthy babies.
Bottom line:
Try your best not to get caught up in the way your bump appears or compare yourself to other pregnant women.
Focus on eating healthy
, and making sure your baby is getting all the nutrition they need. Your provider will give you a heads-up if there are any issues along the way.

title.en-US: What causes leg cramps?

content.value: You knew that a certain amount of weight gain was par for the course, but you may not have known that pregnancy can also come with new aches and pains. You may feel like you’ve been transformed into a much older version of yourself with all-new body ailments that keep popping up on a daily basis. While back aches tend to get the most mention, there’s another ache that may give you more grief—the leg cramp.

Leg cramps can make an appearance any time during your pregnancy. About half of pregnant women experience leg cramping at some point, and they are more likely to strike in the evening time. Here’s what you need to know.
What causes cramping?

Muscle spasms can be caused by additional weight gain, as your growing baby places extra pressure on nerves and blood vessels that travel to your legs. (The spasms can also show up in your back and other spots, too.) This pressure or pinching leads to that “charley horse” feeling that comes out of nowhere and can leave you bracing for it to end.
What can I do to prevent leg cramps?
Prevention is a big part of keeping leg cramps at bay. Here are some tips to help:
Exercise regularly:
Include plenty of stretching before and after, specifically stretches that target your calves.
Stay hydrated:
Drink plenty of water throughout the day and throughout your pregnancy.
Take your prenatal vitamin:

Make sure you are getting enough essential minerals such as calcium and potassium. If you are getting severe leg cramps, talk to your provider about additional magnesium supplementation, as this has been shown to relieve leg cramps in pregnancy.
Elevate your legs:
Kick up your heels (literally) when you can. Taking weight off your legs can go a long way.
How do I treat a leg cramp when it happens?
Even with all of the above precautions, you still might fall victim to a sudden spasm now and again. When they strike, you can ease the pain by:
Massage legs and feet (better yet, asking someone to do it for you!)
Apply heat
Take a bath with Epsom salts to help relax the muscles

Try wearing compression socks
Practice a combination of these tips along with stretching
I’m still getting them. Any other tips?

If you continue to be plagued with leg cramps, talk to your OB-GYN or midwife or book an appointment with one on Maven. They will assess your situation and determine if there’s a separate medical condition that needs attention.
Is it safe to take over the counter medication for leg cramps?

Anti-inflammatory medication is not safe during pregnancy and can lead to complications. Talk to your doctor or an OB-GYN on Maven before taking any medications during pregnancy, including over the counter medications, prescribed medications, and herbal supplements.
When to seek help immediately

While very rare, blood clots can also cause leg cramping. Blood clots are a very serious condition that can lead to complications. If you experience any of the following symptoms, call your doctor or go to the emergency room immediately:
Swelling, pain, or extreme tenderness in one leg (often the left leg)
Leg is warm to the touch
Leg looks red in color
You experience trouble breathing
Sources
Mamach, M. Mayo Clinic. Healthy Lifestyle: Pregnancy week by week. What causes leg cramps during pregnancy, and can they be prevented? June 18, 2019.
https://www.mayoclinic.org/healthy-lifestyle/pregnancy-week-by-week/expert-answers/leg-cramps-during-pregnancy/faq-20057766
. Accessed January 7, 2020.

title.en-US: The ultimate before birth bucket list

content.value: Congrats! You made it through the first trimester and hopefully you’re feeling on the up and up. You’re out of the nauseous stage and the early pregnancy jitters and concerns that go with it. This is a great time to focus on yourself and do some self-care activities that will be a lot harder to do once baby comes along. Try to relax and enjoy these moments through nurturing yourself (and your little one).
Here are 10 things to do before you’re due:
1. Go on a “babymoon”

Plan a getaway with your partner. What that looks like is up to you and depends on how you feel, your finances, and whether you can take time off work. Your trip can be as simple as a weekend jaunt to somewhere nearby or as exotic as an overseas splurge (just get your doctor’s permission first!). Whatever it is, make sure it’s something you and your partner can enjoy together.
2. Make time for date nights

Speaking of quality time with your partner, this is the perfect time to try that new restaurant you’ve been wanting to check out, go see a concert, or attend a sporting event—things that may be harder to do with a newborn. If money is tight, stay in with takeout and your favorite movie, and make it special in your own way.
3. Engage in random acts of fun
Once your baby comes, doing things on the fly will become a lot harder to pull off, so take advantage of opportunities to be spontaneous.
4. Go day trippin’

Once kid(s) are in the picture, your Sunday Funday activities will have a new focus (think zoos, parks,and other family-friendly events). While you can, hit up area attractions made for grownups: museums, shopping trips, outdoor excursions.
5. Put yourself first
Book a massage, a pedicure, a prenatal yoga session or a fancy haircut. Or just stay in and ask your partner for that foot massage they’ve been promising.
6. Bask in having nothing to do

Don’t feel bad about reveling in some guilty pleasures. Sleep in late or nap on the couch, binge watch your favorite shows, read non-baby-related books. Soak in the slow, quiet time before you are on baby duty full time.
7. Socialize

Get together with friends as much as possible. Ask your pals to join you on those day trip adventures or spa day indulgences. Or if distance is a factor, schedule a marathon phone/video chat with your besties. Don’t forget to include your mom (and/or your mother-in-law). You’ll want to make sure your bond is as strong as ever, as you might need to lean on her in the days to come!
8. Get some fresh air
Step out for walks with the dog, strolls with your special someone, or even a hike if you’re up for it. Your baby-in-the-making will enjoy the activity, too.
9. Schedule a maternity photo shoot
Dress up your bump for some pregnancy pics. If you’re not up for a professional session, snap a selfie each week so you can look back and see how your bump has grown and changed.
10. Bond with baby

Right now you and your baby are connected in a way that you will never be again. Take a moment to connect with them by singing to them, reading to them, or simply telling them how excited you are to meet them with each passing day.

Not all of these suggestions are extravagant, and some are downright free. But now is the best time to get started before you head into the third trimester and last-minute preparations. So take a moment to spoil yourself, live in the moment, and have some fun doing it!

title.en-US: Can sex induce labor?

content.value: Pineapples, long walks, and sex have all at one point been given near magical status when it comes to inducing labor. But how much is true and how much is wishful thinking? Read on to find out!
What’s the lowdown on sex during pregnancy?

As you head into the last stage of pregnancy, you may start to feel tired, heavy, and frankly, not so sexy. But for some, those extra pregnancy hormones can make you feel even more in the mood. Since every person is different, how much or how little sex you have really depends on how you feel and what you feel like doing.
Some notes of caution:
Regardless of what type of sex you are having (vaginal, oral, anal), you will still need to protect yourself from sexually transmitted infections/diseases, if you’re at risk of contracting them.
If you experience heavy cramps, bleeding (heavier than light spotting) and/or leaking fluids after sex, call your provider or visit the emergency room right away.
Generally speaking, because of the bacteria harbored in the anus that could be harmful to your baby, anal sex can pose additional risks. Speak with your practitioner first.
Is sex toward the end of pregnancy still safe for baby?

Rest assured, your baby is snug and well protected in their amniotic fluid within your uterus. However, in some cases, women with pregnancy complications may be asked to abstain from sexual intercourse. If you fall into that category, your provider will let you know. And if you have any concerns, don’t shy away from bringing it up at your next prenatal appointment or booking a quick video chat with an OB-GYN on Maven.
Can sex trigger early labor?

The theory behind this is based in science: When we have an orgasm, our bodies release “feel good” hormones that can stimulate contractions. Also, if your partner is male, sperm contains compounds that can help soften and open the cervix, similar to what doctors use as an intervention to get labor started. However, the limited amount of research testing this theory have been inconclusive. For example, a 2006 study published in the journal of Obstetrics & Gynecology found the opposite: Women who had any amount of sex in late pregnancy actually went into labor later than the women who abstained. So the verdict is still out on this one.
What if I’m full term and READY to have this baby?

Once you’ve hit the 40-week mark, many pregnant women are willing to try just about anything to get labor moving! Spicy foods, bumpy car rides, and those pineapples we mentioned earlier are all held as tried-and-true methods depending on who you ask. But do any of them actually work—including sex? While it doesn’t hurt to try any (or all) of them, the only thing we know with certainty is that your body will be ready in its own time.

Silver lining: Even if sex doesn’t produce the outcome you were hoping for (inducing labor), it can be a good opportunity to connect with your partner, and the last chance for intimacy with your partner for a little while. Once you give birth, the doctor will ask you to hold off on intercourse for six weeks (and let’s face it, you’ll both be a little busy and exhausted taking care of your little one).
The bottom line

Unless your doctor has advised against it, sex is safe as often as you like (or have the energy for). Just remember, your body's calling the shots and will let you know when it’s go time. Until then, try to relax and enjoy the ride (which isn’t always easy, we know).
Sources:
U.S. National Library of Medicine National Institute of Health. Sexual intercourse at term and onset of labor.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16738157
. Accessed December 2, 2019.

title.en-US: Headed back to work but baby won't sleep?

content.value: So you’ve been doing this parenting thing for a bit now and are feeling like you’ve maybe got a groove going. Only thing missing? Sleep. We’re not talking a good night’s sleep—at this point any amount of sleep will do! While living the new-parent-zombie lifestyle is somewhat manageable while you’re on leave, it can be harder to maintain when you’re back to your 9 to 5.
Here’s what to expect and how to gear up for sleep training as you head back to work.
When will baby sleep through the night?

This is one of the most frequently asked questions first-time parents have in late-night online searches. And the answer is not so simple. Every baby is different but here are some milestones that are common:
By around 6 weeks,
babies tend to go 3-4 hours between feedings.
By 3-4 months
they sleep longer at night, and you shouldn’t have to wake them up to feed.
At around 6 months
you should be able to eliminate nighttime feedings, which means, in theory, baby should be sleeping a good 6-8 hours.
If by 12 months
your baby is not sleeping solidly through the night, talk to your baby’s doctor.
How do I get my baby started on sleep training before heading back to work?

Developmentally, babies aren’t ready to start sleep training until they are 4-6 months old. The concepts behind sleep training are to help your baby be able to self-soothe and fall asleep on their own, so if/when they wake up in the night they are able to fall back to sleep. There are a number of methods out there so it’s best to choose one that feels right for you and your family.
Until then, you can do a few things to help foster healthy nighttime habits:
Start a bedtime routine

Get baby used to nighttime being sleepy time by doing the same things around the same time every night. For example: give baby a bath, put them in their PJs, read them a story or sing a soothing lullaby, then lay them down for bed. It’s important to do them in the same order to create a routine baby can expect.
Put baby down awake

The key to better sleep is to help your baby get used to falling asleep on their own. While it might be tempting to rock your baby to sleep every evening, that could be setting them up for a tough transition into sleep training. Start slow by giving your baby a few minutes to settle themselves before rushing in.
Fill up the tank

A full tummy will help baby sleep longer, so be sure and top baby off with a nursing or bottle right before bed. Another trick that works for some moms is to wake baby up for a quick feed before you hit the hay, called a “dream feed”.
How can I make it through the work day on little sleep?

Like many moms, you might be heading back to work before your little one is fully sleeping through the night. Nothing says anxiety like the thought of having to jump back into the workplace on zero Z’s. Here are some tips for when you’re in survival mode:
Eat something for breakfast
Try not to rush out the door without having something healthy in your system. An egg, some yogurt, or a healthy smoothie can help give you the energy you need to power through your day.
Tackle your toughest tasks first
Don’t wait until the end of the afternoon to do your most important work. It can be best to tackle detailed work first while you’re fresh.
If caffeine is your friend (water is your BFF)

You may find that you go from a one-a-day to a two-or-more a day coffee drinker during this time. Just be sure to drink plenty of water, too. Caffeine can give you a quick lift but is also dehydrating. If you’re breastfeeding, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends limiting your caffeine consumption to 300 mg a day (or about 2–3 cups of 8 oz. coffee) and some studies have shown that large amounts of caffeine can cause fussiness in babies.
Get some air

Instead of ordering another triple latte, try taking a break for a brisk walk. Getting fresh air in your lungs and our heartrate up can make you more alert and less groggy. (A great move before a meeting!)
Just remember:

This, too, shall pass and soon those 2 a.m. wake up calls will be a thing of the past. And if you ever need some personal tips, book an appointment with an Infant Sleep Coach on Maven. They can help you with sleep training and tackling sleep issues as well as help create a custom sleep routine that works for you and your family.

title.en-US: Worried about affording another baby?

content.value: Having kids can be expensive (and don’t you know it!). But just how much exactly can you expect to spend when looking ahead to baby number two?

According to the USDA’s “Cost of Raising a Child” report, expenses such as housing, food, child care, and all the other stuff that goes into child rearing can add up to $250,000 or more for parents over the 18 years of their child’s life, from birth through high school. In some places, that number is higher (or lower), depending on the average cost of living. And this doesn’t include saving for college.

It’s enough to make your head spin, but before panic sets in, there is a bright spot: many of those core expenses—like housing and transportation—are shared among your total number of children. Which means when you add another child to your family, the overall cost of each declines. The USDA research supports this, finding that married-couple families with one child spend an average of 27 percent more per child than those with a two-child family.

Each additional child costs less overall because children can share a bedroom, a family can buy food in larger, more economical quantities, and clothing and toys can be handed down, etc. Not to mention the fact that we tend to be less focused on buying all the latest and greatest gadgets after our first (because we now have the wisdom that banging on pots and pans with a wooden spoon is probably baby’s favorite toy anyway).
Here are some other ways you can save as you grow your family:
Reuse your baby gear

Chances are, you may have saved some or all of your core baby must-haves: pack ‘n play, swing, bassinet, onesies, tub, high chair, carrier, and infant car seat (just be sure to check the expiration date and recall information at NHTSA.gov). Is your baby a different sex? Remember that a baby doesn’t care if they’re bathed in a pink or blue tub so long as the water is warm and a doting parent is by their side. If it bothers you, see if you can swap or sell to get a different one through online marketplaces focused on baby gear. And be sure to check out
our full list of baby gear to reuse or buy new.
Look out for deals

For items you’ll need to buy, don’t underestimate the power of the coupon or holding out for holiday deals! Maybe you need a double stroller or a toddler bed for your older child. Keep an eye out for sales or gently used items (Craigslist and Facebook Marketplace are especially popular with parents). Take advantage of discounts on everyday baby products, like diapers. The more you stock up now, the less of a financial hit you’ll take once baby arrives. And don’t be afraid to put basic items on your baby registry like diapers and wipes. (The other moms in your life will spot the real needs on your list right away and come through!)
Reduce your child care costs

For much of the country, child care is the second most expensive part of child rearing after housing, and in some states it’s the number-one expense! Luckily, many daycare providers offer some sort of discount for multiple children, and this might be a good time to price out additional options for comparison’s sake. There may also be alternatives that could save you some money, such as nanny sharing or at-home day care. Other local moms and mom groups are a great resource for getting to know all the best options in your area.
Revisit your health insurance plan

With another hospital delivery likely on the horizon, as well as adding another dependent to your health insurance, you might be able to save by switching to a different health insurance plan for your growing family. If you have employee-provided insurance, set up a meeting with your HR office to run through your options. Otherwise, call your insurance provider directly and ask for more detailed information to help you decide.
Lower your tax burden

Check in with your HR department to see if your company offers a dependent-care flexible spending account. This allows you to set aside up to $5,000 pretax toward qualifying expenses like daycare or preschool. Same goes with state-sponsored college savings plans for your child (known as 529 accounts). Many states allow you to deduct your contributions to these accounts, which can save you more at tax time.
Review your budget

A wise woman once said: you won’t know how much you spend until you know how much you spend. And you don’t need an expensive financial planner to find out! Just dust off your spreadsheet skills or try an online app to review your current fixed expenses (the money you have to spend every month for basic living like housing, food, utilities, etc.) and your current spending (the money you spend on everything else). Many banks now offer this as a built-in feature making it easier than ever.

Take a look at where your money went the past 3 months to start. See any patterns? Is there anything you can trim? Many families start by cutting out the “extras” such as eating out, traveling, and big-ticket purchases and see a difference right away. If you can make do on less for at least the next year, you might surprise yourself by how much you can save.
Just remember:
Very few people are 100% financially “ready” for another baby, so you’re not alone in your concerns. Do the best you can to prepare, and you’ll find a way to make it work!
Sources
Lino, M. U.S. Department of Agriculture. The Cost of Raising A Child. March 8, 2017.
https://www.usda.gov/media/blog/2017/01/13/cost-raising-child
. Accessed January 7, 2020.

title.en-US: Pregnancy after preeclampsia

content.value: If you had gestational hypertension (high blood pressure during pregnancy) or preeclampsia (a high blood pressure complication) in your first pregnancy, you may be nervous about it happening again. Here’s what to expect and tips that can help you head into this pregnancy with confidence and a plan to help you manage your blood pressure.
What are the chances of getting preeclampsia again?

While research has found that women who have experienced preeclampsia before are at a higher risk for having it again, there are a variety of factors that can impact your overall risk. For example, how far along you were in your first pregnancy when high blood pressure and/or preeclampsia showed up, the severity of it, and whether you continue to have issues with hypertension can all have an effect. In addition, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) lists these risk factors:
First-time mothers
Younger mothers (below 20 years old)
Older mothers (above 40 years old)
Carrying multiples (twins, triplets, or higher)
Previous experience with high blood pressure in pregnancy or preeclampsia
History of high blood pressure, kidney disease, IVF, obesity, and/or diabetes
History of preeclampsia in the family (specifically sisters or mothers who have had it)
Previous history of pregnancy complications associated with the placenta (IUGR/intrauterine growth restriction, stillbirth, abrution; certain autoimmune conditions such as SLE/lupus)
What steps should I be taking early on in my pregnancy?

If you have a history of preeclampsia in a previous pregnancy or high blood pressure, be sure to share that with your current provider. You can discuss personal risk factors, whether you should be on medication to control your blood pressure, or if it’s safe to take your current medications throughout your pregnancy. With this information, your provider can take additional precautions to monitor your health and stay on top of problems if they arise.
You may also consider talking to high-risk pregnancy specialist who can provide you with additional guidance on managing your pregnancy.
Speak to a high-risk pregnancy specialist on Maven.
Is there anything I can do to prevent preeclampsia?

Unfortunately, there is no sure way to prevent preeclampsia, especially since it is not entirely understood. However, some contributing factors to high blood pressure—such as diet and exercise—can be controlled and put into practice immediately to help reduce your odds.

The best thing that patients at high risk can do is go to prenatal appointments for close monitoring and keep their doctor informed of any early warning signs. Additionally, if you have preexisting conditions such as CHTN or kidney disease, be sure that you tell your doctor to ensure that they’re properly managed.

The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) advises that women at high risk for preeclampsia take low-dose aspirin starting at the end of the first trimester. Low-dose aspirin (81 mg) has been shown in clinical studies to reduce the risk of preeclampsia for women with previous preeclampsia, as well as women who are at increased risk of preeclampsia such as those with chronic hypertension, diabetes, or carrying multiples. Talk to your doctor about the benefits of taking low-dose aspirin.
Know the warning signs

At your prenatal visits, your provider will take your blood pressure and test your urine for protein to check for signs of preeclampsia. If you had preeclampsia in your first pregnancy, it might not show up the same way, and you could experience new or different symptoms. Be sure to keep your provider informed if you experience any of the following warning signs:

Swelling in your face or hands
A headache that doesn't go away
Vision changes, like blurriness or spots in front of your eyes
Pain in your shoulder or stomach
Nausea or vomiting (in the second half of pregnancy)
Sudden weight gain
Difficulty breathing
Just remember:

Talking to your provider and practicing healthy habits is the best way to manage your risk. High blood pressure and preeclampsia can be scary, but try not to let fear and anxiety overwhelm your ability to take action today with your doctor’s support. If you need additional support, reach out to
an OB-GYN or a high-risk pregnancy specialist
on Maven. We’re here for a quick video chat or messaging to put your mind at ease 24/7.
Sources
Giannubilo, SR. Landi, B. Ciavattini, A. Obstetrical & Gynecological Survey. Preeclampsia: what could happen in a subsequents pregnancy? Dec 2014.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25503109
. Accessed January 7, 2020.
The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. Frequently Asked Questions: Pregnancy. Preeclampsia and High Blood Pressure During Pregnancy. Oct 2019.
https://www.acog.org/Patients/FAQs/Preeclampsia-and-High-Blood-Pressure-During-Pregnancy
. Accessed January 7, 2020.
American Pregnancy Association. Preeclampsia.
https://americanpregnancy.org/pregnancy-complications/preeclampsia/
. Accessed January 7, 2019.

Spracklen, CN. Ryckman, KK. Triche, EW. Saftlas, AF. Maternal and Child Health Journal. Physical Activity During Pregnancy and Subsequent Risk of Preeclampsia and Gestational Hypertension: A Case Control Study. June 2016.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26910608
. Accessed January 7, 2020.
The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. ACOG Committee Opinion. Number 743. Low-Dose Aspirin Use During Pregnancy. June 25, 2018.
https://www.acog.org/Clinical-Guidance-and-Publications/Committee-Opinions/Committee-on-Obstetric-Practice/Low-Dose-Aspirin-Use-During-Pregnancy
. Accessed January 7, 2020.

title.en-US: 5 meals to make & freeze (before baby comes!)

content.value: As you may remember, the first few weeks with a new baby can be exhausting, busy, and (we’ll say it) a little chaotic. Not to mention the fact that this time around you have other children to take care of, too. While it’s perfectly normal to let some things slide (a clean house, for starters), eating healthy, home-cooked meals is just as important now as it’s been throughout your pregnancy. Here are some ideas for ready-to-eat meals you or your partner can make now and stash in the freezer so you won’t have to survive on cereal while recovering (though that’s great to have on hand, too!).
Bonus:
All of these are easy to make, freeze well, and are healthy, hearty, and kid-friendly, helping you recover while keeping your entire family fed.
Protein prep

Shredded chicken is versatile and easy to prep. Spend a Sunday afternoon baking chicken breasts (or a whole chicken) in the oven or crockpot, then shred and freeze in sandwich-bag-sized portions. This will give you the makings for a huge range of dishes, from tacos and chili to pasta, stir-fry, and soups. Need to save more time? Try ready-to-go rotisserie chicken from your local grocery store (some sell it pre-shredded) or try a grocery delivery service.
Pro tip:

Use your electric pressure cooker to cut down on cook time—and if you don’t have one yet, you might want to add it to your wishlist! (There’s a reason you’ve been hearing the word “Instapot” from all of your parent friends.)
Soups

When searching for freezer-friendly recipes online, soup recipes abound. The beauty of soup is that it’s adaptable for any diet: vegetarian/flexitarian, paleo, dairy free, etc. Some ideas: lentil soup, white bean and kale, butternut squash and carrots, and (the perennial favorite) chicken noodle.
Pro tip:
Make in bulk so you can enjoy it for dinner now and then freeze the rest in small containers for when baby comes.
Casseroles

Baked ziti and lasagna are solid places to start, include lots of veggies to make them even better (using zucchini slices instead of lasagna noodles is a tasty and healthy swap). Another idea for inspiration: egg- and potato-based casseroles (can double as breakfast!).
Pro tip:
Make a double batch, let it cool, and then portion into freezer-safe containers. (Don’t forget to label and date so you’ll remember what it is in a few months!)
Breakfasts

While dinners can take priority when planning ahead on meals, you don’t want to leave breakfast out of the mix. Put together ready-to-blend smoothie packs of your favorite combinations of frozen fruit/veggies/protein powder/yogurt. Make and freeze some lactation muffins or cookies. Homemade pancakes freeze well, too. Try buckwheat pancakes topped with peanut or a different nut butter for a healthier alternative.
Prefer something fresh? Buying oatmeal in bulk is a great money saver and easy to pop in the microwave with some fresh fruit for a filling and healthy first meal.
Pro tip:
Use tin or glass container to make it easy to safely reheat in the oven or microwave.
Other shortcuts

Buy yourself some time now by cooking and freezing the more labor-intensive parts of your future meals. For example, cooked brown rice can be portioned and frozen. Try cutting up some firm tofu, marinate and bake it, and then freeze. Cooked beans also freeze well (and taste so much better than canned).
Pro tip:

Don’t shy away from asking friends and family to help. (Especially if you are running out of freezer space!) Ask them to store some meals for you, or better yet, bring a freshly made dinner when they come to visit your adorable new baby.

title.en-US: Daycare snafus (and how to deal)

content.value: You know what they say about the “best laid plans”? They often go awry. Same goes with trying to line up a solid, dependable childcare plan. Especially now that you are making arrangements for both your newborn and older child or children.

Maybe the relative who was watching your toddler is having cold feet about adding an infant into the mix. Or you’re having second thoughts about whether you can afford your current daycare, now that you are sending two. Whatever the situation, it can be stressful and emotional, especially with postpartum hormones and sleep deprivation in full effect. If you’ve hit a daycare snafu, take a deep breath and read on for what to do next.
Take a step back
Ask yourself: what is driving this problem?
Are you questioning whether your childcare situation is a good fit?

Try giving it a week or two to see where your misgivings are coming from and whether it’s just unease about the disruption and change or reason to find a new solution. If you still aren’t happy with your situation then see if you can adjust your budget/plan and try something else.
Are you concerned about baby’s safety?
If your current daycare situation feels unsafe, trust your mom gut and go with a different option. Don’t feel like you are stuck with something that’s not 100 percent safe and secure.
Are you having doubts about your ability to manage everything?

If it’s more of an emotional feeling (which is perfectly normal), try not to let yourself get too worked up about the coming changes. Same if you’re feeling nervous or anxious. If your feelings are debilitating, or you’re having overwhelming sad thoughts about leaving your baby in someone else’s care, try reaching out to a Maven mental health provider to talk through what’s going on.
Explore new options
Sometimes things happen that are beyond your control. Here are some tips for executing an 11th-hour search to find a new provider.
Go with Plan B

Make your backup plan your new plan, assuming you have someone you can call in a pinch to pitch in on coverage. Is it a neighbor? Friend? Family member? Maybe your employer offers backup daycare assistance? Look to line up some temporary childcare while you get your ducks in a row.
Get creative

Maybe it’s time to pursue something different. For example, you could try a nanny share so your kiddos can stay home or be watched in a home close by yours. Tap into your networks and reach out to area resources both online and in person. Your pediatrician’s office, online mom groups, co-workers, and family-centered nonprofits are all good places to start.
Buy more time

Have a conversation with your manager to see if you can start part time and ramp up your schedule while you look for better childcare options. Consider asking to work a few days a week remotely to ease the transition. Perhaps your partner can take an extended leave and/or also work part time temporarily to give you more breathing room before both of you are fully back to work.
The takeaway:

Try not to make your decision in a vacuum (especially with the lack of sleep you’re experiencing!). Give yourself some grace and remember: this period of change is temporary, and over time you will adjust to the new normal. In the meantime, don’t be afraid to ask for help and go easy on yourself. Need to talk through your options with someone who gets it? Talk to a
Maven Career Coach today.

title.en-US: Was that a phantom kick?

content.value: There you are, snuggling your newborn babe in your arms when you feel a familiar flutter in your belly as if they’re still inside just waiting to arrive. Is your body (or your mind?) playing tricks on you? Don’t panic. You may have just felt what’s called a “phantom kick”—and they’re a totally normal (if bizarre) experience after birth.

If you’ve ever heard of people who’ve lost an arm or a leg from injury and still feel it from time to time, it’s the same concept with phantom baby kicks. And while it may seem like your body didn’t get the memo that your little one has made the big exit, it turns out you’re not alone. In a recent survey of Australian moms, close to 40 percent of respondents reported feeling phantom kicks, and for many women, the fluttering movements continued long into the postpartum period (an average of 6.8 years later!).

For some women, feeling those pint-sized punches brought back comforting memories of their baby in the womb. For others, instead of the warm and fuzzies, the movements were painful reminders of miscarriage or troubles conceiving again in the years following their first pregnancy. In fact, 25% of women described the experience as positive and 27% reported feeling confused or upset by it.

There has not been much research on the actual cause of phantom kicks but one theory is that as the uterus returns to its regular size in the weeks following birth, it gives out occasional contractions. Another explanation is that after months of being in tune with your body, you are more aware of minor uterine activity, which would explain why some women still feel flutters years later.
Rest assured that what you are experiencing is likely harmless and very common. However, if you have concerns that you might be pregnant or are experiencing any pain, talk to your OB-GYN or a
provider on Maven right away.
Source
Sasan, D. Ward, P. Nash, M. et al. ‘Phantom Kicks’: Women’s Subjective Experience of Foetal Kicks after the Postpartum Period. November 11, 2019.
https://psyarxiv.com/6qad9
. Accessed January 7, 2020.

title.en-US: Can I accidentally hurt my bump?

content.value: Your belly is making an appearance now, and with its expanded size comes the urge to keep your baby bump safe. Suddenly, new threats seem to be popping up when you least expect it: a stray elbow or bump from a stranger to a near-fall on an icy sidewalk!

As your bump grows, your center of balance can shift too, throwing you off-kilter—not to mention pregnancy hormones softening your joints and ligaments, making you more prone to injuries. It’s enough to make you wonder, how protected is your baby, really? Here’s a look at what’s safe and when you need to be a bodyguard for your bump.
Everyday activities

Before you start worrying about everything that might hurt your baby—including literally bumping your bump into things, bending over quickly, wearing tight pants—you can breathe easy knowing that your baby is very well-protected and secure in your body. Baby is sheltered by the bones in your back and your rib cage, on top of being nestled in their amniotic sac, protected by the muscles of your uterus and abdomen.

With all of this natural protection your baby can absorb a bit of disruption in the form of everyday bumps. However, if you’ve taken a particularly nasty fall or experience any vaginal bleeding after a fall or accident definitely give your OB-GYN or midwife a call to be safe.
Exercise

For normal, low-risk pregnancies there is overwhelming evidence that exercise such as swimming, walking, or low-impact aerobics are beneficial. That said, you’ll want to steer clear of activities that can put you at increased risk of falling or injuring yourself. High-impact activities to avoid include downhill skiing, horseback riding, mountain climbing, and contact sports (like football or soccer).
Be sure to keep your provider in the loop about your exercise plans, so they can weigh in if they feel like something is too risky.
Workplace hazards

Jobs that are physically demanding can put a pregnant woman at risk for injury. 
Whether you’re working in healthcare and lifting patients, or a service job where you’re on your feet for long stretches of time, you’ll need to be a little extra careful not to hurt yourself. According to the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, pregnant women should avoid the following:
Repeatedly stooping, bending, or squatting
Lifting (according to the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health):
Prior to 20 weeks
, should not lift anything greater than 36 lbs.
After 20 weeks
, should not lift anything greater than 26 lbs and repetitive lifting (greater than 1 hour per day) should be limited to 18 lbs.
Lifting overhead
Standing for a long time
Exposure to toxins/chemicals
Your employer is legally obligated to work with you to keep you away from harm, whether it’s reassigning you to light duty tasks or making allowances for additional breaks.

Additionally, when it comes to exposure to toxins, you have a right to know what kind of chemicals (if any) are used in your workplace and to be given PPE (personal protective equipment). This includes masks, gloves, and ear protections for loud noises. In the case of teratogenic chemicals, pregnant women should be reassigned. If you work around X-rays, appropriate lead protection should be given, or you should be able to switch to another assignment during the pregnancy.
If you have any concerns, speak to your manager and/or your HR representative.
Automobile safety

Wearing a seatbelt should be a given, but did you know there’s also a right way to wear a seatbelt while pregnant? The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) makes these recommendations:

Buckle the lap belt below your belly so that it fits snugly across your hips and pelvic bone
Place the shoulder belt across your chest (between your breasts) and over the mid-portion of your collar bone (away from your neck)
Never place the shoulder belt under your arm or behind your back
Pull any slack (looseness) out of the belt
If you are in a car accident, seek medical attention right away, even if you are not injured.
Just remember:
When in doubt, err on the side of caution. Don’t hesitate to bring up any questions or concerns with your provider to set your mind at ease or talk to an
OB-GYN on Maven anytime.
Sources

Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH): Reproductive Health and the Workplace. Physical demands (lifting, standing, bending). November 2019.
https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/repro/physicaldemands.html
. Accessed January 7, 2020.
The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. Frequently Asked Questions: Car Safety for Pregnant Women, Babies, and Children. March 2019.
https://www.acog.org/Patients/FAQs/Car-Safety-for-Pregnant-Women-Babies-and-Children
. Accessed January 7, 2020.
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Reproductive Health and the Workplace. November 2019.
https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/repro/specificexposures.html
. Accessed January 24, 2020.

title.en-US: Bring this list to your hospital tour

content.value: If you’re on the fence about what to include in your birth plan, or are unfamiliar with navigating hospitals, a tour is a great place to start! Going on a hospital or birth center tour can help you get a feel for your surroundings, find out what to expect on delivery day, and help you get answers to any questions you might have about the birthing process.
If you’re unsure of what to ask, here are some ideas to get you started. Many of these will likely be addressed during the tour, but keep this list handy (and feel free to add to it!) just in case.
Hospital logistics
Ask your hospital tour guide to walk you through the best way to prep for delivery day.
How do I pre-register?
What’s the best entrance/parking area for labor and delivery?
Can you walk me through the steps that begin when arriving at the hospital to being brought to a labor room?
Will I labor in the same room the entire time or will I stay in a triage area until I have dilated to a particular centimeter? And if so, what centimeter?

Will I share a labor room with another patient?
If I have to have a C-section, where does that take place?
After the birth, will I be moved into a different room or do I keep the same room for the duration of my stay?
What are the fees for private rooms, special birthing facilities, etc. (so I can discuss with my insurance provider)?
Will everyone I might receive care from be covered by my insurance?
What security systems do you have in place to keep babies safe and prevent them from being taken off the premises?
Is there a newborn intensive care unit (NICU)? Where is it located?
Where is the waiting room for my family?
Birth
Whether you have a birth plan or are just figuring it out, there are some basics to cover.
What types of support do you give to women who prefer an unmedicated birth?
If exploring pain management options: what will be available to me to help with the pain?
Is there an anesthesiologist in the hospital 24/7, and if not, what is the labor and delivery coverage arrangement?
What is the hospital’s intervention rate? (Percentage of births that include/result in medical procedures, including C-sections)
What laboring tools does the hospital offer (such as a birth ball, tubs, squat bar, TENS machine, etc.)? And if not available, what does the hospital allow you to bring with you?
Who can be in the room during delivery? Is there a limit on the number of people?
If I have a C-section, how many people are allowed to be with me in the operating room?
Are recording devices (like a video camera and tripod, cell phone, or digital camera) allowed during delivery?
Can I bring my own music and speakers?
Can I dim the lighting in the room during labor?
What are the hospital’s policies on instant skin-to-skin time? (When the baby is placed on the mother’s chest immediately after birth)
Is there a nursery and if so, what are your nursery policies?
Do you offer delayed cord clamping or cord blood banking?
Family-centered policies
Here are some questions to help you get a feel for how the facility supports new parents.
When are visiting hours?
Are there any restrictions to visitors (number of people, children, etc.)?
Is my partner (or other family member) allowed to stay with me overnight?
Will my baby stay with me in the room at all times? Including overnight?
Do you offer breastfeeding support services?

What types of follow-up support do you provide to parents after discharge? (Such as support groups, breastfeeding groups, access to lactation consultants, 24-hour nurse lines for answering questions, etc.)
Just remember:

This might be a starting point for thinking through your birth plan and delivery options. Don’t be afraid to follow up with any additional questions you might have by calling your hospital or birth center directly, speaking with your in-person OB-GYN or midwife or a
provider on Maven.

title.en-US: How to mix powdered formula like a pro

content.value: You know you’re in the thick of the newborn days when you’re trying to mix a bottle of formula, blear-eyed, at 2 a.m. Even if you’re not quite there yet, now is a great time to get to know the basics, so you’ll be able to do it (literally) in your sleep.

Even if you plan on breastfeeding, it can be helpful to know how to mix a bottle of formula just in case of supply issues, daycare snafus, or other changes in plan. While formula is fairly easy to use, you’ll want to get the steps down and make sure that everything is sanitary.
Ready to get into the mix? Let’s do this!
1. Wash your hands
Scrub your hands with soap and hot water for about 20 seconds before handling any formula or bottles (tip: sing your A, B, C’s and that will be about the recommended time).
2. Use clean bottles and nipples

Only use bottles, nipples, and other parts that have been properly cleaned. You can run them through a hot-water and heat drying cycle in your dishwasher in advance or hand wash with hot water and soap and then allow to air dry. You can also buy a bottle sterilizer (or put one on your registry!).
3. Wipe down your work area

Clean the surface you will be assembling on. Don’t want to wipe the counters every time? Consider purchasing a silicone cutting mat you could dedicate solely to bottle prep and then give it a rinse or run in the dishwasher after.
4. Measure

Follow the instructions on the package to measure out the water first, then add the powder. Always put in the exact amounts outlined. If the formula is too weak, your baby won’t get the nutrition they need. If it’s too strong, it can make your baby’s digestion system go into overtime (and lead to a cranky/gassy baby).
5. Use clean water
If you have any doubts about your water quality, boil (and cool) water to reduce impurities, or use distilled bottled water.
6. Check the temperature

Contrary to popular belief, room temperature formula suits baby just fine. If your baby prefers it a little warmer or it has been in the fridge, run the bottle under warm (not hot) water from the faucet for a minute or so (taking care not to get water in the bottle’s nipple). Never use a microwave to warm a bottle, as it can heat unevenly and burn baby’s mouth.
7. Serve or store
Once the formula is made, you have the following options:
Use it up

A prepped bottle of formula should be consumed within two hours. If baby has already started drinking from it, it should be consumed within one hour to avoid bacteria growth (yep, even if refrigerated).
Stick it in the fridge
For bottles you’re not going to use right away, you can store them in the refrigerator for up to 24 hours.
When in doubt, throw it out
Toss any remaining liquid in the bottle after baby’s done eating. The residual saliva on the bottle can make it a breeding ground for bacteria (yuk).
Got the basics down and now you’re ready to go pro?
Once you’re feeling good about the fundamentals, here are a few bonus tips that will make your life even easier:
Invest in extras

Frantically scrubbing bottles while baby is crying for food is stressful. Ensure that you always have enough clean bottles, nipples, necks and caps to get you through a 24-hour feeding cycle (even if you forgot to run the dishwasher!) by investing in extras.
Use a drying rack

Whether it’s shaped like a tree or looks like growing grass, it’s helpful to have a clean, dedicated place for bottles to dry or hang out until their next use. Aim for one that won’t drive you crazy to look at if it stays out on your counter.
Bottle brush
