Use a bottle brush that’s solely for that purpose (not for cleaning other dishes). It’s recommended that you should replace them every month, so add a few to your gift registry!
Up your tech (or get crafty)

For high-tech, there are Keurig-like formula dispenser machines with various settings for bottle size, temperature preference, etc. that can take the guesswork out of bottle prep. On the low-tech side, for a few dollars you can get a formula dispenser—a Tupperware-type container with three divided sections and a spout. Add a bottle’s worth of formula powder to each section and, when needed, add water then pour one into a bottle (pouring the water first so the amount is correct). You’ll have three-bottles worth of formula pre-measured for on the go!
Sources
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Nutrition: Infant Formula Preparation and Storage. May 2018.
https://www.cdc.gov/nutrition/infantandtoddlernutrition/formula-feeding/infant-formula-preparation-and-storage.html
. Accessed January 8, 2020.
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Water, Sanitation & Environmentally-related Hygiene: How to Clean, Sanitize, and Store Infant Feeding Items.
https://www.cdc.gov/healthywater/hygiene/healthychildcare/infantfeeding/cleansanitize.html
. Accessed January 8, 2020.

title.en-US: What to do when you're past due

content.value: The countdown to delivery day has gotten closer, closer...and now it’s in the past. Each day over your due date can feel like it drags on in an agonizingly slow crawl. You’re likely tired, uncomfortable and—on top of it all—you have to contend with well-meaning friends and family calling, texting, and constantly asking, “Is the baby here yet?!”
Here are some tips for how to handle a pregnancy that’s going into overtime.
Should I be concerned that I’ve passed my due date?

Generally speaking, what you’re experiencing is normal. Due dates are merely a “best guess” estimate calculated from the first day of your last period and based on your baby’s size during your ultrasound. Some studies have found that only 5% of babies happen to arrive on target and 66% occur within seven days.
What is considered “overdue”?

Although you may not want to hear it, according to The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG), a baby isn’t considered overdue or “postterm” until 42 weeks. So while you may be on pins and needles waiting for the ball (er, baby) to drop, you may have to keep playing the waiting game a little bit longer.
Why am I overdue?

We know it doesn’t provide much relief but, the reason why your baby is overdue isn’t usually known. ACOG states that some factors can increase the likelihood of going over your due date including, being a first-time mom, having a boy, and having had a postterm pregnancy before.
Is my baby safe?

Going into labor shortly after the 40th week mark is past is rarely harmful to you or your child. However, as the weeks go on, the likelihood of certain complications can increase, such as meconium aspiration syndrome (when baby inhales their fecal matter) or low amniotic fluid. To be on the safe side, your doctor or midwife will start doing more checks to see how she or he is doing and discuss induction if recommended.
Will I need to see my practitioner?

Your OB-GYN or midwife will want to see you more often at this point, to keep a close eye on your baby and make sure everything is going OK. Your practitioner will use some or all of the following to monitor you and your baby:
Kick count:

Your practitioner will likely ask you to pay attention to how often your baby moves, either informally or to actually track the number of kicks/movements per hour. You’ll need to report anything out of the ordinary, just in case.
Nonstress test:
Also known as the NST, you’ll be hooked up to a machine that will monitor your baby’s heart rate for a set period of time (usually 20 minutes).
Ultrasound:

Used to measure baby's size, position, breathing rate, heartbeat, and body movements. Ultrasound is also useful in determining how much amniotic fluid surrounding your baby. There is a possibility of low fluid later in pregnancy that you’ll want to avoid.
Biophysical profile:
A BPP uses both a fetal heart rate monitor and an ultrasound to check on heart rate, breathing, and movement of your baby as well as the amount of amniotic fluid.
Depending on the results of these tests, your doctor may consider inducing labor for the safety of your baby.
Is there anything I can do to speed things along?

Once you’ve hit the 40-week mark, many pregnant women are both more than ready to evict their tenant and excited to meet them. While there are countless opinions of “tried and true” ways to naturally get things moving, there isn’t much scientific proof that any of them work.
How do I deal with waiting?

Hang in there! Many moms find it helpful to stay busy, either by working or finishing up odds and ends before baby arrives. Try to find ways to enjoy this time—maybe a walk in nature or some meditation. Keep your eyes on the prize, and remember that this period won’t last much longer. Before you know it you’ll finally get to meet your sweet baby.
Sources
The Institute for Quality and Efficiency in Health Care. Pregnancy and birth: When your baby’s due date has been passed. September 2008 (last update March 2018).
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK279571/
. Accessed December 18, 2019.
The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. Frequently Asked Questions: Labor, Delivery, and Postpartum care. When Pregnancy Goes Past Your Due Date. June 2017.
https://www.acog.org/Patients/FAQs/When-Pregnancy-Goes-Past-Your-Due-Date?IsMobileSet=false#causes
. Accessed December 18, 2019.
The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists: Committee on Obstetric Practice Society for Maternal-Fetal Medicine. Definition of Term Pregnancy. Number 579, November 2013.
https://www.acog.org/Clinical-Guidance-and-Publications/Committee-Opinions/Committee-on-Obstetric-Practice/Definition-of-Term-Pregnancy?IsMobileSet=false
. Accessed December 18, 2019.
Wang, M. Fontaine, P. The American Academy of Family Physicians. American Family Physician. August 2014, 1;90: 160-165.
https://www.aafp.org/afp/2014/0801/p160.html
. Accessed December 18, 2019.
Khambalia, AZ. Roberts, CL.Nguyen, M. Algert, CS. Nicholl, MC. Morris, J. International Journal of Gynecology & Obstetrics. November 2013, 105-9. Epub August 2013.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23932061
. Accessed December 22, 2019.

title.en-US: Missing your pre-mom life?

content.value: For many moms, one of the hardest aspects of new motherhood is mourning your “old life” and feeling a loss of independence. Gone are the days of grabbing your phone and keys and running out the door at a moment’s notice to meet your friends for brunch or happy hour. Instead, there are diaper bags and infant car seats tagging along, and outings need to be scheduled in-between naps and feedings and even then, may end in a blowout.

If the round-the-clock grind of caring for a newborn is starting to take its toll, leaving you second-guessing your decision to have a baby, remember you are not alone and you’re not a bad mom for feeling this way either. According to the American Pregnancy Association, approximately 50 to 75 percent of new mothers will experience some negative feelings after giving birth (known informally as the “baby blues”). Here are some ways to get through this period of change and start feeling like yourself again.
Make time for your needs

It’s important to remember that you have needs, too. New moms can feel cut off from people and activities they used to enjoy because of the sheer volume of to-do’s that come with taking care of an infant. If it seems like all the fun stuff has been replaced with endless feedings and diaper changes, you could probably use a break to recharge your battery.

Feeling guilty about sneaking away for a cup of coffee? Don’t. Because being a “good mom” means taking care of you, too. To make sure it happens, talk to your partner or a family member about a scheduled time that’s all yours every week. Even if it’s just an hour (heck, we’ll take 30 minutes!) stick to it. You could go for a walk, a coffee, or simply take a nice long shower (remember those?).
Lean on your support squad

Asking for help is not a weakness. Think of the best boss you’ve ever had. Did they do everything themselves? More likely, they delegated responsibilities and made sure that everyone on the team pitched in. That’s the best way to avoid burnout and the same goes on the homefront. When people offer, “let me know if there’s anything I can do to help,” take them up on it! Even having someone keep an eye on your baby so you can cover basics (take a nap, shower, or run an errand) can do a lot to elevate your outlook and makes your friends and family feel helpful (which makes them feel good!).
Bring baby on an outing

It’s normal to feel a little stir-crazy from being pent up in the house and at the same time feel overwhelmed at the thought of leaving it with your infant in tow. Realize that although you need to add in extra prep time to get out the door (and pack what seems like a million things), it’s worth it for the change in scenery. Sometimes mixing up your routine and getting a bit of fresh air can give you a new perspective. The more you get out, the easier it will become, and this will also be good practice for when you have to go back to work.
Set a limit on baby talk

There are times when we all need to get things off our chest and talking with other moms who know that the #momstruggleisreal can really help. But it’s also important to make sure you can have conversations that don’t involve baby from time to time, too. If you manage to meet up for that coffee or lunch with a friend, show them your latest adorable baby pic and then say, “I’d really love to talk about what you’re reading / the last movie you’ve seen / new favorite album / what projects you’re working on” so you can tap back into different aspects of your personality and interests beyond momhood.
Is it something else?

Perhaps what you’re feeling is more than just a little “off.” While the baby blues tend to pass in a few weeks after birth, perinatal mood and anxiety disorders (PMADs) such as postpartum depression, anxiety or PTSD can last longer and be more severe in their symptoms. According to the American Pregnancy Association, postpartum depression (PPD) affects about 1 in 7 new mothers. The shifting of hormones following delivery is partly to blame, along with sleep deprivation, inadequate nutrition, isolation, poor partner support, health issues of mom or baby, a high-need infant, or other major stressors.
Thankfully, mood disorders like PPD are fully treatable. And due to increased awareness, more women are coming forward and getting the help they need early on, before their depression gets worse.

Taking care of a new baby is hard work. Go easy on yourself and remember that this time is temporary and before you know it, you will be looking back on it. Whether you think you’re just adjusting, or it’s something more serious, we’re here for you. You can talk to a Maven Mental Health Specialist anytime about anything that’s on your mind.
Find a Maven provider who is available now.
Sources
American Pregnancy Association. Do I Have The Baby Blues Or Postpartum Depression? August 2016.
https://americanpregnancy.org/first-year-of-life/baby-blues-or-postpartum-depression/
. Accessed January 8, 2020.

title.en-US: How to tell if your baby is happy

content.value: Happy baby, happy...everyone! In these early days, it can be hard to read your baby’s cues and to know for sure what they’re feeling or what they need. Some days your baby may seem happy and other days it can be hard to know if they even like you! (Trust us, they do.) Until they’re truly able to flash you a gummy grin or let out a big belly laugh, focus on doing your best to meet your baby’s basic needs. Because a baby who is safe, warm, fed, and well-slept will one day be a very happy baby indeed.
Baby’s basic needs for happiness
Eat, sleep, poop repeat is the name of the game for newborns. If you’re keeping up with the big three, your baby will be a happy bundle.
Round-the-clock feedings:

Your baby doesn’t care if it’s day or night, they will likely need to eat all day long in these first few weeks. Expect to feed baby 1-3 ounces every few hours. It can be hard to keep up with this demand, but it will slowly wind down and if you ever need any tips on feeding or lactation support, don’t hesitate to talk to a Maven Lactation Consultant.
Frequent diaper changes:

On average, newborns produce 8-12 wet diapers a day. And you’ll soon find yourself preoccupied with tracking your tiny human’s bowel movements as a good indicator of how much they’re eating and general health. Keep in mind that breastfed baby poop is generally a softer consistency than formula-fed babies and frequency varies. Some babies poop eight times a day, and some poop every 3-4 days! Color ranges widely as well, with greens and yellows being most common.
Lots of sleep:

Your baby will be a sleepy monkey for some time, snoozing up to 18 hours a day—thought not necessarily in long stretches. Expect naps of 1-2 hours. They will gradually stay awake longer and sleep for larger stretches.
How to know if baby is eating enough
General rule of thumb: a fed baby is a happy baby. Here’s some advice to ease your mind.
Don’t panic:

According to the American Pregnancy Association, all newborns will lose some weight in their first week of life. Formula-fed babies will lose an average of 5% of their birth weight and breastfed babies will lose an average of 7-10%.
Visit the pediatrician:

Your baby’s weight will be carefully monitored at your pediatrician’s office, so be sure to keep your appointments. The rule of thumb is that your baby should be back up to their birth weight at around the two week mark. If they’re not gaining, your pediatrician will work with you on a plan to ensure they are getting the nutrition they need.
Check the diaper pail:
Here’s where your diaper tracking comes in handy. Count how many they’ve gone through in a day. If it’s significantly less than 8-12, speak to your pediatrician.
Reach out when you need help:

For breastfeeding moms, there are a number of ways you can find a lactation consultant. You may have had a session with a lactation consultant before you left the hospital whom you can call directly. Ask friends for recommendations in your area if you’d like to see someone in person. And know that Maven Lactation Consultants or Maven Pediatricians are here for you 24/7, just book a video chat or send a message anytime.
My baby won’t stop crying! Could it be colic?
The definition of colic:
Crying spells are normal—it's how babies communicate. But if your baby cries constantly or for 3 hours a day (usually in a row) after 3 pm for more than 3 days a week, speak to your pediatrician.
Timeline:
Colic usually rears its head in the second week and tapers off around the three-month mark.
Mystery condition:
The jury is out on what causes colic and why some babies get it. Some experts blame gas; some chalk it up to baby’s nervous system. Unfortunately, the true cause is unknown.
Soothing strategies:

If checking off your baby’s basic needs (see above) doesn’t help, try other comforting techniques like white noise, swings, rocking, car rides, or bouncing on a yoga ball. If your baby isn’t soothed, speak to your pediatrician or a pediatrician on Maven for help. Additionally, always talk to your baby’s doctor before giving them over-the-counter gas drops, gripe water, or other remedies.
Just remember:
As you get to know your baby, you’ll soon pick up on their cues and soon enough you’ll be rewarded with that first coo and a first smile!

Don’t forget that your happiness is important, too. If you are feeling overwhelmed or sad, don’t be afraid to ask for help and support. Your Maven Care Advocate is here for you 24/7 and can connect you with a pediatrician to answer any questions you might have about your baby at any time.

title.en-US: First trimester warning signs to watch for

content.value: To say that your body will go through many changes during pregnancy...is an understatement. While it can be fascinating to see how it knows just what to do, sometimes all these changes can leave you wondering which ones are a normal part of the process (hemorrhoids, who knew?!) and what’s a sign that something may be amiss.

Here are some key warning signs to watch out for in the first trimester—including possible causes and what to do if you’re experiencing them. If you ever have a symptom you’re unsure of, don’t hesitate to contact your OB-GYN or midwife, or talk to a Maven provider. When it comes to you and your baby, being safe is better than keeping symptoms to yourself.
Vaginal bleeding

Vaginal bleeding in the first trimester is fairly common. In fact, about 15-25% of women experience it according to The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. It can be light or heavy, intermittent or constant, accompanied by pain or painless. (Confusing, we know!) Here’s what you need to know to be safe.
What to do

If you are experiencing any bleeding during the first trimester—from spotting to about the same as your period—contact your doctor. They can examine you and perform tests to rule out any of the below. If you are bleeding heavier than a period, go directly to the emergency room.
Possible issues:
Ectopic pregnancy

Ectopic pregnancy is when the fertilized egg attaches somewhere other than the uterus—often in the fallopian tube—and cannot develop safely as a result. About 1 out of every 50 pregnancies is ectopic according to the American Pregnancy Association. Ectopic pregnancies are sometimes accompanied by sharp abdominal pain (often on one side). The doctor will recommend an ultrasound and measure your pregnancy hormone (beta-hCG) to see if it’s rising appropriately. Ectopic pregnancies can be life-threatening, so if you have bleeding and pain, go to the Emergency Room.
Miscarriage

A miscarriage is when a pregnancy ends on its own within the first 20 weeks. Either the threat of a miscarriage, an inevitable miscarriage, or a completed miscarriage can result in bleeding. About 10-25% of all known pregnancies end in miscarriage, with about 80% of miscarriages happening in the first trimester, according to The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. While this stat isn’t the most comforting, it can help to know that you aren’t alone if you do experience one. Your doctor may use an ultrasound or a pelvic exam to determine if you are having a miscarriage.
Implantation bleeding

Implantation bleeding is when a fertilized egg attaches to the lining of the uterus. This can be a normal part of the process and can occur approximately 10-14 days after conceiving. However, not everyone experiences implantation bleeding and it is not something your doctor can test for. If your bleeding is light, you have no sharp pain, it occurs roughly during this timeline, and your doctor doesn’t detect any other source for it, it may be implantation bleeding.
Other cervical, uterine, or vaginal conditions
Your doctor may examine you, perform an ultrasound, or check your vaginal fluid to rule our inflammation, infection, polyps, or fibroids.
Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD)

GTD is the name for a group of tumors with abnormal cell growth that can be found in the uterus. GTDs are rare and, according to the American Cancer Society, most are not cancerous and do not spread. GTDs can be diagnosed by an ultrasound and performing a blood test to check for the pregnancy hormone (beta-hCG). This hormone is typically abnormally high if a woman has GTD.
Nausea or vomiting

Unfortunately, for many women the first trimester can feel like sailing on rough seas. Thanks to an increase in hormones, nausea is very common in pregnancy. In fact, up to 80% of all pregnant women experience it at some point according to research published in JAMA Internal Medicine. Most women begin noticing it around 5-6 weeks gestation and peaking at around 9 weeks. But what’s the difference between common “morning sickness” and something more serious? Read on to find out.
What to do

Some women experience slight queasiness during the first trimester while others struggle to keep anything down! Try to eat small portions of bland foods throughout the day and be sure to stay hydrated. Even if you the mere thought of food makes you cringe, an empty stomach can make nausea worse and drinking water is absolutely essential to you and your baby. If you are unable to eat due to severe nausea or vomiting, contact your doctor right away. And if you’ve been vomiting and dry heaving for longer than 12 hours and cannot get in touch with your doctor, go to the Emergency Room.
Possible issues:
Hyperemesis gravidarum

If you are experiencing severe nausea and vomiting, this is called hyperemesis gravidarum. If it’s mild, your doctor may recommend diet changes. If it’s severe, you may need to visit the hospital for intravenous (IV) fluids to ensure that you’re hydrated. Unfortunately, this condition cannot be prevented, but your doctor can help you manage it and make sure you get the essential nutrients and hydration you need.
Conditions of the thyroid, liver, or pancreas
Excess nausea and vomiting can be signs of something wrong with your thyroid, liver, pancreas. Your doctor will commonly check these organs to rule out any issues there.
Painful urination

Pregnant and postpartum women are at a greater risk for developing conditions that cause painful urination, thanks to changes happening to the urinary tract, a compromised immune system, and (as always) hormones.
What to do

If you experience painful urination, have trouble urinating, or feel a burning sensation when urinating, tell your doctor right away. It could be a small infection that could become much worse if left untreated. Do not take any over-the-counter medications as they may not be safe while pregnant. If you have painful urination and a fever or nausea, go to the emergency room right away. If you have any medication allergies, be sure to tell your doctor.
Possible issues:
Urinary tract infection (UTI)

A urinary tract infection is exactly as it sounds, an infection that can occur in your urinary system. UTIs are caused by bacteria and typically occur in the urethra and bladder, but if left untreated it can spread to your kidneys and become quite serious. Studies show that 2-7% of pregnant women have bacteria in their urine, but don’t have any symptoms and that 20-35% of those women will go on to develop a UTI. Some studies state that as many as 8% of pregnant women will experience a UTI. But the good news is that, when treated early, UTIs can usually be resolved with antibiotics and fluids.
Cystitis
Cystitis is when your bladder becomes inflamed (or swollen and irritated) and is usually caused by a UTI.
Sources
American Pregnancy Association. Urinary Tract Infection During Pregnancy.
https://americanpregnancy.org/pregnancy-complications/urinary-tract-infections-during-pregnancy/

American Pregnancy Association. Ectopic Pregnancy.

. Accessed December 22, 2019.

https://www.cancer.org/cancer/gestational-trophoblastic-disease/about/what-is-gtd.html.
