title.en-US: Is it possible to hold my baby too much?

content.value: Newborns and cradling go together like toddlers and tantrums. But the fact remains that a lot of newborn care is just about comforting your little one in your arms. But by now, you may have been cautioned with unsolicited advice that you’ll “spoil” your baby by holding them “too much” or by giving them too much attention. The TLDR is that you can safely ignore the naysayers and keep the cuddle marathon going strong. Here’s why:
Science supports it

According to a 2017 study of premature babies, positive touch is critical for newborns’ brain development, especially when looking at preterm babies being cared for in hospitals’ Newborn Intensive Care Units (NICUs). This study, and others like it, have reinforced that newborns benefit from gentle touch, being held, and other positive stimulation that comes with holding, rocking, and cooing to your little one.
“Kangaroo care” is a thing

While a lot of the research focuses on babies born prematurely, there are studies showing that full-term infants thrive on touch, too. In response, hospitals and birthing centers are placing emphasis on what’s called “kangaroo care”—or skin-to-skin contact—to promote early parent-child bonding. This type of contact involves a baby wearing only a diaper snuggling into a parent’s bare chest (with a blanket to cover them).

In many hospitals, skin-to-skin is practiced immediately after birth (or as soon as possible) and in the days that follow. In addition to boosting brain development, research points to a number of other health benefits that skin-to-skin contact provides the infant: stabilizing their heart and respiratory rates, improving oxygen saturation rates, regulating body temperature. And for the parent, well there’s no better feeling than cuddling your little one.
Babies have needs

Newborn babies are completely dependent on their caregivers to meet their needs, which are the same as wants at this age: food, sleep, and diaper changes are just as important are comfort, security, and love. While some people might tell you that you’re giving your baby “too much” attention, early child development experts will say quite the opposite: by responding to your baby’s needs, you are helping them feel secure and creating a healthy bond. This can help develop their sense of trust in their parents and create a foundation for self-confidence as they grow.
The takeaway:
Hold newborn baby as much as you’d like. (But don’t feel guilty if you have to put them down in a safe place once in a while either!)
Sources
Maitre, NL. Key, AP. Choma, OD., et al. Current Biology. The Dual Nature of Early-Life Experience on Somatosensory Processing in the Human Infant Brain. Volume 27, Issue 7, p 1048-1054. April 2017.
https://www.cell.com/current-biology/fulltext/S0960-9822%2817%2930204-X
. Accessed January 8, 2020.
March of Dimes. Kangaroo care.
https://www.marchofdimes.org/baby/kangaroo-care.aspx
. Accessed January 8, 2020.
Campbell-Yeo, ML. Disher, CT. Johnston, C. Pediatric Health, Medicine and Therapeutics 2015. Understanding kangaroo care and its benefits to preterm infants.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5683265/
. Accessed January 8, 2020.
Moore, ER. Bergman, N. Anderson, GC. Medley, N. Cochrane Database System Reviews. Early skin-to-skin contact for mothers and their healthy newborn infants. November 2016.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27885658
. Accessed January 8, 2020.

title.en-US: How to safely dress baby in all seasons

content.value: Baby has arrived at last, and you can’t wait to wrap them in all those adorable swaddles you bought months ago. Problem is, it’s summer and the temps are scorchingly hot or it’s winter and a swaddle won’t cut it. What to do? Here are some guidelines for keeping baby comfortable—and safe—in every season.
In the summer:
Strip down
In extreme heat, just a diaper or onesie is a good way to go.
Stay cool
Make sure that baby’s room is well ventilated with a fan or air conditioning.
Check for sweat
If you’re not sure whether your baby is too warm, feel the nape of their neck. If it’s sweating, they’re too hot.
Be shady
When outside, keep baby out of the sun (they can’t wear sunscreen until 6 months old), and cover their head with a sun hat.
Use cotton or muslin
Cotton is a great choice for clothing and muslin is great for swaddles. Both are breathable and can help prevent baby from overheating.
In the winter:
Comfort is key
While it might be tempting to pile on the clothes, too many extra layers can make baby hot or uncomfortable.
Set the thermostat
Unsure about whether to crank up the heat? Experts recommend an ideal room temperature between 68 and 72 degrees F.
Ban the blanket

Resist the urge to cover your little one with a blanket—it can put them at risk for suffocation or overheating. Instead, break out those sleep sacks and swaddles, which are designed to keep baby cozy, warm, and safe.
Venturing out

In cold climates, consider investing in a one-piece fleece layer for baby. Avoid the temptation to dress them in big, puffy coats for going anywhere in the car. It will make getting the car seat straps around baby more difficult and could jeopardize safe car seat riding. Always take any coats or snowsuits off before buckling a baby or child into the carseat. Other options: start the car and let it warm up first or try a car seat winter cover or blanket.
Layer up

Layering can help you better maintain your baby’s body temperature by making it easy to add or remove items as you go in and out of changing climates. Wool can be a great first layer for added breathability.
All seasons:
Practice safe sleep

To avoid the risk of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS), the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) recommends that babies be placed on their backs in their cribs or bassinets for sleep and to avoid using blankets, toys, or bumpers in the crib.
Safe swaddle

Make sure that your baby is always on their back when swaddled. The swaddle should not be too tight or make it hard for baby to breathe or move their hips. When your baby looks like they’re trying to roll over, it’s time to stop swaddling and switch to sleep sacks.
Cover up
Most babies don’t like having a cold head or feet. Try lightweight cotton hats and socks (as long as they will tolerate wearing them).
When in doubt, follow this rule of thumb:

Babies are just like us! They don’t like being too hot or too cold. But they are also more sensitive to changes in temperature, so keep checking in on to make sure they’re comfortable no matter what the climate.

title.en-US: I have separation anxiety

content.value: You spent the past year or so growing your baby and now you’re getting to know them on “the outside.” So it’s only natural that you’re feeling nervous (and/or worried, sad, or guilty) when you have to be away from your baby for a length of time.

You’ve probably heard about babies having “separation anxiety.” This is when babies and young children don’t like having their parents out of their sight, or being apart from them. On the other side of the coin there is such a thing as maternal separation anxiety as well, and it can be a tough part of motherhood.

For many moms, this type of anxiety rears its head when returning to work and/or facing that first drop-off at daycare. For others, it comes with the changes brought on when a little one is going to school for the first time. And for some moms, just being apart for any length of time can be a struggle.
Here are some tips that can help:
Give it some time

A lot of the feelings associated with anxiety (fear, worry, nervousness) stem from anticipation of the unknown. You might be dreading that big day you trust your baby in someone else’s care, only to find that when it actually happens it might not be so bad. If you’ve been back at work and have already been doing drop-offs and still feel miserable about it, try to look at it from a new angle—working is another way of providing for your child. Whatever the situation, try to give yourself some time and patience to start feeling better naturally. It could take a few weeks or months.
Get to know your caregiver

If your anxiety comes from misgivings about your choice of childcare, take some time to ease your fears by transitioning into a full work day over a few weeks, if possible. If that’s not doable, see if you can spend a few hours there with your baby before you return to work to see the caregivers in action. Hopefully your caregiver will understand your concerns and work to make you feel more assured. And if your gut just doesn’t feel right, trust it and look for childcare that will put you more at ease.
Talk about it

Acknowledge your feelings and take comfort in knowing that they are a natural part of doing your job to love and protect your little one. It’s normal to feel sad or worried when you’re away from your baby. Reach out to other moms in your life or coworkers who have been there. Hearing how someone else worked through this difficult time (especially other new moms) can help you feel less on your own. If you need some assistance in talking through these painful emotions,
message a provider on Maven or book a video chat
anytime to talk it through.
Try a new morning routine

Missing that one-on-one time with your little one? Try getting up a bit earlier so you have some dedicated time for baby snuggles in the morning. This can help you and your little one start on the right foot and help you both from feeling rushed out the door.
Just remember:

Your mental health is important! You know how flight attendants say to put on your oxygen mask first before assisting others? First and foremost, you need to make sure you’re doing OK. If you’re feeling anxiety, depression, or other emotions that are affecting your daily life, please know you don’t have to suffer alone. Maven Care Advocates are available 24/7 and can connect you to someone who can help you get back to feeling like yourself.

title.en-US: Your Rh factor test, explained

content.value: First thing’s first—Rh testing can be confusing. If you’re wondering what this test is all about, or what your results mean, we’re here to help break it down.
What is Rh?

Rh stands for Rhesus. Rhesus is a protein found on the surface of red blood cells that you inherit genetically from your parents. You are either Rh(+) or Rh(-). If you’re Rh(-) that means that you don’t have the Rhesus protein. If you’re Rh(+) that means that you do have the Rhesus protein. By itself, being positive or negative doesn’t matter much—but being Rh(-) can matter to your pregnancy (and future pregnancies).
How can my Rh status affect my pregnancy?

If you are Rh(-) but the father of your baby is Rh(+), your baby may be Rh(+) as well. This is called Rh incompatibility or Rh disease. If you’re Rh(-) and your baby is Rh(+), your immune system may start to form antibodies to your baby’s Rh(+) blood.

The placenta acts as a natural barrier and your blood shouldn’t mix with your baby’s blood, but sometimes small amounts can cross during prenatal tests or while delivering your baby. And if it does, it may affect future pregnancies. Here’s how: if your body has made antibodies to your baby’s Rh(+) blood during this pregnancy and you have another pregnancy where that baby is also Rh(+), your immune system may use those antibodies to “attack” their red blood cells while they are in the womb. This can lead to life-threatening anemia for your developing baby.
What is the RhoGAM shot and who should get it?

Because we can’t know with 100% certainty what the Rh status of your baby is until after they are born, if you are Rh(-) you will need to get the RhoGAM shot just in case. The shot is comprised of immune globulin, which prevents a woman’s body from making antibodies if she is Rh(-) and her developing baby is Rh(+). If, after birth, your baby is in fact found to be Rh(+), then you’ll likely get another RhoGAM shot. The shot is safe and has no side effects other than discomfort at the injection site.
In addition to testing Rh(-), The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommends that women receive the RhoGAM shot for the following reasons:
You have had a spontaneous miscarriage or a D&C (dilation and currettage) for a miscarriage. If you have a miscarriage, be sure to have your ER or doctor check your Rh status.
You’re experiencing bleeding during pregnancy
You have an amniocentesis or Chorionic villus sampling during pregnancy
You have an ectopic pregnancy
You have been in a car accident or other trauma which could have lead to mixing of maternal and fetal blood
Can’t we just test the father?

You may be wondering...why not just test the father to know for sure if your baby could be Rh(+)? Because there are instances where the presumed biological father is not, in fact, the biological father, doctors err on the side of caution and give every woman who is Rh(-) the RhoGAM shot. This helps ensure that they do not miss the opportunity to protect a future pregnancy.
Are my baby and my future pregnancies safe?

If you’re Rh(-) and receive a RhoGAM shot during pregnancy and after birth chances are high that your baby and future pregnancies will be protected. If you missed a RhoGAM shot in a previous pregnancy, and your body did develop antibodies and you have a future pregnancy that is Rh(+), you will be considered high risk. To protect your developing baby from anemia, your doctor will likely recommend extra ultrasounds and testing to monitor them and help ensure that you have a healthy pregnancy.

title.en-US: Top foods to avoid while pregnant

content.value: Is it the dirty 30 or the safe 8? Are all cheeses off limits or are some okay? With so many eating “rules” during pregnancy, it can be hard to keep it all straight. Here’s a quick list to keep handy when you’re in the grocery aisle (or treating yourself!).
Certain fish
Avoid these high-mercury fish: shark, swordfish, king mackerel, tilefish, bigeye tuna, marlin, orange roughy.
Avoid undercooked or raw fish as they can cause infection.
Cook all seafood to 145 degrees F, cook smoked seafood to 165 degrees F.
Raw eggs
Avoid raw eggs as they may contain salmonella.
Sprouts
Raw sprouts are dangerous for pregnant women as they have been shown to have high rates of listeria infection.
Unwashed produce
Make sure to wash your fruits and vegetables thoroughly in pregnancy to wash off any contaminants as well as bacteria.
Unpasteurized anything

Unpasteurized milk, cheese or fruit juice can be contaminated with Listeria and E. coli. and have been associated with an increased risk of miscarriage. Always make sure the label says “made with pasteurized milk.”
Certain pre-made salads
Avoid meat or seafood salad like the ones you can get at the grocery store or deli as they may contain listeria bacteria.
Processed meats

Avoid hot dogs or other processed meats. 
If you do eat deli meats, heat them to 165 degrees F.
Alcohol
Sorry, but there is no “safe” level or amount of alcohol in pregnancy.
Processed junk food
Fat is essential in pregnancy, but what pregnant women and their babies need are foods that are rich in macro and micronutrients. Processed food is often full of fat, carbohydrates, sugar and salt.

title.en-US: Do I really need the Tdap shot?

content.value: Pregnancy means many (many, many) visits to the doctor’s office. Between the amount of times you have to provide urine samples to all the blood tests, you may be wondering... “Do I really need the Tdap shot?” And the short answer is a resounding yes!

If you’ve ever heard a seal bark, that’s what it sounds like when a young infant has pertussis. Commonly called “whooping cough,” pertussis is an infection that’s not only heart-breaking to hear, it is very dangerous for infants less than 3 months of age and can even be life-threatening. The Tdap vaccine can help protect your child from pertussis by passing on the antibodies before your baby is even born. Because your baby will not be able to be vaccinated for pertussis until they are two months old, getting the vaccine yourself is the best way to lower their risk of contracting this highly infectious bacteria in their first few months of life.

In fact, the Tdap vaccine protects your baby from three infections: Tetanus, Diphtheria, and Pertussis (hence the name!). Diptheria is a bacterial infection that infects mucous membranes and can also cause difficulty breathing and tetanus is a muscle-paralyzing infection that you can when bacteria enters a deep cut (the kind you might get from a dog bite or stepping on a rusty nail).

It’s best to get the Tdap vaccine between 27 and 36 weeks of pregnancy. Your partner, grandparents, nanny, postpartum doula, or anyone else who will be holding or helping to care for your baby after birth should get one as well. Even if you had the Tdap vaccine in a previous pregnancy, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommends that pregnant women get it during each pregnancy to maximize protection for your newborn.
With your help, your little one will be protected from dangerous infections from day one.
Sources
Immunization for Women.
http://www.immunizationforwomen.org
. Accessed December 23, 2019.
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Vaccines and Preventable Disease: Tetanus.
https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/tetanus/index.html?CDC_AA_refVal=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cdc.gov%2Fvaccines%2Fvpd-vac%2Ftetanus%2Fdefault.htm
. Accessed December 23, 2019.
The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. Tdap Vaccination During Pregnancy.
https://www.acog.org/Womens-Health/Tdap-Vaccination-During-Pregnancy?IsMobileSet=false
. Accessed December 23, 2019.

title.en-US: Could you be anemic?

content.value: You already know that eating a healthy diet is an important part of having a healthy pregnancy, but how do you know if you’re getting enough of the right nutrients? Testing, testing! Around weeks 24-28, your OB-GYN or midwife will likely test you for anemia. What’s anemia and why is this testing important? Read on to find out!
Why anemia testing is done

Mild anemia is common during pregnancy because of an increase in blood volume (your body produces additional blood to support the growth of your baby). When your body is too low in iron, it cannot produce enough healthy red blood cells. Sometimes there are other causes for anemia, like sickle cell disease or thalassemia, but nutritional deficiency is the most common cause.

If untreated, anemia during pregnancy can increase the risks of premature birth, having a baby who is low birth weight, having a baby with delays in development, or needing a blood transfusion during delivery if significant blood is lost.
How it’s done

Your doctor will perform a blood test to check for anemia. This test will usually include measuring the percentage of red blood cells and how much hemoglobin is present (hemoglobin is an iron-rich protein in red blood cells).
What the results mean

If you have low levels of either red blood cells or low levels of hemoglobin, your doctor may perform further testing to rule out any other causes. If it is determined that you are significantly anemic, your doctor will check your iron levels.
What to ask your doctor

If testing confirms that you are anemic, ask your doctor if there are any diet changes you can make to boost your iron supply. Because it’s easier for your body to absorb iron and other vitamins and minerals from food, your doctor may recommend eating iron-rich foods such as spinach, eggs, broccoli and lentils (to name a few). If iron supplements are recommended, ask your doctor about a supplement or syrup that also contains vitamin C to help improve your body’s ability to absorb iron. Want advice on the best iron-rich foods? Talk to a Maven Prenatal Nutritionist who can help you make healthy meal plans and snack ideas over video chat.
One more thing...

Women lose around 300 ccs (or about one soda can) of blood during delivery, so it’s especially important to make sure you have enough red blood cells before delivery day. Being tested for anemia can help you make those important changes that can make a big difference starting today.
Remember, if you ever have questions before or after any prenatal test (we know there are a lot!), ask your doctor or an OB-GYN on Maven. You deserve to have all the information you need to have a healthy pregnancy.
Sources
Mayo Clinic. Healthy Lifestyle: Pregnancy week by week. Iron deficiency anemia during pregnancy: Prevention tips.
https://www.mayoclinic.org/healthy-lifestyle/pregnancy-week-by-week/in-depth/anemia-during-pregnancy/art-20114455
. Accessed December 27, 2019.
American Pregnancy Association. Anemia During Pregnancy.
https://americanpregnancy.org/pregnancy-concerns/anemia-during-pregnancy/
. Accessed December 27, 2019.

title.en-US: What is C-section recovery really like?

content.value: As you wait for your little one to finally make their debut, you may be going through your list of to do’s. While getting the nursery ready is high on the list, one of the very best ways you can prepare is to learn about the recovery process—including recovering from a cesarean. Whether you have a cesarean scheduled or you’re planning on a vaginal birth, it’s important to be fully informed about different birth experiences and the recovery process just in case. Here’s everything you need to know about C-section recovery.
What happens immediately after a cesarean?

After a cesarean you will be taken to a postoperative recovery room. Here, nurses will measure your vitals (heart rate and blood pressure) as well as your uterus’ ability to contract, your bleeding, and how much urine your kidneys are making. All of these help doctors know that you aren’t having any immediate postoperative complications.
How long will the numbness last?

For most women, numbness will wear off within an hour after you are in recovery. You may also experience shaking. This is a common side effect of the regional anesthesia given before your operation. Ask for blankets in the recovery room (they can often provide heated ones!).
Can I breastfeed my baby after a C-section?

Most hospitals support immediate skin-to-skin time in the operating room and breastfeeding in the postpartum recovery room, so you will likely be able to breastfeed your baby right away! The common medications that are given for postoperative recovery from a cesarean are safe for breastfeeding. If you have questions about medications and breastfeeding, visit the National Institute of Health drugs and lactation database or make an appointment with one of Maven’s lactation consultants for all your breastfeeding questions.
What kind of pain medications are given?

In the hour or so after surgery, the spinal anesthesia will begin wearing off. Many women who have had a cesarean will have also received long-acting (24-hours) pain relief through medication that was added when they got their spinal or epidural anesthesia. Some women will also be placed on a patient-controlled analgesia device (press a button, receive pain medication). Oral medications aren’t recommended immediately after surgery as many women have nausea and may not be able to keep medications down. Other pain medications that may be given (or requested) are IV acetaminophen (Tylenol), and IV keterolac (Toradol).
When will my catheter be removed?

During surgery a catheter is placed into the urethra to help drain urine. As soon as you are able to walk to the bathroom with assistance, your catheter will be removed. This usually happens in the first 12 hours after a cesarean.
Will I experience vaginal bleeding?

Yes, you will have vaginal bleeding after surgery and for several weeks after. This is your body’s way of clearing out the blood and tissue from your pregnancy. The bleeding should become gradually lighter.
When can I eat after surgery?

While eating may sound unappetizing after surgery, taking some sips of water or juice can help stimulate the bowels to return to normal function. And studies show that drinking or eating early on can actually speed recovery. Likely your body will tell you when and if you are ready to eat, but 6 hours after surgery is the time that will commonly be recommended by your nurse or OB-GYN.
Will I have gas issues?

It’s common for the bowels to be “sluggish” after major abdominal surgery. It can take over 24 hour for the bowels to start moving or “passing gas” after a cesarean section. Standing and walking can help the gas to pass. There are also medications that can help, and eating and drinking tends to speed things along as well.
When can I shower after surgery

Talk to your doctor about when it is safe to shower in the hospital, but it is usually safe after bandaging from the incision site has been removed. Run warm water over the incision with gentle soap, but avoid scrubbing. Pat dry with a clean towel or bandages. Do not scrub or use a dirty towel to avoid irritation or infection. If needed, your partner may be able to assist you or you may ask for the assistance of your nurse.
Will I have stitches?

All the stitches will dissolve (phew!). Some OB-GYNs use dissolvable stitches under the skin that you can’t see and they will dissolve. Others place staples that will need to be removed ( by the fifth day after the operation). Others will use stitches that you cannot see in addition to dissolvable glue on top. Bottom line, unless your doctor says differently, you can assume that your stitches will dissolve.
Will there be swelling?

Many women in pregnancy, after birth, and after surgery experience bloat and water retention (even more so if they had preeclampsia). Rest assured that this is normal and that the best treatment is time. In the meantime, compression socks can help with swollen feet and legs and, while it sounds counterintuitive, walking also helps. It can take 7-10 days to begin to see the water retention fade.
When can I go home?
After surgery, you will likely remain in the hospital for 2-4 days to ensure that you are stable and recovering.
Will I be able to lift my baby?

Yes. But lifting your baby is the most weight you should lift for the first 6-10 weeks after surgery. Around 10 pounds (or a gallon of milk) is the most that it is safe to lift. If your baby weighs more than 10 pounds, you can still lift them, but be careful to use proper lifting technique. When your baby is in their car seat they will usually weigh more than 10 pounds, so be sure to ask someone else to lift them—especially when you take them to their first doctor’s appointment in the days and weeks after your cesarean.
Will my movement be limited?

For awhile after surgery, sitting up will be painful. While it will aid your recovery to walk a little more each day, you may continue to need help getting up or down from a chair, a bed, a couch, etc. Driving is not recommended for at least two weeks and at any time while taking opioid pain medications.
How can I help my incision heal?

The best way to help your incision heal is to drink lots of water (helps healing), eat a balanced diet, and, if you can, get some sleep (you might need help from your partner or a family member to sneak this one in!). You can wash your incision with warm water and then pat dry with a towel. No special cleansers are necessary. If you notice swelling, redness, or pus, call your doctor right away.
Can I exercise after a C-section?

Because a cesarean section is a major abdominal surgery, you should not exercise until you OB-GYN gives the green light. What you can do while you recover is walk. Walking even in the first days after your cesarean can help prevent pneumonia and blood clots in the legs which can travel to the lungs. Studies have shown that walking can actually help speed recovery.
When will my first checkup be?

You will likely see your OB-GYN or midwife for a checkup 2-3 weeks after surgery. They will check your incision to make sure that it’s healing properly. After this first check, you will likely have a second one at 6 weeks. If you ever have any questions or concerns before your checkups don’t hesitate to talk to your doctor or an OB-GYN on Maven.
When will I be fully recovered?

It will take approximately 6-8 weeks to recover from a cesarean. However, if you had any complications or other health issues it can take longer. Remember, you just had a major surgery (and grew and gave birth to a baby!). It will take time and care for your body to fully heal.
Sources
Mayo Clinic. Healthy Lifestyle. Labor and delivery, postpartum care. cesarean recovery: What to expect.
https://www.mayoclinic.org/healthy-lifestyle/labor-and-delivery/in-depth/c-section-recovery/art-20047310
. Accessed January 13, 2020.
Drugs and Lactation Database (LactMed). National Library of Medicine (US); 2006-.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK501922/.
. Accessed January 13, 2020.
Ituk, U. Enhanced recovery after cesarean delivery. Published online April 2018.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5931266/#!po=51.6667
. Accessed January 14, 2020.

title.en-US: Why the flu shot should top your to-do list

content.value: It cannot be stressed enough how important it is to get vaccinated against influenza (better known as “the flu”). And if you’re thinking of becoming pregnant, trying to conceive, currently pregnant or postpartum, or have recently had a miscarriage, the influenza vaccine should be #1 on your list of things to do.
Why should I get the flu shot?

Women who are pregnant have changes in their immune system, lungs, and heart that make them more susceptible to the flu. Not only are they more likely to get the flu, they are also more likely to have it progress to pneumonia, to be admitted to the Intensive Care Unit, and for the flu to negatively affect their health and the health of their baby. In some instances, it can even be fatal. Having a history of asthma, diabetes, heart, pulmonary or kidney disease significantly increases the risks for pregnant women with influenza.
How does the flu shot protect my baby?

Getting the flu shot while you are pregnant can help protect your infant after they are born. Because infants are not able to get the vaccine until they are 6 months old, your immunity will transfer to your baby while they are in utero. Getting the influenza vaccine also decreases your risk of stillbirth.
Should anyone else in my family get the flu shot?
Any individuals who live with a pregnant woman or care for newborns 6 months of age or younger should be vaccinated as well.
When should I get the flu shot?
It is best to get your yearly influenza vaccine before the end of October, as the flu season can last from October through May.
Do I have to receive a special flu shot if I’m pregnant?

Nope! It is safe for pregnant women to receive the same flu shot as everybody else. However, if you are allergic to eggs, there are influenza vaccines which do not contain any egg product, talk to your doctor to obtain this shot.
What are flu symptoms?
Flu symptoms include:
Fever (100-104 degrees F)
Headache
Body aches
Shortness of breath
Non-productive cough
Runny nose
Sore throat
Generally feeling weak
What should I do if I have symptoms of the flu?

If you are at all worried you might have signs of the flu, you should seek treatment early – ideally within 48 hours of symptoms. Contact your doctor, a Maven provider, or visit the ER right away. If you are unable to retain fluids, have difficulty breathing, chest pain or pressure, call 911.
What should I do if I’ve been exposed to the flu (but no symptoms yet)?

If you are pregnant and have come into contact with someone who has influenza in the last 48 hours, see your doctor (or visit the emergency room) to receive treatment. You will likely receive an antiviral medication which is safe in pregnancy.
Is it safe to breastfeed my baby if I have the flu?
Yes. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, women who are breastfeeding and have the flu can continue to breastfeed or, if feeling too sick to breastfeed, express into a bottle.
How do I avoid catching the flu?
In addition to getting a flu shot, use these tips:
Wash your hands frequently with soap and water for at least 30 seconds
Cover your nose and mouth when coughing and dispose of tissues in waste
Sources:
The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. Influenza Season Assessment and Treatment for Pregnant Women With Influenza-Like Illness.
https://immunizationforwomen.org/downloads/Influenza-Season-Assessment-Algorithm-FINAL-1.pdf
. Accessed November 27, 2019.
The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. Influenza Vaccination During Pregnancy.
https://www.acog.org/Clinical-Guidance-and-Publications/Committee-Opinions/Committee-on-Obstetric-Practice/Influenza-Vaccination-During-Pregnancy?IsMobileSet=false
. Accessed November 27, 2019.
Immunization for Women. Influenza (Flu).
https://immunizationforwomen.org/
. Accessed November 27, 2019.

title.en-US: What is the GBS test?

content.value: At approximately 36 weeks, your doctor or midwife will talk to you about taking the GBS test. Wondering what it is and how it works? Read on to learn everything you need to know about this very important test and how it can help protect your baby.
What is GBS?

GBS stands for Group Beta Streptococcus. It’s a completely normal vaginal bacteria that some women naturally have and some don’t. It is not an STD or a harmful infection for mom but it can cause complications for your baby. If a baby comes into contact with GBS during vaginal delivery, there is a 1 in 50-100 chance that they could develop a serious infection. For this reason, every pregnant woman is tested for GBS and, if they test positive, they are given antibiotics during labor to prevent infection.
What is the GBS test?

The GBS test is a swab test. Your doctor or midwife will use a Q-tip and swipe your vagina and your anus. It is not painful and simply collects a sample of the bacteria present there so it can be tested for the presence of GBS. The test takes just a minute and you will usually receive results within one week.
How does GBS affect babies?
If a baby comes into contact with the GBS bacteria during vaginal delivery it can affect their brain, lungs, and or blood (also known as sepsis). If infected, it can be fatal.
What happens if I test positive for GBS?

If you are positive that means that the GBS bacteria is present and you will receive antibiotics through an IV while you’re in labor to protect your baby. If you are GBS positive and your water breaks, it is best to go to the hospital right away so you can begin antibiotics. The most common medication for GBS is penicillin. If you’re allergic to penicillin, be sure to tell your doctor or midwife so they can suggest an alternative antibiotic.
Some women will automatically be treated for GBS when they go into labor, if any of the following are true:
Previous child who had GBS disease
GBS in urine at any time in the pregnancy
GBS status is unknown and a fever develops during labor
GBS status is unknown and you go into labor prior to 37 weeks
Do I have to take the GBS test?
GBS testing is a very important and painless test all pregnant women should take. Knowing your GBS status before you go into labor can help protect your baby and possibly even save their life.

title.en-US: Preterm birth: Why it happens & what to watch for

content.value: Today, 1 out of 10 babies are born prematurely in the United States. Here’s everything you need to know to help reduce your risk and keep a lookout for possible warning signs.
What is preterm birth?
A preterm (or premature) birth means that the baby is born before 37 weeks of gestation.
What causes preterm birth?

Nearly 70-80% of all preterm births happen spontaneously; sometimes the mother goes into labor, sometimes her water breaks. A preterm delivery cannot always be avoided, but there are certain factors that can make it more likely, including:
Being pregnant with twins
IVF pregnancy
History of preterm birth
Surgery on the cervix or uterus
Acquiring an infection
Chronic health conditions like diabetes and high blood pressure
Are there health risks for babies born preterm?

When babies are born preterm, they're at an increased risk for health issues including short term problems like breathing difficulties, feeding difficulties, risk of infection, inability to regulate temperature, and more long-term health problems such as cerebral palsy, learning disabilities, vision and hearing difficulties.
How can I prevent preterm birth?

Preterm birth isn't always preventable, but certain steps can help. Starting early prenatal care is key. By receiving care at the start of your pregnancy, your doctor has a chance to identify any risk factors you may have for preterm birth and take appropriate steps to help prevent it.

For example, one condition, where the cervix opens up without labor can result in preterm birth. This condition, known as “incompetent cervix” or “weakened cervix,” can be prevented if you have care early in pregnancy. Your doctor can stitch the cervix around weeks 12-14 to prevent it from opening up. Other methods for preventing preterm birth may involve more frequent monitoring with ultrasounds to measure the cervix and provide progesterone shots.
Here are some steps moms can take to help lower the risk of preterm birth:
Quitting smoking
Stopping all recreational drug use
Maintaining a healthy body weight
Avoiding short spans between pregnancies
Going to all your prenatal appointments
What are signs of preterm contractions or preterm labor?
If you have any of these symptoms, don't hesitate to go to your hospital’s Labor & Delivery ward to be checked immediately:
Severe back pain
Cramping pain or contraction pain that does not go away
Feeling as if your water broke or increased vaginal discharge
Pelvic pressure or pelvic achiness
How does a doctor check for preterm labor?

In your hospital’s Labor & Delivery ward, the doctor may perform an exam with their fingers or they may use an ultrasound probe to measure the length of the cervix. If you have a condition like placenta previa, they may measure your cervix using an abdominal ultrasound.

If the doctors think you're at risk for preterm delivery they'll likely administer a shot of corticosteroids that'll help accelerate your baby’s lung maturity and help with brain and digestive maturity, too. You may also be given medication to help stop the contractions, as well as some IV medication to protect your baby’s brain.
What doesn’t cause preterm birth?

Many women believe that exercise or going to work can increase their risk of preterm birth, but they don't. Having intercourse (so long as you don’t have placenta previa) doesn’t increase your risk either.

title.en-US: Listeria: Protect yourself & baby from food-borne illness

content.value: Eating for two can turn not-so-fun when the bacteria listeria is involved. Here’s what you need to know to keep yourself and your baby safe from food-borne illness.
What is listeria?
Listeria is a bacteria that can cause gastroenteritis or “upset stomach”. The infection caused by listeria is called listeriosis.
Is listeria harmful for pregnant women?

Listeria is harmful for any woman, but pregnant women are 13 times more likely to contract listeria, due to their suppressed immune system. And when you’re pregnant it can potentially harm your developing baby.
Listeriosis is most dangerous to your growing baby in the first and second trimester and can cause fetal death, premature birth, or infected newborns
What are the symptoms of listeriosis?

Listeriosis be asymptomatic (meaning there are no symptoms). However, when it is symptomatic, common symptoms include: fever, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, headache, and back pain. Listeriosis usually causes a fever and an infection that lasts for about 2 days.
When do symptoms appear?
Symptoms can appear a few days or as late as 2 months after ingesting contaminated food.
How is listeriosis diagnosed and treated?
Listeriosis can be diagnosed through a blood test. If an infection is detected, pregnant mothers will get IV antibiotics.
How can I prevent contact with listeria?

Prevention is key to avoiding any contact with listeria. You may have heard about avoiding unpasteurized cheese and deli meat, but the number of foods that have carried listeria outbreaks has recently grown to include fruits and vegetables including celery, sprouts, and cantaloupe.
Some quick tips to keep you safe:
Avoid unpasteurized milk and cheese or foods made with them, including raw milk
Soft unpasteurized cheeses are 50 to 160 times more likely to cause listeria infection than when they are made with pasteurized milk
Avoid eating soft cheeses, such as queso fresco, queso blanco, panela (queso panela), brie, Camembert, blue-veined, or feta, unless it is labeled as made with pasteurized milk
Wash fruits and vegetables well before eating them
Eat cut melon right away or refrigerate it
Throw away cut melons left at room temperature for more than 4 hours
Do not eat raw or lightly cooked sprouts of any kind
Rinsing sprouts will not remove bacteria
Cook meat and seafood until they are well done
Cook hot dogs and deli meat to over 165oF
Wash hands after handling hot dogs, lunch meats, and deli meats
Store opened packages and meat sliced at a local deli no longer than 3 to 5 days in the refrigerator
Do not eat refrigerated pâté or meat spreads from a deli or meat counter or from the refrigerated section of a store
Avoid raw eggs and cook until yolk is firm, not runny
Do not eat cold smoked fish unless it is canned or shelf-stable or it is in a cooked dish, such as a casserole
Wash hands, knives, and cutting boards after they touch raw food
What do I do if I think I’ve been exposed to listeria?

If you have an upset stomach and diarrhea (with or without a fever) see your doctor immediately or go to the ER. You will likely receive a blood test and, if positive for listeria, will receive antibiotics. Additional monitoring of your baby may be required, talk to your OB-GYN for more information. Even if you don’t have any symptoms but believe you have been exposed, it is best to tell your doctor right away.
Sources:
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Listeria (Listeriosis).
https://www.cdc.gov/listeria/prevention.html
. Accessed November 27, 2019.
U.S. Food & Drug Administration. Recalls, Outbreaks & Emergencies: Outbreaks of Foodborne Illness.
https://www.fda.gov/food/recalls-outbreaks-emergencies/outbreaks-foodborne-illness
. Accessed November 27, 2019.
FoodSafety.gov. Recalls and Outbreaks.
https://www.foodsafety.gov/recalls-and-outbreaks
. Accessed November 27, 2019.
The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. Management of Pregnant Women With Presumptive Exposure to Listeria monocytogenes.
https://www.acog.org/-/media/Committee-Opinions/Committee-on-Obstetric-Practice/co614.pdf?dmc=1&ts=20151017T1247020511
. Accessed November 27, 2019.

title.en-US: High blood pressure problems in pregnancy

content.value: High blood pressure and pregnancy can be a dangerous combination. Women without any history of high blood pressure or risk factors can develop gestational hypertension (high blood pressure in pregnancy) or preeclampsia (a pregnancy complication of high blood pressure that includes damage to the liver or kidney). And women with a history of chronic hypertension before pregnancy are at an increased risk of complications. Read on to learn how to protect yourself and your baby and have the healthiest pregnancy possible.
I have a history of high blood pressure. How will this affect my pregnancy?

If you took blood pressure medication before becoming pregnant, be sure to see your OB-GYN as soon as you find out that you’re pregnant. They can make sure that you’re on the right medication (that's safe for pregnancy) and taking the correct dosage. It’s important to also regularly attend your prenatal appointments so your doctor can closely monitor your blood pressure throughout your pregnancy.
What happens if I develop high blood pressure during pregnancy?

At each prenatal appointment throughout your pregnancy, your doctor will check your blood pressure. It’s important to regularly attend your appointments so that if your blood pressure begins to rise, your doctor can catch it as early as possible and take action to help prevent complications. If you do develop high blood pressure during pregnancy, your OB-GYN or high-risk pregnancy doctor (MFM) will recommend more frequent ultrasounds and lab work in order to closely monitor your condition, check for worsening disease, and any effects the hypertension might have on your baby.
What is preeclampsia?

Sometimes chronic hypertension and/or gestational hypertension progresses to preeclampsia—a serious condition that can lead to complications. Preeclampsia is a disease that starts in the placenta and travels throughout a pregnant woman’s body to her blood vessels. It can affect her heart, lungs, kidney, brain, bone marrow and liver.

According to the American Pregnancy Association, preeclampsia affects approximately 5-8% of pregnancies and can be fatal for both mother and child. This condition can develop quickly so it is critical that every mother-to-be knows the signs and symptoms and gets help immediately—this can be life-saving for you and your baby.
What are some risk factors for preeclampsia?
First-time mothers
Younger mothers (below 20 years old)
Older mothers (above 40 years old)
Carrying multiples (twins, triplets, or higher)
Previous experience with high blood pressure in pregnancy or preeclampsia
History of high blood pressure, kidney disease, IVF, obesity, and/or diabetes
History of preeclampsia in the family (specifically sisters or mothers who have had it)
What are some symptoms of preeclampsia?
If you experience any of the following symptoms, don't hesitate--call your doctor or visit the emergency room immediately:
Headaches
Abdominal pain
Shortness of breath
Nausea and vomiting
Blurry vision or seeing spots
Decreased urine
Seizure*

*Note: If you experience a seizure in pregnancy that isn’t caused by another known disease, you may be experiencing eclampsia. Eclampsia is a severe complication of preeclampsia. If you have high blood pressure in pregnancy, inform your family to call 911 if you have a seizure.
How is preeclampsia diagnosed?
Typically your OB-GYN, midwife, or family doctor will check your blood pressure at every prenatal visit to check for early signs of preeclampsia. Preeclampsia is diagnosed one of two ways:
When a pregnant woman has high blood pressure (greater than 160 systolic
or greater than 110 diastolic

When a pregnant woman has blood pressure higher than 140/90 and other conditions such as protein in her urine, low platelets, rising liver enzymes, rising creatinine in the kidney, fluid filling the lungs, or brain seizures.
The earlier in your pregnancy preeclampsia is diagnosed, typically the more severe it is.
What happens if I’ve been diagnosed with preeclampsia?

If you have preeclampsia and you're seeing a midwife, you'll likely be advised to transfer your care to an OB-GYN. Sometimes it’s recommended that you go to the hospital for evaluation, and sometimes preeclampsia can lead to preterm delivery. If the disease isn’t severe, your OB-GYN may chose to wait so that the baby can continue maturing.
What should I do if I have a history of preeclampsia?

If you have a history of preeclampsia in a previous pregnancy or high blood pressure, be sure to share that with your current provider so that they can be extra vigilant in checking your blood pressure and providing extra testing and ultrasounds throughout your pregnancy. For women with risk factors or a history of high blood pressure or preeclampsia, your doctor may suggest aspirin starting at 12 weeks of pregnancy.
What are some possible complications of preeclampsia?
Possible complications of preeclampsia include:
Restricted baby growth
Preterm delivery
Placental abruption (where the placenta pulls away from the uterus)
HELLP syndrome (organ failure) (an indication for immediate delivery)
Damage to the brain, kidneys, lungs, heart, and eyes
Increased lifetime risk of cardiovascular disease (heart attack and stroke) due to the damage that preeclampsia causes to blood vessels
How can I lower my risk of preeclampsia?

The best thing any pregnant woman can do to lower their risk of preeclampsia is to attend all of their prenatal appointments, from as soon as they find out that they're pregnant, so their blood pressure can be continuously monitored. If you have a history of high blood pressure or preeclampsia, tell your doctor. Make sure that you know the symptoms of preeclampsia and tell your doctor or visit the ER immediately if you are experiencing them.
Sources
Mayo Clinic. Healthy Lifestyle: Pregnancy week by week. High blood pressure and pregnancy: Know the facts. Last updated February 2018.
https://www.mayoclinic.org/healthy-lifestyle/pregnancy-week-by-week/in-depth/pregnancy/art-20046098
. Accessed January 30, 2020.
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. High Blood Pressure During Pregnancy.
https://www.cdc.gov/bloodpressure/pregnancy.htm
. Accessed January 30, 2020.
The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. FAQ: Frequently asked questions - pregnancy. Preeclampsia and High Blood Pressure During Pregnancy.
https://www.acog.org/Patients/FAQs/Preeclampsia-and-High-Blood-Pressure-During-Pregnancy
. Accessed January 30, 2020.

title.en-US: Best ways to deal with back pain during pregnancy

content.value: We don’t have to tell you that growing another human means a lot of changes for your body, too—especially in your muscles and bones. In placenta and fluid alone, your growing baby can weigh up to 16 pounds. This new weight shift, combined with loosening joints, often leads to one of the most common pregnancy ailments: back pain. The good news is that 80-95% of back pain resolves after pregnancy. Until then, here’s what you can do to find some relief.
What can I do to reduce back pain?
Choose shoes wisely
Wear low-heeled (but not flat) shoes with good arch support.
Lift less
Get help when lifting heavy objects and use good lifting techniques: squat down, bend your knees and keep your back straight when lifting.
Get support

When standing, try using a maternity belt to help hold the weight closer to your center of gravity. When sitting, sit in chairs with good back support or use a small pillow to provide support. When sleeping, sleep on your side with pillows between the knees or a body pillow for support.
Take care
Apply heat and cold to the painful area. Electric heat pads and baths may help to relax the muscles along the spine. Acupuncture, yoga, chiropractic care and massage can also be helpful.
Take breaks
Rest can help alleviate back pain, giving the muscles time to recover.
Exercise regularly

The weightlessness of swimming can feel amazing when you’re pregnant and is a healthy exercise. If you don’t have access to a pool, walks are another great option. Consider talking to a Maven Physical Therapist for additional tips— they specialize in safe and effective pregnancy exercises that can help with back pain.
Healthy weight gain
Talk to your doctor about healthy, gradual weight gain. Overweight and obese women have a 30% increased risk of back pain 12 months after pregnancy.
Medication is not recommended
Medication is rarely recommended for pregnant women with back pain. NSAIDs are not recommended in pregnancy, nor are opioids.

title.en-US: How to cut baby’s nails without fear

content.value: Didn't realize your little one would need manicures so early on? Baby's nails grow quickly and can lead to scratches, so it's good practice to trim them often. A couple ways to keep nails short include filing them, trimming with nail clippers, or using manicure scissors. There are specific baby nail care kits that contain small clippers and soft emery boards designed specifically for their soft little nails.

Keep in mind, that babies don’t quite have an appreciation for spa day just yet—and it can be hard to hold them still for safe trimmings. Try to trim their nails while they’re asleep or distracted during feeding (it can help to ask your partner to do the trimming while you do the feeding or vice versa).
If this task is hard to keep up with or your baby just won’t hold still, you can use baby mittens over their hands to protect them from immediate scratching until you can try again.

While some parents swear by biting baby’s nails, this is not recommended because it can introduce bacteria from your mouth into a cut and cause infection. If you do happen to nick baby’s finger during a nail clipping, it’s okay (and it happens). Hold pressure on the area until the bleeding stops and clean with soap and water to prevent infection.

title.en-US: 10 ways to reduce the risk of SIDS

content.value: Now that you and baby are finally home, it’s time that you both get some much-needed sleep! Follow these specific recommendations from the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) to create a safe sleeping environment for your baby and help protect them against Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS), suffocation, entrapment, asphyxia and other potentially fatal sleep-related dangers.
Back is best
Always put your baby to sleep on their back on a firm surface, such as a crib or bassinet with a tight fitted sheet.
Bare is best
Do not put pillows, blankets, bumper pads, any loose bedding, or toys in baby’s sleep area.
Share a room, not a bed

Baby should sleep in the same room as parents preferably until they are 1, but at least for the first 6 months of life. According to the AAP, room-sharing decreases the risk of SIDS by as much as 50%. However, sleeping in the same bed as parents is not recommended as it increases the risk.
Curb unhealthy habits
Avoid exposing baby to smoke, alcohol or illicit drugs. They can increase the risk of SIDS.
Breastfeed if you can

Breastfeeding is recommended as an added protection against SIDS. After feeding, return your baby to their sleeping space. If you are feeling drowsy, feed your baby in your bed without pillows, sheets, blankets or other items and then return them to their separate sleeping space.
Use a pacifier
Offering a pacifier when putting baby to sleep can reduce the risk of SIDS.
Keep it cool
Do not let baby get too hot, this can increase their risk. The ideal temperature for baby sleep is 65-75° F.
Vaccinate
Make sure that your baby receives all recommended vaccines. Studies show that vaccinated children have a significantly lower risk of SIDS. Likely related to having less infections and fevers.
Have tummy time
Encourage your baby to practice supervised tummy time when they are awake. This helps them strengthen their neck muscles so they can turn their heads while sleeping.
Avoid sleep while seated
Avoid putting baby to sleep in a car seat or any type of seat for routine sleeping as this can restrict their breathing.
Sources
American Academy of Pediatrics. American Academy of Pediatrics Announces New Safe Sleep Recommendations to Protect Against SIDS, Sleep-Related Infant Deaths. October 24, 2016.
https://www.aap.org/en-us/about-the-aap/aap-press-room/Pages/American-Academy-of-Pediatrics-Announces-New-Safe-Sleep-Recommendations-to-Protect-Against-SIDS.aspx
. Accessed February 11, 2020.

title.en-US: When to seek medical attention in baby’s first 1-2 months

content.value: Now that you’re a parent, you will worry about everything. It can help to know when a worry is just part of being a parent and when it’s a real cause for concern. Here are the top things that are worth seeking medical attention for in baby’s first 1-2 months of life.
When to seek immediate medical attention:
If baby is spitting up after every feed or if the spit up is large - in volume or projectile spit up each time
If baby has blood in their stool
If baby is looking more yellowish
If baby has a severe skin rash
If baby has a rectal temperature over 100.4° F
When to call your doctor:
If baby is not having at least 4 wet diapers in 24 hours
If baby sucks poorly or slowly
If baby seems too stiff or too floppy
If baby does not blink in bright light
If baby does not respond to loud sounds

title.en-US: Safety tips for a mobile baby (6-12 months)

content.value: Your adorable little lump on a log is suddenly on the move! As your baby becomes more mobile every day, you may start to look at things that were seemingly harmless in a whole new light. Suddenly light sockets, coffee table corners, and your beloved cactus collection are potential hazards for your little motor boat babe making safety more important than ever.
Accidents are serious, and can cause serious harm to your child, so be sure to use these safety tips to keep your baby safe as they begin to really explore their world.
How to prevent falls

As baby start to roll well, crawl, sit up and pull to stand, falls are incredibly common. Whether it’s falling from a surface baby is sitting on, falling down the steps, or falling from play equipment, it will happen faster than you will ever realize. Take these precautions to help prevent falls.
Install baby gates at all openings and stairs
Don’t use a baby walker (they easily tip)
Install window guards on all windows
Lower baby’s crib as soon as they start to sit up
How to prevent burns

Burns are also very common because babies want everything you have! They will start to grab at things in your hands, off the table, and pull up on things (including the oven door!). Follow these steps to keep baby safe from burns.
Never carry hot food or liquids around your baby
Never hold your baby while cooking
Never have baby near hot cups or plates on the table
When you do need to cook or be around hot things, put baby in their playpen, a stationary play gym or buckled into a high chair
Make sure the hot water heater is set to no higher than 102° F so they will not get burned by water from the faucet
Check that you have working fire detectors on every level of the home and make sure to test them on a regular basis
How to prevent drowning
A baby can drown in less than 2 minutes in less than 2 inches of water. Prevent drowning by taking the following precautions.
Never leave your baby in or near the tub unsupervised (not for a second)
Always drain anything containing water when you are finished including: baby pools, bath tubs, even buckets
Keep the door to the bathroom closed at all times
Put toilet seat locks on toilets if the baby can easily access them
Be sure to have a fence around all four sides of the pool if you have one
How to prevent choking

Your baby will explore by putting everything in their mouth. Know that choking can occur from small toys, foods, balloons, money, batteries, jewelry—honestly anything that is small enough to become lodged in their throat. To avoid choking hazards, use these tips.
Know infant CPR, it can save your child’s life. Ask your child’s pediatrician about a local CPR class or check out
www.redcross.org/
Always monitor your child while they are eating
Keep small objects away from your child at all times
Never feed your baby peanuts, raisins, grapes, or other small food items that could become lodged in their throat
How to prevent poisoning

A mobile baby who loves to put anything and everything in their mouths can be a dangerous combination. Poisoning can occur from common household plants, cleaners, or medicines. Take these steps to keep baby safe.

If your baby ingests something that you are concerned could harm them, call the poison helpline from any phone at 1-800-222-1222 immediately and learn the correct course of action. - Keep this number on your phone and on your fridge.
Keep all cleaning cabinets locked with child-safety locks
Keep medicines in a high, secure cabinet
Keep all plants out of reach (even common household plants can be poisonous if ingested)
How to prevent suffocation and strangulation
Your baby will spend a majority of their day sleeping and suffocation and strangulation can often occur in their sleeping area. Follow these steps to create a safe sleeping environment:
Make sure that your baby’s sleep area contains nothing but a tightly-fitted sheet (do no use bumpers, blankets, pillows, or toys)
Keep your baby’s crib away from windows
Make sure window coverings do not have cords
Keep all cords out of babies reach
Do not put any bags or plastics where baby can reach them
Care safety
The car is another area where safety is of utmost importance. Take the following precautions to keep your baby safe on the go:
The safest place for baby is in the back seat
Your baby’s car seat should also remain rear facing until at least the age of 2
Be sure your car seat is installed correctly and being used properly
Baby should never be left alone in the car, not even for a second to run into the gas station or store
Most fire stations have car seat experts available. Make an appointment to have them check your car and car seat for safety. They can ensure that your car seat is ensured properly.
Never put baby in the car without being correctly secured in a car seat. Most car accidents happen within a mile or two from home.You do not have to go far to get into a serious accident.

title.en-US: Fertility 101

content.value: If you’ve been wading through a sea of fertility advice that leaves you feeling more confused than confident, welcome. Our quick fertility primer will explain all the basics in one place, including the most common fertility treatments, average costs, and what to expect while going through treatment. Read on for clarity and the start of a better fertility journey!
Fast infertility facts
1 in 8
Couples struggle with infertility in the U.S.
1 in 4
Couples struggle with infertility in the developed world
Infertility is 30% male factor, 30% female factor, 30% unexplained, 10% a combination of factors
Average cost for IVF treatment (per cycle)
Average fertility costs covered by employer benefits
Causes of infertility
Male factor (such as structural abnormalities or sperm production problems)
Diminished ovarian reserve (low egg count)
Blocked fallopian tubes (this may be genetic, or caused by pelvic inflammatory disease or other infections)
Ovulation issues (irregular or no ovulation)
Hormonal imbalances (such as thyroid disorders)
Abnormalities of the uterus (uterine anomalies from birth or due to fibroids ,polyps, etc)
Endometriosis
Combination of male and female factors
Unexplained infertility
Common treatment options
Timed intercouse
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
METHOD:
Track your natural ovulation cycle (or ovulation stimulated by medication) to ensure you have intercourse at the ideal time to conceive.
GOOD FOR:
This method can be good for couples with ovulation issues (irregular or no ovulation), no evidence of male factor infertility, and normal anatomy.
PROCESS:
Usually involves coming in for an ultrasound and/or bloodwork around the time you expect to ovulate.
Intrauterine insemination (IUI)
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
METHOD:
A higher concentration of mobile sperm (aka “good swimmers”) are placed into the uterus around the time of ovulation to encourage fertilization.
GOOD FOR:
This method can be good for couples with mild male factor infertility or who have no known infertility issues but haven’t been able to conceive naturally.
PROCESS:

Sperm is washed, concentrated, and placed into the uterus. You may take oral or injectable medications to stimulate ovulation or to increase the number of eggs ovulated. You may also have an ultrasound.
In-vitro fertilization (IVF)
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
METHOD:
When one (or more) embryo(s) are transferred into the uterus.
GOOD FOR:
This method can be good for patients with blocked fallopian tubes, diminished ovarian reserve (low egg count), or more severe male factor infertility.
PROCESS:

You’ll receive medications through injections that will encourage multiple eggs to develop and prevent them from being released, so as many as possible can reach maturity. These eggs will then be retrieved and either placed in a dish with a high concentration of sperm or injected with sperm to try to create embryos. Usually, one embryo is then transferred back to the uterus (aka “single embryo transfer”), although in some cases more than one embryo is transferred. (Learn about
MavenRx
, Maven's partnership with leading fertility pharmacies to offer you discounts on your medications and more.)
Read more about treatments
Success rates

Many couples successfully become pregnant through fertility treatment. However, the success rates are approximate and can vary widely based on the reason for infertility, maternal age, if medication is used, and many other factors.
Timed intercourse success rates
The odds of becoming pregnant using timed intercourse is approximately 14-23% according to one study published in the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews.
IUI success rates
If a couple has an IUI procedure performed each month, success rates may be as high as 20% per cycle according to the American Pregnancy Association.
IVF success rates
According to the American Pregnancy Association, the live birth rate for each IVF cycle started is approximately:
43% for women under age 35
33-36% for women ages 35 to 37
23-27% for women ages 38 to 40
13-18% for women ages over 40
Cost estimates
Estimated pricing
Please keep in mind that these are estimates and that it can take multiple cycles to have a successful pregnancy.
Timed intercourse:
IUI:
IVF:
Factor in medication:
Be sure to ask your doctor about medication costs when calculating total costs of treatment.
Shop around:
If you’re paying out-of-pocket for fertility medication, consider calling a few pharmacies to see if there is a better price.
Read more cost tips
What to expect when going through treatment
Side effects of medication
Generally, patients report being able to continue daily activities without much change. However, for IVF treatment exercise is not recommended.
You may experience bloating and lower abdominal fullness.
You may experience potential changes in mood, fatigue or increased irritability, or improvement in mood as estrogen levels rise.
Time commitment
You may be coming in for ultrasounds every 2 to 3 days (for IVF, not generally used for IUI).
Most clinics do ultrasound visits in the morning (before work).
Find a consistent window each evening that you’ll be available to administer medication.
Emotional support
Going through fertility treatment can take an emotional toll on you and your relationship.
Consider joining an in-person fertility support group to talk to other people going through treatment, or participate in Maven’s community forums.
Talk to a Maven Mental Health Provider for help handling the stress of fertility treatment or support navigating the changes in your relationship.
Find a Mental Health Provider
Managing work
Ask your clinic when monitoring should end so you can set expectations at work.
If it’s helpful, ask the clinic for a note that states that you are undergoing medical treatment that may require multiple visits and share with your employer.
Speak to a Maven Career Coach about how to talk to your manager about the need for flexibility.
Find a Career Coach
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Get support for your fertility journey
Ask a question
Talk to our Reproductive Endocrinologists anytime via video chat or message.
Stay informed
Read hundreds of MD-approved articles on every fertility topic.
Make connections
Share your story and show your support in our community forums.

title.en-US: Fertility stories from our community

content.value: You’re not alone. Maven’s community forums are a safe space to share your fertility story, support other members, and always receive trusted medical advice from our Maven providers.
Find your community
Whatever you’re going through, there’s a community for you. Browse through all of our fertility topics, search for something specific, or start a new thread:
IVF
IUI
Egg freezing
Surrogacy
Adoption
Trying to conceive
Ovulation tracking
Two week wait
Join the conversation
Read and reply to posts, ask a question, or share your personal experience. You can choose to use your name or post anonymously.
Get answers you can trust
Have a medical question? Maven providers answer questions in the community along with other Maven members. Want more 1:1 support? Book a video chat or message them privately at no cost.
Explore our community
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Find a community for you
Ask a question
Something on your mind? Ask away and get advice from other members who’ve been there as well as Maven providers.
Help others
Everyone has a fertility story. Read from others and share your own so members know they’re not alone.
Talk to a doctor (for free!)
